webTitle: Railtrack boss faces the sack as chaos grows for travellers

fields.headline: Railtrack boss faces the sack as chaos grows for travellers
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Gerald Corbett, the rail boss blamed for the chaos engulfing the network, is set to be axed, The  Observer can reveal. As massive disruption spread across the country yesterday, sources revealed that Corbett, head of Railtrack, is to be ousted within weeks.
fields.body:
Gerald Corbett, the rail boss blamed for the chaos engulfing the network, is set to be axed, The Observer can reveal. As massive disruption spread across the country yesterday, sources revealed that Corbett, head of Railtrack, is to be ousted within weeks.

He is being blamed for what has been described as the appalling state of Britain's railways, which emerged following the Hatfield crash 12 days ago.

Westminster sources last night revealed that John Prescott, the Deputy Prime Minister, and Lord Macdonald, the Transport Minister, have 'no confidence' in the Railtrack chief executive.

However, he will not be forced out of his job until he has 'cleared up the mess' which has led to a nationwide slowdown while emergency repairs are carried out, following revelations that thousands of track faults had been ignored.

The widespread disruption and road congestion caused by train delays and cancellations in the wake of the crash are believed by transport experts to have already cost the economy up to half a billion pounds. Romanian engineers are being flown in to try to speed up the repairs.

The rail industry is set to lose a similar amount in fines, compensation to passengers and lost ticket revenue as people switch to other forms of transport. It will be months before the system is back to normal, and the urgent track repairs are being hampered by a shortage of staff. According to the rail union RMT, the number of trained maintenance workers has halved to 15,000 since privatisation.

Corbett's fate will probably not be sealed until the Government has seen the safety report, expected 'around the turn of the year', into the Hatfield derailment.

Sources close to the investigation now say it looks likely that, although maintenance contractor Balfour Beatty had not carried out its work well and is not clear of blame, Railtrack had been told that the track was in dangerously poor condition but failed to close the line, replace the track or impose speed restrictions.

'Gerald Corbett is damaged goods,' said the senior industry source. 'He does not have the confidence of Prescott or Macdonald and he is basically a caretaker. When the facts of Hatfield and broken rails come out his position will be completely untenable.'

The Railtrack chief offered to resign the day after the Hatfield crash when it emerged that a broken rail was probably responsible.

Prescott has been notably mute on the subject of Corbett and it is no secret that he is 'not a fan' of the jovial but pugnacious chief executive. It is understood in Whitehall circles that while the Government is putting on a show of support for unity and stability in the industry while it deals with the crisis, Corbett is seen as a lame duck.

As the head of a private company, he cannot directly be forced out by Ministers, by rail regulator Tom Winsor, or by Sir Alastair Morton, head of the Government's Shadow Strategic Rail Authority.

But as a privatised, regulated monopoly which was handed all British Rail track, signalling, station and land assets in 1994 and subsidised by taxpayers to the tune of £1.3 billion a year, the authorities have some legal and political clout over Railtrack.

The Government has the option of removing Railtrack's operating licence, which would probably result in it being taken over by another company. Even the threat of this would probably result in Railtrack directors deciding to sacrifice Corbett - and possibly themselves in a boardroom clear-out - in order to secure the company's survival. Industry sources regard this drastic option as Prescott's 'nuclear button'.

Meanwhile, it emerged last week that Railtrack had probably been told the track outside Hatfield station was in a dangerous state, but a 'catastrophic failure in the chain of command' and 'management incompetence' within the company and in its links with Balfour Beatty meant repairs were fatally delayed.

The senior industry source said: 'You did not need a magnifying glass to see this rail was in poor condition. It was not a hairline crack, you could see it from 10 metres away and Railtrack had plenty of time to fix it.'

Prescott has already asked Morton to investigate whether there is a conflict between safety and commercial interests. The Transport Bill, which includes stronger powers over the rail industry, is still wading through Parliament and is in danger of falling before it becomes law because of the row over the sell-off of air traffic control.

It has also been revealed by the Health & Safety Executive that Railtrack has sometimes failed to act over warnings of danger points on its network.

Two months before the Hatfield crash it took seven weeks and threats of legal action for Railtrack to obey a demand for 20mph speed limits outside Manchester's Piccadilly station. Signals had become partially obscured by weeds and drivers were passing them on red.

An HSE source said: 'This gives you an impression of the way they work. They are not on top of doing what they say they are doing.'

webTitle: I want to ask killers 'why?' says Bulger mother

fields.headline: I want to ask killers 'why?' says Bulger mother
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: The mother of James Bulger wants to visit his murderers in prison to 'look them in the eye and ask why?' Denise Fergus, 33, is leading a campaign to prevent the young killers getting early release from custody.
fields.body:
The mother of James Bulger wants to visit his murderers in prison to 'look them in the eye and ask why?' Denise Fergus, 33, is leading a campaign to prevent the young killers getting early release from custody.

Jon Venables and Robert Thompson have not been punished for torturing and killing her two-year-old son, she tells the News of the World today. 'I know James is with me everywhere I go. I know he was with me in that courtroom and I know he's helping me through this,' she says.

'I keep saying it will be all right and I will do the best I can, but my best hasn't worked ... the one crumb of comfort I had was knowing these two would be behind bars. Now that has been taken from me and I have no idea why.'

Friends and supporters of James's family want celebrities and famous faces to back an event to raise money for an appeal against the release of the boys.

The gala event is being organised by the pressure group Mothers Against Murder and Aggression, which announced plans for the show after it emerged that the murdered toddler's father, Ralph Bulger, had been denied legal aid for an appeal. Cash raised would also help relatives of other murder victims, the group said.

James was beaten to death on a railway line in Liverpool in 1993 by Venables and Thompson, who were then aged 10. They had abducted him from the Strand shopping centre in Bootle while he was out with his mother.

A High Court ruling last week by the Lord Chief Justice, Lord Woolf, effectively ended the tariff setting the minimum sentence which the pair must serve. This means they could be eligible for parole within months, and that they are unlikely to be sent from the secure children's home where they are being held to a young offenders' institution or a prison.

Originally the trial judge at Preston Crown Court, Mr Justice Morland, recommended an eight-year minimum sentence for what he called 'an act of unparalleled barbarity'. The then Lord Chief Justice, Lord Taylor, increased the term to 10 years. But the European Court of Human Rights ruled that the former Home Secretary, Michael Howard, had acted illegally when he further increased the tariff to 15 years.

In his ruling Lord Woolf said the two boys had done everything to redeem themselves, although their crime was 'horrendous'. He set an eight-year tariff which means they could be eligible for release on 21 February, 2001.

Solicitor Robin Makin, who acts for James's father, was dismayed: 'They still haven't apologised to Mr Bulger or his family. It seems they are being reinvented rather than rehabilitated.'

The ruling took into consideration the extent to which the boys are believed to have been rehabilitated and the continuation of this process.

The Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, said: 'Children who commit offences, however terrible, should always have a chance of a new start once they are adults.'

The Parole Board will now have to decide whether the teenagers still present a risk and whether they are suitable for release.

The fundraising event is likely to take place at Liverpool Football Club or the city's Empire Theatre some time before Christmas. Leading bands, solo artists and comedians have been approached about taking part.

'We will be supporting Ralph and his family and giving them whatever support we can,' said Lyn Costello, of Mothers Against Murder and Aggression. 'There has been an enthusiastic response from people in Liverpool to what we're trying to do.'

If released, Thompson and Venables have been warned they they will face a constant threat from vigilante mobs. They will be given new identities, but will almost certainly have to move abroad to be safe. Both boys will have to cease all contact with their families or risk being traced.

webTitle: My journey to hell and back (aka 15.38 Glasgow-Euston)

fields.headline: My journey to hell and back (aka 15.38 Glasgow-Euston)
fields.standfirst:
You can fly from London to South Africa in nine hours - but as trains slowed to a near halt last week Stuart Millar found that you can also spend that time stuck in Coach C

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: You can fly from London to South Africa in nine hours - but as trains slowed to a near halt last week Stuart Millar found that you can also spend that time stuck in Coach C.
fields.body:
Glasgow, 3.30pm on Thursday. Preceded by a gentle, recorded harp strum, the cheerful conductor welcomed passengers aboard Virgin Train's 15.38 Glasgow Central to London Euston service with good news. Against all the odds, the train was prepared and would depart from Platform 1 on time.

We passengers, who had arrived braced for unhappy tidings, settled back in our seats, picked up our newspapers and smugly congratulated ourselves on our uncanny ability to sidestep the near-paralysis to which Britain's crumbling rail network had been reduced last week.

At 3.39pm, another tinny harp strum. This time, the conductor said, there had been a slight hiccough: there was no driver. Through every carriage swept the resigned groan of travellers. 'We'll be on our way as soon as we find him,' the Tannoy voice added half-heartedly.

It was 40 minutes before the driver appeared for duty. Before it had left the platform in Glasgow, the service was almost an hour behind the timetable. This was an inauspicious start. There was worse to come.

This weekend the rail network is undergoing its biggest repair programme for more than a century. More than 20,000 Railtrack staff are working to repair 41,000 metres of rail identified as unsafe in the wake of the Hatfield derailment 12 days ago. Across the country, engineers have identified 1,850 rails with hairline cracks similar to those responsible for the latest tragedy.

But with 20mph speed restrictions in operation on more than 160 stretches of line and little agreement on how quickly the operation can be completed, it is the hundreds of thousands of passengers, hit by widespread cancellations and severe delays, who are being forced to suffer.

Like us unfortunate souls on the 15.38 last Thursday. For a mid-afternoon service, the train was busy; all the seats filled with business people, Scots heading to London for a long weekend, English families returning south at the end of the half-term break and tourists whose quick jaunt north had turned into an ordeal by rail. In the spaces between carriages, those unlucky enough to have been too late to get a seat made themselves as comfortable as they could as we finally pulled out of Glasgow.

We at least had the small consolation that the train was moving at all. It was one of the first cross-border services to leave Glasgow after Railtrack's sudden decision to close the busy West Coast Main Line between the city and Gretna on Wednesday and equally sudden decision to reopen it on Thursday. Until the 15.38, passengers had been ferried on buses to Carlisle to pick up trains to take them further south.

The West Coast Line is among the worst hit by years of disrepair. It is barely 100 miles from Glasgow to Carlisle, but on that stretch of track last week Railtrack engineers identified 179 hairline cracks. At least 32 of those sites require immediate repair or remedial work. Even taking all this into account, however, we remained warily confident that we would get to our destinations in a reasonable time. I had been assured by the man at the ticket window that 40 minutes late would be about as bad as it got. On top of the 40 minutes we had already waited for the driver, that would mean getting into Euston by 10.30pm, as against the scheduled time of 9.09pm. A respectable result given the poor start, especially as it meant being in London in time for last orders.

For the first hour out of Glasgow, things seemed fine. Admittedly, the train may not have been going flat out, but it was still moving at a steady clip. Twice it had slowed right down, but both occasions had been mercifully brief. Then, at 5.34pm, we stopped. On the steep hillside to the right, a few sheep wandered down for a closer look before continuing their grazing. Through the trees down to the left, traffic flashed south on the M74.

After a few minutes, just as the motorway buses began to take on a Space Age air of sleek efficiency, the train lurched forward into motion. Just. We set off so slowly that the sheep were still able to overtake us in search of fresh grass. As the sky blackened, the passengers on Coach C looked at each other in the grim realisation that the real trouble was just about to start.

'I can't believe this is happening again,' said Lauren Nicholls, a 20-year-old student from Vancouver. 'I travelled up to Scotland from London on Tuesday and it took me 10 hours. I've been up here for two days and I've spent most of that on these trains. This whole trip has been a disaster.'

We trundled on. By 6pm, we should have been long past Carlisle. As the lights of a town finally started to appear, some passengers gathered their belongings and made their way towards the doors. The train rolled along a platform and seemed to be about to stop. Then a sign passed the window: Lockerbie. Nearly two and a half hours after our scheduled departure, we had yet to reach the border.

At 6.39pm, the train finally pulled into Carlisle. According to the conductor, we were now running 107 minutes late. On Coach C, the response was muted. A sort of Dunkirk spirit had kicked in as a group of passengers swapped stories of previous losing battles with the West Coast Line.

David Gordon, from Motherwell, recounted the time he, his wife and two children had been on a train north when it had broken down at Oxenholme station in the Lake District and they had had to wait for two hours on a bus.

Niall Thomas was not to be outdone. The IT consultant from Glasgow had been on his way to a stag night in Newcastle recently when, after many hours of delay and still far short of their destination, it was announced that the train was terminating where it stood. 'The guy came on and said that anybody travelling to Newcastle should try again the next day,' said Thomas. 'The worst thing was, the groom-to-be was with me, so he missed his own stag do.'

'It is a fantastic way to travel when everything goes well,' sympathised Gordon. 'But when it goes wrong, it seems to go horribly wrong.' Prophetic words indeed.

The train continued through the North-West at funeral pace. At times, the only way to be sure we were still moving was by watching the dark outlines of the trees that passed the windows in painful slow motion. By 7.35pm we reached Oxenholme, the third of 13 stops. Preston came into sight 40 minutes later, but with each mile that barely passed beneath our wheels London seemed further away. Gradually, the curiously British thrill at a shared ordeal was replaced by boredom, then frustration and finally anger.

In the buffet car, Paul Donald and Tony O'Keefe had had enough. Their journey had began at 6.15 that morning, 217 miles north of Aberdeen on an oil rig in the Norwegian sector of the North Sea. They should have been in the pub with their mates in Liverpool at the start of two weeks' leave. Instead they were still stuck on a train somewhere to the north. 'This is driving me fucking insane,' Donald growled. 'This lot are taking the piss. If they want to shut down the railway, they should do that, but if they are going to take £75 off me for a ticket they should at least try and get me there. They're too greedy to say no to the money. That's their problem.'

'It's those notice boards they put up in the stations with the efficiency figures,' said O'Keefe. 'It's always 98.8 something. Where the fuck do they get that garbage from?' The feeling of tempers rapidly fraying filled the air. Mine included. In the seat behind me, a small boy decided the best fun he could have was to lift up the tray table attached to the back of my seat and slam it down as hard as his little arms could. For a full half-hour he continued with his game, while his parents looked on, clearly relieved that it wasn't them he was bothering. I could take no more. 'Is there any chance you could get him to stop?' I asked his mother politely. 'He's only three, you know,' she snapped in reply and turned back to her magazine.

Perhaps wisely, the train staff, other than the buffet manager, had been conspicuous by their absence. Apart from one early foray to check tickets, the conductor limited his presence to doleful Tannoy announcements at each station of the number of minutes we were now behind schedule. He was replaced at Crewe by a new man who walked down the train with the latest estimated times of arrival.

At 9.09pm, the scheduled time for reaching Euston, we were still somewhere in the Midlands, north of Stafford. But the new conductor had some news: even at this pathetic rate, we would be in London between 11.25pm and 11.40pm. So when the buffet man announced at 10.30pm that he was closing for the night, we took that as a good sign. Wrong. At 11pm, the conductor came on the Tannoy to tell us that we would now reach Milton Keynes by 11.25pm, and London half an hour later. By a quarter to midnight, with Milton Keynes still to materialise, the conductor gave up making any predictions.

Most of us had given up hope of ever reaching anywhere. As we lumbered through the darkness, it felt as if we had been abandoned to our fate as the rest of Britain tucked up for the night. Occasionally, we would slow down even more. But finally we reached Milton Keynes, then Watford. London could not be far off. Once again we had underestimated the seriousness of our predicament and it was not until 12.59am - nearly three hours 50 minutes late - that we pulled into Euston. Passengers piled out to be greeted by loved ones with the enthusiasm of those who had started to lose all hope.

From Glasgow to London, a distance of 400 miles, had taken more than nine hours, almost the same amount of time as it takes to fly from London to South Africa, across some 53 countries and the length of the African continent. After all this, we deserved some good news and it finally came at Euston. There was another train at least an hour behind us. We were not the most unfortunate souls in Britain after all.

stuart.millar@observer.co.uk

Their journey had began at 6.15 that morning, 217 miles north of Aberdeen on an oil rig in the Norwegian sector of the North Sea. They should have been in the pub with their mates in Liverpool at the start of two weeks' leave. Instead they were still stuck on a train somewhere to the north. 'This is driving me fucking insane,' Donald growled. 'This lot are taking the piss. If they want to shut down the railway, they should do that, but if they are going to take £75 off me for a ticket they should at least try and get me there. They're too greedy to say no to the money. That's their problem.' 'It's those notice boards they put up in the stations with the efficiency figures,' said O'Keefe. 'It's always 98.8 something. Where the fuck do they get that garbage from?' The feeling of tempers rapidly fraying filled the air. Mine included. In the seat behind me, a small boy decided the best fun he could have was to lift up the tray table attached to the back of my seat and slam it down as hard as his little arms could. For a full half-hour he continued with his game, while his parents looked on, clearly relieved that it wasn't them he was bothering. I could take no more. 'Is there any chance you could get him to stop?' I asked his mother politely. 'He's only three, you know,' she snapped in reply and turned back to her magazine. Perhaps wisely, the train staff, other than the buffet manager, had been conspicuous by their absence. Apart from one early foray to check tickets, the conductor limited his presence to doleful Tannoy announcements at each station of the number of minutes we were now behind schedule. He was replaced at Crewe by a new man who walked down the train with the latest estimated times of arrival. At 9.09pm, the scheduled time for reaching Euston, we were still somewhere in the Midlands, north of Stafford. But the new conductor had some news: even at this pathetic rate, we would be in London between 11.25pm and 11.40pm. So when the buffet man announced at 10.30pm that he was closing for the night, we took that as a good sign. Wrong. At 11pm, the conductor came on the Tannoy to tell us that we would now reach Milton Keynes by 11.25pm, and London half an hour later. By a quarter to midnight, with Milton Keynes still to materialise, the conductor gave up making any predictions. Most of us had given up hope of ever reaching anywhere. As we lumbered through the darkness, it felt as if we had been abandoned to our fate as the rest of Britain tucked up for the night. Occasionally, we would slow down even more. But finally we reached Milton Keynes, then Watford. London could not be far off. Once again we had underestimated the seriousness of our predicament and it was not until 12.59am - nearly three hours 50 minutes late - that we pulled into Euston. Passengers piled out to be greeted by loved ones with the enthusiasm of those who had started to lose all hope. From Glasgow to London, a distance of 400 miles, had taken more than nine hours, almost the same amount of time as it takes to fly from London to South Africa, across some 53 countries and the length of the African continent. After all this, we deserved some good news and it finally came at Euston. There was another train at least an hour behind us. We were not the most unfortunate souls in Britain after all. stuart.millar@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Norris rebuked for backing gays
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Steve Norris, the maverick Tory party vice-chairman, has been ordered to tone down his outspoken defence of gay and ethnic minority rights.
fields.byline: by Gaby Hinsliff, chief political correspondent
fields.body:
Steve Norris, the maverick Tory party vice-chairman, has been ordered to tone down his outspoken defence of gay and ethnic minority rights.

His rebuke from the leadership will be seen as a setback for the liberal wing of the party, since Norris was brought in to woo non-traditional Conservative voters with a more progressive line on social issues.

He has thrown himself into the job, backing same-sex registered partnerships to give gay couples inheritance and property rights, accusing party activists of sexism in failing to select women MPs, and attacking Lord Tebbit for 'ranting'.

But even though William Hague knew Norris's views when he appointed him, the MP's colourful style has infuriated some Shadow Cabinet colleagues and made Smith Square nervous.

Seb Coe, Hague's powerful chief of staff, is understood to have fired off a memo warning Norris not to stray off-message again and to refrain from personal attacks on other Tories. 'He has been told that if he doesn't stay in line he might find himself a very short-lived vice chairman,' said one insider.

The move follows a sharp attack by MPs on Michael Portillo, who has led calls for a more inclusive agenda making gays welcome in the party. Baroness Thatcher is said to have told friends that the man she once regarded as her natural heir has become 'very confused'.

The rebuke for Norris, a close ally of Portillo, has angered his supporters. 'Steve has just done what he was supposedly appointed to do, and he is now in trouble for it,' said one friend. 'The thing about Steve is that you can't really control him.'

fields.headline: Trimble survives challenge
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: David rimble, the Houdini of British politics, fought off a challenge to his leadership of the Ulster Unionist Party yesterday, but plunged the Northern Ireland peace process into a new crisis.
fields.body:
David rimble, the Houdini of British politics, fought off a challenge to his leadership of the Ulster Unionist Party yesterday, but plunged the Northern Ireland peace process into a new crisis.

The First Minister survived the fourth assault on his position since the Good Friday Agreement in 1998 and increased his support among the party's ruling body for the first time in 18 months.

Trimble defeated his main rival, the Lagan Valley MP Jeffrey Donaldson, who put a motion to a meeting of the party's ruling council calling on the UUP to leave the Province's power-sharing executive next month if the IRA failed to surrender arms.

A Donaldson victory would have signalled the beginning of the end of the Nobel prize winner's tenure as leader of the Province's largest party. But Trimble's counter-proposal, which allows him to vote Sinn Fein Ministers off the body dealing with all-Ireland issues, has angered nationalists, who regard the cross-border body as central to the Good Friday agreement.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, welcomed Trimble's victory and said he will be meeting the First Minister this week to discuss his proposal on excluding Sinn Fein. In an appeal to nationalists, Mandelson said: 'Don't overreact. Don't jump to conclusions. We all have to work together to get this back on track. If you portray this as a recipe for collapse, it will be a self-fulfilling prophecy.'

However, Gerry Kelly, the former IRA Old Bailey bomber and Sinn Fein negotiator, accused Trimble of being in breach of the Good Friday agreement. Kelly said: 'The result is that Mr Trimble has not stood up to Jeffrey Donaldson.'

The result, announced yesterday in Belfast's Waterfront Hall, came as a relief to the pro-agreement faction of the UUP. Trimble's motion won 445 votes, while Donaldson received 374. Minutes later a breathless Trimble claimed the differences between himself and the Donaldson camp were 'essentially tactical'. He added: 'Jeffrey and his supporters were at pains to make clear that they are committed to an assembly to operate on a cross-community basis.'

Trimble and his supporters have driven a wedge between two factions of the party's anti-agreement wing. One group, led by Donaldson, now longer accepts the need for devolution and power sharing. A smaller rump who want to return to direct rule, led by MPs Willie Ross and Rev Martin Smyth, have been isolated.

On IRA decommissioning, Trimble said the UUP was in this difficulty 'only because the promises made by the IRA have to be delivered'. Trimble denied he was creating a crisis at Stormont by barring Sinn Fein.'

webTitle: Was revenge the key to priest's gay sex murder?

fields.headline: Was revenge the key to priest's gay sex murder?
fields.standfirst:
Police believe killing of prominent Hindu may have been an act of retribution. Tony Thompson reports

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Police believe killing of prominent Hindu may have been an act of retribution. Tony Thompson reports.
fields.body:
Every fourth Friday night is Asian night at the Quebec nightclub, a dazzling silver and steel bar-cum-night club with a predominantly gay clientele in the heart of Leicester's city centre. Against a backdrop of the latest remixes of Kylie, Spiller and Steps, the handful of Asian men and women willing to be 'out' in public dance flamboyantly under the mirrored balls and flashing strobe lights.

It is a small but vibrant scene, which has been the focus of intense media attention since it emerged that Harish Purohit, a prominent local Hindu priest who was found murdered last week, had been living a double life.

By day, the married 42-year-old would juggle his roles as secretary of the National Association of Hindu Priests, president of the Hindu Federation and manager of social services at Leicester City Council with his ceremonial duties at the Shree Shakti Mandir temple, which he ran with his father. By night, he would don designer jeans, smart shirts, shoes, never trainers, and dance until the small hours at the city's gay clubs.

He was last seen alive at 11pm on Thursday, 19 October, when he left home for an unspecified destination. His body was found the following morning in the living room of a house in Harrison Road, close to his temple, that he had bought to renovate as a new family home.

He had been stabbed 13 times with a five-inch knife and died of a punctured lung. After the attack, his killer or killers blocked the front door with a sofa, turned the gas on and lit a fire, hoping to turn the building into an inferno and destroy any forensic evidence. Harish's car was found nearly two miles away: the keys are still missing. The gruesome discovery was made when neighbours reported smoke seeping out from under the front door.

Initial speculation focused on the possibility of a robbery gone wrong or a racially motivated, homophobic attack - a Mardi Gras-style festival planned for Leicester earlier this year was cancelled after vicious threats from right-wing activists. But what is quickly becoming clear is that the men responsible for the death of Harish Purohit were almost certainly Asian and that his murder was a brutal act of revenge.

Harish Purohit loved his religion and his community. But what he loved most of all was sex, mostly with young men, and the riskier the encounter the better. Living at the darkest, seediest end of the gay scene, Purohit spent much of his time at Abbey Park and 'Central Motors', the local names given to the public toilets in the city's two main cruising areas. He would loiter in the toilets awaiting sexual encounters that ranged from flashing to full intercourse.

But that was not enough. Police have learnt that Harish would regularly use his position within the Asian community to take young Asians who had concerns about their sexuality under his wing. He would offer them support and encouragement to 'come out' and then demand sexual favours in return.

For those who refused, Harish would threaten to tell their parents and friends that they were gay. Rather than risk being ostracised from the tight-knit community, many complied. In many cases, being with Harish would have been their first gay sexual experience. On at least one occasion he is accused of committing rape.

As his power and influence grew, so his ploys became more sophisticated. He became a volunteer for a gay switchboard and continued to use his blackmail tactics on the vulnerable Asians who would call him up. He would offer to meet them, discuss their sexuality and then blackmail them into sex. As his reputation began to spread, so he became a figure to be avoided at all costs.

'I knew Harish well, he was a good friend of mine and when he died a friend called and told me to watch myself,' says one gay Asian man, who asked not to be named. 'I told him I had nothing to worry about because I didn't have enemies. Harish had lots. He treated a lot of people on the gay scene very badly. A lot of people would no longer talk to him, they hated him. He said people were simply jealous because he was having sex with lots of nice young men and they were not.'

A few years ago, Harish went into partnership with a friend to establish a series of care homes for people with learning difficulties. It proved to be a successful business venture and as the money started rolling in, so he began to live more flamboyantly. He bought himself a silver BMW 320i, which became his pride and joy, and bought a house in Harrison Road to renovate for himself and his wife. The sparsely furnished house also served as the ideal venue for more lengthy sexual encounters and parties.

'He was a lovely bloke with a fantastic smile and real charisma,' says one friend who asked to remain anonymous. He loved to camp it up on his nights out and he loved dancing while on poppers. We had a lot of good times but I stopped hanging around with him because I was being tarred with the same brush. He was revered within the general Hindu community because of his work as a priest but he was hated within the gay community because of what he had done.'

But the bad feelings were not just confined to the gay community. More than a decade ago, Harish emerged from the city's now-defunct gay night club Spots to find a group of Hindu men waiting for him. Harish had been the priest at the wedding of one of the men who felt his ceremony had somehow been tainted. They beat him so severely he was left with two black eyes and a cracked rib.

'He brushed it off at the time as one of those things,' says his friend. 'It's an occupational hazard for lots of gay men. He was incredibly charismatic, a good talker. He could also be very manipulative. You would think that he would be able to talk his way out of any situation. It makes you wonder what went wrong this time.'

Harish arrived in Britain from Kenya at the age of seven with his three brothers and four sisters. His father, also a priest, founded a temple and brought Harish up in the same tradition. His son proved talented and dedicated to his work, but strived hard to bring a more modern flavour to his religious duties. He was praised for attempting to bridge the gap between young and old Hindus, for conducting his services in English and taking the time to explain the significance of ceremonies to non Hindus.

Harish worked hard to keep the truth about his sexuality secret from many of those closest to him but a surprising number were in the know. 'We all knew, it was obvious,' said one local. 'But it was something that nobody ever spoke about. As long as he didn't bring it with him to the temple, no one minded.' At a press conference soon after his death, his wife of four years, Anjana Joshi, revealed that Harish had told her of his sexuality long before they were wed. 'We were happily married,' she said. 'When you love someone that love is unconditional.'

The news attracted strong criticism from members of the Hindu religious community. Jagdish Bhatt, secretary of the Federation of Hindu Priests, said Hinduism viewed homosexuality as against nature, and a spokesman for the nearby Shree Sanatan temple, Nathubhai Jagjivan, said the revelation was 'shocking'.

Harish's elder brother, Janardan Purohit, said Harish would have been hurt by some of the comments: 'Our teachings tell us not to reject people - regardless of their faith, lifestyle or anything else. My advice to people who are saying things like this is to go back and take another look at the religion.

'I cannot think of any reason why anyone would want to hurt him. Everyone we have spoken to has nothing but good things to say about my brother. There is nothing to suggest why he was murdered, especially like this.'

At 3.30am on Friday, 20 October, just five hours after Harish was last seen alive, three Asian men in their thirties were seen emerging from an alleyway which runs parallel to Harrison Road and connects to the rear of the house in which the priest's body was found. A few seconds later, two more Asian men followed. The five got into a light-coloured saloon car and drove off. Police are trying to track the men who have now become chief suspects in the murder.

The Purohit case is one of the highest-profile murders ever undertaken by the city's police force. More than 100 officers are working on the case. The officer in charge, Detective Superintendent Brian Warraker, has confirmed that his team is probing the blackmail allegations but prefers to keep his best leads close to his chest. 'When I talk to the press, I am talking to the killer,' he said.

But the murder could not have come at a worse time. The Leicestershire force has already had more murders this year than at any time in the past 15 and has had to cancel a number of programmes aimed at vehicle crime and burglary to fund the intense investigation.

What is making the job of the police more difficult is that the very people they need to come forward and testify are those who have the most to lose by doing so. At the end of the first week of inquiries, despite massive publicity, the police hotline had received just 15 calls.

fields.headline: Troops head for trouble spot
fields.standfirst: Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: Britain is planning to send a naval task force and 500 troops to Sierra Leone to help shore up the beleaguered United Nations peacekeeping mission in the war-torn country, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain is planning to send a naval task force and 500 troops to Sierra Leone to help shore up the beleaguered United Nations peacekeeping mission in the war-torn country, it emerged yesterday.

The helicopter carrier HMS Ocean will return to the region accompanied by two other warships and support vessels as well as soldiers from 42 Royal Marine Commando. The vessels are currently on exercise in the Mediterranean, but would reach the West African state in days.

The task force is expected to remain offshore near Freetown as a rapid and flexible reaction force in case the situation there deteriorates further and urgent action is needed. It will have no official role to play as part of the UN force, which has been hamstrung by a recent decision by the Jordanian and Indian components to withdraw.

The news, revealed by the BBC Today programme, prompted condemnation from Tory Shadow Defence Secretary Iain Duncan Smith, who warned that British troops could get dragged 'deeper and deeper into the mess and muddle of Sierra Leone'.

The UN mission to the former British colony has suffered various setbacks in its attempts to bring peace to a country almost destroyed by a decade of civil war. In May, around 500 UN soldiers were taken hostage by rebels, forcing a humiliating crisis that saw British forces intervene to prevent the collapse of the country and the loss of Freetown to anti-government forces.

About 200 British troops are currently in Sierra Leone training and arming a new government army to defeat the Revolutionary United Front, whose soldiers, often children, are notorious for mutilating prisoners and going into battle high on drugs.

However, much of the country, including lucrative and illegal diamond mines, remains in rebel hands.

The training mission has not been trouble-free. In August, 11 British soldiers from the Royal Irish Regiment were captured by the West Side Boys militia after detouring off a main road and driving into the jungle. The hostages were later rescued by the SAS and soldiers from the Parachute Regiment, but a fierce gun battle left one special forces soldier dead.

Details and a timetable for the taskforce - to be known as the Amphibious Ready Group - are expected to be unveiled early next week. A Ministry of Defence spokesman said he could make no comment until the announcement was made.

The move was backed by Liberal Democrat defence spokesman Menzies Campbell, who called for the British troops to join the UN force.

'If we want the UN mission to succeed, we should now assign British troops directly to the UN command,' he said. 'If the UN goes through another crisis like last May, then all the gains since then will simply be lost.'

However, despite previous UN requests for a joint military operation with British forces, such a development is highly unlikely.

Defence chiefs are almost certain to want to preserve their autonomy of action, especially with the UN force widely seen as incompetent and ineffective.

It will have no official role to play as part of the UN force, which has been hamstrung by a recent decision by the Jordanian and Indian components to withdraw. The news, revealed by the BBC Today programme, prompted condemnation from Tory Shadow Defence Secretary Iain Duncan Smith, who warned that British troops could get dragged 'deeper and deeper into the mess and muddle of Sierra Leone'. The UN mission to the former British colony has suffered various setbacks in its attempts to bring peace to a country almost destroyed by a decade of civil war. In May, around 500 UN soldiers were taken hostage by rebels, forcing a humiliating crisis that saw British forces intervene to prevent the collapse of the country and the loss of Freetown to anti-government forces. About 200 British troops are currently in Sierra Leone training and arming a new government army to defeat the Revolutionary United Front, whose soldiers, often children, are notorious for mutilating prisoners and going into battle high on drugs. However, much of the country, including lucrative and illegal diamond mines, remains in rebel hands. The training mission has not been trouble-free. In August, 11 British soldiers from the Royal Irish Regiment were captured by the West Side Boys militia after detouring off a main road and driving into the jungle. The hostages were later rescued by the SAS and soldiers from the Parachute Regiment, but a fierce gun battle left one special forces soldier dead. Details and a timetable for the taskforce - to be known as the Amphibious Ready Group - are expected to be unveiled early next week. A Ministry of Defence spokesman said he could make no comment until the announcement was made. The move was backed by Liberal Democrat defence spokesman Menzies Campbell, who called for the British troops to join the UN force. 'If we want the UN mission to succeed, we should now assign British troops directly to the UN command,' he said. 'If the UN goes through another crisis like last May, then all the gains since then will simply be lost.' However, despite previous UN requests for a joint military operation with British forces, such a development is highly unlikely. Defence chiefs are almost certain to want to preserve their autonomy of action, especially with the UN force widely seen as incompetent and ineffective.

fields.headline: Gore for President
fields.standfirst:
Bush would be bad for the world.

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: In a one billion-dollar campaign for the most powerful job on the planet, it is frightening that America is being offered a choice between two flawed scions of self-perpetuating political dynasties.
fields.body:
In a one billion-dollar campaign for the most powerful job on the planet, it is frightening that America is being offered a choice between two flawed scions of self-perpetuating political dynasties.

The rules of this fight, as Robert Reich explains on these pages, have meant that both George Bush and Al Gore have assiduously avoided the big issues in order to reassure the narrowest band of swing voters, while not scaring their own supporters. The campaign has become an election of concealment, avoiding key issues that confront America in the new millennium - its socially corrosive poverty, its pervasive culture of violence, its failing justice system and the wider role of America in the world.

Al Gore, for all the slickness of his convention performance, has come across as arrogant and prone to exaggeration. In cutting himself loose from the Democratic Party's biggest asset, the formidable campaigning skills of Bill Clinton, his judgment has also come into question. Most worrying is the way in which, in his pursuit of the centre, he has downplayed issues formerly so important to him, such as gun control, poverty and social inclusion.

But beneath his calculated evasion, Mr Gore remains wedded to continuing the broad thrust of the policies of the Clinton administration. His is a vision of an inclusive state which, despite its faults, would remain committed to social justice and to America's role as a force for constructive change in a wider world.

Which brings us to George Bush, the candidate who really scares us, and who should really scare America. He has positioned himself as the Washington outsider, uncorrupted, as he would have it, by the cynicism of 'beltway' politics.

But in a campaign where Republicans have outspent the Democrats by two-to-one, Bush represents a wider corruption of the American political system - by corporate self-interest.

A Bush presidency would see a harshening of American society and a deepening of its social faultlines. In Bush's America, the rich would become richer, while moves to reform gun controls and judicial application of the death penalty would be set back a generation. A Bush administration would also rewrite his country's relationship with the world, rejecting cautious internationalism in favour of a new US unilateralism.

On these grounds, we must hope that it is Al Gore - for all his flaws - who wins next week's election.

webTitle: Straw tells suburbia to 'snitch' on thugs

fields.headline: Straw tells suburbia to 'snitch' on thugs
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Jack Sraw triggered fresh controversy yesterday after calling for 'good neighbours' to tell the police about anti-social thugs and vandals.
fields.body:
Jack Sraw triggered fresh controversy yesterday after calling for 'good neighbours' to tell the police about anti-social thugs and vandals.

The Home Secretary wants the stalwarts of the Neighbourhood Watch to report local thugs and problem families and actively 'get involved' in seeking so-called anti-social behaviour orders against them.

But probation officers warned that attempts to turn the sentinels of suburbia into amateur detectives risked making them targets for violence by accused youths.

Until now decisions on issuing orders - meant to cover behaviour causing 'alarm, distress or harassment' to others - have been left to police, probation officers and local authorities, who proved initially resistant to using them, much to Ministers' irritation.

Although Straw said that more than 100 orders have now been issued after encouragement from the Home Office, the new initiative will be seen as another attempt to override professionals' reluctance by tapping into deep public anxieties about gangs of loitering teenagers indulging in vandalism or harassment.

In a speech to the National Neighbourhood Watch Conference yesterday, Straw said anti-social behaviour 'blights people's lives', adding: 'I want you and your members to get involved in the process itself by notifyng the police and local authorities of cases of anti-social behaviour and asking to be involved in the decision-making process that leads to the application for an order. If you or your neighbours are suffering from anti-social behaviour, do something about it now.'

There will be forms for ordinary people to fill in complaining about issues from teenage vandals and 'neighbours from hell' to prostitution or car crime, Straw said, which they can then present to police or local authorities, pushing for an application for a court order to be made.

But Harry Fletcher, the spokesman for the National Association of Probation Officers, warned the idea risked retribution against Neighbourhood Watch members.

'The Home Secretary is in danger of encouraging a "snitch and reprisal" culture, which would be extremely unhelpful to community relations,' he said. 'He needs to realise that Anti-Social Behaviour Orders are not popular with the courts and they are not popular with the professionals.'

Labour has repeatedly suffered this year from the backfiring of 'tough' measures that turned out to be ill thought through. Straw has previously urged members of the public to tackle thugs directly themselves, pointing out that he himself once rugby-tackled a mugger - prompting police warnings that civilians should not put themselves at risk.

The orders, designed to combat low-level criminality with sanctions of up to five years in jail if breached, were introduced last April but got off to a slow start, prompting Straw to criticise councils and courts for not using their new powers.

Shadow Home Secretary Ann Widdecombe accused him of pushing the responsibility for the poor response to ASBOs on to other people. 'I would never discourage anybody coming forward with information, but this is not what Neighbourhood Watch groups were set up to do.'

webTitle: Dramatic new link to Israeli embassy bomb

fields.headline: Dramatic new link to Israeli embassy bomb
fields.standfirst: Fresh suspect revealed on final day of students' appeal against conviction. Martin Bright and Pete Sawyer report
fields.trailText:
Fresh suspect revealed on final day of students' appeal against conviction. Martin Bright and Pete Sawyer report

Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.body:
A British Muslim convert who posed as a journalist in the Balkans has emerged as a new suspect in the bombing of the Israeli Embassy in London in 1994, The Observer can reveal. The existence of the shadowy figure, known as 'Mohammed', was revealed last week on the final day of the appeal of two Palestinian students convicted of the bombing four years ago.

In a dramatic development at the High Court on Friday, the appeal was adjourned when defence QC Michael Mansfield said a last-minute phone call to Australia had provided spectacular new evidence.

Tim Wise, an Australian freelance cameraman who worked for the BBC and Channel 4, said he had reported his flatmate 'Mohammed' to the police in July 1994, a week after a car bomb exploded outside the embassy in Kensington, injuring 14 people.

Wise claims that he found several documents in Mohammed's room, plus a list of ammunition and arms including AK-47 assault rifles and two expertly drawn maps of London.

One was a plan of the area around the embassy, including its security defences. 'It was like he was casing it out,' he said. No mention was made of Mohammed in the trial, although it is inconceivable anti-terrorist officers would not have been told about the documents.

Samar Alami and Jawad Botmeh each received 20 years for their alleged role in the bombing, although the judge admitted the evidence against them was 'all circumstantial'. They have always professed their innocence despite admitting to amateur experiments with explosives.

Mohammed was living in a room in Wise's London flat and claimed to be a press photographer. With useful contacts in the fundamentalist world, Mohammed said he could give Wise unique access to the kaleidoscope of international Muslim groups fighting in the Balkans.

But the Australian became suspicious after a trip to Croatia, when his flatmate disappeared with money and camera equipment he had borrowed.

Speaking from Sydney this weekend, Wise told The Observer: 'In the corner there was a small washbasin which had been covered with a wooden board, on top of which Mohammed had placed a cloth and various Islamic ornaments. I removed the board and found documents hidden in the basin.' Wise immediately called the local Fulham police and two detectives, DC Holt and DC Wareing, arrived to take a statement. They searched the room and took away documents. Wise never saw the police, his equipment or Mohammed again. A few years later he moved back to his native Australia and thought no more about it.

Last Thursday, Wise received a call from Gareth Peirce, the solicitor representing Botmeh and Alami, after friends of the cameraman who had heard the stories about Mohammed urged her to contact him.

The new evidence from Wise bolsters defence claims that there were other leads in the investigation of the bombing, suggesting the two Palestinian students had nothing to do with it. Last week the prosecution finally admitted that former MI5 officer David Shayler was correct to claim that the security services had received intelligence of a terrorist attack on the embassy several months before the bombing.

They confirmed the foreign terrorist group involved had no connection to the two suspects. The original trial judge had not been informed of the warning and the jury was told there was an 'intelligence vacuum'.

It is the latest twist in a legal saga involving student politics, international terrorism, espionage and claims of cover-up reaching from the police to the office of Home Secretary Jack Straw. Straw made a statement in 1997, when Shayler first made his revelations, saying the bombing could not have been averted.

On Friday, the three judges at the High Court, considering Botmeh's and Alami's appeals, had to adjourn to consider Wise's new evidence. It is unlikely they will meet again for several months, during which time the Crown Prosecution Service is asked to investigate the claims, find the plans and, ideally, locate Mohammed.

Wise remembers his old flatmate well. He had burn marks on his face and back, which he claimed were from battles with the Israeli security forces when he lived in Palestine as a child. He had answered an advert Wise had placed in the papers for a flatmate.

When Mohammed knew Wise was planning a trip to Bosnia he asked to come along, gaining accreditation from a Muslim magazine. 'We flew into Zagreb in Croatia and went down to Split, where we stayed with an Islamic group,' said Wise. 'Mohammed would borrow money from them, go away for a few days on the pretext of doing a story and then come back asking for more money.'

Mohammed loved the romance of the foreign correspondent's life, once insisting on being photographed next to a BBC Land-Rover peppered with bullet holes. 'But then the trouble started,' said Wise. 'The group in Split got suspicious and I began to fear for my life. They confiscated my camera equipment, Mohammed did a runner, and I left. We never got to Bosnia.'

The evidence about a new suspect in the Israeli Embassy case will further embarrass the security services. Last week the prosecution was forced to admit to a catalogue of errors and incompetence by the police, intelligence services and the original lawyers in the case.

The case is the first to test the appeal courts against the new Human Rights Act, introduced this month. The judges may be in breach of the Act by hearing the appeal at all, when so much evidence was withheld from the original judge.

This weekend Wise said he was keen to cooperate with any investigation into his former flatmate. 'I want to see him behind bars, as I'm sure a lot of people do,' he said.

webTitle: Bomb victim families ready for court fight

fields.headline: Bomb victim families ready for court fight
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The families of the victims of the Omagh bomb have spent a year trying to raise £2 million to launch a civil case against the terrorists responsible.
fields.body:
The families of the victims of the Omagh bomb have spent a year trying to raise £2 million to launch a civil case against the terrorists responsible.

Ahead of a meeting with Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson tomorrow, The Observer can reveal that relatives of the 29 men, women and children killed in the atrocity have now raised sufficient funds.

The families have also been in negotiations with the Daily Mail for several months over the paper's proposed fundraising campaign to help the Omagh bomb relatives take civil actions against those suspected of being behind the massacre.

They said talks between their lawyers and the paper began long before BBC1's Panorama named four of the suspects connected with the atrocity. The police think they know the identities of the terrorists responsible, but say they have insufficient evidence to prosecute.

The families had approached the Mail to set up a fighting fund for justice because the paper had backed similar campaigns in the past. They were impressed at the way the Mail supported the family of the murdered black teenager Stephen Lawrence in their fight to bring his killers to justice.

Last year The Observer revealed that a number of the Omagh families were consulting lawyers to see if they could take civil actions in the courts against Real IRA suspects.

'We have yet to decide whether that action is a criminal injuries case, a civil prosecution or a war crimes case in the International Court of Justice in The Hague. But we need money to fight for justice and our lawyers estimate the costs could be up to £2 million. We want to strip these people of their assets and name and shame all of them around the world. The Mail 's fighting fund will help us to do that,' said Michael Gallagher, whose son Adrian was killed in the bombing.

At their meeting with Mandelson, the relatives will ask him to put pressure on America to put the Real IRA on its list of global terror groups.

Including the Real IRA on the list would bar them and their political allies, the 32 County Sovereignty Committee, from fundraising in America.

The list includes the group led by the Saudi fundamentalist Osama bin Laden, the Palestinian rejectionist group Hamas and other Middle Eastern terrorist organisations.

Michael Gallagher, who will be accompanied to the lunch by Stanley McCombe, whose wife Anne was killed in the bomb, said: 'The primary point we want to raise with Mr Mandelson is why the Irish government opposed placing the Real IRA on the Americans' global terrorist list. We want him to ask the US government to ignore the Irish government's opposition and of course we want him to persuade Dublin to change its attitude on this question.'

He said the families were furious over allegations that Dublin interfered with the inquiry to prevent the Irish police using potential 'supergrass witnesses'.

webTitle: Private hospitals to bail out NHS

fields.headline: Private hospitals to bail out NHS
fields.standfirst:
New health chief reveals controversial plan to make space in wards before winter flu crisis hits
Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Private hospitals, long shunned by Labour for being politically incorrect, are to be paid by the NHS to help overcrowded state hospitals during the winter crisis.
fields.body:
Private hospitals, long shunned by Labour for being politically incorrect, are to be paid by the NHS to help overcrowded state hospitals during the winter crisis.

The new NHS chief executive told The Observer that, in a controversial move, patients waiting for non-urgent surgery would be treated in private hospitals.

Longer-term patients will also be decanted into private hospitals so that their beds can be used for emergency cases. Many elderly patients who need lengthy periods of care will be moved, some into nursing homes.

Last year the NHS faced sharp criticism when it was revealed that there were only two intensive care beds available in England and Wales at the height of the winter flu epidemic.

Patients had to be driven hundreds of miles around the country to find a hospital that had the space to treat them. Others were left in corridors on trolleys.

Nigel Crisp, who takes up his new post on Wednesday, said that it was time for 'radical thinking' in the NHS to make sure patients are put first. He has told health managers that they must react quickly to problems over the next three tough months.

He said he didn't know how much NHS money will be spent on private care as local health authorities will make the arrangements. Experts estimated that it would total millions of pounds across England and Wales.

Tony Blair has given the plan his blessing. The Prime Minister knows that long waiting lists and dirty hospitals have eroded support for his Government.

He has told the NHS that it must be 'in delivery mode'.

'This is new thinking,' Crisp told The Observer. 'It is a recognition by us all that we have to be honest. Patients are really telling us that they are fed up with waiting. Staff are telling us that they are really stressed. They are working under a lot of pressure.

'Yes, we need to build up the capacity in the NHS, that will take some time. As we're doing that, let's take some of that pressure out of the system by using the private sector if that is the appropriate thing to do. That is a very practical, very managerial approach to it. That is part of my appointment, marking that change.'

Answering concerns that private hospitals fall below NHS standards, he said inspections would be rigorous.

'We're talking about making sensible decisions for patients,' Crisp said. 'The huge bulk of care in this country is provided by the NHS and paid for by the NHS. But if we can relieve some of the pressure, then let's be very clear that that is what we are doing and not be ideologically opposed to doing that.

'The private sector can help us with relatively small but important numbers of patients. We need to be imaginative.'

The previous Health Secretary, Frank Dobson, was personally suspicious of doing deals with the private sector. But Alan Milburn, the present Health Secretary, has said there should be no political problem with using private expertise. Crisp also said that he would be using 'admission repression' teams to encourage people who do not need care to stay at home.

'My experience last winter was that the vast majority of people you are looking at are elderly. They need care, but not necessarily the care of an acute hospital.

'If you get support at home you may not need to come into hospital. That area needs to be expanded.'

He said that, although bed capacity had increased since last winter, he was sure that some hospitals would struggle this year.

'You can't guarantee anything as to what will happen,' he said. 'We are well prepared, we have got more capacity, [but] I have no doubt that individual hospitals will get into quite critical states.'

Staff are telling us that they are really stressed. They are working under a lot of pressure. 'Yes, we need to build up the capacity in the NHS, that will take some time. As we're doing that, let's take some of that pressure out of the system by using the private sector if that is the appropriate thing to do. That is a very practical, very managerial approach to it. That is part of my appointment, marking that change.' Answering concerns that private hospitals fall below NHS standards, he said inspections would be rigorous. 'We're talking about making sensible decisions for patients,' Crisp said. 'The huge bulk of care in this country is provided by the NHS and paid for by the NHS. But if we can relieve some of the pressure, then let's be very clear that that is what we are doing and not be ideologically opposed to doing that. 'The private sector can help us with relatively small but important numbers of patients. We need to be imaginative.' The previous Health Secretary, Frank Dobson, was personally suspicious of doing deals with the private sector. But Alan Milburn, the present Health Secretary, has said there should be no political problem with using private expertise. Crisp also said that he would be using 'admission repression' teams to encourage people who do not need care to stay at home. 'My experience last winter was that the vast majority of people you are looking at are elderly. They need care, but not necessarily the care of an acute hospital. 'If you get support at home you may not need to come into hospital. That area needs to be expanded.' He said that, although bed capacity had increased since last winter, he was sure that some hospitals would struggle this year. 'You can't guarantee anything as to what will happen,' he said. 'We are well prepared, we have got more capacity, [but] I have no doubt that individual hospitals will get into quite critical states.'

webTitle: Leader: The disease of secrecy behind BSE

fields.headline: Behind BSE lies a disease of secrecy
fields.standfirst:
Ministers' freedom must be checked.

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Freedom of information is a cause beloved of woolly liberals, or so this Government believes. Consequently, it is thought to be an issue with no votes in it. It could be a fatal misjudgment.
fields.body:
Freedom of information is a cause beloved of woolly liberals, or so this Government believes. Consequently, it is thought to be an issue with no votes in it. It could be a fatal misjudgment.

Health, education and pensions are fundamental. But just as important is trust in the very act of government. Ordinary voters might not chart the passage of the Freedom of Information Bill line by line. That does not mean that they are not alert to the sense that 'they' in today's Britain look out for themselves, and that too many bad decisions by those in power go unpunished. The interest in accountability and demand for better government is not confined to Hampstead; it is vigorously expressed in homes across the country.

After the Phillips Report into Britain's worst post-war public health disaster - the BSE crisis - that demand will certainly grow. Although Lord Phillips was at pains not to establish 'scapegoats and villains', the details of his report are excoriating - and he has been close to pusillanimous in not drawing appropriate conclusions. Within the body of his text lie condemnations that even he could not avoid. There was 'positive censorship' in the early days of the BSE crisis. There was a 'clear policy of restricting the disclosure of information about BSE' that 'robbed those who would have had an interest in receiving it of the chance to react'. A Whitehall culture of secrecy led to worse, slower decisions than would have taken place had the automatic presumption been that information should be disclosed. In short, had there been a little more 'woolly liberalism' about freedom of information, many fewer British people would now be dying from variant-CJD.

That is why alongside measures to improve food standards we now need wholesale overhaul of Britain's approach to freedom of information. New Labour was pledged to the cause in opposition but their latest bill would still not address the shortcomings exposed by Phillips. Astoundingly, their proposed framework would not have made one iota of difference to the BSE debacle. Under the suggested regime, we would have had to apply to an Information Commissioner to get factual and scientific information that had already been provided to Ministers, but even then Ministers could veto disclosure. The findings of Maff inspectors about renderers and abattoirs could be similarly vetoed. As for policy advice, if disclosure is deemed to harm the policy-making process it would enjoy automatic exemption.

Worse still, the new bill is even weaker than the Open Government code established by the Major government. That presumed, at least, that information should be provided unless the government proves otherwise - a presumption overturned by New Labour as a concession too far. The Home Office argument that a proper Freedom of Information Bill will weaken democracy because it places limits on Ministerial freedom is entirely bogus, and used by no other democratic government in the world. It is not limits on Ministerial freedom that we need; it is knowledge about what informs their actions.

If Britain is serious about not wanting a repeat of the BSE crisis, we must deprive officials and Ministers of the capacity to make decisions quite as haplessly as they did in the 10 years between 1986 and 1996. It's as simple as that.

webTitle: Anthony Browne on the food chain

fields.headline: The cost of taking nature out of farming
fields.standfirst:
The food chain

Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: As the wide door swings open, the nostril-clenching stench almost knocks you over. Sunlight slices through the windowless gloom, across a jostling carpet of chickens stretching from wall to wall.
fields.body:
As the wide door swings open, the nostril-clenching stench almost knocks you over. Sunlight slices through the windowless gloom, across a jostling carpet of chickens stretching from wall to wall.

Packed so tightly they can barely move, 80,000 birds squeal deafeningly as they wallow in droppings and urine. Scores have toppled over dead from heart attacks. Others have splayed legs, unable to support their unnaturally swollen bodies. The putrid air is thick with ammonia and feathers.

This is the result of 50 years of industrialisation in British agriculture.

Farmers boast that industrialisation has boosted output and cut prices. But critics say it led to food scandals, from salmonella and E.coli to BSE, and damaged the countryside. Reported cases of food poisoning have risen sevenfold since the early Eighties to more than 100,000 cases a year.

After 50 years of rapid advance, industrialised farming has come under siege from health officials, consumers and environmentalists. Genetically modified foods - the latest step in the process - had to beat a hasty retreat in the UK after comprehensive consumer rejection. Demand for organic foods grows by 40 per cent a year. Marks and Spencer now stocks free-range eggs only.

Animal welfare was the first casualty of higher productivity. From veal crates to battery hens, animals have been kept in as small a space as possible. In the UK, veal crates were banned in 1990, and sow stalls were banned last year. By 2012, battery cages for chickens will also be banned.

'The tide has turned. The days of intensification are over,' says Jackie Turner, chief research officer of the charity Compassion in World Farming. But industrialisation has produced lasting gains - and lingering problems.

Shortages during World War II scared the Government into making secure food supplies a priority. The 1947 Agriculture Act required farmers to produce enough food for the nation. With subsidies and technological innovation, advances have been startling.

Before the war, one hectare of land produced on average just over 2 tonnes of wheat. This had risen to more than 8 tonnes by 1996. Selectively-bred dairy cows now produce 50 litres of milk a day, 10 times what a calf needs. In 1936, average hens produced 150 eggs a year. Selective breeding and intensive farming have boosted that to 310.

Mechanisation has advanced, and employment has fallen. The average farm worker produces three times as much food as 25 years ago.

In 30 years, the amount of time it takes a chicken to reach slaughter age has halved to about 39 days, requiring 40 per cent less feed than previously. Now a farmer needs only give a chicken 3.6kg of feed to reach 2kg of body weight.

'It's a sign of tremendous success and development. Cheaper food means we have more money to spend on other things. It's improved prosperity,' argues Professor Allan Buckwell, policy director at the Country Landowners Association. 'Farmers are shell-shocked they've done all this and instead of acknowledgement, they are heaped with criticism.'

But cheap and plentiful food has not come without cost. Intensive agriculture meant the destruction of hedgerows and ploughing up of pastures, as fields and farms grew. Water sources have been polluted with nitrates from fertilisers.

Animals are selectively bred to produce more meat more quickly, while eating less. Broiler hens now grow so fast their legs buckle, and they are often ill. 'The animals are bred like Olympic athletes to do one job. Dairy cows are now basically a skeleton with a big udder,' says Turner.

Animals are given antibiotic growth promoters, mixed into the feed, to kill the bacteria in their guts and let them grow faster. To support such growth, they need cheap, high protein, high energy food. One solution was to recycle animals, grinding their remains into feed for younger ones.

'The idea of feeding one species to itself is astonishing, but it's entirely logical,' Turner says.

Farmers have fed recycled animal remains to the same species since early last century. But its industry-wide practice ensured that BSE spread rapidly. It is still legal to feed poultry offal or blood to cows. Chickens can still be fed their own offal meal and ground-up feathers.

The use of antibiotics in agriculture has risen 15-fold in 30 years, and now more antibiotics are used on farm animals than on people.

The World Health Organisation has warned that as a result, bacteria such as E.coli and Salmonella are more resistant to treatment.
