webTitle: Ian Smith: 'The more we killed, the happier we were'

fields.headline: Ian Smith: 'The more we killed, the happier we were'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Zimbabwe
Rhodesian military history
Special report from oneworld.net, the human rights and development charity
fields.trailText: Former Rhodesian Prime Minister Ian Smith returns a week tomorrow to his home in Zimbabwe. He says he relishes the prospect of facing charges of genocide threatened by President Robert Mugabe, whose hold on power is under threat.
fields.body:
Former Rhodesian Prime Minister Ian Smith returns a week tomorrow to his home in Zimbabwe. He says he relishes the prospect of facing charges of genocide threatened by President Robert Mugabe, whose hold on power is under threat.

But at Oxford last week, in the civilised ambience of a Union debate, Smith found himself on trial for having failed to learn the lessons of history. Smith said he refused to apologise for atrocities committed while he held office. He said he had no regrets about the estimated 30,000 Zimbabweans killed during his rule. 'The more we killed, the happier we were. We were fighting terrorists.'

Smith brushed off last week's threat by Mugabe to put him on trial for 'genocide and atrocities' committed durning the war of liberation in the Seventies. He told The Observer: 'I'm happy about it. I'd come to him, because I've got nothing to apologise for. He's the only one who should be concerned about violations of human rights.'

Smith, who ruled Southern Rhodesia, now Zimbabwe, for 15 years, and once ran on a ticket for a 'whiter, brighter Rhodesia', proposed the motion: 'African leaders put power before their people.'

A skeletal 81-year-old, he used his slot on the debating floor to deliver a lecture criticised as having less to do with the debate than being a 'history lesson' - denouncing Mugabe as a dictator while looking back on his regime with rose-tinted glasses.

When members of the audience asked Smith to explain the differences between his regime and Mugabe's administration, a furious Smith defended his actions. 'We were fighting a war. They were killing innocent people. They were killing their own people. They were massacring innocent people. We never killed civilians.'

Throughout the course of his speech, Smith spoke of the people he used to govern in less than endearing terms, at some points calling them rapists and murderers.

'As the former Prime Minister of Rhodesia, isn't this an opportune time to ask for forgiveness?' interrupted Mrs Pavelyn Tendai Musaka, Zimbabwe's Deputy High Commissioner in Britain. Smith didn't think so. 'We had no atrocities. We killed terrorists... The Shona, they massacred 30,000 Matabele because the Matabele were beginning to stand their ground.'

Professor Welshman Ncube, shadow Home Affairs Minister for the Movement for Democratic Change, was also in Oxford for the debate. He does not see things in the same light as Ian Smith.

'The war Smith fought was definitely not a just war. It was a war to preserve a racist regime, it was a war to retard democratic development in the country, and to think that he could actually today stand up and feel no remorse, no contrition, find nothing wrong in the system he defended, is in itself astounding. In fact, perhaps he needs forgiveness himself.'

Zimbabweans, whether Mugabe or MDC supporters, view him as a racist relic of an old Africa that has had its day.

'The world has moved a long way from the primitive racial things they stood for and caused a lot of death for,' said Ncube. 'So, it's sad to stand back and hear him completely oblivious of the wrong things his government tried to do. But that's the reality. But now, instead of being bogged down in that, we're saying that Zimbabwe faces new challenges today. Smith and his group are history.'

fields.headline: War games
fields.trailText: I'm just minding my own business of making a pig's ear of some roast beef for our packed lunch when the knife slips and accidentally slices my finger off.
fields.body:
I'm just minding my own business of making a pig's ear of some roast beef for our packed lunch when the knife slips and accidentally slices my finger off, which is an excellent way of rousing an English Sunday household from its sleepy repose, what with blood spurting all over the kitchen and my wife dashing in wondering what all the screaming is about the minute she's finished her crossword, by which time I'm holding it under the cold tap not daring to look until such time as our children have dug out our Dorling Kindersley pop-up first aid severed limbs manual. 'Mmm, just as I thought,' my wife says, calmly inspecting the damage before sending the youngest next door to borrow a small plaster.

'But what are we going to do?' I cry, because we are supposed to be on our way out to our local country manor house, who are recreating World War Two to celebrate 60 years of everybody suddenly finding out that Dunkirk isn't in Scotland. 'Don't worry,' says my wife. 'They've probably got a cafe.'

So off we go in the car, me with my finger sticking out like a sore thumb, while my wife tries to calm the children, who are still in deep shock at the prospect of having to do history on their day off. 'It'll be really good,' she says. 'There'll be Spitfires and hand grenades going off and tanks mowing down villages and Nuremberg rallies...'

Needless to say there is no such thing, though on arrival we are treated to a demonstration of how a Dad's Army private can make an explosive device safe using an old routine from the golden age of radio comedy. How we all laugh at the disappointingly small bang at the end, except the children, who have no appreciation that it is good-humoured politeness in the face of humdrum entertainment that makes Britain what it is today.

Afterwards we file through into the steaming kitchen where village scamps in scout uniforms gad about in gas masks and russet-cheeked dinner ladies are busy rustling up a make-do-and-mend three-course lunch out of cabbage stumps, a leg of Spam and two pieces of coal. 'We don't have to eat here, do we?' whispers the seven-year-old, the colour suddenly draining from his face.

'This is what it was like back when Grandma was a little girl,' I whisper.

'What, Grandma used to live in a castle?'

We proceed into the dining room, where members of the local women's hat-wearing society are pretending to enjoy wood soup while the hostess in full furs and tweeds extemporises on the inconvenience of trying to provide the usual hospitality with nothing hanging in the pantry but deserters. 'Game is not rationed, of course,' she is saying, which so surprises none of her luncheon companions that it might as well have been uttered for the benefit of passers-by from the 21st century. We move on to the officers' mess, where a selection of upright chaps are discussing Jerry's movements over badger rissoles. 'Ah, hullo!' roars someone with a big moustache as though we are boffins from divisional HQ on a surprise visit. We smile weakly and make our escape before we are invited to pronounce upon the latest developments in doodlebug technology, only to stumble upon a Mrs Mop-type having a rest in the corridor. 'Just takin' the weight off me blimmin' feet. Bin on 'em all day I 'ave...' she says in a manner suggesting that, on the contrary, she has been spending too much time watching The Lavender Hill Mob .

We go and say hello to the carthorses, who of course in real life would by now have been fed powdered greatcoat and melted down to make chewing gum for the troops, before wandering into an upstairs billet furnished with sacks of straw and deserted except for a ukulele and a George Formby songbook whose owner one can only assume has been taken out and shot for being too cheerful in the face of adversity.

Meanwhile on the front lawn, bayonet practice is in full bellow.

'Is your blood boiling, son?' shouts the sarn'tmajor.

'Yes, corporal,' replies the recruit, jabbing the sack as though he's waking someone up.

My finger is throbbing. Maybe it's trying to tell us something.

webTitle: Rover in talks with Mayflower over UK car future

fields.headline: Rover in talks with Mayflower over UK car future
fields.standfirst: Special report: Rover in crisis
fields.trailText: MG Rover is set to approach UK engineering group and long-term supplier Mayflower about a partnership to invest in a future generation of British cars.
fields.byline: by Joanna Walters and Oliver Morgan
fields.body:
MG Rover is set to approach UK engineering group and long-term supplier Mayflower about a partnership to invest in a future generation of British cars.

Chairman John Towers insisted this weekend that such a move was not at odds with the resignation from MG Rover's supervisory board last Friday of Mayflower executive Terry Whitmore.

He also said any collaboration would not clash with alliance discussions already going on with an overseas carmaker. This is understood to be Proton of Malaysia, as revealed by The Observer, although confusion surrounded the talks this weekend with industry sources in the West Midlands saying Proton had walked away.

In an interview after an MG Rover board meeting in Birmingham, Towers said his company was prepared to talk both to other carmakers and major suppliers about jointly investing £350 million in a new range of medium-sized cars. He hopes to get close to securing a partnership next spring.

Industry observers have made it clear they do not believe MG Rover can survive without a tie-up.

Towers said his strategy of making 200,000 cars a year from next year was 'rock solid. We are in conversations with a potential collaborative partner about a car, but they are at the very early stages. Talks do not touch on the questions of equity or ownership.'

Proton is believed to have been interested in the joint purchase of the engine plant at MG Rover's Longbridge factory in Birmingham, which is still owned by the UK firm's ex-parent, BMW.

But a source close to the negotiations said there were 'complications'. He added that Proton's interest in Rover might be fading. This was because the Malaysian company believed there could be a better opportunity to manufacture at the Nissan plant in Sunderland if, as many fear, Nissan's partner Renault, with whom Proton has links, decides to switch production of the next Micra car to the Continent.

webTitle: Maria Scott: Low taxes now could bring pain later

fields.headline: Low taxes now could bring pain later
fields.trailText: Anyone brave enough to have attempted a long-term financial plan of what they really need to save for retirement will probably have found it deeply disturbing.
fields.body:
Anyone brave enough to have attempted a long-term financial plan of what they really need to save for retirement will probably have found it deeply disturbing.

Everyone except MPs, long-serving civil servants and highly-paid company directors with unbroken marriages and small families must struggle to scrape together comfortable pen sions. A sample of the sums involved to work out what you will need to accumulate is set out on page 21.

If you feel daunted, take heart; an increasing body of research confirms the immensity of the task. The King's Fund think-tank said last week that most people in their fifties, on moderate incomes, will be unable to afford to insure for the costs of care in old age.

The fund urged the Government to be much more explicit in warning people about the amount they will need. The alternatives would be to compel people to save, or much more state funding.

A second report last week, by the National Institute of Economic and Social Research, concluded that taxpayers would face a 5 pence increase in the basic rate of tax to improve substantially the deal pensioners receive from the state. These are the sorts of figures that will continue to deter politicians, Labour and Tory, from increasing pensions in line with earnings, rather than inflation. Labour is increasing means-tested support, but this will lead to tension among pensioners. Those who save something, but not enough, will merely see themselves deprived of benefits. The Government has acknowledged the problem and is taking steps to deal with it. It plans to raise the levels at which savings are disregarded for calculating means-tested benefits, but this will be of limited help. Tomorrow's pensioners, struggling with a complex means-tested system may, with hindsight, feel that a large tax increase would have been money well spent.

 The Consumers' Association goes to court tomorrow to seek an award of costs to fund a legal challenge against insurance giant Axa. The CA wants the firm to change the way it plans to distribute its surplus funds, or orphan assets.

An actuary hired by CA has concluded he does not have enough information to judge fully whether the deal is fair or not. What hope is there, then, for ordinary policyholders?

webTitle: Who towers over the West Midlands?

fields.headline: Who towers over the West Midlands?
fields.standfirst: Special report: Rover in crisis
fields.trailText: As the man said, history is first tragedy, then farce. Although Marx never explained what came after farce, seasoned Rover watchers, looking on dismayed from the sidelines, could be forgiven for feeling history is most definitely cyclical.
fields.body:
As the man said, history is first tragedy, then farce. Although Marx never explained what came after farce, seasoned Rover watchers, looking on dismayed from the sidelines, could be forgiven for feeling history is most definitely cyclical.

BMW's decision to walk away from Rover earlier this year represented a new low for the troubled car maker. But the goodwill that followed the Phoenix's consortium's audacious acquisition of the company is now threatened. The past week may have been an embarrassment to Rover, but it may turn out to be much, much more serious than a few red faces in the West Midlands.

It is hard to know where to begin, although where it may end could be more predictable. Last week, two members of the company's supervisory board - Terry Whitmore and Brian Parker - went to great lengths to explain that they were 100 per cent committed to Rover and its management. Only a few days later, it appeared that the pair were not so committed after all. They resigned.

Why they did it seems to be anyone's guess. There have been suggestions that they were unhappy with the direction Rover, under the chairmanship of John Towers, was taking. Parker, in particular, was said to have questioned - along with everyone else in the motor industry - whether Rover's Longbridge plant can produce 200,000 cars a year profitably. Whitmore, a director of engineering firm Mayflower, said he resigned to avoid a conflict of interest - something that wasn't a problem a couple of weeks ago but is now, apparently.

The confusion over whether the two 'advisers' (no one is sure whether they were directors or not) is symptomatic of the muddle at the heart of the company. This is understandable. The Phoenix bid was launched in desperate circumstances at the eleventh hour. In a bid to avoid further publicity gaffes, Rover has hired a whizzy City PR firm to act as its equivalent of a rapid rebuttal unit and emphasise just how much the remaining members in the upper echelons of the company really do like each other very much indeed.

But Rover needs more than eloquence to answer its critics. The company needs to address the urgent question of who is to be the platform partner for its next set of cars.

There have been talks - denied, of course - that Proton might do the job. There are now suggestions that these talks have fallen through. Denied of course. Towers talks about forging a closer relationship with Mayflower, which is a supplier to the company. But Mayflower's shareholders, who have seen the company's value chopped in half this year, are unlikely to be enthralled at the prospect of getting too cosy. After all, none of the world's biggest car companies seem to want to touch it with a driveshaft.

Perhaps Mayflower's shareholders would be more sanguine if it looked as though Rover could deliver on its promise to produce 200,000 cars a year. But it seems some people at the company now doubt this and are suggesting 100,000 as a more sensible figure.

Even Towers, who vehemently rejects this suggestion, seems to be changing his tune. He now says that Rover is not a mass-production car manufacturer, as he originally claimed. No, apparently, it's a 'specialist' manufacturer because the most it will produce of any one model - the Rover 25 - is 85,000 cars. Slippery semantics may obfuscate the problems facing Rover, but they won't solve them.

Oddly, the term 'specialist' evokes the arguments put forward by Alchemy, the venture capital firm that tried to buy Rover before Towers. Jon Moulton, Alchemy's boss, believed the only way Rover could survive would be to turn itself into a niche manufacturer of sports cars. Unless Towers, whose courage over the past six months has rightly won him admiration from all sides, can come up trumps with a platform partner, we are going to hear a lot more of the 'specialist' mantra and a lot less about mass production. It is a worrying thought. John Towers is the new Jon Moulton.

Trouble in relationships and school tests blamed for 'worryingly high' levels of anxiety

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Trouble in relationships and school tests blamed for 'worryingly high' levels of anxiety.
fields.body:
Children as young as eight describe themselves as 'stressed' by relationships and school, new research has revealed.

More than 200 interviews conducted by a team from one of the country's leading psychotherapy institutes found unprecedented levels of stress in Britons of all ages and 'worryingly high' levels in children. More than a quarter of those questioned by the researchers said they were often or always stressed. Half were 'occasionally stressed'.

Most children who reported stress said problems were caused by school, but the other major factor was 'relationships'.

'We were surprised by the extent of the problem, particularly by the amount of stress reported by very young people,' said Professor Stephen Palmer, from City University, in London, who led the study. 'If you had asked eight-year-olds about stress 20 years ago, they would have looked blank. Now they understand the concept and a significant number report experiencing it.'

Nearly a quarter of the under-18s said they often got stressed, and only one in six never suffered from it.

Psychotherapists say that, left unchecked, stress can develop into serious mental illnesses, such as manic depression or bulimia. Stress can also make children cut class and underachieve.

The research raises concern about mental illness in Britain's young. A recent report by the Mental Health Foundation revealed one in five people under 20 experiences psychological problems from anxiety to psychosis.

Research by Young Minds, the mental health charity, shows a huge increase in recent years in the number of children, as young as four, seeking treatment for severe mental health problems.

'Children often reported that they felt stressed by difficulties in forming good relationships with their peers. They had trouble making friends or felt excluded from groups that they wanted to be part of. That was said to be very stressful,' said Palmer.

Children outside two London comprehensive schools last week agreed with the Palmer team's findings. A nine-year-old girl said the most stressful thing she could imagine happening was her 'boyfriend being unfaithful'.

'It's really hard if people you want to be with don't like you,' said one 11-year-old boy. 'That really does your head in.' One nine-year-old boy said he suffered after 'breaking up' with his girlfriend. 'It really freaked me. I was totally stressed out,' he said.

Most said pressure to perform well academically made them anxious. Compulsory testing, introduced in the last decade or so, is also a major source of stress for children.

Caroline Wigmore, the national president of the Professional Association of Teachers, recently said that youngsters are treated 'like products on a conveyor belt' by the stringent testing requirements. School staff report increased stress among pupils. Half the teachers in a recent survey had seen entire classes suffer mass anxiety or panic attacks caused by testing and exams.

Other research suggests that moving up from primary to secondary school and family difficulties are very stressful for children.

Education specialists are turning to a range of anti-stress techniques. A project to improve exam and test results has been launched in West Yorkshire. It aims to help pupils as young as 10 relax under exam pressure, by teaching them self-hypnosis, breathing or meditation. The scheme has proved controversial, however.

'People often get the wrong impression about hypnosis from stage performers,' says Dr Phil Jones, who runs the project. 'It is very safe and has a proven track record.'

In primary schools in London a local council uses yoga to pacify stressed children. Such schemes are welcomed by Palmer, who says stress management should be part of the national curriculum.

His study also reveals high levels of stress among adults in Britain. Eight per cent said they felt 'always stressed' and a further 19 per cent were 'often stressed'. The most common stress factor was work. Next was family.

The Health and Safety Executive estimates stress is costing the economy £6.4 billion a year.

webTitle: Revealed: affair that led Everest pioneer to attempt fatal climb

fields.headline: Revealed: affair that led Everest pioneer to attempt fatal climb
fields.standfirst: Irvine wanted to escape scandal of lover's divorce, reports Ed Douglas
fields.trailText: On 8 June 1924, Andrew Irvine, a 22-year-old Oxford rowing blue, disappeared with George Mallory as they made their final attempt on the summit of Everest. For decades historians have focused on the better-known Mallory, with little interest in the student who died with him, except to ask why Mallory should have chosen to climb Everest with him in the first place.
fields.body:
On 8 June 1924, Andrew Irvine, a 22-year-old Oxford rowing blue, disappeared with George Mallory as they made their final attempt on the summit of Everest. For decades historians have focused on the better-known Mallory, with little interest in the student who died with him, except to ask why Mallory should have chosen to climb Everest with him in the first place.

Volumes have been written about Mallory - 'the Galahad of Everest' - his life, his disappearance and his obsession with climbing the world's highest mountain. Now, 86 years on, a biography of Irvine written by his grand-niece, Julie Summers, is about to redress the balance. It reveals for the first time the undisclosed turmoil in the young man's life - including the affair with his best friend's stepmother - which contributed to his decision to go to Everest to escape the scandal.

For while Irvine was struggling towards the top of Everest, his lover, a former chorus girl named Marjory Thomson, was being divorced by her husband, the steel magnate Harry Summers - Julie Summers's great-grandfather - over their affair.

Irvine had first met Marjory through her stepson Dick, a shy, dark-haired boy whom Irvine had befriended on the fives court at Shrewsbury School.

The relationship was close. Summers had been devastated by the premature death of his natural mother and thrived on his friendship with Irvine. He gave Irvine the nickname 'Sandy', for his shock of fair hair, by which he would be known. As the friendship deepened, Irvine, who grew up in Birkenhead, would spend summers with Summers at the luxurious Cornist Hall in North Wales. Dick later married Irvine's sister Evelyn, Julie Summers's grandmother.

If Harry Summers's wealth impressed the young Irvine, it also impressed 19-year-old Marjory, whose blue eyes and 'charming, sunny personality' completely bowled over Summers, then 52. They were married in 1917, but the marriage would quickly founder as Marjory lost interest in her older husband and soon started to seek out company more her own age.

By now Irvine had gone up to Oxford in 1922, shoe-horned into Merton for his prodigious talent as a rower, having emerged as one of the stars of the 1919 'Peace Regatta' at Henley. He was part of the winning Oxford eight in the 1923 Boat Race.

In the aftermath of a war that had decimated a generation, it is easy to forget the impact of these young sporting heroes - on young women in particular. 'They were almost like gods,' one female spectator wrote of the Oxford crew, men who had just missed serving on the Western front. 'We stood and stared in awe and admiration.'

And although she had first known him as a boy, Sandy's impressive physique, charm and new celebrity made a considerable impact on Marjory Summers. She began an indiscreet affair, driving Irvine to the theatre in her husband's Rolls and taking him for intimate picnics in North Wales. When Irvine was invited on an Oxford University expedition to Spitsbergen, Marjory joined the team for the first leg to Tromsø, Irvine visiting her first-class cabin at night.

Harry Summers became aware of his wife's infidelity when a friend saw Irvine leaving her bedroom in the middle of the night, soon after he returned from Norway. Divorce proceedings were instigated by the millionaire.

Summers speculates that Irvine loved Marjory but was relieved to be out of the relationship, considering Marjory too poor a catch for marriage.

Irvine's other great relationship, with George Mallory, was perhaps the most unlikely of all. Mallory was 38 and hugely experienced. Irvine had barely climbed at all, but had impressed Noel Odell, who had joined the Spitsbergen expedition as geologist. Irvine was practical, able to strip and repair machinery; that and his strength were, to the Mount Everest Committee, more use on Everest than climbing prowess alone.

During the voyage to India, Mallory, desperate to succeed, found his young partner likeable if dull-witted, telling his wife Ruth that Irvine was 'one to rely on, for everything except for conversation'.

Fearless on Everest: The Quest for Sandy Irvine, by Julie Summers, Weidenfeld & Nicolson, £20.

webTitle: Scarlet kisses of death for Oscar's tomb

fields.headline: Scarlet kisses of death for Oscar's tomb
fields.standfirst: Graffiti and candles have damaged Wilde's memorial but lipstick may ruin it forever, his grandson says
fields.trailText: Graffiti and candles have damaged Wilde's memorial but lipstick may ruin it forever, his grandson says.
fields.body:
Oscar Wilde's grave in Paris has put up with a lot in its first century - the flying angel headstone has been castrated (twice), commemorative candles have scorched the front, and multilingual graffiti are regularly scrawled over the tomb. But now it's suffering from its most damaging assault: hundreds of lipstick kisses.

'It's been going on for decades, but the lipstick is just the final straw. Unthinking vulgar people may have defaced Wilde's tomb forever,' said Merlin Holland, Wilde's grandson. 'If these people want to honour Oscar Wilde's memory, then they should leave the bloody tomb alone. It's made me very angry.'

Hundreds of Wilde fans are expected to visit the grave at Père Lachaise cemetery on 30 November to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the death of the poet, dramatist and wit.

Graffiti include: 'You are the best! You can never die!', 'Oscar forever and more smack!', alongside misquoted lines from his poems. Only on the back of the tomb is there elegantly chiselled a poignant verse from 'The Ballad of Reading Gaol':

And alien tears will fill for him
Pity's long broken urn.
For his mourners will be outcast men
And outcasts always mourn.'

Holland, who is partly responsible for the upkeep of the famous tomb with its distinctive angel relief carved by Jacob Epstein, said that the rash of kisses - some hand-painted, others lip-applied - are the biggest threat to its future.

'Marker-pen graffiti can be cleaned off, and anything that is scratched into the tomb can be rubbed down with sandpaper, but lipstick contains animal fats which sink in to the stone and also leave horrible marks. Even the monumental masons aren't sure if that can be removed. At the cemetery's conservation office they just give me Gallic shrugs and say: "What can you do"?'

The only other tomb at Père Lachaise to suffer similar damage has been Jim Morrison's. The Doors' singer was buried there after his heart attack in a Paris hotel room aged 28 in 1971. His grave became covered with colourful graffiti. Morrison fans also damaged neighbouring graves, painting arrows and scribbled notes (such as 'This way to Jim'). Now, though, apart from rolled-up joints and flowers, Morrison's grave is as sombre as that of a Second Empire banker's. Wilde's has become something he would have hated - gaudy.

Wilde died aged 46 in poverty at the Hotel d'Alsace, 13 Rue des Beaux Arts, Paris, and was buried in a tomb paid for by an anonymous 'lady'. The headstone - a winged, naked and initially well-hung angel - was considered so offensive that the cemetery's head keeper castrated it and for several years used the testicles as a paperweight. Genitals were later restored to the angel, but they were stolen during the Sixties. In the early Nineties, Holland and the family of Wilde's literary executor, Robert Ross, paid for restoration work and a plaque at the base of the tomb which reads (in English and French): 'Respect the memory of Oscar Wilde and do not deface this tomb. It is protected by law as an historical monument and was restored in 1992.'

'For years after that people would leave notes and bits of card which were elegant and touching. Then somebody thought it would be a nice idea to kiss the tomb. Then everybody else joined in. I don't know what to do now. Perhaps I should write to L'Oréal asking them to put warnings on their lipsticks. But I've got to find a way to restore the tomb, and it's going to cost money. I don't mind because he's my grandpa and I love him.'

The damage is upsetting to Holland because he is planning to mark the centenary of his grandfather's death with an exhibition at the British Library called 'Oscar Wilde: A Life in Six Acts' which opens on 10 November.

'For the past 20 years I had been compiling information about the whereabouts of manuscripts, photographs, cartoons and lots of Wilde's ephemera. It was a sort of finding list - if you wanted to know where to find the manuscript of his first play Vera, for example, which was inscribed to the actress Ellen Terry, then I knew how to do it. Then three years ago I was asked by the British Library to put an exhibition together about his life. I was in an ideal position to do it.'

On display will be 250 items, including an autographed manuscript of De Profundis, Wilde's long confessional letter from prison to Lord Alfred Douglas, his lover, whose father brought about Wilde's fall from grace. Holland now devotes himself to writing about his grandfather and editing his letters. On Thursday, Fourth Estate publishes The Complete Letters of Oscar Wilde edited by Holland and Rupert Hart-Davis, a sumptuous 1,200-page volume that includes hundreds of hitherto unpublished letters.

The book includes a letter to Douglas. Written in March 1893 from London's Savoy Hotel, where he was staying in a £49 a week suite, it describes his financial difficulties and his fondness for 'Bosie' who was, for Wilde, 'red and yellow wine'. The letter was used as prosecution evidence at Wilde's trial for gross indecency.

'I'm sure he could have said that this letter was just poetic licence, written to a young friend. It was only when the prosecution started to drag in the rent boys that that line of defence collapsed,' said Holland, who is now writing a book about Wilde's posthumous reputation and the squabbles between his friends.

webTitle: Observer review: John Maynard Keynes by Robert Skidelsky

fields.headline: When Keynes was king
fields.standfirst: Robert Skidelsky brings his mammoth biography of John Maynard Keynes to a close with Fighting for Britain
fields.trailText: Robert Skidelsky brings his mammoth biography of John Maynard Keynes to a close with Fighting for Britain
fields.body:
John Maynard Keynes: Fighting for Britain 1937-1946
Robert Skidelsky
Macmillan £25, pp624
Buy it at BOL

Robert Skidelsky has pulled it off. He has devoted 20 years to his life of John Maynard Keynes and, with this, the third volume of a biography of Proustian proportions, he has demonstrated that the whole enterprise was worth every ounce of the struggle.

The first volume, Hopes Betrayed, took us to 1920, and Keynes's The Economic Consequences of the Peace, whose concerns about the inadequacies of the Treaty of Versailles proved all too well founded. The Economic Consequences made Keynes world-famous even before the launch of Keynesian economics. And, as Skidelsky wrote at the end of volume one: 'In 1925, the world-famous economist would marry a world-famous ballerina in a blaze of publicity.'

Hopes Betrayed was published in 1983, a time when the monetarist and extreme laissez-faire doctrines then prevailing indicated that the Keynesian legacy had been betrayed. The next volume - The Economist As Saviour 1920 - 1937 - came out in 1992 and had to compete with Maynard Keynes - An Economist's Biography by D.E. Moggridge, a distinguished professor of economics.

Problematically, Moggridge took the story right up to the death of Keynes in 1946, whereas Skidelsky, necessarily but irritatingly, stopped a long way short. Nevertheless, there was a lot of good stuff in volume two, and what especially captured the imagination was the genuine love story between Keynes and that world-famous ballerina, the Russian Lydia Lopokova.

The great thing about this third book is that Skidelsky has drawn on Roy Harrod (the first notable Keynes biographer), Moggridge and a veritable treasure trove of official and unofficial documents, not least the archives of the Keynes family and his college, King's, Cambridge. Harrod, who had worked with - and sometimes against - Keynes knew he was, in a sense, contributing to a later biography such as Skidelsky's when he wrote that, if he had made mistakes, 'through lack of sufficient perspective, these can be corrected by future students. My task has been to save them from mistakes, which there would later be no one to correct'.

Skidelsky explained the background to Keynes's General Theory in volume two. As he wrote then, the trouble with the classical economists was that they 'lacked a theory of effective demand. The fatal flaw in the system he [Keynes] pointed out lay in the variability of spending relative to earnings... the result was that the market system was liable to collapse into prolonged depression'. But Keynes's purpose was always to make the market system work, not to replace it by communism or socialism. He was both a Liberal and a liberal, with a strong sense of community, and of the need for the government to fill crucial gaps. As Skidelsky says: 'His ideal was a mix of private and public patronage.'

As Skidelsky shows us in this final volume, Keynes may have been a genius, but he was also a member of the human race, absorbed as much by the detailed management of his small Sussex farm as by high finance, serious economics and the arts. He was also battling against illness for much of this period, whether as 'entrepreneur' for the Keynesian Revolution or as - the major theme of the final volume - Britain's leading general in the financial war against America.

For that is what it was. As Skidelsky puts it, while we were all fighting Germany (and the US had not yet entered the war) 'the Americans tried to use Lend-Lease as a lever to destroy Britain's pre-war financial and trading system, based on the sterling area and imperial preference'. From early on, Keynes, effectively Britain's chief negotiator with the Americans over paying for the war and preparing the postwar settlement, had as a goal 'the retention by us of enough assets to leave us capable of independent action'.

Skidelsky argues that 'America's main war aim, after the defeat of Germany and Japan, was the liquidisation of the British Empire'. One of the greatest ironies was that Harry Dexter White, the senior US Treasury official with whom Keynes did so much negotiation over the postwar economic order and the difficult US postwar loan to Britain, was effectively a Soviet agent. Skidelsky gently puts it as a 'possibility' that 'White's pro-Soviet stance led him to advocate policies designed to boost the international position of the Soviet Union at the expense of Britain and Western Europe'.

A lot of good it did. The Soviet Union did not ratify the Bretton Woods Agreement and that was 'the real start of the Cold War'. In the end, the wartime ally to whom White passed information became the 'Evil Empire' and Western Europe needed to be rescued economically by the Marshall Plan.

The UK was still servicing and paying off the postwar American loan in the Sixties and Seventies. However great Keynes's intellectual powers, the US owned the postwar world. As Skidelsky says, Keynes defended the terms of the loan and the shape of the Bretton Woods Agreement as 'a reasonable compromise between two great nations with the same goal: to restore a liberal world economy'.

People tend to forget how hard Keynes had to fight to get his ideas accepted. What astonishes the modern reader is how much he managed to fit into his life, including, while all the wartime negotiations were going on, with frequent trips to Washington, the creation of what is now known as the Arts Council.

Skidelsky may feel that Keynes's followers pushed his economics to the limit - for Keynes, 'demand management' was more about variations in public-sector investment than discretionary tax changes - but, after a brief monetarist interlude, the Keynesian view that governments can intervene successfully to stabilise the economy is back in vogue, even if they prefer to do it via central banks and interest rates. It should never be forgotten that hoarding, nationally and internationally, can damage your economic health.
fields.bodyText: John Maynard Keynes: Fighting for Britain 1937-1946 Robert Skidelsky Macmillan £25, pp624 Buy it at BOL Robert Skidelsky has pulled it off. He has devoted 20 years to his life of John Maynard Keynes and, with this, the third volume of a biography of Proustian proportions, he has demonstrated that the whole enterprise was worth every ounce of the struggle. The first volume, Hopes Betrayed, took us to 1920, and Keynes's The Economic Consequences of the Peace, whose concerns about the inadequacies of the Treaty of Versailles proved all too well founded. The Economic Consequences made Keynes world-famous even before the launch of Keynesian economics. And, as Skidelsky wrote at the end of volume one: 'In 1925, the world-famous economist would marry a world-famous ballerina in a blaze of publicity.' Hopes Betrayed was published in 1983, a time when the monetarist and extreme laissez-faire doctrines then prevailing indicated that the Keynesian legacy had been betrayed. The next volume - The Economist As Saviour 1920 - 1937 - came out in 1992 and had to compete with Maynard Keynes - An Economist's Biography by D.E. Moggridge, a distinguished professor of economics. Problematically, Moggridge took the story right up to the death of Keynes in 1946, whereas Skidelsky, necessarily but irritatingly, stopped a long way short. Nevertheless, there was a lot of good stuff in volume two, and what especially captured the imagination was the genuine love story between Keynes and that world-famous ballerina, the Russian Lydia Lopokova. The great thing about this third book is that Skidelsky has drawn on Roy Harrod (the first notable Keynes biographer), Moggridge and a veritable treasure trove of official and unofficial documents, not least the archives of the Keynes family and his college, King's, Cambridge. Harrod, who had worked with - and sometimes against - Keynes knew he was, in a sense, contributing to a later biography such as Skidelsky's when he wrote that, if he had made mistakes, 'through lack of sufficient perspective, these can be corrected by future students. My task has been to save them from mistakes, which there would later be no one to correct'. Skidelsky explained the background to Keynes's General Theory in volume two. As he wrote then, the trouble with the classical economists was that they 'lacked a theory of effective demand. The fatal flaw in the system he [Keynes] pointed out lay in the variability of spending relative to earnings... the result was that the market system was liable to collapse into prolonged depression'. But Keynes's purpose was always to make the market system work, not to replace it by communism or socialism. He was both a Liberal and a liberal, with a strong sense of community, and of the need for the government to fill crucial gaps. As Skidelsky says: 'His ideal was a mix of private and public patronage.' As Skidelsky shows us in this final volume, Keynes may have been a genius, but he was also a member of the human race, absorbed as much by the detailed management of his small Sussex farm as by high finance, serious economics and the arts. He was also battling against illness for much of this period, whether as 'entrepreneur' for the Keynesian Revolution or as - the major theme of the final volume - Britain's leading general in the financial war against America. For that is what it was. As Skidelsky puts it, while we were all fighting Germany (and the US had not yet entered the war) 'the Americans tried to use Lend-Lease as a lever to destroy Britain's pre-war financial and trading system, based on the sterling area and imperial preference'. From early on, Keynes, effectively Britain's chief negotiator with the Americans over paying for the war and preparing the postwar settlement, had as a goal 'the retention by us of enough assets to leave us capable of independent action'. Skidelsky argues that 'America's main war aim, after the defeat of Germany and Japan, was the liquidisation of the British Empire'. One of the greatest ironies was that Harry Dexter White, the senior US Treasury official with whom Keynes did so much negotiation over the postwar economic order and the difficult US postwar loan to Britain, was effectively a Soviet agent. Skidelsky gently puts it as a 'possibility' that 'White's pro-Soviet stance led him to advocate policies designed to boost the international position of the Soviet Union at the expense of Britain and Western Europe'. A lot of good it did. The Soviet Union did not ratify the Bretton Woods Agreement and that was 'the real start of the Cold War'. In the end, the wartime ally to whom White passed information became the 'Evil Empire' and Western Europe needed to be rescued economically by the Marshall Plan. The UK was still servicing and paying off the postwar American loan in the Sixties and Seventies. However great Keynes's intellectual powers, the US owned the postwar world. As Skidelsky says, Keynes defended the terms of the loan and the shape of the Bretton Woods Agreement as 'a reasonable compromise between two great nations with the same goal: to restore a liberal world economy'. People tend to forget how hard Keynes had to fight to get his ideas accepted. What astonishes the modern reader is how much he managed to fit into his life, including, while all the wartime negotiations were going on, with frequent trips to Washington, the creation of what is now known as the Arts Council. Skidelsky may feel that Keynes's followers pushed his economics to the limit - for Keynes, 'demand management' was more about variations in public-sector investment than discretionary tax changes - but, after a brief monetarist interlude, the Keynesian view that governments can intervene successfully to stabilise the economy is back in vogue, even if they prefer to do it via central banks and interest rates. It should never be forgotten that hoarding, nationally and internationally, can damage your economic health.

webTitle: Observer review: The Means of Escape by Penelope Fitzgerald

fields.headline: Small but perfectly formed
fields.standfirst: Penelope Fitzgerald's last collection of short stories, The Means of Escape, shows her at the top of her form
fields.trailText: Penelope Fitzgerald's last collection of short stories, The Means of Escape, shows her at the top of her form
fields.body:
The Means of Escape
Penelope Fitzgerald
Flamingo £12.99, pp116
Buy it at BOL

This exquisite, posthumous collection of stories isn't so unmannerly to defy reviewing nor even to disarm it. There's charm here, but it's closely allied to wit and shares with it a piercing quality. Penelope Fitzgerald's swansong simply shows up reviewing as an inefficient mechanism. A 1,000-word piece like this one is easily a thirtieth as long as the compact book itself, but the best it can hope for is to avoid the basely analytical, the slackly descriptive, the excessively quoting. Only in fiction can compression still leave the air in. All of this writer's novels are miniatures, which makes it more surprising (rather than less) that a further reduction of scale should result in work so readable, and so sharply tender.

Fitzgerald, who died this year aged 83, had a famously late start - she didn't publish her first novel until she was 60. Her earlier books methodically used material from her life (running a bookshop, say, or working for the BBC, living with her family on a Thames barge), but then her imagination started roving further afield. Her talent changed its diet.

Four of her nine novels were short-listed for the Booker Prize - an extraordinary statistic - and one won it (Offshore in 1979). There was no such recognition in 1995 for her last novel, The Blue Flower, her delicate evocation of love in eighteenth-century Germany, though there might be said to have been a vacancy on that year's slimline, five-book short list. The book was much admired, nevertheless, and went on to win the American National Book Critics' Circle Award.

Half the eight stories in The Means of Escape are set outside these islands, and more than half have period settings, lightly but authoritatively managed. The modern and domestic stories are, if anything, the less substantial - even if insubstantiality is part of the point of one such story with a contemporary London setting ('The Axe'), specifically the inadequacy of institutional language to accommodate reality.

An office manager writes a memo to his boss about the actual effect of redundancy (the axe of the title, though the story has an element of horror) on a long-term employee. After a paragraph, the tone of voice modulates: 'From this point on I feel able to write more freely, it being well understood, at office-managerial level, that you do not read more than the first two sentences of any given report. You believe that anything which cannot be put into two sentences is not worth attending to, a piece of wisdom which you usually attribute to the late Lord Beaverbrook.'

When a mobile phone rings from the depths of a great beige handbag in 'Not Shown', the detail seems less present to author or reader than the nuances of Muslim teetotalism during the late Ottoman Empire in 'The Prescription' (raki-drinking being permissible on the grounds that it had not been invented in the days of the Prophet), or the glimpses of prison life in Van Diemen's Land, before it became Tasmania, in the book's title story.

A strong authorial persona surfaces unpredictably, one which would be actively brusque without its hint of geniality: '...a remote country place... don't picture a shack, though' (from 'At Hiruharama'); 'What brother or sister likes being asked such questions?' ('Desideratus'); 'Sound is always said to carry well over water. This didn't' ('Beehernz'); 'She belonged to the tribe of torturers. Why pretend they don't exist?' ('Not Shown'). It's clear that Fitzgerald enjoys an absolute authority, but prefers to see what happens when she reins it in.

She has a taste for aphorisms that hark back to Jane Austen, and could occasionally be mistaken for her coinings: 'In time... sharpness might turn into nothing worse than industry, which is harmless' ('The Prescription'), for instance. Or another from the title story: 'The weight of unexpended affection which is one of a woman's greatest inconveniences.' This melancholy formulation isn't applied to the story's main character, Alice Godley, the daughter of the rector of St George's Church, Hobart, in the 1850s, but then Fitzgerald's touch is so sure that it doesn't need to be.

In a melodramatic opening that may owe something to Great Expectations, Alice is surprised, while practising the organ, by an escaped convict, hooded and rancid-smelling, advancing on her from the shadows and demanding her aid. The situation is one of menace, but Alice, with her brittle dialogue, seeks to turn it to social comedy. When he confesses: 'I was a poisoner', she replies: 'I should not have thought you were old enough to be married.'

Fitzgerald is bold enough, when the convict takes off his hood, to describe him not at all, providing only the sufficient sentence: 'Alice looked at him directly for the first time.' That she immediately gives him permission to call her 'Miss Alice' may indicate a satisfactory appearance, or it may be that in her situation any risk is better than none. She has a friend, Aggie, with whom she has 'settled on the age of 45 to go irredeemably cranky', and Aggie doesn't denounce her folly. Instead, she answers, from the same fund of reading - penny dreadfuls, romances - 'Did a sudden strong warmth spring up between the two of you?' It's not just convicts who want to escape in this comedy with sadness hemming it in.

In a number of stories, a character seeks to impose himself on his surroundings - a student of painting by using a local girl as a model; the deputy artistic director of a music festival by tracking down a long-retired conductor; a Greek boy working menially in a dispensary by trying to pick up the pharmacist's trade by stealth. These efforts are mixed successes at best, but the experience is not disappointment for the reader.

In a pattern most perfectly displayed in the little masterpiece 'At Hiruharama', a minor character suddenly expands near the story's end, to the point of displacing the apparent protagonists. In moves of formal neatness and emotional subtlety, the characters are destabilised, but the story never loses its balance.

fields.headline: Reflections of enlightenment
fields.trailText: What is it about the eighteenth century?
fields.body:
What is it about the eighteenth century? This past publishing season has seen the publication of an extraordinary range of exceptional titles with eighteenth-century themes.

First, there was Roy Porter's study of the English Enlightenment (Allen Lane £25), described by The Observer 's reviewer Philip Hensher as 'a brilliant, lucid and admirable book'.

Next, there was Lucy Moore's Amphibious Thing (Viking £20), her biographical study of John, Lord Hervey, a Whig peer chiefly remembered as the butt of Alexander Pope's celebrated and venomous verse portrait: 'Satire or Sense, alas! can Sporus feel?/ Who breaks a Butterfly upon a Wheel?'

Hardly had that arrived in the bookshops than up popped Robert L. Mack's life of Thomas Gray (Yale £25), a minor poet anthologised into immortality for his 'Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard'.

Finally, this week will see the long-awaited publication of Adam Sisman's fascinating study of James Boswell's composition of his life of Samuel Johnson, Boswell's Presumptuous Task (Viking £17.99). No doubt there are other volumes I have overlooked, but these are certainly salient.

Others may have better ideas, but I am inclined to date the vogue for books about the Age of Reason to the sensational success of Dava Sobel's Longitude and Amanda Foreman's Georgiana Duchess of Devonshire . Both resurrected for popular consumption two forgotten and rather unfortunate characters from the English past.

The story of an obscure amateur clockmaker's lifelong struggle to solve the age-old problem of calculating a ship's nautical position against the hostility of the scientific and naval establishments was more than matched by the tragic story of the royal consort who fell from grace with the heir to the throne.

Both told a good tale well (no one ever went broke repeating a good story) and both were surprise bestsellers.

Lucy Moore's Amphibious Thing is a highly intelligent, supremely enjoyable biographical study of the life and times of a celebrated rake, but I don't imagine it will become a bestseller in the Amanda Foreman mould.

Hervey was handsome, witty, cultivated, elegant and worldly, but he is emphatically not a character many readers will want to spend much time with. The seamy side of his personal story that Lucy Moore investigates, his long and mysterious homoerotic relationship with Stephen Fox, will excite the interest of a minority, but it lacks the mass appeal of the spurned wife, Georgiana or the stolid underdog, John Harrison.

More intriguing, however, is the brilliant picture Lucy Moore paints of eighteenth-century aristocratic life in all its brittle artifice. The more you read about the dandyism and debauchery of London in the age of Sir Robert Walpole, the more you are struck by the parallels with our own time.

There is the same rampant capitalism; the same indifference to religious belief; the same obsession with fame and its half-sister, gossip; and the same public grandeur cheek by jowl with private squalor. What's more, where England under the Stuarts seems quite extraordinarily remote, the recently unified Hanoverian kingdom is one in which we can imagine living.

The language of Pope, Johnson and Sheridan, though sometimes encrusted with the archaisms of 'Zounds' and 'Gadzooks', is more or less familiar; the Newtonian universe is not entirely redundant; many great Georgian buildings still play an important part in our imaginative landscape, from the restored splendours of Somerset House to the claustrophobic domesticity of Downing Street.

Finally,the way in which Hervey, the supreme courtier, operated as 'one of the four or five most influential people in the country' reminded me of no one so much as our own contemporary political controversialist, the Prince of Darkness himself, Peter Mandelson.

Perhaps, at some deep, half-conscious level, the origin of the appetite for these books lies in watching our own times reflected in the cracked mirror of the past. I am certainly not the first to suggest that in the strange supremacy of New Labour we have witnessed the return of the Whigs.

robert.mcrum@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Observer review: The Shape of Snakes, The Last Precinct and Listen to the Silence

fields.headline: Has Kay Scarpetta solved her last case?
fields.standfirst: Minette Walters is on top form, Patricia Cornwell gives her readers cause for concern, and Marcia Muller shows that she has lost none of her storytelling skill
fields.trailText: Minette Walters is on top form, Patricia Cornwell gives her readers cause for concern, and Marcia Muller shows that she has lost none of her storytelling skill
fields.body:
The Shape of Snakes
Minette Walters
Macmillan £16.99, pp375
Buy it at BOL

The Last Precinct
Patricia Cornwell
LittleBrown £10.99, pp449
Buy it at BOL

Listen to the Silence
Marcia Muller
Women's Press £6.99, pp289
Buy it at BOL

Minette Walters's seventh novel, The Shape of Snakes, is, quite simply, a tour de force. An ambitiously structured who- and whydunnit, narrated by a woman, Mrs Ranelagh, who, in 1978, found a neighbour dying in the rain-soaked gutter in front of her house, it succeeds magnificently at almost every level. Walters's psychological thrillers have always combined compassion and a strong social conscience with a ruthless ability to create unease, suspense and, sometimes, horror.

The Shape of Snakes is angrily concerned with racism and our attitude to mental conditions: the dying woman, Annie Butts, is black and suffers from Tourette syndrome, whose symptoms include body jerking, talking to yourself and unwillingly spouting obscenities. Those around her, seeing only the symptoms and ignorant of the cause, nickname her 'Mad Annie'.

Although the coroner decided Annie's death was accidental, Mrs Ranelagh has spent 20 years while living abroad trying to prove she was murdered by racist neighbours. Now back in England to confront suspects and witnesses, she reveals that most people on whom her inquiry touches, including her husband, have guilty secrets and the reader finds the chilling reasons for Mrs Ranelagh's own psychological quirks; seldom has a narrator started out more unreliable.

Walters reconstructs Ranelagh's past investigation in the form of emails, letters, newspaper cuttings, transcripts of official reports and even, playfully, photographs, which I suspect come out of the Walters's family album circa 1978. There are perhaps a couple of particularly nasty but not-quite-convincing twists too many but otherwise this is a superb, compelling exploration of guilt and revenge.

Walters's work has always adapted pretty well to television. Surprisingly, only this year, 10 years after Dr Kay Scarpetta made her first, trailblazing appearance in Post Mortem, has Patricia Cornwell's bestselling series been optioned for the movies.

The Last Precinct is Cornwell's eleventh Scarpetta novel and it's hard not to conclude that somewhere along the way the author has lost the plot. She's still unequalled at chilling us with the forensic detail of what suffering the human body can and cannot endure and nobody knows her way round a path lab better; as Val McDermid once remarked, most of Cornwell's regular readers could probably confidently perform autopsies blindfold by now. And The Last Precinct is a significant book in that it places Scarpetta squarely at a crossroads. Once it gets going - and it takes a while - it's a page-turning, bravura piece of writing. But I just don't buy it.

The Last Precinct is billed as a sequel to Black Notice, which ended with Scarpetta narrowly surviving the attack of the werewolf Jean-Baptiste Chandonne. But it's more a reworking of that and a re-examination of other telling episodes in Scarpetta's recent past, from the death of her long-time lover, Benton, to the murder of her antagonist, Dianne Bray, as Virginia's chief medical examiner finds herself under investigation for murder. Unfortunately, Cornwell's ambitious attempt to rework those recent incidents involves plotting that in a writer first acclaimed for her realism becomes increasingly ridiculous.

It doesn't help that even when Scarpetta is on the ropes and hounded at every turn, she still manages to come across as humourless, snobbish and holier than thou, characteristics that have been getting more pronounced with each new book. I understand that Scarpetta's impeccable taste is a deliberate counter to the gruesome requirements of her job as a forensic pathologist, but Cornwell can handle it so crassly. So there's always time, in the middle of the horrors and angst, to advise primly on the best olive oil or Italian wines to buy.

The gang's all here in The Last Precinct including, of course, Captain Pete Marino, even grouchier than usual, and Aunt Kay's niece, the gung-ho, possibly homicidal Lucy. Lucy has always seemed to me essentially a plot device rather than a character - she's like Chandler's man with a gun sent through the door as a way of moving the plot along. So her abrupt change in circumstances near the opening of the novel might be ludicrous but does open all sorts of possibilities for where the series can now go. Back on track would be good.

Marcia Muller made Patricia Cornwell possible. Just before Paretsky and Grafton came along, Muller created the first hard-boiled woman detective in her debut Sharon McCone novel. Now, 20 years on, female protagonists are ubiquitous in mystery fiction. Listen To The Silence shows that Muller has lost none of her taut storytelling skills as her series has progressed.

There's a sense in which all mystery fiction is an exploration of the family and here McCone, who is part native American, investigates a family secret - her own family, her own secret. On the death of her father, she discovers that she is adopted. In tracing her birth parents, she goes deep into native American country and gets embroiled in a family feud and in violence past and present. Impeccably written and fast moving, this is straight down-the-line mystery writing at its best.

Surprisingly, only this year, 10 years after Dr Kay Scarpetta made her first, trailblazing appearance in Post Mortem, has Patricia Cornwell's bestselling series been optioned for the movies. The Last Precinct is Cornwell's eleventh Scarpetta novel and it's hard not to conclude that somewhere along the way the author has lost the plot. She's still unequalled at chilling us with the forensic detail of what suffering the human body can and cannot endure and nobody knows her way round a path lab better; as Val McDermid once remarked, most of Cornwell's regular readers could probably confidently perform autopsies blindfold by now. And The Last Precinct is a significant book in that it places Scarpetta squarely at a crossroads. Once it gets going - and it takes a while - it's a page-turning, bravura piece of writing. But I just don't buy it. The Last Precinct is billed as a sequel to Black Notice, which ended with Scarpetta narrowly surviving the attack of the werewolf Jean-Baptiste Chandonne. But it's more a reworking of that and a re-examination of other telling episodes in Scarpetta's recent past, from the death of her long-time lover, Benton, to the murder of her antagonist, Dianne Bray, as Virginia's chief medical examiner finds herself under investigation for murder. Unfortunately, Cornwell's ambitious attempt to rework those recent incidents involves plotting that in a writer first acclaimed for her realism becomes increasingly ridiculous. It doesn't help that even when Scarpetta is on the ropes and hounded at every turn, she still manages to come across as humourless, snobbish and holier than thou, characteristics that have been getting more pronounced with each new book. I understand that Scarpetta's impeccable taste is a deliberate counter to the gruesome requirements of her job as a forensic pathologist, but Cornwell can handle it so crassly. So there's always time, in the middle of the horrors and angst, to advise primly on the best olive oil or Italian wines to buy. The gang's all here in The Last Precinct including, of course, Captain Pete Marino, even grouchier than usual, and Aunt Kay's niece, the gung-ho, possibly homicidal Lucy. Lucy has always seemed to me essentially a plot device rather than a character - she's like Chandler's man with a gun sent through the door as a way of moving the plot along. So her abrupt change in circumstances near the opening of the novel might be ludicrous but does open all sorts of possibilities for where the series can now go. Back on track would be good. Marcia Muller made Patricia Cornwell possible. Just before Paretsky and Grafton came along, Muller created the first hard-boiled woman detective in her debut Sharon McCone novel. Now, 20 years on, female protagonists are ubiquitous in mystery fiction. Listen To The Silence shows that Muller has lost none of her taut storytelling skills as her series has progressed. There's a sense in which all mystery fiction is an exploration of the family and here McCone, who is part native American, investigates a family secret - her own family, her own secret. On the death of her father, she discovers that she is adopted. In tracing her birth parents, she goes deep into native American country and gets embroiled in a family feud and in violence past and present. Impeccably written and fast moving, this is straight down-the-line mystery writing at its best.

webTitle: Pineapples and Pomegranates by Paul Muldoon

fields.headline: Pineapples and Pomegranates
fields.trailText:
To think that, as a boy of thirteen, I would grapple

with my first pineapple...
fields.body:
In Memory of Yehuda Amichai

To think that, as a boy of thirteen, I would grapple

with my first pineapple,

its exposed breast

setting itself as another test

of my will-power, knowing in my bones

that it stood for something other than itself alone

while having absolutely no sense

of its being a world-wide symbol of munificence.

Munificence - right? Not munitions, if you understand

where I'm coming from. As if the open hand

might, for once, put paid

to the hand-grenade

in one corner of the planet.

I'm talking about pineapples - right? - not pomegranates.

webTitle: Observer review: Demonology by Rick Moody

fields.headline: A master of disguises
fields.standfirst: Rick Moody goes beyond virtuosity in his collection of short stories, Demonology
fields.trailText: Rick Moody goes beyond virtuosity in his collection of short stories, Demonology
fields.body:
Demonology
Rick Moody
Faber £9.99, pp256
Buy it at BOL

'I should fictionalise it more,' says the narrator of the final story of Demonology, a brief, spare story that loops round and back to the collection's beginning, dwelling as both do upon a specific loss. 'I should conceal myself... I should let artifice create an elegant surface, I should make the events orderly... I shouldn't clutter a narrative with fragments.'

Here, in the title story, Rick Moody is apparently offering us a 'real' voice, stripped by pain of all its brilliant disguises. It is about the death of a sister, whose life he offers to us in snapshots: her childhood, her motherhood, her sudden death. 'I should have a better ending,' he says. 'I shouldn't say her life was short and often sad, I shouldn't say she had her demons, as I do too...'

It is tempting to think of this beautiful and melancholy coda to Rick Moody's stories as the appearance of the author, stepping out of the shadows at last, particularly since the first story in the collection is also, though much more obliquely, about the death of a beloved sister. Tempting to think that at last we hear his true voice, emerging from the multiple echo- chambers of the previous stories; speaking finally with a well-earned simplicity.

But it won't do, for Rick Moody - cool, hip and full of flair, a key figure among the group of the new American writers - is the master of many voices. Demonology acts as a showcase for his extraordinary virtuosity, a range that stretches from alto to deep bass. He can write as a mother and ageing actress. He can write a story that purports to be the introduction to the boxed set of one Wilkie Fahnstock, a nicely-tuned jest that edges, in the last few lines, into something else. He can write a strange, modern fairy-tale, as he does in 'Pan's Fair Throng'. He can evoke two entire lives in a few pages, or stretch a handful of minutes into a long, slow movement - going down, not out.

He likes to play with language, mimicking and mocking academic, Latinate dryness, or the windy rhetoric of postmodern art critics. He loves to produce the voices inside the head - the voices that aren't heard normally, the private monologues that we hold back from the world. He loves conversations that are slangy and colloquial but then become sudden poetry, the ordinary made beautiful, in the same way that the deprivations of American urban life can for a few lines turn into beauty.

He has an unerring feel for language, a delicacy of touch and effect. He is especially good at transitions - from humour to grief, mockery to sweetness.

He can write as a dysfunctional young man, as he does in 'The Mansion on a Hill' - a man who first introduces himself to us wearing a chicken mask, which he has to put on to advertise the Hot Bird Café (Bucket of Drumsticks $2.99), and who later winds up working for a company that arranges weddings. Romance to order, the more expensive the better; the staff lay on dreams of happiness ever after, while spying on the couples, discovering grooms kissing bridesmaids, fathers in the broom cupboard with another man's wife.

The narrator is busy saying no to life, to dreams - his story is a monologue addressed to 'Sis'. But Sis died in a car crash; he carries her ashes around in a canister and ends by tossing them (ash rises in a cloud of grey dust; the small pieces of bones drop earthwards) upon the man she was going to marry, now happily saying 'I do' to another. The combination of pain and farce, satire and nostalgia, makes the story strange and unexpected. Subjects collide; there are things in the depths that work their way onto the surface narrative.

In the longest story, 'Carnival Time', Moody gives us two voices: the first a woman trying to get into her own house where she is about to host the 'opening' to a fatuous new art gallery she and her uncommitted boyfriend are starting, but scared back by a couple of barking stray dogs. The second voice belongs to her absent, hopeless boyfriend.

The story is full of the sense of missing: not only do they miss each other, they miss their lives. Happiness comes to them in retrospect. Love passes them by, like a train they don't board. They are lonely, but don't see each other. They can't say the words. They can't rise to the moment. Nothing happens the way it was meant to. They are always looking in the other direction.

Missing is one of Moody's themes - for under all the acts of attention-seeking virtuosity in Demonology there is a kind of unifying sensibility that turns the collection from a dazzling performance into something much more enduring.

Love is difficult, if not impossible. People are haunted by their need for tenderness and haunted, too, by a past they didn't know was important until it was gone. Hands don't meet, gestures aren't seen, words miss their target. Not Moody's, though.

fields.headline: The great entertainer
fields.standfirst: Grand themes may be interesting but a strong plot is what matters
fields.trailText: Grand themes may be interesting but a strong plot is what matters
fields.body:
Observer: What's Code to Zero about?

Ken Follett: It's about a scientist who loses his memory, always a great basis for a plot. I wanted to write about scientists. So then I had to find a moment in history when what scientists were doing was very important on the world stage. The obvious one was the invention of the nuclear bomb, which I rejected because it was too obvious. Then I decided that a forgotten episode from the space race would be good to write about.

At the time, the launching of the first American satellite was hugely important to everybody, though it's since been overshadowed by the moon landings. I knew the story was viable when I discovered that during the Fifties the CIA had a very expensive research programme to try and find drugs that would induce amnesia. Then I realised it was possible for this man to have lost his memory because somebody made him lose his memory.

Obs: Did you do much research into memory loss?

KF: The actual treatment which causes the hero to lose his memory takes place offstage. If that had not been so then I would have needed to do a lot more research. I did research into how people lose their memories and what bits they lose. Memory is not monolithic and Luke in this story never gets his memory back. He discovers it all. That becomes an important point in the drama. One of the ways in which he figures out who he is is by thinking about what he remembers and what he has forgotten.

Obs: Was it a problem having the whole book set in America of the late Fifties?

KF: If I had made dreadful mistakes I assume my American editors would have corrected me, but in fact there weren't many of those. I did persist in saying 'car park' instead of 'parking lot' in the first draft but that kind of thing is very easy to deal with. American speech and American culture is so familiar that it's actually not difficult.

Obs: There are some very big themes - memory, betrayal, love, trust. Do you find that the demands of writing a thriller are at odds with your interest in these themes?

KF: You know, I'm really much more interested in writing the thriller than in those themes. The suspense, the structuring of the novel in such a way that the reader will always be wondering what's going to happen next, is actually the centre of my interest as a writer.

Obs: So you are not one of those genre writers who yearns to win the Booker?

KF: No indeed, no. Trust, loyalty and betrayal are quite interesting, but I don't write books to explore those grand themes. I write books to entertain and amuse and fascinate people. If there's an issue of loyalty and betrayal in the story it's not my main concern.

Obs: I think you want to show that behind these big public events there is a private drama.

KF: That's because private dramas are always so much more interesting than public dramas, especially in a novel.

Obs: You don't have any anxiety about being characterised as a genre writer?

KF: No, no, not at all. I also read across quite a wide range. Funnily enough so do my readers.

Obs: Did you always want to be a writer?

KF: I didn't. When I was 18 I wanted to be a captain of industry. At some point I wanted to be in advertising. I wanted to be a missionary. And then I decided to become a journalist. I started with the South Wales Echo and then I worked for the London Evening News . Quite soon I began to realise that my future was in books rather than in newspapers.

Obs: So you were writing in the evening and at weekends and then the first one took off?

KF: No, no, it was the eleventh one that took off. The Eye of the Needle was my eleventh book.

Obs: Who were your favourite writers when you were growing up ?

KF: At the age of 12 I was allowed to go the adult part of the public library because I'd read pretty much all the books in the children's library. One of the first books I read was Casino Royale by Ian Fleming. I was absolutely blown away, despite the fact that I really didn't understand a lot of it. I was captivated by the character of James Bond and the life he led. That's obviously been a big influence on the kind of books that I write.

Obs: Do you write quickly?

KF: I spend a lot of time planning. My normal cycle is a book every two years. The first year is planning. Part of that is research but it's quite a small part. Most of it is figuring out the structure of the plot. This book takes place over a period of about three days, so I think the idea of having the chapter headings as times rather than chapter one and chapter two adds to that sense of urgency. I think it works.

Obs: And do you prefer books to politics?

KF: Oh, very much.

Obs: Has the row reported in The Observer died down?

KF: I don't think so. I think it'll rumble on as long as Peter Mandelson is an important figure in the Labour Party. I haven't said much to the newspapers for three months, but now Geoffrey Robinson has brought out his memoirs.

Obs: Have you read them?

KF: No, I haven't - I've read about them. You know, when that row blows over then there'll be something else.

Obs: New Labour's not very literary.

KF: No, I suppose that's true. As far as I know none of those guys reads a great deal. Mind you, they're too busy. Harold Macmillan used to read novels, didn't he?

Obs: Jane Austen and Anthony Trollope.

KF: John Major said his all time favourite novel was The Small House at Allington. Whether he actually had time to read while he was Prime Minister I very much doubt. I don't think they do anymore. I think it's just got more high pressure than ever. I bet Macmillan was the last Prime Minister to regularly read fiction.

Obs: As far as you know you're not the favourite reading of Tony or Gordon or Peter?

KF: Every now and again an MP or Cabinet Minister is asked for his favourite read and if they mention me then I always wonder whether it's just out of comradeship. So I don't really know.

 Ken Follett became an international bestseller with Eye of the Needle (1978). His latest in a string of popular thrillers is Code to Zero (Macmillan £16.99)
