webTitle: Observer review: Tank by Patrick Wright

fields.headline: The toy that's no laughing matter
fields.standfirst: Patrick Wright looks at the development of the machine that epitomised 20th-century brutality in Tank
fields.trailText: Patrick Wright looks at the development of the machine that epitomised 20th-century brutality in Tank
fields.body:
Tank: the Progress of a Monstrous War Machine
Patrick Wright
Faber £25, pp499
Buy it at BOL

Among the first British soldiers to see the prototype tank in action were some who died laughing. The lumbering 'Behemoth', as it was dubbed by the war correspondents of the period, for all its promise as a machine that might break the stalemate on the Western Front, inspired such hilarity that some infantrymen were fatally distracted amid enemy gunfire.

Stephen Foot, who saw a tank for the first time in 1916, noted that the 'predominant emotion excited in anyone seeing them for the first time was a feeling of hilarity. One wanted to laugh... standing still, they were funny; moving along, they were a scream'. But the perception of the tank as something ridiculous was shortlived. By the Battle of Cambrai, where Britain's new secret weapon was used effectively for the first time in a way that would come to define the use of tank power for the best part of a century, the laughter had ceased.

Instead, the tank would come to be regarded as one of the icons of a century's brutality, as notorious for its association with the repression of civilian populations as for its ability to win the wars of the new military era that the tank ushered in. In this, the tank has become curiously ambiguous in what it represents in modern culture. Indeed, two images stand out from the last decade that represent the tank's inherent contradictions: of the so-called Tankman in Tiananmen Square, the lone dissident with his shopping bags, tiny and vulnerable before the forward march of a role of Chinese; and of the massed ranks of allied tanks pouring into Iraq during the Gulf War.

Images like this, as Patrick Wright makes clear in this erudite, witty book, have elevated the tank into a powerful symbol for the twentieth century. But as Wright explains, the tank's ascension to its position as the pre-eminent image of war was not guaranteed. Indeed, even as it was being developed, there were many on the General Staff, Lord Kitchener included, who regarded the tank as nothing more than a 'mechanical toy', a sideshow to the real business of the mass attacks by infantry.

Because of this, the 'tank' - and the emerging doctrine of tank warfare - was left in the hands of a group of largely enthusiastic amateurs and esoteric outsiders who made it up as they went along. Disruptive patterning camouflage was thus developed out of the painted landscapes on the side of the machines conceived by the Royal Academician Solomon J. Solomon, whose prototypes featured pink sunsets.

The first drivers of the Heavy Section, as the first tank formation was known, came not from the cavalry, as always assumed, but were misfits who felt out of place amid the strict discipline of the rest of Kitchener's army. These early 'desperadoes', as they were dubbed, adopted as their first cap badge a piratical skull and crossbones.

If there was one figure who summed up the flair and eccentricity of the early tank men, it was J.F.C. Fuller, the spiritual father of all future tank commanders, an enthusiastic disciple and biographer of the satanist, Aleister Crowley, and the first man to understand that tanks should be concentrated in force to allow them to break through on the battlefield. Fuller went down like the proverbial cup of cold sick with his superiors, who still believed that infantry and cavalry would save the day.

What makes Wright's study so compelling is that this is not just a book for military hardware enthusiasts, but a work rich in character studies and anecdote which carefully places the changing status of the tank in contemporary perception.

Wright has uncovered a hidden history rich with ironies, in particular, the phenomenon of the First World War 'tank bank'. This was a hugely successful war bond-raising scheme that attracted millions of ordinary Britons to festivals in every big town organised around appearances of the then extraordinary new weapon. He conjures up the sense of febrile interest in the new weapon.

Because of this, the 'tank' - and the emerging doctrine of tank warfare - was left in the hands of a group of largely enthusiastic amateurs and esoteric outsiders who made it up as they went along. Disruptive patterning camouflage was thus developed out of the painted landscapes on the side of the machines conceived by the Royal Academician Solomon J. Solomon, whose prototypes featured pink sunsets. The first drivers of the Heavy Section, as the first tank formation was known, came not from the cavalry, as always assumed, but were misfits who felt out of place amid the strict discipline of the rest of Kitchener's army. These early 'desperadoes', as they were dubbed, adopted as their first cap badge a piratical skull and crossbones. If there was one figure who summed up the flair and eccentricity of the early tank men, it was J.F.C. Fuller, the spiritual father of all future tank commanders, an enthusiastic disciple and biographer of the satanist, Aleister Crowley, and the first man to understand that tanks should be concentrated in force to allow them to break through on the battlefield. Fuller went down like the proverbial cup of cold sick with his superiors, who still believed that infantry and cavalry would save the day. What makes Wright's study so compelling is that this is not just a book for military hardware enthusiasts, but a work rich in character studies and anecdote which carefully places the changing status of the tank in contemporary perception. Wright has uncovered a hidden history rich with ironies, in particular, the phenomenon of the First World War 'tank bank'. This was a hugely successful war bond-raising scheme that attracted millions of ordinary Britons to festivals in every big town organised around appearances of the then extraordinary new weapon. He conjures up the sense of febrile interest in the new weapon.

webTitle: Observer review: Black Cat by Martyn Bedford

fields.headline: The cat sat on the plot
fields.standfirst: Martyn Bedford returns to the territory he covered in The Houdini Girls with Black Cat
fields.trailText: Martyn Bedford returns to the territory he covered in The Houdini Girls with Black Cat
fields.body:
Black Cat
Martyn Bedford
Viking £9.99, pp240
Buy it at BOL

Last year The Houdini Girl put Martyn Bedford's name up in lights. Black Cat, his follow-up, treads similar thrillery territory with less satisfactory results. A mismatched couple join forces in an attempt to track down a mysterious, panther-like creature, which is savaging local sheep, and, in the process, uncover some disturbing inner truths. This is your average nasty psycho-drama, sub-Barbara Vine, but efficient nonetheless.

Bedford is strong on weather and scenery. He doesn't specify a setting for his story, but it's clearly Yorkshire. He evokes the moorlands with lucid ease: the bulk of hills abruptly rising up at the edge of town; big skies; 'the slow-motion uncoupling of the landscape's component parts' as dawn breaks.

Lost in this landscape are his characters. Chloe Fortune is 22, the daughter of an Californian dowser, and that (apart from the fact that she was, until recently, a member of an anti-roads protest community called Flashville, and has recently split up with a crusty called 'Spoons', who accused her of being a lightweight) is all the background we're given.

Stung by Spoons's criticism, 'perky, quirky' Chloe, now waitressing in a small Yorkshire town, looks for something that will prove him wrong. She'd been 'anti-roads, anti-nuclear, anti-capitalist, anti-establishment, anti-everything' for so long - now, she wants to be 'pro something... pro-active'. To this end, Chloe befriends a moor-dwelling loner called Ethan Grey, a former housing officer who has become a full-time beast sleuth and resolves to help him track the cat.

Because she has inherited her mother's talents, she's soon dangling her wooden plumb bob over a map of the moors, trying to find the cat in its creases. Handily enough, she is able to identify where the cat has been and where it may be in a day's time. And she's usually on the nail. Divine inspiration, you see. Speeds up the plot no end. Trouble is, Chloe is paying more attention to her sixth sense than her common sense. In fact, Spoons was right: Chloe is a lightweight. She falls less for the notion of finding the panther than for the misfit Ethan himself.

Suddenly, Bedford starts to add texture: excerpts from Hansard, police statements, reports from cat-hunters, zoologists, mythologists. Ethan steps out of the shadows and his awkwardness gradually shades into something more sinister. But Ethan, like Chloe, is never made real for us. We do not learn why he is the way he is. We must make do with the idea that his identity has become, in some mysterious way, defined by the creature he seeks.

Bedford is not interested in the past, just the present. This proves a real obstacle to the reader who is trying to get lost in his story.

webTitle: Observer review: Romanticism and its Discontents by Anita Brookner

fields.headline: Duran Duran's debt to David
fields.standfirst: Anita Brookner brings elegance, subtlety and restraint to her examination of the Dionysiac in Romanticism and its Discontents
fields.trailText: Anita Brookner brings elegance, subtlety and restraint to her examination of the Dionysiac in Romanticism and its Discontents
fields.body:
Romanticism and its Discontents
Anita Brookner
Viking £25, pp208
Buy it at BOL

Why do rock stars feel obliged to look sullen? At the root of the explanation is romanticism, which ushered in a concept of the artist as neurotic, disengaged, socially maladapted and intent on cultivating an image of enigmatic uniqueness.

In brief, rock stars want attention. They try to get it by seeming special, and they try to seem special, or different from everyone else, by being odd. To a person living in the mid-eighteenth century, just before the onset of romanticism, such behaviour would have been evidence only of madness. But one result of romanticism was to make madness itself seem worth affecting, given its association with child-like innocence and quasi-prophetic insight.

Perhaps the greatest change which occurred in European culture between the French Revolution and the Battle of Waterloo was that the individual ceased to be of interest merely as an embodiment of general human characteristics, but became, instead, a conduit for new ideas about what human nature was. For, according to Anita Brookner, the old certitudes had been given a mighty knock by the social changes expressed in the French Revolution; and a widespread attitude of scepticism towards them became, for many romantic artists, as indispensable a component of artistic amour-propre as the rock star's look of surly self-obsession.

Yet to say as much is to equate the whole of romanticism with what might be called its 'wild side'. Ask a student of European literature to name a romantic figure and it is likely that Byron will seem to fit the description better than Wordsworth. Ask a student of art history and probably Eugene Delacroix rather than Jean Auguste Ingres (both the subject of separate chapters here) would probably seem best to satisfy the romantic ideal.

But this is, in part, because the ideals which were actually current during the romantic period have themselves been subsequently 'romanticised'. With her own neoclassical blend of delicacy and confidence, Brookner reminds us that romanticism was a reactive movement, and its manifestations necessarily preserve characteristics of the ideology which it was reacting against.

In the fine arts, what this means is that the aesthetic ideology of romanticism incorporates, with degrees of strain which vary from one artist to another, elements of neo-classical aesthetics. This is particularly obvious in the case of Louis David's picture, Napoleon Crossing the Alps, where the clearly delineated forms express an elegance creatively in tension with the energies both of the horse's movement and of Napoleon's concentrated purposefulness.

But, as Brookner shows, in a sequence of chapters dealing predominantly, and in roughly chronological order, with three painters (Antoine-Jean Gros, Delacroix and Ingres) and five writers (Musset, Baudelaire, the Goncourts, Zola and Huysmans), it is the balance of tendencies which determines the character of an artist's work, and this varies according to his allegiances in general.

Thus, David is fundamentally a conservative artist in whose work elements of the new radicalism are temperately permitted to emerge. Ingres, 30 years his junior, shares the same conservative temperament and, hence, clarity of line, but because his own interests impel him to disrupt the cultural traditions he is anxious to preserve, the tension within his work is correspondingly more patent and acute. In Delacroix, however, the preoccupation with the wilder side of romanticism entails a brusque displacement of neo-classical norms.

These discriminations, so finely made by Brookner, are important because of the general point that theories of aesthetic decorum are expressions of moral, social, religious and political allegiance. To oppose the authority of David, as Brookner shows Gros doing, was to oppose, however uncertainly, the central beliefs about human nature and how life should be conducted which David's theories stood for.

The exuberance of opposition subsequently reached such a height, however, that we are now living out the consequences of losing our hold on the values which pre-romantic cultural traditions sought to conserve. The present book, I believe, is the outcome of a conflict between the values implicit in Brookner's own wisely conservative artistry and the post-romantic iconoclasm of contemporary culture.

Brookner defends by example the neo-classical virtues of elegance, subtlety, candour and impassioned restraint. Her book suggests better than any other I know the benefits of trying to appraise romanticism from a standpoint of sympathy with the values it dislodged.

fields.headline: Behind the fringe...
fields.standfirst: Alan Bennett has always been fiercely private, but he's about to reveal more than ever before in a new series of TV monologues. How true a picture of this national treasure do they paint?
fields.trailText: It comes as no surprise, I suppose, to learn that Alan Bennett sleeps in his late mother's bed. Or to find that he takes quiet pleasure from the fact that the bed still bears the marks on its frame made by her toenails as she strained to give birth to his brother. There is something forensic, macabre even, about the way he clings to the detail of his growing up, to the conviction that if he scratches hard enough and often enough at the dull surface of his childhood he will reveal the ingrained emotional tracery that explains who he is.
fields.body:
It comes as no surprise, I suppose, to learn that Alan Bennett sleeps in his late mother's bed. Or to find that he takes quiet pleasure from the fact that the bed still bears the marks on its frame made by her toenails as she strained to give birth to his brother. There is something forensic, macabre even, about the way he clings to the detail of his growing up, to the conviction that if he scratches hard enough and often enough at the dull surface of his childhood he will reveal the ingrained emotional tracery that explains who he is.

In the BBC's forthcoming Telling Tales, an autobiographical version of Bennett's wonderful Talking Heads, some familiar anecdotal keepsakes are thus once again brought out for inspection. There is, for example, the remembered 'dread of imminent exposure' when dining out with his parents in Leeds; the tale of his Uncle Norris who discovered the cure for arthritis, namely cutting the feet out of his socks; and the rerun of Bennett's pious teenage anxiety that he might catch VD from the Eucharist on Christmas Eve, when the congregation was swelled with sinners.

These party pieces, made word perfect over the years, are punctuated by halting memento mori, as when he explains how he very nearly became a vicar, primarily because he looked like one: 'This is not as silly as it sounds,' he intones softly to camera, blinking a little through his glasses. 'People often end up doing what the mirror tells them they are suited for, while feeling themselves quite different inside. And in the process whole lifetimes are thrown away.'

The 10-part series of short films, which begins next Saturday, seems part of an inclination in Bennett's most recent work to take personal stock. His friend, Sir Richard Eyre, sees it as the culmination of a familiar method. 'Alan is very systematic in working the narrow seams of his raw material,' he says. 'There was a Kafka theme; a royalty theme; a spying theme; and in this portfolio there is also a file marked "Alan Bennett". He approaches each of these subjects in the same way; he exhaustively mines his material for all it is worth.'

The file marked 'Alan Bennett' contains the familiar version of himself that the playwright wants his audience to know, and perhaps to love. 'I'd rather the public had an image, and not quite fit it,' he once remarked. 'That way, you're free.' This freedom is carefully guarded. Bennett, now 60, never does press interviews these days, on the grounds that he feels 'less afterwards', although he was happy to be photographed for this piece.

He is said to be troubled by an unauthorised biography, to be written by the comedy writer, Alex Games, which will be published next year. Bennett, characteristically, has reportedly been torn about whether to ask his friends not to contribute to the book; Games described to me his method of researching this most private of writers as being like 'keyhole surgery'. 'Alan has a need to be in control of things to a certain extent, certainly,' says Eyre. 'The idea of a public celebrity appearance, as himself, as the real Alan Bennett, is something that would fill him with absolute horror.'

Some instinct of quiet control asserted itself from the outset of Bennett's career. In Humphrey Carpenter's recent account of the genesis of Beyond the Fringe, it is Bennett who comes across as the sternest and most exacting of the inspired quartet. Jonathan Miller, still Bennett's neighbour, confides that he always felt as though he was 'regarded by Alan as a sort of frivolous, non-contributing dilettante, whose capering around on stage got more attention than he, the diligent writer, got'. (Bennett, for his part, recalls how Miller, 'with characteristic extravagance, once threw a tea service at me. Though again characteristically, it missed'.)

Dudley Moore was, in his own recollection, dismissed altogether by Bennett after hamming to the audience during a sketch. Though the pair had been in the habit of dining together before each show, from then on, Moore recalls: 'He never spoke to me. It was as though he had never met me. We never went out for a meal again. Nothing.'

Still, the impetus to confession in Telling Tales, is not, it seems, simply a question of getting his version of stories in first. In recent articles, he has talked of clearing his shelves, of sorting out mental lumber, this, in part, in response, you might suppose, to a serious illness that he suffered a couple of years ago, from which he has recovered (and about which he does not speak). Last year, in particular, in a piece called 'Untold Stories', in which he detailed for the first time the extent of his mother's depression, there was a sense of him putting his house in order.

The memoir placed his writing about his family history, the bedrock of his work, in a poignant context. When Bennett suggested in the past that 'we must love one another or die - of embarrassment', it had been easy to take the reference lightly, a wry comment on the strangled social awkwardnesses he so delights in exploring.

In a sense though, Bennett's mother did die from embarrassment. 'Wanting to go unnoticed is what Mam's depression is about,' he wrote, recalling, as if it were yesterday, the day in 1966 when he and his father took her to Lancaster Moor Hospital, committing her to a psychiatric ward of 'unimagined wretchedness', and the innumerable hospital visits of the years that followed. She had found the Dales village to which she had moved from 'mucky Leeds' daunting and impossible because she felt the 'centrepiece there'; she had refused in the same spirit, as Bennett discovered in researching his memoir, a proper wedding, getting married at eight in the morning so as not to draw attention to herself. She wanted, in effect, to disappear from life.

Until he was faced with his mother's depression, Bennett had always tended to think of neurosis as something 'put on', a way of making oneself interesting, and in this sense he imagined himself neurotic. Her condition forced him to come to terms with what he calls the 'mundane mad', and to explore that often painfully comic line between eccentricity and insanity, which is at the heart of his best work. In some ways, you could view nearly all of his writing of the last three decades as an attempt to understand that distinction for himself. The Madness of King George, The Lady in the Van, Talking Heads all have one thing in common: they are narratives of people who, in Bennett's terms, are part of a 'story to the meaning of which they are not entirely privy'. People, in this respect, like his mother.

In a brilliant valedictory essay on Philip Larkin, who was an inspiration as a writer to Bennett, and against whose wilful bitterness he seems to judge his humanity, Bennett quotes the poet as having written that: 'My mother is such a bloody rambling fool that half the time I doubt her sanity. Two things she said today for instance were that she had thought of "getting a job in Woolworths" and that she wanted to "win the football pools so she could give cocktail parties".'

In quoting this, Bennett notes how his own mother might have had similar aspirations, particularly about the cocktail parties, and in these passages you can see him marvelling at Larkin's liberating cruelty, and measuring it against his own more complicated compassion: his desire to do his best by his Mam, and his need to understand her legacy in himself.

In the past, he has used a line from a Borges story to describe his own feelings as a comic writer, mining his family's life for 'material', which perhaps in this context can be understood: 'All the books he ever published filled him with a complex feeling of repentance.'

Michael Frayn, who has known Bennett since National Service days, when they studied Russian together, and is now also a neighbour, suggests that 'what a lot of his work is about is the moment when people wake up to the fact that they have passionate feelings, feelings they did not, by background or circumstance, think themselves capable of; these might be passionate sexual feelings, or passionate violent feelings'. In some ways, he imagines, this is a catharsis that Bennett has felt echoes of in his own life, but if it is, it is not one that he has ever directly publicly addressed.

In his most candid interview, with the New Yorker in 1993, Bennett explained how: 'I'd always been in love with guys... but always unhappily. They were straight and it was always totally unfulfilled... I was interested in sex, and whichever way any sex came along you just had to take it - that's how it seemed to me.' In this spirit, perhaps, Bennett then revealed that he had, for the previous 17 years, been enjoying a relationship with Anne Davies, 15 years his junior, who had once been employed as the cleaner in his London house. Bennett had bought Anne ('a reformed hippy') a tea shop in Clapham, the Dales village where his father and mother lived in later life, and where he kept a house (the same house in which his mother imagined intruders behind the pantry door; heard voices conversing in the living-room, and stood stock-still for hours in the hall, waiting for their chatter to stop).

Davies set up home in Clapham with a younger lover, a dry-stone waller from Devon. She saw Bennett about once a month, she subsequently explained: 'He was always gay but he thought men didn't like him. It's like not being picked for the team at school... I was the only woman he had ever been close to... I was like an earthquake, turning his life upside down with my kids and lovers and mess.'

Davies turned Clapham upside down, too, going barefoot in all weathers, wearing bells on her ankles; she was banned from the local pub, and scandalised locals by admitting on one occasion that she had daubed expletives on a heritage sign. In some ways, it seemed, she was another of Bennett's unruly alter egos (along with his late friends, Peter Cook and Russell Harty, in whose shamelessness he revelled), and you could imagine the attraction, the blissful private joke, of putting this woman at the centre of village life, the conventions of which had so hemmed his mother in.

'Most men,' he once wrote, again with Larkin in mind, 'regard their life as a poem which women threaten.' For all his anxieties about his upbringing and his sexuality, Bennett has been conscious in his efforts to prevent his existence from being as miserably precious as the poet's.

Unlike Larkin, he has created for himself a place where he can be comfortable with metropolitan life. His house, friends say, is a monument to his passion for home decor; he is a great cook: 'His kitchen,' one acquaintance told me, 'which you might expect to look like something from the 1950s, is actually a place where Nigella Lawson would feel very much at home.'

Five years ago, Anne Davies remarked how Bennett had been involved, too, in a successful homosexual relationship, and that relationship continues. And, moreover, he has managed, as his diaries reveal, to make much of his life seem like one of his own amusing creations. (Richard Eyre believes that the kind of anecdote for which Bennett is famous tends to 'seek him out... when you are with Alan,' he says, 'you feel that his particular perception of the world is so powerful that the world itself becomes Bennettesque around him'.)

'Art begins with imitation, often in the form of parody,' Bennett once observed, 'and it's in the process of imitating the voices of others that one comes to learn the sound of one's own.' He has spent his career and his life, in this sense, learning to love the sound of his own voice. One of the great pleasures of Telling Tales , and there are many, is to listen to that voice in all of its complex maturity; another is to hear behind those tales it tells, the ghosts of the tales he leaves out.

When Bennett suggested in the past that 'we must love one another or die - of embarrassment', it had been easy to take the reference lightly, a wry comment on the strangled social awkwardnesses he so delights in exploring. In a sense though, Bennett's mother did die from embarrassment. 'Wanting to go unnoticed is what Mam's depression is about,' he wrote, recalling, as if it were yesterday, the day in 1966 when he and his father took her to Lancaster Moor Hospital, committing her to a psychiatric ward of 'unimagined wretchedness', and the innumerable hospital visits of the years that followed. She had found the Dales village to which she had moved from 'mucky Leeds' daunting and impossible because she felt the 'centrepiece there'; she had refused in the same spirit, as Bennett discovered in researching his memoir, a proper wedding, getting married at eight in the morning so as not to draw attention to herself. She wanted, in effect, to disappear from life. Until he was faced with his mother's depression, Bennett had always tended to think of neurosis as something 'put on', a way of making oneself interesting, and in this sense he imagined himself neurotic. Her condition forced him to come to terms with what he calls the 'mundane mad', and to explore that often painfully comic line between eccentricity and insanity, which is at the heart of his best work. In some ways, you could view nearly all of his writing of the last three decades as an attempt to understand that distinction for himself. The Madness of King George, The Lady in the Van, Talking Heads all have one thing in common: they are narratives of people who, in Bennett's terms, are part of a 'story to the meaning of which they are not entirely privy'. People, in this respect, like his mother. In a brilliant valedictory essay on Philip Larkin, who was an inspiration as a writer to Bennett, and against whose wilful bitterness he seems to judge his humanity, Bennett quotes the poet as having written that: 'My mother is such a bloody rambling fool that half the time I doubt her sanity. Two things she said today for instance were that she had thought of "getting a job in Woolworths" and that she wanted to "win the football pools so she could give cocktail parties".' In quoting this, Bennett notes how his own mother might have had similar aspirations, particularly about the cocktail parties, and in these passages you can see him marvelling at Larkin's liberating cruelty, and measuring it against his own more complicated compassion: his desire to do his best by his Mam, and his need to understand her legacy in himself. In the past, he has used a line from a Borges story to describe his own feelings as a comic writer, mining his family's life for 'material', which perhaps in this context can be understood: 'All the books he ever published filled him with a complex feeling of repentance.' Michael Frayn, who has known Bennett since National Service days, when they studied Russian together, and is now also a neighbour, suggests that 'what a lot of his work is about is the moment when people wake up to the fact that they have passionate feelings, feelings they did not, by background or circumstance, think themselves capable of; these might be passionate sexual feelings, or passionate violent feelings'. In some ways, he imagines, this is a catharsis that Bennett has felt echoes of in his own life, but if it is, it is not one that he has ever directly publicly addressed. In his most candid interview, with the New Yorker in 1993, Bennett explained how: 'I'd always been in love with guys... but always unhappily. They were straight and it was always totally unfulfilled... I was interested in sex, and whichever way any sex came along you just had to take it - that's how it seemed to me.' In this spirit, perhaps, Bennett then revealed that he had, for the previous 17 years, been enjoying a relationship with Anne Davies, 15 years his junior, who had once been employed as the cleaner in his London house. Bennett had bought Anne ('a reformed hippy') a tea shop in Clapham, the Dales village where his father and mother lived in later life, and where he kept a house (the same house in which his mother imagined intruders behind the pantry door; heard voices conversing in the living-room, and stood stock-still for hours in the hall, waiting for their chatter to stop). Davies set up home in Clapham with a younger lover, a dry-stone waller from Devon. She saw Bennett about once a month, she subsequently explained: 'He was always gay but he thought men didn't like him. It's like not being picked for the team at school... I was the only woman he had ever been close to... I was like an earthquake, turning his life upside down with my kids and lovers and mess.' Davies turned Clapham upside down, too, going barefoot in all weathers, wearing bells on her ankles; she was banned from the local pub, and scandalised locals by admitting on one occasion that she had daubed expletives on a heritage sign. In some ways, it seemed, she was another of Bennett's unruly alter egos (along with his late friends, Peter Cook and Russell Harty, in whose shamelessness he revelled), and you could imagine the attraction, the blissful private joke, of putting this woman at the centre of village life, the conventions of which had so hemmed his mother in. 'Most men,' he once wrote, again with Larkin in mind, 'regard their life as a poem which women threaten.' For all his anxieties about his upbringing and his sexuality, Bennett has been conscious in his efforts to prevent his existence from being as miserably precious as the poet's. Unlike Larkin, he has created for himself a place where he can be comfortable with metropolitan life. His house, friends say, is a monument to his passion for home decor; he is a great cook: 'His kitchen,' one acquaintance told me, 'which you might expect to look like something from the 1950s, is actually a place where Nigella Lawson would feel very much at home.' Five years ago, Anne Davies remarked how Bennett had been involved, too, in a successful homosexual relationship, and that relationship continues. And, moreover, he has managed, as his diaries reveal, to make much of his life seem like one of his own amusing creations. (Richard Eyre believes that the kind of anecdote for which Bennett is famous tends to 'seek him out... when you are with Alan,' he says, 'you feel that his particular perception of the world is so powerful that the world itself becomes Bennettesque around him'.) 'Art begins with imitation, often in the form of parody,' Bennett once observed, 'and it's in the process of imitating the voices of others that one comes to learn the sound of one's own.' He has spent his career and his life, in this sense, learning to love the sound of his own voice. One of the great pleasures of Telling Tales , and there are many, is to listen to that voice in all of its complex maturity; another is to hear behind those tales it tells, the ghosts of the tales he leaves out.

webTitle: The things we do for love...

fields.headline: The things we do for love...
fields.standfirst: Forget hearts, flowers and chocolates. This is about real love - suffering, turmoil and regrets
fields.trailText: Peter Preston: It sounds like a romantic comedy... but there is nothing remotely comic here
fields.body:
Are you In the Mood For Love? It sounds like a romantic comedy - Ryan and Hanks, even Fred and Ginger - but there is nothing remotely comic here. This love is intricate, consuming and elegiac. And, though the mood is essentially European - say mid-career Truffaut, with a whisper of Brief Encounter - the setting is far away in the Hong Kong of the early Sixties. Wong Kar-Wai, chameleon amongst great directors, has done it again.

Tony Leung Chiu-Wai is Mr Chow, a thirtysomething journalist with a pretty wife. Maggie Cheung Man-Yuk is Mrs Chow, a super secretary married to a travelling businessman. The couples find rooms to live in adjoining flats. Slowly, it dawns on Leung and Cheung that their increasingly absent partners are having an affair. Slowly, Leung begins his pursuit of the wronged wife and she begins to descend into an agony of doubt. If she succumbs, will she be any better than her faithless husband?

Wong Kar-Wai does everything: action movies, cop movies, epics, often with a French new-wave feel of improvisation. Here, there is none of that. Instead, we move meticulously from one little box to the next, from one poky room to the room next door. Other rooms in the apartment block are filmed down corridors or over shoulders; the only excursions beyond are into deserted streets where rain falls torrentially around the sheltering pair. Complete claustrophobia. We never see the faces of the adulterous husband or his mistress, only their backs: they are ciphers throwing Leung and Cheung into starker relief.

Does that sound a trifle dour? It isn't. The family who rent Cheung her room are warm and effusive, always offering food and companionship. Leung's hoary journalist mate is rounded and jolly. There is human life just across the landing or at the office; the characters are rooted in place and time - but that time, too, matters. Falling in love in the Hong Kong of four decades ago isn't a quick, modern fling. You feel the brooding disapproval of a more traditional Chinese society. Contacts must be secret, emotions hidden. Celia Johnson looks out of the railway carriage window. Upper lips stiffen and then quiver. When Cheung is trapped - innocently enough - in Leung's bedroom overnight, because others are playing mah-jong outside, there's no question of a quick roll on the bed. Cheung lies there alone, imprisoned by inhibition.

Wong Kar-Wai is never entirely unobtrusive. The director's presence remains constant - sometimes playing jokes, like rehearsals of the farewell speeches Cheung will make to her husband, which appear, for a moment, to be the real thing. But that constant presence merely focuses us more hypnotically on the central relationship; and upon a particular sequence of months and passions locked away, resistance eroding as the mood takes hold.

It doesn't work completely. Leung and Cheung are two of China's most fêted stars, one stubby, battered and thoughtfully bemused, the other sinuous and tortured. They hold the screen and the still, silent Leung is especially hypnotic as he calculates and manipulates. But Cheung has an almost impossibly testing role. Can she make us, as twenty-first-century spectators, comprehend and share her inner turmoil? Can she become somebody we not only understand intellectually, but weep for in her desperate dilemma of the soul?

Maybe Truffaut could have got that from Nathalie Baye, because her face is infinitely expressive and part of a world we understand. Cheung cannot quite convey that. She agonises, but she can't draw us in. The gap between eras and cultures is too great. The background score, by Mike Galasso, plonks away, sometimes Nat King Cole, sometimes second-hand Michel Legrand, so that you know you ought to understand. But no - you can see the suffering, yet you don't feel it. A love story without the hint of tear.

But for all that this is an accomplished and memorable film, one that Wong Kar-Wai fought to finish through two years of censorship and Eastern financial crisis. Why should the censors have worried? There is no sex here, no sweaty coupling. This is love pursued, love won, love lost; love as a mingling of minds and calculation; love as regret. The chameleon called love.

fields.headline: Fool no more
fields.standfirst: He doesn't want to play the funnyman anymore, so no rabbitears or arrows through his head, and definitely no stand-up. The jerk's grown up and he's written a book to prove it
fields.trailText: Steve Martin has a problem with 'hellos'. He doesn't quite know whether to gush or to play them for laughs. When Richard E. Grant, the English actor who is now one of Martin's closest friends, arrived in Hollywood to start working with him on the film LA Story, their first encounter got off to a stuttering start.
fields.body:
Steve Martin has a problem with 'hellos'. He doesn't quite know whether to gush or to play them for laughs. When Richard E. Grant, the English actor who is now one of Martin's closest friends, arrived in Hollywood to start working with him on the film LA Story, their first encounter got off to a stuttering start.

'We are so thrilled you are able to do this movie,' said Martin, his face wreathed in the magnanimous smiles of the superstar.

'Believe me, the thrill's all mine,' matched Grant.

Then, as a long afternoon of exchanging sugary pleasantries stretched out before them, Martin suddenly switched tactics and went into a comic 'bit' that Grant has come to know as his 'all-purpose Showbiz Schlockmeister routine' and which involves showering the visitor with an intentionally ludicrous stream of stock insincerities.

His pose as a gracious and civil host had lasted less than 30 seconds. This turns out, however, to be longer than many strangers get. Even the printed cards that Martin once handed out to autograph hunters did not take the idea of celebrity very seriously. They read: 'This certifies that you have had a personal encounter with me and that you found me warm, polite, intelligent and funny.'

Over the 24 years since the comedian began to establish himself as a star on the hit television show Saturday Night Live, interviewers have often noted how difficult Martin finds it to present himself 'in person'.

'He wants to be nice. But it is as if he is determined that you shouldn't have the chance to make any harsh judgments, so he goes into a comic persona,' said one New York film writer who spent a day with him last year.

Whether this standard performance is a sign of shyness or control-freakery is anyone's guess, but certainly this month the 55-year-old is asking the world to look at him afresh. His first novella, a poignant romance called Shopgirl, has just been published and the star has taken the opportunity to tell the world that he wants to leave both the stage and the film lot behind him forever.

'I've made two decisions in my life,' he said. 'One was to leave stand-up and go into movies. The other is to write. Now is my time to write.'

Although Bowfinger, Martin's 1999 movie attacking the film industry, was critically well-received, he now intends to turn down the kind of parts that have recently earned him around $6 million a throw. A string of earlier flops, such as Mixed Nuts and Leap of Faith, have had an impact. 'It just wasn't fun anymore,' Martin explained.

This spring he made his first concerted move away from film and back into television. He and his business partner, Joan Stein, have signed a seven figure deal with the Carsey-Werner studio, the makers of Third Rock From the Sun, Cybill and Roseanne. They plan to write and produce a weekly show.

To underline the change in gear, Martin told fans who attended a New York book reading last month that he had hated his time as a famous comic.

'I know it sounds clichéd, but it was the most miserable time in my life. I couldn't leave my hotel room, I couldn't go outside. I was isolated, and isolation is where creativity ends.'

But then again, Martin was talking to an audience at the time. And he was wearing luminous green socks underneath his sober, literary suit.

So are we witnessing the 'tears of a clown' syndrome once again? Is this another cult comic hero who obsesses about the lightweight nature of his talents?

Martin, by now an acknowledged comedian, screenwriter, playwright, author and musician, is regularly likened to Woody Allen. And it is true they have both grown away from pure gags. But there are some big distinctions too.

Allen's innate intellectual confidence means he has never strained to take on any of his new guises. What's more, while both Allen and Martin's early work - in films such as Sleeper and The Man with Two Brains, respectively - was funny because it was truly silly, Martin initially had much the blacker tone. It is Allen, then, who has pushed himself towards heavier dramatic forms and Martin who has leavened his career by taking the primrose path into the Hollywood mainstream.

His 130-page novella marks a turning point. It tells the story of Mirabelle, 'a beautiful wallflower' in her early thirties who is looking for love as she sells gloves in the Beverly Hills store, Neimans. In what is surely a whisper of authorial wish-fulfilment, she one day meets a millionaire in his fifties and a bitter-sweet flirtation begins.

Martin has said the experience of having his heart broken and of breaking other people's hearts has prompted the story. It is a much more deliberately sensitive piece of writing than seen in his best-selling collection of stories and sketches, Pure Drivel.

In 1993 Martin broke up with his English wife, Victoria Tennant, with whom he had starred in LA Story. He then went on to a high profile relationship with the film actress Anne Heche, who eventually left him for the lesbian sitcom star, Ellen DeGeneres.

Most recently the comic's name has been briefly linked with that of another English woman, Helena Bonham Carter, who will appear with him this autumn in a comic thriller called Novocaine. So far, the actor has no children, explaining that he is 'too selfish' and 'moves around too much'.

Martin, the original whacko from Waco, grew up in Texas and later California with his sister, Melinda, in the care of upright, religious parents. He broke away from such church-going strictures when he started selling guidebooks in Disneyland and learned to play the banjo.

A proper job in showbusiness came with the role of television writer for Dick Van Dyke and The Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour, but real fame arrived in 1976 when Martin hosted his first Saturday Night Live. Easily distinguished by the rabbit ears and the arrow he wore on his head, Martin has always had a taste for simple vaudeville. One of his many stage acts, The Great Flydini, consisted of pulling a series of outré objects - for instance, eggs - from his unzipped fly.

Unlikely though it may sound, international stardom followed quickly in 1979 with his film The Jerk and from then on Martin, much like Jerry Lewis before him, was to be strongly identified with the pratfall and the funny walk.

His heroes, he says, were Jackie Gleason and Charlie Chaplin and, revealingly, it is their 'elegance' he singles out for praise. Martin's skill, far from a nerdy lack of physical control, is to see the discipline and grace required for this kind of comedy. Despite his frantic energy, friends and colleagues often sense a distance and a yearning for beauty and calm in Martin.

Jonathan Lynn, the British film maker who directed him in Sgt Bilko in 1996, says he detected a certain remoteness in a man who was also, paradoxically, 'a national institution' in the United States.

Martin's own sister has spoken publically too of his 'distance'. The siblings see each other infrequently and her brother, she has said, kept his links with the family to a minimum.

In 1993 Martin made his debut as a playwright with Picasso at the Lapin Agile, a comic fantasy which went on to have a successful off-Broadway run. He has also appeared on the 'legit' stage in Samuel Beckett's bleak psychodrama, Waiting for Godot, at New York's Lincoln Centre. Nowadays, he is reported to spend a lot of time extending his valuable fine art collection.

If Martin really does retreat from his fans and opt instead to create from behind the scenes as a writer or producer, perhaps the art of stand-up comedy should not feel too neglected. Tastes have moved on, and Martin's comparative restraint might not please the crowds any longer.

After all, even The Great Flydini would look tame today when West End audiences are rolling in the aisles to the sight of live gonad manipulation in the Puppetry of the Penis.

fields.headline: Bijou Phillips
fields.standfirst: Musician, actress and former model - and she's only 20
fields.trailText: Musician, actress and former model Bijou Phillips - and she's only 20.
fields.body:
Bijou Phillips is something of a force of nature. Here, for instance, is her account of how she started her career in the music industry: 'I just kind of got fed up with modelling and living in New York and being fucking bored out of my mind, so I came out to Los Angeles and got a record deal.' Just like that?

Probably. Bijou Phillips has made one album, been in four movies (with more to come), retired from a successful modelling career ('It was bullshit. I don't have one good thing to say about modelling.') and has been on the cover of Playboy . She is 20 years old. Mind you, it is all in the genes. Her father is John Phillips, from the Mamas And Papas, although his days of glory were long gone by the time Bijou was born. One of her half-sisters is Mackenzie Phillips, a teenage sitcom star of the Seventies who became every American tabloids favourite burn-out for a while. Another half-sister is Chynna Phillips, who was in the fleeting daughters-of-the-famous pop group Wilson Phillips, and is now married to William Baldwin. You can take it that fame holds no mysteries for young Bijou.

The first film we'll see her in is James Toback's uneven but fascinating Black And White, among a sprawling cast that includes Robert Downey Jr, Claudia Schiffer, Mike Tyson and Ben Stiller. Bijou plays the high-school age daughter of wealthy Manhattannites who spends her time hanging out - and having threesomes in Central Park - with roughneck aspiring rappers.

It turns out that Bijou herself had wild patches during her adolescence, becoming a notorious figure on the New York club scene at 14. She claims now that it was a brief phase she was passing through, and that she was over all that after a few months. Still, the casting in Black And White makes sense to her. webTitle: Diana's death prompted big rise in suicide rate

fields.headline: Diana's death prompted big rise in suicide rate
fields.trailText: Public grief at the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, took a far more tragic twist in Britain than had been previously thought.
fields.body:
Public grief at the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, took a far more tragic twist in Britain than had been previously thought.

New research shows there was a dramatic increase in women either committing suicide or acts of self-harm in the days directly after Diana died in a car crash on 31 August 1997.

In the week following the accident there was a 33.7 per cent rise in suicides among women in England and Wales and the overall suicide rate, for men and women, increased by 17.4 per cent in the month after her funeral.

Deliberate self-harm - usually attempted suicides - rose by 65.1 per cent in the first week of September 1997.

Previous theories claimed that 'social cohesion' - people drawing together with a sense of shared sorrow which was experienced in America when JFK was assassinated - had prevented any upsurge. But the report to be published in the British Journal of Psychiatry this week is expected to conclude that the figures show a serious impact on many women.

The effect was most clearly seen in women aged 25 to 44. Normally, it is women over 45 who are most at risk of taking their own lives.

The study's authors, among them Professor Keith Hawton of the suicide research unit at the University of Oxford and Louis Appleby, a mental health expert, believe their work will prompt further studies on the affects of major events concerning well-known celebrities.

However, psychiatrists and sociologists point out that most of the deaths occurred among people who were already feeling suicidal.

Professor Cary Cooper, of the University of Manchester, said: 'Diana's death is not going to have caused anybody to kill themselves, rather it will have been a trigger to many who were predisposed to taking their lives.

'It is important to remember that people who will have had such an extreme reaction to Diana's death will have been those already feeling irrational, despondent and depressed.

'The reason the event affected so many women is that they are more likely to have related to Diana through the stresses and strains they saw in her life. Alternatively, some may have thought "well, there's a young woman who had it all and what's the point in me living when you could just go like that at any time?"

'I think there was a lot of guilt when the princess died. People felt very bad at having been part of a society which wanted to know the titbits and read the papers and the magazines avidly. Perhaps had we not dogged her so much she would not have been speeding away in a car from press and cameramen.'

His remarks were backed by the Samaritans' spokeswoman Julie Alexander, who said there had been a marked increase in calls to their helplines around the time of the death and funeral.

'But we wouldn't say her death caused anyone to kill themselves. It is never anyone else's fault when someone takes their own life.

'Self-harm is a noticeable factor. Self-harm rates have been going up quite worry-ingly. It is a massive issue.'

fields.headline: A woman's tale
fields.trailText: So 78 per cent of divorces are initiated by women? Why? Perhaps women are forced to do so to regularise their lives, even knowing it will make them poorer.
fields.body:
So 78 per cent of divorces are initiated by women? Why? Perhaps women are forced to do so to regularise their lives, even knowing it will make them poorer.

My husband spent six months saying he was going to leave me, left, returned, left, and when, after a further four years, I initiated divorce proceedings, protested 'that he didn't think it would come to this'. It took another two years to get my clean-break divorce, with a paltry settlement after paying off his debts, but at least I knew where I stood after seven years of uncertainty. Or should I have welcomed him back, thus making role models for my children of my martyrdom and his fecklessness?
Name and address supplied

fields.headline: Fighter talk
fields.trailText: I was fascinated by the article on the 'phantom' Heinkel 113 German fighter (News, last week). In 1940-41 I was in 801 Naval Air Squadron flying Blackburn Skua and Roc fighter-dive bombers, based in Kent.
fields.body:
I was fascinated by the article on the 'phantom' Heinkel 113 German fighter (News, last week). In 1940-41 I was in 801 Naval Air Squadron flying Blackburn Skua and Roc fighter-dive bombers, based in Kent.

On 21 June 1940 we were despatched to dive-bomb German positions near Cap Gris Nez on the French coast. At 8,000 feet I had a clear view of two German fighters 2,000 feet below me. No doubt they were there to intercept us but failed. For obvious reasons my recognition of enemy fighters was studied intensely and, on return to base at Detling, I reported the two enemy fighters as being Heinkel 113s, which was accepted as fact by the RAF Intelligence Officer who de-briefed us.
George Baldwin DSC
Petworth, W Sussex

fields.headline: Northern time
fields.trailText:
Your timely article regarding the effect of the autumn clock change on seasonally affective disorder (News, last week) prompts me - tongue in cheek - to revisit the ridiculousness of this ritual. Now that we have a Scottish Parliament why should there not be an independent time zone for the North? The objection that this would play havoc with train timetables also no longer holds water; the versatile British public now seems perfectly able to cope with a three-hour train journey which arrives at Waterloo International two hours after its departure from the Continent.
Chris Cooper
Teddington, Middlesex

fields.headline: The wrong track
fields.body:
Separating rail track from rolling stock was a mistake recognised more than 170 years ago. When the Stockton-Darlington Railway was opened in 1825 it was on a bring-your-own-rolling stock principle. The impracticability of this was soon recognised so that when the Liverpool and Manchester line was opened in 1830, track and rolling stock were owned by the same company.
Maurice Packham
Horsham, West Sussex

webTitle: A hate fuelled by Arab gold

fields.headline: A hate fuelled by Arab gold
fields.trailText: For years, I have watched as the tragedy of the Palestinians (News, last week) - consistently kicked around like footballs - has been so like the history of the Jews. The British and French gave their country to the Hashemites and called it Jordan (even today, there is perhaps no other country in the world that has a majority of its population with a foreign nationality; in this case, Palestinian).
fields.body:
For years, I have watched as the tragedy of the Palestinians (News, last week) - consistently kicked around like footballs - has been so like the history of the Jews. The British and French gave their country to the Hashemites and called it Jordan (even today, there is perhaps no other country in the world that has a majority of its population with a foreign nationality; in this case, Palestinian).

Since the establishment of Israel (approved by a UN majority vote), the Palestinians' Arab brethren have supported their hope for a return to their homeland by paying for war against Israel. Their millions (from Saudi, Lybia, Iran) were channelled straight into the war effort, and the PLO's coffers. The shanty towns, mostly in the brethrens' countries, have remained devoid of improved sanitation, housing, education.

No wonder the Palestinians hate. Sadly, that hate is concentrated on the Israelis, and not on those who have dictated the story from behind the scenes. As soon as Chairman Arafat had clasped the hand of Yitzhak Rabin, the flow of Arab funds disappeared. Arafat then came cap in hand to the Japanese, the European Community and to the US for financial support to re-construct Palestine. Now the fighting is back; hatred has again taken over. Why does your story of renewed funds from Saudi not come as a surprise to me? What price peace?
Stephen Pohlmann
London W14

fields.headline: Hope for Glory?
fields.trailText: I was listening to Elgar's 'Pomp and Circumstance March' on Classic FM the other day as I was driving along. My first thought was, 'What a shame that the words in "Land of Hope and Glory" are no longer appropriate.'
fields.body:
I was listening to Elgar's 'Pomp and Circumstance March' on Classic FM the other day as I was driving along. My first thought was, 'What a shame that the words in "Land of Hope and Glory" are no longer appropriate.'

My second thought was, 'Why not modify them to make them appropriate for today!' The Scots and Welsh have their own stirring national anthems and we need an equally stirring English one, rather than the somewhat dreary British National Anthem, for uniquely English occasions.

I look forward to the roofs of the stands at Twickenham being lifted off to some such rousing anthem.
Professor Brian Wilson
Olney, Bucks

webTitle: Foreign tongues spread the English word

fields.headline: Foreign tongues spread the English word
fields.trailText: The accented English of fluent foreigners such as Latino singer Ricky Martin or actress Juliette Binoche is usurping British and American English as the dominant form of the language.
fields.body:
The accented English of fluent foreigners such as Latino singer Ricky Martin or actress Juliette Binoche is usurping British and American English as the dominant form of the language.

This week the Government will announce that the number of people with English as a second language has overtaken the number who speak it as their native tongue.

According to the figures, by the end of the year as many as 750 million people will speak English well enough to use it for business, and as many as a billion people are thought to be learning English at any given time.

The British Council statistics have been seized on by Education and Employment Secretary David Blunkett, who will tell a meeting of business leaders on Tuesday to capitalise on their advantage as native speakers.

English-language books, films and TV shows are worth nearly £5 billion to the British economy, with education materials alone worth £1.2bn. But the rush to share Shakespeare's tongue may see British schoolchildren lose the motivation to learn foreign languages.

Insiders say the drive to make English the global lingua franca comes directly from Tony Blair. The so-called 'Blair Initiative' was launched in 1998 after the Prime Minister was told off by the Mayor of Shanghai, Xu Kuangdi, for failing to promote English abroad. On his return, Blair ordered the British Council to remedy the situation and allocated £5 million for English-language initiatives. The anglophile Xu, who lived as a student in London in the Eighties, said the French, Germans and Americans were far better at promoting their culture. They may also soon be far better at speaking English.

webTitle: Nigella Lawson needs no such defence

fields.headline: Nigella Lawson needs no such defence
fields.trailText: I've only spent one evening in Nigella Lawson's company, but even such a thoroughly unpleasant person as myself could see what an extremely attractive person she is - physically, and in all the other ways that a person can be attractive.
fields.body:
I've only spent one evening in Nigella Lawson's company, but even such a thoroughly unpleasant person as myself could see what an extremely attractive person she is - physically, and in all the other ways that a person can be attractive.

However, I find myself shocked and confused by Carol Sarler's babbling defence of her (Comment, last week). (And the idea that such a formidable woman as Nigella needs defending is an insult in itself, especially in so ill-sorted and over-heated a manner.)

Is Carol Sarler really saying that if someone's spouse is seriously ill, they should be beyond criticism? Really? Why?
Julie Burchill
Brighton

I am really pleased to note that Carol Sarler put the record straight about Nigella Lawson. I've never met the lady either, but have been deeply impressed at the courage and dignity displayed by herself and her family in the face of impending sorrow and loss of immense proportions.

Along with the wit and elegance characterising her recent publication, Nigella has shared her vulnerability with the public - how ironic that it is fellow journalists that have given her such short shrift in exchange. Sad, too, that people who should know better have jumped on that bandwagon so hastily.
Ellen Barr
Colchester, Essex

Carol Sarler makes some odd points in defence of Nigella Lawson. John Diamond's illness is a personal tragedy but should not be used in Nigella's defence. He's already used it as a successful column, book and even play. That's quite enough uses for any illness.

Ms Lawson makes women jealous and irritable because she pretends to think that her lifestyle is not unique and that every hack can afford expensive nurseries, large agreeable houses to work from and guaranteed commissions from cringing editors.

And quite frankly, if she is as concerned about her husband as Sarler claims, then perhaps she should be taking on less work, not more.

As for Sarler's claim that 'journalism exists on Earth for higher purpose', what on this particular Earth was she thinking when she wrote that sanctimonious nonsense? Journalism has many rooms; some people risk their lives writing about dictatorships, others write cookery columns. Others, it seems, toss off any old junk to fill space on a Sunday.
Nicholas Harman
London SW16

fields.headline: Beatles forever
fields.trailText: Stephen Bayley's review of The Beatles Anthology and Lennon Remembers (Books, last week) made me very angry. What does he mean by writing 'there is something - close to ineffable melancholy - that makes the Beatles difficult to listen to'?
fields.body:
Stephen Bayley's review of The Beatles Anthology and Lennon Remembers (Books, last week) made me very angry. What does he mean by writing 'there is something - close to ineffable melancholy - that makes the Beatles difficult to listen to'?

The Beatles music can be sad, but it can also be life-affirming, amusing, incisive and it sounds as fresh to me today as it did more than 30 years ago - though I was a little girl at the time! Bayley fails to explore the extraordinary alchemy of talent of the Beatles and those surrounding them.
Helen Manthorp
Birmingham

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText:
Clocks go back one hour
British Summer Time ended at 2am today. Clocks were put back one hour to Greenwich Mean Time.
fields.body:
Clocks go back one hour
British Summer Time ended at 2am today. Clocks were put back one hour to Greenwich Mean Time.

Sex probe priest 'takes leave'
Father Gerard Flahive, a Catholic priest in Sheldon, Birmingham, at the centre of a police investigation into more than 20 years of alleged child abuse, has been ordered to take 'administrative leave'.

March over deaths in custody
The families of people who have died in police custody, prison or psychiatric hospitals marched to Downing Street yesterday. They demanded an independent inquiry into the 'scandal of custody deaths'.

Arrest as saboteurs target start of fox hunting season
On the first day of the fox hunting season a man was arrested after about 20 saboteurs gathered at the Old Surrey Burstow and West Kent Hunt at Chiddingstone.

Payout after school bullying
A Manchester teenager, now 17, who was the victim of homophobic bullying at Sale Grammar School when he was 12, has been awarded £1,500 damages by his local authority because the school was in breach of its duty of care. His solicitor said it was the first such case to be brought successfully to court.

Crime hatched
The uniform and truncheon of Chief Superintendent David Hatcher, familiar to viewers of TV's Crimewatch UK, were taken from his car by a thief who used them to rob a petrol station at Denham, Bucks.

Furry friends
Naturalists have found red squirrels living beside grey ones in urban woods at Fazakerley, Merseyside. Grey squirrels have driven the red out of many parts of the UK.

24 hours of Des
Nurses at Gloucestershire Royal Hospital raised £700 for equipment by staging a 'Boring Day'. They listened to Des O'Connor records for 24 hours.

Australia is dream destination
A poll for the Association of British Travel Agents shows that Australia is the destination most Britons would pick for a holiday if money were no object. The US was second. One per cent chose England.

fields.headline: Irish News and Mr O'Conner
fields.trailText: Henry McDonald, in his column of 22 October (page 31, Irish edition), headed 'In peace, truth dies', directed extremely serious and entirely unfounded accusations against the Irish News.
fields.body:
Henry McDonald, in his column of 22 October (page 31, Irish edition), headed 'In peace, truth dies', directed extremely serious and entirely unfounded accusations against the Irish News.

Mr McDonald's article referred to a 'corrosion of journalistic values', and went on to assert that large sections of the Irish media had ignored 'uncomfortable facts' in an attempt to protect the Good Friday Agreement.

He singled out the Irish News for criticism in this regard, and specifically alleged that we initially suggested that the recent murder of Joseph O'Connor in west Belfast was the work of the Continuity IRA rather than the Provisional IRA.

No one who has read the coverage provided by the Irish News in the wake of the killing could possibly recognise this version of events.

Mr O'Connor was shot dead on Friday 13 October. The Irish News of the following day was the first news organisation to carry an interview with the O'Connor family, and the first to report the belief of some of the close relatives of the victim that he had been shot by the Provisional IRA.

This story was published on our front page, under the headline 'It was the Provos, says victim's mother', and was extensively followed up by other sections of the media - including The Observer.

Reports in the Irish News over the following week followed a similar theme.

On Thursday 19 October, an Irish News editorial said: 'Although the Provisional IRA has formally denied involvement in the killing of Mr O'Connor, few people in west Belfast have any doubts about who was responsible.'

We went on to list three other recent high-profile murders which were widely believed to have been carried out by the Provisional IRA, despite official statements of denial from the organisation.

In the light of this comprehensive range of material, it was astonishing that Mr McDonald should set out to imply that we had attempted to blame elements other than the Provisionals for the O'Connor murder.
Noel Doran, editor, Irish News

webTitle: EC ban on transfer fees threatens small clubs

fields.headline: Football's past giants face worst penalty
fields.trailText: They are some of the most famous names in English football, evoking memories of an era when fans all wore flat caps, players earned just a few shillings and television coverage was black and white, not digital interactive.
fields.body:
They are some of the most famous names in English football, evoking memories of an era when fans all wore flat caps, players earned just a few shillings and television coverage was black and white, not digital interactive.

But now a host of clubs synonymous with the game's 'golden era', such as Blackpool, Stoke City and Preston North End, are threatened with extinction. A hard-hitting new report warns that scores of the smaller teams among the country's 92 professional clubs could go to the wall because of Europe's controversial drive to scrap transfer fees for players switching clubs.

Leading accountants Deloitte and Touche predict many clubs could either be put out of business, forced to go part-time or be left having to sack players to survive if they are deprived of the income selling talent brings.

They warn that the romance and unpredictability of the domestic game's chase for trophies, and the potential for smaller clubs to beat bigger rivals, will disappear as football becomes increasingly polarised between a rich elite and a much larger number of poor outfits struggling just to stay afloat.

Money currently spent on transfer fees would instead fund hugely increased wages for top stars, who already earn an average £8,000-a-week in the Premier League. Tens of millions of pounds a year would thus leave the game to fund even more lavish lifestyles for players rather than circulating between clubs as a rich-to-poor subsidy.

The English tradition of at least one football team in almost every big town could be at risk as the game is dominated more and more by well-supported big city sides, the study says.

'Football's current [transfer] system helps to bridge the gap not only between big and small, but also geographically, ensuring that football survives in smaller towns, protecting local economies, jobs, identity, pride and social well-being,' the report warns. 'The transfer system is a force for cohesion.'

Deloitte and Touche forecast that ending transfer fees, which the European Commission insists are illegal, will ruin the game as we know it. European football has until Tuesday to try and persuade the EC not to press ahead with its widely criticised plan. But hopes of a compromise have been hit by feuding between the football authorities and the body representing Europe's players.

EC competition commissioner Mario Monti claims transfer payments restrict a player's freedom under the Treaty of Rome to work where he likes. Big-money moves such as Luis Figo's £37 million switch last summer from Barcelona to Real Madrid have angered EC officials.

Uefa, European football's governing body, commissioned the accountants to analyse the likely effects across the continent of outlawing transfer fees, which have existed since 1890. The report backs Uefa's claim they are a vital method of redistributing wealth from well-off clubs and countries to their needier rivals and thus ensuring their viability.

It shows that clubs in the Football League receive tens of millions of pounds a year more in fees from their more glamorous Premier League counterparts than they spend buying players from the top flight. This redistribution of wealth is vital to cover losses in the lower leagues caused by poor crowds, lack of sponsorship and minimal television revenue.

Deloitte and Touche's examination of football clubs' finances shows many get over half their income from transfers. If this goes, minnows of the game such as Crewe Alexandra and Darlington, which have to sell to survive, would be at risk.

'The majority of players would undergo a reduction in salaries and/or lose their jobs as clubs reduce the number of full-time players or go part-time,' says the report.

Production of young players would also be decimated because, with players able to leave for free, clubs would no longer have a financial incentive to nurture talent.

Football League spokesman John Nagle said the report was 'overly pessimistic. Clubs are a lot more resilient than some people think.'

denis.campbell@observer.co.uk
