webTitle: Miranda Sawyer: Talk about pop music

fields.headline: Talk about pop music
fields.trailText: It wasn't until a bit later that I realised that What Music Do You Like was a loaded question: that it meant What Kind Of Person Are You, Really, Inside, and that there were right and wrong answers.
fields.body:
When I was in my early teens, I used to tape the Top 40, every week, every record, from 40 up to Number One. No editing required: ELO, Bucks Fizz, The Kids From Fame sat alongside The Jam, The Clash, John Lennon, and I thought of them all the same. They were just music, the soundtrack to the hopes and obsessions and unspecific hatred of teenage life. When I got a babysitting job and started buying records, I progressed into making compilation tapes: these too, were a mishmash of quality and dross. My brother and I didn't have enough records of our own to fill a 90-minute tape, so my parents' collection - Frank Sinatra, Petula Clark, Burt Bacharach, Bobbie Gentry - was raided to make up numbers. (Taping was a tricky business in the DIY days of the 80s. We had one of those flat-box tape recorders whose microphone registered - fuzzily - every noise within a 4ft radius. You positioned it as close to the record player as you could, put the needle on the 45, pressed down Play and Record and hoped that your mum wouldn't start hoovering in the next three-and-a-half minutes.)

It wasn't until a bit later that I realised that What Music Do You Like was a loaded question: that it meant What Kind Of Person Are You, Really, Inside, and that there were right and wrong answers. Right: New Order, Aretha Franklin, The Fall, Sam Cooke. Wrong: Howard Jones. So I began editing my still-meagre record collection, taping from friends', listening to John Peel, going to clubs, acquiring knowledge and taste and a personal soundtrack that hinted at an intriguing, seductive inner life. 'Ooh, you like Prefab Sprout and Public Enemy! Sensitive yet punchy! A bedwetter with an attitude problem! Care for a shag?'

Such musical - and therefore personal - revision isn't uncommon. There are those who love to recall their Quadrophenia Road to Damascus but not the years they spent listening to mullet-headed cock rock. And you'll never get a 'serious' musician admitting that the first record he ever bought was Bat Out of Hell. We all want to think that we're smart, and have always been so. We strive to learn discernment, to acquire good taste. Yet bad taste will always haunt you. You wake up humming Sonique, you find your foot tapping to Johnny Hates Jazz. Failing memory may mean that you can't recall the name of the shadow trade and industry secretary, nor, indeed, your beloved's birthday. But you will forever know all the words to 'The Piña Colada Song'. And you never even bought the record.

It's music's dreadful ability to dole out Tiger balm for the soul and candyfloss for the mind that has made all those 70s, 80s and 90s Saturday-night telly Top 10s so popular. Essentially, such programmes are just compilation tapes without the aren't-I-clever reworking of hindsight. So you have to sit through Sheena Easton to get to David Bowie, Vanilla Ice to get to Happy Mondays. And you are appalled, and then inspired, because now you can see how great 'Ashes to Ashes' was and you actually understand the words to 'Too Much, Too Young' and you wiggle on the sofa in wonder at 'Kinky Afro' and you finally realise that 'Dance Yourself Dizzy' was utter cack. Yet you can't help singing along. Why is that?

Music is a soul shorthand in a way that books and films and art can never be. It comes closest to expressing our inarticulate yearnings; it provides us with fallible, reachable heroes; it's utterly accessible, a globe-trotting artform that floods our lives simply when we switch on a radio or walk into a bar. You don't have to pay a gallery entrance fee or lock yourself away to read in order to change your world with music. You can be moved to tears whilst doing the washing up. Music is one of the true joys of existence. And maybe bad music is part of that joy. Trite lyrics and predictable tunes provide us with easy comfort, a hug in times of uncertainty, a sugar-rush when it seems too much effort to get out of bed. Descending basslines seem to know where they're going, as Stephen Duffy once said.

webTitle: My money: Rev Dr Colin Morris

fields.headline: Daily thoughts for a reluctant capitalist
fields.standfirst: A top job, a good pension - troubling for a Methodist socialist
fields.trailText: A top job, a good pension - troubling for a Methodist socialist.
fields.body:
Had the Rev Dr Colin Morris remained merely a minister in the Methodist Church, he would now, at 70, be living on a modest pension. Instead, as a former television executive and a regular broadcaster, his retirement is a very comfortable one.

But Morris's feelings about money are far less comfortable. What comes across in his broadcasts (often for BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day ) is a sense of unease, even guilt.

It started in his twenties when he went to Africa as a missionary. 'After being ordained at university, I was sent to the copper belt of Northern Rhodesia. I had a good house and car, in fact a standard of living much better than I'd enjoyed back in Britain - it was almost embarrassing,' he says.

'There's an unresolvable tension because, as a Christian minister, you follow someone who had nowhere to lay his head and yet you're one of the best off in the community.'

Morris describes his early life as classic How Green Was My Valley - his father was a coal miner and trade union activist, unemployed for periods. Morris grew up as both a socialist and a non-conformist and the influences remain strong. 'I've got this nonconformist conviction that one should live within one's means,' he says, 'so I live in absolute horror of being overdrawn. But I know it's a very unsophisticated way of understanding money'.

After returning from Africa in the Seventies, Morris spent several years in the Methodist ministry at Wesley's Chapel in London.

But just as his financial fortunes improved when he became a missionary, so they changed again when he started to present the BBC's new religious programme Everyman.

That led to the job of head of religious programmes and life as a TV executive. 'When I went from being a Methodist minister to head of religious TV, I began to wonder how I'd ever lived on one penny less than I was now earning. Money becomes an absolute necessity. I was dealing with enormous budgets, and it's amazing how quickly you get used to signing large cheques with a flourish.

'I had started off in the anti-capitalist mode, but later I realised capitalism wasn't going to go away. It would be hypocritical to condemn it utterly and draw a pension made by a capitalist system.'

Instead Morris tried at least to be a humane capital ist - espousing ethical investment, the work of Jubilee 2000 in reducing Third World debt and making charitable donations.

Morris feels very lucky to have his BBC pension. His tastes are hardly extravagant: a little flat by the sea, books and the F-reg, 3-series BMW he bought from the BBC when he retired. But being comfortable hasn't taken away the difficult questions.

As a young missionary he admired the White Fathers, a Roman Catholic order that adopted the local population's way of life. He says: 'People like that have an unchallengeable authority as exemplars of the way of Jesus - not having possessions, and turning the other cheek.

'We know that to do it would throw society into chaos. But it's a crunch issue for people like me, because in the end theology isn't what you talk, it's what you do.'

fields.headline: Green houses that we can all warm to
fields.standfirst: Mainstream developers are going eco-friendly,  says Graham Norwood
fields.trailText: Mainstream developers are going eco-friendly, says Graham Norwood.
fields.body:
Energy efficiency is no longer the preserve of the worthy environmentalists or the well-off who design their own eco-friendly houses.

Some of Britain's most expensive properties have long had solar panels, water recycling and more fuel-efficient versions of air-conditioning - but at a cost. Now a new generation of builders are experimenting with relatively low-cost energy-saving measures in comparatively modest houses.

Try Homes, one of Britain's largest builders of new houses, has installed a 'heat recovery' air-conditioning system in some of its new properties. The system uses heat from stale air being expelled from the house to warm new air being bought in .

Insulation in Try's houses exceeds those levels recommended by the National House Building Council, which works out efficiency criteria based on the size of the house, whether it is detached or terraced, and which types of glazing and heating are installed. These properties cost about £180,000 each. Meanwhile, Berkeley Homes is going one step further at its Tydevale development near Newbury. Berkeley has built a four-bedroom house from natural resources with recycling at the heart of its design.

It is timber-framed and has no external brickwork, just wood cladding with an acrylic rendering; plasterboard is used instead of wet plaster for interior walls, and pulped newspaper forms a highly efficient insulating material called Warmcell in the loft and lagged areas. Solar panels will be used for heating, and recycled water from baths and showers is treated before being re-used to flush the toilets.

It is thought this pioneer Integer House could sell for more than £400,000 but a local housing association will rent it for two years to gauge how well it works - then a more modest version will go into low-scale production at different new developments.

But what of older houses? These are notoriously inefficient with more than 40 per cent of the heat being lost through roofs and walls.

The Government is also launching a new £4m campaign by the Energy Saving Trust to heighten awareness of energy conservation and grants to improve peoples' homes.

Grants may be available if you:

 switch from gas or electricity to oil or liquid petroleum gas as your main home fuel.

 switch from a conventional to a condensing boiler.

 use a specialist-approved contractor to insulate walls and roofs with high-quality material.

The EST is also setting up advice centres and mobile energy consultants around the country to hammer home the point to consumers. Simple energy-awareness could save a typical household about £250 a year (see tips below).

Such savings are crucial for those on fixed or limited incomes. Pensioner Bill Crowther, an 80-year-old retired insurance broker who lives with his wife in a three-bedroom bungalow near Matlock in Derbyshire, is benefiting from energy savings.

'I had a small mortgage with the Halifax, but when they demutualised I decided to get one from somewhere more ethical. I approached the Ecology Building Society but they insisted that I make the house more energy-efficient before I could get a mortgage.' says Crowther.

He spent £1,000 on hiring professionals to improve loft and wall insulation and update the gas central heating in his £100,000 house. The Crowthers are already saving between 10 per cent and 15 per cent on their gas bills 'and the house feels a lot snugger now', he insists.

'Of course I was aware of how you could make things more energy-efficient, but I thought it was less feasible for an ordinary property. Even though I had a little money invested in the Ecology I hadn't really consid ered doing it until I asked for the mortgage. It will undoubtedly pay for itself over a few years - if I'm still around to appreciate it.'

This latest drive towards home fuel efficiency comes in the wake of John Major's Home Energy Conservation Act of 1996, which set local councils tough targets to improve all domestic fuel efficiency by up to 30 per cent by 2010. The property finance industry has been quick to offer mortgages with an energy-efficient edge.

The Ecology offers a range of mortgages, although borrowers do not have to be green-minded. The Norwich and Peterborough society offers green mortgages to those with homes that already have a good efficiency rating, or to individuals who want to upgrade their homes to that level.

Both societies specialise in self-build mortgages for individuals building their own houses - often the best way of maximising energy-efficiency at home.

How to save energy

Low-cost or no-cost ways to cut your heating bills:

 Draw curtains at night to prevent heat being lost through windows

 Turn the thermostat down by one degree celsius and heat your home one hour less daily

 Keep the thermostat on your water heater at about 60 degrees celsius

 Showers use less water than baths - and put the plug in your sink to avoid leaving the hot tap running

 Turn off lights when you leave rooms for long periods, and switch off TVs properly - 'standby' uses up to 60 per cent of the electricity

 Defrost fridges regularly

 Make sure washing machines and dishwashers have full loads, and use low-temperature settings if possible

 Use only the minimum water you need for cooking or making drinks

 Use low-energy lamps: they use 75 per cent less electricity and last 10 times as long

 Insulate the loft, which often accounts for the loss of 25 per cent of a house's heat, and make sure hot water tanks and pipes are lagged

Source: London Electricity

Contacts

Free government energy-saving pack 0345 277200

Online energy efficiency tips at www.saveenergy.co.uk

Local Energy Efficiency Advice Centre 0800 512 012

Berkeley Homes 01256 814314

Try Homes 01932 245 800

Ecology Building Society 01535 635933

Norwich and Peterborough Building Society 01733 372372

webTitle: Credit cards have a euro headache

fields.headline: Bubble bursts on a bargain
fields.standfirst: Andrew Bibby on a euro bill mix-up
fields.trailText: Andrew Bibby on a euro bill mix-up
fields.body:
Dr Linda Patterson has a dozen or so champagne bottles in her kitchen waiting to be drunk, a souvenir of a summer holiday spent this year travelling through the Champagne region of eastern France. Far from representing an opportunity for celebration, however, the bottles are simply the cause of a credit card headache.

Having taken the guided tour around Moët and Chandon's famous champagne cellars, Linda Patterson, an NHS consultant, decided also to drop in for a degustation at one of the many small family-run champagne establishments near Epernay.

She and her partner got a warm welcome from the husband and wife who greeted them. 'We went into a little courtyard with a table, and were brought glasses from a number of different bottles to try. I decided to buy six full bottles and six half bottles,' she says.

As well as providing a very pleasant memento of the holiday, buying direct seemed to make good financial sense: the full bottles cost 74 francs (or about £7.40) and the half-bottles 40 francs. 'We were quite pleased. It was a lot less expensive than the prices being charged at Moët,' Patterson says.

However, when the credit card statement arrived after the holiday they got a shock. The total came not to about £65 but £417.24. The bottles in her kitchen had effectively cost her about £45 each.

Dr Patterson had been the victim of a problem that affected other English holidaymakers in France this summer. Instead of the transaction being processed in francs, it had been put through as a payment made in euros. With the euro currently worth about 70p, this meant that the total was seven times greater than it should have been.

French bills and receipts are now usually denominated in both currencies, and Visa says that a number of cases have come to light where credit card payments have come through in the wrong currency. According to a Visa spokeswoman, the problem seems to be retailer confusion rather than fraud. 'We have an obvious concern about this issue, and we're trying to find out if there are retailers who are trying it on. But there's no record of this sort of thing going on regularly,' she said.

Dr Patterson hopes that her experience was simply the result of an error. 'I want to think that the couple who sold us the champagne made an honest mistake. They seemed very nice, and waved us off with a friendly "Bon voyage". But, obviously, it could be a pretty good wheeze,' she says. Her own credit card company, the Co- operative Bank, is formally investigating the transaction through Visa's disputed payments mechanism, following the payment chain, through Visa International and the French merchant processor to the champagne sellers. The Co-op says this process can take 60 days or longer.

Although disputed payments should not incur penalties, Dr Patterson's most recent Visa statement does show interest added for late payment. This adds to the overall feeling of pressure, she says.

She is fortunate in that she still has an original price list showing the prices for the champagne she bought clearly denominated in francs. But her experience should remind other visitors to France (and to the other 10 countries that have adopted the euro) of the importance of checking the currency in which credit card bills are written and of keeping receipts.

Worryingly, Barclaycard, Britain's largest credit card issuer, warns that the onus is on customers to ensure they do not find themselves paying more than they should.

webTitle: With all potential damages I thee endow

fields.headline: With all potential damages I thee endow
fields.standfirst: Neasa MacErlean  on the implications of the pillion widow case for all married couples
fields.trailText: Neasa MacErlean on the implications of the pillion widow case for all married couples.
fields.body:
Many couples may have shuddered when they heard this month about the sad case of widow Sadie Dalziel, whose damages following the death of her husband were reduced by £100,000 in a court case because he had been cheating on her.

Jason Dalziel died in 1996, at the age of 26, when his motorbike collided with a car. His wife, now 30, had never suspected his infidelity until she found out he had been involved for a year with the woman who was the pillion passenger in the accident. Elizabeth Simpson survived the crash and provided more evidence of the fragility of the Dalziel marriage - because he had also proposed to her.

Under existing law, Privilege Insurance, the car driver's insurer, was entirely within its rights to ask that the damages be reduced to the widow on the grounds that the marriage looked un-likely to last. The judge, who presided over the High Court hearing this month, Robert Moxon-Browne QC, was also acting in accordance with the law when he reduced Sadie Dalziel's payout by about 40 per cent because he believed the argument that the marriage was quite likely to fall apart.

Although the Association of British Insurers claims the case is something of a one-off, many married couples may wonder what could happen to them in similar circumstances. Figures from the Office of National Statistics show that while 304,000 couples tied the knot in 1998, about 160,000 got divorced. With divorce rates of about 50 per cent, should we all be worried?

The answer is probably yes. Even Mrs Dalziel's solicitor, David Faithful of Amery Parkes in Birmingham, accepts the basic law is very clear: 'The way the law stands at the mo-ment, judges are entitled to discount damages on the basis that there will be a divorce.'

Faithful believes there could be many disputes of this type, although few go to court: 'These cases are very, very rare. It's a matter for insurers what tactics they adopt.'

Fighting this sort of case is very expensive. It has cost Mrs Dalziel about £10,000 and the issue of money is going to lie very heavily with her, a nursery nurse, when she decides in the next three weeks whether to appeal.

There are two ways this sort of dispute could be treated more sympathetically. The first would involve a more un-derstanding view of marital strife by judges. Many experts believe infidelity is not a strong indicator of relationship breakdown.

Family solicitor Mark Har-per of law firm Withers will not comment on the Dalziel case but asks: 'How can a judge make a decision as to whe-ther a marriage is likely to end just because there has been an affair? Many of my clients tell me of past affairs which have not led to the breakdown of the marriage. It is a very big assumption to say that the existence of another relationship would lead to the breakdown of the marriage. Who can make that judgment?'

It seems as if many other legal and family experts agree. The Law Commission last year urged the government to change procedures so that damages would be reduced only if there were objective evidence of impending divorce, such as the start of divorce proceedings.

The commission is charged with making recommendations for better law. About 70 per cent of its recommendations do eventually make it to the statute books. But the big problem is usually finding the political will for the allocation of parliamentary time.

A spokesman for the Lord Chancellor's Department said: 'The issue is being looked at by officials - but there isn't yet a set date for publishing a definitive report.'

So the status quo will prevail. Damages in these sorts of cases are set very clinically under the Fatal Accidents Act 1976. This legislation sets out the procedures for calculating 'dependency claims' - looking at how much the de-ceased earned, for instance, assuming that 75 per cent of the income went on maintaining the family, deducting the other 25 per cent from the claim, deducting the surviving spouse's income, calculating the life expectancy of the spouse and then making other deductions for possible divorce, poor promotion pros-pects or ill health of the deceased.

Solicitor Anne Davies of law firm Vizards Staples & Bannisters acts for insurance companies and believes the Dalziel case could become an important one. 'The judgment will be used in other cases where a wid-ow is claiming against third parties,' she says. 'There seems to have been a very substantial reduction for a risk that seems to be not particularly quantifiable.'

Insurance lawyers will scrutinise the transcript of the judgement when it comes out - to see if other factors, such as Jason Dal- ziel's apparently poor promotion prospects in the army, also played a part in the discounts to the damages.

The case has clear implications for other people who are killed through the negligence of others. As well as traffic accidents, it could apply to disputes over people killed in the workplace. But, says Davies, it has fewer implications for people with life policies, travel insurance policies and other direct contracts with insurance companies. 'I would want to look at the wording of a life policy, but normally there wouldn't be a deduction of this kind to a widow,' she says.

The difference between the two types of case is that the Dalziel claim is against a third party, the driver of the car which killed her husband, someone whose liability to her was based on his negligence. But a claim on a spouse's insurance policy is one based on a very clear contract which sets out the basis for any claim.

Could it be possible, however, for lawyers in cases of the Dalziel kind to force down damages payments on the grounds that one in two marriages is likely to fail? 'Even as a lawyer who de-fends insurance companies, I would find that an unpalatable argument,' says Davies. 'I don't think it would be accepted.'

But we do not know what is happening in the cases settled out of court.

webTitle: Small businesses: Small can be beautiful

fields.headline: Small can be beautiful
fields.standfirst: Five owners of small businesses share their experiences
fields.trailText: Five owners of small businesses share their experiences.
fields.body:
Toy story of long hours and faith in the catalogue

Dawson & Son
Saffron Walden, Essex

Nigel Dawson founded a mail order company selling traditional wooden toys after he was made redundant two years ago.

He found himself with a 'reasonable' sum of money, which he lived on, and took the chance to set up Dawson & Son. He was looking for wooden toys for his son but was disappointed with what he'd found in the shops. His market research consisted of thinking: 'If I want to buy wooden toys, so must a lot of other people'.

Nigel owns the company with his wife Jo. He employs eight people, four full-time, the others part-time. This year he expects his turnover to be £500,000.

'When you run your own business, everything is down to you,' he says. 'It cost me far more money than I ever thought. If you think it's going to cost you £20,000 to set up your business, double it, and if you think you're going to get a salary from it in six months, budget on 12.

'There are so many unknowns and potential mistakes. I remember working out that if I placed an advert in a particular magazine with a readership of 1 million and got a response of 1 per cent, I would get so much. It was complete garbage: you just don't achieve that. Things never work out the way you'd think.

'But I think that if I put in 100 per cent, things may not be as I planned, but they'll still be all right.'

'The new catalogue went out in September. Before that, the financial situation was very close. We had very little money left. But we had to believe that the catalogue we were sending out would produce revenue. The moment it hits the mat, the phones ring.'

'At the moment, I'm working a minimum of 14 hours a day, seven days a week. It's the busiest time of year and I have to put the hours in. I don't see my wife very much. I don't see our two children. But it's only between now and Christmas.'

'I've got a couple of friends who run their own businesses, and everyone says the biggest problem is staff. You try to pay them a decent wage and look after them, but it's another learning curve for me. You have to learn about everything: accountancy, computers. Mail order is very analytical. We buy databases. It costs about 10p a person, but then you've got to print and post the catalogue. An average response is about 3 per cent.

'When I check the competition, products I had last year are now appearing in other people's catalogues. I should be selling the doll's house for £130 but John Lewis is selling it at £99.99 for Christmas, so to compete I also sell it at £99.99.

'I've never sold toys and I've never had a website so I'm going to make mistakes. But the quicker you realise that you've made a mistake and learn from it and move on, the better. If you try to hang on in there and think that things are going to get better, they're not.'

Hard graft to reach soft centre

Druid Chocolates

Dublin

A love of chocolate has become a business for ex- insurance underwriter Gareth Vaughan and former teacher Ana Marcos.

Gareth, from Dundalk in the Irish Republic, and Ana, from Spain, met when they were both working in Ipswich. His passion for chocolate started when he worked as a student in a chocolate shop in the US. Years later, he lived from savings and worked with the luxury chocolate company, Wittamer, in Brussels.

They started Druid Chocolates in 1996 in Dublin, selling to specialist shops and through their own website. Fortnum and Mason is the first shop outside Ireland to sell their wares. Their turnover this year is expected to be £250,000.

Gareth says: 'It hasn't been an easy ride and it's hard in that you do work 16 or 18 hours a day and you don't get a wage at the end of the month. You know that you have to move forward but you're finding your way.

'When Ana and I came back to Ireland in 1996 we hooked up with an enterprise development programme in Dublin. They gave us a free telephone and about £85 per week. We used a kitchen in the enterprise centre, so we didn't have to worry about health requirements and we started selling chocolates at farmers' markets.

'The chocolate arrives in 10 kilo bricks of chocolate from Belgium. We blend it with fresh Irish cream and butter, and it has its own distinctive taste. We chose the name Druid because it has Celtic and magical associations, and rolls off the tongue.

'I'm still not drawing a full salary but I am earning more than I was earning as an underwriter in Ipswich, although that was five years ago. Now there are eight people on the payroll. About a year ago we knew that we had to start paying ourselves salaries and making profits. The only way to do that was by taking on help to free us up to develop the marketing.

'Starting the business was a personal thing as well as a business thing. Going from insurance to chocolate is a funny transition.

'Yet while people in chocolate tend to work hard and get stressed at Christmas, they're happy.'

Ana says: 'When I met Gareth he started giving me chocolates he'd made himself - classic truffles, with cocoa powder on top. They didn't look very good, but I thought it was so romantic. We weren't happy with the jobs we were doing, and one day we suddenly said: "Why don't we make them for other people?" '

'We had the spirit to do it. We looked under every stone for money and I didn't buy clothes for two years, but when you're busy doing what you want, nothing else matters.

'I used to dream about chocolate but now I dream about finances. I've learnt expressions that I can't translate into Spanish, such as cash flow management. Our sales are growing. We employ six people and they're always coming up with new ideas.

'In the beginning you work all the time, but now we're starting to have a life as well as a business.'

More than a job, less than a life

Number Seven Cafe and deli

Liverpool

0151 709 9633

Helen and Martin Ainscough are siblings and they set up Number Seven, a deli and cafe, five years ago. They now have two pubs, two restaurants and a catering business and next month they're opening Station, a cafe/restaurant/food emporium in Hamilton Square, in the historic Birkenhead area, part of the Hamilton Quarter Initiative regeneration programme. Their turnover is £2.5 million.

Helen says: 'It's enslavement! People imagine that it's really fantastic because you're your own boss and in control of your time but in reality you're not. I made sandwiches all day today because someone didn't turn up in the deli. There is a sense of achievement but there's a real downside to never being let off the hook.

'In terms of salary, I pro-bably earn the same as I did when I was employed: about £23,000 a year, but that's probably about £2 per hour with the amount of hours I work! But I do have a company car and I never buy food because I'm never at home.

'Since I started I haven't really had a holiday. I do feel knackered. I think it's bad in a way because I've become less sociable, although some of my work is really sociable and fun because we're entertaining people. I've been saying to Martin: "I can't go on like this, working 18-hour days. I'd like to rebalance my life a bit and feel less enslaved." One good thing is that I'll have saved up enough to go to The Priory.'

Martin says: 'When you run your own business, you have total freedom: you don't have to answer to anyone yet you're at the beck and call of the business 24 hours a day. I work from 8am until whenever each day, usually until 8pm but probably a bit later. I also work at weekends. As we get bigger, we're determined to lead a more normal life. I'm quite relaxed about it, but Helen worries a lot. She said that she woke up at five this morning, worrying about how we'll get through Christmas.

'We were very lucky because we inherited some money so we've financed what we've done, although there was a big risk when we opened Number Seven and a lot of people thought we were mad. It is generating cash now but that's after five years. We pay ourselves a salary and we put a lot of money into a pension. We pay £1 million a year in wages as we now employ 200 people, but a lot of them work part-time.

'We bought Station, which is in a Regency building, for £150,000 and we'll probably spend half a million on it. We've got grants from English Heritage and the European Development Fund.

'I'm not very good at managing people. Helen's very good at that. I want to keep people and keep them interested so it's all about staff development.

'I would earn about five times as much if I were employed, but what I was doing before wasn't creative. Money isn't everything.'

Keeping their options open

Working Options

020 8932 1462

Working Options is a recruitment consultancy for part-time professionals, set up in January 1999 by Elaine Howe and Lindsay Swan, neighbours in Ealing, London. Elaine is an accountant and Lindsay used to run a PR company. They started Working Options with mothers in mind, but now have 2,000 candidates on their books - many of them men. Most want to work part-time because of children, but others are writing books, going to college,or retraining. Their turnover is 'a six-figure number - but not colossal'. This year they will double it.

Elaine Howe says: 'What I love about it is the flexibility. The flipside is that it's in the home and it's very long hours. I stop work at about 5.30pm for the children but then at about 9pm I'm back at my desk until 11.

'We're now at a point where we need to move the business to the next phase and with that will come the need for outside investment. That will feel different be-cause we'll have to answer to someone. It will have to be more structured. So far we've spent £4,000 on advertising and £6,000 on our website. We don't really take a salary at the moment.

'Lindsay and I meet and talk all the time. I don't think I would have had the motivation to do it on my own. But we're a start-up in a growing market. Eighty per cent of the jobs that come in, we can fill. When we place someone, we take a percentage of two- fifths of a salary but we have to put in just as much effort to fill the position. It's a massive volume of administration. If we were in it purely to make money we'd be recruiting full-time positions.'

Lindsay Swan says: 'When we first started we put in a few hundred pounds each but there weren't really many costs as I was already set up with a computer and a fax. We've saved a lot of money by not having an accountant and not paying for PR and marketing.

'We've recently taken on a lawyer who is going to be our new business person. She works part-time. We also have someone doing ongoing research. We create our own mailing lists. In PR, you learn that you're only as good as your list.'

Open all hours for fun and exhaustion

Trericket Mill guesthouse

Builth Wells, mid-Wales

Alistair and Nicky Legge bought Trericket Mill, on the River Wye, 13 years ago for £146,000. They've spent about £100,000 restoring it, and run it as a guesthouse with 16 beds and camping outside.

Alistair, who studied stage management and worked for the Welsh National Opera, runs the guesthouse full-time. Nicky works part-time in the business and full-time running the Job Centre in nearby Brecon. They employ two part-time staff. They went into profit for the first time three years ago: they made £6,000. Last year their profit was £10,000 and they hope to make a little more this year.

Alistair says: 'We'd been on holiday in the Greek islands and we'd been thinking: "Wouldn't it be nice to run a taverna?" We saw the mill for sale and made an offer. It was a spur-of-the- moment decision.

'We paid too much for it, but we both had houses to sell. I don't know how much it's worth now: It probably didn't make sense spending so much money on it purely as a business prospect but it's our home as well.

'The business is very erratic. It can be stressful. The strong pound means that people go abroad more. But now we're established, half of our custom is repeat business.

'I think that if we started now we'd be struggling. We're still building the business. There is potential to do more food but we'd have to employ more people on a more permanent basis. At the moment we charge £12 for a three-course evening meal. We're not a restaurant: you bring your own wine.

'It's a pretty nice lifestyle if you accept that you're probably working most of your waking hours.'

Nicky says: 'Alistair does all the maintenance and cooking and I do the books. What we earn is no more than Alistair could if he went out and got a full-time job.

'Our life is a bit mad. We miss going out in the evenings and away at weekends. We always say: "When there's no one in, we'll go out", but we usually flop in front of the telly. We have our own flat on the top floor: it's our little bolt hole .

'You have to see it as fun. It's quite exhausting. If we'd thought about it, we'd probably never have done it.'

I don't know how much it's worth now: It probably didn't make sense spending so much money on it purely as a business prospect but it's our home as well. 'The business is very erratic. It can be stressful. The strong pound means that people go abroad more. But now we're established, half of our custom is repeat business. 'I think that if we started now we'd be struggling. We're still building the business. There is potential to do more food but we'd have to employ more people on a more permanent basis. At the moment we charge £12 for a three-course evening meal. We're not a restaurant: you bring your own wine. 'It's a pretty nice lifestyle if you accept that you're probably working most of your waking hours.' Nicky says: 'Alistair does all the maintenance and cooking and I do the books. What we earn is no more than Alistair could if he went out and got a full-time job. 'Our life is a bit mad. We miss going out in the evenings and away at weekends. We always say: "When there's no one in, we'll go out", but we usually flop in front of the telly. We have our own flat on the top floor: it's our little bolt hole . 'You have to see it as fun. It's quite exhausting. If we'd thought about it, we'd probably never have done it.'

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Active funds back on track | Invest with style | Bungee cover
fields.body:
Active funds back on track

Managers of UK growth funds have started to outperform the tracker funds that merely mimic financial indices, according to a review of 98 funds by the financial ratings agency Standard & Poor's.

Over the 12-month review period, the average total return from an actively managed fund was 11.1 per cent - compared with a 7.6 per cent rise in the FTSE All Share index and a 4.4 per cent increase in the FTSE 100.

Managers of smaller companies funds fared even better, returning a sector average of 46.2 per cent, 18 per cent ahead of the FTSE small capitalisation ex-IT index.

S&P says the results show that active management comes into its own in volatile markets. But it warns investors to analyse a fund carefully before putting in money because there can be a big gap in the performance of the top and bottom funds in the review.

Look for consistency of investment approach, it advises.

Four mainstream funds have been awarded an AAA rating: ABN Amro UK Growth, Barings UK Growth Trust, Mercury Offshore Sterling United Kingdom, and the Newton Income.

Invest with style

As if small investors do not have enough complexity to deal with, along comes another investment label: the style fund.

This has nothing to do with catwalks, but describes the methods by which managers choose shares. Instead of selecting shares or bonds according to geography or themes - a specific industry, for example - they are chosen on the basis of whether they offer the prospect of a fast increasing share price, or long term value.

Growth stocks will gener ally be found in fast-growing industries such as technology. Value stocks may be cheap compared to market averages or the company's asset base and may be in a mature industry.

Investment house Schroders believes style investment funds will become widely marketed in the UK. It is launching seven funds, and renaming an eighth, offering a choice of growth or value funds in each of four markets: the UK, continental Europe, the US and Japan.

The initial charges will be 5.25 per cent, discounted by 2 per cent to 3.25 per cent until 31 January. The annual management charge will be 1.5 per cent. Schroders expects them to be sold mainly through independent advisers.

Bungee cover

Insurer MRL is aiming to under-cut the competition with a travel policy for the 600,000 young people who go backpacking each year.

Prices start at £49 for four months in Europe and £89 for roving worldwide. It covers medical expenses, personal accidents, personal belongings and loss of passport expenses as well as hazardous activities such as bungee jumping and white water rafting. Contact MRL on 08708 450 050.

Down Under loans

Borrowing with an Australian flavour is promised with the launch in Britain of the Commonwealth bank of Australia at the end of November.

It will offer a range of flexible mortgages under the brand name NewWorld.

It will offer features not currently found in the UK such as loan portability, product switching between most NewWorld offerings, and borrowers will be able to make their repayments weekly or fortnightly.

As an introductory offer owner-occupiers will be offered a discount of 1.24 per cent off the standard vari able rate of 6.99 per cent.

There will be no redemption penalties on non-fixed products. Visit NewWorld on mynewworld.com.

Cash machine

Software from Microsoft aims to save you money by keeping track of your outgoings and helping manage your investments.

The company says around a third of people either never know how much money is in their account or end up in the red.

Key features of the standard Microsoft Money 2001 package include electronic bill payment and budgeting tools. It costs £29.99.

The £49.99 Money 2001 financial suite will count air miles and organise school fee payments. An intriguing What If? feature shows how different scenarios could affect your finances.

Want a will? Here's a way

More than 1,300 solicitors around Britain are offering their services free of charge in November for people wishing to make a simple will. They will suggest a donation to charity of £50 for a single will and £75 for a couple.

The scheme is the latest brainchild of Will Aid, an organisation set up by solicitor Graeme Pagan who took up fundraising in the mid-Eighties as a result of the Ethiopian famine. The money will go to several charities including the Red Cross, Christian Aid and Save the Children.

Contact Will Aid on 0870 6060239.

Hector's hi-tech fiasco could win you a tax refund

Tax advisers are urging taxpayers to see whether they may be eligible for Inland Revenue refunds for 1997-98 following the Government's decision to write off more than 1 million tax records for that tax year.

This follows difficulties at the Revenue with the introduction of a new computer system. Some taxpayers will escape tax they owe. Others who may be owed tax will have to make a claim.

Among those likely to be affected are people who were employed for part of the year, and who paid tax through PAYE, but then gave up work. If they earned less than that year's personal allowance £4.045, they may be able to claim a refund. Other beneficiaries could be people who gave up jobs to start businesses.

Gerry Hart of the Tax Team, says: 'They are entitled to a year's personal allowance against a few months earnings.' Accountant Moore Stephens says non-taxpayers who had tax deducted at source on savings accounts may also have a claim.

Advisers said taxpayers who think they might be owed money would have to look up any records of their employment and tax paid during 1997-98 and write to their tax office.

Mike Warburton of accountant Grant Thornton said he thought the fiasco might contravene the Taxpayers' Charter which entitled taxpayers to have their affairs settled.

Hart pointed out that taxpayers could face heavy penalties for not keeping their own records in order.

Scottish strife

Thousands of pension investors with Scottish Life are discovering that its takeover by fellow mutual Royal London will not lead to immediate cash windfalls.

The flat payments of £500 being made as part of the deal will not go to individual pension investors. This is because personal pensions and company schemes are run by trustees, and they - in this case, Scottish Life - are the members eligible for the money. However, the insurer will get only one windfall each, not one for each pension customer.

Pension investors who have with-profit policies will receive sums estimated to average £3,500, but these will be paid in the form of bonuses in future years.

Norwich-based employee benefits consultant Robert Clarke describes the structure of the bonus payouts as 'an outrage' that will line Scottish Life's pockets.

The insurer rejects this. A spokesman says it had legal advice that the ownership structure of its pensions did not allow for flat payments to all pension holders.

One-off payments to trustees have occurred in previous demutualisations but Scottish Life seems unusual in writing all its personal pensions in a trust.

Quicker savings

National Savings is introducing bonds with shorter investment terms, and cutting interest rates on the latest issues of all its fixed-rate products by between 0.1 and 0.4 per cent because of falling market rates. Existing customers are not affected.

Spokesman Paul Keeble said of the shorter terms: 'People want the flexibility of not having their money tied up for so long.'

The pensioners' bond, previously available for two or five years, can now be taken out for just one. It has an AER (annual equivalent rate) of 5.9 per cent.

What's the catch?

This is your chance to show yourself and the world that you can look as glamorous as any top model,' says the advertising flyer from Gloss under the headline: 'Win a £500 portrait and makeover.'

But if you are not a winner, you might end up paying £700 for the photos. The main prize may be free of conditions, but only one person a month wins it out of thousands of applicants.

A third win the runners-up prize of a free makeover session and 'same-day viewing of your pictures'. If you want to take the pictures home, they cost from £54.95 each. Gloss will try and sell you a set of 12, which comes to £700.

The free makeover session - make-up, hairdo, mini-facial and photo shoot - is worth much less. Gloss values it at £150. A reader who won the runners-up prize says: 'You have no say as to what kind of make-up you wear and how your hair is done. I asked for the natural look and got Sophia Loren. I also ended up in naff poses.

'You are given the hard sell with the photos. According to the saleswoman, most people pay £700 for a set of 12. I bought two for £100 out of embarrassment. Some people may think they are getting a ready-made portfolio but the photos were not of that standard. I felt cheated because you are told you have won a competition, but you pay for the photos.'

Gloss says: 'The entry form and any information received thereafter make it absolutely clear photographs are not included in their prize.'

 Seen a mailshot or advertisement that seems too good to be true? Write to What's the Catch, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

webTitle: Wealthcheck: Living off the credit card

fields.headline: Stuck learning to crawl as Ireland races ahead
fields.standfirst: Living on credit-card debt isn't ideal, says  Margaret Dibben
fields.trailText: Living on credit-card debt isn't ideal, says Margaret Dibben.
fields.body:
Janice Holmes

Age 33

Lives in Portstewart, Northern Ireland

Occupation Lecturer

Earns £21,000

Mortgage £37,500 endowment

Debts personal loan £15,000, credit cards £4,200

Investments None

Pensions University superannuation scheme and FSAVC

Aims To make ends meet

Janice Holmes left Canada for Ireland 10 years ago, to do the second year of a master's degree in history at Queen's University, Belfast. She found Northern Ireland 'a great place to live', applied for a bursary to do a PhD and stayed a further three years.

'When that finished, I got a job at University College, Dublin and worked there on a post-doctoral fellowship.' She is now a history lecturer with the University of Ulster. She loves the life but there is a problem: 'At the moment I am really struggling to cover all my outgoings. Even as a professional, I can't make ends meet.'

Although she did not get a proper job until she was nearly 29, she had no student loans but, since starting work, has had to borrow heavily: 'I have accumulated all this debt since I bought my house. I didn't have any idea how expensive it was.' Interest rate rises pushed up repayments from £120 a month to £180. 'I think I probably should have kept renting for a while but you feel the pressure to get into the housing market.

Particularly in Northern Ireland there was a concern that house prices had been artificially kept down and were going to sky-rocket.' Her other big expense is the car. One failed the MOT: 'So I changed the car rather than pour more money into it but that was probably the wrong thing to do.' Insurance had been costing £30 a month, but for her new Honda Civic she pays £115 a month, partly because had also lost her no-claims bonus.

She recently spent £200 getting the car fixed: 'I was in an accident and I'm trying to get a no-claims bonus this year, so I'm paying for the repairs myself.' She lives in a rural area and spends about £80 a month on petrol: 'The recent increases in petrol prices have not helped.'

All this has put pressure on her credit card: 'Usually, I use it when 'normal' money is awkward, like buying stuff over the internet or buying cheap petrol in the Republic. But at the moment I'm using my credit card for essentials like petrol and groceries.' She can afford to repay only the minimum amount each month. 'I'm trying to spend less on credit cards and I'm in the process of transferring my balance to two other, cheaper cards.

She supplements her income by £2,700 a year with part-time teaching for the Open University. She contributes £48 a month to a Friends Provident free-standing AVC and £110 to the university pension. She contacted a local financial adviser but he did nothing: 'He said that nobody local dealt with my kind of situation, which I understood to mean that I needed help, but didn't want to buy anything.'

She asks: 'Can you help? Or is the solution to get rid of the television and read the newspaper by candlelight?

Adviser 1: Donna Bradshaw

Janice already has good deals for her mortgage and personal loan but should check out cheaper car insurance and utilities.

After paying her main expenses, she has £680 a month for utility bills, council tax, food, clothing, sundries, and paying off her credit card. This is a reasonable amount to live on so she probably has a problem budgeting.

She should stop paying for petrol on the credit card as this just adds to the problem. Transferring her current credit card debt is a good idea and she should look for a card with a low interest rate that continues until the debt is cleared. Rates start from 5.9 per cent; standard rates may not be so great but if she pays off new purchases in full each month she will not incur further interest. She would do even better not using a credit card until she is out of the woods.

Next she has to cut down on monthly outgoings and start clearing her credit card bill. She should write down absolutely everything that she spends for a month to see where the money is going and why she spends more than she earns.

Janice might also be able to augment her income by car sharing to work or renting out a room in her house for up to £4,250 a year tax-free. She should check her FSAVC as her employer's AVC scheme or added years could be more suitable.

Donna Bradshaw works for London-based Fiona Price & Partners.

Adviser 2: Anna Bowes

At the moment Janice uses her credit card as a float and of course that builds up. She could ask if she can take a contribution holiday, for no more than one year, from the Friends Provident free-standing AVC as this is money that she just does not have at the moment.

As the £15,000 personal loan was for home improvements, she might add that to the mortgage. Spreading the repayments over a longer period dramatically cuts her outgoings and she will pay a lower rate of interest than on the personal loan.

She could also add the credit card debt to her mortgage although this depends on the amount of equity she has in the property and she may feel this is building too much debt for the future. Reducing the mortgage payments and other outgoings should help her pay off the credit cards quite rapidly.

She should shop around for a new credit card provider as this is a competitive market and new issues are being offered all the time.

She could also research car insurance although there is likely to be a penalty for cancelling mid-term, so she may need to wait until the renewal date.

After reinstating the free-standing AVC, she needs to start saving for a rainy day. Inevitably some big bill comes out of the woodwork at just the wrong time and the only way to deal with this comfortably is to have a float.

Anna Bowes works for Bath-based Chase de Vere.

Advice is for guidance only.

 Do you want to appear in Wealthcheck? Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: cash@observer.co.uk. You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

webTitle: Gore: your country needs you more than it thinks

fields.headline: Gore: your country needs you more than it thinks
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: If Al Gore had a coat of arms it ought to have a donkey with a hoof in its mouth as a prominent feature. The US Vice-President is prone to making daft statements about the internet.
fields.body:
If Al Gore had a coat of arms it ought to have a donkey with a hoof in its mouth as a prominent feature. The US Vice-President is prone to making daft statements about the internet.

Rather like our own dear Prime Minister, come to think of it. When the Gore campaign website was first launched some years ago, it briefly included the boast that it was an 'open source' site because it welcomed ideas from visitors.

But this was small beer compared with the Vice-President's gaffe about how he 'invented' the internet. 'During my service in the United States Congress,' he declared, 'I took the initiative in creating the internet.'

On the face of it, this is patently absurd. The internet was not a better mousetrap that emerged fully formed from the creative imagination of a single individual. It is a complex system that was created by a whole community of scientists and engineers, not an 'invention' in the James Dyson sense of the term. Paul Baran, the chap who first conceived the idea of packet-switching, once likened the project to the building of a cathedral in which successive generations of masons build on the work of their predecessors.

'If you are not careful,' he said afterwards, 'you can con yourself that you did the most important part. But the reality is that each contribution has to follow on from previous work.'

So Gore is a fat-head then? Well, up to a point. If you probe beyond the faux pas to the political context behind his ridiculous claim, however, a different picture emerges. For the internet did not emerge from a political vacuum but evolved from the Arparnet, the original packet-switching network funded by the US Department of Defense in the late Sixties. And the Arpanet itself stemmed from a profound belief that government should support the kind of advanced, speculative research that private industry rarely has the vision to nurture.

Left to its own devices, the commercial world would never have created such an amazing, permissive, dynamic, open communications system as the net, and society would have been (literally as well as metaphorically) the poorer.

fields.headline: Glass ceiling shows few cracks
fields.standfirst: Things may have got better, but women are still struggling to make it in the business world, writes  Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: Take two founders of a dotcom company. Overnight one becomes a celebrity while the other languishes in the background, despite the fact that he is the senior of the two. She becomes something of an icon to the City while he is still able to shop in Tesco without being recognised.
fields.body:
Take two founders of a dotcom company. Overnight one becomes a celebrity while the other languishes in the background, despite the fact that he is the senior of the two. She becomes something of an icon to the City while he is still able to shop in Tesco without being recognised.

'It's interesting to reflect on the attention given to Lastminute.com, says Professor John Quelch, dean of London Business School (LBS). 'Martha Lane Fox got much more press coverage than Brent Hoberman, which suggests there was something more unique about her in the minds of the media than him. It's a reflection of the problem facing women in business.'

The depressing fact is that, despite all the talk of closing gender gaps over the last few years, men still wear the trousers in the business world. The few women like Lane Fox who have made it to the top of the tree are seen as freaks, which serves only to reinforce stereotypes and, ultimately, exacerbate the corporate gender divide.

LBS is so concerned at the lack of senior female executives that later this week it will hold a high-profile conference - 'Breaking the Mould' - in an attempt to attract more women to the university and into the business world at large. Only 22 per cent of the school's students are women, reflecting the fact that they form less than a quarter of those who apply. It is a statistic common to business schools nationwide.

Quelch says: 'If you take a profession like medicine or the law, you find women have broken through. About 50 per cent of the people in these two are women. Even in engineering women are making headway. But in business...'

Indeed. The facts are overly familiar. Only one woman - Marjorie Scardino, chief executive of Pearson - heads a FTSE 100 company. Less than 5 per cent of non-executive positions in those companies are held by women. Last week a comprehensive report into executive pay by the research company Incomes Data Services showed that in this financial year a female FTSE 350 director could expect to receive total earnings - including bonuses and share options - of £261,000. Her male counterpart, however, would be in line for a package just shy of £400,000.

Even in the US, seen as home to a more enlightened business culture than the old boy network represented in the Square Mile, there seem few grounds for optimism. An exhaustive study by the National Bureau of Economic Research, which analysed US salary data between 1992 and 1997, showed that women executives earned one-third less than men over the same period: $900,000 compared with $1.3 million - although the differentials were heavily skewed by disparities in age and experience. Even so, it is still a fact that less than 5 per cent of women reach the most senior executive positions in American companies.

But the UK seems to be one of the worst offenders when it comes to top jobs for the boys. Success stories are few and far between. Scardino does, after all, hail from the US. The UK's second highest-profile businesswoman, Barbara Cassani, chief executive of BA's low-cost airline Go, is also from over the pond. A recent edition of Fortune magazine was big on female high-flyers in the US - as you would expect - but it also waxed lyrical about French and Japanese businesswomen. The UK was, with the exception of Scardino, sadly lacking.

The entrenched patriarchal structure of the business world might make for a cosy club, but it doesn't make for strong corporate performances, according to Quelch. This is because the new, knowledge-based economy places much greater emphasis on the need to create enduring working relationships between companies. More and more companies are sharing information, brands and personnel, calling for new management skills.

'The types of challenges facing businesses today are often about managing joint ventures or strategic partnerships. It's not about being a bull in a china shop like the old days. The competitiveness of the UK economy depends on it leveraging the talents of its people and obviously there are demands for people with these sorts of management skills,' Quelch says.

Elizabeth Coffey, author of The Changing Culture of Leadership: Women Leaders' Voices, agrees with Quelch's analysis. She studied 50 of the top businesswomen in the UK and compared their styles of leadership with their male counterparts.

'Women are much more into developing learning cultures. They'll create teams rather than divisions and hierarchies,' says Coffey.

It might sound New Age mumbo jumbo to the pinstriped brigade but Coffey argues that companies will have to start taking such cultures far more seriously in the future. 'Companies will start to pay more attention to this when they ask "who are our customers?" Customers are increasingly female.'

Indeed they are, and it's not just in the obvious conventional retail departments that women are making the purchasing decisions. Four-fifths of all car-buying decisions are made or influenced by women. A survey in the US found that nearly 60 per cent of all car tyre purchases were made by women.

'Companies need to understand how their customers think. That's a primary driver for setting up these learning cultures, so they know how to react,' Coffey says.

The trend to outsourcing is also having an effect. Anna Lloyd, of the Committee of 200, a US society for leading businesswomen, says: 'The market place is demanding a different perspective in relationships. A lot of tasks are now outsourced and consultants are doing everything on the payroll. Managers have to interact differently. The old ways of managing things are changing.'

But, even if this argument holds water, few companies so far give it credence. 'There is still a lot of prejudice against women around. Companies are more aware that they need women in senior posts and they may appoint some more, but does that mean they're just token gestures?' asks Bronwyn Curtis, managing director of Bloomberg TV and Radio in Europe.

Curtis, who was a few years ago the former chief economist at Japanese bank Nomura - still the only woman to have held such a position at a high-profile finance house - is cynical about the future. 'It [the gender gap] is better than when I started in the City in 1987, but I don't think you'll see drastic changes in the next five years. Maybe in the next 10 to 15, but it will take a new generation of men to change it.'

All of the women interviewed by The Observer for this article stressed that men's support will be crucial if women are to break through the glass ceilings of tomorrow. Even at the domestic level this seems vital. Coffey cited research which showed that nearly three-quarters of leading businesswomen claim to have supportive husbands who are sympathetic to their job commitments.

One day we may be saying 'Behind every great woman...' but don't hold your breath.

The gender gap

Women may be finding it difficult to break into the upper echelons of the UK's largest companies but at least there are grounds for optimism in the wider business world. Today, women hold three times as many managerial roles as they did a decade ago, according to a recent report by the Institute of Management.

The report also found that women are closing the gender pay gap. Typically, male managers are paid 8 per cent more than their female counterparts, compared with 38 per cent more a decade ago. Over the past year women managers' pay rose by 6.4 per cent compared with the 5.4 per cent rise received by their male counterparts.

In addition, more women are now making it into the boardroom. Nearly 10 per cent of companies now boast a woman on their board compared with just under 2 per cent 10 years ago.

There is also evidence that women are becoming more entrepreneurial. More than a third of all business start-ups are formed by women. In the US the figure is even more dramatic. Female-owned businesses are the fastest area of business growth in the US, according to the Centre for Policy Alternatives. These businesses now employ one in four of the working population.

fields.headline: Journalists in web tangle
fields.standfirst:
Reporters and sub-editors who hot-footed it to dotcoms because print was yesterday's medium are regretting it today, writes Nick Mathiason

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Reporters and sub-editors who hot-footed it to dotcoms because print was yesterday's medium are regretting it today, writes Nick Mathiason
fields.body:
You'd have to have the sentence-building skills of Arthur Mullard not to score some kind of job in journalism these days.

Thanks to the explosion of web-based news sites, there has been an estimated 15 percent rise in jobs for sub-editors and writers. But a series of announcements last week may be a signal that this 'golden age' is drawing to a close.

Last Monday, Rupert Murdoch, chairman and chief executive of News Corporation, announced a 2.5 per cent cut at New Digital Media, its online media division. NMD, which employed 475 staff before the cuts, will now narrow its focus to national and political news. Reporters covering science and technology are among the first to go.

The lay-offs came days after Murdoch cast doubt on the value of the internet in comments made to shareholders.

Network of the World (NOW), the interactive entertainment service set up by 'Superboy' Richard Li of Hong Kong, is also facing sharp cutbacks. Parent company Pacific Century Cyberworks told analysts it would reduce investment in the London-based service, which employs 350 staff.

So far no details of cuts are available but staff fear the worst. NOW, run by the son of Hong Kong's richest man, Li Ka-shing - known as 'Superman' - is a joint venture between Pacific and Trans World, the TV and online production company.

In the States, NBC Internet has already announced plans to lay off 20 per cent of its staff, while technology news site Red Herring has cut 25 jobs - around 7 per cent of the workforce.

In Britain, the cull hasn't started yet, but it's a matter of time according to Jeremy Dear, national organiser at the National Union of Journalists. 'We still have concerns about how many sites make money. A lot of them hardly get any adverts. They're just pumping money hoping to outlast their competitors,' he said.

The warning signs are clear. Journalists lured to websites by the promise of fat stock options following a float have seen those hopes dashed. 'The investment climate is such that floats are pulled or delayed. Last year a lead weight could have floated but investors have been badly burnt and now bankers are asking when a site's business model will make money. That is a nasty, penetrating question to which there is no short answer,' said one senior web journalist.

'Options are useless,' said another. 'We were promised that our site was going to float but the climate is not right. There's talk of a year-end bonus now, but it's just talk at this stage.'

Accusations are rife within web news sites that they are run as little more than 'sweatshops'. Many say their job is to produce a glorified wire service which reheats press releases and offers little job fulfilment. Stories are often kept to a minimum 300 words, allowing little detail or explanation.

'What happens is that all the sites, whether they're music, news, health or finance, look at what each other does in the afternoon and then tweak it at the end of the day. We haven't added much to the sum total of news output,' said one.

Nils Pratley, former Daily Telegraph and Sunday Business journalist now editing TheStreet.com, a leading financial news and features site, denies this - up to a point. 'We offer analysis, depth and proper comment. We break more stories than most websites. But in the grand scheme of things, most financial stories break in the FT or in the Sundays. That hasn't changed much. Everyone goes on about web sites reinventing journalism. It's hard. But readers are also interested in readable good analysis.'

Certain websites have ridden into a storm over the treatment of freelances. The 365 Corporation, run by television presenter and former Q magazine editor Danny Kelly, earlier this year lost a prominent staff member who resigned in protest at 'stringent' freelance contracts. Pay rates were well below industry rates and journalists had to waive their copyright yet they were were wholly liable in the event of legal action.

Negotiations are still taking place over contracts. But at most sites spawned by established publishing houses, union recognition agreements are already in place.

'We've no problem at FT.com or at the Beeb's site,' said Dear. 'It's the smaller sites where problems arise. The trouble with web news is that people work incredibly long hours. That happens a lot in the media but more so here where news can be released any time of the day.'

Dear said one effect of the the proliferation of web news was a severe shortage of sub-editors on provincial papers. Sub-editors on titles such as the Yorkshire Post earn up to £20,000. Web subs can earn £5,000 more than that - still £10,000 less than wages on a national daily.

On trade news websites, where most web journalists are employed, the job can be very frustrating. 'We are at the mercy of technology,' said the editor of a trade-based travel site. 'You can have the best design and be staffed by intelligent writers but if your email doesn't work or your server regularly breaks down, it means nothing. The problem is that too many companies don't invest in good enough technology to run these sites. So they crash.'

For all the talk of web news reinventing journalism, the reality is that nothing much has changed. True, there is a greater interface with readers and the ability to correct errors is easier. But only Matt Drudge, the man who broke the Monica Lewinsky scandal in America, has ever achieved a cast-iron web scoop.

Not until a web news site does the equivalent of what CNN did to television news journalism can the medium be said to have come of age. And there's little sign of that happening.

Com-rades

Danny Kelly
Danny Kelly, 43, made his name at music title NME, where he was editor before running 'Dad Rock' title, Q. Joined the ranks of dotcom paper millionaires last December when 365 Corporation, the content providing the company he founded, floated. But his paper fortune has dwindled in tandem with 365's stock market performance. Took the opportunity to buy more shares when 365 fell below float price.

Nils Pratley
The appointment of Nils Pratley at financial news site, TheStreet, was the first time the service got a scoop that was followed up by the national papers. Former Questor editor for the Daily Telegraph, Pratley was poached from the relaunched Sunday Business to replace Martin Baker last May. Has done well boosting the subscriber base, now standing at 160,000, and drafting in named columnists but there have too few scoops. Pratley, though, has a loyal following on the shop floor.

Neil Thapar
A former Indie financial hack, Thapar had a huge following on the Financial Mail on Sunday thanks to his share investment column, Midas. Lured by his former technology correspondent, Richard Grant, to join content provider Talkcast - a Durlacher investment, Thapar has helped Talkcast break stories that have been followed up by nationals.

Tim Jackson
OK, Jackson left journalism to form internet auction house QXL but the former Independent and FT journalist has to be mentioned because he is £60m richer thanks to the web. With £500,000 seed capital from an Israeli venture capital fund, Jackson founded QXL in late 1997, expanded into Europe, floated, exited last March and sold a fair whack of his shares before last April's 'dotbomb' crash. Last seen laughing round the other side of his face.
