Has done well boosting the subscriber base, now standing at 160,000, and drafting in named columnists but there have too few scoops. Pratley, though, has a loyal following on the shop floor. Neil Thapar A former Indie financial hack, Thapar had a huge following on the Financial Mail on Sunday thanks to his share investment column, Midas. Lured by his former technology correspondent, Richard Grant, to join content provider Talkcast - a Durlacher investment, Thapar has helped Talkcast break stories that have been followed up by nationals. Tim Jackson OK, Jackson left journalism to form internet auction house QXL but the former Independent and FT journalist has to be mentioned because he is £60m richer thanks to the web. With £500,000 seed capital from an Israeli venture capital fund, Jackson founded QXL in late 1997, expanded into Europe, floated, exited last March and sold a fair whack of his shares before last April's 'dotbomb' crash. Last seen laughing round the other side of his face.

fields.headline: Neutron Jack, worldbeater
fields.standfirst: The fast-talking action man made General Electric the world's biggest company, but what will he leave behind?
fields.trailText: The fast-talking action man made General Electric the world's biggest company, but what will he leave behind?
fields.body:
We all saw the pictures. The deep eye sockets. The streamline features. The gleaming cranium, radiating energy in the glare of his own NBC television lights. We heard the shoot-from-the-hip lingo as he explained how he just snapped together that $45 billion deal between his turbine to twin-tub combine General Electric and industrial controls group Honeywell, in three days.

He told us how a tip from a reporter led him to fax Honeywell's chairman nine days' ago and close a deal gazumping his rival United Technologies the following day. As a result of this masterstroke he's putting off his retirement. But, hey, he's taking the risk: his family has only company stock to live on. He's not doing it because he's an old man who can't let go. To anyone who disagrees, he says: 'I want to take them on right in the chops'.

How do you describe a man like Jack Welch? 'A dynamo,' says one expert. 'A connoisseur of talent,' says another.

'We call him The Penguin,' says one less enamoured engineering firm that has to compete with him rather than lecture about him. 'Tell me if he does not look like Batman's biggest headache. The problem is he has that effect on the competition.'

Welch unnerves people. One official at aero-engine manufacturer Rolls-Royce says: 'One of our executives once asked Jack at a conference what he though Rolls should do. 'Just stay in big engines,' he said. 'Our people spent a while puzzling out whether this was good advice, or if he was trying to get one over on us.'

He unnerves for a reason. Though he talks macho, synergies with Honeywell worth $1.5 billion were 'right in the gunsights' - he delivers.

General Electric is the first and last word in conglomerates. He has built it from the $13bn company he took over in 1981 into the world's biggest company, worth $530 billion.

It has 340,000 employees - 465,000 after the latest merger - in 100 countries, with revenues of $111.6 bn. It sells everything from light bulbs to dishwashers and ovens, to electrical switchgear, aero engines and financial services.

At 64, Welch's raw energy remains famous. One of his better known sobriquets is Neutron Jack - a phrase that gets close to the heart of the man: he destroys whatever gets in the way of what he wants to build. He is charismatic and competitive and has great charm, according to those who have met him. He has judgment - GE is as much about successful delegation as it is about Welch himself - and he is canny.

'All that nonsense about him depending on the success of the deal,' says another competitor. 'He has been getting millions in bonuses. But it's typical Welch: he knows some people will believe it, and he knows they think he does.' Welch is the eighth highest paid US executive, says Forbes magazine .

His upbringing is suspiciously close to the ideal American dream, an idea the old myth-maker does little to discourage. For example, a converted gravel pit in his native Salem, Massachusetts - requisitioned by local boys who ran it themselves because there were no state leisure facilities - was where his first fist fights and ball games were played out. Naturally, he rose to the top.

But for the record, he was born the only son of a railway conductor. His father was often away from home so he was raised by his ambitious mother.

Welch was not shy about ambition himself. He had an accomplished spell at Salem High school, where he was co-captain of golf - he is still very keen - played hockey, and held the post of treasurer.

His teachers said in his college yearbook: 'A keen wit, a wise look and an answer always ready.' Welch said in the school literary magazine: 'repressed desire - to make a million.'

He went to the University of Massachusetts for a degree in chemical engineering, followed by a Phd at the University of Illinois.

He joined GE's plastics division in 1960. Plastics was a buzzing area, with new markets being developed. His career has perhaps come full circle. With the acquisition of Honeywell, GE's $250m plastics division gains critical mass.

'Back then,' says one business analyst, 'he learnt you have to innovate ceaselessly to get margins.'

Welch sped through GE. By 1981 he was joint chief executive and chairman. Jay Conger, professor of leadership at the London Business School, says one of the keys to Welch was spotting defining new trends and remodelling the business around them. 'Control your destiny or die,' he said.

His first initiative was to force the company's operations to focus at being number one or number two in its market. If it wasn't it had to get there. If it couldn't, it would go. This not only refocused the business - hundreds of underperforming operations went - it refocused management and weeded out those who weren't up to scratch.

He called his next move 'speed, simplicity, self confidence'. Welch viewed the GE bureaucracy - an industrial civil service - with suspicion. So he smashed it, gaining that Neutron Jack tag. He thinned out divisions, fired thousands of staff, shed layers of management. Each division would be a business 'laboratory', creating ideas and deciding the best way of making money from them.

Late in the Eighties Welch latched onto globalisation, which he called 'boundarylessness'. GE needed to think globally about everything from labour markets, suppliers and customers to business practice, generating its own ideas and taking them from others.

On top of this it created businesses such as a leasing and financial services division, which made its own products such as aero-engines more easily available. This division now generates $55.75bn of revenue. He realised margins were in servicing engines, not manufacturing them, so bought independent aero engine workshops around the world.

GE has faced challenges throughout - such as the Kidder Peabody financial scandal, which saw a rogue trader lose the financial services arm millions - and some observers have criticised the increasing dominance of financial services. But to his admirers, Welch's success has depended on meeting problems, such as the internet, head on. His response to that? 'destroyyourbusiness.com', an initiative to show top managers that the Net was do or die for GE. The group claims it has already gained $5bn from online operations.

He has faced criticism for it. Last year, for example, Forbes hinted that Welch might be a dinosaur thrashing about in a new age when he refused to link the pay of young webmeisters he had brought in to the profits of their operations. The young things began to defect to dotcoms. Welch was allegedly furious - but who's laughing now?

For Jay Conger there's more to Welch than the corporate engineer. 'Jack Welch is one of the great dealmakers. People know they are facing the quickest mind in business. But there is more than that - they know they are dealing with one of the world's only business celebrities. Welch knows he's going to do a good deal for GE, and so do they.' Thus far it seems self fulfilling - the 1,700 acquisitions under Welch have created GE as a savvy and agile conglomerate.

There are sceptics, particularly over Honeywell. One UK analyst says: 'This could be the mark of an organisation looking for places for its capital. The big question isn't whether Honeywell's a great fit - it isn't perfect - but whether it indicates GE running out of steam. Was it the big man's last gambit?'

Honeywell will almost certainly be his swan song. True to form he has managed his succession - picking candidates and designing the selection process. But will he choose the right man? And has he left a structure that they can build on?

'You wait to see what comes out of the woodwork when he's gone,' says another analyst. 'There's a lesson from the UK. Remember that famously autocratic and successful British boss Lord Weinstock. Do you remember what his company was called?'

Answers on a postcard.

Vital signs

Subject: John F Welch Jr

Age: 64

Job: Chairman and chief executive, General Electric

Hobbies: Golf, baseball, competing

Sayings of chairman Jack

'We will only be number one or two or else we will sell it, fix it or close it.'

'Companies can't give job security. Only customers can.'

'Muscle is the answer. When you have 10 diverse businesses, you have 10 popgun stalls. When they are constructed into one entity that can really do the job, that gives you muscle.'

Anatomy of a giant

Jack Welch may seem like a big deal, but even his stature is dwarfed by the company he runs. General Electric is an American industrial institution. Its origins go back to the 1878 foundation of the Edison Electric company, which turned into GE in 1892. The company history reads like a chronicle of US industrial progress.

Between 1882 and 1968 it built the US's first central power station, launched its domestic appliance company, created the RCA radio corporation, entered commercial aircraft engine manufacture, opened the first licensed nuclear power plant and pioneered consumer, commercial and industrial credit and leasing.

But while the company's life blood has been building industrial businesses across many sectors of US business, its brains, particularly since Welch became a vice president in the Seventies, have been deployed as one of the country's most astute corporate operators.

Under Welch GE has become a deal-making machine - to the tune of some 1,700 acquisitions. Indeed, Welch cited his skills at bedding in deals, particularly the 1985 acquisition of the RCA media business, as the main reason for staying on.

In 1981 GE moved into semiconductors, buying Intercil. In 1983 it consolidated its position in medical scanning technology through acquisition.

A string of deals since then has built GE Capital Services into a massive consumer credit, industrial and commercial financing and leasing operation which dominates the business - some would say too much so.

Welch has also pursued other strategies by acquisition, for example backing his belief in the margins of servicing rather than building aero-engines by buying BA's operations in Wales in 1991 and Greenwich Air services and UNC in 1997.

He's also bought into mobile phones - a joint venture with Ericsson in 1991 - and snapped up operations that fit with the companies earliest origins, such as Thorn EMI's light bulb business in 1991.

He has also jettisoned extraneous operations, such as non financial broadcasting, oil and gas exploration and problematic operations such as Kidder Peabody financial business.

One disposal, made in 1970 when he had been at the company 10 years, may have caught his eye. In that year GE sold its mainframe computer business to Honeywell. Last week's deal brings the business back to GE.

But the world is split over whether Jack's done well on this one. Initial reaction from the markets was twitchy - GE's value dropped by about 4.8 per cent.

Analysts rallied, however, pointing to the strategic fit in aerospace, where GE's $10.6 billion of aero engine sales was matched by Honeywell's $10.5 billion cockpit avionics business. They also pointed to a broader customer base for GE's industrial systems brought by Honeywell's controls division.

Welch himself defended the acquisition of the chemicals business, saying it bulked GE's $250m activities up by $1bn.

He added that these are real technology businesses, with real earnings and real products - unlike the dotcoms - and pointed to real $1.5bn savings from the '90 per cent fit' of the businesses.

In a Merrill Lynch note out on Wednesday analyst Jeanne Terrile says if GE successfully integrates Honeywell it could be the driver of GE's future growth when other businesses, like power, turn down.

But the note is in awe of Welch: 'Fixing Honeywell will call upon a lot of GE's resources, but... GE has done this sort of thing before,' Terrile wrote.' She added: 'The deal seems so much (a) a Jack deal... and (b) will be the thing that investors focus on until it is done... that the succession story becomes much smaller.'

With 3,000 miles perspective, UK analysts are not so sure. ABN Amro's Sandy Morris said: 'There are "yesses" about this. Perhaps Honeywell's automation will allow GE to develop its home products division, for example with fridges that can read barcodes and so on. But nobody has ever demonstrated to me that cockpits (Honeywell's Avionics) and engines (GE) have natural synergies. I'm sure if they had, people would have tried it.

'That said, GE is a phenomenally powerful company with a phenomenal growth record. The question is, is this the best thing it can find to do with its capital, or is it a sign that the momentum is finally beginning to go?'

webTitle: How a broken rail exposed the cracks in a fragmented industry

fields.headline: How a broken rail exposed the cracks in a fragmented industry
fields.standfirst: Hatfield showed up the failures that ran from top to bottom
fields.trailText: Hatfield showed up the failures that ran from top to bottom
fields.body:
On a grey afternoon in London last Wednesday the principal players in the railway industry sat down to discuss how to work together. It was the first time they had done so since privatisation began six years ago.

Railtrack was formed in 1994, British Rail's freight operations were sold two years later and all the passenger operations, train leasing outfits and maintenance companies went before the 1997 general election.

But in a fragmented industry riven by the pressures of commercially driven contracts, fines, penalties and bonuses, the companies at its heart had never before felt obliged to collaborate.

Many of them have come together in the Government's rail summits to make declarations of unity and debate issues of performance. But it took the Hatfield crash 12 days ago to force them to sit down and work out how to run a railway that is safe and can perform well.

The Government has ordered an investigation into whether profit is being put before safety in the industry - not wilfully but by default because of flaws in the contractual relationships drawn up for privatisation.

Hatfield is already seen as a watershed in the short history of the privatised railway. It took a single broken rail to expose the failure in the chain of command running through the fragmented industry.

The Government will not tear up the entire structure, or take a stake in Railtrack, but it has ordered an investigation into all the contractual relationships between the main players.

Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the Shadow Strategic Rail Authority, has been asked by John Prescott, Deputy Prime Minister, specifically to look at whether the commercial regime is fundamentally in conflict with putting safety first.

The focus is very much on the relationship between Railtrack and its principal maintenance contractor, Balfour Beatty. Evidence is emerging that Balfour Beatty's performance has not been up to scratch but that Railtrack, which is ultimately responsible for the standard of work on its assets, did not force improvements from its contractor or act on warnings that the track in the Hatfield area - and at hundreds of spots all over the country, as it turns out - was worn out.

But efforts to identify weaknesses in the industry's structure and strengthen them is not confined to these two companies.

Morton, his chief executive Mike Grant and the rest of his team at the SSRA will examine the commercial relationships between Railtrack, the passenger operators, the freight operators, the rolling stock leasing companies and the myriad of contractors and sub-contractors that repair the network.

A senior industry source told The Observer this weekend that the problem in the chain of command between network owner and maintenance company went from the top of Railtrack right down to the man on the ground working on the tracks for Balfour Beatty.

'What we have is an instance of a very significant failure in the competence of the management of the network,' he said.

Railtrack has been asked to give rail regulator Tom Winsor a 'remedial plan', showing how it will return the network to normal as soon as possible after carrying out emergency works on potentially dangerous areas of track that it should have known about and dealt with long ago. But it will also have to demonstrate that it is correcting its management failures, its lax supervision of contractors and its slowness to correct potentially fatal faults on lines, signals and tracks.

'It should not have been left until they had to do a knee-jerk fix on the network,' the source said.

Early evidence from the Hatfield investigation, revealed to The Observer, suggests Balfour Beatty had told Railtrack the line that broke near Hatfield was dangerous but that Railtrack failed to impose a speed limit or close the track. This was not an isolated example.

That is seen as a failure of management and of Railtrack's contracts with maintenance firms, in many cases, not being designed to cater for a passenger and freight boom.

Railtrack has received very little extra payment from the passenger and freight operators as a result of traffic growing by up to 40 per cent in the last four years - something that Winsor has now addressed in his improved regulatory regime.

And industry observers have pointed out that Railtrack's contracts with suppliers have not allowed enough money or time for extra work to enable the lines to take all the extra traffic. This has left contractors disgruntled.

Meanwhile, the train operators' crammed timetables mean they have, in some cases, been reluctant to give up lines to Railtrack for work to be done. And the system of penalty payments for lack of punctuality has meant that trains often do not wait for connecting services to arrive. In other cases, the operators allow delayed trains to clog up the network rather than cancel them and put the passengers on a relief train, even though that would be less disruptive. This is because cancellations incur bigger penalties.

There have also been accusations that operators are under such pressure not to run late that they sometimes fail to carry out enough braking and other safety checks before leaving the station.

'It was all privatised in a rush and the relationships need to be looked at,' said a source close to the SSRA.

And industry observers have pointed out that Railtrack's contracts with suppliers have not allowed enough money or time for extra work to enable the lines to take all the extra traffic. This has left contractors disgruntled. Meanwhile, the train operators' crammed timetables mean they have, in some cases, been reluctant to give up lines to Railtrack for work to be done. In other cases, the operators allow delayed trains to clog up the network rather than cancel them and put the passengers on a relief train, even though that would be less disruptive. This is because cancellations incur bigger penalties. webTitle: Billions wasted on ticket to nowhere

fields.headline: Billions wasted on ticket to nowhere
fields.standfirst: As Britain veers off the rails,  Joanna Walters asks where all the money has gone
fields.trailText: As Britain veers off the rails, Joanna Walters asks where all the money has gone
fields.body:
Concorde is grounded, the railways have slowed to a crawl because of safety fears and the roads are gridlocked. Suddenly Britain is going backwards.

It came as enough of a shock to rich air passengers and British and French patriotic pride this summer that a piece of burst tyre could put the supersonic queen of the skies out of action. But the great train go-slow imposed after the Hatfield crash 12 days ago and now paralysing large parts of the rail network is a transport disaster of national proportions.

A billion rail journeys are made each year, many of them as a daily commute to earn a living. Passengers were promised a privatised railway that would be safe, punctual and good value for money, with new trains and higher speeds. Instead they have been forced to tolerate late, old, dirty and overcrowded trains, ticket prices that are in some cases the highest in the world and a safety regime that has been called into question after three foreseeable and entirely preventable accidents in three years, two from signals passed at danger, one from a broken rail.

The speed restrictions now in force on up to 300 stretches of potentially dangerous track, together with heightened fears over safety, will inevitably force millions of people back on to the roads in the short term. Domestic air travel will get a boost, but most people will resort to buses and cars to try to circumvent the disruption.

Does this inevitably mean thatthe Government's 10-year target of a 50 per cent growth in passenger numbers and 80 per cent increase in freight traffic is in jeopardy because of the risk of people changing their travel habits for good and the news that it might take 10 years to get the rail network up to scratch?

A lot will depend on how quickly network owner Railtrack retrieves its shattered reputation by spending efficiently and wisely to produce a modern railway. It also depends on how effectively the industry structure is reorganised by rail regulator Tom Winsor and Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the Strategic Rail Authority. It is widely agreed that the system is badly in need of reforms that were already under way before Hatfield, and are now likely to be intensified.

One stark demonstrationof the problem is that the public is constantly being told of record levels of investment in the industry but what they see is a network falling apart. So where does all the money go?

Railtrack's latest annual report boasts: 'The scale of our investment has been transformed over the past four years, with almost £2 billion invested last year - over twice the level we achieved three years ago.'

Two thirds of this was spent on basic maintenance and repairing or renewing worn-out equipment - including track, signalling, bridges and stations. Around 22 per cent was spend on expanding capacity on the network and new 'enhancement' projects, and 13 per cent was spent on the first stage of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link.

Last week Winsor announced his review of Railtrack's finances for the five years from next April. Railtrack's finances are regulated because as a privatised monopoly it receives fixed amounts of revenue from the train operators, subsidised by £1.3bn a year of taxpayers' money. Railtrack's spending will go up to £15bn for the new five-year period, compared with £10bn last time: most of the money comes from pre-determined and subsidised charges paid by the train operators for access to the tracks. The figure has also been increased by £855m from the provisional amount decided by Winsor in July.

This extra £855m will come as a direct grant out of the £60bn announced for the railways by the Government in the summer as part of its £180bn 10-year transport spending plans.

Public spending on the railways as a whole is set to rise from £1.6bn this year to £4bn by 2006 - proof that one of the primary aims of privatisation, that of unburdening the public purse, has failed. And there is a grave risk that without effective reforms, much of the money will be wasted: not just in the high-profile dividends to shareholders and bonus payments to executives that cause such an outcry among the general public, but purely in terms of how much of Railtrack's spending actually produces the desired result.

Consultancy Booz Allen Hamilton reported to the rail regulator in 1999 that Railtrack's project management and spending efficiencies often led to projects going over budget and money being wasted on bureaucracy and an inefficient chain of companies subcontracted to carry out work. In relation to the company's plans to refurbish stations, the report said: 'Serious problems remain, with a "£ in the ground" indicator suggesting that physical works represent less than 50 per cent of project expenditure. Railtrack's project management processes may be adding up to 20 per cent to delivery costs.'

News that the company was wasting 50p in every £1 on invisible overheads enraged the regulator.

Booz Allen also reported that 10 per cent of the network's 20,000 miles of track were in either poor or very poor condition, and the nation's infrastructure was in a worse state than when Railtrack was hived off from British Rail in 1994.

Despite tightening up on project management, driving down costs on contracts and keeping a closer watch on its contractors and their myriad sub-contractors, Railtrack has not solved its problems.

At one end of the portfolio, its biggest project - to modernise the West Coast Main Line - has been subject to delay, and the cost involved rose from £2.3bn to £5.8bn after the company realised it would have to renew all the lineside signalling on the routes from London to Birmingham, Liverpool, Manchester and Glasgow. It had intended simply to remove the existing signals and install an automatic system, but will now have to have both operating alongside each other for the foreseeable future.

With work now going on apace, there have been patches of huge disruption at London's Euston station this year: sub-contractors would cut through the wrong cables or overran working schedules, often bringing the passenger railway to a halt.

At the most basic end of its portfolio, Railtrack has been slated for failing to repair broken and cracked rails fast enough and failing to replace sleepers and stone ballast. The company is on its third attempt to draw up a database of its assets after it was revealed that it did not have a register of the condition, capacity and capability of the network it owns.

There were 755 broken rails on the network in the year to March 1998 but this number rose to 952 the following year. The total of 917 in the year to this spring exceeded Railtrack's first forecast of 770, and its revised forecast of 870.

Winsor decided in August that this was prima facie evidence of a breach of the central condition of its licence - that the company maintain the network properly. He appointed an independent consultancy from the US, TCCI, to carry out an audit. In a report due to be published on Friday the TCCI team is expected to criticise Railtrack's relationship with its contractors, which has led to vital repairs on the network being neglected or delayed, and saw it embroiled in rows about who is responsible and who should pay.

After the Hatfield crash there was claim and counter-claim that Balfour Beatty had warned Railtrack last year that track in the area was worn and that, in turn, the rail company had warned its contractor that it was not carrying out maintenance work properly.

A fresh piece of track had been sitting next to a worn section of track at Hatfield on the East Coast Main Line since May, waiting to be fitted by renewal contractor Jarvis. But the train operators are so keen to run their record numbers of trains that Railtrack had had difficulty getting them to agree to close off track for repairs.

After a privatisation and regulation process that Winsor has criticised as 'cutting corners' and leaving too much to the discretion of Railtrack and the train operators, he and Morton are busy rewriting the contracts that underpin the labyrinth of relationships in the industry.

Morton is redrawing the map of passenger franchises, and last week stripped Connex of its London South Central franchise.

Winsor is tightening up Railtrack's licensing conditions to leave less scope for waste and incompetence in its engineering work and more 'sticks and carrots' to ensure it spends more to renew the railway faster.

Winsor is not expected to recommend to the Government that it removes Railtrack's licence because, as it is a monopoly, there is no one else readily available to run the network.

The Government will not renationalise the railways, and it is understood to be highly unlikely to take a token stake in Railtrack, because that would give it little extra power over the company while opening it up to blame whenever anything goes wrong.

Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott prefers to rely on Winsor and Morton, the two men he personally appointed to shake up the railways, to bring greater accountability, responsibility and investment into the industry.

That means more of Railtrack's pounds going in the ground more quickly so that the taxpayer can at last get a decent ride - both safe and punctual - on a railway for which it is paying through the nose.

fields.headline: Dogfight over the skies
fields.standfirst: The Government's setback over air traffic control is seen as good news by the airlines, which want a European solution.  Oliver Morgan reports
fields.trailText: The Government's setback over air traffic control is seen as good news by the airlines, which want a European solution. Oliver Morgan reports
fields.body:
First it was petrol. Next it was trains. Last week it was the turn of planes to prompt a crisis for the Government. Following in the wake of the Hatfield crash and the fuel protests that brought motorised Britain to a standstill, last Thursday saw its attempt to sell off 51 per cent of Britain's National Air Traffic Control System (Nats) rejected by the House of Lords .

The vote to delay the sale until after the next election won all-party support and came a day after Tony Blair refused to back down on the public-private partnership policy. The Government has pledged to reverse the change in the Commons before sending it back to the Lords.

Labour peer Lord Brett questioned the scheme's safety and disagreed with Blair that PPP was the only way to attract future investment in the system. Other ways - a public trust, for example - could do it without the 'conflict of interest' private firms might bring with them.

Within the wider context of air traffic control the vote against the UK scheme - under which 5 per cent would be sold to staff - was seen by many in the industry as a blessing. There are two reasons for this. First, Nats was a UK-only solution and airlines and aircraft manufacturers are far more interested in programmes that integrate airspace over continents rather than compartmentalising them. Only in this way can the growing congestion in the skies be eased.

Second, Nats paid little attention to the technological possibilities that a full modernisation of air traffic control systems should include. This, according to those who promote these solutions, is so as to ensure that the huge forecast increases in air travel can be controlled.

The International Airline Trade Association (IATA) points out that air traffic volumes rise by 5 to 6 per cent a year, and double every 10 years. The worst affected parts are north-east US and Europe, where volumes have shot up.

Airlines have been lobbying for change, particularly in Europe. Continental air traffic control systems are grossly inefficient, they contend. The reasons are partly political - individual states are loath to cede control of their airspace - and as a result Europe has more than 40 main traffic management centres to America's four. They are also technical - a plethora of different ground-based systems have grown up, sucking in investment.

Reforms proposed by IATA include more co-operation between nations in managing pan-European airspace, rationalisation of the ATC centres, a co-ordinated strategy to create more capacity in the skies, and liberalisation - not privatisation - of ATC. Airlines are desperate for more capacity. But they believe a satellite future is some way off in Europe.

'A solution can only be found by individual governments becoming co-operative, allowing others to operate through their airspace and not going out to pursue their own schemes for liberalisation or increasing capacity without co-ordination,' said a spokeswoman. Nats would clearly have failed on these criteria.

Alongside the geographical and structural issues are technological ones. The UK, like other European countries, has invested billions in state-of-the-art radar control facilities. This, say some in the aerospace industry, is missing the point. There needs to be a generational leap in technology to a satellite-run system.

The importance of technology depends on your future strategy. As far as the two major aircraft manufacturers are concerned, these could not be more different. Airbus sees the future in traffic-light mega-airliners such as its A3XX superjumbo, which can land 800 people a time at international hubs. The plane itself is part of the solution, thinning out the clutter of smaller aircraft.

Boeing, on the other hand, sees the future in traffic-heavy 'fragmentation' - more smaller planes flying higher-value short-haul routes to airports closer to travellers' final destinations. Here the planes are part of the problem: contributing to a lack of airway capacity.

As Boeing's chief operating officer, Harry Stonecipher, said last week at a meeting in London: 'The problem has got to be solved, otherwise growth in air travel slows, and that unpicks our company's airplane business.'

Boeing considered bidding for Nats but decided against it. It gave two reasons: it was a UK-only project, while the future required a Europe-wide one and it was not technologically radical enough. Nats, said Stonecipher 'is not about a solution. It is about nothing more than privatisation'.

At the meeting he announced that within a year Boeing planned to unveil a satellite-based scheme capable of total overhaul of air traffic control, managing it more efficiently than the current radar/satellite hybrids operating around the world and creating 50 per cent more space. The project would take five years before it could be rolled out. It will cost between $10bn and $20bn, of which Boeing is prepared to foot a significant proportion.

The fundamental difference between satellite and radar is this: radar tracks from the ground, plotting accurately an aircraft's progress on to a screen every three seconds or so. Satellites rely on the plane sending them signals before relaying them to the controller's screen.

Satellite, which is already in use through the US government's military GPS system where radar is uneconomic and impractical, are potentially quicker and more accurate than radar - allowing more planes to fly.

A next-generation system would initially run on GPS satellites but would eventually need a dedicated fleet of new-generation satellites capable of greater accuracy and predictive power, since plotting an aircraft's future course is as vital as knowing where it is now.

GPS can place aircraft to within 7 metres of their position. Fine on remote segments of long-haul journeys, where traffic densities are low, and where the satellite-based Future Air Navigation system has been rolled out.

But the key economic battleground will be shorter haul routes in Europe and north-east US. It is only here that the commercial disadvantage of congestion makes the multibillion dollar investment numbers add up behind satellite. Seven metres is not good enough.

Of course, it is Boeing, with its strategy of fragmentation, for which a new solution is most important. And the company intends to unveil its system next year in the US, where there are no political borders and less recent investment in terrestrial systems to hold it back.

The key problem then will be overcoming the scepticism of an industry more than ever aware of safety, and voters more wary about throwing money in the air now than they were during the Cold War, when the last 'Star Wars' initiative was pursued.

David Learmount, operations and safety editor of Flight International, says: 'The key thing is integrity. Radar doesn't lie. The controller knows a plane is where the dot on the screen says it is. But if the plane sends out a wrong signal to the satellite, the dot and the plane may not be the same at all.'

Boeing's key problem is to overcome such scepticism. If the system is workable, it will prove that Boeing was right to think small rather than big, as has Airbus.

It will also create an immensely powerful aerospace group, managing the airways as well as selling the planes to fill them.

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.standfirst: <A HREF="http://www.mediaguardian.co.uk/">MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Pantomime time
fields.body:
Pantomime time

It's the gig everyone in the wacky world of Theatreland is just dying to get. At this time of year thesps up and down the land are anxiously phoning their agents and tearfully asking: 'Any news from Classic FM?' But now the agonising wait is over. The narrator of this year's musical panto - Sleeping Beauty - is to be Side Show Bob, also known as Ross Kemp, or Grant from Eastenders. Classic FM insiders deny Bob's amour, the well-known paedophile hunter and Screws ed Rebekah Wade, will take the role of Beauty. However, we have seen exclusive extracts from the script. In a break with tradition, Bob's somewhat gritty narrative loudly implores Beauty to 'JUST WAKE UP WILL YOU?' Those familiar with the rehearsals say in terms of pathos the scene matches Ross's memorable soliloquies following the death of Tiff.

Gossip corner

Talking of la Wade, the diary is sad to witness the tawdry goings-on surrounding Sun gossip hackette Marina Hyde. It was the Screws editrix who was responsible for sending Hyde to hack school at City University. But, Hyde, frog-marched out of the Sun after the Mekon found out she had been emailing the heart-throb who is Piers Morgan up to 10 times a day, did not do the whole course. Unfortunately, Hyde was not sent on a chunk of the course which no self-respecting journo should be without: ethics in journalism. Maybe, if Wade had exercised a bit more maternal control and forced Hyde to complete her studies, Fleet Street's gutter press would not have been dragged down by such unseemly shenanigans.

Chinese puzzle

The surprise news earlier this month that Gao Xingjuan, the veteran exiled Chinese dissident novelist and playwright, had been awarded the Nobel prize for literature had many of the scribbling world's finest scratching their heads in bewilderment. Gao's work has, up until now, been recognised only by those in the know and even they were somewhat perplexed. But not for much longer. The £615,000 prize will focus attention on what has been a remarkable life. Gao, currently classed as an 'unperson' by the Chinese authorities, had to flee Beijing in 1983 for fear of imprisonment. His novel, Soul Mountain, chronicles the months after his departure. Gao's publisher must be delighted at the news. Except that HarperCollins, (prop R Murdoch) is not renowned for its commitment to publishing books that attack the Chinese authorities.

So bye bye David Elstein, cerebral head of Channel 5. And a big hello to Dawn Airey, the woman who turned Channel Five into Channel Filth. It is salutary to learn that, despite the claim by Five's shareholders to be hurt by their reputations as semi-pornographers, when the crunch came and they had to decide between Airey and Elstein, the phwoar factor won through. Don't feel sorry for Elstein, who departs with zillions in bonuses. No, instead feel sorry for the Daily Mail, which has waged a protracted and vicious attack on Airey, whom it sees as the antithesis of family values. Middle England suffers another devastating blow.

webTitle: UBS go for richest web bankers

fields.headline: UBS go for richest web bankers
fields.trailText: UBS Warburg is offering nearly 250 staff on its ditched internet operation double bonuses to stay, according to sources close to the company.
fields.body:
UBS Warburg is offering nearly 250 staff on its ditched internet operation double bonuses to stay, according to sources close to the company.

The investment bank decided to drop its proposed pan-European private banking operation despite ploughing £108 million into the venture over the last two years. It was due to launch this November.

Instead, UBS Warburg will import the financial adviser-based model of Paine Webber, the US bank it has bought for $12.4 billion.

The adviser model is pitched at the top end of the high net worth market - clients in the US have holdings that average $750,000 - while the abandoned Warburg operation had its sights set lower at Europe's new affluents, those that have gained most from years of economic growth.

Staff working on the internet operation e-services are said to be angry at the move and have been offered the bonus, payable in February, as an incentive to stay.

UBS hopes to 'wrap' the technology already developed into the new system. It insists the money so far invested in the technology has not been written off. Paine Webber, which merges with Warburg on Friday, has about 8,500 advisers in the US who use its system, which has attracted $200bn in the last three years.

To make the personal adviser model profitable in Europe, Warburg will raise the minimum investment required to $500,000. The e-services programme was aimed at those with at least $100,000 to invest.

Other banks with 'mass affluent' internet projects in the pipeline are Credit Suisse and HSBC in conjunction with Merrill Lynch.

fields.headline: UK woos the saffron start-ups
fields.trailText: The Government is looking at ways of using the UK's cultural connections with India to strengthen links between hi-tech businesses.
fields.body:
The Government is looking at ways of using the UK's cultural connections with India to strengthen links between hi-tech businesses.

Patricia Hewitt, the e-commerce minister, flies to India today for a week-long tour of the country to encourage partnerships and investment in both countries.

Hewitt said: 'In the past, the UK has not appreciated the benefit of our economic and cultural links with India. It is set to become one of the largest and most exciting knowledge-driven economies of the twenty-first century'.

There is a raft of successful e-commerce entrepreneurs around Bangalore, in India's version of Silicon Valley. They include Sabeer Bhatia, who sold Hotmail, the web-based email service, to Microsoft for $400 million. These entrepreneurs have given rise to the 'saffron start-up' phenomenon. And their success has provided the networks and investment to help turn Indian software services companies into Nasdaq-listed IT giants.

Hewitt will meet Narayana Murthy, chairman of Infosys, the software services company worth $17bn which recently signed a global alliance with Microsoft.

Despite the UK's traditional links with India, US companies have stolen a march in forging links with Indian companies, particularly in Bangalore, its technology capital.

'Silicon Valley was there first, but the message I want to put across is that we are ahead of the US in the next generation of technology - mobile telephone and digital television,' said Hewitt.

There is a thriving Indian-origin business community in the UK, particularly in hi-tech sectors. A London chapter of the Silicon Valley networking organisation, the Indus Entrepreneurs, opened earlier this month. Around 20 UK-based businesses will discuss partnerships in India as part of the trip.

Hewitt will see government officials to learn about the development of a network of elite technical colleges, the Indian Institutes of Technology, the hubs for a thriving e-commerce sector.

webTitle: Is this the Chancellor's poll tax?

fields.headline: Is this the Chancellor's poll tax?
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Keynes would have been in favour of Gordon Brown's policy of reducing government debt in times of plenty. He would also have warned Nigel Lawson in 1988 that the good times never last.
fields.body:
Keynes would have been in favour of Gordon Brown's policy of reducing government debt in times of plenty. He would also have warned Nigel Lawson in 1988 that the good times never last.

The Chancellor must reflect with some amusement, as he prepares next week's pre-Budget Report that some of the commentators now drawing attention to his £15 billion or even £20bn 'war-chest' are the very same people who were warning not so long ago that his ambitious public spending plans for 2001-2002 onwards would put a strain on the economy and lead to higher interest rates.

For it should not be forgotten that give or take little local difficulties with pensions and fuel tax, the budgetary plans for the next few years have already been announced. After several years of famine, the Government plans to inject so much money into the public sector that, always providing Whitehall departments have not forgotten how to spend, the Government could be back in deficit by 2005.

The Treasury is criticised for its cautious assumptions about the growth of revenue, but the whole institution was hit for six by the post-Lawson experience. As Ed Balls, the Treasury chief economic adviser, recently observed: 'Better to plan with the benefit of hindsight than wait for hindsight to hit you in the face.'

Recent reminders that in-ternecine strife is part and parcel of all Labour governments should not divert attention from the extraordinary budgetary position this Labour Government has contrived to be in. My own view is that the public spending freeze did great harm and that the high exchange rate's impact on manufacturing industry is a time-bomb waiting to explode. But the combination of restraint on the public spending side and higher revenues from sustained economic growth has put the Chancellor in a commanding position.

Labour's strategists were determined to avoid falling foul of the Treasury. The attempt to undermine the Treasury's dominance of economic policy via the creation of the Department of Economic Affairs in the Sixties ended in tears. This Government feels it has captured the Treasury and got it working with the grain of the Chancellor's macro-economic strategy and his often convoluted micro and social agenda. Indeed, so pervasive is Brown's Treasury that old hands sometimes quip it has become the Department of Social Policy, as well as the Treasury and Department of Economic Affairs rolled into one.

The theory now is that we have a Treasury working to achieve a Labour Government's aims, not trying to undermine them. This is true up to a point. Often in the past Labour's aims undermined themselves; with Sir Douglas Wass as permanent secretary in the late Seventies, the Treasury did its best for Labour in very difficult circumstances.

There is also a sense in which, as Professor Colin Campbell of Georgetown University has pointed out, Whitehall and the Treasury have captured New Labour. The mean-minded way in which some single parents and disabled people were treated showed the Treasury trying on policies that did not even reach parts of the last Conservative Government.

The Treasury feels it has learned a few lessons from these mistakes, which were made during a rather triumphalist period. The interesting thing is that, for all Brown's remarkable success with the economy, the Treasury is now under pressure for the first time.

The good news is that he will be able to boast next week that we are close to full employment (on an admittedly rather dubious definition) and that growth and inflation next year are still expected to be in line with Budget forecasts, at respectively 2.5-2.75 per cent (new growth forecast) and 2.5 per cent (new inflation forecast).

The bad news from the Treasury's point of view is that it is under pressure from the road hauliers, the pensioners, and Number 10.

A difficult political judgment has to be made. The Chancellor and his Treasury advisers are instinctively reluctant to accede to the demands of the road hauliers, let alone to the wider calls for lower fuel taxes. Quite apart from the fact that they just love the revenue, they see lower taxes as being the wrong thing from the environmental point of view, and also macro-economically dangerous because they serve to boost demand at the wrong time. Another consideration is that the oil companies are all too keen to boost their profits by raising prices at the slightest opportunity. New Labour took time to realise that capitalists behave like capitalists.

It is likely that the Chancellor will promise some environmentally friendly measures, and sizeable rebates off fuel duty for the hauliers, but not as much as the 15p they have demanded. He can decide not to index fuel duties in line with inflation while the trouble lasts; but actual cuts in the standard rates of duty on petrol and diesel do not find favour in the Treasury.

My impression is that the Chancellor will hope to deflect the widespread criticism the Government has faced recently with a 'pensioners' package' which is sufficient to redeem him after the infamous 75p increase. While stopping short of a permanent commitment to the re-indexation of pensions to earnings, he will bid strongly for the so-called 'grey vote'. But there will be a limit to his concessions on fuel.

This could be a test of public opinion. The fuel protesters had the public with them - and the Daily Mail until it feared its newsprint would not be delivered. The economist David Henderson pointed out in his recent Wincott lecture ('Anti-Liberalism 2000') that, in the face of demands from the pressure groups, 'typical voters ... have ideas and opinions concerning what is fair, just and acceptable, and as to what actions are likely to promote social or national goals of which they approve.'

There seemed to be public sympathy with the fuel protesters, not least because so many of the public also buy fuel. But there is also public sympathy with 'environmentalism,' and with the plight of many pensioners. It will be interesting to see how a pensioners' package and 'up to the point' fuel concessions go down. The Chancellor did not quite answer my question when I asked him recently whether this was New Labour's poll-tax revolt.

webTitle: Boeing hits at air traffic control sale

fields.headline: Boeing hits at air traffic control sale
fields.trailText: Boeing, the world's leading aircraft manufacturer, has criticised the Government's determination to sell off part of the UK air traffic control system. The US firm says the plan offers no solution to the problem of an ever-increasing number of planes in European airspace.
fields.body:
Boeing, the world's leading aircraft manufacturer, has criticised the Government's determination to sell off part of the UK air traffic control system. The US firm says the plan offers no solution to the problem of an ever-increasing number of planes in European airspace.

Seattle-based Boeing had been pondering the merits of joining the bidding for the 46 per cent of the National Air Traffic Services (NATS) being made available to a 'strategic' private sector partner . It decided against a bid because it did not consider the scheme addressed the congestion problem.

Harry Stonecipher, Boeing's chief executive, said the privatisation plan was 'not about a solution [to congestion]. As I understand it there it no fundamental change.'

'We think there is a total European solution, as opposed to a UK solution.'

Stonecipher's comments come at a critical time for the £500 million NATS sell-off, as a cross-party coalition of peers last week voted by 112 to 90 to delay the project from next March until after the next general election.

The vote puts pressure on the Government's Transport Bill, which includes measures to tackle the rail industry. There is speculation it may drop the sale to save the rest of the bill, although the Department for the Environment, Transport and the Regions has maintained that it will press ahead.

The congestion problems are acute for both airlines and plane manufacturers. The more crowded the skies, the less attractive flying becomes, particularly in valuable short-haul markets such as Europe.

Stonecipher said Boeing plans to unveil a satellite-based system capable of a total overhaul of air traffic management across continents. However, Europe was too fragmented a market in which to launch the system, he added. Political and technical barriers prevented it from being an immediate prospect.

Boeing's plan is to launch it first in the US next year.

webTitle: Feathers fly as bra maker talks turkey

fields.headline: Feathers fly as bra maker talks turkey
fields.standfirst: Wonderbra's creators are expanding, reports Nick Mathiason
fields.trailText: Wonderbra's creators are expanding, reports Nick Mathiason
fields.body:
You know the business world is weird when the makers of Wonderbra want to buy Bernard Matthews, the poultry food producer.

But next week, expect the first salvos in what could be a vicious battle for the soul of one of Norfolk's biggest and most famous firms.

Giant US conglomerate, Sara Lee is likely to bid for Bernard Matthews. And the battle could be grisly.

Matthews, the 70-year-old who brought turkeys to the masses and coined the phrase 'bootiful', last week announced plans to take his firm private. Those close to him insist he would resist all moves to rip the company from his grasp.

Bernard Matthews is seen as one of the naffest companies in Britain. Any firm in the business of killing animals is never going to be regarded as sexy. And everyone dislikes the 'bootiful' catchphrase. Even the man himself is embarrassed by it. What's more, its turkey burgers, cooked meats and birds for roasting are the fare of students and those on low incomes.

But in the midst of the biggest farming crisis to hit Britain for generations, Matthews is thriving.Never mind that sterling's strength against the euro has made life intolerable for British farmers. Matthews vies with Bird's Eye to dominate the £600 million frozen poultry market, has more than 50 per cent of the £300m cold-cooked poultry meat market and is making serious inroads into fresh turkey meat and breaded poultry products.

While his core market is Britain, he is beginning to spread his wings overseas - a notoriously tricky thing to pull off for UK food producers and retailers. Matthews is selling to Germany, New Zealand and, most crucially, Hungary, where he rears vast numbers of birds and which is proving to be a lucrative market. It eventually will be a launch pad for an assault on what could be a profitable eastern European market.

For Sara Lee, buying Bernard Matthews makes sense. OK, it makes Pretty Polly tights, Radox, Brylcream and Douwe Egbert coffee. But it is also the world's biggest processed-meat producer. A bid for Matthews would cement its dominant position and give it the opportunity to drive into Europe.

Matthews and Sara Lee's chairman and chief executive, John Bryan, go back years. In fact Sara Lee bought the technology that rips out the poultry's innards from Matthews 10 years ago.

For some time Bryan has coveted Matthews' business. Next week he will strike. For Bryan, this deal will be chicken feed. His firm generates revenues of more than £10 billion, compared with Matthews' turnover of £344m.

But if Bryan is to succeed, he will have to pay a high price. Matthews' offer to shareholders to take his firm private is 185p per share. There is every indication that 13 per cent of shareholders are happy with that price. With Matthews owning more than 40 per cent of share capital, he is in a strong position.

But there are several who think Matthews' offer is too low. They are eagerly expecting a Sara Lee bid weighing in at over 230p.

Matthews' institutional backers include some of the bluest blue chips around: the likes of Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch , Fidelity and M&G, whose shares have leapt in value since its original investment.

While these institutions are not entirely happy with Matthews' offer, they know that Matthews himself has to be prepared to sell in order for Sara Lee to triumph. In which case a bid of 250p a share valuing Bernard Matthews at about £310m is a price he may be prepared to accept.

If Matthews decides to reject Sara Lee the future direction of the company would be unclear.

None of Matthews' children has seemingly any interest or experience in food production. And he is not getting any younger.

Two years ago, he suffered from ill health and, while those close to him say he is now fit, the bid to take the company is seen as a sign that he wants to tidy up his affairs.

But there is always the possibility that Matthews, who started his company in 1950 with 20 turkey eggs and an incubator for £2.50, is playing a cute game.

Knowing that Sara Lee has always been interested in his firm, a bid to take it private could flush out a fantastic offer giving his dependants a fat inheritance. Bootiful!

In which case a bid of 250p a share valuing Bernard Matthews at about £310m is a price he may be prepared to accept. If Matthews decides to reject Sara Lee the future direction of the company would be unclear. None of Matthews' children has seemingly any interest or experience in food production. And he is not getting any younger. Two years ago, he suffered from ill health and, while those close to him say he is now fit, the bid to take the company is seen as a sign that he wants to tidy up his affairs. But there is always the possibility that Matthews, who started his company in 1950 with 20 turkey eggs and an incubator for £2.50, is playing a cute game. Knowing that Sara Lee has always been interested in his firm, a bid to take it private could flush out a fantastic offer giving his dependants a fat inheritance. Bootiful!

fields.headline: Wealth and efficiency
fields.standfirst: UK productivity still languishes below that of our rivals - and it's not because we're lazy.  Faisal Islam reports
fields.trailText: UK productivity still languishes below that of our rivals - and it's not because we're lazy. Faisal Islam reports
fields.body:
A curious poster has appeared outside Number 11 Downing Street, which reads: 'UK productivity, lost or stolen in the mid-Sixties; multibillion pound reward on offer for its safe return.'

Okay, it doesn't actually exist... yet, but the Chancellor could be forgiven for resorting to such desperate measures following this month's launch of his much-hyped challenge to UK industry to end years of low productivity. It is Gordon Brown's third such challenge in as many years.

The Chancellor will be chanting the same mantra during next week's pre-Budget report. But one question must be asked: will UK productivity ever change? Opinions are divided.

Some pundits opt for a fashionable explanation, that a large-scale investment in information and communications technology - along the lines of that of the US - could bridge the productivity gap. Others say that the gap is closing, but our methods of measurement are not sophisticated enough to capture the changes. And there are others who say the considerable investments made in the IT sector have yet to kick in as workers acquire the skills to use new technology

But as the current statistics stand, the UK's poor productivity performance continues. The most comprehensive and up-to-date estimates of the productivity gap were made for last year by Mary O'Mahony of the National Institute for Economic and Social Research and Nick Crafts of the London School of Economics. The study awarded the UK a score of 100 index points for output per worker. By contrast, the US scored 135, France and Germany 127 and 126 respectively.

Factor in the number of hours worked by each employee, however, and France comes out on top with 133, followed by Germany on 129 and the US on 126. The UK still languishes on 100.

One thing is clear, the UK productivity gap is as wide as ever. And it's not because we're lazy, says Francis Green, professor of economics at Kent University. He compares productivity and measures of worker effort from surveys in the 1980s and 1990s. Over the past decade, the UK topped the European league of worker effort.

'During the Thatcher years, manufacturing work intensified and this seemed to be linked with high productivity increases, despite the fact there was little investment,' Green says. But there's only so much productivity that can be squeezed from placing higher demands on the workforce. 'There is a satiation point at which productivity growth needs to rely on modernising industry through investment rather than further work intensification.'

Studies of the causes of productivity gaps between different countries confirm this view. O'Mahony says: 'Compared with Germany and France, it is an investment story - we have consistently invested less in capital equipment.'

Productivity growth has been seen as the holy grail of current economic policy. Where once industrial policy involved picking winning industries, like automotive, shipbuilding and steel, or sustaining failing, but politically important sectors, it now focuses rigidly on increasing productivity.

Whichever Treasury policy initiative you examine, the productivity mantra can be found: controversial public-private partnerships for the provision of public services, to the myriad retraining schemes and tax breaks for hi-tech investment. The intention of all these schemes is to increase the efficiency, competitiveness and, ultimately, the productive capacity of the economy.

But the UK is still anxiously waiting for lift-off. And for a Government that attaches so much importance to increasing productivity, the stubborn absence of an upturn is a matter of deep concern.

History shows there is no simple way of achieving this. In the early 1980s it was fashionable to say that the Thatcher labour reforms - watering down workplace rights and clamping down on the unions - could solve the problem. But the argument now favoured by this Government is that such an approach ignored the need to improve and invest in the skills of the workforce. As O'Mahony says: 'The things that matter, such as R&D, capital investment and skills, are factors that take a long time to change.'

Private investment is another key area. Venture capital is the petrol of high productivity industries. The conservative attitude displayed by pension funds towards investing in emerging sectors is under particular scrutiny, namely the explanation for why they put 0.5 per cent of their investments into venture capital compared to 5 per cent in the US.

For manufacturing, however, the productivity question is a drop in the ocean in terms of our international competitiveness compared with the high pound.

'The UK couldn't really have a productivity gain big enough to offset the effect of the strong pound,' says Alison Cottrell, economist at Paine Webber.

But, conversely, the strength of sterling may help lick UK companies into shape. Last week's announcement of an export surplus with the European Union provides evidence that companies are finding ways to compete.

'The high pound has made productivity even more important for the UK. The strong yen for many years during the 1980s forced Japanese companies to keep on innovating,' says Cottrell.

But some express fears that the strong pound could end up scaring inward investment away, thereby hitting productivity. Recent research by the NIESR found that foreign-owned firms have 'a significant positive effect on the level of technical efficiency in domestic firms'.

Investment is the key in the medium- and long-term. In the UK's main hi-tech cluster, Silicon Fen, a neglected public infrastructure threatens to put the breaks on growth. Equally worrying is the negativity of investment intentions in the private sector. Despite seven years of macroeconomic stability, a luxury which should encourage forward-looking investment behaviour, a recent CBI survey predicted a fall in manufacturing investment of 8.8 per cent this year, on top of last year's 13.6 per cent drop.

The Chancellor has already granted research and development (R&D) tax credits to small companies. The larger companies that actually carry out most of the R&D will be eagerly awaiting similar concessions to encourage investment. Otherwise Brown's productivity roadshow may have to go on indefinitely.

Vital Statistics

The UK's low productivity may be solved with considerably less effort than expected - by altering the statistics. But this may not be the quick fix that it sounds. Productivity figures for service industries are notoriously difficult to measure, and this sector has become more important. And the IT revolution has contributed a whole new set of measurement problems.

In the US, statistics are adjusted to take account of the rapid changes in the quality of computers. Such adjustments, known as hedonics, are the cause of considerable controversy in economic circles. Some argue that they overstate US output and productivity growth. Goldman Sachs economists David Walton and Ben Broadbent calculated that making hedonic adjustments would add up to 0.5 per cent a year to UK productivity growth since 1995.

The quality of data is another issue. 'The US is very good at producing numbers on time, and in Europe there's not the same confidence invested in the data, they often come late,' says one banker.

Markets place a lot more faith in the US figures. EU statisticians are hard at work recasting their statistics, but collating together 11 already uncertain datasets is a difficult task. In the UK, the Office for National Statistics will, by next year, publish a wider range of productivity statistics.

fields.headline: Pubmaster eyes treble chance
fields.standfirst: Private firm set to bid for 3,000 Whitbread pubs  Bass and Wolves chains also targeted
fields.trailText: Pubmaster, the tenanted pubs company which rose out of the ashes of the Brent Walker empire, is to launch an audacious bid for Whitbread's 3,000 pubs. Analysts have valued the estate at up to £2 billion.
fields.body:
Pubmaster, the tenanted pubs company which rose out of the ashes of the Brent Walker empire, is to launch an audacious bid for Whitbread's 3,000 pubs. Analysts have valued the estate at up to £2 billion.

The shock move comes at the same time as Pubmaster, which owns around 2,000 pubs in the UK, considers separate bids for 900 pubs owned by Bass as well as the whole of Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries. The company is determined to secure one of the three deals. Many in the City would doubt whether Pubmaster, which has yet to float, would have the financial firepower needed to pull the Whitbread deal off.

However the company believes it can do the deal. It has already secured a bridging loan from a range of banks and has appointed financial advisers to help it draw up plans to launch a securitisation programme.

The plan would be to sell off chunks of the estate to other parties but retain the lion's share and convert these into tenancies. A separate company with its own management team would then be drafted in to oversee the estate which the company would look to securitise by issuing bonds backed by income from the pubs - an increasingly common form of financial engineering in the sector.

Pubmaster has been looking at the 900 pubs Bass recently put on the market but it is also running its eyes over Wolverhampton & Dudley, the Midlands brewer and pub operator.

It is believed to have signed confidentiality clauses with both companies. The plan is to table exploratory offers for all three concerns. Chief executive John Sands is believed to have made the Whitbread estate his number one target, followed by Wolves.

Pubmaster, which earlier this year raised £109 million through a securitisation programme, is anxious to expand its estate. The UK pub sector is in a period of intense consolidation, and Pubmaster is keen to avoid falling to a predator. Last year it bought Swallows' estate of pubs for £127.5 million.

But acquiring the Whitbread estate would enable Pubmaster to seek a flotation sooner than expected. In the past the City has not been overly interested in small pub companies, and Sands is understood to be prepared to bide his time until his company achieves sufficient size.

Part of the problem is that the pubs sector is out of fashion with the market.

Whitbread's shock decision earlier this month to place its entire estate - which is comprised of around 1,700 tenanted and 1,300 managed pubs - on the market was the most obvious reaction to this shift in sentiment. Instead the company will now focus on developing its portfolio of hotels, health clubs and restaurants.

If Pubmaster were to pull off the Whitbread deal it would be a remarkable coup. In 1992, its parent company, Brent Walker, founded by former heavyweight boxer George Walker, was reporting losses of £427 million, and was saddled with huge amounts of debt. Pubmaster eventually emerged from the wreckage.

Pubmaster faces tough competition for the Whitbread estate. Alchemy, the venture capital firm, which tried to buy Rover earlier this year, is also known to be interested.

fields.headline: Tories favour N-plants
fields.trailText: A new generation of nuclear power stations is being mooted as a solution to serious doubts about the UK's ability to meet targets for the reduction of carbon dioxide emissions.
fields.body:
A new generation of nuclear power stations is being mooted as a solution to serious doubts about the UK's ability to meet targets for the reduction of carbon dioxide emissions.

Conservative trade and industry spokesman David Heathcoat-Amory believes construction of up to eight new-generation pressurised water reactors - the technology used in Britain's most modern plant at Sizewell B in Suffolk - should be considered as a possible solution to Britain's energy problems.

Heathcoat-Amory, a former Energy Minister, was due to unveil the new policy at a Commons debate tomorrow on the Government's public-private partnership proposals for British Nuclear Fuels.

That debate has been postponed, but Nick Gibb, junior Conservative DTI spokesman, intends to argue the case in the rescheduled debate later this month.

It will be the first time a major political party has seriously put forward the construction of nuclear power stations since the idea for a third reactor at Sizewell was abandoned in the early Nineties.

Heathcoat-Amory told The Observer: 'Taking a blinkered view of this could be cutting off one of the key solutions. There are strong grounds for considering it seriously - grounds of global warming and of security of supply. We should be seeing if nuclear is an option for the future.'

Heathcoat-Amory pointed to government figures in the DETR's Draft Climate Change Programme, which predicted carbon dioxide emissions to fall from 1990 levels - 168 million tonnes of carbon - to 152.2m in 2000, before rising to 156.3m in 2010 and 164.9m in 2020.

The document itself identifies the tailing off of the current nuclear programme as part of the problem.

Dr Helen Wallace of Greenpeace said: 'There is no place for nuclear power as a solution to climate change. Nuclear waste, accidents and the threat of proliferation are all unavoidable dangers.'

fields.headline: Saints and sinners
fields.standfirst: Are you jealous of Paul McCartney and Heather Mills or just mad about Pete Postlethwaite?
fields.trailText:
Stars and Their Lives ITV
The Sins BBC1
Marion and Geoff BBC2
EastEnders BBC1
fields.body:
Stars and Their Lives ITV
The Sins BBC1
Marion and Geoff BBC2
EastEnders BBC1

I'd somehow missed out on the Heather Mills phenomenon, having only the vaguest sense of her as a tabloid-dweller poised at the outer limits of Dianaville with easy access to the Beckham ring road. Last Sunday on Stars and Their Lives, in a breathy whirlwind of alliteration, Carol Vorderman helped fill in the gaps - 'She's gorgeous but she's gutsy too! She's the Geordie with the giant heart! The beauty who battles against the bad times! The model who became a model campaigner' - when she introduced the celebrity amputee and consort to Sir Paul McCartney on ITV's answer to This Is Your Life .

I couldn't work out how this inscrutably blank-faced Barbie-blonde (see, it's catching) ticked, even while friends from Chris Eubank to Richard Branson to the Duchess of Kent testified to her all-round gutsy goodness, her toughness and non-conformity. Heather accessorised herself with a dry Geordie wit, thereby unsettling the audience who didn't know quite how to respond to stuff like 'I thought: what's my leg doing over there? I've just bought those trainers! I'll never get the blood off!'

But then McCartney came on to kiss her and tell us he loved her, which was like watching the post-coital analysis in an edition of Celebrity Blind Date . Macca had improbably starry eyes, youthfully-tinted hair and described his girlfriend as 'a very beautiful true fine momma'. He looked about as besotted as a man can be without having to display a Do Not Disturb sign. 'I always had this dream of a knight in shining armour,' said Heather.

Carol told the couple that there is a lot of goodwill towards them, 'isn't there?!'. 'Mmm!' muttered the audience. But, and I can't put my finger on quite why this should be, given Macca's recent pain and Heather's tireless charity work, Carol was wrong; there isn't quite as much goodwill towards them as they'd like. 'People that are jealous of us, or bitter, you look at those people's lives and they give and do nothing for anyone else. But people who like us are giving, nice people,' explained Mills, which presumably leaves most of us in Nowhere-Man's-land, slightly bemused by the combination of Heather's strident sanctimony and Sir Paul's slavering.

Funnily enough, Pride was the first of the sins to be tackled in... well, The Sins, BBC1's new go-on!-guess-how-many-parts series, in which Pete Postlethwaite plays Len, an ex-getaway driver determined to go straight. I couldn't take my eyes off that spin-dried Sinatra face, in which sweetness and menace seem to fight for control of his features. So much so, that scenes without Postlethwaite faltered slightly, not through any fault of the script or the acting, but just because Pete fills the screen with so much mutable gravitas.

Frank Finlay came close, though, as Len's Uncle Irwin, a funeral director contemplating retirement, regretful that 'there is no obvious replacement chomping at the funereal bit' and operating just a few doors up the road from the Hammer House of Horror: 'I have some lungs to drain, but I can work quite happily while you rummage around.' After his turn as Dylan (love-of-my-life) Moran's evil father-in-law in How Do You Want Me?, Finlay is rather belatedly cornering the market in menacing campery - which is odd given that he was doing it brilliantly as far back as Bouquet of Barbed Wire .

Len's sin manifested at a party thrown to celebrate his release from a four-year stretch, where he told his crime cronies they were 'dullards' and proclaimed his freshly minted middle-classness: 'I live in Paradise Drive, I've had a letter published in the Telegraph, one of my daughters is up at Oxford', which, predictably, went down like a pair of concrete wellies, particularly with his family. Suddenly, Len's wife (Geraldine James) couldn't get her regular table at Mario's ('Am I or am I not Len Green's wife?' 'Len Green is not Len Green any more,' shrugged Mario) and 'in the light of recent developments' her credit was revoked at the local boutique.

Meanwhile, Len was off to the Job Centre, demanding 'proper, stimulating, middle-aged, middle-England legal employment'. The Sins is deliciously wordy, funny and even had a great car chase - very rare on TV, where even Grand Prix look as though everyone's pootling around the M25 in third gear. Next week sees Len working, inevitably, as an undertaker while struggling with Covetousness, particularly in relation to top-of-the-range, fully-loaded hearses. Can't wait.

BBC2's Marion and Geoff is a 10-part series of 10-minute dramatic monologues by Keith, minicab driver, divorcee and owner of a selection of Alan Partridge's cast-off sweaters (Steve Coogan is one of the show's producers). Last week saw the halfway mark, which is as good a place as any to ponder Keith's swiftly unravelling grip on what little is left of his sanity. The Marion and Geoff of the title are, respectively, Keith's ex-wife and her new husband, who live in Cardiff with Keith's two young sons, while Keith lives in London but regularly drives through the night accompanied by binoculars, a rifle (with telescopic sight) and toys for the children: 'I thought the Action Man might be too violent but, like his mother says, he's a very violent child.'

What initially looked like tragic stoicism in the face of complete rejection (re Geoff: 'I don't feel like I've lost a wife, I've gained a friend!') is proving to be a dangerously thin veneer. Last week, Keith told us how he'd gone to see Father Paul, a pastor - he said: 'You don't need the Church, Keith, you need a bloody good solicitor' - and though we are another five fraught weeks away, the dénouement looks likely to inspire a nationwide mini-cab boycott.

Luckily, young Sonia Jackson got a lift to hospital in a black cab when she gave birth, unexpectedly, to Martin Fowler's daughter in Thursday's EastEnders. This was a disappointing episode not least because too many storylines jostled for our attention. Wasn't a teenage girl going into labour without knowing she was pregnant considered enough to sustain 30 minutes of sudsy excitement? Given that Natalie Cassidy is such a good little actress and Sonia such a sympathetic character, they could both have been allowed to hog the show. Instead, the drama was squandered by having Mo Harris play midwife, and constant cutting to the rows between Melanie and Steve, trysts between Frank and Pat, a showdown between Pauline and Martin and, to top it all, an unnecessarily drunk, and therefore pantomimic, Dot Cotton.

These days, EastEnders is often distracted from what, in soap terms at least, used to be a laudable concentration span in which plotlines could develop and thrive. At the moment, the cast is too big and too starry and so, perhaps, too demanding of the spotlight. Poor Sonia - she could hardly hear her baby crying over all that din.
