But, and I can't put my finger on quite why this should be, given Macca's recent pain and Heather's tireless charity work, Carol was wrong; there isn't quite as much goodwill towards them as they'd like. 'People that are jealous of us, or bitter, you look at those people's lives and they give and do nothing for anyone else. But people who like us are giving, nice people,' explained Mills, which presumably leaves most of us in Nowhere-Man's-land, slightly bemused by the combination of Heather's strident sanctimony and Sir Paul's slavering. Funnily enough, Pride was the first of the sins to be tackled in... well, The Sins, BBC1's new go-on!-guess-how-many-parts series, in which Pete Postlethwaite plays Len, an ex-getaway driver determined to go straight. I couldn't take my eyes off that spin-dried Sinatra face, in which sweetness and menace seem to fight for control of his features. So much so, that scenes without Postlethwaite faltered slightly, not through any fault of the script or the acting, but just because Pete fills the screen with so much mutable gravitas. Frank Finlay came close, though, as Len's Uncle Irwin, a funeral director contemplating retirement, regretful that 'there is no obvious replacement chomping at the funereal bit' and operating just a few doors up the road from the Hammer House of Horror: 'I have some lungs to drain, but I can work quite happily while you rummage around.' After his turn as Dylan (love-of-my-life) Moran's evil father-in-law in How Do You Want Me?, Finlay is rather belatedly cornering the market in menacing campery - which is odd given that he was doing it brilliantly as far back as Bouquet of Barbed Wire . Len's sin manifested at a party thrown to celebrate his release from a four-year stretch, where he told his crime cronies they were 'dullards' and proclaimed his freshly minted middle-classness: 'I live in Paradise Drive, I've had a letter published in the Telegraph, one of my daughters is up at Oxford', which, predictably, went down like a pair of concrete wellies, particularly with his family. Suddenly, Len's wife (Geraldine James) couldn't get her regular table at Mario's ('Am I or am I not Len Green's wife?' 'Len Green is not Len Green any more,' shrugged Mario) and 'in the light of recent developments' her credit was revoked at the local boutique. Meanwhile, Len was off to the Job Centre, demanding 'proper, stimulating, middle-aged, middle-England legal employment'. The Sins is deliciously wordy, funny and even had a great car chase - very rare on TV, where even Grand Prix look as though everyone's pootling around the M25 in third gear. Next week sees Len working, inevitably, as an undertaker while struggling with Covetousness, particularly in relation to top-of-the-range, fully-loaded hearses. Can't wait. BBC2's Marion and Geoff is a 10-part series of 10-minute dramatic monologues by Keith, minicab driver, divorcee and owner of a selection of Alan Partridge's cast-off sweaters (Steve Coogan is one of the show's producers). Last week saw the halfway mark, which is as good a place as any to ponder Keith's swiftly unravelling grip on what little is left of his sanity. The Marion and Geoff of the title are, respectively, Keith's ex-wife and her new husband, who live in Cardiff with Keith's two young sons, while Keith lives in London but regularly drives through the night accompanied by binoculars, a rifle (with telescopic sight) and toys for the children: 'I thought the Action Man might be too violent but, like his mother says, he's a very violent child.' What initially looked like tragic stoicism in the face of complete rejection (re Geoff: 'I don't feel like I've lost a wife, I've gained a friend!') is proving to be a dangerously thin veneer. Last week, Keith told us how he'd gone to see Father Paul, a pastor - he said: 'You don't need the Church, Keith, you need a bloody good solicitor' - and though we are another five fraught weeks away, the dénouement looks likely to inspire a nationwide mini-cab boycott. Luckily, young Sonia Jackson got a lift to hospital in a black cab when she gave birth, unexpectedly, to Martin Fowler's daughter in Thursday's EastEnders. This was a disappointing episode not least because too many storylines jostled for our attention. Wasn't a teenage girl going into labour without knowing she was pregnant considered enough to sustain 30 minutes of sudsy excitement? Given that Natalie Cassidy is such a good little actress and Sonia such a sympathetic character, they could both have been allowed to hog the show. Instead, the drama was squandered by having Mo Harris play midwife, and constant cutting to the rows between Melanie and Steve, trysts between Frank and Pat, a showdown between Pauline and Martin and, to top it all, an unnecessarily drunk, and therefore pantomimic, Dot Cotton. These days, EastEnders is often distracted from what, in soap terms at least, used to be a laudable concentration span in which plotlines could develop and thrive. At the moment, the cast is too big and too starry and so, perhaps, too demanding of the spotlight. Poor Sonia - she could hardly hear her baby crying over all that din.

fields.headline: NTL may float business arm
fields.trailText: NTL, the cable television and telecoms company, is examining plans to float its business division in a bid to revive its flagging fortunes.
fields.body:
NTL, the cable television and telecoms company, is examining plans to float its business division in a bid to revive its flagging fortunes.

Chief executive Barclay Knapp believes that the financial markets have failed to value NTL properly, with analysts too focused on the company's cable TV distribution platform at the expense of its other divisions.

NTL, which has spent £4.5 billion laying fibre optic cables across the UK, has a market capitalisation of around £10bn. In addition, the company is saddled with around £7bn worth of debt, though it has more than £1bn in cash reserves.

The plan to float the busi ness division is in its infancy, according to sources familiar with the company's thinking. It will be considered more actively next year.

It is most likely that NTL would look to float between 20 and 30 per cent of the division - which this year is on course to produce revenues of around £500 million - in the form of an initial public offering.

However the sources suggested that the company, which switched to the New York Stock Exchange from the Nasdaq last week, could also consider issuing a tracking stock instead.

The business division, which carries voice traffic for the mobile phone companies Orange and Vodafone, is described by NTL as 'the hidden jewel in the crown'.

The division also provides the telecoms infrastructure for Boots, the Metropolitan Police, the Ministry of Defence and most Oxbridge colleges. In recent months it has targeted the small business sector, where it aims to have 30 per cent market share by next year.

A partial flotation of its business arm would be the next logical step in Knapp's thinking. He has taken steps to position NTL as a company comprising three separate divisions in a bid to provide greater clarity to sceptical analysts.

In addition to the consumer and business arms, it has a broadcast division, which is responsible for the terrestrial delivery of ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5 to viewers.

The company is to issue a tracking stock for its broadcast division on the New York Stock Exchange in the near future.

Knapp has in the past expressed a desire to obtain a primary listing for NTL on the London Stock Exchange. However, differences between US and UK listing practices would mean the company incurring a multimillion pound tax bill.

Recently NTL made headlines after pulling out of a £328m deal to buy the pay-per-view rights to Premier League football.

fields.headline: Coward's way out
fields.trailText: Fallen Angels Apollo London W1
fields.body:
Fallen Angels Apollo London W1

Just up the street from The Seven Year Itch , Noël Coward's Fallen Angels could easily be subtitled 'The 12 Year Itch'. That's how long Julia (Felicity Kendal) and Jane (Frances de la Tour) have been married to their husbands, and life is beginning to pall. So when the men have rolled off for a golfing weekend and a postcard heralds the arrival of an ex-lover with whom they both had a premarital affair, they are determined, after a token attack of conscience, to misbehave.

While waiting for Maurice - a romantic Frenchman, and the antithesis of their tweedy spouses - to arrive from Paris, the two women dress spectacularly for dinner in Julia's Mayfair flat and proceed to get royally drunk. Thus ensues a hilarious piece of comedy - wonderfully choreographed by director Michael Rudman - as Kendal somersaults over the sofa, slithers horizontally over the furniture on to the floor to light de la Tour's cigarette, and de la Tour tries to remove her shoes while standing firmly rooted to the ground.

Yet under the slapstick runs the icy rivalry of what will actually happen when Maurice does turn up. Who will he choose? How will the other one react? Will they really be able to maintain their close friendship as they claim?

All this seems fairly commonplace for the year 2000, but it shocked critics to the core when it first opened in 1925 with Tallulah Bankhead as Julia. The notion that the women had had sex before marriage, and were contemplating adultery almost lost the play its performing licence.

The work is a fine piece of Coward writing: witty, trenchant, superficially frothy but actually questioning the empty lives led by these indolent, privileged people. It is dominated by strong, feisty women reminiscent of Hay Fever, and there is one of Coward's fantastically eccentric maid characters - Saunders, deftly played by Tilly Tremayne - subtly stealing the limelight from time to time along the lines of the dour Miss Erickson in Present Laughter. Stephen Greif is a smooth Maurice who has lost none of his charm; it is the two husbands - James Woolley and Eric Carte - who have to make the best of feeble parts.

fields.headline: Postcard from Beirut
fields.standfirst: Holy wars and hostages: Lebanon should be a hotbed of political pop. So why is it all German metal?
fields.trailText: Holy wars and hostages: Lebanon should be a hotbed of political pop. So why is it all German metal?
fields.body:
Radio Music Lebanon is a privately owned FM station based in the Christian quarter of Ashrafieh, a suburb of Beirut. The station has been broadcasting every day since 1979 - except for one month in 1990, when the FM tower was destroyed by an Israeli bombardment. On the eighth floor of the still-dilapidated building, Claude Kawas, the 29-year-old station manager, walks me into a studio.

In a country repeatedly scarred by war, a country where many young people idolise Hizbollah, the Iranian-backed militant group famous for kidnapping Israeli soldiers, you might expect the music on the airwaves to be a cauldron of radical politics. If any nation on earth were likely to be a fount of political pop music, Lebanon should surely be it.

Yet the only radicalism that RML broadcasts is the anti-PC, corrupt westernisms of American hip-hop stars such as Eminem, Dr Dre and the Wu Tang Clan. That and heavy metal. 'The kids especially like German metal music,' says Kawas. He laughs incredulously: 'Yes, I know: German metal! I don't understand it either.'

For over 20 years, RML has doggedly stuck to its policy of avoiding political comment on the airwaves. This, despite Muslim-Christian wars, clashes between rival Islamic groups, a border war with Syria and two Israeli invasions. 'We want to bring people down from the level of war,' says Kawas. 'What we do here is pure entertainment. This isn't a country where political expression is tolerated.'

The station's current advertisement shows Lebanese politicians graphically manipulated to dance to the tune of Stardust's 1999 hit, 'Music Sounds Better With You'. 'We took a chance with that,' Kawas admits. 'It was dangerous.'

The only person in Lebanon who dares to write political pop songs, he tells me, is veteran rock singer Gassan Rahbani, the very mention of whose name tends to make people look startled and slightly scared. For more than 20 years, Rahbani has been, effectively, Lebanon's only protest singer. At 36, his cultural standing is best approximated as Public Enemy mixed with Neil Young.

Rahbani Studios is located in Italias, a Beirut suburb nearly 30 miles north of the city centre. During the Lebanese civil war of 1975, Italias withstood heavy artillery fire from the fighting Muslim and Christian factions - and with reconstruction still limited to Beirut, the suburban skyline is dominated by bombed-out high-rise buildings.

Rahbani greets me and leads the way to his office. The wood flooring is cluttered with boxes of CDs and vinyl. The walls are lined with pictures of him on stage. He looks an unlikely pop star - nearly middle-aged, balding and with a scraggly beard. A trio of metallic laminates on the wall advertise his favourite rock performers - Jimi Hendrix, Whitesnake and Deep Purple. 'I loved Whitesnake,' he says. 'I could kiss the hands of David Coverdale.'

His father, Elias Rahbani, 62, is a multiculturalist composer celebrated throughout the Middle East. Back in the Eighties, the younger Rahbani was catapulted to early success with his hard rock group, Wild Days. And over a 20-year career, he has amassed a back catalogue of 11 albums. His most famous tunes include 'Prohibited' (his denunciation of censorship), 'The Municipality of Beirut' (a scathing attack on local pollution) and 'The Road To The Airport'.

One of his most recognised songs, 'Stranger Go Home', has become a veritable national anthem against Syria's 35,000 occupation forces, who have been stationed in southern Lebanon since 1990. Against squealing guitars and thunderous drums, Rahbani delivers his ultimatum to the occupiers: 'You gotta know that/ You'll have to leave/ I'm warnin' you for the last time/ We are a country that could never die/ We'll keep on fighting/ Till you can't find your way home'.

Why is heavy metal so popular here, I wonder? 'Heavy metal reminds me of war - the drums are like the cannons,' Rahbani says, matter-of-factly. 'And the raps are like the sound of chaos.'

At BO18, a local nightclub on Thursday evening, the city's well-heeled Lebanese teenagers dance to the latest R&B and hip-hop imports. The girls stand jiggling their wares by their boyfriends, clutching glasses of orange juice as the menfolk hold bottles of beer. Many of them are students at the American University of Beirut, where student fees climb up to $4,000 per term.

'Hip-hop is very popular,' says Abou Aziz, 23, a local promoter. Aziz puts together touring packages of local groups, booking them into Beirut, Saida and Tripoli. 'Rap music is aggressive,' he continues. 'You have to speak your mind. People have not learned to do that here yet - Rahbani is the first one to do it. Who knows, maybe something will happen to him. Many people are still scared.'

Standing next to him, MC Yusef, 25, gets ready for his turn on the nightclub's turntables. Of Pakistani origin, Yusef has released one hip-hop single to date - 'My Drive Home' - a humorous song about drink-driving. It has become an underground hit, but Yusef is thinking of reinventing himself as a militant rapper. 'I like Hizbollah,' he explains, 'because they hate Israelis.'

However, there is a problem. Yusef's expression grows darker, and he mumbles. 'But Hizbollah does not like music,' he tells me. From outside, we can hear the muezzins call from the minarets for the last prayer of the evening. 'Hizbollah would not like raps,' Yusef says. 'In Islam it is forbidden.'

fields.headline: Come back, Paul
fields.standfirst: Despite too many bongos, Paul Simon's first London gig in 10 years was a triumph
fields.trailText: Paul Simon Hammersmith Apollo, London W6
fields.body:
Paul Simon Hammersmith Apollo, London W6

No one does 'unprepossessing' like Paul Simon. He comes on stage looking like he has just driven a busload of fans down from Rhyl. He's wearing one of those 'I'm not bald' baseball caps. He'll be 60 next year. He's not getting any taller. And yet who out of this packed audience wouldn't swap their full head of hair and 10 years out of their life for an ounce of this man's exquisite talent?

Well OK, maybe not the hair, but he is rather brilliant, kicking off with a song from the new album, You're The One, which has had rave reviews, though admittedly not in my house, where we prefer our Paul Simon a bit less 57 varieties of percussion and a bit more tuney and poetic. Even so, the 11-piece band (two keyboards, two guitars, bass, drums, horn section, herds of bongo and maraca) are so steamingly hot that even the new material makes me want to rush home and give it the benefit of the doubt with the sound turned up and the washing machine off.

In any case, there's a ton of back catalogue to get through - rich selections from Graceland, Rhymin' Simon, Still Crazy - one diamond-cut song after another (very sensibly nothing from The Capeman, I notice, the fruit of his ill-starred dalliance with Broadway musicals).

The audience show their appreciation in the usual way, but is it enough? I mean, there'll always be someone hired to bellow incoherently from the back and one or two isolated displays of uninhibited joy but, on the whole, artists of Paul Simon's vintage tend to attract a more sedate crowd. It occurs to me that maybe his management should insist on a 'drunks-only' door policy to guarantee the kind of audience ready to conga round the theatre during those 'contagious' Latin numbers or even perhaps stifle a collective sob when he gets to that line, 'Losing love is like a window in your heart/ Everbody sees you're blown apart...'

But then halfway through the spine-tinglingly sublime 'Boy in the Bubble', a quartet of lovely young women in a state of unabashed rapture come twirling down the aisle and start dancing at the front of the stage. Who are they? How did they get past the doorman?'These are the days of miracle and wonder,' Paul is singing, and suddenly he is right. Of course, the girls have to be ushered away by someone in a blue blazer, but it is a moment to suggest that this night - Simon's first London concert in 10 years - might be one to remember. And so it proves to be. By the end, grown men and women are practically climbing on each other's shoulders just to touch his hand.

There are unexpected treats on the way - an anthemic 'I Am a Rock' fattened up with swirling keyboards; spartan treatments of 'Homeward Bound' and 'American Tune', displaying Simon's often overlooked talent as a guitar picker of invention and sensitivity - not to mention the trademark purity of his vocals, remarkably unwithered by time. Even 'Bridge Over Troubled Water', refashioned with moaning cello and echoing electric guitars, is more than enough to reach the right parts of those customers who thought they'd be happy not to hear it again.

I suppose I could carp at his weakness for 'novelty' songs - '50 Ways to Leave Your Lover' is precisely the kind of number that encourages people to clap along delightedly out of time with the music; I could grimace at the bongo-heavy reworking of 'Kodachrome' played at the speed of sound; I might suggest that improvised body movements of all kinds be left to the likes of Tina Turner (Simon spends what guitar-free time he has prowling the stage practising a bizarre air-stroking routine).

But I won't. As the man says: 'You can't be forever blessed.' Though he does come pretty close to it.

I suppose I could carp at his weakness for 'novelty' songs - '50 Ways to Leave Your Lover' is precisely the kind of number that encourages people to clap along delightedly out of time with the music; I could grimace at the bongo-heavy reworking of 'Kodachrome' played at the speed of sound; I might suggest that improvised body movements of all kinds be left to the likes of Tina Turner (Simon spends what guitar-free time he has prowling the stage practising a bizarre air-stroking routine). But I won't. As the man says: 'You can't be forever blessed.' Though he does come pretty close to it.

webTitle: He flies through the air with the greatest of ease

fields.headline: He flies through the air with the greatest of ease
fields.trailText:
Akram Khan Lilian Baylis Theatre, London EC1
Swan Lake ROH, London WC2
fields.body:
Akram Khan Lilian Baylis Theatre, London EC1
Swan Lake ROH, London WC2

Akram Khan dances in freefall, composed and intense, hanging in there for dear life. Where ballet dancers try to escape gravity, he ignores it. Thanks to his training in the Kathak tradition of Indian dance, he can scoot around space like a jump-cut edit. He's moved before you can blink.

Khan has launched his own company (now touring) with a trio, Rush, following his concentrated solo, Fix. The solo is addictive, changing subtly each time he has performed it over the past year. Last week's account was the most ascetic yet, more a Sufi meditation than a journey of discovery.

The question of whether Khan can transfer his skills to other bodies is part-answered by Rush. He takes motifs from Fix - spins, falls and rolls - and formalises them into rhythmic patterns. At first, you watch only him; then the structure takes over. Gwyn Emberton and Moya Michael contribute their own qualities; where Khan floats, they flail themselves into weightlessness. Rush feels like a work in progress, ready for further elaboration.

Anthony Dowell's last season as artistic director of the Royal Ballet opened with his 1987 production of Swan Lake. No doubt the first thing his successor, Ross Stretton, will do is replace it with his own. Maybe then we'll be sorry to lose Dowell's version.

But since the last Swan Lake we saw on the Opera House stage in summer was the Kirov's, it is obvious how much the Royal Ballet has been missing over the years. Compared with the Kirov's classic account of the white acts, Dowell's looks decadent, sentimental. His swan-maidens are fluffy, lakeside creatures, their abstract patterns blurred by fluttery dresses and a flock of swan-children, cute, minute and in the way.

This soft-edged corps bears no relation to the strikingly athletic Odette of Darcey Bussell, a bird-woman whose pinions have to be held down by her determined suitor (Roberto Bolle). She dances with admirable power, then mars her clean sweep by adding flapping hands and a pained expression. Instead of moving in a sustained flow, as Kirov swan queens do, Bussell goes from one pose to another. She end-stops the dance phrases by holding balances as long as she can.

It is an approach that works triumphantly in Act III, where her Odile is boldly alluring. Bolle's Siegfried succumbs without a qualm. A discreet partner and excellent dancer, Bolle needs to assert himself more forcefully to complement Bussell's Olympian magnetism.

Johan Persson, making his debut on Wednesday with Tamara Rojo, portrayed a feckless Euro-princeling, obstinately falling for the wrong girl.

Rojo's Odile was wicked in the modern sense, whipping off triple fouettés and shooting seductive glances from under her dark brows. As Odile, she was all of a piece; as Odette in Act II, she seemed to be giving two interpretations - her own and the Royal Ballet's.

Everything came together in the last act, where she and the swans, companions in distress, finally inhabited the same world. Act IV is the climax of this production, instead of the coda, a sign of how skewed towards soppiness Dowell's vision has become.

webTitle: The things we do for love...

fields.headline: The things we do for love...
fields.standfirst: Forget hearts, flowers and chocolates. This is about real love - suffering, turmoil and regrets
fields.trailText: In the Mood For Love (98mins, PG) Directed by Wong Kar-Wai; starring Tony Leung, Maggie Cheung
fields.body:
In the Mood For Love (98mins, PG) Directed by Wong Kar-Wai; starring Tony Leung, Maggie Cheung

Are you In the Mood For Love? It sounds like a romantic comedy - Ryan and Hanks, even Fred and Ginger - but there is nothing remotely comic here. This love is intricate, consuming and elegiac. And, though the mood is essentially European - say mid-career Truffaut, with a whisper of Brief Encounter - the setting is far away in the Hong Kong of the early Sixties. Wong Kar-Wai, chameleon amongst great directors, has done it again.

Tony Leung Chiu-Wai is Mr Chow, a thirtysomething journalist with a pretty wife. Maggie Cheung Man-Yuk is Mrs Chow, a super secretary married to a travelling businessman. The couples find rooms to live in adjoining flats. Slowly, it dawns on Leung and Cheung that their increasingly absent partners are having an affair. Slowly, Leung begins his pursuit of the wronged wife and she begins to descend into an agony of doubt. If she succumbs, will she be any better than her faithless husband?

Wong Kar-Wai does everything: action movies, cop movies, epics, often with a French new-wave feel of improvisation. Here, there is none of that. Instead, we move meticulously from one little box to the next, from one poky room to the room next door. Other rooms in the apartment block are filmed down corridors or over shoulders; the only excursions beyond are into deserted streets where rain falls torrentially around the sheltering pair. Complete claustrophobia. We never see the faces of the adulterous husband or his mistress, only their backs: they are ciphers throwing Leung and Cheung into starker relief.

Does that sound a trifle dour? It isn't. The family who rent Cheung her room are warm and effusive, always offering food and companionship. Leung's hoary journalist mate is rounded and jolly. There is human life just across the landing or at the office; the characters are rooted in place and time - but that time, too, matters. Falling in love in the Hong Kong of four decades ago isn't a quick, modern fling. You feel the brooding disapproval of a more traditional Chinese society. Contacts must be secret, emotions hidden. Celia Johnson looks out of the railway carriage window. Upper lips stiffen and then quiver. When Cheung is trapped - innocently enough - in Leung's bedroom overnight, because others are playing mah-jong outside, there's no question of a quick roll on the bed. Cheung lies there alone, imprisoned by inhibition.

Wong Kar-Wai is never entirely unobtrusive. The director's presence remains constant - sometimes playing jokes, like rehearsals of the farewell speeches Cheung will make to her husband, which appear, for a moment, to be the real thing. But that constant presence merely focuses us more hypnotically on the central relationship; and upon a particular sequence of months and passions locked away, resistance eroding as the mood takes hold.

It doesn't work completely. Leung and Cheung are two of China's most fêted stars, one stubby, battered and thoughtfully bemused, the other sinuous and tortured. They hold the screen and the still, silent Leung is especially hypnotic as he calculates and manipulates. But Cheung has an almost impossibly testing role. Can she make us, as twenty-first-century spectators, comprehend and share her inner turmoil? Can she become somebody we not only understand intellectually, but weep for in her desperate dilemma of the soul?

Maybe Truffaut could have got that from Nathalie Baye, because her face is infinitely expressive and part of a world we understand. Cheung cannot quite convey that. She agonises, but she can't draw us in. The gap between eras and cultures is too great. The background score, by Mike Galasso, plonks away, sometimes Nat King Cole, sometimes second-hand Michel Legrand, so that you know you ought to understand. But no - you can see the suffering, yet you don't feel it. A love story without the hint of tear.

But for all that this is an accomplished and memorable film, one that Wong Kar-Wai fought to finish through two years of censorship and Eastern financial crisis. Why should the censors have worried? There is no sex here, no sweaty coupling. This is love pursued, love won, love lost; love as a mingling of minds and calculation; love as regret. The chameleon called love.

webTitle: If you go down to the woods today, you're sure of a big demise

fields.headline: If you go down to the woods today, you're sure of a big demise
fields.trailText:
Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 (90mins, 18) Directed by Joe Berlinger; starring Kim Director, Jeffrey Donovan
It Was an Accident (100mins, 18) Directed by Metin Hüseyin; starring Max Beesley, Thandie Newton
I Could Read the Sky (86 mins, 15) Directed by Nichola Bruce; starring Dermot Healy
fields.body:
Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 (90mins, 18) Directed by Joe Berlinger; starring Kim Director, Jeffrey Donovan
It Was an Accident (100mins, 18) Directed by Metin Hüseyin; starring Max Beesley, Thandie Newton
I Could Read the Sky (86 mins, 15) Directed by Nichola Bruce; starring Dermot Healy

Sometimes, one and one don't make two. Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2, has next to nothing of the Project that set cash registers ringing. Not the same cast, the same director, the same style or any continuation - if that were possible - of the same story. This is tosh of an altogether lower order. There isn't even, since you ask, a book of shadows.

Forget the artful triumph of what we must now call Blair Witch 1, the hand-held cameras which followed three students into the woods of Black Hills, Maryland, and, half-way between documentary and drama, appeared to chronicle their vanishing, victims of a phantom we never saw. If that was docuhorror, this is schlocku-horror.

It doesn't start like that. Joe Berlinger, who specialises in filming real murder mysteries, has had the bright notion of taking the actual fame that the Project brought to the village of Burkittsville and sending five more potential victims into the woods on a kind of idiotic guided tour. Cue in two minutes or so of genuinely funny cod interviews with local residents. Hope rises.There weren't many jokes in BW1. Hope falls. The quintet are standard freaks for the teenage market. They reach the house at the heart of darkness, they come out intact: but then, in the old warehouse which Jeffrey Donovan, their loopy tour guide uses as his Blair Witch mail shop, the curse of the Black Hills catches up with them. Standard freaks, standard mayhem.

Where the chill of the original came from not knowing, not seeing, Berlinger jolts the screen with blood and guts. Where the sparse, $30,000 production values of BW1 were integral to its queasy credibility, here cash and computer effects rule this dotty roost.

Our unfortunate five give us nothing to identify with. Donovan's Jeff is fresh out of an asylum, but nothing's ultimately made of his supreme flakiness. Kim Director wears white pancake make-up straight out of The Munsters and has the occasional gift of prophesy, except where her own fate's concerned; Erica Leerhsen is a student witch much given to hopping round in the nude; Tristan Skyler and Stephen Barker are dopey young lovers. None of them is going to win an Oscar. When Donovan protests out loud that 'I don't understand this' the audience gurgles with instant derision.

Still, it will doubtless make a few million - and deserve to, not entirely for its effrontery. Berlinger knows how to keep the action zipping along. Arch references to movies past and present are scattered liberally. If BW1 hadn't existed, BW2 might have passed muster in the Saturday night stalls. Go expecting to be kept awake, but not to be amazed or chilled.

So to two films from closer to home, both derived from successful novels, both blessed with an Arts Council grant. Why are the financial arbiters of culture favouring It Was an Accident? Does somebody up there in Great Peter Street think that British film is perishing for lack of London gangster movies? They might as well erect a statue of Ray Winstone in Trafalgar Square.

To be fair, this Accident, contrived by Ol Parker from Jeremy Cameron's book, has some promising things going for it. Belly laughs for a start; a Runyonesque version of Walthamstow street life for another. Nicky Burkett, played by Chjwetel Ejiofor, is back on those streets after four years in the slammer.

He wants to go straight and shack up with a policeman's daughter (Thandie Newton), but villains keep getting in his way. There's Mickey Cousins (Max Beesley), your original blond idiot; there's Rameez (Sidh Solanki), your Asian Mr Big; there's Fitch (James Bolam), who 'used to drive for the Krays'.

The first half bowls along nicely, full of neat touches. The cops, save for Newton's thoughtful black dad (Hugh Quarshie), are Keystone galumphers. Ejiofor, of course, has a wonderfully lippy kid by a discarded partner. The dodgy flats, motors and market tradesmen combine to make this Walthamstow a fun place to be. Metin Hüseyin (from Common as Muck ) knows how to stage comic setpieces. Where does it all go wrong? Pacing, tone, language.

You can't keep going as fast as this without a break. What works for a TV sitcom doesn't work for a film three times as long. The haste becomes frenetic, and thus disjunct. And this is a Brit gangster effort (without Sadie Frost for once) so, naturally, it can't be all laughs, can it? You have to have a bit of - you know - thumping and shooting and smashing. Bring on the gratuitous violence. Exit the light touch.

Language? I should effing say so, every effing 15 seconds. It ain't a matter of prudery, mate, it just gets effing boring in the effing end.

The great unresolved question is how Thandie Newton, luminously svelte in Mission Impossible 2 , here turns up as Ehofor's relatively chaste bit of fluff in an anorak, but her very presence makes the wider point. Newton is a considerable actress who can play a human being (among many other things). Ol Parker's script gives here little to do but frown and look disapproving. That's not an accident - it's an effing waste of effing talent.

Those who like their art with a capital C, as in Council, will find I Could Read the Sky more their evocative fix. It's an adaptation, by Nichola Bruce, of the 'photo-novel' by Timothy O'Grady and Steve Pyke which was Gerry Adams's best book of 1997. Dermot Healy, the distinguished Irish novelist, has the central acting role. He is old, creaky Irish labourer, and he lives in a London garret, shuffling the bare boards, remembering.

He remembers the white-washed cottage in the green fields of home. He remembers his mum and dad and the poverty that forced him to come, with thousands of others, to the building sites of England. He remembers the wife who died and the mate who died sleeping in a giant sewage pipe and his mother who died, black with cancer when they did the post-mortem, and the father whose grave he was left to disinter in the mud and rain. All this with the photos of the book opened out into landscapes and small scenes from the past, performed by Ireland's finest, like Stephen Rea.

It is a tour de force from Healy, a ginger, shambling wreck who speaks the almost-poetry with arresting precision. Beautiful words; beautiful music, from Iarla O'Lionaird; beautiful moving pictures from Nichola Bruce. Too beautiful, too relentlessly melancholic? That's the trouble.

The photo-novel works so brilliantly because you can linger over O'Grady's prose and set it against Pyke's photographs, choosing your own pace and time, letting the images grows. Contract that into 86 minutes of movie narrative, though, and the obligatory returns to Healy's garret become a bit of chore, without light and shade. You either want to know more or less - and the death of his inevitably beautiful wife (Maria Doyle Kennedy) feels merely gratuitous, one more awful thing piled on top.

For all the novelty of its form, we've been here before amid the Irish mists of exile. Somehow, I wanted to be told something new.

fields.headline: Troy, Troy, Troy again...
fields.standfirst: It may be 12 hours long but this modern epic based on Greek myth is mesmerising
fields.trailText: Tantalus Denver Center for the Performing Arts, Colorado
fields.body:
Tantalus Denver Center for the Performing Arts, Colorado

Why Denver? After 15 years of labour, John Barton, director and co-founder of the Royal Shakespeare Company, produces a massive cycle of plays. It's based on Greek mythology, which means that it touches on almost every issue flying around the twenty-first century: vengeance after war, the chances of a just peace, the impossibility of assigning blame and the point at which a beauty becomes an icon. Stephen Daldry declares he would rip out the seating in the Old Vic in order to stage it.

Peter Hall, Barton's life-long friend who becomes, together with his son, Edward, director of the cycle proclaims that if he were running the RSC he'd 'scrap some of the repertory' in order to put it on. But when the premiere of Tantalus takes place it is hundreds of miles away, at the Denver Center for Performing Arts in Colorado.

Lack of cash meant that the RSC, who commissioned the piece, couldn't put it on. There was no room at the Dome. And no television company was prepared to stump up. As if the Fates had been at work.

A play which shows the sacking of one civilisation and the making of another - Greece - was performed in a town whose glossy towers and silent gleaming malls are surrounded by the relics of faded glories, by old mining towns with names, such as Silver Plume, as evocative as Troy, though now their only gold hangs from aspen branches. It was acted by a cast of Americans and Britons in a place formed by Hispanic and Native American and pioneer cultures.

And Denver's craggy setting proved particularly piquant. Tantalus was punished by continual threat and constantly frustrated desire for betraying the gods. In Hades, grapes were dangled in front of his mouth and a rock was suspended precariously above him: in the Halls' production, you see sand drifting down and at crucial moments hear warning groans, as if an avalanche were about to launch itself on to the stage. Where better to acknowledge this stony menace than in a city shadowed by the Rockies?

It's a tribute to Tantalus that it wakes you up to such parallels.

And the tribute's the greater because Barton's enterprise has one foot in the academy. He has created his own version of the conduct and consequences of the Trojan War. He has drawn on ancient sources, though without using lines from classical drama. He has written in unrhymed verse, though the verse format isn't always detectable, or delectable. He has larded the dialogue with literary allusions ranging from Troilus and Cressida to The Importance of Being Earnest: 'One rape is a misfortune; two cause comment.'

Tantalus has been cut and edited by the directors. But its nine remaining plays - in which the playwright Colin Teevan is credited with providing some 'additional text' - still amount to a marathon: at Denver, they started at 10am and ended at 10.45pm. It is, remarked one member of the audience, 'such a dare to do something this long about something so old'.

A battery of surprises keeps the audience on its intellectual toes, not to say tantalised. The structure of the plays is unexpected: a series of cliffhangers, which Barton has described as soap-operatic. The dialogue switchbacks unpredictably from bleak to droll. The plot twists are startling: the Greeks sail off for Troy, but land up in Mysia; Helen is said not to have gone to Troy at all because that was another, more superficial Helen. And, alongside a reprisal of classical tragic themes - do human beings have any control over their own destinies? Are patterns of revenge imprinted through generations? - Barton charts his own concerns. Not least of these is the history of drama, a movement from storytelling to acting, which suggests that Ulysses started out as a bit of a fraud, and that Achilles's son was the first actor - getting himself up in drag in order to beguile the Trojans.

Some of this is exhilarating. There are terrific performances from the fluidly transforming (American) Analee Jefferies and from (British) Greg Hicks, as a wry Agamemnon and a tottering carnival Priam. Some of it is casually misogynistic: does Helen, in a world of adulterous men, have to be pure to be adored?

Some scenes are made more vital by the Halls' robust, sometimes gorgeous production: the Trojan women, about to be branded by their conquerors, appear in their red wedding dresses like the stumps of teeth; Mick Sands' dulcimers and drums ripple through the action; Dionysis Fotopoulos's design, a hemisphere of sand with a screen of smokey glass at its back, is transformed by Sumio Yoshii's lighting into a rippling underwater region.

Other episodes are made more ludicrous: it's bad enough that Barton's female chorus is required to behave like stooges teasing out information from a charismatic male poet. ('Yes he was a god-swan.' 'Which god was it?') But the clumpiness is increased by setting the scene on a Fifties-going-on-Sixties beach, with a gaggle of girls, clenched by bikinis and clutching transistors, desperately trying to look hip. Never can there have been so much explanation with so little clarity. It's a fluent, exciting production which is insufficiently peculiar.

It has spawned its own epic struggles. The artistic director of the Gate, Mick Gordon, was engaged to work with the Halls, but exited early. One actor was sacked; one left. Barton has described the performed version of his cycle as drastically condensed', and explains 'my own vision, however passionate may not necessarily be welcome'. He was not at the premiere.

fields.headline: The final countdown
fields.standfirst: The search for the nation's favourite song - and the one we most love to hate - is almost over. But, as  Sam Taylor finds, there's a thin line between turning the radio up and wanting to throw it out of the window
fields.trailText: The search for the nation's favourite song - and the one we most love to hate - is almost over. But, as  Sam Taylor finds, there's a thin line between turning the radio up and wanting to throw it out of the window
fields.body:
Well, one more day of voting to go and it's looking like a two-horse race. Both of the major prizes on offer - the Best No 1 of All Time and the No 1 We Most Love to Hate - are being contested by two front-runners. Not, I should stress, the same two front-runners. Indeed, they are very different. The two songs at the top of the Most Loved poll are classics from the Seventies, while the two songs at the top of the Love to Hate poll were both released in the last five years. Sorry, I can't tell you more than that. You'll just have to wait till January, when the final results will be broadcast on Channel 4.

However, I can tell you about some of the broader trends highlighted by the poll results so far. The Seventies, for instance, despite being the decade in which the current Top Three were recorded, seems far from the golden decade if you take into consideration the rest of the results. Of the Top 40 Most Loved No1s, 12 are from the Sixties, 12 from the generally reviled Eighties, and nine from the Nineties (including eight in the Top 30), while a mere five songs have made it from the halcyon era of disco, glam and rap.

Oh, and one from the twenty-first century. Yes, rather astonishingly, Spiller's 'Groovejet (If This Ain't Love)', the sole post-millennial entrant, is in the Top 10. The Rolling Stones' only entry, meanwhile - '(I Can't Get No) Satisfaction' - barely scrapes into the Top 40, way behind their supposedly lesser contemporaries The Monkees, The Animals and The Kinks.

There are lots of quirks like this in the results. As a child of the Eighties, I have to say I'm rather gutted (and genuinely surprised) that Human League's mordant classic 'Don't You Want Me?' is not even ranked in the top half. For me, the early Eighties were a golden period for the pop single: the combination of post-punk aesthetics, the liberating technology of the synthesiser and a certain manic boldness in the fashion world made the years 1980-83 an extremely colourful period in chartland. Yet not only did the panel ruthlessly (and, let's face it, wrongly) dispose of Adam & the Ants and Duran Duran, but of the eight tracks in this list that fit my criteria (ie they made my heart beat faster as an 11-year-old), only 'Tainted Love' has exceeded expectation by scraping courageously into the Top 20. Otherwise, classics by The Jam ('Going Underground'), Frankie Goes to Hollywood ('Relax'), Blondie ('Heart of Glass') and Human League are all muddling around in mid-table mediocrity. As for Spandau Ballet ('True'), The Specials ('Ghost Town') and The Pretenders ('Brass in Pocket'), well, they're so far down, they're practically out. Come on people, Tony Hadley gives you 'the sound of his soul' and you rank him 50 places below Robbie Williams's smarmy 'Millennium'? You ingrates...

Elsewhere, there are some startling incongruities. Is the Manic Street Preachers' 'If You Tolerate This, Your Children Will Be Next' really more loved than Gloria Gaynor's 'I Will Survive'? Can 'Gangsta's Paradise' genuinely be better thought of than 'I Heard It Through the Grapevine'? Well, yes - but only by one vote. So all you Marvin Gaye fans should get on the modem now if you want your idol to overtake Coolio.

In terms of the kind of songs that are doing best, the received wisdom has always been that ballads sell better than uptempo tracks. That would appear to be backed up by the Top 10 - seven of which are heavy, slushy ballads with a capital B. Seven and a half if you count the opening section of 'Bohemian Rhapsody'. Of the songs ranked 11-40, however, only nine are ballads. In other words, only 16 of the Top 40.

My idea of a great pop single is, by contrast, something that fizzes with invention, melody, wit and a certain kind of brazenness, yet still manages to sound a little odd . It has to have a chorus that echoes in your head after the second listen (there are exceptions to this rule, obviously - 'Bohemian Rhapsody' being the most daring and popular), but it also has to be non-formulaic and unclichéd. It needs to have gracefulness and a kind of gleaming perfection, yet also some buried weirdness, an emotional subtext that you didn't expect. And it has to fade or climax before you're ready for it to end, so that your initial impulse is to hit the repeat button or pull the needle back to the outside groove. Every second has to count, from the first sound you hear - the prowling bassline in 'Grapevine', the first high synthesiser note of 'Nothing Compares 2 U' - to the final chord. And it needs passion. In other words, 'Strawberry Fields Forever' rather than 'Hey Jude'; 'Roxanne' rather than 'Every Breath You Take'; 'Wannabe' rather than 'Holler'...

As for the great historical war between rock bands and pop acts (recently reactivated by Bono), that's alive and well. Of the Top 40 Most Loved No1s, 16 are by pop acts, 16 by rock acts. There are also three dance, two hip-hop and two soul tracks, plus Gloria Gaynor's disco anthem.

The chosen ones are a fairly heterogenous bunch - mostly white, straight and male. Only nine of the Top 40 are by black artists (and that's including Michael Jackson!), with a further two by racially mixed groups (The Prodigy and, er, Band Aid). Eight are sung by women (eight and a half if you count Band Aid), while only four are by openly gay artists.

Only two songs out of the 105 have received more votes in the Love to Hate category than in the Love category, which is surprising in such a cynical age, and particularly on a topic like No1 singles, which by their nature tend to be so ubiquitous and overplayed that even the ones you start out loving will begin to grind on you after a while. It's interesting, though, that ballads do even better in the Love to Hate category than in the Most Loved category: sugary sentimentality is clearly something of an ambiguous obsession for the British record-buying public.

But it's also noticeable that many singles appear close to the top of both categories. Of the Top 40 Most Loved No1s, 14 are also in the Top 40 singles that we most love to hate. Seven appear in both Top 20s. It is, as The Pretenders once sang, a thin line between love and hate. Now, that was a single...

fields.headline: 'I feel guilty about Mother'
fields.trailText: Until last January, my 85-year-old widowed mother lived in her own suburban home. She was hospitalised with flu and assessed as needing full-time nursing care, as her family had known for some time. Since then, she has lived in a nearby, cheerful, friendly nursing home but as her strength has improved she has become more and more depressed at her situation to the point of needing medication.
fields.body:
Until last January, my 85-year-old widowed mother lived in her own suburban home. She was hospitalised with flu and assessed as needing full-time nursing care, as her family had known for some time. Since then, she has lived in a nearby, cheerful, friendly nursing home but as her strength has improved she has become more and more depressed at her situation to the point of needing medication.

Although her short-term memory loss and Parkinson's means that she can't sustain her thoughts, they clearly centre on: 'Why am I here?'

I know she feels that she has a right to be cared for by my brother or myself, just as she cared for her own mother-in-law for 10 years.

My brother and his wife live nearby but work full-time. My husband and I, while early retired, live six- and-a-half-hours' drive away in a remote location. When any of us visit her she clings to us and asks us to stay with her. I do not feel I could possibly offer her what she needs but I also feel I have abandoned her.

Please would you comment on all this?

W.A. of Pembrokeshire

A person who gives up her own concerns to look after another individual shows an awesome degree of philanthropy, which I for one could not match. Giving total care can be tough and heart-breaking, and virtue very seldom brings its own reward.

Everyone gets more selfish with passing years, progressive incapacity and narrowing horizons, and less able to see matters from another perspective. This defect is multiplied when there is encroaching senility. If you were to restructure your life to take on your mother's care, you could well find the task you had set yourself intolerably burdensome.

You might discover, as others have done, that your own marital relationship suffer to the point of collapse, and that even your own patience and good intentions break down in the face of unrelieved, infuriating, round-the-clock demands.

Instead, your mother is in a professionally-run home where the weight of caring is spread among several attendants who can hand over at the appropriate time, walk away, enjoy their own concerns, take a break, recharge their own batteries. Ask yourself: would your mother in, when fully compos mentis, have wanted you to give up all your retired comfort to dance attendance on her? I should abhor the idea of becoming that sort of drag on my children.

Sometimes, senility reproduces reflexes which are peculiar to early infancy, such as the clutching and clinging that you describe. They invoke similar responses in you as in young mothers, a stressful perception of the needs of this helpless being, and an urgent desire to meet them. The manipulation is not intentional but it is compelling.

Don't let the discomfort of your conscience drive you to take on an unreasonable task, but don't let it drive you away either. There is much you can do, visiting and adding to her comfort, being loving and cheerful, but firm.

With a rising proportion of elderly folk in the population and a government that distances itself from the responsibility of providing care for them, your problem is going to become increasingly common. If it is expected that old people are to be looked after by the next generation, there must be a cut-off point; people in their seventies should not be full-time carers for people in their nineties.

I've an idea that we should reactivate the concept of national service for young people after leaving school; two years of caring for old people in various circumstances.

The old and the young meld very well together, and exposure to the needs of others is excellent training, and the scheme would provide huge potential employment at many levels for organisers and supervisors. Some such innovation will be needed if present trends in longevity continue.

Next week's dilemma is from A.M. of Lincoln

I am in the process of divorcing my husband of five years. We have a two-year-old daughter. When we first separated, he came to see her regularly but his visits have now become less frequent because, he says, he cannot bear seeing me.

So far, I have done nothing to encourage him because, although my rational self is keen for him to stay in contact with us so that he and our daughter can build a relationship, there's a part of me that would not be sorry to see him fade away.

He has an alcohol problem which has worsened over the years, and I worry what kind of a role model he will be and whether our daughter will be able to cope with his problems.

Should I encourage him to see her regularly or let him quietly drift away?

webTitle: They're over here and they're over the top

fields.headline: They're over here and they're over the top
fields.standfirst: While surtitles worked well at the Royal Opera House, they were a blot on the landscape at Glyndebourne
fields.trailText:
The Last Supper GTO, Glyndebourne, Sussex
The Magic Flute ETO, Richmond Theatre
BBC Symphony Orchestra Seventieth Birthday Barbican, London EC2/ Radio 3
fields.body:
The Last Supper GTO, Glyndebourne, Sussex
The Magic Flute ETO, Richmond Theatre
BBC Symphony Orchestra Seventieth Birthday Barbican, London EC2/ Radio 3

We try to disguise the fact with argument and sweet reason, but reviewing is a fickle game. What we love one moment we may hate, passionately but logically, the next. Last week, the surtitles at the ROH's Tristan und Isolde won my special praise. This week, I would like to burn every surtitle screen in the land.

This rumbling issue (it's more than a decade since they were introduced) took a new twist at the UK premiere of Harrison Birtwistle's The Last Supper . In Berlin earlier this year, the work, sung in English, had German surtitles. Here, it was sung in English with English surtitles. In Germany, it was easy to ignore them. At Glyndebourne, it was impossible not to. Instead of serving this compellingly audacious work, they got in the way. Robin Blaser's libretto, though occasionally plain and effective, had seemed the weak link in this bold treatment of one of the world's most potent myths.

Birtwistle wanted his opera to centre on '13 blokes sitting round a table'. Blaser aims for high poetry. In Berlin, enough guiding words could be heard, but the force of the piece was primarily musical. Here, the text interposed itself between score and audience. Words half heard or intuited through Birtwistle's blaze of music looked mawkish in their naked state.

In other respects, this co-production between Glyndebourne and the Deutsche Staatsoper had new focus. Martin Duncan's staging, with strong designs by Alison Chitty and lighting by Wolfgang Gobbel, was better prepared than in Berlin. The musical performance, in the hands of Elgar Howarth, a faithful Birtwistle interpreter, was excellent.

It is hard to imagine any group playing this glinting, scintillating, pulsating score better than Glyndebourne Touring Opera's fine musicians managed here. The voices of the unseen 'chorus mysticus' singing their ethereal counterpoint had precision and mystery. Ghost, the only female voice (the formidable mezzo-soprano Susan Bickley), offered a radiant contrast to the dark timbres of a violin-free orchestra and the men's voices, led by Thomas Randle as a potently sullen Judas. The three wordless 'visions' which halt the sequence (or dramatic tableaux, as the work is subtitled) are as impressive as anything Birtwistle has written. The composer has elsewhere, notably in Gawain , been lucky in his librettists. Here, it was impressive he could climb so high using such a rickety ladder.

The ritual of Birtwistle's The Last Supper , in unexpected ways, is not so far from The Magic Flute though Mozart's last opera has a better line in jokes. Sarastro, High Priest of Isis and Osiris, heads a male order dedicated to the pursuit of wisdom and light. Ceremony and symbol play a central role and the Queen of the Night represents the evils of the world. The work's complexity, often buried by those productions which play up the much- loved pantomimic elements, was exposed with bright intelligence in English Touring Opera's new production, which travels to eight venues until December.

Inspired by the star-canopied landscape of Simon Quaglio's Munich 1818 production, ETO sets the opera in an extraterrestrial woodland glade, naive in style, compact and adaptable in function. The Earth spins slowly through the rim of a crater-like hole at the back of the set. (In response to Tamino's 'Where am I?', a member of the highly engaged Richmond audience helpfully replied: 'On the flipping Moon, mate'.) Political correctness makes a predictable appearance: Monostatos the Moor, as disagreeable a racist stereotype as any attributed to Wagner, has become a white thug who all but rapes Pamina. The lovers are fresh-faced teenagers, Tamino in shorts and rugby shirt, Pamina a trim prefect in blouse and pleated skirt.

These somewhat unromantic details robbed the piece of a degree of magic. In its place, the production probed the uneasy heart of the work and raised many usually unasked questions. Whereas the end is usually depicted as a straightforward victory for good, here Pamina is visibly - and convincingly - distraught at being initiated into a sect which, in the name of wisdom, is prepared to destroy her mother. She alone apprehends this contradiction while her naive lover follows his new guru with wide-eyed zeal.

The immediacy of the staging generally worked well in this small theatre. As Tamino, Eugene Ginty sang boldly and accurately, if a little too starkly, but earned bonus points for being an actual player rather than mimer of the eponymous flute. After a stiff start, Richard Burkhard relaxed and enjoyed the humour in Papageno. He sings lyrically, with excellent diction. Every word of Jeremy Sams's classic translation was audible. Laure Meloy's thoughtful Queen of the Night was virtuosic and not the usual pantomime caricature of evil.

The talented cast and chorus were well supported by Martin Fitzpatrick who, in addition to playing the magic bells with great spirit, drew crisp results from ETO's small, dedicated band.

The flourishing BBC Symphony Orchestra gave its first concert at the Queen's Hall 70 years ago. This event was celebrated at the Barbican and live on Radio 3 with a characteristically varied programme conducted by the American Leonard Slatkin, the new chief conductor. What other orchestra has the financial freedom to follow such a daring artistic brief, often to less than full houses? One great tradition has been to support British music via premieres of new works (more than 1,000 to date). Two were included here: Simon Bainbridge's skittering Scherzi was inspired by Mendelssohn's Midsummer Night's Dream and possessed of a similar mercurial spirit. The orchestra's new associate composer, Mark-Anthony Turnage, had reworked a jazz-like piece for trombone solo and orchestra, now entitled Another Set To. Turnage's career took a leap forward when he held a similar post in Birmingham with Simon Rattle.

Last week, the CBSO announced that Julian Anderson is the next composer in association. Even post-Rattle, this city continues to be a seedbed of compositional talent on which others are happy to thrive.

webTitle: A tasteful Turner. Surely some mistake

fields.headline: A tasteful Turner. Surely some mistake
fields.standfirst: It's Turner Prize time again and - whisper this quietly - this year's nominees are actually quite talented
fields.trailText: Turner Prize 2000 Exhibition Tate, Britain, London SW1 to 14 January
fields.body:
Turner Prize 2000 Exhibition Tate, Britain, London SW1 to 14 January

There are two Turner Prize shows every year: the one on the box - when the winner, by tradition, mutters a totally inarticulate speech - and the one in Tate Britain, where the four shortlisted artists display their work for several months. This show used to be token and meagre, a handful of samples in a little room on which no final judgment was based. Now it makes all the difference. When the judges walk through the four galleries devoted to the prize these days - a solo show for each artist - it may be the first time that some of them have actually laid eyes on the shortlisted art.

If that seems outrageous, bear the following in mind: the Turner Prize is open to any British or British-based artist under 50 who's had a show anywhere on the planet in the past 12 months. Faced with the impossibility of seeing even a percentage of this imponderable sum, the five judges are naturally forced back on catalogues, reproductions and tips from their art-world colleagues. It's clear that at least one of them saw Michael Raedecker's embroidered paintings in Eindhoven last autumn, since he happens to be director of the museum in which they were shown. But I strongly doubt that all five flew to Los Angeles to see Glenn Brown's startling new sculptures.

So that's just one of the anomalies, along with the closed shop of judges, the annual conflicts of interest and the general, all-welcome pretence, that make the Turner such a slippery award. The best thing to do is ignore it as a low-credibility competition and enjoy it as an exhibition.

This is not always possible. Last year was a complete slug of a show, its vitality registering only in tabloid headlines about The Bed. This year's show is tasteful, steady and, in two cases, highly accomplished. There's nothing wilfully bad, flash or obscure here: the services of the Tate's head of interpretation will not be required. Take your grandmother, take your children - the only shock is that there isn't a single video.

Tokyo-born Tomoko Takahashi literally wastes her space. Takahashi is best known for sorting several tons of discarded junk into family heaps on the floor of the Saatchi Gallery. Here, she does exactly the same thing, but without the eerie effects she achieved there with fluctuating light bulbs and flickering tellies.

Takahashi is not a magpie so much as a beaver. She prefers standard-issue flotsam to discarded glitz and she forms little nests of like-with-like in an archipelago across the gallery. The ceiling is hung with steel shelves and plastic pipes; fake foliage garnishes the filing cabinets below. The look is somewhere between B&Q and a fire-sale at a borough council. Once you've recognised the tidy categories, the inventory seems oddly pointless. So much stuff, so little to look at.

Wolfgang Tillmans, the German-born photographer, makes a bigger point with bulk. Tillmans has no style but every style, no subject except everything he sees in the world. He does casual portraits, black-and-white reportage and cibachrome panoramas saturated with sunset colours. He does them framed, unframed, magnified, cropped, minuscule and the size of a billboard. Some are taped to the wall, others suspended from clips. He's showing 57 varieties, mounted from skirting-board to ceiling, plus a whole lot more in glass cases, including spreads for a recent Big Issue .

The installation looks like a magazine layout minus the text. Sure enough, these images speak for themselves: a day at the beach, strap-hanging on the Tube, clothes drying, planes flying, two lilies, some bees and a moon rise. You might call it looking at the overlooked, except that this is exactly what we do notice daily. Tillmans just likes to bring it all together in a vista of shared normality. The only photograph of moment for me was a tightrope walker, side-lit in the style of Caravaggio. But that's an unusually beautiful shot. Generally, Tillmans rejects the outstanding for the unexceptional.

This is pure sedative compared with the YBA stress on pricks and kicks in recent years. Glenn Brown is the only shortlisted artist with any links back to that phase - he was included in Sensation. But Brown is a loner, an obsessive who paints flawless reproductions of photographs: photographs of famous paintings. You can't see a brushmark in his ultra-flat pictures, a perverse achievement that forces you to admire his cold virtuosity before all else. This technique also deletes the painterly nuances of the original. Frank Auerbach loses his crucial impasto; Fragonard's delicacy becomes frozen and stiff.

Over the years, Brown's repertoire has expanded to include Rembrandt, Dali, Baselitz - and rather more of Brown himself. He doesn't just quote, he flanges, reworks and distorts. One of his paintings in the Tate flattens the face from an Auerbach, sets it in an eighteenth-century lunette and colours it in the palette of Landseer's 'Monarch of the Glen'. Retitled 'The Marquess of Breadalbane', after the man who commissioned the Landseer, the picture becomes a multi-layered game, a portrait of a portrait, via other artists and centuries.

The creepy thing about these paintings is that you're never quite sure whether Brown likes the originals or is suffering from the anxiety of influence and wants to cancel them out. I much prefer his recent sculptures, which move into another dimension. Some look like meteorites, others like abstracted bouquets or heads. All are created out of globs of pigment, licked into shape with sensuous, liberated brushmarks. Sculptures that look like paintings, they are much less trapped and melancholy than all his paintings from photographs.

A little bit of Brown's deadpan paint seems to have gotten into Michael Raedecker's pictures. Here and there, in these evacuated landscapes, a flat patch of white doubles as both water and sky, twisting perspective and baffling the eye. Raedecker won the John Moores Prize last year for 'Mirage', his eery painting of desert which turned out to be stitched and sequinned. He plays paint against thread to create these spacey, spectral illusions.

Raedecker's scenes are dreamy in the first place - motel rooms drifting with tumbleweed, cabins snowed up in winter, forest clearings at twilight. But he deepens the disquiet, as in 'Kismet', with this fusion of materials. Mohair trees cast painted shadows; distant mountains, woven in twine, are shrouded beneath rain-grey pigment.

Raedecker uses needle and thread to draw shadows and light, veils of paint to disturb the atmosphere. In 'Echo', an oasis is barely visible behind skeins of Spanish moss, yet it also seems to hover as reflection in a pool surrounded by wave-rippled sands. It's a weird phantasm, a figment from Crusoe's dreams translated in silk on linen and the most seductive work here by some way. Raedecker and Brown have been jostling for position at the bookies for several weeks. But that was before they, we or the judges had a chance to see the Turner Prize show.

He does them framed, unframed, magnified, cropped, minuscule and the size of a billboard. Some are taped to the wall, others suspended from clips. He's showing 57 varieties, mounted from skirting-board to ceiling, plus a whole lot more in glass cases, including spreads for a recent Big Issue . The installation looks like a magazine layout minus the text. Sure enough, these images speak for themselves: a day at the beach, strap-hanging on the Tube, clothes drying, planes flying, two lilies, some bees and a moon rise. You might call it looking at the overlooked, except that this is exactly what we do notice daily. Tillmans just likes to bring it all together in a vista of shared normality. The only photograph of moment for me was a tightrope walker, side-lit in the style of Caravaggio. But that's an unusually beautiful shot. Generally, Tillmans rejects the outstanding for the unexceptional. This is pure sedative compared with the YBA stress on pricks and kicks in recent years. Glenn Brown is the only shortlisted artist with any links back to that phase - he was included in Sensation. But Brown is a loner, an obsessive who paints flawless reproductions of photographs: photographs of famous paintings. You can't see a brushmark in his ultra-flat pictures, a perverse achievement that forces you to admire his cold virtuosity before all else. This technique also deletes the painterly nuances of the original. Frank Auerbach loses his crucial impasto; Fragonard's delicacy becomes frozen and stiff. Over the years, Brown's repertoire has expanded to include Rembrandt, Dali, Baselitz - and rather more of Brown himself. He doesn't just quote, he flanges, reworks and distorts. One of his paintings in the Tate flattens the face from an Auerbach, sets it in an eighteenth-century lunette and colours it in the palette of Landseer's 'Monarch of the Glen'. Retitled 'The Marquess of Breadalbane', after the man who commissioned the Landseer, the picture becomes a multi-layered game, a portrait of a portrait, via other artists and centuries. The creepy thing about these paintings is that you're never quite sure whether Brown likes the originals or is suffering from the anxiety of influence and wants to cancel them out. I much prefer his recent sculptures, which move into another dimension. Some look like meteorites, others like abstracted bouquets or heads. All are created out of globs of pigment, licked into shape with sensuous, liberated brushmarks. Sculptures that look like paintings, they are much less trapped and melancholy than all his paintings from photographs. A little bit of Brown's deadpan paint seems to have gotten into Michael Raedecker's pictures. Here and there, in these evacuated landscapes, a flat patch of white doubles as both water and sky, twisting perspective and baffling the eye. Raedecker won the John Moores Prize last year for 'Mirage', his eery painting of desert which turned out to be stitched and sequinned. He plays paint against thread to create these spacey, spectral illusions. Raedecker's scenes are dreamy in the first place - motel rooms drifting with tumbleweed, cabins snowed up in winter, forest clearings at twilight. But he deepens the disquiet, as in 'Kismet', with this fusion of materials. Mohair trees cast painted shadows; distant mountains, woven in twine, are shrouded beneath rain-grey pigment. Raedecker uses needle and thread to draw shadows and light, veils of paint to disturb the atmosphere. In 'Echo', an oasis is barely visible behind skeins of Spanish moss, yet it also seems to hover as reflection in a pool surrounded by wave-rippled sands. It's a weird phantasm, a figment from Crusoe's dreams translated in silk on linen and the most seductive work here by some way. Raedecker and Brown have been jostling for position at the bookies for several weeks. But that was before they, we or the judges had a chance to see the Turner Prize show.

webTitle: Keep your eyes on the prize

fields.headline: Keep your eyes on the prize
fields.standfirst: The Stirling Prize is architecture's big award and may not yet have the glamorous appeal of the Turner or the Booker, but this year you can both watch and wager
fields.trailText: The Stirling Prize is architecture's big award and may not yet have the glamorous appeal of the Turner or the Booker, but this year you can both watch and wager
fields.body:
The point of the Stirling Prize is, ostensibly, to find the architect of the year. Or, as the rules put it, 'the architects of the European building which has made the greatest contribution to British architecture in the past year'. But, in fact, the prize has more to do with boosting the profile of the architectural profession as a whole, rather than creating stars in the way that the Turner Prize does. Architects - outsize egotists though they may well appear to be to the rest of us - suffer endless doubts about themselves. When they are not traumatised about being blamed for everything from the disembowelling of the inner cities in the 1960s to the problems of leaky tower blocks, they need constant reassurance that they are not being ignored by the world at large.

As they see it, as a group, they have lacked the clout of writers in a culture as literary as Britain's. And they have seen a new generation of British artists shoot past them in the public recognition stakes. So the Stirling Prize is a chance for them to squeeze into their black velvet tulip-lapelled dinner jackets, drink champagne in the lurid purple glare of the Science Museum's new Welcome wing next Saturday, and watch Waldemar Januszczak hand the winner their £25,000 cheque and bask in a bit of reflected glory. It's a chance to say 'look how much we matter'.

The trouble is, until now it has been pretty hard to make the proceedings anything but tedious. The prize is run by the Royal Institute of British Architects, and is based on a shortlist drawn from the institute's own awards scheme. It is limited to buildings designed by members, who, though they don't have to be based in Britain, can only submit projects completed in the European Union. It has turned out on occasions to be a fairly flimsy set of guidelines. Technically, Ahrends Burton and Koralec's British Embassy in Moscow stands on British soil, so it got on the long list, but was eventually rejected on grounds of aesthetics rather than geography. Herzog and de Meuron, though Swiss, would be eligible for our RIBA membership, but they did not enter Tate Modern, the building that did more for the popular appreciation of architecture in Britain than any other in the past year.

There have been plenty of rows, but nothing to catch the imagination. Nor have the tabloids found an architectural equivalent of Tracey Emin to sink their fangs into. Instead there have been predictable moans from everybody outside London about being snubbed by London-dominated judges. Part of the trouble is that much of the short list consists of major work from established names with little room for surprise discoveries, more like the summer show at the Royal Academy than the Saatchi collection.

But despite all these handicaps, this year the Stirling Prize does seem finally to be on the point of catching fire. A new sponsor has been found to put up the £25,000 prize money. The award is getting television coverage for the first time. But what really thrilled the RIBA was persuading William Hill to open a book on the result. In a perverse, blokeish kind of way architecture is only seen to be on level pegging with the cultural heavyweights, the Turner and the Booker, when it gets into the betting shops. This suggests to the sentimentalists at the RIBA that the prize is well on the way to becoming an institution, clasped to the nation's bosom. There is still time to put your shirt on Norman Foster or Caruso St John, joint favourites. But if you feel like going for an outsider, Sauerbruch Hutton's Berlin HQ for the city's housing association looks cheap for what is by any standards a beautiful building.

William Hill has not as yet been exactly deluged with eager punters. 'I'm not expecting this to rival the Grand National just yet,' says Graham Sharp, who set the odds. 'It doesn't matter what you like yourself. The secret is to work out what you think the judges will be looking for. That's why we have joint favourites. With such a London-leaning short list, you might conclude the judges would find it more acceptable to give the prize to Walsall.'

Richard Murphy, one well-regarded architect from Edinburgh who is not on the shortlist, claims that it is not where architecture is that matters but how good it is. 'It's not that the list is so London-based that bothers me. The trouble is there is a certain type of building which always seems to do well in awards. They seem to be all about funny shapes.' Murphy is sceptical about Will Alsop's library. 'I looked at the plan and it seems like the guy who delivered the shelves just dumped them on the floor. It's just a big gesture.'

Tracey Emin, the one non-architect judge (the celebrity factor), makes a different point. 'So many of the best architects have to get work abroad to survive.' She confesses to having been uncharacteristically reticent in jury deliberations. 'It was fun, but hard. I found myself keeping very quiet at first, all the others seemed to know what they were talking about and I was much more emotional. I couldn't just say that I liked a building just because I liked it. And it's tough to compare. It's easy to make an office block look sexy, but a hotel with about 1,000 fire escapes, now that really is hard to get right. I was very disappointed that there weren't any on the short list'.

Five that got away

 Tate Modern designed by Herzog and de Meuron

 The Royal Opera House designed by Dixon and Jones

 The Lowry Centre, Salford designed by Michael Wilford

 The Lighthouse, Glasgow designed by Page and Parks

 The St. Martin Hotel, London designed by Philippe Starck

www.architecture.com
