webTitle: How you can keep swinging well into your seventies

fields.headline: How you can keep swinging well into your seventies
fields.standfirst: We are living longer now so don't retire from investment planning too early, writes  Adrian Holliday
fields.trailText: We are living longer now so don't retire from investment planning too early, writes Adrian Holliday.
fields.body:
Should pensioners invest for their old age? The question is not as ludicrous as it sounds. Increasing life ex-pectancy means many people aged 65 or more could well live for another 20 to 30 years.

In investment terms, 20 years is certainly a decent period to acquire some capital growth. However, getting the balance between investment income - what many old people really need in old age - and long-term capital investment growth is quite a trick, especially in today's low interest-rate environment.

What, then, are the op-tions for the silver-haired in-vestor? Mark Bolland of In-dependent financial adviser firm Chamberlain de Broe advises looking hard at your income needs first.

'A lot of older people want to know how much income they can get from a lump sum. I always turn the question on its head and say how much do you need? Wanting an income of £2,000 a month is all very well but will fast eat up your capital. Asking for £250 a month gives you far more flexibility in terms of future growth, and won't erode your capital investment so quickly.'

Capital ero-sion, especially for 'young' pensioners, can be disastrous, particularly if inflation re-emerges to eat away your purchasing power. So resisting the temptation to tuck into too much pension in-come too early is vital.

For those wanting income with the opportunity for a little capital growth, Kim North of London IFA firm Calkin Pattinson suggests looking at corporate bonds. Issued by companies as a form of debt, they are traded in the stock market but pay set rates of return.

North says: 'I'm a big fan of these as they are a good halfway house between cash and equities. Both Perpetual's Monthly Income Plus and ABN Amro High Income are worth a look.'

But be careful. Although some corporate bond funds provide attractive levels of income, they can expose your capital to some risk, particularly if interest rates go up. This usually reduces demand, which affects prices.

Income can also fluctuate. The country's largest corpo rate bond fund, CGU Monthly Income Plus, is cutting its annual income from 7.8 to 6.3 per cent from November. The fund could no longer maintain the higher return without eating into capital.

Equity income funds, on the other hand, take a less ambitious attitude to in-come, generally providing yields of around 3 per cent. This means, crucially, that your capital is unlikely to be used up so quickly. Equity income funds are better suited to those who only need a small income top-up.

Ben Yearsley, investment manager for Hargreaves Lansdown, suggests looking at Newton Higher Income. 'This fund concentrates on buying out-of-favour stocks on high, sustainable yields and selling them once prices go up - it's a good, classic income fund. Newton staff hold a significant minority stake in the company, so they're highly incentivised to provide results.'

Tax-paying pensioners need to look for ways to earn income and growth tax-free. Using up annual allowances for Individual Savings Accounts -£7,000 for an individual in one tax year - is one method.

Another route to maximising in-come is through your £7,200 capital gains tax allowance, possibly via zero dividend preference shares - a very complicated name for a simple, low-risk product.

Zeros, as they are called, are a class of share in an investment trust that pays no income but a pre-set level of capital return. They are particularly good for low- to medium-risk investors with modest funds. You can cash in the zeros on maturity and use the profit as tax-free income.

Rosemary Heaversedge of Shropshire Independent Financial and Mortgage Services says: 'Retired people who want income should look at these, which are relatively low risk.'

Older investors should work out how much income they can manage on, how much they might need for potential long-term healthcare costs or help in the house and set aside a rainy day fund of cash. Only then are they in a position to think aboutlong-term capital growth.

Share prices have been turbulent recently, particularly those of telecoms, media and telecommunications companies. But shares have historically proved far better investment vehicles than cash or gilts, even in the long stock market downturn in the Sixties and Seventies.

Although investing in shares can be risky, you don't have to play too safe and you don't have to confine yourself to buying individual stocks. Taking a small holding in, say, technology or a Far East fund doesn't have to jeopardise your capital too greatly, and can add a little zing to your portfolio.

But if you like the idea of investing in straight companies, stick to FTSE 100 blue chips, says Stephen Bland of the Motley Fool personal finance website.

'No more than 10 to 15 holdings are needed, even for very large amounts of money. Avoid too much concentration in a particular sector. A couple of banks would be fine, but you don't want eight, even if they are attractive long-term yielders at present.'

Bland says another advantage of direct equity investing is that the money can be taken out without penalty at any time - 'not the case with many other investments to which older people are sometimes drawn'.

However, as with all stocks and shares, equities need to be watched closely. Com-panies, like any other business, go through their good and bad patches.

Points to consider:

 For a non-tax-paying wife whose husband may have a good pension, one tax-efficient manoeuvre is to take out an offshore investment in her own name. Also, consider putting the major part of bank or building society deposits in the wife's name so she can have the interest paid tax-free (ask for form IR85), making use of her personal tax allowance.

 Be careful when looking at with-profits bonds. Although they have performed well in the last 10 years, past returns of 10 per cent annual growth are unlikely to be repeated; 6-7 per cent is more likely to be the new norm. Also, with-profits bonds are commonly perceived as low-risk. They are not.

 Don't turn your nose up at annuities. Despite declining yields they could sink even lower in years to come. For anyone who lives to a ripe old age, a guaranteed income is worth having. The longer you live, the better the deal.

 Remember there is no point in living frugally to maintain capital investment value if your dependents have little need for an inheritance

 After the age of 80, circum stances often change; you are less likely to be seeking capital growth than income. Make sure your financial arrangements are flexible.

 Don't believe everything you read. 'What you must not rely on is company literature saying we have had 19 per cent growth,' says Rosemary Heaversedge. 'You can't rely on past performance tables - I never send clients these as I think they're often misleading.'

fields.headline: Bringing banking to everyone
fields.standfirst: No-frills accounts will help the excluded, writes  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: No-frills accounts will help the excluded, writes Neasa MacErlean
fields.body:
The flavour of the month is the basic bank account - no-frills accounts catering for people who keep their cash under the bed or in their pocket. The banks have been rushing to meet the Hallowe'en deadline set by the Government; Lloyds TSB and Barclays came out with their accounts last week, and HSBC is expected to squeeze in before the deadline.

The bank accounts are 'much of a muchness', says Liz Chettleburgh of MoneyFacts, a research organisation. 'The biggest difference is that some pay interest and some don't,' she says. Intelligent Finance, the Halifax telephone and internet subsidiary, pays the highest rate: 4.89 per cent on credit balances. 'Some banks are offering totally new accounts - like NatWest's Step ac-count,' she says. 'Others are giving their basic current account with fewer features - so, for instance, they limit you to a cash card which is not a cheque guarantee card.'

The Halifax is the prime example here: it has been running its basic account for 15 years and has about 2 million account-holders.

But the aim of the ac-counts is to offer a simple service where you cannot go overdrawn; can get money from cash machines, pay in your salary or benefits, set up standing orders and direct debits and not get charged. The issue to watch when withdrawing cash, however, is charges if you use another bank's cash machine.

A useful service provided by some of the banks (see table) is a cash withdrawal card that doubles as a debit card at retail outlets. As Anne Pilkington of the Woolwich explains: 'Every time you use the card in a shop the transaction is authorised online so that you cannot go overdrawn.'

The crucial difference between a no-frills account and normal current ac-counts is that applicants do not have to get through a credit-scoring exercise. This means that people with debts or no credit history or ex-offenders - who would otherwise probably be ruled out - should now qualify. A spokeswoman for the Halifax says: 'People coming out of prison would be able to meet this account - so long as they have a permanent address and can show some means of identification.'

Behind the scenes, the issue is more controversial. The Government has put considerable pressure on the banks to meet the needs of the 'socially excluded'and not just out of the kindness of its heart. It is expensive for the Department of Social Security to give out cash payments to the 16 million pensions and other benefits claimants who prefer cash in hand. A lot of money would be saved if those people had accounts instead. This is why the Government is also setting up the Universal Bank through the Post Office. Likely to get going in 2002, it will also offer very simple accounts.

The Universal Bank ac-counts might appeal to some people who are socially ex-cluded because they do not live near a mainstream bank. The banks have been rushing to meet the Hallowe'en deadline set by the Government; Lloyds TSB and Barclays came out with their accounts last week, and HSBC is expected to squeeze in before the deadline. The bank accounts are 'much of a muchness', says Liz Chettleburgh of MoneyFacts, a research organisation. 'The biggest difference is that some pay interest and some don't,' she says. Intelligent Finance, the Halifax telephone and internet subsidiary, pays the highest rate: 4.89 per cent on credit balances. 'Some banks are offering totally new accounts - like NatWest's Step ac-count,' she says. 'Others are giving their basic current account with fewer features - so, for instance, they limit you to a cash card which is not a cheque guarantee card.' The Halifax is the prime example here: it has been running its basic account for 15 years and has about 2 million account-holders. fields.headline: Everybody's got a price - name yours before it's too late
fields.standfirst: Virginia Wallis on how to work out what to pay into your pension to secure a comfortable retirement
fields.trailText: Virginia Wallis on how to work out what to pay into your pension to secure a comfortable retirement.
fields.body:
You can't put a price on happiness,of course, but, according to the NatWest pensions index, you can give a figure for what it takes to be financially content in retirement.

On average, pensioners questioned for the NatWest survey said that they found life easy with a yearly before-tax income of £10,000 - although retired members of the professional classes said they needed an average of £15,000 to feel comfortably off.

The good news for future pensioners is that, since starting the survey in 1998, NatWest has found that the proportion of people on track for financial contentment has gone up from a fifth to a quarter of current workers.

And the bad news?

Three out of four people are heading for a financially difficult retirement because they are not paying enough into their pensions.

How much is enough?

Whatever it takes to achieve your desired retirement income. If you are in an occupational pension scheme, your employers should be able to tell you whether the amount you pay is sufficient or whether you need to top it up by making additional voluntary contributions (AVCs).

I've got a personal pension.

In that case, enough means the amount it will take to build up a sufficiently large fund to buy the level of income you think you will need to live on in retirement.

Can you be more specific?

When do you want to retire?

When I'm 60 in 20 years' time.

And how much income do you think you will you need?

Without taking a drastic cut in income, not much less than my current salary of £30,000.

Are you sure about that? How much do you currently spend on your mortgage and pension?

Including mortgage protection insurance, we spend about £600 a month on the mortgage and I pay £200 into my pension. I'm not sure what my wife pays.

And will you still need income to pay for those things once you're retired?

No. The mortgage will be paid off by then and I was rather hoping that the pension would start paying me.

In that case, would you agree that you could do without £9,600 of income a year?

I suppose so - and presumably I wouldn't need the £200 a month I pay in National Insurance either.

True. So a target pension of £18,000 would be quite reasonable?

Yes, but that still doesn't tell me whether I'm paying enough into my pension.

What is your personal pension currently worth?

About £30,000.

You're not paying enough.

What makes you so sure?

If you retired at age 60 today, you would need a fund of about £215,000 to buy an annuity which would pay you a pension of £18,000.

In 20 years' time - assuming that you want your target pension to keep pace with inflation at 3 per cent a year - you'll need a fund of about £390,000 to produce the same level of retirement spending power.

That's assuming that annuity rates remain the same, which is unlikely given that they have been falling in recent years.

Have you taken growth in my current fund and monthly contributions of £200 into account?

Yes, and basic-rate tax relief too. And even taking a supremely optimistic view - which is to assume that your fund will grow by 9 per cent a year - your fund would still be worth about £50,000 less than it needs to be. If the fund grew at 5 per cent a year, you would have less than half the amount you will need to buy a pension of £32,500.

Where did that figure come from?

It's £18,000 inflated at 3 per cent a year. If you want to check it, punch 18,000 into your calculator and keep multiplying by 1.03 until you've done it 20 times. Alternatively, multiply 18,000 by 1.03 to the power 20.

I see. So how much extra will I have to contribute to be sure that inflation doesn't erode the value of my pension before I've even started spending it?

If you want a precise figure which takes charges into account, ask your pension company. But make sure you ask them for an illustration for the 20-years hence pension figure rather than your target income in today's money.

Don't they do that automatically?

No. Only figures for 'protected-rights' pensions, which are those funded by contracting out of Serps (the state earnings-related pension) have to be given in real terms.

What if I can't afford to pay any extra?

You can forget early retirement.

webTitle: Record oil profits set to fuel anger

fields.headline: Record oil profits set to fuel anger
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the petrol war
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The oil giants are set to announce record third-quarter profits as the spiralling price of crude and huge refining margins combine to produce results 100 per cent up on last year.
fields.body:
The oil giants are set to announce record third-quarter profits as the spiralling price of crude and huge refining margins combine to produce results 100 per cent up on last year.

Analysts are predicting that the third-quarter profits to be announced over the coming weeks from UK and European oil majors will represent a 10-year high.

Shell kicks off the reporting season on Thursday, with analysts predicting increases of between 70 and 90 per cent on last year's numbers. BP's figures are expected to be even higher.

The timing of the results could not be more sensitive for UK oil companies. BP's come on 7 November, the day before Chancellor Gordon Brown is due to announce his pre-Budget report, and six days before the deadline for a fresh round of refinery blockades by demonstrators protesting at fuel duty levels.

The Government was angered by the role of the oil industry during the fuel crisis and has sought to deflect blame for the unrest on to the high price of oil, which, it argues, is the cause of the majority of the increase in prices at the pump, rather than high fuel duty.

There has been speculation that Brown may alter the North Sea tax regime. But Ministers are concerned that this may undermine investment in the North Sea; they recently said publicly that Brown is unlikely to do this in his pre-Budget statement.

However industry analysts and motoring groups argue that Brown could link Petroleum Revenue Tax to the crude oil price without frightening off investment.

Commerzbank oil analysts Steven Turner and Clay Smith stated in a research note last week: 'It is difficult to imagine a more favourable environment than that which existed in the third quarter, 2000. Oil prices hit their highest average level since the Gulf war while refining margins have more than doubled in all major refining countries compared with the third quarter 1999.'

The average price of Brent Crude in the third quarter of 2000 was $31.3 a barrel, compared with $20.9 a year ago.

Commerzbank calculates Shell's net income at $3.17 billion, up 75 per cent on a year ago, although Lehman Brothers has the figure higher, at $3.4bn, up 88 per cent.

BP is expected to declare net income of $3.47bn, up 77 per cent on the previous year. Both sets of figures have been driven by the crude price.

Commerzbank's Clay Smith told The Observer: 'This certainly represents a 10-year high - and may be an all-time high - but I have only been covering the sector for 10 years. It is worth noting that the US majors have been reporting, and their figures have come in 5-25 per cent higher than analysts' forecasts, so the UK figures could be higher still.'

Another reason for Brown's reticence is the threat by oil companies to scale down North Sea investment plans - slated for a 33 per cent increase to £4bn next year.

Oil companies argue that their returns are minimal during cyclical troughs in the crude price - determined in part by the Opec cartel - and that they are facing problems downstream at the petrol pump, where high prices work against their margins.

webTitle: Small businesses: Do you dare dive out of 9 to 5?

fields.headline: Do you dare dive out of 9 to 5?
fields.standfirst: Sandra Deeble investigates the gain and pain of being your own boss
fields.trailText: Sandra Deeble investigates the gain and pain of being your own boss.
fields.body:
The other day I was in a restaurant, eavesdropping on a couple having a leisurely, mid-week lunch. The woman's mobile phone rang. Her spoon was halfway to her mouth as she said: 'Yes, you can make tea and coffee in your room. Yes, they're all en-suite. Fifty pounds deposit usually, a cheque's fine'. After the call she said to her husband: 'I forgot to tell you, the hand basin in the pink room is blocked again'.

Running your own business - whether it's a hotel or anything else - may give you flexibility, but mention the word 'freedom' to many owners of these enterprises and they're likely to respond with a hollow laugh. Yet surely it must feel great, calling the shots? You can put your mark on something, make decisions, choose who you work with, and take a break without needing to get your holiday form signed by the powers that be.

When you are employed by someone else and your concentration lapses during the Monday morning meeting, you may find yourself dreaming again of that restaurant you'd really like to open, possibly in Devon, or maybe even in Cornwall? One day you'll do it. It would be a dream come true!

Yet there are dreamers and doers. Galvanising yourself to hand in your notice, to give up a job that pays the bills and comes with four weeks' paid holiday is not for the fainthearted.

Nevertheless, according to a recent NatWest survey, 440,000 new businesses were set up in 1999, the highest number for 10 years. Does that mean that the entrepreneurial spirit is on the up? Indeed, if the stereotypical Open All Hours culture of a small business owner may have previously put off the steady nine to fivers, in a world where working hours have been stretched beyond all recognition and with organisations in constant flux, perhaps more of the employed brigade are wondering whether they should give it a whirl?

'It may be sensible to make sure you're in control of your destiny, rather than being in the hands of a multinational,' says David Boyle of the New Economics Foundation, a think-tank.

Some people try their luck, but then have second thoughts, according to Andrew McDougall of Barclays Small Business Banking. 'People start out in a business venture, but then they might get a better offer of employment,' he says.

Which may console the many people who are still toying with the idea of being mavericks, yet remain fearful about the financial precariousness associated with running a business: wages to pay and the ever-present threat of mounting debts and bankruptcy.

'People have fear, and one of the things we put our fear on is money,' says Nick Williams, a former Eighties yuppie who gave up a highly paid job in computers to advise people how to find their ideal employment. 'Yet fear and money are different.'

Williams, author of The Work You Were Born To Do , published by Element Books at £9.99, says our belief in the work ethic can shackle us further if we run our own businesses: 'One of our beliefs is that we can only earn money through hard work, effort and struggle so we may make ourselves work harder when we are self-employed. You can end up being your own worst boss.'

Yet self-employment is something that more and more of us are turning to as freelance and portfolio working becomes a more flexible and profitable option. Does that mean that anyone with a laptop can claim to run a small business?

'For me, a business is something that has an intention to grow,' says Andrew James, publisher of Better Business magazine. 'Any business that is going to grow probably doubles in size by the end of the first year. And the only way that you can grow a business is by delegating.'

James says it's important to recognise the difference between a business and a job: 'There are a number of people who start a business. There are many more who buy a job for themselves: they don't really see themselves as running a business.'

So what makes people grasp the nettle? For some it's redundancy. For others it's a mid-life crisis - the 'there must be more to life' syndrome suffered after being in a job where one's creativity is stymied - can fuel a now-or-never attitude.

Other people have a spirit shot through with an entrepreneurial, inventive streak. They have an idea and they want to make it work. Think Diane Keaton in Baby Boom.

Whatever the initial motivation, you'll need energy, determination, a Zen-like philosophical outlook and passion. And wave farewell to holidays, at least for the first few years.

Where to get help

Better Business publishes newsletters and runs a website with useful links, help and advice for self-employed people and small business owners.

Nick Williams at the Heart at Work project runs courses that examine our relationship with money. The next workshop - on abundance - is at the Commonwealth Institute, London, on 25 November: tel 07000 781 922.

Business Link has regional offices and offers advice and runs courses for people wanting to start businesses.

Enterprise Ireland.

Barclays Small Business Banking.

The New Economics Foundation.

fields.headline: Accounting for very little
fields.standfirst: The conventional ways of the bean counters are bankrupt, writes  Simon Caulkin
fields.trailText: The conventional ways of the bean counters are bankrupt, writes Simon Caulkin
fields.body:
Why are the stock market valuations of dotcoms so volatile? Why do so many acquisitions fail to live up to financial expectations? Why do managers notoriously spend more time debating the paint-job on the bike shed than the training of their employees?

The answer to these questions lies in part in one of the most surprising and, outside the business world, least noticed management failures of the past 20 years - the implosion of traditional accounting. Backward-looking and rooted in the needs of statutory financial reporting, conventional accounting has long been of little help to managers in carrying out their day-to-day work. In the past few years the concerns of the two have diverged so far that it has become as misleading as a back-to-front signpost.

'An entire industry - accountancy - is based on a fiction: that the valuations auditors produce reflect the real value of the companies they audit,' charges a new report, Dynamic Reporting for a Dynamic Economy, produced for the Academy of Enterprise. 'They simply do not.' Academy founder Professor Alec Reed, chairman of Reed plc and an accountant by training, adds: 'Traditional accountancy should be swept away. We desperately need a new model.'

Reed complains that present-day accounting tells shareholders, investors and managers nothing useful about corporate value. It used to be that a company's market value was roughly equivalent to the sum of the physical assets - the land, plant and capital - that industrial companies primarily used to create profits and cashflows. In the new economy, however, even old-line industrial companies rely less and less on physical assets to create value. Value is in fact overwhelmingly generated by the so-called 'intangible assets' which lie at the heart of today's competitive advantage: brands, knowhow, intellectual property, R&D and, above all, people.

The result is a yawning gap between corporate stock market valuations - what investors say companies are worth - and the book value accountants attend to. Take Microsoft. Just 10 per cent of its $300bn market capitalisation is backed by physical assets recorded on the balance sheet. Its real value-creating engine, its software development skills, do not appear on the balance sheet at all - which, as Bill Gates has pointed out, 'is probably not very enlightening from an accounting point of view'.

In a fast-changing world, cashflows themselves are losing their predictive, and therefore some of their financial, value. In the case of established companies they can vanish overnight; at Amazon.com and other internet high-flyers, valuations are not based on cashflows, and still less on today's meaningless balance-sheet figures, but on the as-yet-unknown options that their ideas, people and customer relations give them. As Reed says: in today's conditions, balance sheets are irrelevant, profit-and-loss statements are misleading, and business plans are not worth the paper they are written on.

Behind the Academy's intangibles report is the belief that in future firms may have to reinvent themselves for mobilising and developing people rather than capital. As the report points out, accounting's inability to keep up with this fundamental shift creates all kinds of problems for investors and lenders, favouring insider trading, making 'weightless' companies hard to value, and encouraging market volatility.

Just as serious are the side-effects within the firm. It's a management truism that what gets measured gets managed. And all too often 'the fiction of accounting' concentrates managers' attention on the wrong things.

For a start, the failure to value people (in both accounting and managerial senses) makes potential acquisitions hard to value and may be a factor in the mispricing and subsequent mismanaging of many large-scale takeovers.

webTitle: Nuclear sub was hours from meltdown

fields.headline: Nuclear sub was hours from meltdown
fields.standfirst: HMS Tireless:  How a 'minor defect' could have caused disaster
fields.trailText: Only now, more than five months after the Ministry of Defence assured Gibraltarians that it was only a "minor defect", are the full extent and dramatic consequences coming to light. HMS Tireless, which has been moored off the Rock since May, was close to a disaster, its nuclear reactor "at the very point of failure", sources have told the Guardian.
fields.body:
Only now, more than five months after the Ministry of Defence assured Gibraltarians that it was only a "minor defect", are the full extent and dramatic consequences coming to light. HMS Tireless, which has been moored off the Rock since May, was close to a disaster, its nuclear reactor "at the very point of failure", sources have told the Guardian.

The crack, far more serious than first thought, is understood to be at a critical junction of pipes in the pressurised water reactor's cooling system which cannot be isolated. The navy now recognises it is not simply a question of wear and tear: it is a potentially catastrophic design fault. Asked whether it could have foreseen what it is now suspected is a "generic" problem, navy sources sidestep the question. They respond by repeating the mantra that safety is of "first importance".

There is no doubt the navy treats the safety issue extremely seriously. What worries defence and nuclear sources is not what action was taken after the leak on the Tireless was eventually diagnosed - the recall of Britain's entire fleet of strike submarines - but why the initial leak, a symptom of what has turned out to be a much more devastating problem, was not discovered earlier.

"The cracks could not be in a worse position. It is critical to safety," the Guardian has been told. Sources say the Tireless reactor was "at the very point of failure" - in other words a meltdown.

The critical junction of pipes where the welding fault was finally discovered had not been inspected since the first Swiftsure class submarines with this reactor design were built in the early 1970s, sources have revealed. They added: "It is a very serious failure of the navy's inspection monitoring system. It's quite remarkable".

The problem is compounded because the Ministry of Defence, not the manufacturers, Rolls-Royce, is the submarines' "design authority". That is to say, the MoD monitors the submarines; the makers are not liable for any faults.

Naval engineers are said to have been astonished to discover the problem on the Tireless turned out to be so serious. Equally alarmingly, navy sources say the splits in the pipes of the reactor's cooling system were discovered only because of new technology of which they had no previous experience.

Yet the navy is not short of experience of problems with its submarines' nuclear reactors. Polaris nuclear missile submarines were afflicted by reactor problems which turned out to be the same that crippled the navy's older fleet of hunter-killer submarines: cracked pipework in the primary cooling system.

As far back as 1991, Reg Farmer, a member of the MoD's nuclear-powered warships safety committee, revealed that cracks had been found at the base of steam generators in the nuclear reactors. He spoke to Thames Television after the MoD had persistently refused to answer questions from MPs on the grounds that they covered "sensitive military areas".

This week, the MoD said it could not disclose what is wrong with the Tireless reactor "without consulting the Americans first" - the reactor is based on an American design. In July, John Spellar, armed forces minister, told MPs: "The repair work on HMS Tireless is a standard repair following a contained leak of coolant water in her reactor compartment." The work, he added, would be completed "in the autumn."

Given the sensitivity of Gibraltarian opinion, it is likely that repairs on Tireless will not begin until work is completed on one of its sister boats in Britain. Gibraltarians face the prospect of an immobile Tireless sitting off the Rock for a year.

"The mood in Spain, in the towns near Gibraltar, is that it should be towed back to Britain," Michael Castiel, the lawyer representing opposition groups in Gibraltar, said yesterday.

For the MoD that may be a little local problem compared with the navy being deprived of its entire submarine strike force for at least five months. It would be crass not to admit the "pain and grief" involved, a navy source said.

The recall coincides with the sale of Britain's remaining conventionally powered submarines to Canada, a decision taken by the Tory government.

fields.headline: Start afresh with Lottery
fields.trailText: Malcom Dean underlines the case which we have made to government. The UK is now famous throughout Europe as a nation of loutish and violent drunks.
fields.body:
Malcom Dean (The culture that cultivates crime, October 25) underlines the case which we have made to government. The UK is now famous throughout Europe as a nation of loutish and violent drunks. We see this trend coming from a youth culture which is not really a culture but a void. The propagation of real culture, via the arts and sport, seems the swiftest and easiest way of getting the youth of the country back on track and protecting the general populace from unnecessary violence.

We set up the National Lottery to improve quality of life for all, but it has done no such thing. So the Department of Culture, Media and Sport should reshape the lottery from top to bottom, quickly. First endow coaching in arts and sports for everyone from the age of seven upwards, using up the idle £3.3bn lottery reserve funds. That creates a permanent charitable provision for the young, not subject to political whims.

Then invite the commissioners to reject both current bidders for the new franchise, as their interests are too complex to allow a simple choice between them. Camelot has presided over three years of falling sales, which are now £1.4bn a year less than the Italian lottery, and £2.4bn below New York's sales, on a per capita basis.

If Camelot is able to increase the money to good causes, why can't it do that now? And should the DCMS charge Sir Richard Branson up to £1bn a year for the free prime-time advertising which his participation in the lottery would give his 200 companies? Although he has removed all trace of the Virgin name from his bid, it stays in the public mind.

The solution is an unencumbered not-for-profit operator. If he is intent on improving the quality of life with arts and sports participation for all, the lottery can become everyone's favourite charity.

Denis Vaughan
Executive director, Lottery Promotion Company

fields.headline: World of  wonders
fields.standfirst: Middle-aged guy who fails  to live up to his early promise, a new partner and a surprise pregnancy.The perfect role for Michael Douglas? Joe Queenan thinks not
fields.trailText: Middle-aged guy who fails to live up to his early promise, a new partner and a surprise pregnancy.The perfect role for Michael Douglas? Joe Queenan thinks not
fields.body:
Two years ago, director Curtis Hanson delighted audiences and critics with his devout adaptation of James Ellroy's LA Confidential, a classic example of book noir. It was a rare example of a very good novel being turned into a very fine movie, a transubstantiation that did not come to pass with The Talented Mr Ripley, The End Of The Affair, Les Miserables, The Great Gatsby or any number of War And Peace adaptations.

One thing that gave LA Confidential a certain cachet was its mesmerising sense of place, its faithful portrayal of Los Angeles, circa 1950, as a balmy Inferno where the Borgias and the Medicis would not have felt out of place: Purgatory del Rey, if you will. It was as if LA was a character in the movie, the way London is a character in those old Sherlock Holmes films.

Now Hanson is back with another book adaptation set in a troubled municipality. In Wonder Boys, the backdrop is studiously unglamorous Pittsburgh, a city that was once the capital of the US steel industry, which has somehow managed to avoid becoming an out-and-out hellhole like Gary, Indiana, or Camden, New Jersey, but has not actually succeeded in becoming anything other than Pittsburgh, former capital of the US steel industry. In this dowdy town abides a middle-aged, dope-smoking, skirt-chasing creative writing professor played with commendable industry by Michael Douglas.

Michael Douglas has a history of making good movies in which he is the least talented of the major players - The China Syndrome, Wall Street, The War Of The Roses, The Star Chamber, The Game - and Wonder Boys is no exception. Tobey Maguire, Frances McDormand, Rip Torn and Robert Downey Jr are all far better actors than Michael Douglas and discreetly outperform him here. But without Michael Douglas, movies like Wonder Boys don't get made. Or, if they do get made, they star somebody perfectly awful, like Kurt Russell. So we should all be thankful for small mercies.

The term "Wonder Boys" refers to fabulously talented young male writers who may fail to live up to their youthful potential because life, drugs, alcohol, women or a combination of all four get in the way. Douglas was once a Wonder Boy: Seven years earlier he wrote a magnificent first novel entitled The Arsonist's Daughter and seemed destined for greatness.

But now he is bogged down in a 2,612-page epic that does not appear to be about anything in particular, and it is not anywhere close to completion. He is no longer a Wonder Boy. He is now looking more like a precocious has-been.

Worse still, his wife has just left him; his mistress (McDormand) - who happens to be his boss's wife - is pregnant; and his struggling New York editor (Downey) is coming to town to read the novel he has not finished writing, hoping to get his own career back on track.

Into Douglas's life steps Tobey Maguire, a Wonder Boy whose life is even more of a mess than his: a young, depressed, sexually repressed, anti-social novelist who lives in the local bus station because no one else will have him. Least of all his parents. Douglas, who smokes more dope in Wonder Boys than Jeff Bridges smoked in The Big Lebowski, reluctantly takes the prodigy under his wing.

The results of their 48-hour liaison are comical but disastrous, leaving the chairman of the English department's blind dog dead and Douglas badly bitten in the calf area. Worse still, Maguire has made off with a prized trophy that the department head keeps stored in a bedroom safe that Douglas has foolishly opened: the tiny, fur-lined jacket that Marilyn Monroe wore the day she married baseball legend Joe DiMaggio.

Bear in mind that the man's wife is already pregnant with Douglas's child. All in all, not a very good weekend. Stripped to its fundamentals, Wonder Boys is a coming-of-middle-age tale in which a talented writer finally realises that God-given talent can also be taken away, sometimes by God. As such, it has a certain wry appeal.

Unlike most films about fabulously gifted novelists who have wasted their abilities - not that there are that many films in this genre - Wonder Boys is not hobbled by angst, ennui, anomie or any of the other novelistic emotions imported from the Continent. Moreover, it is not stupid, a virtually unparallelled achievement in American films about writers.

All the same, Wonder Boys ultimately falls short of the mark. The fault, alas, lies in the casting. While Robert Downey Jr is perfect as the jaded, sexually perplexed, morally depleted book editor who has flown in for the weekend; and Frances McDormand exudes the kind of weary sexuality that is typical of academics' wives; and Rip Torn does yeoman service as the blustery hack who fancies himself the second coming of Emile Zola, and Tobey Maguire is positively adorable as the confused wunderkind, Michael Douglas simple cannot carry the load as the burned-out novelist.

The reason he cannot carry the load is that Michael Douglas is too LA. No matter how old and jowly he gets, Douglas retains that buoyant Southern California demeanour and those Malibu Beach speech patterns. Proving, once again, that you can take the boy out of the surf, but you can't take the surf out of the boy.

In an effort to make him seem more downscale and pathetic and more believable as a Pittsburghian, Hanson dresses him like a bum, gives him standard-issue props like reading glasses and ratty bathrobes and has him fall down a lot, but it's no go. Douglas is superb when he plays ruthless cops, predatory industrialists, unfaithful husbands, jaded lawyers.

But cast as the author of a great American novel, Douglas is about as convincing as he was when he played a vaunted lion hunter in The Ghost And The Darkness. One has to admire his courage. But one has to question his judgment.

Wonder Boys is out on Friday

While Robert Downey Jr is perfect as the jaded, sexually perplexed, morally depleted book editor who has flown in for the weekend; and Frances McDormand exudes the kind of weary sexuality that is typical of academics' wives; and Rip Torn does yeoman service as the blustery hack who fancies himself the second coming of Emile Zola, and Tobey Maguire is positively adorable as the confused wunderkind, Michael Douglas simple cannot carry the load as the burned-out novelist. The reason he cannot carry the load is that Michael Douglas is too LA. No matter how old and jowly he gets, Douglas retains that buoyant Southern California demeanour and those Malibu Beach speech patterns. Proving, once again, that you can take the boy out of the surf, but you can't take the surf out of the boy. Douglas is superb when he plays ruthless cops, predatory industrialists, unfaithful husbands, jaded lawyers. But cast as the author of a great American novel, Douglas is about as convincing as he was when he played a vaunted lion hunter in The Ghost And The Darkness. One has to admire his courage. But one has to question his judgment. Wonder Boys is out on Friday

fields.headline: Losing with dignity
fields.standfirst: Having made a memorable impression in American Pie (in more ways than one), Jason Biggs is learning about the pitfalls of movie life, and snowboarding
fields.trailText: Having made a memorable impression in American Pie (in more ways than one), Jason Biggs is learning about the pitfalls of movie life, and snowboarding
fields.body:
Jason Biggs became a youth icon last year by demonstrating the proper manner of making love to pastry in the comedy hit American Pie. An odd path to international stardom, maybe, but capitalising on his fame has not, so far, been easy. Biggs had the only good role in fizzless romantic comedy Boys and Girls (due for release in December), but even more vexing is Loser, written and directed by Clueless's Amy Heckerling and co-starring Pie-mate Mena Suvari. Loser stars Biggs as a nerdy university freshman who can't get anything in his life to work right. Unfortunately, little in the film did, either, Biggs' performance being a notable exception.

Most women seem to think you're just the cuddliest thing. How come you're so often cast as a guy who can't get a date?

I like to think that I have a sympathetic quality that the audience can root for, even while I'm playing an outcast. In order for American Pie to have worked, you had to have a character that, even while he is humping a pie, the audience still liked him; and in order for Loser to work, you have to have a guy who, even while he is the biggest outcast, is still likable.

More speciÞcs on Mena, please. This is the second film you've made together.

Mena is great and completely unchanged by all the success of American Beauty and everything, which was hitting right when we started shooting this. She was very humble about it, and we had such a great time, always kidding around and laughing. There were a lot of inside jokes. I believe that our chemistry on screen is great, and I think that's because our chemistry off screen is great.

For whatever reason, though, Loser did pretty lousy when it was released in the US last summer. Did that bother you?

It would be foolish of me to take full responsibility for the movie, but at the same time, I'm very proud of it. So however the movie did, and whether or not it will impact on me or not, who knows? The only thing that I can control in the end is my performance. That's the only pressure that I feel, not so much for the film to succeed, because I am my own worst critic.

You seem to be working non-stop. Are you compulsive that way, or have you had time off we don't know about?

No, I stopped, but... American Pie came out, and so I travelled around the globe to do publicity for it, and then I came back and I started work on Boys And Girls and Loser, which I did at the same time. I finished that at the end of last January and I had a break. So then it was like, "Alright, it's Jason time! I'm going to go snowboarding, and have fun!" Then on my Þrst trip snowboarding, I dislocated my shoulder really badly. So Jason time turned into recovery time; I spent three months in physical therapy and a month in a sling. Then I started my next two projects, Saving Silverman and Prozac Nation.

Let's go out on a cheery seasonal note, then. What was the best Halloween costume you've ever worn?

There were two. One was when I was a prostitute in the sixth grade. My mom helped me out with that one. She cut some tennis balls in half and got this crazy wig and, like, put on the lipstick and short skirt. I shouldn't say prostitute, that's kind of heavy, I was a girl; but if you saw me, you would think that I belonged in a brothel. And I was a baby in the fifth grade, the year before that. I had a big diaper with a big pin, and a big paciÞer.

Man, sounds like you really were a loser.

No, that was cool! It was fun because I didn't have to leave for bathroom breaks.

fields.headline: Living legends
fields.standfirst: The ancient oaks of Wistman's Wood are an enduring mystery of Dartmoor, says  Roly Smith
fields.trailText: The ancient oaks of Wistman's Wood are an enduring mystery of Dartmoor, says Roly Smith.
fields.body:
The fairytale, lichen-encrusted oaks of Wistman's Wood are a bit of a mystery. Ecologists are still puzzled over why its wizened and gnarled trees, some of which are over 300 years old, are all of the lowland, pedunculate variety, whereas all those in the well-wooded valleys on the edge of the moor are the more hardy sessile oaks, usually found in the uplands of Britain.

Another mystery is that this incredibly ancient-looking wood, which feels as though it has been there since the beginning of time, is on the move. Not only are its trees twice the height they used to be 80 years ago, but the wood itself has doubled in size over the past 60 years, and is slowly but surely creeping up the slopes of neighbouring Longaford Tor.

This part of the mystery, however, is easier to solve. As the plentiful new acorns germinate, they are sheltered by the older trees from the prevailing westerly winds which are therefore responsible for gradually pushing the wood uphill. So despite its venerable and unchanging appearance, Wistman's Wood is what the ecologists call a "dynamic ecosystem". This arboreal enigma lies hidden away in the desolate valley of the West Dart river in the moorland heart of Dartmoor, near the National Park's epicentre at Two Bridges. For many it represents the essence of Dartmoor.

While it is usually heralded by guidebooks as "the last great wilderness of southern Britain", Dartmoor's spirit is not necessarily to be found on the open, tor-topped moors, described by their most famous chronicler, Arthur Conan Doyle, as "so vast, and so barren, and so mysterious".

Wistman's is thought to take its name from the old West Country word "wisht" which means sad or uncanny, so "Wistman" may mean "Wisht-man", and the wood may be named after a local, other-worldly spirit. Certainly, early Dartmoor antiquarians were keen to link this ancient oakwood with the activities of Celtic Druids, who were known to favour oak groves for their pagan ceremonies.

But perhaps the most remarkable feature of Wistman's Wood, apart from its exposed position at 400m (1,300ft) above the sea, is its luxurious mantle of mosses, ferns, liverworts and lichens. They drip from the branches of the weirdly-contorted branches like the epiphytes and bromeliads of an Amazonian rain forest, and in fact represent a habitat which is every bit as rare and threatened.

The loss of the rare and beautiful moss antitrichia curtipendula, which formerly hung in liana-like fronds from the branches of many of the trees in Victorian times, is blamed on the increase in airborne pollution, and the gradual opening-up of the wood has in turn caused a loss of humidity which has affected the moisture-loving ferns and liverworts.

Wistman's Wood is now a National Nature Reserve managed by English Nature under agreement with the Duchy of Cornwall, and access is strictly by written permission only. However, a public footpath runs conveniently past the wood, and you can peep into it along this easy, three-mile stroll from Two Bridges.

Start from the quarry car park on the side of the B3357, opposite the Two Bridges Hotel. The way leads clearly north along a track towards Crockern farmhouse, where a stile takes you out into open country and the first sighting of Wistman's Wood, low-lying like a hedge on the slopes of the valley ahead.

The prominent rocks on the hillside to your left are Beardown Tors, parts of which make up the Merrivale Firing Range, still in use by the Army despite the fact it is now situated in a National Park supposedly set aside for the quiet enjoyment of the public. When a red flag is seen flying from the tors, firing is taking place and walking is forbidden on these hills.

The winding artificial waterway that can just be seen contouring beneath the tors is the Devonport Leat, cut between 1793-96 to take water from the West Dart river, whose natural course flows down in the valley below, to the Burrator Reservoir and thence to the then fast-growing dockyard town of Devonport.

As you step out across the rock-strewn moorland heading due north towards the approaching wind-stunted "hedge" of Wistman's Wood, you may notice some broken down walls and mounds emerging from the moorland grass. The map of Dartmoor is scattered with the words "settlement" and "hut circle" in that Gothic lettering the Ordnance Survey reserves for ancient monuments. These humps are all that remains of medieval and earlier villages and farms that once made Dartmoor one of the most populous places in the south west.

Indeed, it is said to contain, "fossilised" under the moor grass, the most important and complete prehistoric landscape in north-west Europe.

Walk around the top edge of the wood, looking inside at what one author has described as "the ultimate in arboreal deformity" and "a phantasmagoria of greenleaf and granite". Wistman's Wood covers about four hectares (8.5 acres), and its amazing survival is thought to be due to the fact that the trees have grown in the shelter of the rocky crevices of the "clitter" (the Dartmoor name for loose rocks). These create a favourable micro- climate, protecting the trees from gales and frost and, above all, from being nibbled by local sheep.

When you reach the northern end of the wood, turn right and head steeply uphill to reach the rocky summit of Longaford Tor, from where a splendid view opens up to the north towards the 1,978ft (603m) Cut Hill, perhaps the most remote of the Dartmoor summits. The nearer tor is Higher White Tor, and between that and Longaford Tor are the remains of one of Dartmoor's enigmatic prehistoric stone rows.

Take the ridge due south, crossing the strange, masonry-like blocks of Littaford Tors and down through gaps in the walls towards Crockern Tor.

It is now a short step due west and downhill, passing some more pillow mounds, to reach Crockern again and your outward route back to Two Bridges.

The practicals

Wistman's Wood is near Two Bridges in the centre of Dartmoor, off the B3357 Dartmeet-Tavistock road. The walk is approximately three miles in length and should take about 2 hours. It is over rough moorland, so appropriate footwear should be worn. Indispensable for any exploration of Dartmoor is the Ordnance Survey's 1:25,000 Outdoor Leisure Map No. 28, covering the National Park. The Two Bridges Hotel (tel: 01822 890581) has a beautiful riverside setting near the junction of the West Dart river with the Cowsic, and is very popular with walkers. The nearest National Park Information Centre is the splendid High Moorland Centre occupying the former Old Duchy Hotel in the centre of Princetown (tel: 01822 890414).

webTitle: Jonathan Freedland on sleeping while you travel

fields.headline: Shut-eye from New York
fields.trailText: Can the red-eye be abolished forever? Can a night-flight be transformed from a punishing experiment in sleep deprivation into a travellers' treat, on a par with the old luxury night-trains of old?
fields.body:
Can the red-eye be abolished forever? Can a night-flight be transformed from a punishing experiment in sleep deprivation into a travellers' treat, on a par with the old luxury night-trains of old?

British Airways certainly hopes so. That's why it's equipped its club-class quarters with a perk that used to be confined to first: a flat-bed seat. Think of it as the latest offensive in the great furniture war of the air - a bed in the sky for every business-class passenger between London and New York.

Personally, I couldn't resist. I've done that overnight run often, always in economy, emerging the next morning with aching limbs, matted hair, clingy trousers and a desperate need for slumber. Wouldn't it be great to dodge the entire experience by bedding down for the night at JFK and arriving in London fresh and ready for the new day?

BA's new service is obsessed with achieving that outcome. Sleep is the goal, pursued relentlessly. There's pre-board dining in the newly-built Terraces lounge in JFK: that way you can eat first, wasting no valuable sleep time onboard. If you're one of those travellers who skids into the airport with seconds to spare - and no time for the lounge - then the on-board menu includes a sleep-well option (olive bread stuffed with beef and ricotta cheese, followed by hot chocolate and cookies). It's not so much food as a soporific.

But the heart of the matter is the seat. It looks less like a chair than a pod. There are two seats in each unit, forming an S-shape - with a handy, fan-like screen to ensure no peeking between you and your neighbour (unless you want to). A TV screen swings out on a steel arm; there's a tiny little stand for cocktails as well as the regular tray table stowed in the seat arm. Also stashed away is a TV remote control, which doubles as a telephone, and a clutch of light-switches and gadgets. Once you've checked out all that lot - and the instruction manual is essential - you'll feel like Blofeld in a Bond movie. It's not a chair, it's a console.

If you find cramped legroom the true curse of economy travel, your heart will leap when you see the footstool folded away in front of you. Unlock it and a neat pumping action raises or lowers it to just the right height. Press the recline button and you'll think yourself blessed: comfy chair, feet up - the perfect conditions for watching a movie or reading a book.

But that's not the point. You must keep pressing the button and keep pressing some more. For the chair bends further and further back (forcing you to move your bottom, lest your backside gets trapped in the chair like a foot in an escalator). The electric movement takes the seat back to a full horizontal, until its front edge meets the footstool. Ta-da: it's a bed!

The frequent fliers are unfazed by all this, of course; these blasé habitues of business class know exactly what to do. They put away their Wall Street Journal before take-off, heading instead to the (larger than usual) bathroom where they swiftly change into sweatpants and cosy top (BA only provides the "sleepsuit" to first class). They don't eat on the plane, waving aside the offer of a menu, and they certainly don't drink. They don't bother unwrapping the headset or checking out the film guide.

Instead, they curl up under the blanket, buckle their belt over the top (so the steward can see it, and won't wake them during turbulence), and drop off in an instant. It seems high-powered folk are focused about everything they do - even sleep.

Within minutes, the cabin has the feel of a boarding-school dorm. The lights are dimmed, there are no announcements and all is quiet. And people are really asleep! Mouths are open, arms are dangling. No one snored on my flight but the business elite were definitely in the land of $500,000-a-year nod. (One cannot escape the suspicion that a few of them were getting a bit of chemical help: among the jetset, sleeping pills are the new coffee.)

I, alas, was not among them. My chair was comfortable, and it was long enough even for me (at 6 ft 1). But somehow I was denied full unconsciousness. Normally I would blame that on the plane and the tiny seat. Now I know the truth: the seat is perfect - it's me who has to change.

 A BA fully-flexible return ticket to New York costs £3,743. A Premium Leisure Saver in Business Class costs £3,375. Details: 0845 7733377.

fields.headline: Waltz time
fields.standfirst: The approach of Christmas and the new opera season breathe new life in to the Austrian capital, says  David Clement Davies
fields.trailText: The approach of Christmas and the new opera season breathe new life in to the Austrian capital, says David Clement Davies.
fields.body:
Vienna is the grand capital of music. Hadyn, Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert all thrived in its bubbling coffee-house culture and came to pay court to the Habsburgs and to each other. Today along the Kartnerstrasse, Vienna's central shopping street, busy Viennese still hover patiently as buskers tune up. Even the mobile phones chime.

Now is a good time to ride Vienna's trams around the Ringstrasse, looping the old city. The opera season is starting and, with Christmas approaching, Vienna lights up like a sparkler.

But the home of so much pleasure is also the city of Freud and that artistic reject Hitler; a place that can still cast truly grotesque shadows. For an outsider Vienna can be over-rich to say the least and, on a weekend break, penetrating its charmed musical circle is as intimidating as the overmighty Hofburg palace. Fear not though, Vienna is actually remarkably easy to get around.

Tuning up

Buy a Vienna Card (£9 for three days - from underground stations and tobacconists) for unlimited use of trams, subway and discounts to most museums. For anyone vaguely nervous of all that noise, there is only one place to start. Just three months old, Vienna's newest, slickest, most hi-tech museum, the Haus der Musik, is a revelation. It starts with a computerised introduction to the sounds of music and music of sounds, and ends in a futuristic playground of sonic massages and sound morphing. You can even conduct the Vienna Philharmonic courtesy of a computer program masterminded by the university of Linz.

For a genuine insight into what made all those metronomes tick, the coupes de theatre are the walk-through biographies of Vienna's seven great composers, from "Papa" Hadyn to Mahler and the dissonance of the 20th-century Viennese School. They brilliantly weave their stories into the fabric of the city and show how music, beginning in the churches, moved to the court and aristocratic salons, then through Schubert's open-air gatherings to the all-popular waltzes of the Strausses, preparing the way, in the collapse of empire and two world wars, for the shattering atonalities of the 20th century. "When you hear a sound you are also hearing the space in which it is made." It couldn't be truer than in Vienna.

Haus Der Musik, Seilerstatte 30. (+4315164851 www.houseofmusic-vienna.at). Open 10am-10pm daily. Adults £5, family ticket £11.

Next stop the Hofburg palace and an exhibition of 16th-century musical instruments, not just to touch bass but as an introduction to the Habs burgs. The winter palace of the Holy Roman emperor Franz Joseph, who defined the staggering pomp and circumstance of the 19th- century city, the Hofburg lies at Vienna's epicentre. It symbolises how this capital of an empire, once uniting 56 million people in the heart of the European maelstrom, became such a glittering focus for art and culture.

The Hofburg could take a weekend in itself but a must on a short trip is the Hofburg Chapel where every Sunday morning you can hear the Vienna Boys Choir. Make sure to get a seat near the front, otherwise you will have to peer at those angelic faces on a monitor.

Instruments of the 16th Century - National Library in the Hofburg Palace, Innere Stadt. Open 10am-5.30am except Tuesday. £2.50.

If the Hofburg testifies to the importance of patrons, it is the composers who play on and, armed with enough anecdotes, Vienna's drama explodes in the places they frequented. I didn't know Beethoven was always running upstairs or that Mozart spent a third of his life in carriages.

Everywhere you'll see plaques to Vienna's musical worthies, but two of the most important pilgrimage sites are the Pasqualati House and The Figaro House . Beethoven - who moved house 97 times - found a burgherish patron in Herr Pasqualati. The charming Figaro House lies in cobbled streets behind the all-imposing St Stephen's, the only surviving residence of Vienna's best loved visitor, Wolfgang Amadeus. Under the baroque ceiling in his bedroom you do get a real sense of Mozart's (or perhaps Peter Schaffer's) Vienna. Headphones and digital harpsichords allow you to indulge in some of the greatest works in situ.

It was the commercially-minded Strausses who really began to exploit popular music with their celebrated waltzes. Although the Danube is not and never has been blue, as you will see from the tributary that now forms Vienna's famous canal, you will hear the strains of waltzes everywhere. Vienna's ball season starts again too in November, although it doesn't reach its peak until January and February.

PasqualatiHaus, Molkerbastei 8. FigaroHaus, Domgasse 5. Johann Strauss Memorial Rooms, Praterstrasse 54. All open 9am-12.15pm, 1pm-4.30pm Tues- Sun. Closed Jan 1, May 1 & Dec 25.

Nights at the opera

The two main concert halls are the Musikverein (1 Bösendorferstrasse 12, tel: 505 8190) and the Konzerthaus (3 Lothringerstrasse 3, tel: 712 1211), home of the Vienna Philharmonic and Symphony orchestras.

But the high altar of musical culture is the splendid Staatsoper (1 Opernring 2, tel: 5144 42960), completely rebuilt in 1945. Sometimes, the humourless Viennese could do with the Marx brothers around, but for me there was no greater thrill than watching those deep-red curtains rise on a production of Verdi's Enani, as well-dressed Viennese showed their love, knowledge and appreciation in one of the world's greatest opera houses. Of course, seats are expensive but you can stand for around £5 - if you can get tickets.

Try, too, the Volksoper (9 Währingerstrasse 78, tel: 51 444) - the People's Opera. Far more relaxed, it still reaches a high standard and you are more likely to hear the strains of Figaro or Don Giovanni drifting through the doors.

For tickets to everything theatrical and musical, go to the Bundestheatrekassen (1 Hanuschgasse 3, down from the opera house, tel:5144 42960).

Tone deaf

If music isn't your thing, Vienna has plenty of other attractions. It is a city of theatres and museums, 90 in fact. A reason to go now is the exhibition in the Belvedere of Klimt's Women; a banquet of the painter's rich, jewelled colours, and decadent sensuality. To escape take a boat along the canal and loop out into the Danube.

Klimt's Women, Belvedere, Landstrasse. Until Jan 7. Open 10am-6pm except Mondays. Thurs to 7pm. £5. www.klimt-frauen.at.

In Vienna, even the horses love to dance and though it's difficult to get tickets you can watch them training in the mornings at the Spanish Riding School (Hofburg, Josefplatz).

Fiakers, Vienna's famous horse-drawn carriages, are very expensive and far better value is a personal guided tour.

For some darker notes, try the Prater Park and the sounds of the funfair. From the famous Ferris wheel where Harry Lime spills the beans in The Third Man you can gaze out across the city, over to the UN building, housing among other things the Drug Control Agency. For film buffs there is also a guided tour down to the sewers, called The Return of The Third Man (tel: 585 6455).

Where to eat

Vienna is almost as famous for food as music. The Sacher Hotel (1 Philharmonikerstrasse 4, behind the Opera House, tel: 514 560) invented the sachertorte (chocolate cake) for Prince Metternich, and everywhere windows groan with pastries, puddings and sweets. This is all most pleasurable in the city's numerous coffee houses.

Several boast musical associations but my favourites are the pink-fronted Café Diglas (1, Wollzeile 10, tel: 512 8401), and Hawelka (1 Dorotheerhasse 6, tel: 512 8230), still frequented by artists and musicians.

The tourist board has an excellent booklet of concert-cafés.

Café Landtmann (1 Dr-Karl-Lueger-Ring 4, tel: 532 0621) was a favourite of Freud's and is great for music.

You shouldn't leave Vienna without trying tafelspitz , a delicious Viennese beef stew, best at Plachutta (1 Wollzeile 38, tel: 512 1577). For lunch, Hansen (1 Wipplingerstrasse 34 in the basement of the Stock Exchange, tel: 532 0542) is trendy, the Cantino (at the top of the Haus der Musik) good, while Zum Zwarzen Kameel (1 Bognergasse 5, tel: 533 8967) is famous for its reislings and a still-unpaid bill of Beethoven's.

If you are going to the opera, be careful because Vienna seems to close suprisingly early. However, there is a good restaurant right opposite the Volksoper and several places to eat next to the Staatsoper. Corso (1 Hotel Bristol, Mahlerstrasse 2, tel: 5151 6546) is wonderful if you are really pushing the boat out, but for an after-opera meal go next door. Drei Husaren (1 Weihburggasse 4, tel: 5121 0920) is another famous upmarket restaurant, while Barbaro's (1 Kärtner Strasse 19, tel: 513 1712) at the top of a modern department store is not expensive and has great views. A traditional pre-opera tipple is a glass of champagne at the Reiss Bar ( Marco D'aviano-Gasse 1).

For some real life and the street culture that fed all that genius, try the student bars around Juden Strasse.

Where to stay

As everything happens in the charmed inner circle, district number 1 is the only place to stay. Our hotel the Romischer-Kaiser (1 Rathausstrasse 17, just next to the Haus Der Musik, tel: 512 7751) is both comfortable and elegant.

Another delightful though expensive hotel is König Von Ungarn - The King of Hungary (1 Schulerstrasse 10, tel: 515 84, doubles around £120). With a lovely inner courtyard it is next to Mozart's house and the Café Diglas just round the corner.

For somewhere cheaper, try Drei Kronen (Schleifmühlgasse 25, tel: 710 1919, doubles £44 per night) in the unmissable Naschmarkt, Vienna's most exciting market.

 David Clement-Davies' novel Fire Bringer is published in paperback by Macmillan at £5.99.

The practicals

Inghams Eurobreak (020-8780 7700, www.inghams.co.uk) offers two nights at the four-star Hotel Romischer Kaiser for £172 per person including Buzz return flights from Stansted and a free Dorling Kindersley guidebook worth £14.99. Tickets for the Volksoper (£14-£61) and Staatsoper (£17-£165) and the half-day city tour (£22pp) can be booked in advance through Inghams.

webTitle: Johnny Scott: Shepherd's crook | Kendal Mint Cake | Hat

fields.headline: Johnny Scott never travels without...
fields.trailText: Shepherd's crook | Kendal Mint Cake | Hat
fields.body:
A necessity: My shepherd's crook, a working leg crook with a ram's horn handle. It fits the palm of the hand perfectly. It's the right height and the right weight ,long enough to balance binoculars on and also to fit under the armpit and lean on.

A luxury: Kendal Mint Cake. It is refreshing to eat and full of energy - in short, delicious survival food.

A memento: I have a hat my daughter brought back for me from Rajastan. It is an odd shape and people tell me it looks like a cow pat. You can wear it in all weathers because it is like a stocking. You can roll it up, and in cold weather you can roll it down over your ears. She also gave me an antique

leather tobacco pouch from Florence. It is like a sausage, and I keep my tobacco, which I always take with me along with my pipe.

If only: Endless supplies of Avon Skin-So-Soft. It is an effective remedy against midges, which are a terrible problem on hot days in the countryside, though if it weren't for the midges Scotland would be absolutely be overrun in the summer.

 Clarissa and the Countryman is broadcast on BBC2 Fridays at 8.30pm. The book of the series is published by Headline at £20.

fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.trailText: Andrea Crisp is planning to take a year off to cycle round the world on the cheap. She wanted to know how much she should budget for on a daily basis.
fields.body:
Andrea Crisp is planning to take a year off to cycle round the world on the cheap. She wanted to know how much she should budget for on a daily basis.

 Your budget will depend on which countries you are visiting, with developing countries being obviously cheaper than developed countries.

Two years ago I cycled around the world and found that £20 per day in countries such as Australia and New Zealand was perfectly adequate and that about £7 per day in Asia was more than enough.

There were periods on the road when I spent very little, such as in the outback of Australia, which meant that I could save money to use when I felt like spoiling myself.

It is worth bearing in mind that there will be times when you feel like taking a break from the cycling and doing something else, such as an organised tour to a place that is not easy to reach, or an activity such as trekking or diving. So, it is worth having a contingency fund to enable you to do this.

Also, in developing countries there are times when you feel like spoiling yourself, perhaps by staying at an upmarket hotel or resort. It is worth having a bit of cash in reserve for the odd spot of self-indulgence.

Tim Cox

 In 1980, I was away for 12 months cycling overland to India. Although prices have gone up since then, it should still be incredibly cheap if you spend time in Asia rather than Europe.

Once past Istanbul I rarely paid for accommodation at all because people were so hospitable. If you stay away from big cities except where absolutely necessary, then you'll have a great and relatively inexpensive time - and you'll meet some wonderful people along the way. Language barriers will melt away if you spend long enough crossing each country to learn the basic vocabulary to get by on a daily basis.
Pete Bailey

Helen Jacobs wanted to know where she could buy an electronic mosquito deterrent.

 I must disagree with Hans Heap (Octobet 21). He bought an electronic mosquito deterrent in 1979. It didn't work. That was a long time ago. I bought one about four years ago and it works brilliantly. I bought it from a catalogue that came through the letterbox - Home Free. Unfortunately a couple of years ago when I tried to buy more of these devices as Christmas presents, the catalogue company said that they no longer supplied them. I never found out why. A friend in Tanzania speculated that the anti-malaria drugs companies might have bought the supplier simply in order to close it down and so remove the competition.
Mary M Scott

 Like your correspondent Hans Heap, I had an electronic mosquito deterrent device similar to the one he describes. However, the principle was supposed to be that it imitated the male insects. (Since it was the pregnant females who did the biting, they wished to avoid the further attentions of the males.)

It worked wonderfully well. In situations where I would previously have expected to have been badly bitten I would escape completely or very lightly.
Gerry Bates

This week's question

Heather Simmonds wants to fly to an airport in the south of France next year and then hire a VW camper/ motor home for the duration of her holiday. Can anyone suggest companies to approach?
fields.bodyText: Andrea Crisp is planning to take a year off to cycle round the world on the cheap. She wanted to know how much she should budget for on a daily basis.  Your budget will depend on which countries you are visiting, with developing countries being obviously cheaper than developed countries. Two years ago I cycled around the world and found that £20 per day in countries such as Australia and New Zealand was perfectly adequate and that about £7 per day in Asia was more than enough. There were periods on the road when I spent very little, such as in the outback of Australia, which meant that I could save money to use when I felt like spoiling myself. It is worth bearing in mind that there will be times when you feel like taking a break from the cycling and doing something else, such as an organised tour to a place that is not easy to reach, or an activity such as trekking or diving. So, it is worth having a contingency fund to enable you to do this. Also, in developing countries there are times when you feel like spoiling yourself, perhaps by staying at an upmarket hotel or resort. It is worth having a bit of cash in reserve for the odd spot of self-indulgence. Tim Cox  In 1980, I was away for 12 months cycling overland to India. Although prices have gone up since then, it should still be incredibly cheap if you spend time in Asia rather than Europe. Once past Istanbul I rarely paid for accommodation at all because people were so hospitable. If you stay away from big cities except where absolutely necessary, then you'll have a great and relatively inexpensive time - and you'll meet some wonderful people along the way.
