fields.headline: Ugly versus pretty
fields.standfirst: It's the dilemma facing all skiers when they book their package, says  Nicky Holford
fields.trailText: It's the dilemma facing all skiers when they book their package, says Nicky Holford.
fields.body:
In the brochure the chalet looked idyllic. It was framed by thick lusty pine trees topped with generous dollops of snow. Inside a log fire blazed. It was a short walk from the slopes, where a small gondola took you to the main ski station at Courchevel 1850.

Unlike the functional but unattractive hub of the Trois Vallées, we were staying in Courchevel 1550 - one of the five components of the resort that link to the 600km of pistes. Down the mountain from the jet-setting Courchevel 1850, we were in a small, quiet and attractive village, ideal for families and substantially cheaper.

A short gondola ride or alternatively a regular bus service were all that separated the two areas - that is until it started to snow, and snow and snow. Later that night we watched the snow build on the balcony, and as the flakes grew to the size of a fist and the wind started to howl our first concerns set in.

The next morning all was quiet, there was no hum from the gondola, our essential link to the main ski area, and the buses had stopped running. Eventually, a short Poma lift was opened, but it didn't go anywhere, all it did was justify the price of a lift ticket. We were well and truly cut off.

In New York City, any real estate agent will tell you that the three most important factors to take into account when looking for accommodation are location, location, location. The same could well apply to ski resorts. Sadly though, the most attractive resorts may not have the best skiing or reliable public transport, while the most convenient may not be attractive. In many cases it comes down to what you are prepared to pay.

Many of the purpose-built resorts are popular because they offer location and convenience at affordable prices. This doesn't mean that you should forego the pretty villages where the smell of manure wafts through the narrow cobbled streets and 400-year-old chalets groan from the passing of time, but that you should choose your alpine hideaway with care.

In Austria, where many traditional alpine villages have barely changed and hotels have been modernised or expanded in good taste, there are many resorts that combine convenience, and an attractive village, and a few that can add excellent skiing to the list.

In Switzerland, beware the antiquated four-star hotel. Last year, I went to Villars for the first time and found it a delightful location, with excellent skiing. But the so called four-star hotels, while meeting international standards, were tired and badly in need of renovation.

Italian resorts such as Courmayeur and Cortina D'Ampezzo have it all, but there are many other attractive Italian centres such as Livigno and Gressoney where you can find charm and good, albeit mostly, intermediate skiing. In France you'll find the purpose-built resort as the gateway to many of the largest ski areas.

Pretty Alpbach, Austria

The classic chocolate-box village with old wooden chalets, a small attractive church, narrow streets, and two 16th-century hotels run by the same family for several generations. The skiing is mostly intermediate on the Wiedersbergerhorn reached by a free shuttle bus. It's typically Tyrolean - expect cream teas, lederhosen and accordion players rather than tequila slammers and hip-hop.

Who goes there:

Crystal Holidays 0870 848 7000
Inghams 020-8780 4444
Made to Measure 01243 533333
Megève, France

An exclusive and chic resort that attracted the likes of Brigitte Bardot, Roger Vadim and other celebrities in the 1960s. As the years passed, it kept its exclusivity intact as others seeking adventure continued on to Chamonix half an hour away. Now its much improved skiing, high standard of restaurants and luxury and unspoilt medieval village centre makes it very attractive indeed, although it is not cheap.

Who goes there:

Powder Byrne 020-8246 5300
Elegant Resorts 01244 897333
Thomson 0870 606 1470
Cortina d'Ampezzo Italy

Set in the Ampezzo valley and surrounded by the dazzling beauty of the Dolomites, Cortina is one of Europe's most attractive resorts. The traffic-free centre makes it easy to walk around a town with beautiful old frescoed buildings, lively shopping and excellent restaurants. The skiing is varied but best for intermediates and beginners.

Who goes there:

White Roc 020-7792 1188
Abercrombie & Kent 020-7559 8585
Momentum Travel 020-7371 9111
Wengen, Switzerland

As the train winds its way up from Interlaken to Wengen, the majestic setting of the Jungfrau region and the fabled Eiger is spectacular. I first went to Wengen when I was five and subsequently joined the Coggins, the kids classes of the Downhill Only Club begun by the British in 1925. We used to toboggan down the main road but no one seemed to mind. Many years on, it hasn't changed. There are still no cars, the skiing is superb and you can get the best hot chocolate and cream teas in the Alps.

Who goes there:

Swiss Travel Service 01992 456123
Plus Travel 020-7734 0383
Neilson 0990 141414
Grimentz, Switzerland

Situated in the lovely Val d'Anniviers, not far from Crans Montana, Grimentz is a small, uncrowded, rustic village with no large buildings and a town centre where the ancient chalets on either side of a narrow cobbled stone path practically touch. It shares a ski pass with a few other small resorts that between them have varied and attractive skiing. Each month, there is a cheese- fondue evening and the opportunity to ski from the highest part of the resort to Grimentz under the light of the full moon.

Who goes there:

As yet no tour operators although Switzerland Tourism can arrange holidays 00800 100 200 30

Crested Butte, Colorado

Slip into the days of the Wild West as you drive down Main Street, where old buildings have been restored and have brightly painted wooden fronts that look like the set of a western. At night, the town centre looks like a fairyland but is still quintessentially American, with cold beer, good service, and cheery waitresses. The skiing, a couple of miles away is either intermediate or extreme. It has a cache of deeply challenging slopes in its Extreme Limits attracting the US's best.

Who goes there:

Ski Independence 0870 555 0555
Ski the American Dream 020-8552 1201
Ski Equipe 0870 444 5533
Ugly La Plagne

La Plagne has one of the largest integrated ski areas in the Alps and is made up of 10 separate villages between 1,800m-2,100m, of which six are purpose-built. Those built in the 1960s are the ugliest, such as Aime La Plagne and Plagne Centre. Those built later - at Plagne 1800, Plagne Villages and Plagne Soleil - are less forbidding. The most popular is Belle Plagne which has an attractive town centre. These centres or satellites do represent some of the best ski-in ski-out convenience, which for families is a major selling point. One way to get away from the architectural eyesore is to find a secluded chalet.

Who goes there:

Ski Beat 01243 780 405
Simply Ski 020-8541 2209
Erna Low 020-7584 2841
Flaine, France

Flaine is a 1960s example of Bauhaus architecture. Its massive concrete buildings, designed to mirror the shadow and light of their surroundings, are enough to make any prospective skiers' heart sink. The skiing is excellent and varied with an abundance of snow that quickly compensates for the surrounding architecture.

Who goes there:

Made to Measure 01243 533333
Thomson 0870 606 1470
Inghams 020-8780 4444
Tignes, France

Anyone who chooses to base themselves at Tignes, among arguably the worst architecture in the Alps, is there for one reason, the skiing. Tignes is not a good family resort and the public transport is frequent but crowded, but it's one of the best locations for ski-in ski-out accommodation and the skiing is sensational. No matter what conditions are like, there is always the Grande Motte glacier which is open all year and together with Val d'Isère it's the easiest access to the 300km of pistes. It's also popular with snowboarders.

Who goes there:

More than 40 ski operators offering a variety of both hotel and chalet accommodation, notably:

Silver Ski 01622 7355440
Ski Club of Great Britain 020-8410 2022
Ski Solutions 020-7471 7777
The Ski Company 01451 843123
Best of both worlds Zermatt, Switzerland

Arriving by train, as you have to in this carless village with the Matterhorn in the background, takes some beating. Small battery-operated taxis take you to your hotel, often down a warren of streets where wooden cow sheds battle for space inbetween restaurants and chalets. The variety of skiing and the number of cosy mountain restaurants is unlimited. For a good cappuccino (not that you can't get it in Zermatt), ski over the Italian border to Cervinia.

Who goes there:

Inghams 020-8780 4444
Kuoni 01306 742500
Ski Total 020-8948 3535
St Anton, Austria

In the heart of the Arlberg region surrounded by magical mountain scenery and small villages easily reached on skis for lunch, St Anton can provide whatever you require. It has opulent top hotels, modest accommodation, nightlife for those with stamina, romance for newlyweds, sophistication for an older crowd. The off-piste skiing is limitless but you can take a piste circuit to St Christoph, Stuben and Lech, or you can drop off the back of the Valluga (accompanied by a guide) and head into Zurs.

Who goes there:

Lotus Supertravel 020-7962 9933
Flexiski 0870 909 0754
Mark Warner 0870 848 0480
Val d'Isère, France

Val lacks the cosy charm of small romantic destinations such as Alpbach, but much of the heart of town has been thoughtfully renovated, with the facade of most buildings executed in the local stone. There are some heavenly luxury chalets, the nightlife is good and the skiing sublime. It kicks off the season in early December with the first World Cup men's downhill.

Who goes there:

Over 40 tour operators, including:

The Ski Company 01451 843123
Ski Val 01822 611200
YSE 020-8871 5117

fields.headline: Break with tradition
fields.standfirst: Can't decide whether to settle for the Terry's All Gold or head for Tierra del Fuego this Christmas?  Charlotte Atkins takes the wraps off some seasonal packages
fields.trailText: Can't decide whether to settle for the Terry's All Gold or head for Tierra del Fuego this Christmas? Charlotte Atkins takes the wraps off some seasonal packages.
fields.body:
Staying power

Celebrate in style, with all the trimmings but none of the chores, at a country house hotel. The party at Pale Hall, on the edge of the Snowdonia National Park in North Wales, for example, one-time favourite with Queen Victoria, begins with tea beside roaring log fires, followed by a series of hearty meals, cocktails and stunning views of the estate (three nights from £300pp with Sunvil UK (020-8232 9788).

Christmas in the four-star De Vere Hotel in Blackpool is bolder and brassier but a bundle of fun. The package includes the Ice Show at Blackpool Pleasure Beach on Boxing Day before a gala dinner and evening entertainment. Three nights with Superbreak (0990 992993) £275pp full board.

Other hotels where the spirit of Dickens will be getting its annual airing include: The Bath Spa (01225 444424) with champagne reception, optional midnight mass at Bath Abbey, Christmas Day evening buffet with string quartet, tickets for Cinderella panto at the Theatre Royal and a Monte Carlo casino evening (three nights from £695pp full board); Armathwaite Hall in Cumbria , which offers a Buck's Fizz breakfast, Trotters Animal Farm, a black-tie dinner and a candlelit walk around the hotel's extensive grounds (three nights £455pp with Superbreak); The Cadogan Hotel on Sloane Street (020-7235 7141), ideally situated for last-minute London shopping (two nights, £350); and Eastwell Manor (01233 213000) in Kent , where the three-night break includes a car treasure hunt, Dickensian evening, falconry, quiz, dance and a spa (£525 pp).

Useful central hotel booking numbers include: Pride of Britain (01264 324400), Forte (0345 404040); Wolsey Lodges (01473 827500), Virgin Hotels (01642 700767), Swallow Hotels (0870 600 4666), Best Western (01904 695400) and Marriott (0800 221 222).

Country pursuits

If you don't mind the festive chores but would prefer a change of scene in which to perform them, there are any number of heated manors, cottages, castles and farms available for hire in the deepest pockets of Britain's countryside. Country Holidays (01282 445095) maintains that the most requested feature over Christmas is an open fire, preferably with a chimney broad enough for Santa's belly, and an Aga in which to roast the bird. Costs vary: reckon on anything from £300 to £600 a week for a cottage sleeping six. The National Trust (01225 791199) has cottages over the Christmas and the New Year sleeping between two and six people. Also try English Country Cottages (0870 585 1155), Helpful Holidays (01647 433593) and Blakes (01282 445097), or call individual owners listed in the Good Holiday Cottage Guide (Swallow Press, £5.95).

How stylish

Style victims will feel at home in the recently-opened Beau Rivage on the east coast of Mauritius . Good food, good weather and a good soak are guaranteed - extravagant double baths feature in each room. For children there's a Little Mermaid Club, for grown-ups land sports, watersports, a health suite and a gym. Two weeks from December 20 cost £2,987 per adult, £1,482 per child half board including flights. Details: Classic Connection (0870 751 9320).

On ice

The Ice Hotel in Lapland (pictured above) is the world's largest igloo, which melts away in May and is redesigned and re-sculpted every November. Experienced dog-sled rides, snow-scooter safaris, the Absolut Icebar, a spine-tingling open-air sauna, and nights wrapped in reindeer skins upon a carved bed of ice are all part of the package. Two nights B&B cost £549pp, three nights £625 with Thomson Cities (0870 606 1476).

On the beach

Lunn Poly (0870 333 4400) believes that holidays in the sun are selling fast. Among the leftovers available through any of their high-street outlets are the Kaskazi Beach Hotel in Diani Beach in Kenya (two weeks all-inclusive £1,495pp); a week in Thailand split between Bangkok and Pattaya (£1,146pp); and 14 nights on the beach in Goa (£939pp B&B). Closer to home you could book Christmas week in a finca in Lanzarote (Simply Winter Sun, 020-8541 2212), or 10 sunny days in a five-star hotel with health club in Madeira through Cadogan (0870 036 4532).

Snowbound

Families dreaming of a white Christmas should think Ski Esprit (01252 618300), the children's ski specialist that is offering all accompanying grandparents a reduced rate of £250.

Regular prices start at £510 per adult at La Plagne departing December 24 . The price includes a chalet prettied up with tree and paper chains, flights and half-board accommodation, as well as two nights' babysitting (under 18s up to 50% discount, infants under two pay £70).

Further north, you can spend Christmas Day racing through the snow in Norway admiring the view from a torch-lit horse sleigh with Headwater Holidays (01606 813367).

Its cross-country skiing week costs £799 per adult, £426 per child which includes flights, full board, cross country skiing on 160km of marked trails, dog sledding, a traditional Christmas Eve dinner with carols and a visit from Mr Christmas. Ten nights (£949/£519) covers New Year's Eve fireworks, champagne, dinner and dancing.

Afloat

Explore the quiet reaches of the Norfolk Broads by cruiser or several canals by traditional narrowboat. Blakes (01603 739300) has boats sleeping from two to 12 and all have effective heating, some with woodburing stoves for both warmth and atmosphere. From around £120 per person for a week for a boat sleeping between four and six.

Christmas Eve will be celebrated in true Norse style on board Norwegian Coast Voyage's ships, (020-7559 6666, pictured above), which will be leaving Bergen between December 19 and 24. In addition to Christmas dinner, presents, a visit from Santa and Christmas carols, expect a Boxing Day dance and several lectures, including one on Norwegian Christmas and its traditions. A 13-day voyage starts at £940pp including flights, one night's B&B in Bergen and full-board afloat.

Cityslickers

Get back to the root of it all. The legend of Father Christmas, or "Noel Baba", is believed to have begun in Turkey when a 4th-century Christmas bishop, later called St Nicholas, gave anonymous gifts to dowryless village girls. Three nights in the four star Hotel President in the old quarter of Istanbul , with an indoor rooftop pool that looks down on the city's market, palaces and mosques, costs £432pp B&B with Sovereign Cities and Short Breaks (0870 576 8373).

For flights only, browse through the www.cheapflights.com range of worldwide destinations. It currently features Paris from £88pp (before December 31), for example, New York City from £249, and Lyon (a snowball's throw from the French pistes) from £165.

Spot of culture

Why couch down with the latest James Bond when your heart could be singing to Don Giovanni in Prague, La Bohème in Budapest, the Marriage of Figaro in Berlin or Die Zauberflote in Paris? Travel for the Arts (020- 7483 4466) can tailor-make packages to all these destinations including Eurostar seats, B&B hotels and opera tickets. Two nights in Paris, for example, cost from £299. Other city breaks on offer from the operator over Christmas include Chicago, New York City, Vienna, Munich and Barcelona.

Across the Atlantic

Swap olde England for New England, which knows a thing or two about warm inns, comfortable rooms, open hearths with log fires and rustic charm. Osprey Holidays (0870 5605 605) has a wide selection of characterful hotels, romantic country inns and smart resorts, for example the four-star Steamboat Inn in Mystic, Connecticut which has 10 rooms, each with a waterside view, whirlpool bath and fireplace. Flights and car hire for seven days start at £365pp. The Steamboat Inn costs from £51pp per night.

With a theme

Christmas doesn't come with more saccharine than at Disneyland Paris, which is open from 8am to 9pm on the big day itself, and for the whole of Christmas week. For the first time this winter, an Electrical Parade will light up the sky every evening as more than one million light-bulbs twinkle down Main Street on giant floats. That's in addition to a daily musical procession of snowmen and plum puddings. At nightfall, Father Christmas's sleigh, drawn by reindeers from the North Pole, arrives for the tree-lighting ceremony. Between November 11 and January 7, a two-night package staying at the Sequoia Lodge starts at £179 per adult and £41 per child based on two adults and two children sharing a family room, including breakfast, return ferry crossings and unlimited access to the theme park (0870 5030303).

Nature calls

There are not many reindeer but plenty of blue-booted booby birds to be spotted from a porthole on the Beagle III, the historical research motor cruiser which Worldwide Journeys & Expeditions (020-7386 4646) uses to cruise the Galapagos Islands. A cruise glides alongside sea lions, giant turtles, penguins and shoals of tropical fish, and costs from £2,195 (one week), £3,260 (two).

Down Under

While we shiver beneath our Barbours, Down Under they are in their swimmies, enjoying chilled beers on the beach and barbecued turkey thighs. For various New Zealand options call the NZ Tourism Board (09069 101010); for Oz contact the Australian Tourist Commission (020-8780 2229).

On the hoof

"Stuff the Turkey" is a five-day holiday in the southern Peak District for singles who want to forget about the wholebusiness. Indeed, Christmas is not even mentioned, says Old Furnace Walking Holidays (01538 703331). The 25th could be any old Monday, and lunch will be at the pub, as it is the rest of the week. The package (£295pp) includes accommodation, selected meals and daily rambles.

Budget option

Thirty-nine youth hostels in coastal, rural and city locations in England and Wales are open over Christmas, and eight have special seasonal packages. Three nights at the Victorian hostel perched on the hillside above the beautiful "plague village" of Eyam in Derbyshire, for example, costs £99 per adult, £79 for under 18s, and £59 for under-10s. Details: 01727 855215.

Matter of faith

Wherever you are in the world, your hotel will probably manage to rustle up a Christmas lunch, but in non-Christian countries there will be little in the way of razzmatazz for dessert.

For a Christmas virtually untouched by Western influences, Regal Holidays (0870 2201 777) recommends flying to the Red Sea resort of Hurghada in Egypt on December 22 where you can take a three-day Fastrack PADI Open Water learn-to-dive course from December 23-25, which will qualify you to dive almost anywhere in the world. A week at the Hurghada Hilton Villas costs £489pp B&B (diving an extra £240pp).

Further afield, Explore Worldwide (01252 760200) could have you on a Rajasthan Desert Safari (22 days, £1,395); searching for the Bengal Tiger in India (22 days, £1,495); cruising down the Amazon (22 days, £2,935) or gazing at the Angkhor Wat temple in Cambodia on Christmas Day (21 days £1,715). All these beat taking a snooze on the sofa.

Christmas in the four-star De Vere Hotel in Blackpool is bolder and brassier but a bundle of fun. The package includes the Ice Show at Blackpool Pleasure Beach on Boxing Day before a gala dinner and evening entertainment. Three nights with Superbreak (0990 992993) £275pp full board. Other hotels where the spirit of Dickens will be getting its annual airing include: The Bath Spa (01225 444424) with champagne reception, optional midnight mass at Bath Abbey, Christmas Day evening buffet with string quartet, tickets for Cinderella panto at the Theatre Royal and a Monte Carlo casino evening (three nights from £695pp full board); Armathwaite Hall in Cumbria , which offers a Buck's Fizz breakfast, Trotters Animal Farm, a black-tie dinner and a candlelit walk around the hotel's extensive grounds (three nights £455pp with Superbreak); The Cadogan Hotel on Sloane Street (020-7235 7141), ideally situated for last-minute London shopping (two nights, £350); and Eastwell Manor (01233 213000) in Kent , where the three-night break includes a car treasure hunt, Dickensian evening, falconry, quiz, dance and a spa (£525 pp). Useful central hotel booking numbers include: Pride of Britain (01264 324400), Forte (0345 404040); Wolsey Lodges (01473 827500), Virgin Hotels (01642 700767), Swallow Hotels (0870 600 4666), Best Western (01904 695400) and Marriott (0800 221 222). Country pursuits If you don't mind the festive chores but would prefer a change of scene in which to perform them, there are any number of heated manors, cottages, castles and farms available for hire in the deepest pockets of Britain's countryside. Country Holidays (01282 445095) maintains that the most requested feature over Christmas is an open fire, preferably with a chimney broad enough for Santa's belly, and an Aga in which to roast the bird. Costs vary: reckon on anything from £300 to £600 a week for a cottage sleeping six. The National Trust (01225 791199) has cottages over the Christmas and the New Year sleeping between two and six people. Also try English Country Cottages (0870 585 1155), Helpful Holidays (01647 433593) and Blakes (01282 445097), or call individual owners listed in the Good Holiday Cottage Guide (Swallow Press, £5.95). How stylish Style victims will feel at home in the recently-opened Beau Rivage on the east coast of Mauritius . Good food, good weather and a good soak are guaranteed - extravagant double baths feature in each room. For children there's a Little Mermaid Club, for grown-ups land sports, watersports, a health suite and a gym. Two weeks from December 20 cost £2,987 per adult, £1,482 per child half board including flights. Details: Classic Connection (0870 751 9320). On ice The Ice Hotel in Lapland (pictured above) is the world's largest igloo, which melts away in May and is redesigned and re-sculpted every November. Experienced dog-sled rides, snow-scooter safaris, the Absolut Icebar, a spine-tingling open-air sauna, and nights wrapped in reindeer skins upon a carved bed of ice are all part of the package. Two nights B&B cost £549pp, three nights £625 with Thomson Cities (0870 606 1476). On the beach Lunn Poly (0870 333 4400) believes that holidays in the sun are selling fast. Among the leftovers available through any of their high-street outlets are the Kaskazi Beach Hotel in Diani Beach in Kenya (two weeks all-inclusive £1,495pp); a week in Thailand split between Bangkok and Pattaya (£1,146pp); and 14 nights on the beach in Goa (£939pp B&B). Closer to home you could book Christmas week in a finca in Lanzarote (Simply Winter Sun, 020-8541 2212), or 10 sunny days in a five-star hotel with health club in Madeira through Cadogan (0870 036 4532). Snowbound Families dreaming of a white Christmas should think Ski Esprit (01252 618300), the children's ski specialist that is offering all accompanying grandparents a reduced rate of £250. Regular prices start at £510 per adult at La Plagne departing December 24 . The price includes a chalet prettied up with tree and paper chains, flights and half-board accommodation, as well as two nights' babysitting (under 18s up to 50% discount, infants under two pay £70). Its cross-country skiing week costs £799 per adult, £426 per child which includes flights, full board, cross country skiing on 160km of marked trails, dog sledding, a traditional Christmas Eve dinner with carols and a visit from Mr Christmas. Ten nights (£949/£519) covers New Year's Eve fireworks, champagne, dinner and dancing. Afloat Explore the quiet reaches of the Norfolk Broads by cruiser or several canals by traditional narrowboat. Blakes (01603 739300) has boats sleeping from two to 12 and all have effective heating, some with woodburing stoves for both warmth and atmosphere. From around £120 per person for a week for a boat sleeping between four and six. Christmas Eve will be celebrated in true Norse style on board Norwegian Coast Voyage's ships, (020-7559 6666, pictured above), which will be leaving Bergen between December 19 and 24. In addition to Christmas dinner, presents, a visit from Santa and Christmas carols, expect a Boxing Day dance and several lectures, including one on Norwegian Christmas and its traditions. The legend of Father Christmas, or "Noel Baba", is believed to have begun in Turkey when a 4th-century Christmas bishop, later called St Nicholas, gave anonymous gifts to dowryless village girls. Three nights in the four star Hotel President in the old quarter of Istanbul , with an indoor rooftop pool that looks down on the city's market, palaces and mosques, costs £432pp B&B with Sovereign Cities and Short Breaks (0870 576 8373). fields.headline: Travel tip
fields.body:
If you ever have to change flights at Amman (Jordan) airport, remember it has two almost identical terminals which you can wander between without realising it. In an addled state halfway through a longhaul to India, it is easy to get muddled. We almost missed our onward flight this way.
Dave Timms and Jessica Hardy

webTitle: Time Out Book of New York Walks

fields.headline: Time Out Book of New York Walks
fields.standfirst:
Published by Penguin, £10.99
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Time Out Book of New York Walks
fields.body:
This is a book, listing 23 walks in the Big Apple, that I would definitely take on my next trip there.

Typically, for Time Out, they are not your usual touristy walks, and all of them have been written by personalities in love with the place, such as the author William Boyd, New York Queen Lady Bunny or former homeless person turned novelist Lee Stringer. All of them are either historians, novelists, journalists or comedians.

Boyd takes us on a stroll of the Upper East Side from his local bolt hole, the Lowell Hotel, up Madison and down Lexington - it is his walk every day to the New York Society Library on 79th Street where he works.

His words - on his favourite bookstore (Crawford Doyle) and on the joys of visiting the Metropolitan Museum - are followed by extensive listings of places along the way in which to eat, accommodation, bookshops, shops and galleries.

All are presented differently. Some follow a theme - such as a Dorothy Parker walk with Marion Meade, or Damon Runyon's Broadway by Minda Novek - while others are personal.

All these pieces, covering all five boroughs, have the whiff of the city. Read them and you're there.

fields.headline: Via Dolorosa revisited
fields.standfirst: David Hare's Via Dolorosa
fields.trailText: David Hare's Via Dolorosa
fields.body:
Via Dolorosa is a monologue, ideally to be performed by its author. As the audience arrive, the author is at the side of the stage. When they are all in he begins to speak.
People always say that in the west we lead shallow lives. Our lives must be shallow because we live in countries where nobody believes in anything any more. All my life, I've been told "Western civilisation? An old bitch gone in the teeth." And so people say, go to Israel. Because in Israel at least people are fighting.

In Israel, they're fighting for something they believe in. Israel is, first and foremost, a cause, the cause being a patch of land, north to south on the eastern shore of the Mediterranean, lying like a small brown anchovy set down on a school atlas, to which the most persecuted people of modern times - perhaps the most persecuted people of all times - after the matchless catastrophe of the Holocaust rushed in the perfectly reasonable belief that they would never be safe until they had a country of their own. "We appealed to the conscience of the world. The world has no conscience. We have no one but ourselves." The fight. The struggle. The historic destiny. The return of the people. The cause: life therefore having a meaning and shape that eludes the rest of us in the endless wash of "What the hell are we doing here?" In a single day, says an Israeli friend, he experiences events and emotions that would keep a Swede going for a year.

Zionism being a movement with only a short history, and distinguished from other political movements of our time by the fact that it was invented by a playwright. Yes, Theodor Herzl, in 1894 takes a mere three weeks to write his play Das Neue Ghetto, in which the Jewish hero, struck down by his enemy, dies at curtain-fall, his last words ringing out through the darkened theatre: "I want to get out! Out of the ghetto!" Nine years later it is the same Herzl who is chairman of the World Zionist Congress when Lord Lansdowne, on behalf of the magnanimous British Empire, is generous enough to offer a small chunk of Uganda as a suitable place for the Jews to "live and observe their national customs". Incredibly, a fair number of delegates are hotly in favour - a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush, and Africa, after all, is better than nothing - but the option is finally rejected on the grounds that Uganda does not have the spiritual quality the Jews require. From this moment on, the central argument is foreshadowed. Is this a Biblical mission? Or is Israel to be a secular state? Throughout the 80s, organizations like the Friends of Israel offer to pay for writers to visit their country. Later, my friend Philip Roth goes off his own bat and returns home inspired by his meeting with the settlers, those religious Jews who have turned their whole lives into an act of political defiance by establishing Jewish townships on hitherto Arab land. "You've got to go, David. You've got to go and see it for yourself. These people are absolute lunatics. They're the maddest people I've ever met in my life. For any writer of fiction, they're the most wonderful material." "But surely," I say to Philip, one of America's most gifted comic novelists, "they're your material, not mine." "Oh no," says Philip, "You have no idea. These people are so crazy there's room enough for all of us."

On all occasions I refuse. It is only now, it is only 10 years later that I realise, almost without noticing, that for some time my subject as a playwright has been faith. My subject is belief. And so it comes to seem appropriate - no, more than that, it comes to seem urgent - that the 50-year-old British playwright should finally visit the 50-year-old state. The week before, the Israeli novelist, David Grossman, comes to my house in Hampstead. He says that whenever he comes to London, he makes sure to walk on Hampstead Heath. "I have some sort of mineral reaction to the place I don't get anywhere else in the world. Just to breathe the air makes me feel happy." Obscurely, I feel proud when he says this, as if somehow Grossman's happiness in Hampstead reflected credit on me, as if it were part of the glory of happening to be British to be able, rather casually, to offer foreigners the wonderfulness of Hampstead Heath. But "mineral reaction"? Grossman has thought so deeply about the problems of Israel and has lived so long with questions from people like me that he can't help wincing at my clumsiness. "What you call the major problems of Israel can one day be solved. There will be a Palestinian state. When I said this 10 years ago, everyone told me I was crazy. But now in their hearts people know it will happen. There are huge issues. But they are essentially soluble. What is less soluble is the underlying moral question: how does a majority which itself has been historically unloved now deal fairly with an unloved Palestinian minority in their own midst? Are we mature enough, are we courageous enough to internalise the idea of equality?" I say, surely this has always been the problem at the heart of Zionism. Israel is effectively a religious state. It now admits immigrants of only one faith. Won't it one day have to become a modern country, multi-cultural, like any other?

Grossman smiles. "Yes, but for us that's very difficult. I don't see it the way you do. I don't think you have to be religious to be a Jew. There is no God in my life, and I'm as Jewish as it's possible to be. If you want to understand Israel, look to the six day war. That war changed everything. Myself, I feel we were much more Jewish before 1967. That war destroyed our essential Jewishness, because up till then places and buildings and stones didn't mean anything to us. They weren't important. What mattered to us were ideas.

"Something very profound happened to Israel during the six day war. For the first time we seized land, we took land by conquest, and suddenly the religious Jew saw the Bible not as a historical story, but as a contemporary operations manual. Yes, I want Israelis to have access to the Wailing Wall, but I don't need to own it. Nor do I need to own any of these holy places. It's new this idea. That you have to own things. It's new and it's profoundly un-Jewish." On arrival in Tel-Aviv I am rushed down Californian highways in the company of Sigal Cohen, the young and humorous translator who will accompany me wherever I go. I had expected massive security precautions and I boast of the ease with which I have sailed through immigration. "Yes," she says, "Israel is a very easy country to get into but it's an impossible country to get out of." At my nasty western-style downtown hotel, my chief British Council host Keith Lawrence is waiting. He is very thin, like a teddy-boy with tapered trousers and a collarless jacket. Give him a tall, skinny latte and this could be Soho. He is the man who is bringing plays like Shopping and Fucking to Tel-Aviv. He keeps saying Tel-Aviv is sexy and a happening kind of place, especially for a beach bunny, and sometimes he refers, rather unexpectedly, to the 'buzz'. When I try to find out exactly what the buzz consists of, everyone tells me that it has mostly to do with sitting in cafes and fucking. Later somebody tells me that Tel-Aviv is the fucking capital of the world.

No chance to observe, because I am off to eat baked sea-bream, in a stunning waterside restaurant in the nearby port of Jaffa, at the invitation of the Israeli theatre director Eran Baniel. Eran is a fine-looking man in his early 50s, bearded, articulate, in a black corduroy suit. Now we drink Rothschild's Red Merlot and discuss the profound divisions which have emerged between the secular and religious ways of life. At the foundation of the state, the religious orthodox were guaranteed a special status. Anyone who entered a yeshiva to study the Talmud was exempted from the army, and given a public salary. At the time, there were just 500 students, but by the early 1990s there were over 100,000, says Eran "effectively living off the state for life".

"For years," says Eran, "the Jew believed that when the goy persecuted you, it gave you the right to shortchange him. Hence the racial stereotype of the Jew who smiles while he swindles you. Well now we are the goy. Israel is the goy. And the religious orthodox have become the thieving Jew. They go to whoever wants to be prime minister and say, yes, you can have our votes but only if you promise to give us our money. They don't serve in the army. They smile and smile, and rob the country blind."

Eran, it is clear, is a secular Jew. His life was changed by his famous co-production of Romeo and Juliet. This was presented in the middle of Jerusalem. The Palestinians played the Capulets and the Jews played the Montagues. There were five months of rehearsal, with the Palestinian producer George Ibrahim in charge of the Capulets and with Eran directing the Montagues. The project took eight years to achieve. In this production the Capulets really hated the Montagues. This was not a production about love, but about hate. Neither side needed the rhetoric at the beginning. "You know that bit," says Eran, "where the two sides line up and sort of say "Fuck you, Montague" and "Fuck you, Capulet". Well, we cut all that. Because Israelis and Palestinians go straight to the emotion: you pick up a stone and throw it straight away."

Eran says he never really understood the occupation until he did this job. "Most Israelis," says Eran, "don't even notice the Palestinians. They don't see them. Have you seen how Israelis drive? They don't drive. They own the road." His voice is rising now. "Have you been to the Palestinian territories? Look how the water is allocated. In the settlements, you have the obscene spectacle of Israelis sitting by their swimming pools while Palestinians carry their drinking water round in jerry cans." He uses a phrase I have heard before. "It's un-Jewish, it's un-Jewish behaviour." By chance, a play of mine, Amy's View, is currently rehearsing at the Cameri, one of Israel's foremost theatres. Next morning I kick my way through the litter-strewn streets to meet the cast, who have two hours of questions. At one point I say the play is about how we no longer expect society to validate our beliefs. Our only values are private values. The last line of the play is: "So. We're alone." Israel, I say, may be the worst place in the world to perform the play since here people are still arguing passionately about where their country is heading. Whereas in England Tony Blair represents all things to all men. What does he believe? Nobody knows. What will he do? Whatever is popular. Where is he heading? He never tells us. At once, an Israeli actor interrupts: "Oh please, please, send us your Tony Blair."

In fact, theatre is making me impatient because I am longing to get going and spend Sabbath in the Jewish settlement of Sheri Tikva which lies some miles inside the borders of the Palestinian territory. It takes us hours to push our way out of town on a Friday afternoon, in the pre-Sabbath rush, but finally Tel-Aviv falls away, and the road opens out. I think of my Sunday school, Sunday afternoons in a stuffy wooden hall in Bexhill-on-Sea. I look from the window of the car and the pale, stony landscape of dusty hills and olive-groves feels familiar, like a drawing from memory.

I have now to be careful, because 10 minutes later a feeling arrives, unbidden. My mind is slipping, I am dreaming, perhaps of Israeli wine and fresh fish, when suddenly, in open country at last, it occurs to me, as I look out the window, that the Jews do not belong here. This thought is so unexpected and of course implicitly so inflammatory that I turn guiltily, blushing, to see whether anyone in the back of the car can tell what I'm thinking. Up till now I have spent time in Tel-Aviv, a town which, on its surface at least, is sophisticated and western, but now I am speeding through a huge land mass - I feel the topography, I feel the land, a great hot continent stretching away to my right, Arab country after Arab country - and for the first time I understand how odd, how egregious Israel must look to the Arab eye.

Extract two

For any writer of fiction, they're the most wonderful material." "But surely," I say to Philip, one of America's most gifted comic novelists, "they're your material, not mine." "Oh no," says Philip, "You have no idea. These people are so crazy there's room enough for all of us." On all occasions I refuse. It is only now, it is only 10 years later that I realise, almost without noticing, that for some time my subject as a playwright has been faith. My subject is belief. And so it comes to seem appropriate - no, more than that, it comes to seem urgent - that the 50-year-old British playwright should finally visit the 50-year-old state. The week before, the Israeli novelist, David Grossman, comes to my house in Hampstead. He says that whenever he comes to London, he makes sure to walk on Hampstead Heath. "I have some sort of mineral reaction to the place I don't get anywhere else in the world. Just to breathe the air makes me feel happy." Obscurely, I feel proud when he says this, as if somehow Grossman's happiness in Hampstead reflected credit on me, as if it were part of the glory of happening to be British to be able, rather casually, to offer foreigners the wonderfulness of Hampstead Heath. But "mineral reaction"? Grossman has thought so deeply about the problems of Israel and has lived so long with questions from people like me that he can't help wincing at my clumsiness. "What you call the major problems of Israel can one day be solved. There will be a Palestinian state. When I said this 10 years ago, everyone told me I was crazy. But now in their hearts people know it will happen. There are huge issues. But they are essentially soluble. What is less soluble is the underlying moral question: how does a majority which itself has been historically unloved now deal fairly with an unloved Palestinian minority in their own midst? Are we mature enough, are we courageous enough to internalise the idea of equality?" I say, surely this has always been the problem at the heart of Zionism. Israel is effectively a religious state. It now admits immigrants of only one faith. Won't it one day have to become a modern country, multi-cultural, like any other? Grossman smiles. "Yes, but for us that's very difficult. I don't see it the way you do. I don't think you have to be religious to be a Jew. There is no God in my life, and I'm as Jewish as it's possible to be. If you want to understand Israel, look to the six day war. That war changed everything. Myself, I feel we were much more Jewish before 1967. That war destroyed our essential Jewishness, because up till then places and buildings and stones didn't mean anything to us. They weren't important. What mattered to us were ideas. "Something very profound happened to Israel during the six day war. For the first time we seized land, we took land by conquest, and suddenly the religious Jew saw the Bible not as a historical story, but as a contemporary operations manual. Yes, I want Israelis to have access to the Wailing Wall, but I don't need to own it. Nor do I need to own any of these holy places. It's new this idea. That you have to own things. It's new and it's profoundly un-Jewish." On arrival in Tel-Aviv I am rushed down Californian highways in the company of Sigal Cohen, the young and humorous translator who will accompany me wherever I go. I had expected massive security precautions and I boast of the ease with which I have sailed through immigration. "Yes," she says, "Israel is a very easy country to get into but it's an impossible country to get out of." At my nasty western-style downtown hotel, my chief British Council host Keith Lawrence is waiting. He is very thin, like a teddy-boy with tapered trousers and a collarless jacket. Give him a tall, skinny latte and this could be Soho. He is the man who is bringing plays like Shopping and Fucking to Tel-Aviv. He keeps saying Tel-Aviv is sexy and a happening kind of place, especially for a beach bunny, and sometimes he refers, rather unexpectedly, to the 'buzz'. When I try to find out exactly what the buzz consists of, everyone tells me that it has mostly to do with sitting in cafes and fucking. Later somebody tells me that Tel-Aviv is the fucking capital of the world. No chance to observe, because I am off to eat baked sea-bream, in a stunning waterside restaurant in the nearby port of Jaffa, at the invitation of the Israeli theatre director Eran Baniel. Eran is a fine-looking man in his early 50s, bearded, articulate, in a black corduroy suit. Now we drink Rothschild's Red Merlot and discuss the profound divisions which have emerged between the secular and religious ways of life. At the foundation of the state, the religious orthodox were guaranteed a special status. Anyone who entered a yeshiva to study the Talmud was exempted from the army, and given a public salary. At the time, there were just 500 students, but by the early 1990s there were over 100,000, says Eran "effectively living off the state for life". "For years," says Eran, "the Jew believed that when the goy persecuted you, it gave you the right to shortchange him. Hence the racial stereotype of the Jew who smiles while he swindles you. Well now we are the goy. Israel is the goy. And the religious orthodox have become the thieving Jew. They go to whoever wants to be prime minister and say, yes, you can have our votes but only if you promise to give us our money. They don't serve in the army. They smile and smile, and rob the country blind." Eran, it is clear, is a secular Jew. His life was changed by his famous co-production of Romeo and Juliet. This was presented in the middle of Jerusalem. The Palestinians played the Capulets and the Jews played the Montagues. There were five months of rehearsal, with the Palestinian producer George Ibrahim in charge of the Capulets and with Eran directing the Montagues. The project took eight years to achieve. In this production the Capulets really hated the Montagues. This was not a production about love, but about hate. Neither side needed the rhetoric at the beginning. "You know that bit," says Eran, "where the two sides line up and sort of say "Fuck you, Montague" and "Fuck you, Capulet". Well, we cut all that. Because Israelis and Palestinians go straight to the emotion: you pick up a stone and throw it straight away." Eran says he never really understood the occupation until he did this job. "Most Israelis," says Eran, "don't even notice the Palestinians. They don't see them. Have you seen how Israelis drive? They don't drive. They own the road." His voice is rising now. "Have you been to the Palestinian territories? Look how the water is allocated. In the settlements, you have the obscene spectacle of Israelis sitting by their swimming pools while Palestinians carry their drinking water round in jerry cans." He uses a phrase I have heard before. "It's un-Jewish, it's un-Jewish behaviour." By chance, a play of mine, Amy's View, is currently rehearsing at the Cameri, one of Israel's foremost theatres. Next morning I kick my way through the litter-strewn streets to meet the cast, who have two hours of questions. At one point I say the play is about how we no longer expect society to validate our beliefs. Our only values are private values. The last line of the play is: "So. We're alone." Israel, I say, may be the worst place in the world to perform the play since here people are still arguing passionately about where their country is heading. Whereas in England Tony Blair represents all things to all men. What does he believe? Nobody knows. What will he do? Whatever is popular. Where is he heading? He never tells us. At once, an Israeli actor interrupts: "Oh please, please, send us your Tony Blair." In fact, theatre is making me impatient because I am longing to get going and spend Sabbath in the Jewish settlement of Sheri Tikva which lies some miles inside the borders of the Palestinian territory. It takes us hours to push our way out of town on a Friday afternoon, in the pre-Sabbath rush, but finally Tel-Aviv falls away, and the road opens out. I think of my Sunday school, Sunday afternoons in a stuffy wooden hall in Bexhill-on-Sea. I look from the window of the car and the pale, stony landscape of dusty hills and olive-groves feels familiar, like a drawing from memory. I have now to be careful, because 10 minutes later a feeling arrives, unbidden. My mind is slipping, I am dreaming, perhaps of Israeli wine and fresh fish, when suddenly, in open country at last, it occurs to me, as I look out the window, that the Jews do not belong here. This thought is so unexpected and of course implicitly so inflammatory that I turn guiltily, blushing, to see whether anyone in the back of the car can tell what I'm thinking. Up till now I have spent time in Tel-Aviv, a town which, on its surface at least, is sophisticated and western, but now I am speeding through a huge land mass - I feel the topography, I feel the land, a great hot continent stretching away to my right, Arab country after Arab country - and for the first time I understand how odd, how egregious Israel must look to the Arab eye. fields.headline: That's the ticket
fields.standfirst: Survey finds more package holidaymakers are returning happy
fields.trailText: Survey finds more package holidaymakers are returning happy.
fields.body:
Fewer package holidaymakers are returning home disgruntled, new research suggests, but a disturbing 9% of customers still protest that descriptions in tour operators' brochures are inaccurate.

All but 8% of those questioned this year were happy with their breaks, compared with 87% in a similar survey two years ago and 90% felt they had received good value for money, a rise of 3%.

The research was carried out by MORI for the Association of British Travel Agents, which unveiled the results at its annual conven tion on the Greek island of Kos this week.

But if operators are gradually improving quality they clearly still have some work to do when it comes to rose tinted views of resorts or hotels. While the survey indicates greater trust in brochure copy, with 73% of holidaymakers accepting that descriptions were fair against 70% last time, 9% said felt they had been the victims of "inaccurate representation". The rest expressed no opinion one way or the other. Within the overall figure, 4%, or around 850,000 people, still "strongly disagreed" with the premise that brochures gave a fair picture, compared with 5% in 1988.

The number of people booking direct with tour operators rose, from 24% to 27%, but if the research results are to be believed, that figure suggests increasing consumer sophistication rather than scepticism about High-Street travel agents.

The proportion booking through agents fell by 2% and almost one third of those who did (32%), thought the advice they got was more trustworthy" than in 1998. And despite the recent fuss about agents who recommend the holidays of linked operators, 37% believe they provide unbiased advice.

Researchers also asked holidaymakers about the impact of tourism on the environment. Almost one fifth (18%) claimed they switched off air conditioning to save energy, 17% said they avoided having towels changed too often, 36% saved water by showering rather than taking baths and 84% avoided leaving litter. Nearly two thirds (64%) claimed they would pay £10-£25 extra for environmental, social or charity reasons.

But while just over half of the respondents said they would like to discover more about social and environmental issues in the resorts they visit, 46% said they had little or no interest.

And when consumers were asked where they would go if money were no object, Australia won hands down (see the table right). It was chosen by 22%, followed by the United States with 11%. No other destination managed to record double figures.

fields.headline: Flights of fancy
fields.standfirst: Don't even think about relying on one travel site when you want to book flights, warns Ros Taylor
fields.trailText: Don't even think about relying on one travel site when you want to book flights, warns Ros Taylor
fields.body:
Be promiscuous. Don't even think about relying on one travel site when you want to book flights - fidelity gets you nowhere if you want the most inexpensive flights on given dates.

Taking a hypothetical weekend trip to New York City on Friday, November 17 with a partner, travelling economy and flying from anywhere in London to anywhere in NY, I found erratic service and prices that varied from the reasonable to the wildly extortionate.

The best: www.thomascook.co.uk

£220.10 on Air France

Change at Paris Charles de Gaulle at six in the morning and be back at your desk by 10am on Monday - customs, baggage carousels and the Heathrow Express permitting.

The worst: www.lastminute.com

No flights found

Lastminute's redesign has undoubtedly made the site sharper and easier to navigate, but some fundamental flaws remain. It was easy enough to find an Alitalia return for £247 which left on the Friday, but that price was only available on return flights at least a week later. Since this was the only flight Lastminute came up with, searching again was pointless. No weekend breaks for less than £500 were available, either.

The rest

Cheapflights

From £179

You can't search by date at Cheapflights, so it was impossible to know whether the dozens of prices and agencies quoted had seats available that weekend. Print out the page and start working down the list by phone.

Ebookers

£247.50 on Icelandair

No luck. Ebookers' tiresome booking system produced a reasonable flight with a stopover in Reykjavik and noon arrival on Monday.

UTravel

£229.80 on Virgin Atlantic

Again, choosing these seats means you won't be home until Monday afternoon. Nonetheless, the flight is direct and UTravel's redesign has improved the site considerably.

British Airways

£883

If you really must be back at work on Monday morning, BA enables you to leave JFK and arrive at Heathrow on the same day with an impressive range of costly flights.

Expedia

"Your request cannot be completed at this time. Please try again later. If your itinerary requires immediate action, please call our customer service centre."

Unfortunately, subsequent attempts to book also proved fruitless.

Virgin Atlantic

£1,022

Attempt one: "Your connection to the booking information has been reset. Please try your booking again."

Attempt two: an extortionate fare was quoted from Gatwick to Newark. Returning the following day, this time from JFK to Heathrow was slightly more expensive.

webTitle: The recent release of long-banned films

fields.headline: In the realm of the censors
fields.standfirst: The vaults are suddenly giving up their secret hoard of sex and slasher movies - Texas Chainsaw Massacre has its TV premiere tonight. But, asks Steve Rose, were they worth the  wait?
fields.trailText: The vaults are suddenly giving up their secret hoard of sex and slasher movies - Texas Chainsaw Massacre has its TV premiere tonight. But, asks Steve Rose, were they worth the wait?
fields.body:
Lock up your daughters, sons, livestock and power tools, because the floodgates are open. After decades of holding back the tidal wave of sex and violence, Britain is now undergoing a veritable frenzy of liberalisation.

Once we took pride in our reputation as the repression capital of Europe, but virtually every film you were never allowed to see has suddenly emerged from hibernation. "Hardcore" porn videos can now be bought over the counter instead of over the Channel; historical scandalisers like The Story Of O, Salo and In the Realm of the Senses are all enjoying a renaissance.

Former gore shockers like Texas Chainsaw Massacre are now material for primetime rather than municipal incinerators. Graphic sex is writhing its way onto the big screen, and the small screen too, as FilmFour prepares to broadcast Catherine Breillat's highbrow sexathon Romance in November.

Not that any of this should necessarily be reason to rejoice. For one thing, these liberties have had to be wrested from the hands of the moral minority, and for another, not all of these films were necessarily worth banning, or watching, in the first place.

Ever since Jack The Ripper caught sight of an exposed table leg and was impelled to embark on a Victorian killing spree, the link between provocative images and real-world side effects has taken a powerful hold in this country. Our moral custodians have unerringly erred on the side of caution, seizing anything remotely perturbing with a vigilance bordering on the fanatical, and justifying their actions legally with grey terms like "corrupt" and "deprave".

So what's changed? About four years ago, police informed the British Board of Film Classification (BBFC) that material being released as R18 (ie hardcore porn) was actually too tame to merit the description, and therefore misleading. New guidelines were half implemented, but then Jack Straw entered the Home Office and effectively reversed the process.

A ping-pong match of appeals, refusals and judicial reviews ensued, and to everyone's surprise, the courts ruled that watching sex on TV really didn't harm many people (repetitive strain injury aside). "We don't sit in our ivory tower and say what people should watch," says Sue Clark of the BBFC, which recently undertook an extensive public survey. "We still have some of the strictest censorship rules in the world, but now we effectively accept that adults should be allowed to decide what they want to watch."

So here we are, officially relaxed and eager to watch anything we once couldn't. As any record producer knows, an official ban is the best publicity one could hope for, which explains why any film with a vague whiff of scandal attached to it is now being sprung from the vaults.

To put the record straight, though, the BBFC does not "ban" films. It classifies them, or doesn't as the case may be, and local authorities decide whether or not to screen them. This was the case with "cult erotic dramas" like The Story Of O, a kinky confection of Ferrero Rocher styling and consensual sado-masochism that caused a stir in 1975 and finally received a UK release this year.

Director Just Jaeckin, who also directed the equally notorious Emmanuelle (which received a certificate, with cuts), has fond but vague memories of the film: "For me, it was a beautiful story about love. It was not corrupting or pornographic, it was a fantasy, like Alice In Wonderland. But erotic, of course."

While it's unlikely The Story Of O or Emmanuelle could have corrupted anyone, it's also quite a stretch to imagine that they could have aroused anyone either. Apart from crimes against interior design, the only real reason to suppress them was so that bands like Air could rip off their soundtracks undetected.

Jaeckin's films did, however, show others the way to get sex onto cinema screens: make your film foreign and try to have some kind of plot. "Arthouse" has always been a way of evading the censors' scissors. Nagisa Oshima's In The Realm Of The Senses was passed in 1991 (only a 15-year wait), and the old erect-penis taboo was later lifted for Lars Von Trier's The Idiots, and Leos Carax's Pola X.

Catherine Breillat's Romance, in many ways an updated Emmanuelle, has as many erections as an R18 film, but was passed for cinema release virtually uncut. Pasolini's Salo has fared less well. Despite impeccable arthouse credentials, its blend of perverted sex, sadistic violence and coprophilia went down as well as an excrement souffle with the authorities, despite the fact that its themes of repression, consumption and sexuality were serious-minded.

Currently up for reclassification, it was seized by police when shown uncut at a Soho cinema in 1977 - narrowly staving off a nationwide outbreak of faeces-eating.

The only films truly banned in the UK were the infamous "video nasties" of the 80s. In this instance, the Department of Public Prosecutions stepped in to staunch the Betamax bloodbath which the BBFC was powerless to stop, and prosecuted about 60 films, including future classics such as The Driller Killer, The Evil Dead and Andy Warhol's Flesh For Frankenstein (Texas Chainsaw Massacre was not on the list, although it had been refused a certificate since 1975).

The "but horror films are supposed to be scary" argument didn't wash; a racy title or a lurid cover was enough (like the relatively tame I Miss You Hugs And Kisses, unwisely tagged "for those who like their sex with a lot of violence").

In the sober light of the 21st century, the majority of these low-budget splatterdramas are more hilarious than disgusting - such as Forest Of Fear, in which hippies become zombies after the FBI sprays their weed with an experimental herbicide, or Night Of The Demon, in which a victim is disembowelled by bigfoot, then whipped with his own intestines in slow motion.

There are still many uncertified titles, some of which are unlikely to ever see the light of day, but others only remain "banned" because they are so bad nobody has bothered to re-submit them. Despite our new climate of acceptance, censorship is still full of contradictions.

We are legally allowed to have sex at 16, but must wait another two years to see it on a screen. We are allowed to buy R18 videos but not receive them by mail, or bring them from abroad. And what we consider 18-certificate material, our European counterparts regularly classify as 15 or even 12. European porn producers still tone down their films for the UK market.

Perhaps another side-effect of this liberation is the consequences for eroticism as opposed to pornography. With a rising background-smut count - thanks to increasingly sexualised advertising, television, magazines - pornography is scuttling up the hardcore ladder into bizarre, almost medical realms. If there's a relationship between what is forbidden and what is erotic, we're heading for an age of tedious sexual ubiquity, where everything is permitted and nothing is exciting.

Perhaps we're overcompensating for all those years of repression and in a few years, as has happened with violence in films, we'll reach saturation - and start campaigning for less sex on our screens.

Texas Chainsaw Massacre, 11.45pm, Sat, C4; In The Realm of the Senses is on limited release; Salo is showing at the ICA and NFT in London; The Story Of O is out on DVD and video on Monday

Reel shockers
Five Þlms the censors still don't want you to see

Cannibal Holocaust (Ruggero Deodato, 1979)
The gory effects were so realistic Deodato had to go to court to prove it was fake. The ban is due to a brutal rape-murder and real-life animal killings. Makers of The Blair Witch are probably pleased since they ripped off its "found footage" structure.

Snuff (Michael & Roberta Findlay, 1974)
Argentina-made Manson family-like horror that spawned the "oh my god, they're really killing someone!" urban legend. In reality it was a B-grade horror (Slaughter) with a film-set killing tacked on the end.

Straw Dogs (Sam Peckinpah, 1971)
Highly accomplished thriller with Dustin Hoffman declaring war on Cornwall. Overshadowed by its notorious depiction of Susan George being raped and enjoying it. The censors always had it in for Peckinpah anyway.

Nekromantik (Jorg Buttgereit, 1987)
Necrophilia is a definite no-no, kinky threesomes with a corpse are positively unacceptable. And as for killing and skinning a real live rabbit, Nekromantik 2 features a particularly revolting seal autopsy.

Boy Meets Girl (Ray Brady, 1994)
Low-budget torture-chamber sexual horror set in London - not as grisly as some. Recently given an 18 certificate but still too nasty for video.

In the sober light of the 21st century, the majority of these low-budget splatterdramas are more hilarious than disgusting - such as Forest Of Fear, in which hippies become zombies after the FBI sprays their weed with an experimental herbicide, or Night Of The Demon, in which a victim is disembowelled by bigfoot, then whipped with his own intestines in slow motion. There are still many uncertified titles, some of which are unlikely to ever see the light of day, but others only remain "banned" because they are so bad nobody has bothered to re-submit them. Despite our new climate of acceptance, censorship is still full of contradictions. We are legally allowed to have sex at 16, but must wait another two years to see it on a screen. We are allowed to buy R18 videos but not receive them by mail, or bring them from abroad. And what we consider 18-certificate material, our European counterparts regularly classify as 15 or even 12. European porn producers still tone down their films for the UK market. Perhaps another side-effect of this liberation is the consequences for eroticism as opposed to pornography. With a rising background-smut count - thanks to increasingly sexualised advertising, television, magazines - pornography is scuttling up the hardcore ladder into bizarre, almost medical realms. If there's a relationship between what is forbidden and what is erotic, we're heading for an age of tedious sexual ubiquity, where everything is permitted and nothing is exciting. Perhaps we're overcompensating for all those years of repression and in a few years, as has happened with violence in films, we'll reach saturation - and start campaigning for less sex on our screens. Texas Chainsaw Massacre, 11.45pm, Sat, C4; In The Realm of the Senses is on limited release; Salo is showing at the ICA and NFT in London; The Story Of O is out on DVD and video on Monday Reel shockers Five Þlms the censors still don't want you to see Cannibal Holocaust (Ruggero Deodato, 1979) The gory effects were so realistic Deodato had to go to court to prove it was fake. The ban is due to a brutal rape-murder and real-life animal killings. Makers of The Blair Witch are probably pleased since they ripped off its "found footage" structure. Snuff (Michael & Roberta Findlay, 1974) Argentina-made Manson family-like horror that spawned the "oh my god, they're really killing someone!" urban legend. In reality it was a B-grade horror (Slaughter) with a film-set killing tacked on the end. Straw Dogs (Sam Peckinpah, 1971) Highly accomplished thriller with Dustin Hoffman declaring war on Cornwall. Overshadowed by its notorious depiction of Susan George being raped and enjoying it. The censors always had it in for Peckinpah anyway. Nekromantik (Jorg Buttgereit, 1987) Necrophilia is a definite no-no, kinky threesomes with a corpse are positively unacceptable. And as for killing and skinning a real live rabbit, Nekromantik 2 features a particularly revolting seal autopsy. Boy Meets Girl (Ray Brady, 1994) Low-budget torture-chamber sexual horror set in London - not as grisly as some. Recently given an 18 certificate but still too nasty for video.

webTitle: Who lost their heart in Perth, Australia?

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Perth, Australia
fields.standfirst: Dennis Waterman
fields.trailText: Dennis Waterman
fields.body:
Why: Perth is pretty sophisticated; the food is good and it is near some of the best wine country in the world. Although they call it a city, it is really a large country town sandwiched between the desert and the Indian Ocean. The beautiful thing about western Australia is that you can go to a totally empty beach only 20 minutes away or you can stay in the town and have a bit of rock 'n' roll. You don't have to go very far to be in a landscape that couldn't be anywhere else but Australia.

My perfect day: Golf has to have something to do with it. There are a couple of stunning golf courses nearby. One word of warning: snakes are not uncommon, so don't go too far into the rough to find your ball. Get up early, play 18 holes, get back into Perth and sit out at a restaurant on Scarborough beach and eat lobster, oysters and drink some wine.

What's the best thing? Perth is just so calm. I now have several friends there so it is always very welcoming. I really like the Australians. They can have a seriously good time or just be very laid back and sit round the barbecue. You don't feel any pressure.

My advice: The real problem is the travelling. I've always gone for two months at least, and because I'm working with Australians they tell me where to go. You can't do it in a week. To fly for 23 hours and then spend a week somewhere is impossible - you are just too tired. So you should go for long enough to allow for a few days relaxing to get over the jet lag - just sit and look out over the Indian Ocean. When you're feeling rested, go exploring.

How to get there: Qantas (www.qantas.com, 0845 774 7767) flies from Heathrow to Perth via Singapore for around £670 return.

 Reminder, by Dennis Waterman is published by Random House at £16.99.

webTitle: Leader: Peace in Ulster endangered again

fields.headline: High noon in Ulster
fields.standfirst: Peace is on the line - again
fields.trailText: Another Saturday, another high noon for Ulster unionism. Once again the party's 860-member ruling council is gearing up for a round of civil war, with the two camps squaring off in what promises to be yet another nailbiting vote. Once again, the choice David Trimble has put before his council members is "back me or sack me". Once again, the peace process is said to hang by a thread.
fields.body:
Another Saturday, another high noon for Ulster unionism. Once again the party's 860-member ruling council is gearing up for a round of civil war, with the two camps squaring off in what promises to be yet another nailbiting vote. Once again, the choice David Trimble has put before his council members is "back me or sack me". Once again, the peace process is said to hang by a thread.

One could forgive the people of the province if they were getting slightly sick of this never ending saga: unionism on the Edge of a Nervous Breakdown. At the very least they must be suffering an acute case of déjà vu. The protagonists are the same: peacemaker Trimble against hardliner Jeffrey Donaldson. The issue is the same: the decommissioning of IRA guns. And the underlying choice is the same: to proceed with the Good Friday agreement, hard though that is, or to let it die.

There are a couple of differences this time and they are both positive. First, Mr Trimble enters Belfast's Waterfront Hall taller than before. He can claim strength from yesterday's Belfast Telegraph poll which found 68% of the UUP's own voters backing Mr Trimble's belief that the party should stay in Northern Ireland's executive - compared to just 27% who favour Mr Donaldson's talk of an early exit. Almost 60% of Ulster unionist voters still regard Mr Trimble as the best person to lead the party, beating Mr Donaldson by two to one. Of course, Ulster Unionist council members are more militant than regular voters, but yesterday's poll may well cool their ardour: they will surely not want to become too far out of step with their own constituents.

The second boost comes from Mr Trimble's own handling of the current crisis. Rather than seek yet another backroom stitch-up, one which might delay the inevitable showdown, the leader has clearly decided to take Mr Donaldson on. By attacking the latter's demand for decommissioning to happen before a November 30 deadline as "Jeffrey's letter to Santa", he has at last come out fighting. This will delight those supporters who have long believed that Mr Trimble has a good case - he needs only to argue it.

On the current point of dispute, he clearly has the better of his rival. The leader is quite right that deadlines for disarmament have proven to be counterproductive, casting unionists, not republicans, as the block on the peace process. He is right, too, that by adopting a hard line, unionists would end up with the worst of both worlds - certainly no decommissioning, but no assembly or executive either. Finally, as Neil Kinnock, Margaret Thatcher or Tony Blair would all testify, the party leader who confronts his or her internal critics always comes off looking stronger. Mr Trimble appeared weak when he tolerated Mr Donaldson's breathtaking disloyalty. By attacking the anti camp's "constant warfare" on the leadership, Mr Trimble should have increased his own respect.

Still, the Ulster Unionist council is a large, unwieldy, unpredictable body. They may not be cowed into submission by the new, bullish tactics of the leader. Some of them could react against Peter Mandelson's recent warning that, if the agreement collapses, there will be more, not less, Dublin involvement in the running of Northern Ireland's affairs. That prospect scares unionists, but they may regard the secretary of state's mention of it as blackmail - voting to collapse the agreement just to spite him. So Mr Trimble needs to navigate carefully through the Waterfront Hall today. But he should gain strength from the knowledge that he has both his own constituency - and right - on his side.

fields.headline: Gemini macpac
fields.trailText: It has zips on both sides that can lock at the top, a compartment that tucks in at the bottom, and a detachable 15-litre day pack.
fields.body:
This may look the bee's knees, but am I going to be digging around for socks at the bottom?
No, it has zips on both sides that can lock at the top, a compartment that tucks in at the bottom, and a detachable 15-litre day pack.

What else is special?
A padded top and side handles and a padded shoulder strap for hauling it onto conveyor belts, tuk-tuks or ox carts, and the day pack's got a zip organiser. It's waterproof, has 85 litres capacity, weighs 2.9kg and costs £199.95.

But is it comfy?
Unlike most backpacks, this has a choice of harness, including different sizes for women and an adjustable hip strap so you can tailor it to fit your back exactly.

Where do you find it?
It's a New Zealand export, but until recently it's been hard to find in the UK. Try Trekkitt Mountain Sports 01600 715777, Trekmate 020-7836 8818, Cotswold Outdoor 020-8743 2976 or Snow+Rock 0845 100 1000.
