fields.headline: The mark of Zoroaster
fields.standfirst: Author  Paul Kriwaczek and his guide to how to brave fearsome traffic, cheap hotels and a tight 10-day schedule aboard a clapped-out Fiat in a search for the heart of a 2,500-year-old civilisation
fields.trailText: Author Paul Kriwaczek gives a guide to how to brave fearsome traffic, cheap hotels and a tight 10-day schedule aboard a clapped-out Fiat in a search for the heart of a 2,500-year-old civilisation.
fields.body:
The notice by the museum entrance said: "Iranians 500 tumans, Foreigners 5,000." Ali, my guide, interpreter and general fixer was asking the unshaven attendant in the kiosk for tickets.

"One Iranian and one foreigner."

The official looked puzzled. "Where's the foreigner?"

Ali pointed to me.

"Oh, I thought that was your Iranian grandfather."

I was wondering whether to be offended by the insult - surely I don't look ancient and decrepit enough to be the grandfather of an overweight 26-year-old - when the ticket-seller addressed me in such fast colloquial Persian that, though my command of the language is better than it has any right to be after 30 years of disuse, I couldn't quite catch his drift. Before I could stop myself, I had cupped my hand to my ear and, in the quavering, piping voice of an old, deaf and stupid grandfather, was asking: "What? What?"

"You ... are ... welcome ... Sir," the man said very slowly, loudly and patronisingly. "May ... you ... never ... be ... weary!" It's a common enough Persian greeting, but he seemed to me to say it more pointedly than necessary. I consoled myself with the thought that I had saved myself 4,500 tumans (about $25) . Over the next 10 days, as we toured the country in Ali's clapped-out Fiat, playing the Iranian grandfather was to save me a lot more money, as well as getting me into the kind of cheap lodging-house that wasn't willing to take foreigners. This was lucky, since I was visiting the country at a time of year when most decent hotels are full.

Having come to Iran to look at pre-Islamic sites for a book about the ancient Persian prophet Zoroaster, I particularly wanted to witness the Persian New Year celebrations, still strongly Zoroastrian in tone in spite of nearly 1,300 years of Islam. This is the most popular holiday of the Iranian year and the Lonely Planet Guide suggested that it was not the best time for a visit: "You should seriously consider avoiding Iran altogether for about 10 days before and after Noruz, the chaotic Iranian New Year, which starts on or about 21st March."

Ignoring this advice, my plan was to spend 10 days driving in a great circle around the country. Iran is a difficult country to travel in. Neither trains nor planes seem to serve the most sought-after destinations, and I had no idea of the condition of the roads. It was going to be touch and go whether I would make it back to Tehran in time for my return flight and my daughter's birthday back home.

The start was inauspicious. Daylight-saving time began the day I arrived, and I dutifully set my watch forward. The next morning we were to set off at six, but Ali was more than an hour late. He laughed when I pointed to the clock on the hotel lobby wall. "We don't work for the government," he protested. "And the Mullahs don't control the sun."

Nor, it seems, the roads. After two hours' playing dodgem through Tehran's insane morning traffic I was genuinely relieved to find myself still alive. No self-respecting Iranian driver will forego overtaking just because another vehicle is coming the other way. Two lanes are expected to accommodate three cars, or even trucks, abreast, even if it means scraping through, hooting like mad, with only inches to spare on either side.

Starting out, you can't help holding your breath and gripping the seat, white knuckled, at the hairiest moments. But there is a limit to the number of times you can brace yourself for certain death. In the end you learn to say, with the Iranians, Masha'allah: whatever God wills.

Our first, 500-mile drive south through the rolling desert took us to the oasis city of Yazd, with its unique skyline of tall wind towers, designed to catch any faint breaths of breeze and funnel them down into secret retreats at the heart of the huddle of mud-brick houses. We spent the next day visiting Yazd's spectacular mosques, its prison attributed to Alexander the Great and its Zoroastrian fire-temple, packed during Noruz with Iranian tourists craning to catch a sight, through the protective glass, of the sacred fire which has been burning continuously since AD 470, though not in this same place.

A few years ago after a great windstorm, Yazdis were amazed to see the top of a dome peek out of the sand just outside town. Much digging exposed an entire buried village, perfectly preserved, complete with a fire-temple of its own. During our visit, a local family party arrived. The father, who seemed to have insider knowledge, was lecturing his wife and daughter about Zoroastrian beliefs in the wildly theatrical style Iranians use when reciting verse - drawling out the long vowels as if eating them, peppering each sentence with sudden loud phrases or unexpectedly ... slowing ... right ... down. I whispered to Ali that this must surely be a schoolteacher by trade. The man heard me and turned on us.

"Were you speaking English?"

Ali confessed. The man pointed at me.

"Is he British? Because there are some things that should not be spoken in front of some people."

"Well," Ali told him, "he carries a British passport, but his family came from Czechoslovakia and he himself was born in Vienna."

The schoolteacher looked at me a little more benignly. "Then his sins are diminished."

Afterwards I said to Ali "I thought it was the Americans who were the Great Satan."

"Oh no," he explained, "Iranians believe that the Americans are good people at heart but innocent and naïve. It is always the British who command them to do bad things."

The first threat to our tight schedule came on my third Iranian night. All hotels in Yazd being full, we were sleeping on the living room floor of a local man's basement flat. Generously hospitable like all Iranians, he brought out a hookah and a brace of bottles of wine for his guests.

"Alcohol? Isn't that against the law?"

"I don't drink it for enjoyment, only for health," he emphasised, as if that made all the difference. "Anyway, it's not made from grapes, but from pomegranates and honey." The first taste confirmed that nobody could drink it for enjoyment.

The resulting hangovers delayed our next day's departure south over the mountains until noon, so that it was too dark to see anything by the time we reached Cyrus the Great's tomb at Pasagard and the spectacular remains of Persepolis, the summer capital founded by Darius and burned by Alexander. My executive decision was to press on to Shiraz and return again very early the next morning.

Even at 10 o'clock, Shiraz, elegant city of palaces, poets and perfumed gardens, was like a madhouse. All of Iran seemed to have congregated there for Noruz. Festive crowds pressed along the decorated streets, while gaily-dressed wedding parties, the women's black chadors barely concealing their finery, crammed on to the backs of lorries and paraded through the city centre, shouting and hooting and blaring raucous wind instruments.

After two hours of fruitless driving around to find a vacant hotel room, Ali regretfully conceded that we would have to make do with a common lodging house. He found the Heavenly Guesthouse near the central glittering Sayyed Mir Ahmad shrine but came out looking gloomy.

"You won't like it," he said.

I didn't. The tiny room, with space only for a double bed and a washbasin, was so filthy that Ali suggested we avoid undressing. The smell of urine forced us to leave the window open, and rowdy wedding parades outside kept us awake till three. It was no hardship to be up again and ready to leave town at five.

Lost time was impossible to make up, however. Though we were back shortly after seven at Cyrus's movingly simple and dignified tomb, the entrance gates to the site were locked and, in spite of my offer of money and Ali's improbable claims of high political influence, a dishevelled and bad-tempered official refused us admission for nearly two hours.

Late that night, we were 200 miles behind schedule when exhaustion forced us to stop in a small town on the road, at a guest house which proved to be, if anything, even more awful than the one in Shiraz.

In the morning I asked Ali the name of the place. "I want to be sure never to come here again."

"Beh-behan," he said. "Literally, it means 'Used-to-be-better'."

Driving on that night into the hours of darkness turned our careering descent to the oilfields of Mesopotamia into an awesome light show. Gigantic gas flares sprang from the ground on all sides, painting the entire sky a flickering rose red, as if we were entering the gates of Hell. It was almost a surprise to arrive unscathed in the cool modern urbanity of the great oil town of Ahwaz.

Next day, it was an even greater surprise to be thoroughly frisked on leaving the slick shopping mall by the banks of the Karun river, though Ali took the indignity for granted. "Otherwise people would steal things," he said.

But even Ali was taken aback when the best hotel in town refused to change my dollars at a respectable rate, on the grounds that some of them were more than a year old. The cashier claimed to be worried. "Perhaps they are not valid any more."

I suggested that the day that two-year-old dollar bills went out of date, the world economy might as well close down. "Why?" he asked. "Here we change our money all the time."

By the time we had reached the nine o'clock position in our 360 degree circumnavigation of the country, we were falling ever more behind schedule. We had to press on far into the night to reach Shush, the site of Susa, one of oldest and longest-lasting of ancient Iran's cities - and one that took the brunt of the enemy onslaught during the Iran-Iraq war. The dusty hill of ruins which was once the biblical Shushan stands opposite the supposed tomb of the Prophet Daniel, the forecourt of which - for the benefit, I suppose, of Jewish pilgrims - is daubed with a huge savage mural, in uncannily Belfast-like style, showing heroic Muslims capturing Jerusalem. Close by is a gruesome blood-and-guts exhibition memorialising the martyrs to Saddam Hussein.

Leaving the ancient mound, I was so affected by this combination of ruthlessness and horror that I quite forgot my Iranian grandfather role - until three angry men came running up to stop us in the street. Too late, I realised that I had been speaking English.

"You didn't say you were with a foreigner when you bought tickets," their spokesman accused Ali aggressively.

"You didn't ask."

"Foreigners must pay 10,000 tumans."

Ali was squaring up for an argument. "There is no sign that says so."

Ali did, but with ill grace. "It's $57. You know the money will go straight into their pockets."

The check-in clerk looked sombre. "I am sorry," he said. "Your flight is being diverted via Baku. You are going to miss your connection to London. The airline will pay for your overnight hotel in Dubai."

I protested, of course. But this time there was absolutely nothing I could do.

You can apply for a tourist visa at the Iranian consulate in London (Kensington Court, London W8, tel: 020-7937 5225), for a non-returnable fee of £40. You may be asked for a sponsor in Iran. Iran Air (020-7409 0971) flies Heathrow to Tehran from £380 return. British Airways (0345 222111) flies Heathrow to Tehran from £559 return. Cox and Kings (020-7873 5000, www.coxandkings.co.uk) organises a 10-night Treasures of Persia tour for £1,495.

It's definitely worth calling in at the BA travel health centre in Regent Street (London W1). For a reasonable fee, they will provide all necessary jabs as well as give you a computer printout detailing the latest health news and Foreign Office travel advice.

Ali, my guide, interpreter and general fixer was asking the unshaven attendant in the kiosk for tickets. "One Iranian and one foreigner." The official looked puzzled. "Where's the foreigner?" Ali pointed to me. "Oh, I thought that was your Iranian grandfather." I was wondering whether to be offended by the insult - surely I don't look ancient and decrepit enough to be the grandfather of an overweight 26-year-old - when the ticket-seller addressed me in such fast colloquial Persian that, though my command of the language is better than it has any right to be after 30 years of disuse, I couldn't quite catch his drift. Before I could stop myself, I had cupped my hand to my ear and, in the quavering, piping voice of an old, deaf and stupid grandfather, was asking: "What? What?" "You ... are ... welcome ... Sir," the man said very slowly, loudly and patronisingly. "May ... you ... never ... be ... weary!" It's a common enough Persian greeting, but he seemed to me to say it more pointedly than necessary. I consoled myself with the thought that I had saved myself 4,500 tumans (about $25) . Over the next 10 days, as we toured the country in Ali's clapped-out Fiat, playing the Iranian grandfather was to save me a lot more money, as well as getting me into the kind of cheap lodging-house that wasn't willing to take foreigners. This was lucky, since I was visiting the country at a time of year when most decent hotels are full. Having come to Iran to look at pre-Islamic sites for a book about the ancient Persian prophet Zoroaster, I particularly wanted to witness the Persian New Year celebrations, still strongly Zoroastrian in tone in spite of nearly 1,300 years of Islam. This is the most popular holiday of the Iranian year and the Lonely Planet Guide suggested that it was not the best time for a visit: "You should seriously consider avoiding Iran altogether for about 10 days before and after Noruz, the chaotic Iranian New Year, which starts on or about 21st March." Neither trains nor planes seem to serve the most sought-after destinations, and I had no idea of the condition of the roads. Daylight-saving time began the day I arrived, and I dutifully set my watch forward. The next morning we were to set off at six, but Ali was more than an hour late. In the end you learn to say, with the Iranians, Masha'allah: whatever God wills. Our first, 500-mile drive south through the rolling desert took us to the oasis city of Yazd, with its unique skyline of tall wind towers, designed to catch any faint breaths of breeze and funnel them down into secret retreats at the heart of the huddle of mud-brick houses. We spent the next day visiting Yazd's spectacular mosques, its prison attributed to Alexander the Great and its Zoroastrian fire-temple, packed during Noruz with Iranian tourists craning to catch a sight, through the protective glass, of the sacred fire which has been burning continuously since AD 470, though not in this same place. A few years ago after a great windstorm, Yazdis were amazed to see the top of a dome peek out of the sand just outside town. Much digging exposed an entire buried village, perfectly preserved, complete with a fire-temple of its own. During our visit, a local family party arrived. The father, who seemed to have insider knowledge, was lecturing his wife and daughter about Zoroastrian beliefs in the wildly theatrical style Iranians use when reciting verse - drawling out the long vowels as if eating them, peppering each sentence with sudden loud phrases or unexpectedly ... slowing ... right ... down. I whispered to Ali that this must surely be a schoolteacher by trade. The man heard me and turned on us. "Were you speaking English?" Ali confessed. The man pointed at me. "Is he British? "Well," Ali told him, "he carries a British passport, but his family came from Czechoslovakia and he himself was born in Vienna." The schoolteacher looked at me a little more benignly. "Then his sins are diminished." Afterwards I said to Ali "I thought it was the Americans who were the Great Satan." "Oh no," he explained, "Iranians believe that the Americans are good people at heart but innocent and naïve. It is always the British who command them to do bad things." The first threat to our tight schedule came on my third Iranian night. All hotels in Yazd being full, we were sleeping on the living room floor of a local man's basement flat. Generously hospitable like all Iranians, he brought out a hookah and a brace of bottles of wine for his guests. "Alcohol? Isn't that against the law?" "I don't drink it for enjoyment, only for health," he emphasised, as if that made all the difference. "Anyway, it's not made from grapes, but from pomegranates and honey." The first taste confirmed that nobody could drink it for enjoyment. The resulting hangovers delayed our next day's departure south over the mountains until noon, so that it was too dark to see anything by the time we reached Cyrus the Great's tomb at Pasagard and the spectacular remains of Persepolis, the summer capital founded by Darius and burned by Alexander. My executive decision was to press on to Shiraz and return again very early the next morning. Even at 10 o'clock, Shiraz, elegant city of palaces, poets and perfumed gardens, was like a madhouse. Gigantic gas flares sprang from the ground on all sides, painting the entire sky a flickering rose red, as if we were entering the gates of Hell. It was almost a surprise to arrive unscathed in the cool modern urbanity of the great oil town of Ahwaz. Next day, it was an even greater surprise to be thoroughly frisked on leaving the slick shopping mall by the banks of the Karun river, though Ali took the indignity for granted. "Otherwise people would steal things," he said. But even Ali was taken aback when the best hotel in town refused to change my dollars at a respectable rate, on the grounds that some of them were more than a year old. The cashier claimed to be worried. "Perhaps they are not valid any more." I suggested that the day that two-year-old dollar bills went out of date, the world economy might as well close down. fields.headline: In your dreams
fields.standfirst: No TV, no radio and out of the range of mobile phones,  Harriet Sherwood finds herself in splendid isolation just south of the equator
fields.trailText: No TV, no radio and out of the range of mobile phones, Harriet Sherwood finds herself in splendid isolation just south of the equator.
fields.body:
It's 6.45am, and there's a gentle tapping on the door. You might be on holiday, but on Denis Island in the Seychelles it's time to get up and go fishing.

On the beach, a dozen yards from the veranda, is Mayjoe, impatient in his Aston Villa shorts. He and the skipper, Etienne, have a lot of fish to catch and they want to get going before the pearly morning light is consumed by the heat of the tropical sun.

Three miles from shore, Etienne cuts the engine and Mayjoe helps set up the lines. A weight and five baited hooks are attached to a fine nylon rope. It's tossed overboard, unravelling to a depth of 50m, and secured in your hand. You sit back and wait for a tug on your forefinger. This comes soon and it comes often: fishing in the Indian ocean does not require a huge amount of skill. Bonito, red snapper, parrot fish, capitaine blanc, job fish, groupier, the occasional baby shark - they're all delicious and waiting to be caught. At the end of the day, there is an absurd sense of pride in seeing your fish served for dinner.

Denis Island relies on the well-stocked sea surrounding its 2 sq kms to feed its guests. Privately owned, there is nothing on the island apart from the lodge and a farm which supplies it with pork, chickens, eggs, vegetables and fruit. Everything else comes from the sea or is flown in on the 20-seater plane which lands on the 900m grass airstrip four times a week.

It is precisely this remoteness that makes Denis so special. Three degrees south of the equator and 95km from Mahe, the main island of the Seychelles, the coral atoll is the kind of place you dream of on a dreary October afternoon stuck at your desk. As the plane approaches, you can see from your window a crescent of lush green, bordered by blindingly white sand, ringed by turquoise water skimming over coral, set in the deep blue ocean. The island is rich in vegetation and, like all the Seychelles, a haven for birds.

Touchdown on the grass airstrip - used most of the time for either grazing cattle or practising golf shots - is not for the fainthearted, but once on the ground you are reassured by the friendly greeting of Denis's staff and the offer of cold towels and fresh fruit juice.

The lodge - 10 minutes walk from the airstrip - prides itself on informality, urging its guests to make themselves at home. Several things mark it out from a conventional hotel: principally the feeling that the whole island is yours for the duration of your stay. There are no locks on the doors of the 25 "cottages" scattered among the trees along the beaches - there is no need, according to the lodge, as the island's resident population of about 40 all work either at the hotel or the farm. There are no televisions, radios or phones in the rooms, and the island is just out of range for the use of mobiles. Messages from the outside world can get through, but most people don't want to be disturbed.

Richard, the Welsh barman at the lodge, had been on Denis for four weeks, having escaped from a pub in Aldershot by tracking down and securing his desert island dream on the internet. "The world could be ablaze and I'd know nothing about it," he said. He spends his freetime swimming and snorkelling.

The lodge operates only on a full-board basis - there is nowhere else to eat on the island. Breakfast and lunch are both buffets, with guests often eating barefoot. Dinner is less casual, although unlike many exclusive hotels there is no obligation to dress up. There is always a choice of three main courses including a meat option, and the food is fabulous: vodka-cured tuna; fish baked in spicy creole sauce; octopus and coconut curry, exotic fruits and home-baked bread.

Drinks are added to your bill, and you could end up with a reasonably hefty charge at the end of your stay depending on your taste: beers are cheap, cocktails expensive. But, apart from drinks, scuba-diving and deep-sea fishing, there is literally nothing on the island to spend money on. The lodge has a tiny shop, selling trin kets and a few essentials; there are shelves of books in the bar for guests to borrow; billiards, table-tennis, backgammon and chess-sets are available for those who have not quite reached the empty-minded, staring-out-to-sea, completely-chilled condition that is what Denis is really all about.

Once you have reached that state, the best place to be is on the beach. If the stretch of brilliant sand in front of your cottage is not deserted enough, you can easily find a real Robinson Crusoe experience elsewhere on the island. It takes about two hours to walk round Denis, and for most of that time you will be entirely alone among the crabs and driftwood. Take some flippers and a snorkel, and you can spend hours floating face down in the warm sea gazing at fluorescent fish darting in and out of the coral.

The cottages are generously spaced and roomy. Each has a large veranda facing the sea, a sitting area and a big bathroom with disturbing floor-to-ceiling windows and glass door leading to a tiny walled courtyard with an outdoor shower to rinse off the sand.

The average stay on Denis is nine nights, although one emotional entry in the visitors' book recorded a four-month stay. Right up until the last possible minute, you can bury your toes in the warm sand on the beach or sip an ice-cold beer at the bar. When you hear the plane's engines overhead, it's time to walk down to the airstrip to say your reluctant goodbyes.

Luxury is readily available in the Seychelles, but comes in different forms. Denis is understated and casual; the five-star Lemuria Resort on another island, Praslin, which opened earlier this year, is sophisticated and elegant. Once behind its tall gates, you need never leave. Built into granite boulders, the hotel centres round a spectacular three-level pool, and houses a golf course, spa and treatment centre, tennis courts and children's centre.

One of the loveliest beaches in the Seychelles, Anse Georgette, can be reached only by boat or through the hotel grounds. Georgette and a neighbouring beach, Anse Lazio, voted by German tourists as the most beautiful in the world, are exactly like your favourite fantasy: coconut palms bending low over pristine sands, warm crystal water, a few footprints to show you are not entirely alone.

P raslin is the second largest of the Seychelles islands with about 6,000 inhabitants. Beaches and watersports aside, there is little to do or see.

At the heart of the island is the Vallée de Mai, a living remnant of prehistoric forest, now a World Heritage Site and protected by the Seychelles Islands Foundation. It is the home of the Coco de Mer, a palm which for many years was thought to grow under the sea until it was discovered here. The trees reach 30m, and produce the largest seed in the world, weighing up to 20kg.

The valley is also the home to the black parrot, only found on Praslin. Entrance to the site is about £5.50, and for the same price you can hire a private guide to point out and explain the extraordinary palms, plants, birds, lizards and spiders.

Back at the hotel, there are endless permutations of eating and drinking. Three excellent restaurants, including one situated on the beach; extensive room service; sandwiches and drinks can be brought to you by the pool. Apart from breakfast,everything - including drinking water, which is only available from the mini-bar in the room - is added to your final bill.

The service is discreet and efficient. At about 6.30pm, just as darkness is about to drop like a heavy curtain, a man glides into your elegantly-decorated and enormous room, bearing a flute of champagne and a single canapé on a porcelain plate. You take it out onto your terrace or balcony, feeling the weight of the velvety tropical night in sharp contrast to the air-conditioned luxury of your room.

Maybe the meek will inherit the earth, but in the meantime paradise is yours if you can afford it.

The practicals

Harriet Sherwood travelled with Abercrombie & Kent/Air Seychelles. The package, from £2,388 per person based on two sharing, features four nights on Denis Island in a cottage on a full-board basis and four nights bed & breakfast in a Junior suite at Lemuria Resort on Praslin. Abercrombie & Kent 0845 0700611, www.abercrombiekent.co.uk. Air Seychelles (01293 596 656) flies two times a week from Gatwick.

Georgette and a neighbouring beach, Anse Lazio, voted by German tourists as the most beautiful in the world, are exactly like your favourite fantasy: coconut palms bending low over pristine sands, warm crystal water, a few footprints to show you are not entirely alone. P raslin is the second largest of the Seychelles islands with about 6,000 inhabitants. Beaches and watersports aside, there is little to do or see. At the heart of the island is the Vallée de Mai, a living remnant of prehistoric forest, now a World Heritage Site and protected by the Seychelles Islands Foundation. It is the home of the Coco de Mer, a palm which for many years was thought to grow under the sea until it was discovered here. The trees reach 30m, and produce the largest seed in the world, weighing up to 20kg. The valley is also the home to the black parrot, only found on Praslin. Entrance to the site is about £5.50, and for the same price you can hire a private guide to point out and explain the extraordinary palms, plants, birds, lizards and spiders. Back at the hotel, there are endless permutations of eating and drinking. Three excellent restaurants, including one situated on the beach; extensive room service; sandwiches and drinks can be brought to you by the pool. Apart from breakfast,everything - including drinking water, which is only available from the mini-bar in the room - is added to your final bill. The service is discreet and efficient. At about 6.30pm, just as darkness is about to drop like a heavy curtain, a man glides into your elegantly-decorated and enormous room, bearing a flute of champagne and a single canapé on a porcelain plate. You take it out onto your terrace or balcony, feeling the weight of the velvety tropical night in sharp contrast to the air-conditioned luxury of your room. Maybe the meek will inherit the earth, but in the meantime paradise is yours if you can afford it. The practicals Harriet Sherwood travelled with Abercrombie & Kent/Air Seychelles. The package, from £2,388 per person based on two sharing, features four nights on Denis Island in a cottage on a full-board basis and four nights bed & breakfast in a Junior suite at Lemuria Resort on Praslin. Abercrombie & Kent 0845 0700611, www.abercrombiekent.co.uk. Air Seychelles (01293 596 656) flies two times a week from Gatwick.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Flood alert

Frantic work is going on in the Aosta Valley region of northern Italy, where a state of emergency was declared following the floods earlier this month. The local tourism minister, Claudio Lavoyer, said the priority was to restore normal transport services and guarantee that the forthcoming winter season will not be affected. The area includes the resorts of Courmayeur and Cervinia.

A real buzz

A new theme park has opened in France, devoted to the life of insects. Micropolis is in Saint-Léon-en Lévezou, near Rodez in the Aveyron region in southern France. The town is the home of the famous French entomologist Jean-Henri Fabre. Adults Ffr53, children Ffr37. Tel: 00 33 565585050 (www.micropolis-cite-des-insectes.tm.fr).

Welcome change

Change for Good, the donation of foreign currency on board British Airways' flights, has raised in excess of £10m for Unicef projects worldwide since it started in April 1994, it was announced this week. The average donation is £1.80.

Hot spots

An estimated 3m people are set to go abroad for some winter sunshine this year. Thomas Cook predicts that the top 10 places will be: 1, Canary Islands; 2, United States; 3, Spain; 4, Caribbean; 5, Cyprus; 6, Indian Ocean; ==7, Portugal/Balearic Islands; 9, Far East; =10 Tunisia/Morocco.

National treasure

A guide for visitors to Hadrian's Wall during the winter has been produced. The guide, covering the period until May 26, will be available from all Tourist Information Centres and National Park Visitor Centres in the area, or call Hadrian's Wall Information line 01434 322002.

Sleep easy

A new edition of Bed and Breakfast for Garden Lovers, listing 103 B&Bs has been published. To obtain it send six loose first-class stamps to BBGL, Handywater Farm, Sibford Gower, Banbury, Oxfordshire OX15 5AE (www.bbgl.co.uk).

Lost and found

Atlantic, the suitcase manufacturer, has teamed up with the Yellowtag lost-property retrieval service to offer a free yellowtag.com individual e-mail address with every piece of luggage sold in November and December. Information on Atlantic stockists in the UK, 01462 832000.

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: First impressions
fields.body:
First impressions

A major exhibition taking a look at the techniques behind impression, including paintings by Manet, Monet, Renoir, Van Gogh and more.

Nov 1-Jan 28 2001. Daily 10am-6pm, Wed until 9pm. £7/£5. The National Gallery, Trafalgar Square, London (020-7747 2885).

Welsh wizardry

Showcase Wales features work by artists from the principality, from 1900 to the present day; take your cheque book as many exhibits are for sale.

Free.10am-2pm except Sun. The Museum of Modern Art, Heol Penrallt, Machynlleth, Powys (01654 703355).

Ghostly goings-on

Discover the spooky stories behind the 12th-century Augustinian abbey; try and catch a glance of the lavatory-emptying monk and his barrow load of ghostly waste.

Nov 28, 29. 11am-noon and 2.30pm-3.30pm. £1.95/£1. Haughmond Abbey, Upton Magna, Uffington, Shropshire (01743 709 661).

Bed time

National Trust conservationists at the 19th-century property, Standen will be demonstrating how the priceless collection of rugs, furniture and William Morris wallpaper is cleaned and restored before the house is put to bed for the winter.

Nov 1-5. 2pm-5pm. £5. Standen, East Grinstead, West Sussex (01342 323 029).

Season's greeting

Watch the burning of a 24ft wicker effigy to banish the darkness and welcome the beginning of winter in a day of Celtic celebrations, including mask making, drumming and a feast of the dead.

October 29.10am-5pm. £5/£3/£14.50. Archaeolink, Prehistory Park, Oyne, Insch, Aberdeenshire (01464 851 500).

That's treason

Last chance to visit Chastleton House this year, the Jacobean house where Robert Catesby hatched the infamous Gunpowder Plot in 1605.

Oct 28. Access by timed ticket - call 01494 755572. £5.10/£2.55/£12.75. Chastleton House, Chastleton, Moreton-in-Marsh, Gloucestershire.

That's the spirit

Lady Suffolk and other costumed characters make a ghostly appearance this weekend to entertain visitors with spooky tales about nutcrack night, as Halloween was once known.

Oct 28-29, noon-3pm. £4/£2. Marble Hill House, Richmond Road, Twickenham, Middlesex (020- 8892 5115).

Light fantastic

An evening of drama, music, fireworks and food celebrating Diwali, the Hindu festival of light.

Nov 3.6pm-1am. £2.50. Queen Elizabeth Hall, West Street, Oldham, Greater Manchester (0161-911 4072).

webTitle: Euro rises as result of slowdown in US growth

fields.headline: Euro rises as result of slowdown in US growth
fields.trailText: Evidence of a dramatic slowdown in the US economy helped boost the euro on the foreign exchanges yesterday as dealers contemplated the end of record American expansion.
fields.body:
Evidence of a dramatic slowdown in the US economy helped boost the euro on the foreign exchanges yesterday as dealers contemplated the end of record American expansion.

The US economy grew at annual rate of 2.7% in the third quarter, the slowest pace for
more than a year and well below market expectations. In the second quarter the economy expanded by 5.6%.

Europe's beleaguered single currency jumped half a cent on the news, which provoked fears of a sharp end to the US economy's nine-year boom. The euro finished trading in London at 84.1 cents against
the dollar, up from 83.3 earlier, and its highest level for a week.

"The GDP figures played on the fears of a hard-landing scenario in the US," Marc Chandler at Deutsche Bank said, adding that it was still too early for the Fed to ease monetary policy.

Robust US growth has been blamed for the 30% fall in the
euro since its launch in January 1999. Investors have rushed to buy dollar-denominated assets in the expectation of better returns in US markets than in Europe.

Signs of a slowdown in the United States could prompt the end of the long dollar bull market, according to some analysts. But others were warned
that the third-quarter slowdown could be short lived.

"The headline figure suggests a steep deceleration, but if you look beneath the numbers there is some cause for caution. Consumption was actually stronger than in the previous quarter," said Mike Moran, an economist at Standard Chartered Bank in London.

webTitle: Fed breathes a sigh of relief

fields.headline: Fed breathes a sigh of relief
fields.standfirst: Notebook Lower US rates look unlikely
fields.trailText: Yesterday's third-quarter US GDP figures must come as a relief to the policymakers at the Federal Reserve. With a tight labour market and an annualised second-quarter figure of 5.6% the Fed was under pressure. Some argued its chairman Alan Greenspan was losing the touch that has elevated him to near legendary status. Others that he was allowing Opec to do the Fed's dirty work for it through an escalating oil price. Certainly, given the closeness of the presidential election, the Fed had little room for manoeuvre on interest rates.
fields.body:
Yesterday's third-quarter US GDP figures must come as a relief to the policymakers at the Federal Reserve. With a tight labour market and an annualised second-quarter figure of 5.6% the Fed was under pressure. Some argued its chairman Alan Greenspan was losing the touch that has elevated him to near legendary status. Others that he was allowing Opec to do the Fed's dirty work for it through an escalating oil price. Certainly, given the closeness of the presidential election, the Fed had little room for manoeuvre on interest rates.

In the event, yesterday's figure of 2.7% must have been as good as the Fed dared hope. It was undoubtedly a great deal better than Wall Street had been expecting. With the Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq now well below their overvalued peaks and evidence that the economy is slowing Mr Greenspan might claim to be viewed as a man who kept his nerve rather than one who had lost the plot.

Well, maybe. One swallow does not make a summer, nor one set of GDP figures a soft landing. Even within yesterday's numbers there is cause for concern. It is business, rather than the consumer, which is spending less. That 2.7% would look more benign if the emphasis was the other way round. And while US share prices have pulled back from earlier scary heights, recent volatility shows they could yet deliver a destabilising shock.

So far, so good, then, Mr Greenspan. But there is still a long way to go - far enough indeed to make yesterday's talk of lower US interest rates look singularly premature.

Time to decide

It has been the most delicious of ironies - a hostile bid for a stock exchange. But now day 46 has come and gone and with it OM's last chance to raise its offer for the London Stock Exchange. All that remains is for shareholders to choose and for the votes to be counted. It is too early to be certain but at this stage it looks as if OM has shot its bolt.

Many in the City have been impressed by the OM campaign. Sadly for the Swedes they may well have persuaded shareholders that more value can be wrung out of the exchange than either the incumbent management has yet achieved (not difficult) or that they themselves have put on the table. But if exchange shareholders do spurn the Swedish overtures - as they should - what then? The stock exchange has, finally, shown a degree of energy and robust thinking in its defence against OM.

What is clear is that if it does escape the bid it cannot rest on its laurels. The exchange needs a strategy to meet the demands of the big players in the equities game. That will mean, at the very least, new partners, new relationships. At the same time it needs to keep the smaller broker-shareholders on board. That is not impossible.

But the exchange will need to be more aware, more astute and more diplomatic than it has been in the past if it is to prevent a tranche of the membership turning luddite. Otherwise it may find another bidder on the doorstep or, worse still, that it turns into a wallflower at the bourses ball watching its business waltz away.

Clever lender

A top-of-the-cycle air is hanging over the mortgage market: house prices have topped out, the government is worried about "irresponsible lending" and lenders are getting cleverer. Maybe too clever.

Commonwealth Bank of Australia has joined the growing list of lenders offering "flexible" mortgages which allow homeowners to overpay or underpay their mortgages according to their personal circumstances.

These also present a seductive temptation: get into financial difficulties, and stop payments for a couple of months. Before long the mortgage is an overdraft facility.

Dangerous stuff given that total consumer debt has jumped by a quarter in the past three years; the savings ratio is at its lowest level since the Lawson boom. The likelihood of these new style loans being paid off early rather than late is low.

The sister product to flexible mortgages is all-in-one accounts - current account, mortgage, savings and credit card all wrapped into one. On paper they work fine but again the house becomes a cheque book.

Such schemes are highly popular in Australia - one in three Aussies run them - yet Commonwealth Bank is hesitant about bringing them to Britain although Barclays, Royal Bank of Scotland and other banks are known to be considering new launches shortly.

On Monday a government-ordered "debt summit" will take place. While this new market should not be choked off, it may be time to ensure lenders make clear the downside to these enticing products, and put in place controls to check that individuals do not use them to spiral further into debt.

webTitle: Billionaire peer continues to bankroll Tories

fields.headline: Billionaire peer continues to bankroll Tories
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Michael Ashcroft, the newly-enobled Conservative treasurer, gave his party another £1m last year, plus £390,000 worth of gifts in kind that included staff, marketing costs and the use of aircraft, Tory HQ revealed last night.
fields.body:
Michael Ashcroft, the newly-enobled Conservative treasurer, gave his party another £1m last year, plus £390,000 worth of gifts in kind that included staff, marketing costs and the use of aircraft, Tory HQ revealed last night.

The billionaire businessman, who recently relocated himself from Belize to Britain for tax purposes, remained the party's biggest private benefactor as William Hague's team struggles to rebuild their financial base after the 1997 election disaster.

In the year ending March 31 2000, the number of people donating more than £5,000 rose to 126, compared with 83 last year and 33 in 1998, but that statistic disguises the dominant position of a few major donors such as Lord Ashcroft, many of them grateful self-made entrepeneurs like Lord Harris of Peckham, the carpet tycoon.

Mr Hague's party is still £5m in debt - the same as last year but well down on the £19m peak after the election. Yet the party managed to trade at a slender £4,000 profit, much better than the £1.9m deficit a year earlier.

Unexpectedly the largest single source of the increased Tory income in the past year - up 36% from £9.8m to £13.4m - is what many Tory activists will regard as a far more disreputable one than the Ashcroft millions. It is the government, which sharply increased the financial aid given to opposition parties.

In the Tory case that amounted to £3.468m compared to £1.113m in 1999. So large is the sum that it may renew Labour backbench complaints that Mr Hague has located much of his leader's office at party HQ in Smith Square, 400 yards from the Palace of Westminster, in order to use public funds to shore up the party's structure. That is denied, and last night Labour's fire was again concentrated on Lord Ashcroft, who took his seat in the Lords last week after fullfilling the political honours scrutiny committee's condition that he repatriate his tax bill.

The Cabinet Office minister, Ian McCartney, said: "This is yet another reminder of the real sources and rewards of Tory funding. Under William Hague, the Tories' chief fund-raiser, chief donor, chief financial officer and treasurer are all the same person - Michael Ashcroft. His peerage will be a constant reminder of the lack of probity which has always surrounded Tory party funding."

Mr Ashcroft gave £766,000, almost exactly the same as last year, but turned a £250,000 loan into a gift - the remnant of a £2m loan which had also been converted this way. The billionaire businessman, who recently relocated himself from Belize to Britain for tax purposes, remained the party's biggest private benefactor as William Hague's team struggles to rebuild their financial base after the 1997 election disaster. In the year ending March 31 2000, the number of people donating more than £5,000 rose to 126, compared with 83 last year and 33 in 1998, but that statistic disguises the dominant position of a few major donors such as Lord Ashcroft, many of them grateful self-made entrepeneurs like Lord Harris of Peckham, the carpet tycoon. Mr Hague's party is still £5m in debt - the same as last year but well down on the £19m peak after the election. Yet the party managed to trade at a slender £4,000 profit, much better than the £1.9m deficit a year earlier. Unexpectedly the largest single source of the increased Tory income in the past year - up 36% from £9.8m to £13.4m - is what many Tory activists will regard as a far more disreputable one than the Ashcroft millions. It is the government, which sharply increased the financial aid given to opposition parties. In the Tory case that amounted to £3.468m compared to £1.113m in 1999. webTitle: Face to Faith: A two-minute guide to God

fields.headline: A two-minute guide to God
fields.trailText: The brief is for two minutes at the outside: and it must be topical. I make the half-hour drive to the local radio studio, arriving at 6.35 in the morning. My slot is at 6.45 and, passing through the empty city centre, I feel sure that this Topical Thought, which I am happy to do, remains in the schedule purely as a sop to the church lobby.
fields.body:
The brief is for two minutes at the outside: and it must be topical. I make the half-hour drive to the local radio studio, arriving at 6.35 in the morning. My slot is at 6.45 and, passing through the empty city centre, I feel sure that this Topical Thought, which I am happy to do, remains in the schedule purely as a sop to the church lobby.

To present something broadly religious at 6.45am is safe for the radio station because very few people are listening. But at midnight last night, I sat mouthing my 360 words to a stopwatch like a silent madman in a forgotten corner of a mental ward.

In the studio, I do my bit with all the energy I can muster. I have remembered that, to one listener, I am an intimate companion as they surface from the deep bliss of sleep. To another, I am a distant voice to accompany the morning thunder of the plumbing, or a watery burble as lather is scraped from a face. To others, I am a background to the crunch of cornflakes, or a noise in the car, droning on as they reverse into the road.

Some of my friends think I am mad to make this 36-mile drive for just two minutes on the wireless. A 6.45 slot certainly is marginalised - and what can you say in such a short time?

God does not get much of a profile on our local breakfast show but, up and down the country, the picture varies widely. Some stations still have a God slot every day; in others, the contribution is appreciated so much that it gets replayed later in the show. Whatever happens, I am also aware that even if only 500 people are listening, it is still far more than many clergy see on Sunday. And even at 6.45am, I am keeping the rumour of God alive on a weekday.

But what can I say in that significant 360 words? Nobody wants to hear a theological treatise or a sermon. But more will identify with my Christian perspective than any producer dares imagine. I cannot moralise or evangelise, and, in truth, I do not want to do either - although the station manager probably fears I might. Harassed managers, qualified to analyse listener figures and sum up the opposition, are often out of touch with the spiritual need of their constituents.

Equally, there will be those within the church ready to dismiss my efforts savagely with, "You'd think the Cross never happened" or "Why won't he just talk straight about sin and justification?"

The answer is that these short "thought" slots are still a gift to the church and other faith communities prepared to train people to deal with them properly. They are not given for use as free advertising space, for proselytism or idealistic propaganda. They must be used for one simple purpose: to make people think.

People of faith, be they Christian or of any other religious tradition, come to the business of life in ways coloured by their perceptions of God. They communicate best when they tell relevant stories full of human interest, stories about people and events which relate both to the reality of their listeners' lives and to the reality they know through their relationship with God.

It is hard to forget the more lurid comments of breakfast show producers following contributions from well-known Christians - usually along the lines of "God, that was so boring" - so a few pointers might be useful.

The Topical Thought must never bore. It must stimulate reflection: "Hey! I've not heard that angle before". It must reflect the gravitas of the day's news - offering a light touch, perhaps but never trivial. It must be satisfying to hear; first thing in the morning is no time for cleverness.

It must not sound as if it is only for "people in the know". Christian culture uses words like "sin" and "redemption", which only have meaning within the church. Even words like "peace" and "love" are often used in ways only meaningful to insiders. The Topical Thought must seek to identify with those who might be listening, but on their terms, not on mine.

To my mind, the early morning drive is worth the effort not because my words will suddenly transport anyone to the Damascus Road, although a process may start which could lead eventually to significant change in someone's life. It is bigger than that, and has a more far-reaching prophetic edge.

It is worth doing because it ensures that a tiny voice is heard crying in the wilderness of the airwaves that God is still a vital companion in everyday life for countless thousands of ordinary people.

Mark Rudall is development worker for the Oxford-based Churches Media Trust

fields.headline: Have exams got easier?
fields.standfirst: The topic is splashed across newspapers every August when the results come in. Have the questions become blander? Has the marking become more lax? Or could it even be that students are  brighter and better taught? As Lee Elliot-Major explains, that the standards debate isn't as simple as it is sometimes portrayed...
fields.trailText: The topic is splashed across newspapers every August when the results come in. Have the questions become blander? Has the marking become more lax? Or could it even be that students are brighter and better taught? As Lee Elliot-Major explains, that the standards debate isn't as simple as it is sometimes portrayed...
fields.body:
"Today's standards in basic education are lower than they were 55 years ago." No, not the latest swipe against rising numbers of top grades in GCSEs, A-levels or degrees. The complaint dates from 30 years ago. The then respected academic, Cyril Burt, set off a media frenzy with new research concluding that exam standards were not as good as they had been before the first world war. The 'research' was later found to have been fabricated.

Educational standards, it seems, have always been better in the past. National debates over falling standards are now an annual event. The twist on this year's coverage was girls outperforming boys at A-level, and the chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, attacking 'vacuous' university degrees as well as falling A-level standards. Studies will be commissioned. All will end inconclusively. The claims are impossible to prove one way or the other. The tragedy of this yearly obsession is that it obscures the real question that needs to be discussed: what knowledge, skills and values do we want to bequeath to our next generation? The answer shifts over time, reflecting how we change as a society. Education remains the stepping stone to better job and life prospects, placing it at the heart of political, economic and social debate. It is not a coincidence that all major legislative changes in education during the 20th century directly followed major wars (1902, 1918, 1944 and 1988) - times of re-evaluation and reflection. Education serves as a barometer of society's changing values; examinations serve as the fluctuations that reveal those changes.

What do exams in 1951, 1977 and 2000 tell us about how our lives have changed over the last half-century? We have become more socially inclusive, less authoritarian and more liberal-minded. We now allow the young to think and argue for themselves rather than adhere to accepted views. We let them apply knowledge rather than memorise it. Science and technology have transformed the world. And, at the dawn of the new millennium, the education system faces perhaps its toughest dilemma yet: is it still possible to transmit a core set of common values for the multicultural citizenry of the future?

Perhaps it is not surprising that exams have become more accessible. English educational reforms have attempted to replace a system originally intended for a ruling gentlemanly elite with a mass education system useful to all, irrespective of class, gender or race. In the collective days after the second world war, universal free secondary education was first introduced, based on three types of schools: grammar, secondary modern and technical. In 1951, ordinary and advanced levels and certificates for secondary education arrived, completing a system aimed to cater equally for those academically, vocationally and technically gifted. In the 1960s the Robbins report heralded the expansion of universities. Then came comprehensive schools for children of all academic abilities.

In the 1980s O-levels and CSEs were merged into the broader general certificate of secondary education (GCSE). Then came the Dearing decade, with three reports chaired by Sir Ron Dearing rationalising the new national curriculum for GCSEs, proposing broader A-level exams (not unlike the exams before 1951) and introducing tuition fees for university students. Education has been transformed. In 1955 just over one in 10 of 16-year-olds were at school; in 1975 four in 10; in 1995 seven in 10. In 1955 one in 25 school leavers went to university; in 1975 one in seven; in 1995 one in three. Demand for highly educated workers has increased with the move from manufacturing to service industries to a modern-day breed of companies, where ideas and knowledge are treasured as key commercial assets.

Exams over the last 50 years have reflected this rapid social change: they have become clearer, more structured; cover broader subject areas and abilities. A study comparing English, maths and chemistry GCSEs and A-levels in 1975 and 1995 by the School Curriculum and Assessment Authority suggested that: "standards shown by the majority of candidates have risen, because of the greater emphasis on breadth and the accessibility of questions, but they have fallen for the most able." Another study revealed broader, shallower coverage in maths degrees.

Wider social access has been accompanied by an empowerment of individual expression. The exams show that students are now encouraged much more to express their own views, backed up by argument, rather than accept a single world-view of events. In history A-level exams, you are now asked to justify interpretations of events, and deploy different historical methods to illuminate the past. In politics the emphasis has moved from government to politics. In GCSE geography, physical geography has given way to a greater focus on human and social issues. This new questioning spirit has been partly fuelled by advances in knowledge. Content of exams has inevitably changed, with views about which topics should be covered in a constant state of flux.

In 2000, biology A-level candidates were expected to know how genetic information is stored in DNA molecules. In 1951 the structure of DNA had yet to be unravelled. English literature A-level students were this year asked to assess Tom Stoppard's use of past and present in his play Arcadia. In 1977 students were asked to analyse the causes and consequences of the Cold War - hardly a question 1951 candidates might be expected to answer.

Technological advances have also left their mark. Calculators became commonplace in schools 20 years ago. These days the debate concerns whether degree students should be able to do exams on their computers, rather than using largely redundant pen and paper. Students are also now asked to apply knowledge rather than regurgitate it. Mathematical formulae are now listed in exam papers. In languages, more emphasis is placed on speaking, rather than just writing and translating. The same trends in schools are mirrored in higher education. The most popular degree subjects now were unheard of 50 years back: business studies, media studies and computing. When the 1997 Dearing review re-evaluated the aims of universities set out by the 1962 Robbins review, there were two major changes. Dearing placed more emphasis on the practical uses of degrees, and dropped altogether the earlier vow to transmit 'a common culture and common standards of citizenship'. Instead the report stated that academia should merely play a 'major role in shaping a democratic, civilised, inclusive society'. The onus has been placed on individual expression to such a degree that it is now felt impossible to preach a common framework of values.

All these changes render meaningless any attempt to assess how exam standards have changed over the last half-century. It is like comparing the football abilities of Stanley Matthews with David Beckham, or the musical prowess of Radiohead with the Beatles. These are irresistible, but ultimately unanswerable questions. The proportion of students securing top marks in GCSEs and A-levels has steadily risen. Exams and syllabuses have been transformed, becoming more transparent and accessible. A broader range of 16-year-olds now take A-levels, yet more are from the middle classes. University lecturers say standards are falling, yet degree results across all universities show the same proportional increases of graduates with top degrees.

In 2020 someone will be complaining about the fall in exam standards over the previous 20 years. But what values, knowledge and skills will our children be learning then? Will we be able finally to nurture both our academically and technically gifted offspring, and separate the academic elite from the social elite? In the world of individual empowerment, will there be any set of common values to speak of at all?

 Lee Elliot-Major is higher education editor of Guardian Unlimited

fields.headline: An extremely naff idea
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: Some of the headlines were harsh: "Pan's pet starved alone", "Drug MP's cat horror", and "Pan's pussy shock"
fields.body:
Saturday, October 21, Ashby-de-la-Zouch
Last week Pandora was climbing the rungs of the snakes and ladders of life. This week she is sliding down a python's back (so to speak). The papers today are full of pictures of her cat, Maurice, who had to be rescued by the RSPCA on Thursday night after neighbours heard piteous miaowing coming from Pandora's flat in Pimlico. Unfortunately, she was on a fact-finding mission with Keith Allen in Ayia Napa at the time of the cat's rescue. An RSPCA spokesperson said: "Dr Pandora Braithwaite may be charged with the neglect and cruelty of an animal. Maurice had not been fed for five days and was in an emaciated condition."

I phoned Pandora's mother, Tanya, for the inside story and she told me that Maurice's computerised feed-a-pet feeding bowl had developed a fault and had refused to open up and feed the ravenous beast. Some of the headlines were harsh: "Pan's pet starved alone", "Drug MP's cat horror", and "Pan's pussy shock".

In my role (unpaid) as Pandora's advisor on Middle England, I rang the House of Commons to offer my help. Unfortunately, she was not able to take my call as she was in emergency talks with Alastair Campbell. I left a message with her private secretary, Nigel Hetherington, "Tell her to make a large donation to the Cat Rescue Mission." Nigel said: "How very, very original. Thank you for your extremely naff idea, Moley."

It still rankles with me that Pandora chose Nigel to be her right-hand man rather than me. Okay, so he may have three degrees - in management, business and fashion - but I feel that he lacks a certain je ne sais quoi. I am extremely experienced when it comes to dealing with the media. In 1993, for five months I was the Ashby Bugle's poetry correspondent (unpaid) until the editor was sacked for gross subordination (throwing an empty vodka bottle at the proprietor). Unfortunately, the new editor was obsessed with sport and turned my weekly column into a Spot The Ball competition, to the detriment, in my opinion, of Ashby-de-la-Zouch's cultural landscape. William is not eating. I suspect he is seeking attention.

Sunday, October 22
Millbank released a photograph of Pandora and Maurice today together with a condemnation of computerised feeding bowls. Pandora is calling for an enquiry into their reliability. She has vowed to use a cat-sitter in future. When asked about her relationship with Keith Allen, she said: "Mr Allen and I were in Ayia Napa on a fact-finding mission. We were investigating the swamping of the British Consulate by penniless British youngsters demanding their airfare home.

Monday, October 23
The police in Nottingham are now strolling about in the city centre with guns. How long will it be before Ashby-de-la-Zouch rings to the sound of the Kalashnikov? Surely we are on a slippery slope.

Tuesday, October 24
Eddie rang today to complain that I haven't turned up for work. I explained about my childcare problems during half-term. He said: "I'm tryin' to run a bleedin' caff 'ere. I don't give a toss about yer private life, Mole." This is typical of Britain's and Eddie's attitude towards children. It's no wonder that three of Eddie's offspring are currently enjoying custodial sentences and that one, Shane, is dancing with the Royal Ballet. Glenn has begged to be in charge of cooking in future. I was happy to pass on the Mole apron. I hadn't realised that he was interested in the culinary arts.

Wednesday, October 25
William's appetite has picked up. Glenn has bought Jamie Oliver's Naked Chef book with the money he has made guarding the cars of the social workers visiting the estate.

fields.headline: Charles Rembar
fields.standfirst: Anti-censorship lawyer who won freedom for Lady Chatterley and Fanny Hill in America
fields.trailText: The lawyer Charles Rembar, who has died aged 85, won some of the most important censorship cases in America, defending the publishers of Lady Chatterley's Lover, Tropic Of Cancer and Fanny Hill. In each case, he argued that the artistic merit of the books outweighed any possible obscenity and should be protected by the first amendment of the US constitution.
fields.body:
The lawyer Charles Rembar, who has died aged 85, won some of the most important censorship cases in America, defending the publishers of Lady Chatterley's Lover, Tropic Of Cancer and Fanny Hill. In each case, he argued that the artistic merit of the books outweighed any possible obscenity and should be protected by the first amendment of the US constitution.

When he set up his practice in New York, after serving in the second world war, one of his first clients was his cousin, Norman Mailer, whose novel, The Naked And The Dead (1948), had its publishers worried about earthy expletives. Rembar suggested "fug" was a phonetically close, but legally safe, alternative.

Later, he became involved in a legal wrangle over another Mailer novel, The Deer Park (1955). It had been accepted for publication, and typeset, by Rinehart & Co, who then decided that it was unpublishable because it was obscene. They subsequently claimed that the obscenity of the book made the contract invalid. Rembar disagreed, and was willing to test his ideas in court. Faced with a potentially costly suit, Rinehart paid Mailer his contracted advance and let the book go to GP Putnam's Sons, where it became a bestseller.

The Lady Chatterley trials began in 1959 when Grove Press, always at the forefront of publishing contentious or avant-garde literature in America, produced an unexpurgated edition of DH Law- rence's novel, which was, at the time, banned in the US in all but a bowdlerised version.

Copies sold via the Readers Subscription Book Club were detained by the American postal authorities (which they were, arguably, entitled to do under the 19th-century Comstock Act). After arguing their case within the post office's own judiciary system - and losing - Rembar and Grove filed a suit against Robert Christenberry, the New York city postmaster. The New York courts found in favour of Grove Press, and an appeal brought by the federal government affirmed the decision. (In England, Penguin Books followed Grove's lead and, in 1960, successfully defended Lady Chatterley's honour in one of Britain's most celebrated court cases.)

In 1961, Grove was in even deeper trouble with Henry Miller's Tropic of Cancer. Rather than defending a single summons, the publishers found themselves helping to defend more than 60 cases brought against booksellers all across the US. Although not involved in any of the local cases, Rembar successfully argued two appeals, in Massachusetts and New Jersey. A suit bought against Miller, and a conspiracy charge against Grove Press and publisher Barney Rossett, was dropped before it got to court.

In 1965, Putnam's public- ation of John Cleland's Memoirs Of A Woman Of Pleasure, better known as Fanny Hill, saw Rembar defending the book all the way to the US supreme court. With the overturning of a temporary restraint against the book in New York, sales rocketed, but Rembar found himself on more uncertain ground when he tried to argue the literary merit of the book and its author's intent in writing it.

On publication, in the mid-18th century, Cleland, broke and facing debtor's prison, had written the novel and sold it outright for £20, which made any attempted defence that he had crafted the novel with serious literary intentions patently absurd. The eventual decision of the supreme court was six to three in the publisher's favour.

Rembar's book on these cases, optimistically titled The End Of Obscenity (1968), was a mixture of court testimony, history and sharp, sometimes amusing, asides into the history of American law. It won the George Polk Memorial Award for the best book of 1968. The New York Times reviewer wrote that Rembar had talked the US courts into "capsizing more than a century of court-blessed censorship."

Rembar himself was no mean writer, contributing to the Atlantic Monthly, New Republic and Esquire magazines. His collection of essays, Perspective, appeared in 1975, and, five years later, came a history of the evolving American legal system, The Law Of The Land.

In the latter, Rembar incisively explained the most complex laws, complaining that "for centuries, our lawyers, a priestly caste, used a mysterious tongue, composed of Latin, French, English, incantation and a bit of mumbling. These continue, more or less, to the present day - Latin less, English more, French absorbed, incantation down a bit, mumbling steady". He had a shrewd ear for a soundbite, none better than his claim that "pornography is in the groin of the beholder".

The son of a hotelier, Rembar was raised in New Jersey and educated at Harvard and Columbia University law school. Before the war, he worked for the New Deal agencies and the Office of Price Administration in Washington. As well as his work in court, he also represented many leading literary figures, including Mailer, Herman Wouk, Saul Steinberg and Tom Clancy.

Until he fell ill last July, Rembar continued to attend his New York practice every day. He is survived by his wife and two sons.

 Charles Remar, lawyer and author, born March 12 1915; died October 24 2000.

fields.headline: What's selling in audiobooks
fields.trailText: Should you be in need of some aural comforting, you could do worse than work your way down the top 10 audiobooks, a soothing blend of tried-and-tested radio comedy and undemanding fiction
fields.body:
Should you be in need of some aural comforting, you could do worse than work your way down the top 10 audiobooks, a soothing blend of tried-and-tested radio comedy and undemanding fiction. Indeed, the public's weakness for its favourite wireless stars extends to their forays into writing, with Terry Wogan's autobiography making an appearance halfway down the chart.

Those hoping for a critique of Corporation life might find themselves disappointed, but we certainly learn more about behind-the-scenes antics at Blankety Blank and on Wogan - more nostalgia. In a list dominated by the BBC, Simon Schama creeps in at number 10 by going rather further back. This is surely the acme of in-car self-improvement; Timothy West's fruity tones reciting 1066 and All That for grown-ups. The Beeb can only hope for a repeat of their big audio success, This Sceptred Isle.

Maeve Binchy, read by Kate Binchy

fields.headline: Behind the painted smile
fields.standfirst: Lesley Downer won the confidence of geishas in the Gion district of Kyoto and gained a rare insight into their history and influence
fields.trailText: Lesley Downer won the confidence of geishas in the Gion district of Kyoto and gained a rare insight into their history and influence
fields.body:
Geisha: girl power. Not a high-class prostitute, but a liberated woman. "Geisha never cook", was one of the more intriguing pieces of information I heard when I went to live in the geisha quarter of Kyoto. But I did not realise quite how far their refusal to set foot inside a kitchen extended until I made my first visit to a geisha house. (Geisha - meaning "arts people" or "entertainers" - live in an okiya. They carry out their nightly work, entertaining at banquets, in an ochaya, or teahouse.)

Haruta-san, the proprietress or "mother" of the house, was a big-hearted, straight-talking woman of 50 - utterly different from the simpering geisha of the western stereotype. She welcomed me in and offered me coffee, then settled down for a chat. I was still wondering when she was going to put the kettle on when the doorbell rang and a young man arrived from a nearby cafe, bearing two cups of steaming coffee on a tray.

The Kyoto geisha districts - of which the most famous is Gion - fulfil one's every fantasy of the mystery and enchantment of the geisha world. They are medieval thoroughfares, picturesque rabbit warrens of tiny alleys, too narrow for cars to pass through, lined with wooden geisha houses and teahouses. At dusk white lanterns begin to glow outside the doors of the teahouses, indicating that they are open for business. That is the time when one might spot a maiko ("dancing girl", or trainee geisha) or a geisha, flitting along like an apparition from another age.

The maiko are the most extraordinary. Their faces are painted eggshell white, their eyes lined in black, their mouths rosebuds of red. As they pass by, you notice that their ornate kimonos, primly wrapped at the front, are pulled down shockingly low at the rear to reveal a white-painted expanse of back. At the nape of the neck, the part of the body which Japanese men find most sexy, is a tantalising fork of bare skin, the shape of a serpent"s tongue, left unpainted.

Their world is enveloped in secrecy. Most Japanese have never seen a geisha and even fewer have ever managed to meet one. They are the confidantes of some of the country's most powerful politicos and businessmen, who need to be sure that whatever is said or done at a teahouse party remains strictly confidential. Added to which, an evening at a teahouse is liable to run to several thousand pounds. Even those who have the connections and budget to afford such entertainment still see only the geishas' public faces.

But I wanted to meet the real women behind the painted smile, to find out who they were and how they perceived their lives and their work. I had some advantages: I was not male, like their customers; and I was single and had experienced life in Japan as a single woman. I also had some idea of how to behave in the proper Japanese way - not pushy but restrained, quiet and eternally polite.

Eventually it all paid off. As we sat over our coffees in the kitchen of her geisha house, Haruta-san told me her story. She was born on the impoverished island of Kyushu to a wealthy landowner and a geisha. Her mother disappeared after her birth, and her father took her in. Tormented by his legitimate children, she ran away at 10 to find her mother, by then married and living in Osaka. But the mother was far from pleased. She beat her, bullied her, refused to let her go to school, then sold her to a hospital to work rinsing out filthy rags.

At the age of 12 Haruta tried to commit suicide. By 14, barely literate, she was working in a "cabaret" (a euphemism for a brothel) in Osaka. There she met a woman who suggested that she become a geisha. As a geisha, she was told, she would be provided for throughout her life.

The woman found a guarantor to give her an introduction to a geisha house. There she again found herself at the bottom of the heap. "In winter they wouldn't let me take a bath," she said. "I had to wash in freezing cold well-water. They wouldn't let me sit on tatami [woven straw] mats, they made me kneel on the hard wooden floor in the entrance hall. But I persevered. I put up with it all and eventually they realised they could trust me."

Many years and several lovers later, she inherited the keys to the house. When I met her she was a prosperous businesswoman, providing for and training two maiko and a geisha who lived with her.

The geisha world was Haruta's salvation. For many women of her generation, the geisha world offered a way of surviving and even, with luck, financial indepen dence. Modern-day geisha no longer have bad-luck stories. These days no one turns to the profession out of desperation, neither is anyone sold by their parents. But many young girls still wish to wear the white face and an ornate kimono as the embodiment of traditional femininity.

Harumi, one of the maiko to whom Haruta was "mother", was the epitome of geisha prettiness. She grew up in a village just outside Kyoto. Her father was a builder, her mother a taxi driver. "I wanted to be a geisha ever since I was a little girl," she told me. Like modelling, becoming a geisha is a career where beauty is all; class and qualifications count for nothing. At 13, Harumi left home and regular schooling to move into Haruta's house. When I met her she was 15, brimming with confidence, used to mixing with and being admired by business magnates, politicians, actors and rock stars; people who she could otherwise never have dreamed of meeting.

In the 17th century, long before the word geisha was coined, their precursors were performing on stages in the dry bed of the river Kamo in Kyoto. The most original of all, a woman named Izumo no Okuni, electrified her public by cross-dressing. She performed erotic dances and saucy sketches wearing brocade trousers and an animal-skin jacket like a dashing young man about town. She even dressed as a priest. People called her performance "kabuku", meaning "to be wild and outrageous".

This was the beginning of the kabuki theatre. In those days, the line between acting and prostitution was very thin. Soon there were troupes of courtesans performing risqué dances across the country and providing other services after the show. The shogunate, the government of the day, was less worried about morality than about threats to public order, and only banned actresses from the public stage in 1647, after squabbles between samurai over particularly desirable women.

Women's kabuki was replaced by young men's kabuki; but the problem remained the same, with beautiful young actors offering sexual favours. Finally that too was banned and replaced by adult men's kabuki, as we have it today, in which men take the parts of women.

In those days, according to the Confucian code, it was considered grossly immoral to marry someone you loved; marriage was arranged by your parents. It was also improper to enjoy sex with your wife. The function of marriage was to produce offspring and sex was expected to cease once that function had been fulfilled.

The government, however, appreciated that men had needs; hence the provision of licensed pleasure quarters, which quickly turned into glamorous entertainment hubs offering far more than sex. There, men went to enjoy fine music, food, dancing and conversation. If they were lucky, the evening might culminate in sex; but the top courtesans had the right to refuse and would only agree to share their beds with the most charming and sophisticated suitors.

The first people to go by the name of geisha appeared around the turn of the 17th century. Strangely enough, they were men. Their job was to entertain with bawdy conversation, song and dance. Around 1760, women began to join their ranks and quickly outnumbered the men. Soon the word "geisha" was used primarily of women. The courtesans, gorgeous though they might be, were caged birds, literally imprisoned within the walled pleasure quarters. Yet the geisha were free spirits; their skills at music and dancing gave them independence. They came and went as they pleased and relied on their arts, not their bodies, for their living.

Although they have always had an ambivalent position on the edge of society, some geisha, like the hetairae of ancient Greece, are trained to be the companions of brilliant and powerful men. Many have been the lovers and sometimes the wives of prime ministers. Often wealthy men, forced by their fathers into an unhappy first marriage with a "suitable" woman, get a divorce as soon as they become powerful in their own right and are then free to marry the woman of their choice, who may be a geisha whom they have met at a teahouse party. Ex-geisha, of course, make the most charming society hostesses.

Many geisha are supported by a "danna" or patron, often elderly men who can afford to support them as well as their wife and children. But having a patron does not impinge on independence. As one long-time (male) foreign resident of Japan put it, "They are like cats, dignified and totally independent." Until the second world war, every geisha assumed that she would have a danna, who would provide her with a house, pay for her kimonos and dance classes and give her a regular allowance.

Like modern western women, the geisha's career is the centre of her life. In the daytime she hones her classical dancing and music skills which are her chief arts, and which she continues to study throughout her life. In the evening she appears at teahouse parties, providing witty conversation, a ready ear and entertaining the customers with her exquisite singing and dancing. Whether any more goes on is up to each individual but it is not part of the job.

And, of course, the geisha never emerges before 11am. Then you can spot her in the street, pale and bleary-eyed after the night's partying, perhaps with her hair still unbrushed or in her nightwear, on her way to the local coffee shop for eggs and toast.

 Geisha by Lesley Downer is published in hardback on Thursday, priced £18.99, by Headline Book Publishing Ltd. To order a copy at the special price of £14.99 + 99p UK p&p per order, either phone 0800 316 6102, or send a cheque to Guardian CultureShop, 32-34 Park Royal Road, London NW10 7LN.
