In those days, according to the Confucian code, it was considered grossly immoral to marry someone you loved; marriage was arranged by your parents. It was also improper to enjoy sex with your wife. The function of marriage was to produce offspring and sex was expected to cease once that function had been fulfilled. The government, however, appreciated that men had needs; hence the provision of licensed pleasure quarters, which quickly turned into glamorous entertainment hubs offering far more than sex. There, men went to enjoy fine music, food, dancing and conversation. If they were lucky, the evening might culminate in sex; but the top courtesans had the right to refuse and would only agree to share their beds with the most charming and sophisticated suitors. The first people to go by the name of geisha appeared around the turn of the 17th century. Strangely enough, they were men. Their job was to entertain with bawdy conversation, song and dance. Around 1760, women began to join their ranks and quickly outnumbered the men. Soon the word "geisha" was used primarily of women. The courtesans, gorgeous though they might be, were caged birds, literally imprisoned within the walled pleasure quarters. Yet the geisha were free spirits; their skills at music and dancing gave them independence. They came and went as they pleased and relied on their arts, not their bodies, for their living. Although they have always had an ambivalent position on the edge of society, some geisha, like the hetairae of ancient Greece, are trained to be the companions of brilliant and powerful men. Many have been the lovers and sometimes the wives of prime ministers. Often wealthy men, forced by their fathers into an unhappy first marriage with a "suitable" woman, get a divorce as soon as they become powerful in their own right and are then free to marry the woman of their choice, who may be a geisha whom they have met at a teahouse party. Ex-geisha, of course, make the most charming society hostesses. Many geisha are supported by a "danna" or patron, often elderly men who can afford to support them as well as their wife and children. But having a patron does not impinge on independence. As one long-time (male) foreign resident of Japan put it, "They are like cats, dignified and totally independent." Until the second world war, every geisha assumed that she would have a danna, who would provide her with a house, pay for her kimonos and dance classes and give her a regular allowance. Like modern western women, the geisha's career is the centre of her life. In the daytime she hones her classical dancing and music skills which are her chief arts, and which she continues to study throughout her life. In the evening she appears at teahouse parties, providing witty conversation, a ready ear and entertaining the customers with her exquisite singing and dancing. Whether any more goes on is up to each individual but it is not part of the job. And, of course, the geisha never emerges before 11am. Then you can spot her in the street, pale and bleary-eyed after the night's partying, perhaps with her hair still unbrushed or in her nightwear, on her way to the local coffee shop for eggs and toast.  Geisha by Lesley Downer is published in hardback on Thursday, priced £18.99, by Headline Book Publishing Ltd. fields.headline: Big in crime
fields.standfirst: Maxim Jakubowski hunts for clues amid  the autumn rush of crime novels
fields.trailText: Maxim Jakubowski on Pagan Babies, Perish Twice, The Bottoms, The Mile High Club, Hot Six, Listen To The Silence and The Shape of Snakes
fields.body:
Autumn always brings out the big editorial guns, and on the criminal front it's a veritable battle of the heavyweights. The struggle for the reader's hard-earned cash sees Evanovich, Muller and Walters in the pink corner versus Leonard, Parker, Lansdale and Friedman in the blue corner.

When it comes to fighting prose, no one approaches the venerable Elmore Leonard. With Pagan Babies (Viking, £16.99), his 36th novel, he is on majestic form, juggling his deceptively colloquial style with darker-than-usual subject matter; the result is a winner by knockout. Father Terry Dunn returns home to Detroit from Rwandan atrocities and meets up with Debbie Dewe, an ex-con working in stand-up comedy. They soon hit it off in a big way (Terry is not that priestly) and also discover a shared talent for making money. However, the Detroit mafia stands in their way. With whiplash action and sparkling repartee, this is Leonard at his coolest and best for years: the undoubted champion of American hardboiled prose.
Buy it at BOL

Boston private eye Sunny Randall makes her second appearance in Robert B Parker's Perish Twice (John Murray, £16.99). This new adventure sees her perfecting the art of multitasking: protecting a lesbian activist from a stalker, dealing with friends' and relatives' crumbling marriages and falling back into bed with her own ex, despite his mob connections. Striking an uneasy balance between job and personal life, Randall is a classic female sleuth, but despite the tight, controlled plot, one feels Parker is coasting on past success.
Buy it at BOL

Meanwhile, racing in overdrive from his Texas gonzo corner comes young pretender Joe R Lansdale with The Bottoms (Gollancz, £16.99), an evocative Depression- era mystery that draws on Texas folk tales and plunges into gothic darkness. The elderly Harry Collins remembers his youthful discovery of the mutilated body of a young black woman on the banks of the Sabine River. His father, both town barber and constable, endeavoured to solve the crime but managed only to upset the racial apple cart. Part horror mystery (with legendary local bogeyman, the Goat Man, lurking in the wings), part coming-of-age tale, this is a wonderful evocation of times and ghosts past, in the tradition of To Kill a Mockingbird. A winner on points by a large margin.
Buy it at BOL

Lighter fare comes with The Mile High Club (Faber, £5.99) by Kinky Friedman, the maverick country-and-western singer turned crime writer who never passes up a pun or a scabrous situation. The irreverent caper begins when the author's namesake meets a femme fatale on a plane and is left holding her cosmetics bag at the airport when she disappears. Assisted by his sidekicks, the Village Irregulars, the Kinkster is soon on the bawdy trail and knee-deep in the customary manure. An infectious ride with smiles to spare, it's a satisfying technical knockout. Give the man a cigar.
Buy it at BOL

And how do the women of the killing fields respond? With talent, elegance and wit, Janet Evanovich's Hot Six (Macmillan, £14.99) sees the return of big-hair New Jersey bounty hunter Stephanie Plum and consolidates the author's title as undisputed queen of the comedy beat. Stephanie is again lumbered with man trouble: fellow bounty hunter Ranger, on the run from a murder rap, leaves her loyalties to law and lust severely tested; then there's sexy vice cop Joe Morelli and a certain orange dog who howls when left alone. What is a gal to do? A hilarious rollercoaster ride with a heroine who would have Bridget Jones for breakfast.
Buy it at BOL

Assuredly more serious and socially committed is Marcia Muller's sleuthette Sharon McCone in Listen To The Silence (Women's Press, £6.99), in which the Californian investigator follows a trail of evil to a Montana Indian reservation and into a web of intrigue and repressed emotions. Humane crime writing in touch with the inner devils of today's society, this will grow on you while you least suspect it. A winner by stealth.
Buy it at BOL

Minette Walters's The Shape of Snakes (Macmillan, £16.99) begins in 1978's winter of discontent and binds the death of a black woman in a rain-soaked gutter with the life of the young white woman who discovers her corpse. First-person narrative and documents combine in a complex psychological story with hidden depths. Not completely convincing, but still superior to the careful cosiness of most contemporary British mysteries.
Buy it at BOL

webTitle: Review:  Wherever Green Is Worn by Tim Pat Coogan

fields.headline: Turning the world green
fields.standfirst: Roy Greenslade  on global Irishry in  Wherever Green Is Worn by Tim Pat Coogan
fields.trailText: Roy Greenslade on global Irishry in Wherever Green Is Worn by Tim Pat Coogan
fields.body:
Wherever Green Is Worn

Tim Pat Coogan

746pp, Hutchinson

£25
Buy it at BOL

The English colonised most of the world, turning the map pink. The Irish have peopled the world, ensuring every country has its patches of green. In the process, the descendants of English colonisers have all but vanished; they may know their lineage but, if they care at all, find it largely irrelevant. They are Americans and Australians and South Africans now; there isn't any lingering affection for the old country. The same could never be said of the émigré Irish, who proudly proclaim their hyphenated status. They are Irish first, regardless of the generations that have passed since their ancestors set sail from Erin's green shores (and ballads with lines like that are just one example of the way in which they ensure that Ireland remains part of their continuing consciousness).

Tim Pat Coogan's exploration of the itinerant Irish who span the globe is part history, part contemporary cultural study and part political tract. It is amusing, interesting and often absorbing, but despite its length, intelligence and wit it doesn't really answer the key questions. Why is the vast Irish diaspora still so committed to Ireland? Why have they maintained the religion and the culture? Why the maudlin sentiment about a homeland that has - for so many - never been their home?

On Coogan's journey through Irish pubs, clubs and embassy dining halls, from Auckland to Paris to San Francisco, we meet scores of expatriate Irish who have prospered in their new lands but have never sought to cut the umbilical cord with Ireland. So powerful is its hold that even those who marry people from different backgrounds manage to impose within their "mixed" family a strong sense of Ireland. I recently met a distant cousin of my wife's, whose grandmother emigrated to Philadelphia in 1904. She married a man who believes his background to be Swiss. Yet their children have been raised as if they are Irish-Americans, able to recite Yeats, knowing the words to scores of Irish songs and sticking fast to the Roman Catholic faith.

This has nothing to do with the conflict in Northern Ireland; they are not politically active. For them, as for so many of their ilk, the romantic attachment to Ireland has been part of their upbringing. Nor does it stem from ignorance. They have made many visits to the country of their ancestors and are well aware that modern Ireland is nothing like John Ford's representation in The Quiet Man (and never really was anyway).

In my progress through Coogan's impressive range of interviewees I searched in vain for an explanation of some kind. I readily admit that this didn't spoil the journey: there is much to enjoy along the way, and it is peppered with the kind of Irish humour that can make you laugh out loud. Coogan tells of a visit to a Gaelic Athletics Association football pitch notorious for its poor facilities. Having looked in vain for somewhere to wash, he asked one of the organisers: "Where are the showers?" The man, pointing to some approaching black clouds, replied: "You'll get plenty of showers when those come over." In Buenos Aires, where a sizeable Irish community flourishes, Coogan discovered that during the Falklands war a group of Argentinian patriots had blown up a bust of Padraig Pearse, one of the leaders of the 1916 Easter Rising, mistaking him for a British hero. In New Orleans, he reports, the tradition in the St Patrick's Day parade is for revellers on the floats to throw the contents of an Irish stew at spectators.

It isn't all fun, export Guinness and uplifting rags-to-riches stories. A section on a priest savagely tortured in Argentina is but one example of the extraordinary heroism exhibited by many Irish missionaries down the years. There are also reminders of the hostility faced by Irish immigrants, especially in Britain in the 1950s, who were met by notices outside lodging houses that read "No Irish need apply" and often "No Irish. No blacks. No dogs." Yet Coogan does not hide the other side of the coin, pointing to instances of anti-black racism by the Irish in the States, relating tales of gangsterism in south Boston and the bending of the democratic will once the Irish gained control of Tammany Hall. Sometimes the Irish fought dirty to win the recognition they now enjoy in both America and Australia.

With the rise of the Celtic tiger and the declining birth rate, emigration has fallen away in recent years. That is good for Ireland, of course, but it means the rest of the world is bound to be a slightly poorer place without its regular green influx. Still, there are 70 million people outside Ireland laying claim to be Irish - and that's quite enough to be going on with, is it not?

webTitle: In search of ghosts at the edge of the world

fields.headline: In search of ghosts at the edge of the world
fields.trailText: Director's diary
fields.body:
Six months before leaving the National Theatre I was asked to write and present a series of programmes about the history of 20th-century theatre for BBC2. This is an account of the filming. The actual start was several months earlier, when I interviewed John Gielgud, in case he "dropped off the twig", as he put it.

September 13 1999

To the Aran Islands, to film a sequence about Synge, who went there in 1898 for four summers, out of which came three great plays. We arrive from Stansted at Knock airport in Galway - a monument to the capitalist instincts of the Catholic church - and drive to an airstrip in Connemara, through Knock and Tuam and Galway City. The west of Ireland has an air of yesterday: no factory farming, not much speculative building, the shop fronts all gloss paint and Celtic lettering, none of the graphics and logos of the New Europe.

The airstrip is a thin tear of tarmac in a field. The plane seats six. We skim the sea and within minutes see the small island of Inishmaan before us, like a giant sleeping seal, scarred with hundreds of drystone walls, containing pockets of scrubby grass, and houses dotted over the island like a ragged white necklace. We land on one of the few large, unenclosed fields, next to a Gaelic football ground with, surrealistically, only one set of goalposts. We go out on a recce round the island and watch the sun go down through huge waves, standing on a cliff at the west tip of the island - nothing between us and America.

September 14

Dawn. Standing on a grey, sandy beach, we film the sun rising over the hills of County Clare. It's very mild, a clear sky, butter-gold sun, a perfect morning. It doesn't seem to fit with what I've written about Synge coming to a bleak, weather-beaten place.

It's too sunny to film on the rocky outcrop where we stood last night, so we go off to another location, where huge slabs of limestone pave the fields like abandoned car parks, and massive chunks stand up, sliced by the weather into great grey lumps with six-inch crevasses. This is the spot for my first "PTC" - I'm learning: PTC, piece to camera. I have to walk along the edge of a limestone cliff, stepping over the crevasses, talking to the distant camera, following a route that I'm assured looks great on camera but demands that I stop on the words "edge of the world" at the edge of a 50ft drop. Ah yes, no trouble. It's hard enough to remember what I've written, but walk, talk, don't fall off and look at the camera? Now I really admire Anneka Rice.

The sun is hot. We move around the island to other locations. To someone used to filming drama accompanied by actors, extras, a crew of 30 odd and an army of vehicles, driving around in a old Land Rover with a crew of three seems deeply enviable.

The weather changes: the cliff that we recced last night is thought to be suitably stormy. This time I have to walk towards the camera while stepping over large sharp rocks, skirting craggy pools, trying not to slip on sea-weed, pointing to America, then to England, and talking to an unresponsive lens about the way British drama has been dependent on the Irish for centuries. When I reach the camera without messing up my words or slipping into the sea, there is jubilation from the crew. "The waves behind you!" they shriek. "We thought you were going to be dragged into the sea!" And there I was worrying about my lines.

September 15

The cottage where Synge stayed: it's small, low and long. Perhaps a dozen people lived here in four small rooms, one of those being occupied by the paying guest. The cottage has been restored by the great-granddaughter of Synge's hosts: a labour of love, she's raised the money to restore the cottage, dilapidated since her parents moved to a new cottage just below in 1978. It has a new earth floor in the kitchen, floorboards next door in Synge's room, a new rye-thatched roof.

Synge was sent here by his producer, Yeats, who did something that producers often do, but it seldom works: he told Synge what to write about. "Give up Paris," he said. "Go to the Aran Islands. Live as if you were one of the people themselves; express a life that has never found expression." Yeats and Lady Gregory had been here; she was remembered for her snobbery, for refusing to give sweets to the kids, and for bribing neighbours to keep their dog quiet when she stayed in the cottage. Synge wrote listening to the comforting chatter of the women in the kitchen speaking Irish, which he learned from a Martin McDonagh - almost certainly a distant cousin of the prolific young author of The Cripple of Inishmaan (who lives in Elephant and Castle). The islanders still speak Irish among themselves.

Life on the island is still hard and poor. There are photos of 19th-century evictions in the house: they had to pay a ground rent to an English landlord, only a few shillings, but imagine evicting people who had to make a living from this unforgiving soil.

In the evening we film in the bar; we've brought some musicians over from Galway. It starts to fill up around 10 o'clock. Only one man complains of being "exploited" by the BBC. He's an immigrant - a Dubliner - and he's told by an islander not to be so inhospitable. Mostly they seem indifferent to our filming. After all, they're used to film crews here; they had Flaherty doing Man of Aran in 1934. Rivers of Guinness flow, every table with black columns of creamy Guinness lined up like skittles. After we stop filming, people start to sing - unaccompanied, unselfconscious Irish songs, the strange intervals made stranger by the loose relation with pitch, straying around the note like the wind through trees.

September 16

We fly back to Connemara. At the tiny airport shop (which sells home-made scones) I buy another copy of Synge's journal, The Aran Islands. "He was through here today, you know," says the man behind the counter. "You could have got him to sign your book."

 This is the first of our weekly edited extracts from the diary that Richard Eyre kept while filming Changing Stages. The first part is on BBC2 at 6pm on Sunday 5 November. The book of the series is published next week by Bloomsbury, price £30.

In the evening we film in the bar; we've brought some musicians over from Galway. It starts to fill up around 10 o'clock. Only one man complains of being "exploited" by the BBC. He's an immigrant - a Dubliner - and he's told by an islander not to be so inhospitable. Mostly they seem indifferent to our filming. After all, they're used to film crews here; they had Flaherty doing Man of Aran in 1934. Rivers of Guinness flow, every table with black columns of creamy Guinness lined up like skittles. After we stop filming, people start to sing - unaccompanied, unselfconscious Irish songs, the strange intervals made stranger by the loose relation with pitch, straying around the note like the wind through trees. September 16 We fly back to Connemara. At the tiny airport shop (which sells home-made scones) I buy another copy of Synge's journal, The Aran Islands. "He was through here today, you know," says the man behind the counter. "You could have got him to sign your book."  This is the first of our weekly edited extracts from the diary that Richard Eyre kept while filming Changing Stages. The first part is on BBC2 at 6pm on Sunday 5 November. The book of the series is published next week by Bloomsbury, price £30.

fields.headline: Last chance to see
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark  on a prophetic tale of ecological destruction in Susan Hillmore's  Malaria
fields.trailText: Alex Clark on a prophetic tale of ecological destruction in Malaria by Susan Hillmore
fields.body:
Malaria
Susan Hillmore
134pp, Jonathan Cape
£10
Buy it at BOL

Mannar, the anonymous fabulist narrator of Susan Hillmore's compact, elliptical novel tells us, was once regarded as a latter-day Garden of Eden, an earthly paradise in which "sparkling streams cascaded down hillsides and meandered through green valleys. Elephants browsed with deer and roamed in peace. Cranes and pink-headed duck reflected their plumage in water tanks built by kings on the fringes of ancient cities." No longer. Now, we are told, rivers stagnate, oily coral lies blasted and flora and fauna have reached or already passed the brink of extinction.

Although Mannar's postlapsarian state is fleetingly ascribed to the forgetfulness of the gods, there is little doubt as to the true culprits. Presided over by corrupt politicians and ransacked by the reckless activity of its people, who are desperate to exploit its natural abundance, the island has been turned from heaven into hell by human beings. Into this debased perfection steps Sir Alexander Haye, a zoologist wreathed in TV celebrity, bent on capturing Mannar's last surviving herd of elephants on film - not, we understand, in the spirit of a conservationist plea, but as a panacea to concerned western viewers as well as a gambit, with the ruling elite's connivance, to boost the island's failing tourist industry.

The PR stunt that ushers in this dubious project is the gift of a baby elephant to London Zoo, to be escorted from the remote, inaccessible hills to the airport by Alexander's twin brother Max, who himself lives in reclusive opulence on one of Mannar's rocky outcrops. The central strand of the novel concerns Max's hellish, allegorical journey upcountry, during which a stealthy mosquito infects him with the malaria of the title. Distressed at his own complicity in this act of bad faith - as the baby elephant is whisked away in an aeroplane, its enraged mother runs pell-mell through hangar and over runway - Max succumbs to the disease, and when he returns to his shuttered castle, he is plunged into a hallucinatory fever that mirrors Mannar's plight.

This section of intensely imagined, dense descriptive writing is perhaps the strongest part of a novel that evokes the miserable reality of ecological destruction and its concomitant political and social malaise without exploring it in any great depth. Hillmore is adept, however, at translating her subject into powerful, lyrical prose, most notably when she is portraying Max's delirium: "Outside the sea had boiled itself away and over the grey salty landscape a terrifying sun burned in the sky. On cracked dusty earth lay desiccated fish whose flesh was being stripped from their bones by scavenging seabirds." As his fever subsides, Max is visited by a vision of mermaids drowning in the poisoned sea, their agonising death throes later echoed by the popular revolt that sweeps the island, leaving in its wake massacred orphans and rotting piles of charred corpses.

If Alexander's philanthropic posturings strike a false note - the possibilities for his film are increased five-fold when the elephants he plans to portray are discovered splayed out in a mass grave - then Max's disengaged horror is equally useless. Indeed, there is little cause for optimism in Malaria, where entropy and brutality have combined to snuff out the future. Not developed fully enough to serve as cautionary tale, Hillmore's bravura depiction of this unrelenting nightmare is, however, a striking and compelling reflection of the world as it may yet become.

fields.headline: Non-fiction: 28 October
fields.trailText: Vera Rule on narratives of the Mayans in The Lost Chronicles of the Maya Kings and the history of the concept of zero in The Nothing That Is
fields.body:
The Lost Chronicles of the Maya Kings
David Drew
(Phoenix, £8.99)
Buy it at BOL

A narrative of the Mayans from pre-history to survivors lurking in the jungle. The latter wrote to Queen Victoria asking if they might join the British empire; their current keeper of the holy books accesses the maize-fed memories of four millennia. Also an account of the fantasies (and fantastic truths) of those Europeans who sought the builders of the lime-white pyramids of central America; and how Mayan hieroglyphics were cracked by a Russian scholar who saved a sole volume from a burning library in Berlin. Great darknesses of blood shed in fear of eternal oblivion, shot through with the brilliant plumage of quetzal birds.

The Nothing That Is
Robert Kaplan
(Penguin, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

The Maya again, in a chapter in this history of the concept of zero. Kaplan explains their temporal mathematics, arranging multiple cycles of days intended to defer vulnerable dates and so avert the end of time. When all the calendar noughts came up, a man impersonating a hero and another garbed as Zero, God of Death, played a lethal ball game with the body of an important captive. A terrible metaphor for zilch, nada, nowt, nothing, which more contemplative societies discerned as the pregnant void, mother of the infinite universe. "Mathematics," writes Kaplan, a poet in soul, "always follows where elegance leads."

Hear an extract
You will need RealPlayer to listen to this clip. You can download it here free
fields.trailText:
Clark's widow suggested that their elder son James record this next instalment of his dad's diaries - and, equally oddly, he agreed. But why?
Hear a real audio clip
fields.body: Clark's widow suggested that their elder son James record this next instalment of his dad's diaries - and, equally oddly, he agreed. But why? There is a small drawling vocal similarity between père and fils, though you'd never mistake the two. The son has a softer voice, lacking that harder, curled-lip edge that suited dad's right-wing jingoism; he lacks the performer's skill to convey Alan's insights, and there is something distinctly rum about hearing the son give voice to dad's lechy ambitions about women other than his mum. Orion unwisely sent just a couple of cassette-sides, one of which is almost entirely taken up with Clark's creepy delight during the Falklands War. It frankly turns you off the rest, whatever it might be like.

fields.headline: Fiction: 28 October
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery on updated 19th century tales plpus Lee Trebilcock in the 20th Century, Border State and The Fish Can Sing
fields.body:
The Bad Sister
Emma Tennant
(Canongate, £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

This omnibus first offers a double portion of Tennant's 19th-century psychological tales - The Bad Sister, an unsettling reworking of Confessions of a Justified Sinner, and Two Women of London, which relocates Jekyll and Hyde to Notting Hill and adds a feminist twist. Both play on the theme of doubles and madness. To this febrile pair Canongate adds Wild Nights, a family chronicle inspired by Tennant's own background, and a deft introduction from Candia McWilliam. Being Scottish may help, as McWilliam says, to understand Tennant's exploration of a divided self, but non-Scots can still relish the shifting perspectives that give her writing its peculiarity.

Lee Trebilcock in the 20th Century
Hannah Crow
(Anchor, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Set in a seaside town in the south-west of England and with an improbably named hero, Crow's debut is an impressive novel of white, working-class male anger. Lee works at Do It Easy and hopes, as any 19-year-old would, that divorcée Lorraine from fitted kitchens will "do it easy" with him in the lunch break. He goes home to a council estate and a mother suffering with Alzheimers and goes around with mascara'd Hawley until Uncle Septor and his camera club decide to rid the estate of "perverts". Crow's portrait of adolescence is wonderfully tart, with Lee a bleakly nihilistic yet engagingly outrageous character.

Border State
Tonu Onnepalu
(Northwestern University Press, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

There are 20-odd books in NUP's series of "Writings From an Unbound Europe" - Czech, Serbian, Hungarian and Polish writers who would otherwise rarely be read elsewhere. This small novel by the Estonian Onnepalu is written as a series of letters from an eastern European, meandering through Euro-land in the company of a lover whom he eventually murders. Elliptical and overly poetic in places, Border State nonetheless rings with fury and bewilderment at the prostitution of one half of Europe to the empty freedoms offered by the other. The metaphor is blunt, but the sentiment compelling.

The Fish Can Sing
Halldor Laxness
(Harvill, £10.99)
Buy it at BOL

This story of an orphaned boy growing up in Reykjavik at a time when fishermen grazed horses around its outskirts describes an utterly foreign world. The Fish Can Sing meanders beautifully, catching at inconsequential anecdotes, descriptions of the narrator Alfgrim's life and the stories of his grandparents and the visitors who stay in their loft at the turn of the century. This might seem to colour the narrative with folksy nostalgia, but Laxness's view of a child's bounded universe has humour and a light touch. As an antidote to psychological "Danish novels", he creates an engrossing alternative way of telling stories.

webTitle: Pick of the week: Articles of Resistance, by Paul Foot

fields.headline: Not left behind
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard defends Paul Foot's principles in the collection Articles of Resistance
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard defends Paul Foot's principles in the collection Articles of Resistance
fields.body:
Articles of Resistance

Paul Foot

(Bookmarks, £14.99)
Buy it at BOL

I recall a review of The Guardian Year '94 in the TLS, in which Geoffrey Wheatcroft wittily described Paul Foot as a writer who is "wheeled on for the delectation of bus-pass revolutionists, balding and menopausal soixante-huitards who still remember Grosvenor Square, and those who think that Labour's great mistake in 1975-85 was not moving far enough to the Left".

Speaking as someone who pays for his bus fares, has most of his own hair and was five in 1968, I fail, unlike Wheatcroft, to see the big picture in all of this; but I do take on board his point about the Labour Party. The decade of treachery to its principles that Wheatcroft refers to may be extended, on either side. In 1994, Foot closed an article on Blair and Co with the words: "They are preparing the ground for an assault on Labour voters more outrageous and contemptible than even Ramsay MacDonald ever imagined." As various PFI schemes wait in the wings, ready to do more harm to our infrastructure than anyone could have imagined possible from a so-called "Labour" government, we may muse on Foot's supposed irrelevance to the debate.

So why should old Paul Foot, or more specifically, the latest collection of his journalism, be "wheeled out" yet again? I have no idea. The man is obviously a complete waste of space. He writes for magazines with titles like (tee hee!) Socialist Review. A journalist of Wheatcroft's calibre may be able to explain better than Foot why people such as (a) those who died in the Lockerbie crash, (b) the population of East Timor, (c) the Bridgewater Four, (d) those who died in the Marchioness disaster, or (e) employees of the late Robert Maxwell - or even (f) anyone who was offended at the antics of Jonathan Aitken - should not be worth the scrutiny and solidarity of a man who latched on to the relevant issues before the rest of the pack, and held on to them with passionate tenacity.

He may also laugh at the idea of a socialist (haw!) who could write for both the Mirror and the London Review of Books, getting his ideas over with as much simplicity or complexity as he felt was appropriate to each audience. Perhaps Wheatcroft disapproves of Foot's humour; another way of insinuating poisonous lefty ideas into the minds of the great unwashed. Or Foot's love of literature, his principles, his hatred of injustice ... yes, truly all these must contribute to Wheatcroft's contempt. From which we may choose to infer a great deal about where Wheatcroft stands on these issues.

Perhaps readers should make up their own minds about Foot, rather than take the Wheatcroft line without question. This wide selection of Foot's pieces from the last ten years or so is necessary - even at a price that only running dogs of capitalism can afford - as a history of both injustice and hope in this country. In this he may well be considered the inheritor of Orwell's mantle, at least as far as journalism is concerned. He is a professional, and, moreover, gets his points across with absolute clarity. He may gush, or over-sentimentalise at times; the more fastidious may blush when he says, in 1994: "I haven't seen Raining Stones yet, but the clips are all of Ricky Tomlinson defying and laughing." Then again, if you're going to gush about any actor at all, Ricky Tomlinson is your best bet. Perspicacious of Foot, too. I suspect that one of the reasons he's trustworthy like that is because he gives a damn.

webTitle: Review:  Bertrand Russell 1921-70 by Ray Monk

fields.headline: A booting for Bertie
fields.standfirst: AC Grayling  defends Bertrand Russell from a biographical mugging by Ray Monk in  Bertrand Russell 1921-70: The Ghost of Madness
fields.trailText: AC Grayling defends Bertrand Russell from a biographical mugging by Ray Monk in Bertrand Russell 1921-70: The Ghost of Madness
fields.body:
Bertrand Russell 1921-70: The Ghost of Madness

Ray Monk

574pp, Cape

£25
Buy it at BOL

Any tender-minded reader is likely to be filled with pity by the time he or she finishes Ray Monk's large second volume on the life of Bertrand Russell. The pity will not be for the Nobel Prize-winning philosopher but for his suffering biographer, who found himself in the ghastly situation of being offered lots of money to write about a man whom - as he already knew when he banked the cheque - he loathed. The cheque was big because of his successful biography of Wittgenstein, whom by contrast he worships; the choice was forced on him by the fact that Russell was the only obvious place to go once his Wittgenstein book was done.

Monk has taken the sole course open to anyone who finds himself in this plight. His bulky life of Russell is a sustained attack, in which he lays two charges against the philosopher, trying to make each as serious as he can. The first is that Russell made a living as a journalist, a crime in Monk's view because journalism is necessarily more popular and accessible than Russell's masterpiece, Principia Mathematica. He works himself into a lather of rage and contempt over Russell's addressing himself to the general public in terms it can understand, describing as "superficial", "trivial", "naive", "dishonest" and worse the newspaper articles and popular books by which for several decades Russell supported his family.

His second charge is that the thrice-divorced Russell was emotionally stunted to the point of being a monster of coldness and indifference who hurt his wives, children and grandchildren profoundly. In particular Monk blames him for the mental breakdown of his son John, and even for the unhappiness of John's daughters. But by a quirk of the biographer's art, Monk provides all the materials for a refutation of his own view of Russell, who emerges from the mugging Monk attempts with his famous halo of white hair sticking up rather more than usual, but looking as quizzical and stoical as ever.

The first charge would scarcely be worth rebutting if Russell's endless labours for peace - and for the improvement of humanity, which he saw as a necessary condition for attaining it - had not filled so much of his life after 1918. In common with others, including Karl Popper and Wittgenstein, he thought that the only hope of fashioning a new world was better education. He founded a school, which he had to finance by writing journalism and giving exhausting lecture tours in America. Wittgenstein did not survive long as a teacher, being hounded from the profession by irate parents of children he bullied, but Russell and his second wife Dora ran their school until the early 1930s. Russell's involvement ended only with his divorce from Dora, who by then had given birth to two children by another man. In addition to disdaining the books Russell wrote to pay for the school, Monk mocks his efforts to use what were then the latest psychological theories to teach his children and other pupils, and ignores his struggles to keep his marriage going for his children's sake, blaming him for the unhappiness they felt when it ended.

This calumniating style prevails throughout. Monk's method is to gather vignettes of Russell from the writings of contemporaries who disliked him, so that we see him as vain, unfeeling and glib, cracking his acid witticisms at dinner parties and discoursing on the state of the world while neglecting his own offspring. Like Monk himself, the unimpeachably earnest Beatrice Webb thought that Russell was wasting his great powers by writing popular literature, although she did not explain how Russell was to have earned a living from logical treatises.

When he was a young man Russell gave his inheritance away to the budding London School of Economics, founded by the Webbs, so Webb's attitude is hardly fair. But Monk relishes her attitude and makes it his own. Russell can do no right in his eyes; he scours Russell's journalism and blames him when he detects a change of mind - and also when he finds him saying the same thing. He blames him for addressing the general public when he should have been doing philosophy - and then berates him for returning to philosophy in the 1930s and 1940s, on the grounds that he had been away from it too long. There are too many such contradictions in Monk's endless complaints to detail. One thing he seems unable to recognise - or when he does, to abide - is Russell's irony and his witty use of contradiction and startling generalisation to make swift, thought-provoking points. Monk treats Russell's sallies with humourless seriousness, trying to get us to see them as proof of intellectual irresponsibility.

In the decades after 1945, as the threat of nuclear disaster increased, Russell bombarded world leaders with telegrams urging peace and disarmament. Monk describes this as Russell's fantasy that he had a world role. Since Krushchev, Kennedy, Nkrumah, Nehru, Chou En Lai and others replied, and even sometimes negotiated with each other by means of their letters to him, it is hard to see how Russell could have avoided thinking so.

Monk reserves most of his ire for what he sees as Russell's disastrous effect on his family, and it is here he does him deepest injustice. He tells us that Russell gave a home and an education to his children and grandchildren, fought to save his marriages for their sakes, suffered tremendously from the destructive behaviour of his second and third wives, loved his children profoundly and was devastated when his son John became schizophrenic - and yet, according to Monk, was still to blame for all that went wrong with them. In a way exactly reminiscent of his Nelson's-eye attitude to Wittgenstein's unpleasant character, Monk reports but passes no judgment on the amazing antics of Russell's wives and the dreadful harm done by John and his equally unstable wife to their children. He also reports, but does not comment upon, the enduring love for Russell of his daughter Kate and her children, his first wife Alys and both his second and third wives, facts that scarcely suggest the monster of Monk's imagination. The result is a badly skewed portrait.

To readers who remember Russell's last years it will come as no surprise to have it confirmed that his apparent nonagenarian metamorphosis into a revolutionary follower of Che Guevera was the result of his name being misused by his egregious "secretary" Ralph Schoenman, an intemperate supporter of fiery causes. Russell was bitterly opposed to the Vietnam war, but the crude propaganda about it that Schoenman had him sign was certainly not his. Monk is vague about the degree to which Russell knew what Schoenman was doing (not much, the evidence suggests). fields.bodyText: Bertrand Russell 1921-70: The Ghost of Madness Ray Monk 574pp, Cape £25 Buy it at BOL Any tender-minded reader is likely to be filled with pity by the time he or she finishes Ray Monk's large second volume on the life of Bertrand Russell. The pity will not be for the Nobel Prize-winning philosopher but for his suffering biographer, who found himself in the ghastly situation of being offered lots of money to write about a man whom - as he already knew when he banked the cheque - he loathed. The cheque was big because of his successful biography of Wittgenstein, whom by contrast he worships; the choice was forced on him by the fact that Russell was the only obvious place to go once his Wittgenstein book was done. Monk has taken the sole course open to anyone who finds himself in this plight. His bulky life of Russell is a sustained attack, in which he lays two charges against the philosopher, trying to make each as serious as he can. The first is that Russell made a living as a journalist, a crime in Monk's view because journalism is necessarily more popular and accessible than Russell's masterpiece, Principia Mathematica. He works himself into a lather of rage and contempt over Russell's addressing himself to the general public in terms it can understand, describing as "superficial", "trivial", "naive", "dishonest" and worse the newspaper articles and popular books by which for several decades Russell supported his family. His second charge is that the thrice-divorced Russell was emotionally stunted to the point of being a monster of coldness and indifference who hurt his wives, children and grandchildren profoundly. In particular Monk blames him for the mental breakdown of his son John, and even for the unhappiness of John's daughters. But by a quirk of the biographer's art, Monk provides all the materials for a refutation of his own view of Russell, who emerges from the mugging Monk attempts with his famous halo of white hair sticking up rather more than usual, but looking as quizzical and stoical as ever. The first charge would scarcely be worth rebutting if Russell's endless labours for peace - and for the improvement of humanity, which he saw as a necessary condition for attaining it - had not filled so much of his life after 1918. In common with others, including Karl Popper and Wittgenstein, he thought that the only hope of fashioning a new world was better education. He founded a school, which he had to finance by writing journalism and giving exhausting lecture tours in America. Wittgenstein did not survive long as a teacher, being hounded from the profession by irate parents of children he bullied, but Russell and his second wife Dora ran their school until the early 1930s. Russell's involvement ended only with his divorce from Dora, who by then had given birth to two children by another man. In addition to disdaining the books Russell wrote to pay for the school, Monk mocks his efforts to use what were then the latest psychological theories to teach his children and other pupils, and ignores his struggles to keep his marriage going for his children's sake, blaming him for the unhappiness they felt when it ended. This calumniating style prevails throughout. Monk's method is to gather vignettes of Russell from the writings of contemporaries who disliked him, so that we see him as vain, unfeeling and glib, cracking his acid witticisms at dinner parties and discoursing on the state of the world while neglecting his own offspring. Like Monk himself, the unimpeachably earnest Beatrice Webb thought that Russell was wasting his great powers by writing popular literature, although she did not explain how Russell was to have earned a living from logical treatises. When he was a young man Russell gave his inheritance away to the budding London School of Economics, founded by the Webbs, so Webb's attitude is hardly fair. But Monk relishes her attitude and makes it his own. Russell can do no right in his eyes; he scours Russell's journalism and blames him when he detects a change of mind - and also when he finds him saying the same thing. One thing he seems unable to recognise - or when he does, to abide - is Russell's irony and his witty use of contradiction and startling generalisation to make swift, thought-provoking points. Monk treats Russell's sallies with humourless seriousness, trying to get us to see them as proof of intellectual irresponsibility. In the decades after 1945, as the threat of nuclear disaster increased, Russell bombarded world leaders with telegrams urging peace and disarmament. Monk describes this as Russell's fantasy that he had a world role. Since Krushchev, Kennedy, Nkrumah, Nehru, Chou En Lai and others replied, and even sometimes negotiated with each other by means of their letters to him, it is hard to see how Russell could have avoided thinking so. Monk reserves most of his ire for what he sees as Russell's disastrous effect on his family, and it is here he does him deepest injustice. He tells us that Russell gave a home and an education to his children and grandchildren, fought to save his marriages for their sakes, suffered tremendously from the destructive behaviour of his second and third wives, loved his children profoundly and was devastated when his son John became schizophrenic - and yet, according to Monk, was still to blame for all that went wrong with them. In a way exactly reminiscent of his Nelson's-eye attitude to Wittgenstein's unpleasant character, Monk reports but passes no judgment on the amazing antics of Russell's wives and the dreadful harm done by John and his equally unstable wife to their children. He also reports, but does not comment upon, the enduring love for Russell of his daughter Kate and her children, his first wife Alys and both his second and third wives, facts that scarcely suggest the monster of Monk's imagination. The result is a badly skewed portrait. To readers who remember Russell's last years it will come as no surprise to have it confirmed that his apparent nonagenarian metamorphosis into a revolutionary follower of Che Guevera was the result of his name being misused by his egregious "secretary" Ralph Schoenman, an intemperate supporter of fiery causes. webTitle: The Saturday Poem: 'Come Back in Twelve Months' by Elizabeth Bewick

fields.headline: 'Come Back in Twelve Months'
fields.trailText:
Allotted span of threescore years and ten

and then one more to celebrate the rest...
fields.body:
(for Mr R. M. Rainsbury)
Allotted span of threescore years and ten
and then one more to celebrate the rest,
to wait and speculate on whether fate
has something up her sleeve, new game to play,
after the fine excess of seventy springs.

A year of celebration and of hope
yet, looking back, I see it as a year
taut with expectancy, and fraught with fear;
the passing days were a kaleidoscope
as childhood dreams and visions rocked the dark.

Some women wear bright colours to deceive
themselves and others facing bitter truth;
wearing my purple with a jaunty air,
leaving a trail of perfume in my wake,
I flaunt my vaunted courage in the street.
Tomorrow brings new knowledge where I stand
in freedom with my thoughts and my desires,
wearing the pattern of my vibrant year
for all to see the colours that appeared
and glowed more strongly through long months of doubt.

webTitle: A life in writing: Russell Banks

fields.headline: A working-class hero is something to be
fields.standfirst: Russell Banks tells Nick Hasted of his attraction to ice-bound aloneness
fields.trailText: Russell Banks tells Nick Hasted of his attraction to ice-bound aloneness
fields.body:
Russell Banks's characters tend to be called "trailer trash", but it's a phrase you'll despise after reading his fiction. His new short-story retrospective, The Angel on the Roof, sinks especially deep into the ice-bound aloneness of small towns and trailer parks in upstate New Hampshire and New York, the American North Country he's staked as his own. We see the inhabitants of one lakeside terminus from a dozen angles, each enriching the pride, idiocy, selfishness, sympathy, nobility and wreckage-clinging survived despair to be found in such lost corners.

In the novel Continental Drift (1985), the careening effort by Bob Dubois to escape his caged small-town prospects tears him away from himself and his family, and leads to devastating loss. In Rule of the Bone (1995), a teenage boy's need to out-race alienation and parental abuse spins him off America's edge. The busload of drowned, frozen schoolchildren in The Sweet Hereafter (1997) and the middle-aged man doomed by his drunk, violent father's example in Affliction (1989) - both recently adapted as Oscar-winning films - show abandonment from other angles, a genetic flaw in America's heart. Banks knows this whole story. Born in New Hampshire, he's fought off his own violent father's example, freed himself from a fated life with fiction. He knows his subjects aren't a Jerry Springer freak show. They're humanity.

"There's an important tradition in American writing," the 60-year-old says, in the upstate New York small town where he now lives, when not teaching at Princeton, "going back to Mark Twain and forward to Raymond Carver and Grace Paley, whose work is generated by love of people who are scorned and derided. The people I'm writing about are the ones you normally don't feel affection for when you see them in the street or the shopping mall. I have an almost simple-minded affection for them. My readers are not the same as my characters, as I'm very aware. So I'm glad when they feel that affection too."

Vann, in the story "Plains of Abraham", stands for almost all Banks's male characters: "a complex, layered mind with only a few compartments connected". Alienated from his culture and class, unable to understand his own nature, he has no way out. "I think that's particularly true of men," Banks says. "They feel their lives are being mysteriously controlled by forces they can't even name. As a defence they compartmentalise their experience into little boxes that don't communicate, because the truth is too painful. At some point, they hear rapping through the walls of those boxes, and they start to realise something's deeply wrong. Most of my male characters then struggle back to some place in their past, to find when the light at tunnel's end dimmed."

Banks's life was like that of his own future characters until his mid-twenties, fitted to the shape set for him: wife at 18 (first of four), baby at 19, divorced at 20, a small-town New Hampshire pipe-fitter in a pick-up truck. It was writing's discipline - Jack Kerouac's harsh background and the paternal friendship of Nelson Algren were among his inspirations - that plucked him to a different life. But this uprooting left guilty scars on work that was at first constrained, in denial. "I felt I'd betrayed my past and the people who made it up. My writing was in a netherland: fearful of my own sources, of myself, till my mid-thirties, when I accepted them."

The source that was most difficult to admit was his father, a violent drunk who abandoned the family when Banks was 12, and around whom he was physically anxious even in the man's old age. "He remains the centre of my imaginative life. He wasn't just a violent, alcoholic brute, no one is. He died in 1979, and yet he appears in my dreams two or three times a week, as he was in his mid-forties, when he was at his most powerful. He left a residue of violence my neurons are still patterned around. It's trauma that rewires them, usually. Goodness never provides a trauma. Violence does. Abandonment does. Betrayal does. My adult life has been lucky, people have been faithful and loving. So my wiring's the same."

"The Visit", in which a successful middle-aged man revisits a childhood home electrified with shadowy, threatening memories, is also Banks's attempt to invoke what he calls the "heat and light" of violence, "its erotic charge, its intensity of attention", for both victim and victimiser - a seduction that he later sought out in senseless bar-room fights which would have left him dead if writing hadn't stepped in. Affliction's paternal tragedy was his fictional goodbye to all that. "I was glad I wrote that story. It meant I wouldn't have to again."

The Sweet Hereafter and Rule of the Bone instead focused on 1990s children: Nicole in one, Bone in the other, both sexually abused. The former's schoolbus, in which a town's children sink inexorably away from their parents through cracked ice, is later a refuge from parents for Bone, abandonment unbroken. Recently, Cloudsplitter (1999), about violent Abolitionist John Brown, investigated racism's stain.

Banks, meanwhile, is back where he started, in a working-class small town. "I had to will myself back. But these people are my birthright. Writing saved me by letting me leave once. But I can never go too far. All the truth I know is here."

webTitle: The Loafer: Ulysses, scooters and naked women

fields.headline: Ulysses, scooters and naked women
fields.trailText: A science book, a novel hailed by one editor as "the Ukrainian Ulysses" and a Hungarian novel offered in English from the German translation of the original were among the biggest books at the 52nd Frankfurt Bookfair
fields.body:
 A science book, a novel hailed by one editor as "the Ukrainian Ulysses" and a Hungarian novel offered in English from the German translation of the original were among the biggest books at the 52nd Frankfurt Bookfair - this last remaining unsold at the close of play as several English publishers slugged it out at £150,000. By several accounts, this year's proceedings were busy but dull, with little Hollywood glitz to spice them up. Lucky, then, that the sale of hip Edinburgh publishers Canongate to Grove/Atlantic gave the chatterers something to mull over, not least because the deal brought together the notorious partygoer Morgan Entrekin and his UK alter ego, Jamie Byng.

 Indeed, those hardy souls lingering in the bar until the small hours were witness to an extraordinary display of corporate bonding, as Entrekin encouraged his new business partner to join an Apache-style group hug that lasted for, according to onlookers, well over 10 minutes. Byng apparently took to it like a duck to water, although the head of Grove UK, Toby Mundy, was distinctly uncomfortable.

 With more than 50,000 visitors a day to the fair, free movement around the vast halls proved somewhat taxing. What a clever entrepreneur it was, then, who set up a scooter stall, selling little "Messekickers" at £60 a go. More astonishingly, there were only two accidents, both occurring before a large display of a naked woman.

 Next weekend's Aldeburgh Poetry Festival might be the last, according to its organisers. Having lost funding from Suffolk County Council some years ago on the grounds of elitism, the festival now faces the chop from Eastern Arts Board, who require evidence of local-authority funding - something of a double bind. For reference, Aldeburgh's average gate is 200 per event.

 Whether to go to Stephanie Theobald's launch party, which promises lap-dancing, or the gathering for a book entitled Cock (a work on Indian fireworks)? The Loafer is in something of a dilemma. Instead, perhaps, one might attend the party for No Place Like Home, not our colleague Gary Younge's journeys through America, but a new cookbook from Rowley Leigh. Evidently, a good title can't go to waste.

webTitle: Review: Mendel's Demon by Mark Ridley

fields.headline: Demonic sexuality
fields.standfirst: We are evolutionarily impossible, finds  Andrew Brown in Mark Ridley's  Mendel's Demon: Gene Justice and the Complexity of Life
fields.trailText: We are evolutionarily impossible, finds Andrew Brown in Mark Ridley's Mendel's Demon: Gene Justice and the Complexity of Life
fields.body:
Mendel's Demon: Gene Justice and the Complexity of Life
Mark Ridley
348pp, Weidenfeld
£20
Buy it at BOL

Although this book, like everything else these days, has genes in the title, Mark Ridley, an Oxford biologist, is at the far end of the profession from the genetic engineers. He and his kind represent what might be called genetic physicists: people who look for the deep theoretical underpinnings behind the immediately visible quirks of nature. In fact, this book is an attempt to explain everything living that we can see without a microscope, so it's not lacking in ambition. The title alludes to Maxwell's Demon, an imaginary being devised by James Clerk Maxwell who distorts the normal processes of thermodynamics to make a lawful but very unlikely order; Ridley's version names the processes that maintain complex information in DNA against the efforts of time and chance to garble or degrade it.

The central question he considers is why there should be anything on earth more complex than bacteria; bacteria do very well, thank you. According to some calculations, they constitute the majority of living things on earth; they had the place to themselves for about 1.5 billion years before the first more complex cells appeared, and according to Ridley it was nearly another 1.5 billion years of more or less exciting amoebae before the first animals appeared. What took us so long?

The answer he derives sweeps over these billions of years, but comes simply enough from two founding principles of selfish-gene theory: that life is essentially a process of copying information contained in strings of chemicals - usually DNA - and that the competition to be copied between different strings of DNA, or genes, is unceasing and pursued with the utmost ingenuity. This language of agency is very difficult to avoid, although Ridley is scrupulously careful not to anthropomorphise his genes. Some people have argued that the evolution of complexity is in some sense inevitable in a Darwinian world, if only because all the simple niches in it fill up fairly soon. Certainly, Ridley believes that there will almost always be an advantage available for a creature more complex - by which he means having more genes - than any predecessor. So this makes the time it took to develop creatures capable of exploiting smaller ones all the more puzzling.

The difficulty, as he sees it, is not that such creatures might evolve in the first place; mutations are common enough that some helpful ones are bound to appear over millions of years simply because it's difficult for cells to copy very long strings of DNA accurately as they divide. However, this simplicity also makes it very difficult for creatures of interesting complexity to maintain themselves. In the first few chapters Ridley proves with elegant calculations that humans are evolutionarily impossible: we ought to disintegrate as a species in a welter of copying mistakes and degenerating mutations.

The process has been observed in artificially pampered fruit flies; the worry, in one form or another, is as old as genetics. To paraphrase Goldsmith: ill fares the land, to hastening ills a prey, where health accumulates and genes decay. This genetic fragility is why Ridley believes that human cloning is impossible on any large scale. Despite all this elegant theory, we're still here; and most of the book is taken up with a detailed and fascinating account of the ways in which sex and gender may have evolved so as to guarantee the stability of complex animals (this is not just a matter of ensuring that the DNA is copied accurately enough through the generations, and repaired where possible). Sex and gender are two different things, and in Ridley's account they serve two different purposes.

Sex, or the exchange of genetic material, is known between bacteria: it allows the correction of copying mistakes. Gender, on the other hand, follows from the accident that plants and animals are made up of cells that are themselves more complex than bacterial cells. They have inner nuclei, in which most of the DNA is stored (unlike bacteria, who keep theirs slopping around anyhow). Gender results from the fact that when two such cells have sex, the DNA outside the nucleus of one is either stripped away or destroyed. From this simple asymmetry, cells have specialised to be either sperm or eggs and their bearers to be either male or female. This made possible the baroque multiplications and divisions that chromosomes undergo when sex cells are formed, and these in turn ensure that genes must cooperate with each other or fail to be copied.

This isn't really a popular-science book. It is elegantly written, very informative and free of mathematics, but it suffers from its donnish virtues. Ridley writes like a good lecturer, and he makes the reader feel like a good undergraduate. But even if he is too scrupulous to succeed in a marketplace full of loud certainties, he carries off the traditional pop-science ending in fine style. This is the point at which the author suddenly expands his conclusions to take in the whole universe and the future of mankind; true to the form, Mendel's Demon ends with a very funny riff on the mating habits of angels.

 Andrew Brown is the author of Darwin Wars (see www.darwinwars.com).

This made possible the baroque multiplications and divisions that chromosomes undergo when sex cells are formed, and these in turn ensure that genes must cooperate with each other or fail to be copied. This isn't really a popular-science book. It is elegantly written, very informative and free of mathematics, but it suffers from its donnish virtues. Ridley writes like a good lecturer, and he makes the reader feel like a good undergraduate. But even if he is too scrupulous to succeed in a marketplace full of loud certainties, he carries off the traditional pop-science ending in fine style. This is the point at which the author suddenly expands his conclusions to take in the whole universe and the future of mankind; true to the form, Mendel's Demon ends with a very funny riff on the mating habits of angels.  Andrew Brown is the author of Darwin Wars (see www.darwinwars.com).

webTitle: Review: Tom Clancy and Andy McNab

fields.headline: Boy zone
fields.standfirst: Chris Petit  takes on action men Tom Clancy and Andy McNab
fields.trailText: Chris Petit takes on action men Tom Clancy and Andy McNab
fields.body:
The Bear and the Dragon
Tom Clancy
1040pp, Michael Joseph
£17.99
Buy it at BOL

Firewall
Andy McNab
411pp, Bantam
£16.99
Buy it at BOL

Tom Clancy was always something of a cold war man, and given its absence he does the next best thing: makes up another one, this time China versus the USA, with Russia in the middle. Russia, in economic disarray, has discovered large deposits of oil and gold in Siberia. China, being cash-poor after an overspend on defence, is keen to settle a trade agreement with the US, although there are diplomatic complications. China is in dispute over US recognition of Taiwan, while its own record on human rights and enforced population control is deplored in the west.

Meanwhile, spies monitor each other's secrets and the Americans achieve a notable coup with the penetration of a top-level Chinese secretary. Clancy's scenario is ambitious: to show how the various facets of industry, trade, the military, espionage and government work in foreign affairs, and what happens when the diplomatic process breaks down and military aggression takes over. When John Chinaman - as Clancy so quaintly calls him - finds himself cornered by circumstance, he decides to plunder Siberia for its newly discovered raw materials, which leads to a ground war and the threat of a Chinese nuclear strike.

This synopsis is offered merely as proof that the book has been read. Clancy - a terrible old windbag - takes more than 1,000 pages to tell a story that should have taken half that; given his top-selling status, he has clearly progressed beyond any kind of editing. With its blockbuster cast, wodges of undigested research and useless insider information, endless acronyms and countless dreary minor anecdotes, the book is clunkily authentic and insistent on leaving nothing to the imagination. Clancy comes into his own as a techno-bore, but in spite of all the hardware authenticity - and plausibility of the central scenario - as an objective political analyst, he is in the world of Boys' Own. The general tone is one of old-fashioned colonial propaganda: devious Oriental control freaks versus the responsible statesmanship and reasoned informality of US government (the president calls his wife "Babe"; the head of the CIA calls her husband "Honeybunny"). Clancy's president is an anodyne Kennedy retread, minus infidelities, while the Russians - now that we know them better - turn out to be soulful, reliable and, well, not wily. "He was a Russian patriot," we are solemnly informed in tourist-brochure prose, "who loved the very smell of Russian soil, the birch forests, the vodka and the borscht."

The writing - never any great shakes to start with and at best done in a style that could be called runaway word processor - is by now on full autopilot, and readers who haven't already quit from exhaustion might get the sneaking suspicion that the author too has long jumped ship. From here on few sentences stand up to inspection, particularly those relating to routine and time (most of the book): "The morning sun that lit up Beijing had done the same to Siberia even earlier in the day."

The Bear and the Dragon lends new evidence to the theory that Clancy is in reality a CIA committee designed to produce US propaganda in the form of popular entertainment. In its bulk and lack of conspicuous authorship, the work is clearly beyond the scope of a single writer, just as it is equally obvious that the jacket photo of "Tom Clancy" is in fact Big Ron Atkinson moonlighting as an author double.

After Clancy, Andy McNab is a breeze: Blue Peter for big boys - "Here's a bomb I made earlier". McNab is on-the-ground, hands-on and presenter-led with a hero who can manage a bit of fieldcraft, is professionally efficient and privately a mess; prone to dodgy women and sentimental about children. Like Clancy, McNab is a secure franchise, an authentic storyteller on the grounds of his been-there, done-that experiences in the SAS, thanks to which he is able to dispose of the notion of writing as a poncy business. His language favours the vernacular, and any evidence of interior life is rendered only in terms of the accepted visceral response, as in "gutted".

McNab's plots, which are efficient and uncomplicated, could be primly summarised as: the best-laid plans go awry, so get out of that. Yet, for all his reliance on formula, he never emerges as a cynical writer and with this novel shows signs of studying the craft. Firewall is essentially an update of Len Deighton's Billion Dollar Brain , down to its Scandinavian locations and computer plot - a debt belatedly admitted when McNab writes "I felt like Harry Palmer in one of those Michael Caine films from the 60s" - and it succeeds in capturing something of early Deighton's insolent, other-ranks tone.

webTitle: Review:  The Hill Bachelors  by William Trevor

fields.headline: Comfort of strangers
fields.standfirst: Aisling Foster  acclaims Ireland's modern Chekhov, William Trevor, for his latest book The Hill Bachelors
fields.trailText: Aisling Foster acclaims Ireland's modern Chekhov, William Trevor, for his latest book The Hill Bachelors
fields.body:
The Hill Bachelors
William Trevor
256pp, Viking
£15.99
Buy it at BOL

In his complete control of the short-story form, William Trevor follows in the tradition of Chekhov, but his material often swerves towards Dostoevskian lower depths: murder, paedophilia and terrorism, as well as the strands that bind families and friends, are the stuff of this collection. Each story reveals lives cut open with the precision of a surgeon's scalpel, every scene is probed with the thrill of a torch through a keyhole. Roving between Ireland, England and France, the author writes from the minds of his characters, understanding the kind of reticence that damages as often as it heals. In their fear of speaking up, nobody is completely innocent. Whether they are young or old, clever or stupid, the silence between individuals echoes with words they are unable to utter, as well as an abiding sense of guilt at their failure to do so.

Yet there is hope in that silence. Trevor's characters are not the victims of the classic Irish short story. They are saved by a perception that even if they fail, something good may emerge from the mess they have made. In "Death of a Professor", the wife of an ageing Oxford don is unable to break the news that his obituary has been mischievously published in the morning papers. Her attempt to shield him from the hoax leads to further humiliation among his colleagues. Forgiven, she realises she cannot even tell her husband that she loves him for his wisdom: "Not brains, they all had brains. Not skill. Not knowing everything, for they knew less than they imagined. His wisdom is almost indefinable, what a roadworker might have, a cinema usher or a clergyman or a child."

In another story, a child actor hopes that her part in a film will bring her estranged parents together again. She is playing a paedophile's victim, the ramifications of which are never explained to her. Told "we're into compassion here", she must act in such a way that the audience "will feel the pity thing" for her molester. She becomes increasingly frightened of the man playing the role, and when drama becomes reality keeping quiet seems the only way to go on. Another secret condemns a young Irish labourer in London to a lifetime of silence. The confusion of loneliness and a patchy camaraderie of strangers have drawn him into involvement with the IRA; when he finally confronts the implications of what he is doing, he knows his moment of courage can never be shared.

Some of Trevor's characters do not recognise the difference their decisions can make. In "Of the Cloth", an aged Donegal rector attends the funeral of his gardener in the local Catholic church. He is impressed by the apparent confidence of the congregation, comparing it to his own disappearing religion, whose designation, Church of Ireland, "had long ago seemed too imposing a title, ludicrous almost in its claim". That night, when he is visited by the young priest, they find common ground in a shared love for their country and the sense of change that is affecting both their lives. The priest had come to thank the rector for his protection of a parishioner, "and by saying it had found a solace for himself. Small gestures mattered now, and statements in the dark were a way to keep the faith, as the monks had kept it in an Ireland that was different too."

Only the story of a medieval monk's road to Damascus fails to convince. Trevor has respect for his subject, but seems unable to empathise with so much blind faith. Personal insights offer more comfort. In "Against the Odds", a Belfast con woman arrives in a small country town just as the Northern Irish peace process is beginning. When she selects a tragically widowed turkey farmer as her next soft target, she "felt as she often felt when she got to this stage in a bit of business - that some shadow of herself was having its way with her". In another story, a middle-aged couple decide to leave London for the country. They are upset when a bachelor friend appears to imagine that he might move in with them. The idea is farcical, but the wife finds herself pleading his case, admitting that this hopeless misfit harbours an attraction to her and that "you can pity a child ... no matter what a child is like".

In Trevor's world, even self-delusion can be tinged with a miraculous shaft of grace. His universe is illuminated by an imagination that is rich and various, while the structure of each piece draws you into the next like a fugue. And this modern master is never more Chekhovian than in the way that rereading promises subtleties still not guessed and patterns that will emerge when the first frisson of satisfaction is over.
