fields.headline: The heart is the Highland
fields.standfirst: Gaelic and modern, homegrown and far-flung: Scottish poetry has a rich legacy
fields.trailText: Gaelic and modern, homegrown and far-flung: Scottish poetry has a rich legacy
fields.body:
The New Penguin Book of Scottish Verse

ed by Robert Crawford, Mick Imlah

554pp, Penguin

£20
Buy it at BOL

100 20th-Century Scottish Poems

ed by Douglas Dunn

96pp, Faber

£4.99
Buy it at BOL

No Great Mischief

Alistair MacLeod

262pp, Jonathan Cape

£15.99
Buy it at BOL

One of the best anthologies of all is John Buchan's The Northern Muse, a selection of verse in "the Scots vernacular". It appeared in 1924, at the very time when Hugh MacDiarmid was writing the lyrics in "synthetic Scots" that were to bring Buchan's taste into question. But there's hardly a piece in the book that doesn't give pleasure; Buchan chose only what he liked, and it shows. Pleasure, in the sense of editorial predilection, stands at the opposite pole of representativeness in the work of anthologists, who can seem to be facing a choice between putting in what they like and putting in what other people have liked (and what their friends have written). This doesn't mean that The Northern Muse fails as a record of what lots of people have liked, but Buchan is unScottishly keen, as some might think, on pleasuring himself.

Few of his choices are to be found in the New Penguin Book of Scottish Verse compiled by Robert Crawford and Mick Imlah, a selection more interested than Buchan's in inclusiveness. But this is a good book too: the poet editors are attentive to the verse of their contemporaries and to translations from Gaelic and Latin (excellent ones by Crawford himself, including a banishment "knee-deep in shite" to the croft and the plough, from the Latin of Shakespeare's contemporary Arthur Johnston). It has its "finds" and its serendipity, as in the case of gentle Allan Ramsay's little-known dying words or "Last Advice" of the granitic madam of an Edinburgh brothel.

The 16th century yields a find in the vengeful Mrs MacGregor of Glenstrae, on a clanship matter, a Campbell crime: "May sickness kill my father/ And Colin die of the plague." And 100 years on, there's Francis Sempill of Beltrees, whose Maggie Lauder is told by a passing piper: "My name is Rob the Ranter:/ The lassies loup as they were daft,/ When I blaw up my chanter." Marion Bernstein of Victorian Paisley is soundly opposed to blood sports, and there's a welcome MacGonagall.

The scarcity here of Buchan's selections testifies to the richness of the heritage and to a difference of opinion concerning the black hole which is often felt to have opened up in 19th-century Scottish literature, whose Kailyard school, with its vernacular and its rural settings, can be seen as a response to the subordination of Scots speech promoted by parliamentary union and urban and industrial development. MacDiarmid set himself to cut out the soft heart of the "mawkish" Kailyard, and the impact of his early poems drew Scotland towards modernist practice, where a dislike of Victorian sentimentality was routinely aired.

Country life of the sort embodied in Burns's poems, write the New Penguin editors, "shrank smartly into the margins as industry took root". Smartly? MacDiarmid spent most of his life in the country, and his early poems are set there. Writers and others went on living there, and the version of pastoral that arose during these dark years and on into the new century produced valuable poems, several of them by upper-class women. The accomplished Violet Jacob, daughter of the 18th Laird of Dun, is rife in Buchan, but not in the New Penguin or in Douglas Dunn's successive anthologies of Scottish verse.

Two of the most popular poems of the northern 19th century were James Hogg's "Kilmeny", in which a pure young girl goes to fairyland and experiences an overflight of Scotland and its history, and his friend William Laidlaw's "Lucy's Flittin". Extracts from "Kilmeny" are provided in the New Penguin. The Laidlaw, a Kailyard precursor dear to Buchan's project, is omitted. It is a fine poem, and an intensely sentimental one. Why does Servant Lucy leave everyone on the farm in tears? Two charged and equivocal lines may be the answer to that ("ettled" means meant, or ordained): "If I wasna ettled to be ony better,/ Then what gars me wish ony better to be?" Lucy may have been looking to improve herself.

Hogg's many poems are thinly represented here. I turned to "The Witch O' Fife" hoping for the exhilarating night-rider ballad of that name done in the synthetic, antique Scots he devised for his ballads. What I found was a lyrical appendage to this ballad with a sprinkling of Scots words. The editors sometimes seem a little leery of Scots. Stevenson's lively vernacular poems, of interest to Buchan, are not among the 10 of his that are picked (double the tally for Dunbar, but well worth picking, admittedly).

A selection by Douglas Dunn of 20th-century Scottish verse appeared towards the end of that century, in 1992. Here for the hip pocket is a digest of that anthology, 100 20th-Century Scottish Poems, with choices revised and a string of recent poems added. One recent poem by Donny O'Rourke, about a father who mends grandfather clocks, chimes with an earlier one by Angus Martin, who says "I am a Scottish wood collector" - two enjoyable occupational lyrics. Another appealing poem, Mick Imlah's "Goldilocks", is less straightforward. It is in both Dunns, but in the slim one stanzas absent from the parent anthology are restored or added. A galloping outdoors metre is applied to a state of inwardness, as the poet discovers a Scots-speaking tramp doppelgänger in his Oxford college bed. In the Dunn book of 1992 are four poems by Alasdair Maclean, a Highland poet from Fife who is cross at times, and Larkin-like. In the digest there are none, and none in the New Penguin either. This is a loss.

Another poet of that name is the Gael Sorley Maclean, whose symbolist elegy "Hallaig"- translated by himself from Gaelic into English - no anthologist of the period would be likely to leave out. It is one of the high points in Scottish literature of the last century, and a reminder of how complex, in one important respect, its achievements are: they are in more than one language and hail from more than one part of the world. All three of these anthologies acknowledge the existence of a Scottish diaspora and of a Scottish complexity.

Among the flowering of Scottish prose and poetry that has taken place in the last few years can be identified, without presumption or piracy, an unforgettable work of the last few weeks - the novel No Great Mischief by a Canadian of Gaelic stock, Alistair MacLeod. It's about family feeling and clanship, it prefers a harsh maritime countryside to the city, and it shares some of the starkness of Mrs MacGregor of Glenstrae. MacLeod's rural world - with its rigours and dangers, its duties and skills - also has something of the world of Odysseus. The sun moves on "its appointed journey" through the sky. Here is a lordless, lairdless Nova Scotian Ithaca. It is both a Canadian book and a Scottish book; there are moments when Gaelic utterance makes it bilingual. When the narrator's twin sister turns up in Scotland, she is recognised as one of theirs; she belongs "here". The heart is Highland.

Scots and English have been described as languages of the heart and the head respectively - categories mentioned in MacLeod's novel. It makes more sense to describe them as dialects of the same language. But it should also be said that this is a language of many dialects, both literary and demotic, and that in the work of many writers Scots and English are one.

A galloping outdoors metre is applied to a state of inwardness, as the poet discovers a Scots-speaking tramp doppelgänger in his Oxford college bed. In the Dunn book of 1992 are four poems by Alasdair Maclean, a Highland poet from Fife who is cross at times, and Larkin-like. In the digest there are none, and none in the New Penguin either. This is a loss. Another poet of that name is the Gael Sorley Maclean, whose symbolist elegy "Hallaig"- translated by himself from Gaelic into English - no anthologist of the period would be likely to leave out. It is one of the high points in Scottish literature of the last century, and a reminder of how complex, in one important respect, its achievements are: they are in more than one language and hail from more than one part of the world. All three of these anthologies acknowledge the existence of a Scottish diaspora and of a Scottish complexity. Among the flowering of Scottish prose and poetry that has taken place in the last few years can be identified, without presumption or piracy, an unforgettable work of the last few weeks - the novel No Great Mischief by a Canadian of Gaelic stock, Alistair MacLeod. It's about family feeling and clanship, it prefers a harsh maritime countryside to the city, and it shares some of the starkness of Mrs MacGregor of Glenstrae. MacLeod's rural world - with its rigours and dangers, its duties and skills - also has something of the world of Odysseus. The sun moves on "its appointed journey" through the sky. Here is a lordless, lairdless Nova Scotian Ithaca. It is both a Canadian book and a Scottish book; there are moments when Gaelic utterance makes it bilingual. When the narrator's twin sister turns up in Scotland, she is recognised as one of theirs; she belongs "here". The heart is Highland. Scots and English have been described as languages of the heart and the head respectively - categories mentioned in MacLeod's novel. It makes more sense to describe them as dialects of the same language. But it should also be said that this is a language of many dialects, both literary and demotic, and that in the work of many writers Scots and English are one.

fields.headline: Thinking for England
fields.standfirst: A controversial academic and apologist for the political right, he's been a lightning rod for criticism and abuse by the left for more than 30 years. His views on nationality and hunting still cause outrage. But now he's written an elegy for his country, and it's won   him some surprising allies. By Nicholas Wroe

fields.body:
For Roger Scruton, as for so many of his generation, the Paris riots of May 1968 were the defining political moment of his life. He was in the Latin Quarter when students tore up the cobblestones to hurl at the riot police. His friends overturned cars and uprooted lamp-posts to erect the barricades. Representatives of his own discipline, old philosophers like Marx and new ones like Foucault, were providing the intellectual fuel for the fire raging on the ground.

As he watched the events unfold from his apartment window, and listened to his friends, drunk on revolutionary hope and excitement, Scruton found his own emotions and opinions crystallising. "I suddenly realised that I was on the other side," he says. "What I saw was an unruly mob of self-indulgent middle-class hooligans. When I asked my friends what they wanted, what were they trying to achieve, all I got back was this ludicrous Marxist gobbledegook. I was disgusted by it, and thought there must be a way back to the defence of western civilisation against these things. That's when I became a conservative. I knew I wanted to conserve things rather than pull them down."

His efforts to do this over the next three decades have made him one of the most contentious figures in British public life. As an academic, journalist and writer he has been a lightning rod for criticism and abuse from the left. While he has a reputation as a first class professional philosopher among other academics of all political persuasions, he has regularly been shouted down in universities and prevented from speaking.

His books have been unmercifully slaughtered by reviewers and his pronouncements on society mocked. He is accused of being a grammar-school boy in thrall to the upper classes: "it is all a bit like Charles Ryder in Brideshead", says one observer. The fact that he used to go fox-hunting wearing Enoch Powell's old hunting clothes - the jacket split the first time he used it - says it all for many others. "I do ask myself why I make people so enraged, because I only ever say what I think. And while I know it might not be everyone's point of view, that doesn't seem particularly intolerable to me."

Part of the reason is, of course, straightforward political disagreement. As an academic in the 1980s, for instance, he did not make himself popular among his peers by defending education cuts. But this doesn't explain the venomous intensity of the attacks. For this, one must look at his interventions in social and cultural issues, where gut reactions can count for more than the sophistication of the argument. One such issue is national identity, which has increasingly entered the cultural and intellectual mainstream. Britishness has become a legitimate subject for discussion with two recent debates - one trivial, one less so - flickering across the public consciousness; the Runnymede Trust report on the future of multi-ethnic Britain, and whether the England football team should have a foreign coach.

It wasn't always this way. The incendiary combination of nationality, race, history and culture was until recently something most sensible commentators avoided. But not Scruton. In 1982, as editor of the conservative philosophical journal The Salisbury Review, he published an article called Education And Race by Ray Honeyford, a Bradford headmaster. The gist was that multi-cultural education was actually harmful for immigrant children.

"All hell broke loose," recalls Scruton. "But Ray Honeyford is not racist. He spent his whole life teaching Pakistani children in Bradford, trying to do the best for them against their parents and the mullahs. He recognised the terrible conflicts. But then, in the 80s, any questioning of the left-liberal orthodoxy could only have a racist motivation, or be seen to give succour to racists. I'd argue that not addressing these issues gives succour to racists. But it got us into terrible trouble."

His latest book, England: An Elegy tries to show England as reflected in its own ideals, he says. "I know ideals aren't realities, but they do influence reality - social, legal, political, cultural." Its reception shows the change in mood. Of course he gets his share of sneering reviews but there is a recognition of his breadth of reference and scholarship and he wins less grudging support from some surprising quarters.

Labour Peer Melvyn Bragg describes it as "an elegant and moving book", before claiming Scruton "is excellent at bringing common sense to bear on the distressing frenzy which has overtaken those whose views of England can only be doom-struck and void of all praise." Anthony Barnett, the founding director of Charter 88, who also has written on Englishness from a radical perspective, has worked with Scruton. Together they set up the Town and Country Forum to bring a non-partisan approach to discussion of urban and rural conflicts. He praises Scruton's willingness to engage.

"People who take these things seriously are trying not to think in received political terms any more," Barnett says. "Agri-business, medical ethics, environmental questions can't just be thought about in terms of right and left. Even on a red-flag issue like hunting there is no simple left position." Scruton himself, for instance, is in favour of higher fuel taxes although he is not surprised that their implementation was so contentious.

But for all this apparent reasonableness, he still puts himself out there to be shot at. Shortly after he first became a father, two years ago, at 54, he wrote a tongue-in-cheek article about childrearing. "It goes without saying that Sam will not enjoy his childhood", he said before going on to anticipate their "nightly readings of the classics and our home performances of Shakespeare," and the young Sam, like John Stuart Mill, would be reading Greek by the age of six. The Guardian Diary responded by launching the Samuel Scruton Playstation appeal, but he was duly castigated and mocked elsewhere for his antediluvianism.

Again, this hasn't stopped him writing about his own experiences, and his last two books have contained significant autobiographical content. The opening lines of his historical and social celebration, On Hunting, said his life divides into three parts. "In the first, I was wretched; in the second, ill at ease; in the third, hunting." In England: An Elegy, his starting point is himself. "TS Eliot said writing autobiography was, 'imposing order on and eliciting order in, one's life'. It did bring order to my life which I needed."

Scruton was born in 1944. His father was a left-wing working-class Mancunian who became a teacher. Jack Scruton hated the upper class and loved the English countryside. Scruton's mother, Beryl Claris - always called Johnny - was a more genteel figure who read romantic fiction and, "entertained blue-rinsed ladies who appeared miraculously almost as soon as he [father] was out the door."

Roger and his two sisters were brought up in Buckinghamshire, in Marlow and High Wycombe, and he remembers, "a sort of Lawrentian class-tension between my parents. There were terrible rows which frightened the children. My father went through a very depressed period - partly through not getting anywhere with his career but also something deeper - about the time I was entering puberty. Life at home wasn't very good and I had really left by the time I was 16 and didn't go back until after Cambridge when I went to look after my mother when she was dying."

In both On Hunting and England: An Elegy, Scruton continually nags at his father's viewpoint and arguments. "My father was a man of principle," he says, "who found his principles confirmed in the unremitting failure which they brought on him. But my personality was significantly shaped by him. He represented to me a personality that was quintessentially English in the determination to be himself and entertain his own cantankerous views. But he also represents a view of the world against which I found myself at an early age in rebellion."

In fact Scruton was on the left at school, High Wycombe Grammar. But even then he didn't go along with "all the fashionable causes of the day", and was shocked when a friend was imprisoned after an Aldermaston march. Scruton has little but praise for the school, which the headmaster self-consciously modelled on Eton. Many of the staff had been in the war and in the colonial service; the children were clever and keen; but Scruton says he wasn't the brightest boy. "There was one who could play all the Beethoven sonatas. When he was 14 he introduced me to Oswald Spengler's Decline Of The West. But many grammar schools were like that then. There was a ferment of intellectual activity as we explored the post-war world."

For all this, he says he refused to fit in. He shunned the cadets and sports, played bass guitar when he was 16, and was into the Beatles. He was eventually expelled, although only after he had won a scholarship to Cambridge. "The headmaster had wanted to throw me out for a while but he recognised that I was good for the statistics. We put on this play and he came and saw the stage on fire with a half-naked girl on it. His solution was to expel me."

In his gap year - as it then wasn't called - Scruton washed-up in a Lyons corner house on the Mile End Road, east London, hitchhiked to Greece and then to Egypt before getting a boat to Lebanon, where he ran out of money. He couldn't work his passage home on British boats because he wasn't in the union - "my first experience of the trade unions which my father admired" - so ended up on a Norwegian vessel carrying potatoes.

When he got to Cambridge, in 1962, his adventures made him feel much older than his contemporaries, and he changed courses on the first day, from natural sciences to philosophy. He says he was not political. "But this was pre-1968. There was an old idea of education that prevailed. I went to lectures on Kant and Hume and logic and literature and I couldn't tell you what my lecturers' political beliefs were."

In his new book he claims that England died about the time he was at university. From his father he got a pessimism about the fate of rural England and had a melancholy sense that western civilisation was doomed. "But like anyone who was brought up on Leavis, I had a tremendous belief in English culture and literature. I never though there was an alternative to what we had inherited. You either learn to inherit it properly or you become disinherited. I always thought the oriental faction - the hashish-smoking people with pony tails and dreamy eyes - were escapists. They hadn't found an alternative but were just deceiving themselves."

Although destined for an academic career, a life at Cambridge didn't appeal. "It was then quasi-monastic. There weren't many women around, there was this mist of nostalgic pederasty that hung over it all." He had ambitions to be a writer but took a job at the University of Bordeaux where he rented a cottage in the foothills of the Pyrennees. He then moved to Rome, where he wrote a novel that was never published, and returned in 1969 to Peterhouse, Cambridge, as a research fellow in aesthetics.

Two years later he moved to Birkbeck College, London. He was made professor of aesthetics in 1985 and stayed at the college until 1992. "When I went to Birkbeck I was already in a conservative frame of mind," he says. "My colleagues regarded me with great suspicion. The waves of 1968 had just reached London University. There were attempts to introduce more Foucault and Marx on to the curriculum. I had been brought up in Cambridge with this completely de-politicised view of what philosophy should be, so was obviously against all this."

While at Birkbeck he read for the Bar as a fall-back position. "I thought I might have to get out of this, and the law seemed a career where conservatives might be welcomed. I thought I ought to have an exit route." AC Grayling was a colleague in the Birkbeck philosophy department and says Scruton is a very good professional academic philosopher "and a wonderful teacher of philosophy. The pedagogic works he wrote for students and the general public are clear, lucid and accurate. It is partly because of Roger's presence that the department is one of the best in the country." Grayling, who says he and Scruton disagree politically, also says what a "very charming and somewhat sweet man," he is in person. "This rather glum, obtuse figure who pops up every now again to say 'bring back hanging', or something, is not really characteristic of him."

Ralph Walker of Magdalen College, Oxford, agrees about Scruton's academic stature, but claims that what he tries to do, at least part of the time, is to stimulate people. "Some of the views he expresses in conversation or print are not necessarily views he would hold to the bitter end. They are often put in a provocative form for people to think about. Roger irritates people who find they don't like the position he's taken, but can't argue back. That can show itself as anger or accusations of extremism."

This was Scruton's "ill at ease" period, made harder by a failed marriage. He had met Danielle Laffitte, a student, in France. After a long on-off affair they married in 1973, but were divorced in 1979. She still lives in England and they meet occasionally. "It wasn't a very happy experience. I think marriages are much less stable if you live together first," he says. "You don't have that sense of the metaphysical transformation from one condition to the next. The rite of passage is lost."

He and Danielle didn't have children because there was, "not sufficient commitment. Also there was selfishness. Perhaps if we had [children] we would have stayed together." Scruton did not become a father until two years ago when he and his second wife, Sophie Jeffreys, had Samuel. A second child, Lucy, was born last August. Jeffreys, an architectural historian, is 28 years his junior. They live contentedly on a farm in Wiltshire. Scruton also has a two-room apartment in Albany, the exclusive lodgings on London's Piccadilly. His rooms used to be the late MP Alan Clark's servant quarters.

As Birkbeck only operated in the evenings, it gave Scruton time to pursue a career as a writer cum journalist as well as moving into the world of politics. He says he was appalled by the Heath government. "There seemed to be a lot of thinking to be done and no-one was doing it." Along with the MP Hugh Fraser, Jonathan Aitken and academic John Casey, Scruton founded the Conservative Philosophy Group. Antonia Fraser, then married to Hugh Fraser, the Tory MP, and herself on the left, has been a friend since that time. Through her, Scruton got to know her present husband, Harold Pinter; this proved useful when Scruton was in financial difficulties.

"Wine has been the most important factor in my life, apart from women and song, but it can be an expensive taste. When I was a don at Cambridge I could buy it at cost and I bought a lot of 1961 clarets. But I fell on hard times and couldn't pay my tax bill so I sold the lot to Harold Pinter. He was the only person who would trust me that these bottles really were what I told him they were, because all the labels had come off. He was just marrying Antonia and wanted a proper cellar. He was very generous and did invite me to drink some of it afterwards." Scruton is often associated with Margaret Thatcher's reinvigoration of the Conservative party through a red-blooded commitment to the market in the mid 1970s. But he says that process happened quite independently of anything he was doing. "Thatcher was completely indifferent to our kind of conservative philosophy. I'd never heard of her gurus - people like Alan Walters and Alfred Sherman."

Scruton was associated with writers at the Spectator and Telegraph, exponents of a more settled, patrician conservatism. "It was about a subdued sense of the importance of history and tradition, of doing things in an orderly way. Small-scale improvements. The market economy was a good thing but it wasn't the foundation of social order, and should be heavily qualified by all the traditions that enable people to live with each other rather than just compete. But under Thatcher it was completely the free market."

His association with Thatcher didn't do him any good. "I was identified in the intellectual world with this terrible woman - who I never knew, although I do now - and was blamed for everything she did, without me knowing what she would do." He did attempt to get on the Tory candidates' list in 1978 but was turned down - "too bookish". Soon after, he began a crash course in very practical politics. In 1979 he was invited to an aesthetics conference in Krakow, Poland. It was just after the election of a Polish Pope and just before the birth of Solidarity. "Culpably, I had never engaged with communism," he says.

"When the Prague Spring happened in 1968, I so identified it with the ghastly students I'd seen in Paris I didn't have much sympathy, which I now realise was a terrible wrong. It showed a lack of moral imagination on my part and unfortunately I never acted upon it."

His visit to Poland disturbed him. He then went on to Prague to give a secret lecture with the dissident Czech philosopher Julius Tomin. After the lecture he accompanied Tomin back to his apartment. Waiting for them at the entrance was a secret policeman who refused to let Scruton in and then threw him down the stairs. From then on Scruton was a marked man. He was eventually arrested when two policeman stepped out from behind a bush in Brno and soon after he was thrown out of the country.

"I realised that this was a situation that was complete outside anything in my experience," he says "And at the same time this was a place which was dear to my heart. The intellectual life was genuinely dangerous. They were being put in jail by a left-wing police force."

Along with other British academics, mostly from Oxford, he began to work with the Jan Hus educational trust - named after the 13th century Czech reformer and martyr - to provide books, support samizdat production and teach courses. The foreign office had been lukewarm about their activities until Malcolm Rifkind became minister of state with responsibility for eastern Europe in 1982. "The foreign office's job was to maintain links with government," explains Rifkind, "but I thought we could have links with unofficial bodies as well and should make contact with dissidents." He lent support to Scruton and others and commends their bravery. "Travelling as an individual in quite hostile terrain, they were putting themselves at risk."

Scruton learned Czech and threw himself in to the culture. Pavel Bratinka, a nuclear physicist in Prague who, because of his opposition to the regime, was forced to work as cleaner on the metro, attended Scruton's seminars. After communism collapsed he held several ministerial posts in the new government. "As a thinker whose point of departure was conservative he was very important here," explains Bratinka. "His reputation in academic circles is very high. They know that what he did was for no personal reward and we are extremely grateful to him. I hope after he dies they name a street for him here in Prague."

After communism collapsed, to Bratinka's huge surprise, the alumni of his classes were suddenly in charge. Scruton formed a consultancy firm to make contacts between western businesses and the new governments. However, his friends' power was short-lived, and he is depressed that the communists hadn't gone away after all. "They worked out that they would do far better if they gave up the nonsense of political power and just seized the assets of the country instead. They privatised the whole economy to themselves."

He says he had no hope that communism would go away. "I thought that perhaps we were keeping the light of learning burning just a little longer than it would have otherwise. But it was the right thing to do, and you do get comfort from doing something that is morally right. As there was no way this could be publicly known, that was the only motive for doing it. It was hugely important to me." Scruton was subsequently awarded the Czech republic's highest civilian honour for his work.

During the 1980s he was having a very hard time. He says his columns in the Times and editorship of the Salisbury Review had identified him as an intellectual traitor, a rightwinger and a person of ill-repute. He then tried writing a novel, Francesca, about a grammar-school boy who falls for an upper-class girl, which reviewers rushed to annihilate. "It felt unjust," he says. "I don't mind people criticising me. I'm bound to be criticised because I say strong things that are controversial, although I do try to back them up. But that is not the same as being mocked and made to look ridiculous by people who don't understand what you are saying."

So shaken was Scruton by the reviews of Francesca that he stopped writing fiction. Instead he turned his creative energies to music. He is a very good pianist and, perhaps surprisingly, has a keen appreciation of 20th century music. He wrote an opera, The Minister, about a politician who sacrifices his personal life to ambition. It was staged in the Czech republic and in Oxford.

His other response to the relentless criticism in this country was to accept the post of professor of philosophy at Boston University in the US. While he says that many of the students weren't very good, "those that were good were fantastic. Especially those from the bible belt, who were a gift to someone like me. They had that residue of European culture which most young people in England no longer have. American culture can be what you want: you can make around yourself a circle of people that are your type." This is more difficult to do in England. He claims English culture has become mediocratised in the last 10 years: the legitimisation of pop music and football as genuine manifestations of the nations culture being prime examples.

His next novel, Xanthippic Dialogues, written in dialogue form about Plato's women, was better received, and encouraged Scruton to return home full-time. "I'd found an idiom that synthesised my philosophical side and my fiction side. I always think that a world view is incomplete if it can't be embodied in some way in the human situation. This makes Shakespeare into a truly great philosopher.

You can explore his characters and come across metaphysical layers and an archaeology of knowledge in each of them. I don't have the talent, but I would like to be a really serious philosopher who absolutely concretised his philosophy in individual characters in a situation that makes them live."

A C Grayling says that "the intellectual class and the academic class only fractionally overlap these days. Most academics are great experts in their field, but that's no guarantee they will be widely read and cultured individuals. Roger certainly is. He could see the wider picture and had an appreciation of the wider civilisation to go along with his academic and professional knowledge."

Scruton says he regrets as a young man "dithering" as to what type of intellectual he should be. "I knew since I had been in France that I was an intellectual in the French mould. I should be sitting in a cafe rather than a lecture room. But I was brought up on analytical philosophy. It isn't people showing off and trying to be incomprehensible and deep, but addressing real problems. It gets technical and dry and seems detached from ordinary human life and from culture and the spiritual - all the things you go to philosophy for as an amateur in the first place.

"Even though I knew it was a means, not an end, I should have been much more clear at the beginning that I would try to internalise that discipline but nevertheless be true to my cultural identity - somebody attempting to express a vision of human life rather than attacking tiny little problems within it. That's been hard but I think it has come together much more now."

There is still a way to go before he can expect people to disentangle the personality of the man from his work. He says he was astonished by the reaction to his jokey piece on child-rearing. "There was such a complete lack of a sense of humour in the people who responded to it. It was tongue-in-cheek. But of course irony can be difficult. That's why Socrates was put to death in Athens. His irony was not only a form of truth-telling but it made people inferior because they were. He brought them face to face with their own inferiority. No wonder they put him to death."

Life at a glance: Roger Vernon Scruton

Born: February 27 1944.

Education: High Wycombe Grammar School; Jesus College, Cambridge.

Married: 1973 Danielle Laffitte, divorced 1979; 1996 Sophie Jeffreys (one son, one daughter).

Career: Research fellow, Peterhouse, Cambridge 1969-71; Birkbeck College, lecturer in philosophy 1971-79, reader 1979-85, professor of aesthetics 1985-92; professor of philosophy Boston University 1992-95. Called to the Bar 1978; Editor Salisbury Review 1982- present.

Philosophy publications: Art And Imagination 1974; The Aesthetics Of Architecture 1979; Kant 1982; The Aesthetic Understanding 1983; Sexual Desire 1986; The Philosopher On Dover Beach 1990; An Intelligent Persons Guide To Philosophy 1996; The Aesthetics Of Music 1997.

Politics publications: The Meaning Of Conservatism 1980; The Politics Of Culture 1981; Dictionary Of Political Thought 1982; Thinkers Of The New Left 1985; Conservative Texts 1992.

Fiction: Fortnight's Anger 1981; Francesca 1991; A Dove Descending and Other Stories 1991; Xanthippic Dialogues 1993.

Others: An Intelligent Persons Guide to Modern Culture 1998; On Hunting 1998; Ed. Town and Country 1998; England; An Elegy 2000.

The opening lines of his historical and social celebration, On Hunting, said his life divides into three parts. "In the first, I was wretched; in the second, ill at ease; in the third, hunting." In England: An Elegy, his starting point is himself. "TS Eliot said writing autobiography was, 'imposing order on and eliciting order in, one's life'. It did bring order to my life which I needed." Scruton was born in 1944. His father was a left-wing working-class Mancunian who became a teacher. Jack Scruton hated the upper class and loved the English countryside. Scruton's mother, Beryl Claris - always called Johnny - was a more genteel figure who read romantic fiction and, "entertained blue-rinsed ladies who appeared miraculously almost as soon as he [father] was out the door." Roger and his two sisters were brought up in Buckinghamshire, in Marlow and High Wycombe, and he remembers, "a sort of Lawrentian class-tension between my parents. There were terrible rows which frightened the children. My father went through a very depressed period - partly through not getting anywhere with his career but also something deeper - about the time I was entering puberty. Life at home wasn't very good and I had really left by the time I was 16 and didn't go back until after Cambridge when I went to look after my mother when she was dying." In both On Hunting and England: An Elegy, Scruton continually nags at his father's viewpoint and arguments. "My father was a man of principle," he says, "who found his principles confirmed in the unremitting failure which they brought on him. But my personality was significantly shaped by him. He represented to me a personality that was quintessentially English in the determination to be himself and entertain his own cantankerous views. But he also represents a view of the world against which I found myself at an early age in rebellion." In fact Scruton was on the left at school, High Wycombe Grammar. But even then he didn't go along with "all the fashionable causes of the day", and was shocked when a friend was imprisoned after an Aldermaston march. Scruton has little but praise for the school, which the headmaster self-consciously modelled on Eton. Many of the staff had been in the war and in the colonial service; the children were clever and keen; but Scruton says he wasn't the brightest boy. "There was one who could play all the Beethoven sonatas. When he was 14 he introduced me to Oswald Spengler's Decline Of The West. But many grammar schools were like that then. There was a ferment of intellectual activity as we explored the post-war world." For all this, he says he refused to fit in. He shunned the cadets and sports, played bass guitar when he was 16, and was into the Beatles. He was eventually expelled, although only after he had won a scholarship to Cambridge. "The headmaster had wanted to throw me out for a while but he recognised that I was good for the statistics. We put on this play and he came and saw the stage on fire with a half-naked girl on it. His solution was to expel me." In his gap year - as it then wasn't called - Scruton washed-up in a Lyons corner house on the Mile End Road, east London, hitchhiked to Greece and then to Egypt before getting a boat to Lebanon, where he ran out of money. He couldn't work his passage home on British boats because he wasn't in the union - "my first experience of the trade unions which my father admired" - so ended up on a Norwegian vessel carrying potatoes. When he got to Cambridge, in 1962, his adventures made him feel much older than his contemporaries, and he changed courses on the first day, from natural sciences to philosophy. He says he was not political. "But this was pre-1968. There was an old idea of education that prevailed. I went to lectures on Kant and Hume and logic and literature and I couldn't tell you what my lecturers' political beliefs were." In his new book he claims that England died about the time he was at university. From his father he got a pessimism about the fate of rural England and had a melancholy sense that western civilisation was doomed. "But like anyone who was brought up on Leavis, I had a tremendous belief in English culture and literature. I never though there was an alternative to what we had inherited. You either learn to inherit it properly or you become disinherited. I always thought the oriental faction - the hashish-smoking people with pony tails and dreamy eyes - were escapists. They hadn't found an alternative but were just deceiving themselves." Although destined for an academic career, a life at Cambridge didn't appeal. "It was then quasi-monastic. There weren't many women around, there was this mist of nostalgic pederasty that hung over it all." He had ambitions to be a writer but took a job at the University of Bordeaux where he rented a cottage in the foothills of the Pyrennees. He then moved to Rome, where he wrote a novel that was never published, and returned in 1969 to Peterhouse, Cambridge, as a research fellow in aesthetics. Two years later he moved to Birkbeck College, London. He was made professor of aesthetics in 1985 and stayed at the college until 1992. "When I went to Birkbeck I was already in a conservative frame of mind," he says. "My colleagues regarded me with great suspicion. The waves of 1968 had just reached London University. There were attempts to introduce more Foucault and Marx on to the curriculum. I had been brought up in Cambridge with this completely de-politicised view of what philosophy should be, so was obviously against all this." While at Birkbeck he read for the Bar as a fall-back position. "I thought I might have to get out of this, and the law seemed a career where conservatives might be welcomed. I thought I ought to have an exit route." AC Grayling was a colleague in the Birkbeck philosophy department and says Scruton is a very good professional academic philosopher "and a wonderful teacher of philosophy. The pedagogic works he wrote for students and the general public are clear, lucid and accurate. It is partly because of Roger's presence that the department is one of the best in the country." Grayling, who says he and Scruton disagree politically, also says what a "very charming and somewhat sweet man," he is in person. "This rather glum, obtuse figure who pops up every now again to say 'bring back hanging', or something, is not really characteristic of him." Ralph Walker of Magdalen College, Oxford, agrees about Scruton's academic stature, but claims that what he tries to do, at least part of the time, is to stimulate people. "Some of the views he expresses in conversation or print are not necessarily views he would hold to the bitter end. They are often put in a provocative form for people to think about. Roger irritates people who find they don't like the position he's taken, but can't argue back. That can show itself as anger or accusations of extremism." This was Scruton's "ill at ease" period, made harder by a failed marriage. He had met Danielle Laffitte, a student, in France. After a long on-off affair they married in 1973, but were divorced in 1979. She still lives in England and they meet occasionally. "It wasn't a very happy experience. I think marriages are much less stable if you live together first," he says. "You don't have that sense of the metaphysical transformation from one condition to the next. The rite of passage is lost." He and Danielle didn't have children because there was, "not sufficient commitment. Also there was selfishness. Perhaps if we had [children] we would have stayed together." Scruton did not become a father until two years ago when he and his second wife, Sophie Jeffreys, had Samuel. A second child, Lucy, was born last August. Jeffreys, an architectural historian, is 28 years his junior. They live contentedly on a farm in Wiltshire. Scruton also has a two-room apartment in Albany, the exclusive lodgings on London's Piccadilly. His rooms used to be the late MP Alan Clark's servant quarters. As Birkbeck only operated in the evenings, it gave Scruton time to pursue a career as a writer cum journalist as well as moving into the world of politics. He says he was appalled by the Heath government. "There seemed to be a lot of thinking to be done and no-one was doing it." Along with the MP Hugh Fraser, Jonathan Aitken and academic John Casey, Scruton founded the Conservative Philosophy Group. Antonia Fraser, then married to Hugh Fraser, the Tory MP, and herself on the left, has been a friend since that time. Through her, Scruton got to know her present husband, Harold Pinter; this proved useful when Scruton was in financial difficulties. "Wine has been the most important factor in my life, apart from women and song, but it can be an expensive taste. When I was a don at Cambridge I could buy it at cost and I bought a lot of 1961 clarets. But I fell on hard times and couldn't pay my tax bill so I sold the lot to Harold Pinter. He was the only person who would trust me that these bottles really were what I told him they were, because all the labels had come off. He was just marrying Antonia and wanted a proper cellar. He was very generous and did invite me to drink some of it afterwards." Scruton is often associated with Margaret Thatcher's reinvigoration of the Conservative party through a red-blooded commitment to the market in the mid 1970s. But he says that process happened quite independently of anything he was doing. "Thatcher was completely indifferent to our kind of conservative philosophy. I'd never heard of her gurus - people like Alan Walters and Alfred Sherman." Scruton was associated with writers at the Spectator and Telegraph, exponents of a more settled, patrician conservatism. "It was about a subdued sense of the importance of history and tradition, of doing things in an orderly way. Small-scale improvements. The market economy was a good thing but it wasn't the foundation of social order, and should be heavily qualified by all the traditions that enable people to live with each other rather than just compete. But under Thatcher it was completely the free market." His association with Thatcher didn't do him any good. "I was identified in the intellectual world with this terrible woman - who I never knew, although I do now - and was blamed for everything she did, without me knowing what she would do." He did attempt to get on the Tory candidates' list in 1978 but was turned down - "too bookish". Soon after, he began a crash course in very practical politics. In 1979 he was invited to an aesthetics conference in Krakow, Poland. It was just after the election of a Polish Pope and just before the birth of Solidarity. "Culpably, I had never engaged with communism," he says. "When the Prague Spring happened in 1968, I so identified it with the ghastly students I'd seen in Paris I didn't have much sympathy, which I now realise was a terrible wrong. It showed a lack of moral imagination on my part and unfortunately I never acted upon it." His visit to Poland disturbed him. He then went on to Prague to give a secret lecture with the dissident Czech philosopher Julius Tomin. After the lecture he accompanied Tomin back to his apartment. Waiting for them at the entrance was a secret policeman who refused to let Scruton in and then threw him down the stairs. From then on Scruton was a marked man. He was eventually arrested when two policeman stepped out from behind a bush in Brno and soon after he was thrown out of the country. "I realised that this was a situation that was complete outside anything in my experience," he says "And at the same time this was a place which was dear to my heart. The intellectual life was genuinely dangerous. They were being put in jail by a left-wing police force." Along with other British academics, mostly from Oxford, he began to work with the Jan Hus educational trust - named after the 13th century Czech reformer and martyr - to provide books, support samizdat production and teach courses. The foreign office had been lukewarm about their activities until Malcolm Rifkind became minister of state with responsibility for eastern Europe in 1982. "The foreign office's job was to maintain links with government," explains Rifkind, "but I thought we could have links with unofficial bodies as well and should make contact with dissidents." He lent support to Scruton and others and commends their bravery. "Travelling as an individual in quite hostile terrain, they were putting themselves at risk." Scruton learned Czech and threw himself in to the culture. Pavel Bratinka, a nuclear physicist in Prague who, because of his opposition to the regime, was forced to work as cleaner on the metro, attended Scruton's seminars. After communism collapsed he held several ministerial posts in the new government. "As a thinker whose point of departure was conservative he was very important here," explains Bratinka. "His reputation in academic circles is very high. They know that what he did was for no personal reward and we are extremely grateful to him. I hope after he dies they name a street for him here in Prague." After communism collapsed, to Bratinka's huge surprise, the alumni of his classes were suddenly in charge. Scruton formed a consultancy firm to make contacts between western businesses and the new governments. However, his friends' power was short-lived, and he is depressed that the communists hadn't gone away after all. "They worked out that they would do far better if they gave up the nonsense of political power and just seized the assets of the country instead. They privatised the whole economy to themselves." He says he had no hope that communism would go away. "I thought that perhaps we were keeping the light of learning burning just a little longer than it would have otherwise. But it was the right thing to do, and you do get comfort from doing something that is morally right. As there was no way this could be publicly known, that was the only motive for doing it. It was hugely important to me." Scruton was subsequently awarded the Czech republic's highest civilian honour for his work. During the 1980s he was having a very hard time. He says his columns in the Times and editorship of the Salisbury Review had identified him as an intellectual traitor, a rightwinger and a person of ill-repute. He then tried writing a novel, Francesca, about a grammar-school boy who falls for an upper-class girl, which reviewers rushed to annihilate. "It felt unjust," he says. "I don't mind people criticising me. I'm bound to be criticised because I say strong things that are controversial, although I do try to back them up. But that is not the same as being mocked and made to look ridiculous by people who don't understand what you are saying." So shaken was Scruton by the reviews of Francesca that he stopped writing fiction. Instead he turned his creative energies to music. He is a very good pianist and, perhaps surprisingly, has a keen appreciation of 20th century music. He wrote an opera, The Minister, about a politician who sacrifices his personal life to ambition. It was staged in the Czech republic and in Oxford. His other response to the relentless criticism in this country was to accept the post of professor of philosophy at Boston University in the US. While he says that many of the students weren't very good, "those that were good were fantastic. Especially those from the bible belt, who were a gift to someone like me. They had that residue of European culture which most young people in England no longer have. American culture can be what you want: you can make around yourself a circle of people that are your type." This is more difficult to do in England. He claims English culture has become mediocratised in the last 10 years: the legitimisation of pop music and football as genuine manifestations of the nations culture being prime examples. His next novel, Xanthippic Dialogues, written in dialogue form about Plato's women, was better received, and encouraged Scruton to return home full-time. "I'd found an idiom that synthesised my philosophical side and my fiction side. I always think that a world view is incomplete if it can't be embodied in some way in the human situation. This makes Shakespeare into a truly great philosopher. You can explore his characters and come across metaphysical layers and an archaeology of knowledge in each of them. I don't have the talent, but I would like to be a really serious philosopher who absolutely concretised his philosophy in individual characters in a situation that makes them live." A C Grayling says that "the intellectual class and the academic class only fractionally overlap these days. Most academics are great experts in their field, but that's no guarantee they will be widely read and cultured individuals. Roger certainly is. He could see the wider picture and had an appreciation of the wider civilisation to go along with his academic and professional knowledge." Scruton says he regrets as a young man "dithering" as to what type of intellectual he should be. "I knew since I had been in France that I was an intellectual in the French mould. I should be sitting in a cafe rather than a lecture room. But I was brought up on analytical philosophy. It isn't people showing off and trying to be incomprehensible and deep, but addressing real problems. It gets technical and dry and seems detached from ordinary human life and from culture and the spiritual - all the things you go to philosophy for as an amateur in the first place. "Even though I knew it was a means, not an end, I should have been much more clear at the beginning that I would try to internalise that discipline but nevertheless be true to my cultural identity - somebody attempting to express a vision of human life rather than attacking tiny little problems within it. That's been hard but I think it has come together much more now." There is still a way to go before he can expect people to disentangle the personality of the man from his work. He says he was astonished by the reaction to his jokey piece on child-rearing. "There was such a complete lack of a sense of humour in the people who responded to it. It was tongue-in-cheek. But of course irony can be difficult. That's why Socrates was put to death in Athens. His irony was not only a form of truth-telling but it made people inferior because they were. He brought them face to face with their own inferiority. No wonder they put him to death." Life at a glance: Roger Vernon Scruton Born: February 27 1944. Education: High Wycombe Grammar School; Jesus College, Cambridge. Married: 1973 Danielle Laffitte, divorced 1979; 1996 Sophie Jeffreys (one son, one daughter). Career: Research fellow, Peterhouse, Cambridge 1969-71; Birkbeck College, lecturer in philosophy 1971-79, reader 1979-85, professor of aesthetics 1985-92; professor of philosophy Boston University 1992-95. Called to the Bar 1978; Editor Salisbury Review 1982- present. Philosophy publications: Art And Imagination 1974; The Aesthetics Of Architecture 1979; Kant 1982; The Aesthetic Understanding 1983; Sexual Desire 1986; The Philosopher On Dover Beach 1990; An Intelligent Persons Guide To Philosophy 1996; The Aesthetics Of Music 1997. Politics publications: The Meaning Of Conservatism 1980; The Politics Of Culture 1981; Dictionary Of Political Thought 1982; Thinkers Of The New Left 1985; Conservative Texts 1992. Fiction: Fortnight's Anger 1981; Francesca 1991; A Dove Descending and Other Stories 1991; Xanthippic Dialogues 1993. Others: An Intelligent Persons Guide to Modern Culture 1998; On Hunting 1998; Ed. Town and Country 1998; England; An Elegy 2000.

fields.headline: Rational magic
fields.standfirst:
Julia Eccleshare hails heretical fantasist Philip Pullman in his final part of the Dark Materials trilogy, The Amber Spyglass
Read an extract
fields.trailText: Julia Eccleshare hails heretical fantasist Philip Pullman in his final part of the Dark Materials trilogy, The Amber Spyglass
fields.body:
His Dark Materials III: The Amber Spyglass
Philip Pullman
500pp, Scholastic
£14.99
Buy it at BOL

One of the most eagerly awaited events of the children's publishing year will happen next week, when the third volume of Philip Pullman's Dark Materials trilogy finally hits the bookshops. Publication of The Amber Spyglass completes Pullman's radical three-volume reworking of Paradise Lost. Readers who - noticing that it has taken him an extra year to publish the final volume - thought he might have lost the trail he took up in Northern Lights and The Subtle Knife need not have feared.

If anything, The Amber Spyglass is more intense than its predecessors. The climaxes are bigger; there is a fresh fire in the writing; and there is a wonderful new cast of characters - notably, a pair of gay angels. Above all, Pullman pursues his central philosophical theme with even greater passion. In his world, the temptation and fall are not the source of all human misery but the end of repression by what he calls "the Authority" and the beginning of liberation and freedom of thought. What's more, it is Lyra and Will, two children on the threshold of growing up, whose embrace of knowledge saves the world, overturning the traditional view of childhood innocence.

For those who don't know Pullman's Dark Materials, it is a single story published in three volumes - an exhilarating and poetic mixture of adventure, philosophy, myth and religion enriched by a heady brew of quantum physics. It is heavily influenced by Milton and Blake, but also by Swift, Goethe, Norse legend and Greek tragedy.

Central to the story are Pullman's life-affirming belief in free will and the power of scientific rationalism and his deep dislike of hierarchical religion and the repression it sanctions. The first two volumes have already been dismissed as "the stuff of nightmares" by the Catholic Herald. Pullman won't be drawn into a theological debate, insisting that he is not setting down an argument or writing a philosophical treatise but telling a story.

This is a touch disingenuous and Pullman knows it, since he insists that his story, despite its parallel worlds and huge host of ingenious characters, is not a fantasy. It is, he says, "stark realism. The only thing that is interesting about fantasy is if you can use it to say something truthful and realistic about human nature." In his universe, for instance, everyone has a "daemon"; an aura or alter ego signifying their true soul, which may change in childhood but becomes fixed in adults.

Through his portrayal of real people dealing with weighty moral issues within a mythic story and in a fantasy setting, Pullman has rearranged the landscape of writing for children. His central characters, Lyra and Will, have fantastical adventures, but their success within them comes from knowing what is true and what is real. It is knowledge, not fate, that shapes their destiny.

Pullman's insistence on truth to human nature lies behind his dismissal of the fantasy writers to whom he is often compared: JRR Tolkien and CS Lewis. "I dislike them for different reasons. The Lord of the Rings, for all its scope, weight and structural integrity, is not a serious book because it doesn't say anything interesting or new or truthful about human beings. It tells an essentially trivial story. The goodies are always good and the baddies are always bad. CS Lewis comes from a different tradition: in the Narnia books he struggles with big ideas. I dislike the conclusions he comes to because he seems to recommend the worship of a god who is a fascist and a bully; who dislikes people of different colours; and who thinks of women as being less valuable in every way.

"And it is a god who hates life because he denies children life. In the final Narnia book he gives the children the end-of-term treat of being killed in a railway accident so they can go to heaven. It's a filthy thing to do. Susan is shut out from salvation because she is doing what every other child who has ever been born has done - she is beginning to sense the developing changes in her body and its effect on the opposite sex. For all those reasons I profoundly disagree with Lewis and with the conclusions he reaches."

The conclusion Pullman has come to is that people have within them the capacity to react and respond in a number of ways. His characters change; they make choices. His children, especially, are neither all good nor all bad. Lyra has spent a lifetime lying but it doesn't stop her having integrity when she needs it; Will has killed a man. "I'm not dewy-eyed about children like Kenneth Grahame or AA Milne. I spent too long as a teacher," he says. "I'm clear-eyed about them. I like the current, non- sentimental writing for children of authors like Anne Fine and Jacqueline Wilson, where they can be good and bad. I also value the process of growing up. It's an unavoidable fact that we're going to grow up. But that's hopeful."

fields.headline: A difficult martyr - part 2
fields.trailText: I have never been a good or conscientious letter-writer...
fields.body:
I have never been a good or conscientious letter-writer. My father, in contrast, was an inveterate letter-writer, always firing off missives in his beautiful, slanted handwriting. He wrote to me after his arrest and I replied, commiserating with him but explaining that I was busy settling into my first job since leaving journalism school. I told him about the difficulties I was having trying to place the story of his arrest in the British media. It was a small lie, because all I had done was send out a press release. I knew, deep down, that he was innocent, but acknowledging his innocence would mean I would have to abandon my life to help him. And not only would I be pulled into the struggle, but I would have to take a position against my cousins who had already publicly sworn to avenge their father's death.

I told him that my cousins and other Ogoni in London and in Nigeria had been trying to persuade my mother to turn against him. I wanted him to realise that his fate was in my mother's hands, to pay him back for all the times he had hurt her. I wanted him to sit in his cell and contemplate the fact that she would be justified in taking her family's side against him. It was a cruel thing to do, but our emotional attachment had been almost severed by the years of mutual suspicion and misunderstanding.

I didn't hear from him for two months. In a way, his silence was a relief because it shielded me from having to make a decision I would have been happy to put off for the rest of my life. I buried my head in the sand, hoping the situation would somehow resolve itself.

But the silence was unbearable. His silence and my own.

I flinch now at how cold I was. It seems obvious, especially with the benefit of hindsight, that anything, however banal, would have kept his spirits up. But I was paralysed by an awareness that if I wrote to him, I would have to answer the issue dangling like a large question mark between his hot, filthy prison cell in Port Harcourt and my comfortable misery in London: What was I going to do?

A letter arrived from Nigeria.

Dear Junior,
I have not heard from you in months.
Your father

Only three lines, but three lines that spoke volumes. In that anguished letter, I felt his pain, his anger. He must have thought that I had abandoned him. I threw it in the bin. I felt my anger was justified, but the letter sat in the bin, insisting that I stand up for my father. At last, some time later, I wrote a long letter to my father. I have kept almost all the letters my father ever wrote to me, but I wish I had been as careful and conscientious with my own. I wish I could retrieve that particular letter I wrote, because it changed the dynamics of our relationship.

What I do remember clearly is that I finally found the courage to confront my father about his relationship with my mother. I told him he was lucky to have a wife like her, and I explained that she had always been responsible for keeping his children, especially me, loyal to him, that she had never once tried to turn me against him. He had done that all by himself. I told him that she had always advised me to stand by him, no matter how rough their marriage was for her. I reminded him that he hadn't always been as faithful, and that he had often tried to blame her for his difficulties with his children.

I also told him I was going to marry Olivia; I went about it in a cautious, circumspect way. I had read somewhere that Ogoni were forbidden to marry outside their race, and I somehow imagined that since he had become such an Ogoni nationalist, he would disapprove of my choosing to marry outside. His reply came back to me in less than a week. Nigeria's notorious postal system had never been so efficient. He described my letter as "a very encouraging and cheering Xmas gift". He wrote positively about my mother, my upcoming wedding, the need to work hard and to save. That letter remains the most important one my father ever wrote to me. But as was my wont in those days, I zeroed in on his criticisms of me: I was ashamed that he felt I was "lazy". He could have said I was lacking in direction, but my father never minced his words, especially when he was trying to motivate me. It did the trick, however, because I handed in my notice at work the very next day. I decided it was time to show him what I could do. At the time, I rationalised my decision as giving up my life to try to save his. But when I look back on it, it is probably fairer to say that I had decided to make something of my life by trying to save his.

I was standing in a newsroom of the BBC World Service in London when I heard that he had been sentenced to death. I was leaning against a desk when a disembodied voice suddenly bounced out of a nearby speaker, announcing that Janet Anderson, the BBC correspondent in Nigeria, was standing by to file a report from Port Harcourt. The volume on the speakers seemed to rise a couple of notches as a voice boomed out like an announcer at a train station:

"KEN SARO-WIWA HAS BEEN SENTENCED TO DEATH ..."

It didn't register at first, because by then Ken Saro-Wiwa was someone I had been writing and talking about for a year, someone I prefaced as a minority-rights activist, as an environmentalist, a poet, a writer, an Amnesty International prisoner of conscience or a Nobel Peace Prize nominee. The name Ken Saro-Wiwa had lost some of its personal meaning to me. He was already a symbol in my mind, and it took a few moments before it registered that my father had just been sentenced to death. But as soon as I absorbed the thought, I quickly blocked it out and concentrated on my response.

My reaction was on the tip of my tongue. I barely had to think about it because by then I was a fluent activist. I was playing the role my father had always hoped I could play; I was his witness, his mouthpiece. Ken Saro-Wiwa and Ken Wiwa flowed seamlessly from one to the other. I had come to accept my role. I actually enjoyed being his "spokesman". I travelled around the world, meeting the good and the great as he had predicted, basking in the spotlight of his name, seduced by the prospect that he was becoming a cause célébre.

Three days later, I was on a plane, heading to Auckland, New Zealand, to make a last-ditch plea to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, which was to convene in Auckland in the first week of November.

In Auckland, Wiwa had fruitless and frustrating discussions with Commonwealth leaders such as Lady Lynda Chalker, Britain's Overseas Development Minister, Jim Bolger, New Zealand prime minister, and Jean Chrétien, prime minister of Canada. I had done everything I could do. It was in God's hands.

The atmosphere in the city that evening reminded me of the brooding silence before a thunderstorm in Nigeria. At dinner that night there was good-natured banter around the table and I joined in, trying to keep my mind from the events back in Nigeria. Just before midnight I felt a short, violent, tugging sensation in my chest.

That was the longest night of my life. Although I was shattered, my nerves rubbed raw, and I hadn't had a full night's sleep since my father had been sentenced to death, I couldn't rest. I knew my father was probably dead, but I clung to a forlorn hope that everything would be okay in the morning.

I fretted, tossing and turning in state of suspended anxiety, drifting in and out of a fitful sleep. At one point I became conscious of movements outside my room, doors opening and closing, people whispering and shuffling around in the corridors. I wanted to get up and find out what all the noise was about, to confront the news head on, but I couldn't move. I lay there, paralysed by fear. Waiting. Waiting for the morning and God knows what. After a while, I noticed that there was an ominous silence in the corridor. The only noises I could hear were the sporadic sounds of early morning traffic drifting in and out of my room from the streets outside. When I heard a timid knock on my door, I jumped out of bed and threw on some clothes. My hands were shaking as Richard Boele, a fellow activist, slipped into the room. He was as pale as a ghost. He had spent the night trying to confirm the sketchy reports coming out of Nigeria. It was written on his face. I stood in front of him, searching for a sign that everything was still okay. He looked at me, then pursed his lips. "Your dad's dead."

I used to wonder why people said they felt "lonely" or alone when their fathers died. But that was exactly how I felt on November 12, 1995. Lonely.

It took two years, two months and 13 days after his death to make peace with my father. I was driving home in my car and reached Ñ as I always do when I need to calm down - for U2's album Achtung Baby. It was Tedum's favourite.

Will it make it easier on you now You got someone to blame ... You gave me nothing Now it's all I got.

I rewound the song and played it again. The song struck a chord in me. And suddenly all the emotion that had been bottled up for so long came pouring out. It dawned on me as I sat crying in my car that I had lost a friend, a wise old man to confide in. I cried like a little boy that night.

The next day, I sat down at my computer. I clicked on the file called "The End". It contained a letter written by a fellow Ogoni prisoner giving a detailed eye-witness account of my father's last moment on the gallows. I had never been able to bring myself to read it. Now I took a deep breath and began. I read every word of the letter to the end. Drained but calm, I closed the document. I slid a compact disc, The Indestructible Beat Of Soweto, into the computer. A sparkling guitar solo danced out of the speakers. I looked out of the window and up to the sky, where I imagined my father was watching me, and smiled. I started jumping around the study, dancing and laughing hysterically. As I leapt around, I remembered a poem my father had written from detention:

Dance your anger and your joys. Dance the guns to silence. Dance. Dance. Dance...

I knew, deep down, that he was innocent, but acknowledging his innocence would mean I would have to abandon my life to help him. I told him that my cousins and other Ogoni in London and in Nigeria had been trying to persuade my mother to turn against him. I wanted him to realise that his fate was in my mother's hands, to pay him back for all the times he had hurt her. I wanted him to sit in his cell and contemplate the fact that she would be justified in taking her family's side against him. It was a cruel thing to do, but our emotional attachment had been almost severed by the years of mutual suspicion and misunderstanding. I didn't hear from him for two months. In a way, his silence was a relief because it shielded me from having to make a decision I would have been happy to put off for the rest of my life. I buried my head in the sand, hoping the situation would somehow resolve itself. But the silence was unbearable. His silence and my own. I flinch now at how cold I was. It seems obvious, especially with the benefit of hindsight, that anything, however banal, would have kept his spirits up. fields.headline: The Ship Hotel, Chichester
fields.trailText: Food was delicious and well presented with a yummy breakfast worth getting up for. A restaurant where people whisper rather than talk.
fields.body:
Address: North Street, Chichester, West Sussex PO19 1NH

Tel: 01243 778000

Web address: www.shiphotel.com.

First impressions: Paintings celebrating our glorious naval past, grand (and very old) staircase with wrought-iron railings. Helpful and charming staff. You have to negotiate a warren of corridors to reach your room.

What are the rooms like? All rather old-fashioned, some quite tight on space, others huge. Heavy on floral wallpaper, swags and borders.

The bed test: Firm and comfortable, with crispy white sheets. Just one blanket, though, although the room was warm. Pillows were a bit limp.

The bathroom test: Small but spotless. Complimentary smellies were flowery rather than trendy.

The restaurant: Décor was a bit inhibiting - intensely floral wallpaper and carpet. Highly starched linen napkins and tablecloth. Food was delicious and well presented. Good choice, though vegetarian dishes by request rather than listed on menu. Yummy breakfast. A restaurant where people whisper rather than talk.

What is there to see within walking distance? The Chichester Festival Theatre, the cathedral, a couple of local museums, lots of quaint shops, some pleasant parks and the ancient city walls.

What is there to see within a 10-minute drive? The sea - the Witterings for beaches, and Bosham and Chichester Marina for boats. The Roman Palace at Fishbourne, the fantastic open-air museum at Singleton and loads of rolling countryside and ancient hostelries.

How much a night? Single rooms from £69 per night B&B, doubles from £95. Good value is dinner, B&B deal from £119 per night for a couple staying at least two nights.

Would you go back? Definitely with retired colonel uncle. Probably not with loud teenage children or for passionate weekend.

fields.headline: Cubist Charlie Chaplin, Fernand Leger (1923-4)
fields.trailText: Portrait of the week No 29
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Fernand Léger (1881-1955), a follower of Picasso and Braque, one of the best of the so-called Salon Cubists until his time in the trenches in the first world war filled him with a new awe at modern technology and the dignity of the working class. Léger's paintings became poems to modernity, translating the rhythms of urban life into blocks of colour and tubular, robust figures in Men in the City (1919) and his indoor pastoral scene Three Women (Le Grand Déjeuner) (1921). In 1924, he made one of the first avant-garde films, Ballet Mécanique.

Subject: Charlie Chaplin (1889-1971), who grew up destitute in London, entered the music hall and travelled to America in 1913 with a pantomime troupe. His performance as a comic drunk got him noticed by Mack Sennett. Chaplin soon broke loose to direct himself, in stories of modern life including The Tramp (1915), The Immigrant (1916), City Lights (1931) and his satire on Hitler, The Great Dictator (1940).

Distinguishing features: This Chaplin is a principle of energy. Léger was fascinated by mechanism, by the power of the automaton, and saw the brave new world of the modern machine as potentially utopian. His Chaplin is the spirit of cinema itself. This figure, constructed from pieces of wood, is a jerky puppet that appeared in Léger's Ballet Mécanique. The splitting of his body into different dancing segments imitates the way cinema consists of a series of still images creating the illusion of motion. Charlie flicks his right arm in the air, as straight and graceful as his dancing on screen, and raises his leg with jaunty gravitas. His cane on the right is an extraneous object and, as it is in the films, a dancing partner - the embodiment of his cheeky spirit.

His face is the biggest surprise. There is no trace of the soft Charlie who saves girls, just a violent toothy grin. This is the harder edge seen in his early films when he was always ready to kick his opponents when they were tying their shoes.

"Charlot" was a hero to avant-garde Paris at this stage. Later he was attacked by the surrealists; Luis Bunuel accused him of selling out. By 1918, he had a contract with First National Pictures for $1m a year. In European eyes, he may have been a symbol of the common man, but he was also an icon of American capitalism.

Léger, however, lacked the elitism of many modern artists and critics, remaining true to an innocent idea of modern art. This is a revolutionary Charlot, dancing into the future: he arrives in New York in The Immigrant to try to exist in the modern metro- polis. Chaplin was later to savagely satirise the machine in Modern Times (1936), but in his tramp character there is a lot of adeptness, a proficiency for technical feats.

Léger did other versions of this, including ones for magazine publication. He saw Chaplin as the spirit of modernity, the essence of the explosive, electric new humanity, a trickster spirit of modern times.

Inspirations and influences: Cubism was developed by Picasso and Braque, then taken up by followers like Léger as a way of capturing the fragmentary drama of contemporary life, including popular culture.

Where is it? In Painting the Century at the National Portrait Gallery, St Martin's Place, London WC2 (020-7312 2452), until February 4.
