fields.headline: A simple plan
fields.standfirst: Pacific Rim cuisine first hit the United Kingdom some 10 years ago. This weird jumble of ingredients from the Americas, Australia, Asia and beyond is still with us, yet chefs from those countries are cooking to a very different beat. Sure, they continue picking up ideas and techniques from overseas, but they have also moved on. As Weekend's  Autumn Food Special  shows, fusion no longer means confusion; it's now about creating a country's culinary identity. We start in  Australia , with a chef who opted for the simple life. Then it's off to the  US, for a lesson in modern Californian cuisine. Next up,  Japan, with sushi master Yosuke Imada, before we head across the seas for a taste of street food in  Chile and  Indonesia. And to wash it all down, there are round-ups of the Pacific's  beers,  wines,  spirits and  soft drinks.  The Knowledge  rounds things off by with a guide to doing it all at home...
fields.trailText: As Weekend's  Autumn Food Special  shows, fusion no longer means confusion; it's now about creating a country's culinary identity. We start in  Australia , with a chef Russell Jeavons who opted for the simple life.
fields.body:
In its most interactive mode, the restaurant is open just one night a week: Friday. And there is just one simple centre to the range of food on offer: pizza, cooked in a wood-fired oven that is the heart of the kitchen. What's more, there are no plates or cutlery. On top of that, you place your own order at the kitchen bench. And the wine list is functionally negligible at best (though you can BYO to your heart's content - most do).

Despite such apparent limitations, however, this remarkable restaurant, Russell's, has so much bonhomie running through it that eating here is a more consistently positive experience than any (or at least many) more up-themselves eateries in Australia, which is why upwards of 150 people come here every Friday, and why the place is booked solid for weeks in advance.

Forty kilometres south of Adelaide, in a former blacksmith's cottage in one of the oldest settlements in South Australia, and bang in the middle of one of the country's premier winemaking districts, Russell's is the workplace of Russell Jeavons. Jeavons had established a reputation as one of Australia's culinary godfathers after years at the stoves of the landmark Salopian Inn in McLaren Vale, when in 1993 he just upped sticks and stepped back from the rigours of haute cuisine. The food community was shocked, but Jeavons simply wanted a lifestyle that was more in keeping with that of his family.

So off he went in search of that goal, picking up all manner of influences along the way, including the ascetic aesthetics of Japanese food and the rather less ascetic (but no less rigorous) aesthetics of Italian cooking. By the time he opened the doors of his cottage for business later that same year, this philosopher of the kitchen had settled on an approach to food and hospitality that was worthy of a Provençal villager, for it is utterly rooted in the soil and climate of the district in which he lives and works.

Plentiful food and fresh running water year round had established Willunga as a meeting place for the local Kaurna peoples long before the first colonists arrived; 150 years later, the culinary influence of a couple of postwar generations of southern European settlers had made a lasting impact on the local gastronomy, which had adapted to take advantage of the thoroughly Mediterranean climate. So much so that the district became a centre of almond and olive production, as well as of grapes.

Seven years on, and Jeavons's restaurant is now synonymous with Willunga. Its renown has spread around Australia and beyond, most of all for its unique and unapologetically simple character. The continued success of Russell's is testament to Jeavons's talent. But then, it's not like any other pizza joint you'll have come across - and there's a lot more to its appeal than thin crusts alone.

Of course, nothing so simple could be arrived at without a great deal of thought. Russell's has been called "the most environmentally-friendly restaurant in the country", not to mention "the least wanky" - the wood-fired oven that drives the whole operation is fired by the cuttings of vines, grapes and almonds, as well as olive pressings (and the odd deconstructed deckchair). The entire cooking process, from starters through main courses and on to puddings, is sequenced to take advantage of every phase of each oven firing (the recipes opposite, for example, can be made in one firing), right down to the ultra-slow roasting of almonds and spice seeds as the oven cools, which culminates in his local, almond-rich version of Lebanese dukkah.

Another appeal of Jeavons's approach to cooking, which had already manifested itself at the Salopian Inn, is his insistence on sourcing ingredients locally. In fact, it's more of an obsession: a large proportion of his stock comes from within a few hundred yards of his place of work. It's a culinary philosophy that informs everything he does, from the moment he starts work each week by resuming an ongoing quest to come up with the "perfect" unleavened sourdough bread. The restaurant's kitchen garden, which is hoed and nurtured by the man himself, supplies many of the herbs and the freshest salad greens imaginable (not much here makes it to the compost bin).

From there, although the supply lines do fan out, they do so only slightly: a radius of about 10km is as far as he'll venture from home to source ingredients. For example, now, as Willunga enters spring, asparagus and strawberries are picked on Friday morning from fields nearby and brought to the cottage for dinner that night; and a local vigneron has a grove of Tahitian limes that are ready for pickling, so Jeavons is busy incorporating them into his planning. And so it goes on, with Jeavons both capitalising on the bounty of the season at hand and putting aside anything that can be preserved for seasons of less plenty.

Intense preparation in the days before opening means that, on Friday night, Jeavons can take up a place front of house, guiding customers through, explaining and smoothing the way, until, at the end of the evening, the tables in the "ballroom" out the back are pushed against the wall and the dancing begins. While he facilitates, the "kids", as he calls them (though, to be fair, his own children are among them), keep the dukkah, pizzas and desserts coming, while customers mingle in the dining room and by the fire outside, developing from bemused novices to confident familiars in one night. Jeavons is currently toying with the idea of extending his opening times, although he's already booked for private parties most Saturdays and for showcase dinners through the week, and he also has to fit in the the occasional catering gig further afield.

Russell's has a confidence and maturity born of its past and sure of its future - to the customers who promise to return, next year or whenever, the response from Jeavons is always the same: "I'll be here."

All recipes serve four.

Dukkah: An adaptation of a traditional Middle Eastern blend of nuts and seeds that is rich in almonds. The proportion of nuts to seeds is not as important as correct roasting. This makes a fantastic nibble before getting down to the main dishes.

200g almonds
80g sesame seeds
50g coriander seeds
25g cumin seeds
tsp salt
Black pepper

Roast the nuts and seeds separately at 100C/gas mark (it is much better to do them slowly on a low heat), until they are lightly coloured and aromatic. In a food processor, grind the almonds to a coarse texture. The coriander and cumin seeds need to be ground finely, so use a coffee grinder or pestle and mortar. The sesame seeds can be bruised, cracked or even left whole. Mix all the ingredients together, adding salt and pepper to taste.

Serve as a dry dip with olive oil and crusty bread. You can also sprinkle dukkah on hard-boiled eggs, or on pasta or use it as a seasoning for cooked vegetables.

Asparagus and olive frittata

1 bunch asparagus
60g Kalamata olives, halved and seeded
8 eggs
1 onion, thinly sliced
4 tbsp chopped flat-leaf parsley
tsp salt and pepper (4:1 ratio)
4 tbsp olive oil

Sweeten the onion in a small sauce-pan with the olive oil - to 'sweeten' means to cook slowly without burning, which will leave the onions translucent, soft and sweet! Blanch the asparagus for a minute in boiling water, then plunge into cold water and drain. Trim off the woody base of the stalk and cut the rest into 3cm pieces.

Break the eggs into a bowl, add all the other ingredients and stir around a bit - don't beat the eggs, under any circumstances.

Pour the egg mixture into an oiled, ovenproof stainless-steel, Pyrex or earthenware baking dish - preferably one that is round and not too big, as the frittata needs to be quite thick (depending on the type of vessel you use, you may need to line it with silicon paper, to prevent it from sticking).

Bake for 35 minutes at 150C/300F/ gas mark 2 (ie, not too hot), until set. Turn out on to a platter and serve cold.

Quail with olives and rosemary

4 quails
4 potatoes
4 tbsp fresh thyme, picked and finely chopped
2 tbsp fresh rosemary, picked and very finely chopped
4 cloves garlic
6 tbsp olive oil
60g Kalamata olives
1 tbsp redcurrant or quince jelly
1 tsp salt and pepper (4:1 ratio)

The following method can be applied to any thin, fast-cooking meat (that is, you can use it just as easily on chicken leg fillets or even spring lamb chops). The over-riding principle is to use a mixture of very good-quality olive oil, salt and pepper, with an aromatic coating, all of which help enhance the natural flavour of whatever meat you use. As a result, no further oil is needed for the pan, which helps prevent wastage and also means you won't burn it.

Bone the quails, leaving them in two pieces (half a quail each), then toss in a bowl with half the olive oil, half the salt and pepper and the finely chopped thyme. Set to one side.

Boil or steam the potatoes in their skins until they are just cooked (but not mushy). Plunge them into cold water to cool. Cut into 1cm thick slices and place in a bowl.

Chop the garlic and rosemary together as finely as you can manage, mix thoroughly with the remaining olive oil, salt and pepper. Pour this mixture over the potatoes, to coat them, just like you would with a dressing, then fry the potatoes on both sides in a pan (there is no real need to add any more oil), or bake them in the oven until they have some golden colour.

Fry the quails quickly in a hot pan (again, no further oil is required), turning only once - quail eats best if slightly underdone. Put the birds back into the bowl they came from and toss them with the fruit jelly. Serve with the potatoes, olives and a few salad greens. (Serious foodies can make a stock from the quail bones, reduce it to a glaze and add four tablespoons to the jelly when coating the quails after cooking.)

Simple almond cake: Serve with strawberries and cream.

300g almond meal, sifted
1 dssp plain flour, sifted
200g caster sugar
8 egg whites

Mix the almond meal and flour in a bowl. Make a meringue by beating the egg whites to a soft peak (and/or until there are no big bubbles left), then keep beating while adding the sugar over a minute or two. Gently fold in the almonds - while sprinkling in the nuts, try to retain the air in the egg mixture.

Bake at 175C/350F/gas mark 4 in a spring-form tin for 20 minutes or until done. Slice the cake through the middle, spread with whipped cream and fill with strawberries. Put another layer of cream and strawberries on the top. If you like, you can halve and slice the strawberries first, and sprinkle them with a little orange juice and brandy

 Russell Jeavons is chef at Russell's, 13 High Street, Willunga, South Australia, tel 0061 (0)88556 2571.

Asparagus and olive frittata 1 bunch asparagus 60g Kalamata olives, halved and seeded 8 eggs 1 onion, thinly sliced 4 tbsp chopped flat-leaf parsley tsp salt and pepper (4:1 ratio) 4 tbsp olive oil Sweeten the onion in a small sauce-pan with the olive oil - to 'sweeten' means to cook slowly without burning, which will leave the onions translucent, soft and sweet! Blanch the asparagus for a minute in boiling water, then plunge into cold water and drain. Trim off the woody base of the stalk and cut the rest into 3cm pieces. Break the eggs into a bowl, add all the other ingredients and stir around a bit - don't beat the eggs, under any circumstances. Pour the egg mixture into an oiled, ovenproof stainless-steel, Pyrex or earthenware baking dish - preferably one that is round and not too big, as the frittata needs to be quite thick (depending on the type of vessel you use, you may need to line it with silicon paper, to prevent it from sticking). Bake for 35 minutes at 150C/300F/ gas mark 2 (ie, not too hot), until set. Turn out on to a platter and serve cold. Quail with olives and rosemary 4 quails 4 potatoes 4 tbsp fresh thyme, picked and finely chopped 2 tbsp fresh rosemary, picked and very finely chopped 4 cloves garlic 6 tbsp olive oil 60g Kalamata olives 1 tbsp redcurrant or quince jelly 1 tsp salt and pepper (4:1 ratio) The following method can be applied to any thin, fast-cooking meat (that is, you can use it just as easily on chicken leg fillets or even spring lamb chops). The over-riding principle is to use a mixture of very good-quality olive oil, salt and pepper, with an aromatic coating, all of which help enhance the natural flavour of whatever meat you use. As a result, no further oil is needed for the pan, which helps prevent wastage and also means you won't burn it. Bone the quails, leaving them in two pieces (half a quail each), then toss in a bowl with half the olive oil, half the salt and pepper and the finely chopped thyme. Set to one side. Boil or steam the potatoes in their skins until they are just cooked (but not mushy). Plunge them into cold water to cool. Cut into 1cm thick slices and place in a bowl. Chop the garlic and rosemary together as finely as you can manage, mix thoroughly with the remaining olive oil, salt and pepper. Pour this mixture over the potatoes, to coat them, just like you would with a dressing, then fry the potatoes on both sides in a pan (there is no real need to add any more oil), or bake them in the oven until they have some golden colour. Fry the quails quickly in a hot pan (again, no further oil is required), turning only once - quail eats best if slightly underdone. Put the birds back into the bowl they came from and toss them with the fruit jelly. Serve with the potatoes, olives and a few salad greens. (Serious foodies can make a stock from the quail bones, reduce it to a glaze and add four tablespoons to the jelly when coating the quails after cooking.) Simple almond cake: Serve with strawberries and cream. 300g almond meal, sifted 1 dssp plain flour, sifted 200g caster sugar 8 egg whites Mix the almond meal and flour in a bowl. Make a meringue by beating the egg whites to a soft peak (and/or until there are no big bubbles left), then keep beating while adding the sugar over a minute or two. Gently fold in the almonds - while sprinkling in the nuts, try to retain the air in the egg mixture. Bake at 175C/350F/gas mark 4 in a spring-form tin for 20 minutes or until done. Slice the cake through the middle, spread with whipped cream and fill with strawberries. Put another layer of cream and strawberries on the top. If you like, you can halve and slice the strawberries first, and sprinkle them with a little orange juice and brandy  Russell Jeavons is chef at Russell's, 13 High Street, Willunga, South Australia, tel 0061 (0)88556 2571.

fields.headline: Dry dry dry
fields.standfirst: It's almost a cliché by now - pop star succumbs to drugs - but no one ever thought it would happen to Marti Pellow of Wet Wet Wet. Least of all him. He tells Caroline Sullivan where it all went wrong, and why, having cleaned up his act, he's so keen to start over again

fields.body:
It's usually pretty easy to predict which pop stars will end up confessing all to the tabloids in one of those "My Drug Hell" pieces. Marti Pellow definitely wasn't one of them. The chipper housewives' choice who led Glasgow's Wet Wet Wet to 26 hit singles (including the sickeningly sincere Love Is All Around, which stayed at number one for 15 long weeks in 1994) was the good boy in a profession of delinquents and misfits. Aptly nicknamed Smiler since schooldays, his only addiction seemed to be an attachment to the old R&B albums that inspired him to form a band back in the mid-80s. He was the Ronan Keating of his day, the perfect gent with no bad habits.

That was before the revelation, in February 1999, that Smiler wasn't so well-adjusted after all - he collapsed at the Conrad Hotel in Chelsea, west London, from an apparent drugs binge. The shock had barely subsided before his girlfriend, a former Miss Scotland named Eileen Catterson, revealed the even more unlikely truth: he had been on heroin for three years, and on the day in question became ill from "unintentionally" mixing alcohol with prescription drugs that he was using to withdraw from the heroin.

It was passed off as an accident, but Pellow now admits, "I was weaning myself off smack with methadone and Librium, yet I was still self-destructive, so I thought, 'Have a drink!' I drank copious amounts of vodka and Strega for two or three hours, and collapsed."

My drugs hell, indeed. Suddenly Pellow, who had been quietly forgotten about since Wet Wet Wet's long run of hits ended in 1997, was front-page news again. It wasn't just the drugs that shocked, but the realisation that, in an age where celebrities compulsively air their private lives, so little was known of his. He'd been a major star, and his relationship with Catterson made them the Caledonian equivalent of Posh and Becks, but he had seemed so uninterestingly normal that the media had left him alone.

"He was the clean-cut boy with the nice grin, so when people found out he was a heavy drugs user they were so shocked, especially because there were never even any rumours," says a Scottish tabloid reporter. His former publicist, Linda Valentine, adds, "I was completely stunned when I heard, because I'd had chats about heroin with him and he knew it was a disaster area."

Pellow has maintained a wary silence until now. He's never been one for five-page spreads in Hello! anyway, but now he needed space to pull himself together as he prepared to relaunch his career. His debut solo album will be released early next year, and next month he begins a tour in which he'll be playing his new music. Finally he's feeling more confident about talking publicly.

"I'm more in touch with my feelings now," he says wryly. "A while ago, I had a really weird feeling of impending doom and I got really uptight - you know the kind of thing? And my friends who'd been in the same situation, they said, 'It's just a feeling, Marti.'" He shakes his head in wonder, almost embarrassed.

He has the air of a man who has the chance of making a new beginning and is going to make the most of it as he takes a seat in a restaurant near Kensington Palace and orders a cappuccino - caffeine being the only drug, other than nicotine, in which he still indulges. Clean since July 1999, and a conscientious attender of Narcotics Anonymous meetings, Pellow is evangelical about the NA programme, which he says changed his life. He's on the fourth step, which advises "making a moral inventory". Apparently, this is the most difficult step, because it requires complete honesty on the addict's part. He says that it has forced him to rethink his priorities: "That step's a long-term project. Living with an addict is so frustrating because [other people] want to help, but it's got to come from the addict," he says in an accent that remains crunchy despite 13 years spent mostly outside Scotland. "Sobriety has been humbling, being in these rooms [at NA meetings]. There's a great cross-section of people. I hadn't done shit in 10 years because everything was done for me. I paid wages, so I didn't have to think of anything. Check myself on to a plane? Get my passport? 'This way, Mr Pellow, this way.' If it happens long enough, it becomes the norm. For me, it's been a real godsend that I can get in touch with my feelings."

He speaks with the earnestness of the newly sober, so absorbed that he's soon leaning forward and making unwavering eye contact. After three years of drug abuse he is still handsome enough - or famous enough - for the waitress to flutter a bit as she brings his coffee. He's rather too thin - he's 5ft 11in and claims he was down to nine-and-a-half stone during his worst patch - but, physically, has weathered pretty well. The only outward sign of his travails is one of those mood bracelets, black for "peace and serenity", worn on the opposite wrist from a dangly gold Cartier watch. The latter was a gift from Elton John's ex-manager, John Reid, who managed Pellow for a short time last year before they split in mysterious circumstances that neither is willing to discuss.

It's late morning, and Pellow is in talkative mood. I'd been told as much by his new songwriting partner, former Squeeze singer Chris Difford (the Cockney baritone on Cool For Cats). The two met in the Priory, where Difford was being treated for cocaine addiction, and Difford now functions as lyricist and unofficial helper. He ushers us to a table, gives Pellow a paternally anxious glance and adjourns to the lobby, where he settles down with a copy of the Mirror. Difford's involvement has been questioned by Pellow's former manager from the Wet Wet Wet years, Elliot Davies, from whom he split last year - "Chris Difford has never managed a band in his life," Davies gripes - but it's clear that his role is more to do with emotional support than business.

Pellow talks with hardly a pause for two hours, sketching the 5am panic of running out of drugs, the Florida cottage where he spent Christmas 1998 alone and desperate, how he felt finishing treatment and going straight back on to heroin. "I was depressed every day. There was a tremendous amount of isolation. Just leave me alone with my drug of choice," he remembers.

Yet there were never any rumours because he seemed so happy in his job as frontman of Scotland's biggest band. A natural attention-seeker, he was completely at home in front of huge audiences (a situation that occurred less often as the 90s wore on), flourishing under the spotlight. When his looks got him more notice than the rest of Wet Wet Wet, he didn't even pretend to be embarrassed. Some musicians find touring a necessary evil; for Pellow, it was an opportunity to bask in his public's approval. Linda Valentine says, "He was a charmer who just wanted to be liked. In the early days, when he finished a show, he'd go to the gym. I never even saw him smoke a spliff."

Yet once Wet Wet Wet's career peaked with Love Is All Around and began a gentle downward slide, he needed numbing drugs just to get through the day. What he's never talked about until now is the lifelong sense of emptiness that drove him to find validation on stage: "I'd like to have thought I was a normal working-class kid, but I can remember being six or seven at school, and at the end of the day I would go off alone. I always felt there was something missing. I'd want to be with people, but then I couldn't because I could only take so much. The most poignant thing about my childhood was that I was always alone. When I discovered things - like the first time I've ever seen this tunnel or whatever, the things that kids do together - I'd do it alone."

It's an equation that you keep encountering in the music business: an empty childhood plus a craving for attention equals a troubled pop star. "Big ego plus low self-esteem? That's the makings of an addict," points out a friend of mine who has grappled with addiction himself. But what's unclear, and even Pellow can't put his finger on it, is the source of this emptiness. His family, who come from a working-class part of Glasgow called Clydebank, was happy, he says, and even exceptionally attractive. His father was a bricklayer, his mother a singer and Marti, whose real name is Mark McLachlan, and his older brother John were the apples of their eye. John, who at 38 is three years Marti's senior, has been an alcoholic for some years. "He's working through it, but it's got to come from him," he sighs.

"Is it better to be good-looking?" Pellow muses. "Ask John Merrick, the Elephant Man. Being nice-looking and a great singer ... can I have all that and credibility, too?"

Ah, the C-word. Musical credibility has always been at the top of his wish-list, and the lack of same has been a thorn in his side for years. Not that he isn't justly renowned for his expressive voice - an early NME review advised him to ditch the rest of Wet Wet Wet - but real kudos somehow eludes him. When lists of classic British male vocalists are compiled, he's rarely included - overlooked, perhaps, or maybe just too identified with Wet Wet Wet's period of teen-idoldom. He never wanted to be a pop star in the first place, seeing himself and schoolfriends Graeme Clark, Tommy Cunningham and Neil Mitchell as inheritors of a Celtic white-soul tradition stretching back to the Average White Band in the 70s. Their heroes were Al Green and Marvin Gaye, unusual influences for a young band in the middle of the Culture Club 80s.

Studying their musty vinyl records as if they were texts, Wet Wet Wet developed a soul-tinged sound that was hugely successful with the public but never quite passed muster with the critics. The Virgin Encyclopaedia Of Popular Music sniffs that they were "agreeable blue-eyed soul", while others derided them as "faceless" or "innocuous". Pellow's silky singing was praised by Al Green's producer, Willie Mitchell, as the best he'd heard since Green himself, but the package as a whole attracted slatings that stopped the Wets rising to the superleague. In a tangential way, much of the negativity was generated by Pellow himself or, rather, by his looks. With a face like his, he was a bespoke teen idol, and the teen 'zines pounced as soon as the band's debut single, Wishing I Was Lucky, came out in April 1987. With his first Smash Hits cover went any hope of credibility. Worse, he seemed unsure of which side of the fence he was on, anxious as he was for both populist adulation and critical plaudits.

Wet Wet Wet also had the bad luck to come along just as British pop was about to be purged by the Madchester movement. The Wets - unfortunate abbreviation - suddenly looked like earnest traditionalists in stonewashed denim. So, while they were commercially hot, selling 2.5 million copies of their first album, Popped In, Souled Out, the more adult press never took them seriously. It bothered Pellow - a lot.

"Credibility and success never came hand in hand," he says resignedly. "We had the success, so who was I searching for to say it's okay? The magazines, the papers? Within the nucleus of the band, they were annoyed that I was singled out. They got used to it after a few albums, because they got an extra hour in bed."

As Wishing I Was Lucky became the first of 26 hits, they quickly got rich, too. Fresh off the dole, they indulged themselves like lottery winners. It wasn't just Ferraris (Pellow had two) and big houses, but larks such as having curries flown from their favourite Glasgow takeaway, Cafe India, to gigs in Europe. "Who cares how much it cost?" he says, still amused. "It made sense at the time. A lot of stuff like that went on. We were young guys with lots of money and no ties and not a care in the world. I look back and think how amazing it was, first time in Paris, the Eiffel Tower, Australia. I'd never even been out of the UK before."

He still can't quite articulate what he sought from drugs, just that an indefinable something was missing from an otherwise enviable life. He had £3 million in the bank, the esteem of fans and a long-term relationship with the supportive Catterson. And yet, he gropes to explain, "it became hard work".

It is currently fashionable for pop stars to insist that, despite achieving everything they have ever hoped for, it hasn't filled the void within. Robbie Williams claims that being rich and adored has left him "in bits", while Spice Girl Mel C recently admitted to being on anti-depressants. The term "paradise syndrome" has been coined to describe the feeling, pithily summed up by the late Michael Hutchence, of "getting to the top and finding there's nothing there". When it hit Pellow, 10 years into his career, he smothered the feeling with the strongest medication he could find.

"The heroin started around 1996. I had always dabbled in other drugs and I was really drinking heavily by then, big time. Life was great, and I should have been happy, but ... I had the cars, the big house, but I lived in the servants' quarters. What's that all about? It was bullshit."

He swirls his coffee and props his chin in his hand, looking unhappy. "I suddenly thought that there's not a day gone by that I haven't had a drink in the past five years. I'd binge for two or three days at a time. And then, as soon as I first tried heroin, I thought, 'Where has this been?' I'd found my private Idaho. What a pain reliever. It made me feel whole, made me feel ..." He pauses, searching for the word.

Warm? He nods emphatically. "It's still crazy for me. I knew smackheads in the [housing] schemes and I used to think, 'I'll never do that', but when I started, I thought, 'This is what it's all about.'" His use quickly escalated. "As soon as I started, I wanted it all the time. I stopped drinking, substituting one for another. It was about self-medicating, making myself numb. I kept piling shite on, piling it on. I felt very dark. At Christmas 1998, I didn't want to be with anyone I knew, so I stayed alone in a cabin. I called my mother and Eileen to wish them happy Christmas and managed to sound happy. But I'd be up at 5am and run out of drugs and be having cold sweats and think, 'Fuck, why am I doing this?' I'd get occasional little moments of clarity and see pain on the faces of my family."

He had tried rehab in the summer of 1998 at the Meadows clinic in Arizona, but bought more drugs the day he left. "They told me that I'd have to commit to a lifetime of sobriety, and I was like, 'Aaaahh!' But I had more knowledge of my disease after that, so using was never the same again. My disease wanted me dead. I was afraid to stand in front of the sun because [I thought] you'd see all my internal organs. Everyone in the Wet Wet Wet camp acknowledged the problem, but I was still in denial."

Then came his collapse at the Conrad Hotel, after which he checked into the Priory and became the latest popster to begin the well-trodden road to recovery. He grins almost fondly. "My charm did not work in the slightest at the Priory. My smile was the first thing to go." He spent six weeks there, and his first act on leaving was to quit the band - against manager Elliot Davies's wishes. "The best chance he has of getting back to his best is to get back to Wet Wet Wet," Davies still maintains a year later. Pellow disagrees.

That he has thrown himself into sobriety is obvious from a vocabulary that's dotted with words such as "sharing" and "co-dependence". Sometimes, he goes to more than one NA meeting a day, and says that he takes his recovery a day at a time. He's been proactive, finding new management and making a new album, which is said to be adult pop with a soulful twist. He recorded it in Memphis with Willie Mitchell, who apparently amused him during the sessions by telling stories about his old buddy Martin Luther King. "The feel is real, it's me. There's a dignity and simplicity to the songwriting I've never had before," he says, relieved to be talking about music, still his chief passion.

Pellow is now a member of that very Y2K club of celebrities who nearly fell off the edge and were pulled back by a combination of therapy and abstinence. His experience has made him a more rounded individual, but for those to whom he'll always be Smiler it is still a shock. If even Smiler couldn't hack success, can any other supposedly wholesome star be quite what they seem?

 Marti Pellow's tour begins on November 10 at the Manchester Apollo and finishes at the Clyde Auditorium, Glasgow, on November 21, taking in the Albert Hall, London, on November 13 and 14.

I look back and think how amazing it was, first time in Paris, the Eiffel Tower, Australia. I'd never even been out of the UK before." He still can't quite articulate what he sought from drugs, just that an indefinable something was missing from an otherwise enviable life. He had £3 million in the bank, the esteem of fans and a long-term relationship with the supportive Catterson. And yet, he gropes to explain, "it became hard work". It is currently fashionable for pop stars to insist that, despite achieving everything they have ever hoped for, it hasn't filled the void within. Robbie Williams claims that being rich and adored has left him "in bits", while Spice Girl Mel C recently admitted to being on anti-depressants. The term "paradise syndrome" has been coined to describe the feeling, pithily summed up by the late Michael Hutchence, of "getting to the top and finding there's nothing there". When it hit Pellow, 10 years into his career, he smothered the feeling with the strongest medication he could find. "The heroin started around 1996. I had always dabbled in other drugs and I was really drinking heavily by then, big time. Life was great, and I should have been happy, but ... I had the cars, the big house, but I lived in the servants' quarters. What's that all about? It was bullshit." He swirls his coffee and props his chin in his hand, looking unhappy. "I suddenly thought that there's not a day gone by that I haven't had a drink in the past five years. I'd binge for two or three days at a time. And then, as soon as I first tried heroin, I thought, 'Where has this been?' I'd found my private Idaho. What a pain reliever. It made me feel whole, made me feel ..." He pauses, searching for the word. Warm? He nods emphatically. "It's still crazy for me. I knew smackheads in the [housing] schemes and I used to think, 'I'll never do that', but when I started, I thought, 'This is what it's all about.'" His use quickly escalated. "As soon as I started, I wanted it all the time. I stopped drinking, substituting one for another. It was about self-medicating, making myself numb. I kept piling shite on, piling it on. I felt very dark. At Christmas 1998, I didn't want to be with anyone I knew, so I stayed alone in a cabin. I called my mother and Eileen to wish them happy Christmas and managed to sound happy. But I'd be up at 5am and run out of drugs and be having cold sweats and think, 'Fuck, why am I doing this?' I'd get occasional little moments of clarity and see pain on the faces of my family." He had tried rehab in the summer of 1998 at the Meadows clinic in Arizona, but bought more drugs the day he left. "They told me that I'd have to commit to a lifetime of sobriety, and I was like, 'Aaaahh!' But I had more knowledge of my disease after that, so using was never the same again. My disease wanted me dead. I was afraid to stand in front of the sun because [I thought] you'd see all my internal organs. Everyone in the Wet Wet Wet camp acknowledged the problem, but I was still in denial." Then came his collapse at the Conrad Hotel, after which he checked into the Priory and became the latest popster to begin the well-trodden road to recovery. He grins almost fondly. "My charm did not work in the slightest at the Priory. My smile was the first thing to go." He spent six weeks there, and his first act on leaving was to quit the band - against manager Elliot Davies's wishes. "The best chance he has of getting back to his best is to get back to Wet Wet Wet," Davies still maintains a year later. Pellow disagrees. That he has thrown himself into sobriety is obvious from a vocabulary that's dotted with words such as "sharing" and "co-dependence". Sometimes, he goes to more than one NA meeting a day, and says that he takes his recovery a day at a time. He's been proactive, finding new management and making a new album, which is said to be adult pop with a soulful twist. He recorded it in Memphis with Willie Mitchell, who apparently amused him during the sessions by telling stories about his old buddy Martin Luther King. "The feel is real, it's me. There's a dignity and simplicity to the songwriting I've never had before," he says, relieved to be talking about music, still his chief passion. Pellow is now a member of that very Y2K club of celebrities who nearly fell off the edge and were pulled back by a combination of therapy and abstinence. His experience has made him a more rounded individual, but for those to whom he'll always be Smiler it is still a shock. If even Smiler couldn't hack success, can any other supposedly wholesome star be quite what they seem?  Marti Pellow's tour begins on November 10 at the Manchester Apollo and finishes at the Clyde Auditorium, Glasgow, on November 21, taking in the Albert Hall, London, on November 13 and 14.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Uganda's Ebola toll reaches 68
fields.body:
Uganda's Ebola toll reaches 68

Sixty-eight out of a reported 191 victims of the deadly Ebola fever in northern Uganda have now died, the World Health Organisation said yesterday.

They include a nurse who died after being infected through contact with patients. WHO expects the outbreak to last another two to three months and that the number of cases will rise.
Reuters, Geneva

Spanish ports under siege

Spanish fishermen protesting at high fuel prices blockaded Barcelona, Bilbao and other ports for four hours yesterday.

Meanwhile, Spain's largest oil company, Repsol YPF, announced its second big price rise in two weeks, raising the prospect of renewed demonstrations by farmers, truckers and taxi drivers, most of whom accepted a package of government concessions last month to end fuel protests.
AP, Madrid

Envoy quandary for Bangladesh

Bangladesh has found itself in a diplomatic dilemma after busting a smuggling ring which uses foreign envoys.

In the past month contraband cigarettes, alcohol and watches worth £2.5m brought into the country in diplomatic baggage have been seized. Although the diplomatic missions of Iraq, the Philippines and Bhutan have been implicated, no one has yet been arrested.
Arshad Mahmud, Dhaka

Faroes set for freedom vote

The Faroe Islands may vote next year on independence from Denmark, which is currently in charge of foreign, security and defence policy for the cluster of 18 tiny islands and their 45,000 inhabitants.

Talks on a new treaty between the Faroes and Denmark broke down on Thursday, prompting the Faroese prime minister, Anfinn Kallsberg, to announce the referendum plan.
Reuters, Copenhagen

Czech reactor is shut down

The nuclear reactor at the controversial Czech power plant in Temelin has been shut down because of a failure of the pumps in the circulation system.

The plant's safety system was not affected, a spokesman said, adding that the company which provided the technology, the American corporation Westinghouse, was identifying the exact cause of the failure.
AP, Prague

Dog's life ends in gator's jaws

An alligator crawled out of a pond and ate a dog as it splashed in the water in Bossier City, Louisiana. The dog's owner, Bill Jones, said he tried to grab the labrador but was knocked down by the alligator's tail.

Alligators can be found in every big lake, river, bayou, creek and farm pond in Louisiana, said Steve Hebert, a wildlife division supervisor.
AP, Bossier City

webTitle: Big-name brands bonanza for the bargain hunters

fields.headline: Big-name brands bonanza for the bargain hunters
fields.standfirst: Marks & Spencer is joining the ranks of retailers offering stock at big discounts in factory outlets all over the country. Jill Papworth has a guide for frugal shoppers
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer is joining the ranks of retailers offering stock at big discounts in factory outlets all over the country. Jill Papworth has a guide for frugal shoppers.
fields.body:
This autumn is a great time for bargain-hunters. The UK's latest factory shopping village, the McArthurGlen Designer Outlet in Livingston, Scotland, opened this week offering 30%-70% off the normal retail prices of more than 100 well-known brands under one roof plus themed restaurants, an eight-screen cinema and a fitness centre.

Also launched this week was the eighth edition of that bargain-hunter's bible The Good Deal Directory 2001, which provides county-by-county listings of 2,800 factory shops, permanent discount outlets, dress agencies and architectural salvage sites in the UK with money-saving tips on buying top brand names at discount prices.

The book is accompanied by a new website, www.gooddealdirectory.co.uk, which, as well as listing factory villages and other discount outlets, offers the latest news on sales and bargains around the country and a search facility for shoppers trying to track down specific cut-price brand names in their area.

The latest big name to join the discount scene is Marks & Spencer, which is opening its first three factory shops in the next month at Ashford, Kent (November 2), Cheshire Oaks, South Wirral (November 9) and the new Livingston site (November 16).

Among bargains to be had at the M&S cut-price stores will be ladies' silk cashmere cardigans down from £75 to £37.50, men's wool suits down from £150 to £75, ladies' leather shoes down from £35 to £20 and ladies' satin pyjamas down from £25 to £15.

There are about 1,500 individual factory shops in the UK, many of them in isolated spots or on industrial estates, selling manufacturers' surplus stock - cancelled orders, returned merchandise, over-production, seconds and discontinued lines - at prices much below those in the high street shops which the factory supplies.

"Discounts vary, but in general they are higher in the fashion sector, where an outfit can become out of date very quickly and where mark-ups can be as high as 280%, and lower in ceramics and glassware," says Noelle Walsh, author of The Good Deal Directory. "The older the item is, the cheaper the price. As a general rule, you can expect at least 30% off and up to 80%."

In the 90s developers started gathering together lots of these shops on one site in factory shopping villages ranging in size from K Village in Kendal, Cumbria, with a dozen shops, to McArthurGlen's Cheshire Oaks village in South Wirral with more than 150. With new villages due to open during 2001 at Harwich in Essex, Lichfield in the west midlands and at Salford Quays in Manchester, there will be at least 35 by the end of next year.

Best for label snobs and fashion aficionados, according to Noelle Walsh, is Bicester Village in Oxfordshire, boasting more than 70 shops with prices reduced by up to 60%, and McArthurGlen's York outlet, currently with 75 shops and 150 more planned.

Home-loving families looking for children's wear should head for Clarks Village at Street in Somerset and McArthurGlen villages in Swindon and Cheshire Oaks.

And if you want to combine bargain shopping with a fun day out for the family, best bets will be the Clacton Factory Outlet Village in Essex and the Freeport Shopping Village in Fleetwood, Lancashire, which both have seaside locations offering plenty of leisure facilities such as children's play areas and rides.

Top tips for factory shop bargain hunters

Visit villages if possible on a week day when things are quiet - 80% of factory village shopping customers visit on a weekend.

Although they don't advertise the fact, most factory villages slash prices still further at traditional high street sale times - January and June/July. The downside is that your choice of lines will be more limited at sale times.

Best buys are always the more expensive items. So use factory shopping as a chance to "go up a brand" from those you can normally afford.

Turnover is usually very fast. So if you like something, buy it; you are unlikely to find it again.

Carry the measurements of rooms, windows and family members with you so that you are prepared to snap up bargains as and when you spot them.

Never travel a long way without phoning first to check opening hours and directions. If you are after particular brand names, also check first on stock levels.

When buying discounted goods, you have the same rights under the Sale of Goods Act 1979 and the Consumer Protection Act 1987 as you would in mainstream shops.

Check if an item is a sec ond. You'll usually find a label on the garment stating why this is so. Although your statutory rights are in place at factory shops, you can't return a second because of a fault indicated at the outset.

Items are not always as flatteringly presented as in high street stores, so be prepared to rummage.

If you are looking for the height of fashion, factory shopping isn't for you. But factory shopping is great for children's clothes, jeans, leisure wear, sweaters, underwear and classic items which don't date such as blazers, coats and raincoats.

 The Good Deal Directory 2001, costing £9.99 plus £1 p&p, can be ordered on 01367-860016 or via the website, www.gooddealdirectory.co.uk. Details of McArthurGlen Designer Outlets on 0800-316-4352; Freeport Designer Outlet Villages on 020-7299-9360; on 01869-323-200. K Village, Cumbria 01539-732363. Clacton Factory Outlet Village 01255-430777

fields.headline: Omagh families launch civil action
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Relatives of four children killed in the Omagh bombing are to launch a civil action against a group of suspects named in a BBC Panorama investigation into the 1998 atrocity.
fields.body:
Relatives of four children killed in the Omagh bombing are to launch a civil action against a group of suspects named in a BBC Panorama investigation into the 1998 atrocity.

The families of James Barker, 12, Samantha McFarland, 17, Lorraine Wilson, 15, and 20-month-old Breda Devine believe that suing the suspects is their only hope of justice.

Police insist that they know the identities of the bombers from the breakaway Real IRA who launched the attack which killed 29 people in the Co Tyrone town in August 1998. But the authorities have been unable to mount prosecutions because they do not have sufficient evidence to bring the suspects to court for the single worst atrocity in the Northern Ireland troubles.

James Barker's father, Victor, said last night that his family was determined to see justice. "There cannot be peace without justice," Mr Barker said. "We feel it's high time these people were made to account for their movements and civil action is one way to do that. It may well be in the course of that action other information might come forward which would help the police pursue their criminal inquiry."

Mr Barker said the relatives had decided to launch the civil action in the names of the families of four children to simplify proceedings. "We chose a small cross-section to highlight the fact that so many children and young people were killed," he said. "This is not a political issue, it is not sectarian, it is a question of justice."

The Daily Mail today launches a campaign to help pay the families' legal costs for the civil action, which is likely to be launched in the Irish Republic. Mr Barker said the action would only go ahead if the families were able to raise £2m.

The Omagh campaign follows a Panorama programme in which the Northern Ireland reporter John Ware named four men from the Irish Republic who were allegedly involved in the bombing.

fields.headline: Yorkshire khat 'mules' arrested in US
fields.trailText: More than a dozen Britons have been arrested in the US in recent months for importing bags of khat - the plant that when chewed produces a similar effect to amphetamine, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
More than a dozen Britons have been arrested in the US in recent months for importing bags of khat - the plant that when chewed produces a similar effect to amphetamine, it emerged yesterday.

The plant, illegal in the US but legal in Britain, is consumed by the Ethiopian, Somali and Yemeni communities. Chewed in moderation, khat reduces fatigue and suppresses appetite.

A Foreign Office spokeswoman said that the arrested Britons came from West Yorkshire and had claimed they were approached in Wakefield and asked to carry luggage to the US.

In Atlanta, one has been convicted and given eight months, while others await a hearing. In Chicago, two were deported after being arrested.

Dave Bayless of the Chicago police department said: "Khat is not a topic of discussion here. I suspect people are trying to sell it where there are east African communities such as the old, large cities like New York and Philadelphia."

In the UK khat is categorised as an unlicenced medicine. It is an offence to supply or sell it, but not to possess it.

In the US one of khat's ingredients, cathinone, is classed as a narcotic.

fields.headline: Bush sweeps into huge lead
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush has surged to a 13-point opinion poll lead over Al Gore with just 10 days to go before the US presidential election on November 7.
fields.body:
George W Bush has surged to a 13-point opinion poll lead over Al Gore with just 10 days to go before the US presidential election on November 7.

Mr Bush, the Republican nominee, is on 52%, with the Democrat, Mr Gore, now trailing on 39% in the latest Gallup daily tracking poll for CNN and USA Today. The Green candidate, Ralph Nader, has 4%.

The new poll means that Mr Bush has benefited from a three-point swing in the past 24 hours, a remarkable boost by any standards. In Thursday's Gallup poll, Mr Bush was on 49% with Mr Gore 42% and Mr Nader 3%.

Yesterday's 13-point margin is Mr Bush's biggest lead over Mr Gore since before the party conventions in August.

If the Gallup poll is correct - and some experts think it could be a rogue result of the kind that shows up in any campaign - Mr Gore would seem to face an almost hopeless task with only 10 days before election day.

The Republicans, meanwhile, stand on the threshold of regaining the White House after eight years of Bill Clinton's presidency.

The accuracy of the Gallup finding was challenged last night by the polling director of the Washington Post, which is conducting its own daily tracking polls, similar to the Gallup survey. The latest Washington Post survey showed Mr Bush with a much narrower 48%-45% lead over Mr Gore, while a third tracking survey for Reuters/MSNBC showed Mr Bush on a slim one-point lead.

"All I can say is I would love to be tracking the election that Gallup is tracking," said Richard Morin, the Post's polling director. "It's a lot more interesting election than the one I'm looking at. I see something far more stable than the Gallup numbers suggest."

But a separate Gallup survey for Time magazine today also showed Mr Bush with a clear lead, 49%-43%, over Mr Gore, with Mr Nader on 3%.

All three tracking surveys produce rolling results based on the last three days of daily surveying. Each day's new result is obtained by adding the latest day's sample and discarding the four-day-old segment.

Such tracking polls have become increasingly prominent in this year's Bush-Gore contest because of what has otherwise been an exceptionally close and volatile race. Mr Gore led by 46% to 45% in Gallup's tracking survey as recently as Tuesday.

The fluidity of the closest presidential contest in decades was underlined by a series of state-based polls which brought some comfort to all the candidates. Mr Gore campaigned yesterday in Pennsylvania where a poll gave him a five-point lead. Mr Bush, meanwhile, was in Michigan, where the two men are in a virtual dead heat in the state which could ultimately tip the balance. Meanwhile, Mr Bush was eight points up in Ohio, a local poll suggested.

Mr Nader's increasing importance was underlined by a poll in Minnesota that showed him holding the difference between the two frontrunners. Mr Bush had a 41% to 38% lead over Mr Gore in the always independent-minded state, with Mr Nader on 10%.

The increasingly tense and bitter final stages of the election were marked yesterday by an extraordinary off-message move by supporters of the Bush campaign in Texas, who began airing a television advertisement implying that Mr Gore would lead the US into a nuclear conflict with China.

The ad, which is modelled on a celebrated 1964 commercial which did much to destroy the presidential campaign of the Republican presidential candidate, Barry Goldwater, in his contest with Lyndon Johnson, shows a young girl picking the petals off a daisy as a nuclear explosion occurs. It began running in Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Florida yesterday.

The commentary claims the Clinton-Gore administration "sold" America's security "to Communist red China in exchange for campaign contributions".

Mr Gore claimed the ad was "another personal attack" by Mr Bush's supporters. A campaign spokesman for Mr Bush disavowed the ad.

Mr Bush had a 41% to 38% lead over Mr Gore in the always independent-minded state, with Mr Nader on 10%. The increasingly tense and bitter final stages of the election were marked yesterday by an extraordinary off-message move by supporters of the Bush campaign in Texas, who began airing a television advertisement implying that Mr Gore would lead the US into a nuclear conflict with China. The ad, which is modelled on a celebrated 1964 commercial which did much to destroy the presidential campaign of the Republican presidential candidate, Barry Goldwater, in his contest with Lyndon Johnson, shows a young girl picking the petals off a daisy as a nuclear explosion occurs. It began running in Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Florida yesterday. The commentary claims the Clinton-Gore administration "sold" America's security "to Communist red China in exchange for campaign contributions". Mr Gore claimed the ad was "another personal attack" by Mr Bush's supporters. A campaign spokesman for Mr Bush disavowed the ad.

fields.headline: Weller rape case dropped
fields.trailText: Paul Weller was told by police yesterday that he would not be charged with rape after being arrested last week.
fields.body:
Paul Weller was told by police yesterday that he would not be charged with rape after being arrested last week.

The rock singer said: "Rape is despicable, and to be accused of the crime has been one of the most depressing moments of my life."

Weller added that, in the light of his experience, both parties in rape cases ought to be given anonymity, especially before any charge being brought, and suggested that the news of his being cleared would not get the prominence given that of his arrest.

The former Jam and Style Council star, 42, was questioned by Surrey police and later released on police bail. The incident was alleged to have happened in Farnham at the end of 1996, the alleged victim being a 36-year-old woman, believed to be from Streatham, south London.

fields.headline: Dutch raids bare Bond-like cache
fields.trailText: Mobile telephones that shoot bullets and lethal key-rings have been found by the Dutch police in a cache of weapons which would not be out of place in the latest James Bond movie, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Mobile telephones that shoot bullets and lethal key-rings have been found by the Dutch police in a cache of weapons which would not be out of place in the latest James Bond movie, it emerged yesterday.

The weapons, intended for Europe's increasingly sophisticated criminal underworld, include mobile phones which fire .22-calibre bullets at the touch of a button and miniature handguns disguised as innocent-looking key-rings. The eight lethal phones confiscated hold four bullets each, while the 29 key chains take one shot but can be reloaded.

"It's the first time we've come across weapons such as this and, at close range, they can be deadly," a police spokesman said.

"The key-rings are very small, mostly black and are a similar shape to a Zippo cigarette lighter. They look very normal."

Other, more conventional, tools of the criminal trade - machine guns, handguns, 20 hand grenades, 2,000 bullets and 12kgs of explosives, were also found in five different house raids in the past month in the suburbs of Amsterdam and in the outlying towns of Amstelveen and Bos en Lommerbuurt.

Five men and a woman have been arrested, several of whom are known to be Yugoslavs and Turks. Most of the hi-tech weaponry originated in Yugoslavia.

webTitle: Doctor, I think I'm a pair of curtains

fields.headline: Doctor, I think I'm a pair of curtains
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of the NHS
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: My wife works for the NHS, and the other day she received a printed selection of "actual sentences found in patients' charts", meaning the notes made on cases by doctors, nurses and consultants. It's one of those lists every profession seems to have circulating, but none the worse for that. There are too many to print, but here are some of my favourites:
fields.body:
My wife works for the NHS, and the other day she received a printed selection of "actual sentences found in patients' charts", meaning the notes made on cases by doctors, nurses and consultants. It's one of those lists every profession seems to have circulating, but none the worse for that. There are too many to print, but here are some of my favourites:

"She has no rigors or shaking chills, but her husband states she was very hot in bed last night."

"Patient has chest pain if she lies on her left side for over a year."

"The patient is tearful and crying constantly. She also appears to be depressed."

"Discharge status: alive, but without my permission."

"The patient refused autopsy."

"Between you and me, we ought to be able to get this lady pregnant."

"She stated she had been constipated for most of her life, until she got a divorce."

"Examination of the genitalia reveals that he is circus-sized." (What makes me think that one was dictated to a secretary?)

"The patient was to have a bowel resection. However, he took a job as a stockbroker instead."

"Rectal examination revealed a normal sized thyroid."

"The patient has no previous history of suicides."

"She has been depressed since she began seeing me in 1983."

Some of them have a further use: they are an excellent reminder for children of the importance of good punctuation.

I spent last weekend in Cheltenham at the annual literary festival, which is always huge fun. On the Saturday I took part in a discussion of political diaries, along with Joe Ashton MP, whose often hilarious memoir Red Rose Blues is just out, Ion Trewin, who edited the latest Alan Clark diaries, and Gyles Brandreth, whose diaries of a whip, Breaking The Code, I can also recommend. (Though Gyles is one of nature's instinctive sycophants. He approached us all with warm words of praise for something we'd just done. I said, "Gyles, the day you come up to me and say, 'Simon, what you write in the Guardian is utter crap,' is the day I shall believe you.' " But his book is genuinely good, even if I cannot bring myself to tell him personally.)

He told an interesting story about the Tory whips' office. Whenever someone came into possession of a particularly intriguing nugget about an MP, on either side, whether gossip or hard fact, they had to write it down and lock it away in a safe for future use.

The safe had a combination lock, but to make sure everyone could remember the number, they selected the digits of the prime minister's birthday.

"But with John Major being famous as the grey man, nobody could remember what his birthday was. So they had to leave a copy of Who's Who open at 'M' next to the safe," he revealed. A smart cat burglar-cum-blackmailer could have retired for life if they had known that.

The following day I took part in a cunning wheeze: every year Cheltenham has a "Booker Prize" for a particular year, in this case 1925. It was a rich crop, including Gentlemen Prefer Blondes, by Anita Loos, Mrs Dalloway by Virginia Woolf, The Great Gatsby and Carry On, Jeeves. My book, An American Tragedy by Theodore Dreiser, was, at 846 pages, longer than the other four combined. My arguments cannot have been persuasive, because it was one of the first to be tossed out of the reckoning. (Gatsby rightly won.)

The other speakers were all of a scholarly and literary bent, able to marshall influential arguments smoothly and articulately. After a while I began to feel unnervingly out of place, like the thick Brummie in The Fast Show. When someone said, "Well, Simon, that's a very unusual way of putting it," I did reply: "Royt, oy'll just get me coat..."

I ran into a crossbench peer this week, who told me that Baroness Jay, the owner of so many lovely houses, is now universally called Posh Spice. The flame-haired Baroness Hollis is known as Ginger Spice, and awed lords refer to Baroness Blackstone as Scary Spice. But Baby and Sporty are still up for grabs; he hoped for suggestions.

I won't bore you with the grisly details of my train journeys this week. (Average nominal length, one hour. Average delay, 52 minutes). However, the scene in our railway stations would fill a canvas worthy of Frith. At the great terminals people gaze mournfully up at the departure boards, like the survivors of the Medusa looking desperately for a sail.

Periodically impenetrable voices boom out bringing news of fresh delays and cancellations, though to which trains it is impossible to say. At unmanned rural halts, disembodied upper-class women recite prerecorded lies, promising the imminent arrival of services that do not exist.

It is like one reads about wartime: people turn up at the station in the hope of a train, and if there is one, they climb aboard in hope, not expectation. Some are so crowded that it would be illegal to carry cattle in the same conditions.

At Paddington, where I have spent a large part of the week, there are now dozens of smart new retail outlets, selling exotic soups, handbags, groceries, jewellery, saucy birthday cards and electrical goods. These shops are bright and efficient, and this week thronged with people.

The difference is that these stores are all in competition: if their shareholders are to get their money they have to offer a first-rate service. But the railways are run by subsidised monopolies, which can divert our fares and taxes to their shareholders whether they run trains or not.

Soon, I suspect, they will abolish that side of the business, and these once great temples to Victorian pride and engineering will exist solely as upmarket malls.

fields.headline: Allied Domecq agrees to £1bn deal
fields.trailText: Spirits group Allied Domecq has agreed a deal worth more than $1bn (£700m) to take control of the Captain Morgan rum brand in a move that puts it in pole position in the auction for Canadian group Seagram's drinks business.
fields.body:
Spirits group Allied Domecq has agreed a deal worth more than $1bn (£700m) to take control of the Captain Morgan rum brand in a move that puts it in pole position in the auction for Canadian group Seagram's drinks business.

Captain Morgan is at present produced by a Puerto Rican firm, Destileria Serralles, but distributed and marketed worldwide by Seagram.

In the event of a change of ownership of Seagram, the Puerto Rican firm has first refusal to buy back the rights to the rum.

Under the terms of yesterday's agreement Destileria Serralles will exercise its right to snatch full control of Captain Morgan, irrespective of the outcome of the battle to buy Seagram.

It will then sell on the international rights to Allied Domecq.

Allied's chief executive, Philip Bowman, said: "I've always said that in our brand portfolio we don't have a dark rum and we don't have a vodka. This fills a gap.

"Captain Morgan is a large brand and it's been showing very significant growth, particularly over the last five years." Captain Morgan is considered one of the jewels in the crown of Seagram's £4.5bn drinks business, which also includes Chivas Regal whisky and Martell cognac.

Allied Domecq is battling to buy Seagram's portfolio but faces stiff opposition from a joint bid by Diageo and Pernod Ricard.

Seagram's founders, the Bronfman family, are also planning a bid but are seen as outsiders.

At the least, yesterday's deal will give Allied a consolation prize if it looses out on the bidding for the rest of Seagram.

webTitle: Narrow gap between US presidential candidates

fields.headline: Close encounter
fields.standfirst:
Not since 1960 has the gap been so narrow

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Not since 1960 has the gap been so narrow, reports Martin Kettle in Washington.
fields.body:
George W Bush and Al Gore are locked in the closest US presidential election since 1960, and campaigns don't come any closer, or any dirtier, than that one.

According to most opinion polls, John Kennedy and Richard Nixon were dead level at the end of the party convention season. Then, after the four presidential debates in September and October, Kennedy inched slightly ahead.

In the final days of the campaign, however, President Dwight D Eisenhower began to campaign for Nixon, and Kennedy's narrow lead began to be eroded.

The campaign was marked by a barrage of dirty tricks on both sides as Kennedy and Nixon used their underworld connections and their money to try to swing the election.

Both sides dug for dirt. The Kennedy camp was on the verge of releasing a story that Nixon had regularly attended parties with prostitutes at the Florida home of his friend Bebe Rebozo when they discovered that Kennedy had been a visitor too.

The FBI director, J Edgar Hoover, slipped the Nixon campaign several files on Kennedy's sex life, including the rumour that JFK had a secret first marriage: a revelation which would have been devastating to the Catholic Kennedy.

Ironically, in light of Nixon's later career, the Republicans were convinced that Kennedy had bugged their telephones. Nixon himself later claimed that Robert Kennedy, John's younger brother and later his attorney general, was the worst. "He illegally bugged more people than anyone. He was a bastard."

John Kennedy, no slouch in the political black arts himself, was no less outspoken. In the final week of the campaign he told his speech writer Richard Goodwin that Nixon was "a filthy, lying son of a bitch, and a very dangerous man".

The role of organised crime in the election continues to intrigue new generations of investigators. At the time the Chicago mafia boss Sam Giancana, who shared a mistress with Kennedy, bragged that JFK "wouldn't even be in the White House" without his organisation's intimidation at the polls in Illinois.

The result of the 1960 election was the tightest in modern times: Kennedy became president with 49.71% of the popular vote, compared with Nixon's 49.55% - a margin of 113,000 votes from a turnout of nearly 69m voters.

To his dying day Nixon believed that 1960 was the stolen election. Dirty tricks were alleged in several states, notably Illinois, Missouri, New Jersey, Texas, and West Virginia. Mayor Richard Daley of Chicago - the father of Al Gore's campaign manager, Bill Daley - famously told Kennedy late on election day: "With a little bit of luck and the help of a few close friends, you're going to carry Illinois."

The turnout in Chicago in 1960 was an amazing 89%: nationally it was only 63%.

webTitle: BSE teams rethink size of epidemic

fields.headline: BSE teams rethink size of epidemic
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Government scientists are making an urgent reassessment of the possible size of the human BSE epidemic after confirmation that a 74-year-old man has died of the disease.
fields.body:
Government scientists are making an urgent reassessment of the possible size of the human BSE epidemic after confirmation that a 74-year-old man has died of the disease.

The victim , believed to be from North Yorkshire, was 20 years older than the previous oldest known case of the inevitably fatal condition.

The man died last year and his case was only revealed after doctors, worried that this might be a highly unusual instance of the disease known as variant CJD, referred the case to the CJD survillance unit at Edinburgh.

It was also revealed last night that officials responsible for the safety of medicines are to look at the use of vaccines used throughout the 1970s.

This followed the finding of Lord Phillips' BSE inquiry report, published on Thursday, that BSE might have existed in a series of rapidly increasing epidemic waves from 1970 until it finally became obvious as hundreds of cows began to die in 1987-88.

Previous checks concentrated on those using calf serum from pregnant cows used to develop products in the 1980s and only last week the Department of Health found that one of those was still in use despite guidelines that were meant to ban the use of products made from British bovine sources.

Victims of vCJD have previously all been between 15 and 54, although a 14-year-old girl who first displayed signs of the disease when she was 12 is still alive. But the latest revelation of a much older victim is expected to lead to increased scrutiny by neurologists of older patients, previously thought less susceptible to the disease.

The government is already funding a study in Nottingham in which experts are re-assessing diagnoses of dementia in older people who died in the area in recent years. But it has not yet uncovered any mistakes. The health department said it would not hesistate to act quickly if any new cases of older victims were revealed.

No one was prepared to speculate openly on the significance of the new discovery last night but the government will be hoping the latest victim was an older consumer, during the 1980s, of cheap beef products that were usually eaten by far younger people.

Among alternatives being considered, however, is that the older man came from a previous wave of "infection" during the 1970s when the population's exposure to BSE was far lower and the possibility of being unlucky to catch a fatal "dose" far lower.

Eating cheap meat before anti-BSE measures to protect human health were phased in from 1989 is the explanation still favoured by most experts but Lord Phillips said there must be a re-examination of other possible routes.

The most recent estimates of the size of the epidemic - from just over 100 to over 100,000 - were based on the pattern of cases so far, the percentage of the population thought at risk, the relative infectivity of cattle, and the likely incubation period.

The Oxford-based team responsible for the estimates suggested in August that young people were either more susceptible or more exposed to BSE. But Prof Roy Anderson, one of that team and a member of the government's spongiform encephalopathy advisory committee (Seac), said of the new case: "This leads to a reappraisal of the ages at which people are susceptible to this disease."

He said there were still many unknowns about the disease, including the incubation period. "If that incubation period is short - and this is an optimistic scenario - say eight years, then this year and the next two years may see the worst of the epidemic.

"If, which is equally probably at the moment, that incubation operiod is long, perhaps 20-30 years, then we have only seen a very small part of the epidemic." He added: "We can't say with any certainty where the number will lie."

Seac was already reassessing predictions because of a sharp rise in cases of vCJD in recent months. Eighty Britons have died from the disease and five more still alive have been diagnosed as victims.

The Department of Health said of the new case: "This certainly raises a lot of questions. It reinforces the need for vigilance, particularly when you are looking at older patients."

On vaccines, the committee on the safety of medicines would look again at safety issues although it was believed that most in use in the 1970s, were either made from British bovine material in the 1960s when BSE was not in the herd or from American BSE-free sources.

He added: "We can't say with any certainty where the number will lie." Seac was already reassessing predictions because of a sharp rise in cases of vCJD in recent months. Eighty Britons have died from the disease and five more still alive have been diagnosed as victims. The Department of Health said of the new case: "This certainly raises a lot of questions. It reinforces the need for vigilance, particularly when you are looking at older patients." On vaccines, the committee on the safety of medicines would look again at safety issues although it was believed that most in use in the 1970s, were either made from British bovine material in the 1960s when BSE was not in the herd or from American BSE-free sources. webTitle: Microsoft: Whodunnit? The professional hacker or unwitting employee

fields.headline: Whodunnit? The professional hacker or unwitting employee
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of Microsoft
Net news
fields.trailText: Cock-up or conspiracy? Only the hacker and Microsoft know whether the penetration of its computer systems was a skilled break-in using custom code, or whether somebody working for the software giant did something human, and stupid. Microsoft is not saying.
fields.body:
Cock-up or conspiracy? Only the hacker and Microsoft know whether the penetration of its computer systems was a skilled break-in using custom code, or whether somebody working for the software giant did something human, and stupid. Microsoft is not saying.

Chris McNab, a network security analyst at MIS Corporate Defence Solutions in Maidstone, says there are three possible scenarios. The most feasible, in his view, is that the hacker got a Trojan (rogue program) past Microsoft's defences using email.

The second possibility is that the hacker exploited a security lapse: perhaps an employee disabled his security software, or not all Microsoft's anti-virus software was kept up to date.

The third possibility is that it was "an inside job": a disaffected employee or "summer intern" let the hacker in.

The current speculation is that Microsoft's firewalls (software designed to block intruders) and mailsweepers (software to detect malicious code attached to email messages) were penetrated by a Trojan: a program that presents itself as, perhaps, a useful document, image file, utility or game.

When the user runs the attachment, the hidden Trojan code is installed on their computer.

Once installed, the Trojan could, for example, record log-on names and passwords and email them to an address outside Microsoft. The Love Letter virus used similar techniques to mail itself to people in its victims' address books.

The hacker could use the stolen names and passwords to log on to Microsoft's internal network, in effect pretending to be an employee.

Depending on that user's security level, the hacker might be able to find and download the "source code", the program code used to create popular applications such as Microsoft Office or Windows 2000.

Having the source code could enable a hacker to learn the strengths and weaknesses of Microsoft's programs.

According to the conspiracy theory, a skilled hacker created a custom Trojan to evade Microsoft's defences.

But according to the cock-up theory QAZ, or a similar Trojan, was installed by accident, and a hacker got lucky. Perhaps someone downloaded an infected program from the internet, installed it from a CD-rom, or brought in an infected notebook computer.

Such things should not happen, but they do.

Graham Cluley, senior technology consultant at Sophos Anti-Virus in the UK, says: "All companies are at risk, because firewalls and anti-virus software are not enough. Staff have to realise that they can't download programs from the web, and they can't run programs unless there's a justifiable business reason for running them."

fields.headline: After BSE: other scare stories
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the BSE crisis
After BSE: a crisis for science
After BSE: future safety issues
fields.trailText: Mobile phones
fields.body:
Mobile phones

Initial scientific evidence has found exposure to radio frequency radiation might have subtle effects on biological functions, including the brain. Children may be more vulnerable because of their developing nervous system. The tiny pulses of microwaves emitted by mobile phones are of the same type as the radiation used in microwave ovens.

But the safety message is mixed. A DTI report suggested hands-free kits reduce radiation entering the brain. But the Consumers' Association said the kits act like aerials, increasing the radiation.

GM foods

Some scientists fear the artificial nature of modern genetic technologies could damage our environment and health. Ecologists are worried about the danger of herbicide-resistant genes spreading to wild flowers and plants. There is little evidence so far on the dangers but other scientists welcome the development, which could lead to a reduction in the use of pesticides.

Fluoride in water

Opponents claim fluoride causes bone disease, cancer, hyperactive behaviour and impaired intellect, and argue that adding it to water amounts to enforced medication.

Supporters say adding it to water supplies would be the single most effective way of improving dental health.

Nuclear power stations

In April, research suggested women living downwind of mudflats that contain discharges from Hinkley Point in Somerset have twice the risk of breast cancer. Leukaemia clusters have been found near all three nuclear reprocessing plants. So far scientists have failed to agree on the cause.

Antibiotics in foods

Growth promoters have been used extensively in animals' feed and water in British farming for 40 years, especially in the poultry and pig industries. Proponents argue that chickens grow faster and the saving on feed costs is vital in keeping businesses viable and producing birds of the quality required by supermarkets. But there are worries that humans who eat them will become immune to antibiotic medicines.
