fields.headline: BSE nightmare takes new twist
fields.standfirst:
Pensioner's vCJD death raises spectre of 25-year incubation and far more victims

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Even as Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, and health minister Alan Milburn were preparing to make their apologies for the failures of successive governments in getting to grips with BSE and its nightmare human form, revealed in the devastating Phillips report into the catastrophe on Thursday, more bad news was being passed on to their officials.
fields.body:
Even as Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, and health minister Alan Milburn were preparing to make their apologies for the failures of successive governments in getting to grips with BSE and its nightmare human form, revealed in the devastating Phillips report into the catastrophe on Thursday, more bad news was being passed on to their officials.

Investigations into the death of a 74-year-old man last year had concluded that he, too, was a victim of vCJD - news that could lead to a fundamental reassessment of the disease.

No wonder then that Mr Brown announced that the government was already "commissioning an independent assessment of current scientific understanding of the disease, including emerging findings, on the origins of the BSE epidemic".

Behind that flat matter-of-fact announcement was a worrying realisation that the Phillips inquiry belief that BSE could have been in cows since the early 1970s - at least three cycles of the infection before it burst in its full horror on to Britain's dairy farms - would mean scientists would have to think yet again about all the potential risks to human health.

Vaccine

Volume eight of the 16-volume report advises the government it may have to check all vaccines made during the 1970s. Bovine material sourced from Britain in the 1980s is now banned but previous, allegedly inadequate checks by medicine control officials between 1988 and 1992 failed to establish the source of bovine ingredients used in the 1970s to develop the master stocks of batches that could have remained in circulation for years.

Now, said Phillips, "batches of vaccines manufactured during the 1970s cannot therefore be ruled out as a source of infection merely because of their date of manufacture. Patients with vCJD born before 1960 are unlikely to have been infected by childhood vaccination, but the possibility of infection by vaccination in adulthood may merit consideration."

The Phillips team, of course, did not know of the 74-year-old. Now people are wondering just how exposed people were to eating infected meat in the 1970s - long before there were any control mea sures to combat the hidden BSE that can exist in infected cattle well in advance of when they display the classic "mad" signs.

Lord Phillips has made clear that however quickly the government had reacted to the cattle epidemic in the 1980s - and it was sometimes painfully slow - it could not have stopped thousands of diseased and infectious cows entering the food chain and infecting unknown members of the population.

Iceberg

That situation is still far from clear in the population. Is this old man just an unusual aberration in the normal profile of vCJD victims? One of the first reasons early cases of the disease came to attention was their relative youth compared to other sufferers of debilitating and fatal neurological conditions.

Analysis of the ages of the first 77 deaths revealed earlier this month indicates that since 1995, a dozen teenagers have succumbed, three dozen aged between 20 and 29, about 20 between 30 and 39, and about 10 others up to the age of 54. The assumption until now has been they were exposed to poisoned bovine material as the epidemic in cattle began to spiral, perhaps between 1984 and 1989. That would suggest relatively short incubation periods for some, around 10 years.

Zoe Williams, still alive at 14, but a known victim of vCJD at 12, would have been just four when the main anti-BSE measures were introduced.

Yet such vCJD-like diseases can have incubation periods running to 25 or even 35 years. Just suppose the new victim was exposed to BSE in the mid-1970s. But would he be the herald of a new "iceberg" or was he just unlucky?

The truth is that no-one yet knows. So much about the disease is still a mystery despite the huge advances of recent years. No-one knows what the level of an infective "dose" is for a human - BSE-infected material the size of a peppercorn was enough for big cows - or the length of incubation; whether genetic make-up makes people more susceptible (all confirmed cases so far have been from the same group that makes up just under 40% of the population) and whether other factors such as youth, illness, sores or even new teeth increase the risk.

The Phillips team also recommends further investigation of the consumption of cheap beefburgers and other meat products made from mechanically recovered meat which, unlike other risky parts of cows, was not banned until 1995. These are now among prime candidates for carrying infectivity, even if no-one knows how much.

Now, the potential exposure to infected meat spreads more than 20 years - from the mid-1970s and mid-1990s.

No-one knows what the level of an infective "dose" is for a human - BSE-infected material the size of a peppercorn was enough for big cows - or the length of incubation; whether genetic make-up makes people more susceptible (all confirmed cases so far have been from the same group that makes up just under 40% of the population) and whether other factors such as youth, illness, sores or even new teeth increase the risk. The Phillips team also recommends further investigation of the consumption of cheap beefburgers and other meat products made from mechanically recovered meat which, unlike other risky parts of cows, was not banned until 1995. These are now among prime candidates for carrying infectivity, even if no-one knows how much. Now, the potential exposure to infected meat spreads more than 20 years - from the mid-1970s and mid-1990s. webTitle: Leader: America should oust Jesse Helms

fields.headline: Slaying the hawk
fields.standfirst:
America should say goodbye to Mr Helms

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: America's most powerful politician will not be elected next month. For those on the receiving end of US foreign policy, at least, that person, arguably, is Jesse Helms. The hawkish Republican senator from North Carolina is well into his fifth, six-year term. He does not face re-election until 2002.
fields.body:
America's most powerful politician will not be elected next month. For those on the receiving end of US foreign policy, at least, that person, arguably, is Jesse Helms. The hawkish Republican senator from North Carolina is well into his fifth, six-year term. He does not face re-election until 2002. In the meantime, he continues as chairman of the Senate foreign relations committee which, in concert with Congress as a whole, holds the purse strings and has oversight of almost every aspect of US global diplomacy. Nor is Mr Helms at all bashful about exercising his considerable powers or advancing his trenchant opinions.

In the past few weeks alone, Mr Helms has denounced Yasser Arafat as a "terrorist"; dismissed Iranian reform efforts as "hogwash"; described Fidel Castro as a "deadbeat" and "swindler"; condemned normalised trade relations with "communist China"; ridiculed the "sorry performance" of UN peacekeepers in Sierra Leone; blasted the Clinton administration for "inexcusable" delays in building a national missile defence system; and hammered away at the old enemy, Russia.

Thanks in no small measure to Mr Helms, the US has in recent years defaulted on its UN dues, tried to block the planned international criminal court, failed to ratify the comprehensive test ban treaty, been slow to deploy ground troops in both Bosnia and Kosovo (and whinged about it ever since), imposed sanctions on dozens of countries it dislikes, pursued a fruitless, destructive vendetta against Iraq and swung, ideologically speaking, towards an ever more overweening unilateralism.

All this goes down a treat in rightwing circles at home. When George W Bush talks of pulling troops out of the Balkans, Mr Helms's influence is at work. Some foreigners are impressed, too. Lithuania recently gave him the illustrious Medal of Grand Duke Gediminas to add to his two Senate Golden Gavels and his US police federation Golden Eagle Award. All the same, it really is time that Mr Helms, aged 79, slowed down a bit.

Luckily, an opportunity is at hand. If the Democrats can gain five seats on November 7, they will retake control of the Senate and Mr Helms will lose his chairmanship. They may also win the House of Representatives. There are many reasons for wishing the Democrats success in the congressional elections. But for vote-less foreigners, the reactionary, Blimp-ish Mr Helms is the most pressing.

webTitle: Leader: The young are surprisingly bright

fields.headline: Not quite so dumb
fields.standfirst:
The young are brighter than they appear

Special report: are we dumbing down?
fields.trailText: At first sight it looks grim. With its low-scoring results for young adults, the Guardian/ICM poll, as collected in the first of three issues of Dumb?, appears to suggest that British culture is moving towards the evening of its day with unseemly haste. The enormous expansion in education and media over the past half-century - two phenomena one might have expected to encourage the spread of knowledge - only appear to bear out Kingsley Amis's crusty, unpleasant dictum: "more means worse".
fields.body:
At first sight it looks grim. With its low-scoring results for young adults, the Guardian/ICM poll, as collected in the first of three issues of Dumb?, appears to suggest that British culture is moving towards the evening of its day with unseemly haste. The enormous expansion in education and media over the past half-century - two phenomena one might have expected to encourage the spread of knowledge - only appear to bear out Kingsley Amis's crusty, unpleasant dictum: "more means worse".

But it is not as simple as that, which is why there is a question mark on the end of the title. Certainly, a lack among younger people of a reasonable standard of general knowledge (over the next three weeks Dumb? looks at everything from politics to Pokemon, unzipping the very idea of what culture is) raises issues for the future of democracy: how can people exercise an informed choice with apparently empty minds?

Yet we are looking, in 18- to 24-year-olds, at the first generation to have grown up with computers readily available. They know, almost instinctively now, how to retrieve information, and they know they do not have to commit it to memory. In a world of information overload, that might even be a bad idea.

There is plenty in Dumb? that is good news. Our comparative study of exams since 1951 shows pretty conclusively that far from being easier, they are now more sophisticated, more inflected with a real sense of what a society needs from education. In other areas, too, such as the rise of popular science, it is clear there has been a change for the better.

Yet still some will take the view that low culture is in the ascendant. The series in fact suggests something quite otherwise: that "high" and "low" categories are, if not outmoded, then usefully antagonistic, always nourishing each other. Cultural value and cultural diversity are alive and well. You just have to know where to look.

fields.headline: The diseased herd
fields.standfirst:
Roy Hattersley

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Neither the grieving relatives, who hoped for retribution, nor the ministers and civil servants, who feared exposure and humiliation, should have expected Lord Phillips's CJD report to set Whitehall ablaze with avenging fire. Official inquiries never have that sort of vulgar result.
fields.byline: BSE inquiry: What are we to make of the huge and painstaking Phillips report?
fields.body:
Neither the grieving relatives, who hoped for retribution, nor the ministers and civil servants, who feared exposure and humiliation, should have expected Lord Phillips's CJD report to set Whitehall ablaze with avenging fire. Official inquiries never have that sort of vulgar result.

Everyone knew that the withdrawal of the Royal Navy's survey ship from the South Atlantic convinced the Argentine junta that Britain no longer cared about the Falkland Islands. But Lord Franks absolved the government, which had saved £3m by bringing HMS Endurance home and spent £1.6bn on the war which that decision provoked, from all blame.

Sir Richard Scott judged that "parliament and public were designedly led to believe that a stricter policy towards non-lethal defence exports and double-use exports to Iraq was being adopted than was, in fact, the case." Then he concluded - with fine disregard for dictionary definitions of "designedly" - that ministers had "not acted with any duplicitous intention". The establishment rarely condemns its own.

There is nothing dishonest nor discreditable in the basic instinct to believe the best about men and women who devote their lives to public service. The great and the good take it for granted that other members of that elite group are (like themselves) doing their honest best. They may make mistakes. But error is not an automatic reason for severe blame.

Indeed, wherever possible, blame is to be avoided completely. A marginal overstatement of legitimate criticism might convince the tabloid-reading public that ministers are either profoundly incompetent or deeply corrupt. Then the stability of the whole system would be imperilled. And stability is the establishment's primary pre-occupation. Politicians can abuse each other without serious people taking very much notice. But if a high court judge, master of an Oxbridge college or retired senior civil servant exposed the processes of government as rotten, our comfortable world would never be the same again.

So it was no more reasonable to expect Lord Phillips to denounce and condemn the BSE ministers than it would have been to expect his participation in a street demonstration against global capitalism. He did his job in strict conformity with the precedents - a rigorous analysis of what went wrong but a determination not to allocate an iota more blame than the most generous interpretation of responsibility allowed. When, earlier this week, Mr John Gummer refused to acknowledge that he was the man on the end of the mobile telephone, he should have told the assiduous reporter who had discovered his number that he was too busy sighing with relief to speak.

Lord Phillips conceded that two ministers of agriculture (John Gummer and Douglas Hogg) and Stephen Dorrell (when he was secretary of state for health) underplayed the risk of eating infected meat. "The public," the report says, "was repeatedly assured that it was safe to eat beef." Eighty families now know that not to be true. But at least it can be said in the government's defence that, for a time, it actually believed its own propaganda. Then ministers realised that transmission to humans was possible. But "believing that the risks ... were remote", it played them down because it was "preoccupied with preventing an alarmist over- reaction".

Lord Phillips concludes that "the campaign of reassurance was a mistake".

Amen to that. But it is less easy to endorse his judgment that "the government did not lie". It was certainly - to use the latest phrase to be added to the establishment lexicon - "economical with the truth". Lord Phillips observes, with magnificent judicial restraint, that, when the risk of death and infection was confirmed, "the possibility of a risk to humans was not communicated to the general public or to those whose job it was to enforce precautionary measures". That sounds to me like the intention to deceive - the best definition of a lie which is available to us.

The lie was collective. But individuals - both civil servants and ministers - were, even by the judgment of the Phillips report, individually guilty of confusing public understanding. Sir Donald Acheson, the chief medical officer, gave unsustainable assurances about beef safety - and later attributed them to a slip of the tongue. Douglas Hogg, the minister of agriculture, tried to persuade members of the government's BSE advisory committee to back his public statements on the remote possibility of infection.

That, Lord Phillips says, was "not a desirable exercise". Even John Selwyn Gummer, excoriated at the time for publicly feeding his daughter a hamburger as part of the reassurance campaign, is said to have been put in an impossible position by the media. The BSE report does not excuse or exonerate the guilty. It just treats them very gently.

That does not mean that the report has failed in its task. It has identified crucial shortcomings in the machinery of government - most of them associated with the Ministry of Agriculture, which has long been recognised as little more than a client of the industry which it blatantly represents rather than supervises. A blow of sorts has been struck against secrecy, the enemy of good government and the ally of inadequate administration down the ages.

But will a new generation of ministers and administrators take any notice of that admirable advice if, after reading Lord Phillips's conclusions, they are confronted by the belief that, even when they transgress, they will not be held up either to contempt or ridicule?

I doubt if Lord Phillips would argue with my judgment that, after identifying innumerable errors and mistakes, his report leaves readers with the feeling that, for most of the time, both ministers and civil servants were doing their best. Perhaps they were. But if that was the case their best was woefully inadequate - not least because their behaviour was dominated by the belief that avoiding trouble and maintaining good order and discipline was the first duty of government.

It has been a good week for Douglas Hogg, John MacGregor, John Gummer and their Ministry of Agriculture civil servants, but a bad one for publicly accountable government.

fields.headline: QC laments safety shortfall
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Hatfield train crash
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: A damning criticism of the lack of an adequate safety system on Britain's railways was made yesterday at the closing stages of the joint inquiry into the Paddington and Southall rail disasters.
fields.body:
A damning criticism of the lack of an adequate safety system on Britain's railways was made yesterday at the closing stages of the joint inquiry into the Paddington and Southall rail disasters.

It came from the health and safety executive which said that the £400m train protection warning system (TPWS), dubbed second rate by victims of the crashes, had come too late and was "unlikely to be of much benefit" for preventing accidents.

Railtrack is fitting the system throughout the network following the Paddington crash and a promise by John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, that money was no object. Installation will not be complete until 2003. The system is only designed to stop trains at up to 70 mph passing red signals.

Hugh Carlisle QC, for the HSE, said that the installation of ETCS, a much more expensive system widely used in Europe, was required as soon as possible. "The lack of protection until ETCS is fitted is unacceptable," he said.

Mr Carlisle said interim measures were required.

He said that the HSE would be pressing for TPWS to be installed in less than three years with the fitting of the European-style system, said to cost up to £2 bn, to be completed over the next decade.

He added: "We believe that such protection will make a significant contribution to railway safety in the future."

Ian Burnett, QC, counsel for the inquiry, said that to abort the current system would put lives at risk. In his closing speech, he said the number of trains passing signals at red - the primary cause of the Paddington and Southall crashes - was "intolerable" and the installation of TPWS should be allowed to continue.

Stopping the TPWS programme would use up financial and human resources in "a grossly disproportionate way" on lines where trains did not travel above 70mph and leave other important measures short of funds.

Mr Burnett recommended that the industry should not wait for next spring when the final report on Paddington and Southall is published before setting out a timetable for the introduction of the more expensive European system.

John Hendy QC, speaking for the passengers and bereaved said: "Risks of a high speed catastrophic collision remain. TPWS is a second rate, stop-gap system."

Roger Henderson QC, for Railtrack said that it could not fit the more expensive system at present because of its limited financial resources.

webTitle: Man cleared of poisoning doctor with sulphuric acid

fields.headline: Man cleared of poisoning doctor with sulphuric acid
fields.trailText: A mother cried out in grief and rage as the man accused of poisoning her daughter with sulphuric acid walked free from Birmingham crown court yesterday.
fields.body:
A mother cried out in grief and rage as the man accused of poisoning her daughter with sulphuric acid walked free from Birmingham crown court yesterday.

The family of Karenina Longe, 27, who died on February 6 last year after drinking drain cleaner, remained composed as the jury cleared her former partner Andrew Gardner, 41, of murder after more than two days of deliberation.

But when the four women and eight men gave their second verdict "not guilty of manslaughter" an hour later, Carole Longe screamed from the public gallery: "There is no justice here. Where's the justice? It's nonsense. It's absolutely farcical."

Mr Gardner, a former laboratory technician, was accused of poisoning Dr Longe at the home they had shared in Sheldon, Birmingham because he was angry that she had ended their five-year relationship.

He initially claimed that she had drunk the acid accidentally, but later insisted to police that she had deliberately harmed herself because she was under stress.

Dr Longe drank the Liquid Plumber while visiting Mr Gardner and died the next day in Heartlands hospital, where she worked as a senior house officer. She would have suffered the "torments of hell" as acid burned through her stomach and "cooked" her organs, Stephen Linehan QC, prosecuting, had told the court.

He alleged that Mr Gardner had somehow tricked her into drinking the liquid. There was no sign that she had been forced to drink it.

Mr Gardner waited 23 minutes before calling an ambulance, telephoning plumbers for advice instead. When he finally called the emergency services Dr Longe's agonised screams could be heard in the background.

After telling paramedics that it was an accident, he sent his teenage son in the ambulance and went drinking in local pubs. He briefly visited the hospital later that day but fled to London after learning Dr Longe would die, using her cashcard to spend £800 on drink and nightclubs.

Three weeks later, after police appeals, he handed himself in, claiming to have taken an overdose of paracetamol. Doctors who examined him said it was a lie.

Mr Linehan told the court that Mr Gardner had "lied, lied and lied again" in his accounts. Even his own defence team described him as a liar and womaniser with a drink problem.

He did not give evidence during the trial, but in interviews told the police that Dr Longe had deliberately harmed herself because of stress. His claim that she had drunk three-quarters of a bottle of vodka that morning was proved false by a post-mortem examination.

Mr Gardner claimed he had not called an ambulance because he did not realise how serious the situation was and feared that a suicide attempt would damage Dr Longe's career. He said he had fled to London out of panic.

The prosecution cast doubt on key parts of his story, such as his claim that Dr Longe had first complained of stomach pains while making love.

The liquid she drank was more than 93% sulphuric acid and would have burned her instantly. Four weeks after her death it was still burning holes in her clothes.

Mr Gardner lived in Zimbabwe until 1988, working on the farm of his wealthy parents after a brief spell fighting in the civil war, but moved to England after his stormy and violent marriage broke up.

Mr Gardner met Dr Longe while both were working at St Bartholomew's hospital in London. He had a child with another woman and continued to to live with her until he followed Dr Longe to Birmingham in September 1998.

But the relationship became strained as Mr Gardner failed to find a job and drank heavily. On the Monday before her death he hit her and kneed her in the stomach during an argument. She moved into hospital lodgings and told her mother the relationship was over. Mr Gardner denied this.

Courtenay Griffiths QC, for the defence, told the jury: "I'm not asking you to like this man, this alcoholic, this clear womaniser, this fickle individual, who left his 15-year-old boy to, in fact, clear up the mess, sponging off a stressed-out young female doctor.

"You've got good reason to dislike him. You may even feel he's responsible for her death. But responsibility for her death and guilt of her murder are two completely different things."

In a statement Mr Gardner said he "remains devastated by the suicide of Miss Longe. This prosecution was not based on hard evidence but on pandering to people's emotions. We are therefore grateful to the jury for preventing a miscarriage of justice."

But family and friends refused to accept that the popular, high-achieving doctor could have committed suicide.

Her mother said: "We all know Nina Longe would not kill herself. Everybody who knew her knew she was a young woman who had everything to live for.

"She was very focused, very organised, but very compassionate. She was mature beyond her years and I think she would have gone on to realise her dream and lead a very full life."

Dr Longe, born in Lagos, was sent to a boarding school in Yorkshire at 13. Her family have set up a bursary in her memory, helping young doctors to carry out research or train in Africa.

After telling paramedics that it was an accident, he sent his teenage son in the ambulance and went drinking in local pubs. He briefly visited the hospital later that day but fled to London after learning Dr Longe would die, using her cashcard to spend £800 on drink and nightclubs. Three weeks later, after police appeals, he handed himself in, claiming to have taken an overdose of paracetamol. Doctors who examined him said it was a lie. Mr Linehan told the court that Mr Gardner had "lied, lied and lied again" in his accounts. Even his own defence team described him as a liar and womaniser with a drink problem. He did not give evidence during the trial, but in interviews told the police that Dr Longe had deliberately harmed herself because of stress. His claim that she had drunk three-quarters of a bottle of vodka that morning was proved false by a post-mortem examination. Mr Gardner claimed he had not called an ambulance because he did not realise how serious the situation was and feared that a suicide attempt would damage Dr Longe's career. He said he had fled to London out of panic. The prosecution cast doubt on key parts of his story, such as his claim that Dr Longe had first complained of stomach pains while making love. The liquid she drank was more than 93% sulphuric acid and would have burned her instantly. Four weeks after her death it was still burning holes in her clothes. Mr Gardner lived in Zimbabwe until 1988, working on the farm of his wealthy parents after a brief spell fighting in the civil war, but moved to England after his stormy and violent marriage broke up. Mr Gardner met Dr Longe while both were working at St Bartholomew's hospital in London. He had a child with another woman and continued to to live with her until he followed Dr Longe to Birmingham in September 1998. But the relationship became strained as Mr Gardner failed to find a job and drank heavily. On the Monday before her death he hit her and kneed her in the stomach during an argument. She moved into hospital lodgings and told her mother the relationship was over. Mr Gardner denied this. Courtenay Griffiths QC, for the defence, told the jury: "I'm not asking you to like this man, this alcoholic, this clear womaniser, this fickle individual, who left his 15-year-old boy to, in fact, clear up the mess, sponging off a stressed-out young female doctor. "You've got good reason to dislike him. You may even feel he's responsible for her death. But responsibility for her death and guilt of her murder are two completely different things." In a statement Mr Gardner said he "remains devastated by the suicide of Miss Longe. This prosecution was not based on hard evidence but on pandering to people's emotions. We are therefore grateful to the jury for preventing a miscarriage of justice." But family and friends refused to accept that the popular, high-achieving doctor could have committed suicide. Her mother said: "We all know Nina Longe would not kill herself. Everybody who knew her knew she was a young woman who had everything to live for. "She was very focused, very organised, but very compassionate. She was mature beyond her years and I think she would have gone on to realise her dream and lead a very full life." Dr Longe, born in Lagos, was sent to a boarding school in Yorkshire at 13. Her family have set up a bursary in her memory, helping young doctors to carry out research or train in Africa.

webTitle: Apex fares cancelled by train companies

fields.headline: Apex fares cancelled by train companies
fields.standfirst:
Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: Passenger misery caused by long delays or cancellations on rail services was compounded yesterday by the withdrawal on some services of the cheaper Apex advance fares due to the lack of a regular timetable.
fields.body:
Passenger misery caused by long delays or cancellations on rail services was compounded yesterday by the withdrawal on some services of the cheaper Apex advance fares due to the lack of a regular timetable.

Some train operating companies charged full fare even to travel off peak, to offset claims by passengers for refunds on tickets when services ran late.

Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the shadow strategic rail authority, said he hoped that the 25 operating companies would look kindly on reasonable claims. But the authority had no power to step in.

A spokesman said: "The fare is a contract between the passenger and a private company, but if passengers have a genuine complaint we would hope they would receive compensation."

The authority said passengers were entitled to a 20% refund if delayed more than an hour, but most train companies were more generous.

The Association of Train Operating Companies, representing all 25 operators, including National Express, Virgin and Stagecoach, said: "These are difficult times. The companies should use their discretion in dealing with demands for compensation, but we do sympathise with passengers."

The association said it was not issuing guidelines, although the matter could be discussed at the next board meeting.

Passengers on Midland Main Line trains have been among the worst affected. It emerged yesterday the company was selling in advance only tickets at full price and no cheap return fares.

The company said: "There has never been any intention to force people to buy dearer tickets, but until we have got the revised timetable up there is no way we can book people advanced tickets on to trains when we do not know when they are going to be running.

"We hope to have everything up on the system by Monday and will be able to start offering advanced tickets like the Apex then."

A spokesman for Virgin trains said: "We are not going to reduce the price of tickets because at the moment we are having to spend more money running the trains.

"If people have tickets then we have to honour them and get them to their destination, but buses and taxis don't come cheap. At the moment we are just working from day to day trying to hold the service together."

Only First Great Western has allowed passengers holding cheap saver tickets to travel during peak times over the weekend.

However, a spokesman said the policy would be up for review before Monday.

Tony Blair did little to quell passengers' irritation yesterday when he gave Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, an easy time when he called him in for a 30-minute briefing.

A Downing Street spokesman said Mr Blair believed that the industry was doing the best it could in difficult circumstances.

It had to strike a "sensible balance" between safety work and keeping the network moving.

"Gerald Corbett is carrying out an important job at the moment and trying to resolve the problems that are the result of decades of underinvestment in the railways," the spokesman said.

webTitle: Nasa plots course to take man to Mars

fields.headline: Nasa plots course to take man to Mars
fields.standfirst: Scout missions will seek water and life forms. Then people may follow
fields.trailText: Humiliated last year when two missions worth $500m came to grief on arriving at Mars, US space scientists are keeping alive the tantalising possibility of a manned mission to the Red Planet within 20 years.
fields.body:
Humiliated last year when two missions worth $500m came to grief on arriving at Mars, US space scientists are keeping alive the tantalising possibility of a manned mission to the Red Planet within 20 years.

Last month Nasa outlined plans for a landing by roving robots in January 2004.

Now its planners have made it clear that they will keep going to Earth's smaller colder, dustier neighbour every 26 months until 2010, despite last year's loss of an orbiter and a landing vehicle within a three-month period.

They intend to follow up the 2004 robot landing by launching a scientific observer orbiter in 2005 with instruments so powerful they will be able to make images of rocks the size of footballs.

And in 2007 Nasa could send the first of a series of "scout" missions, possibly equipped with robot balloons or even a low-flying robot aircraft to skim over the Martian landscape, for close observation over a much larger range than any tracked vehicle or robot rover could manage.

It will also try to put down a "smart" landing craft - smart enough to avoid the dangerous rocks and ravines that menace a descending vehicle - fitted with a scientific laboratory.

And in 2009 the Americans could team up with the Italians to drop yet another orbiter into the Martian skies, this time with ground-penetrating radar to "feel" for water under the surface.

The US has signed a declaration of intent with France to cooperate on a new generation of tiny landers which could "sniff" for traces of the chemistry generated only by living things, and has revealed that talks have begun with the Italians to put a communication satellite around Mars, to handle the huge traffic in data.

And, as interest in Mars grows, there could be a "biopsy" mission: in 2011 at the earliest, Nasa said, a mission could land on Mars, scoop up samples of rock and soil, and return to Earth.

Mars is an earthlike planet, with a thin carbon-dioxide atmosphere and hostile temperatures. The more scientists learn about other planets, the better they understand the dynamics of their own.

And Mars is the only rocky planet available for study. Venus is impossibly hot and masked by clouds of acid vapour.

Mars is too cold, and its atmospheric pressure too low, for liquid water to exist. But a study of its landscape shows that it was once washed by seas and lakes and scoured by rivers, so it must have once held a thicker atmosphere, and been warmer.

In theory it could have had a population of creatures. Earlier this year photographs showed remarkable evidence of apparently fresh drainage patterns, as if something had burst from the soil and flowed into a deep gully.

This raised the tantalising idea that if liquid water could exist under the surface, so might life.

"We are going to dig deep into the details of Mars's mineralogy, geology and climate history in a way we've never been able to do before," said Ed Weiler, one of Nasa's science chiefs.

"We also plan to 'follow the water' so that in the not-to-distant future we may finally know the answers to the most far-reaching questions about the Red Planet we humans have asked over the generations: Did life ever arise there, and does life exist there now?"

Mars is a long and dangerous trip. Only when it and Earth are at the right places in their respective orbits are missions affordable - every 26 months. Then a journey can be completed in as few as seven months. So planning has to begin early and timetables are tight.

Paradoxically, although yesterday's Nasa statement made no mention of it, the next instrument to land on Mars could be British. Beagle 2 is likely to travel with a European spacecraft called Mars Express, and to drop on Martian soil in December 2003 to begin looking for evidence of bygone life just days before the US landers arrive.

But the most dramatic moment of all will be the possible announcement, some time in the next decade, of a manned mission to Mars. Space scientists and engineers have been lobbying Washington for support for a Mars expedition.

The European Space Agency has begun examining the strains on health and physique for humans who might have to survive in free fall and low gravity for 18 months or two years.

Meanwhile scientists at Cornell University in New York state have been experimenting with a mission menu based entirely on vegetables which could be grown hydroponically in a spacecraft, using recycled waste and water.

But Dr Weiler said it was far too early to even hazard a guess about when the human exploration of Mars might begin.

"Before we send humans to a place, we need to know where we're going."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Other news in brief
fields.body:
Abrupt halt to bombing appeal

An appeal by Palestinians convicted of involvement in the 1994 bomb attack on Israel's London embassy abruptly adjourned yesterday. Michael Mansfield QC, counsel for Jawad Botmeh and Samar Alami, told the appeal court a warning of a possible bombing had been handed to officers at a police station before the attack on the embassy.

Prostate cancer 'remedy'

A Chinese remedy used by prostate cancer patients appears to work, according to researchers at the University of California. It involves the preparation of eight herbs.

Over the moon about Saturn

Four more moons have been discovered orbiting Saturn, raising the planet's total to 22. The discovery was announced by the European Southern observatory at Garching in Germany.

Drivers face licence threat

Any motorist caught doing more than 25mph over the speed limit on French roads will lose his or her licence on the spot, under a law giving police the power to penalise foreign drivers. It would be returned on leaving France.

Protesters to confront hunt

The Hunt Saboteurs Association promises a "huge demonstration" today at the first meet of the Old Surrey, Burstow and West Kent Hunt.

webTitle: Blair pledge to Spain on crippled sub

fields.headline: Blair pledge to Spain on crippled sub
fields.standfirst: Nuclear sub was hours from meltdown
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday announced a special international working group to monitor the condition of a faulty nuclear submarine stranded in Gibraltar.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday announced a special international working group to monitor the condition of a faulty nuclear submarine stranded in Gibraltar.

Trying to calm local fears about the submarine, which has been in Gibraltar since May after a crack was found in its cooling system, he said the submarine was safe, and he promised more transparency, although he ruled out towing it back to Britain.

During a working visit to Spain Mr Blair faced criticism from the Spanish press for not providing enough information about the submarine.

He said: "We accept full responsibility for safety. This has been very carefully studied, the problem has been identified, there is no risk whatsoever."

He said experts from both countries would meet next week to discuss repairs carried out on the hunter-killer HMS Tireless. The navy's most senior adviser on nuclear safety has also flown to Spain.

Assurances by both governments that there is no danger of a radiation leak affecting the 250,000 people in the Gibraltar area have failed to quell disquiet, especially after the Ministry of Defence last week admitted the damage was more serious than first thought and recalled 12 sister submarines.

There were demonstrations outside the British embassy in Madrid yesterday. Concern over the submarine overshadowed Mr Blairs meeting with the Spanish prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, scheduled to discuss joint European Union initiatives, although they issued a joint statement of confidence in the euro.

Mr Aznar insisted the submarine had not damaged relations with Britain, but earlier this week his foreign minister complained about lack of information on the Tireless.

There have been calls for Spanish experts to be allowed to visit the submarine. Up to now they have been briefed by the Royal Navy but not allowed to see for themselves.

Mr Blair said the issue of access by technicians "would be discussed". That may anger Gibraltar, always wary of Spanish attempts to claim sovereignty over the Rock.

fields.headline: French 'monster brothers' get life
fields.trailText: Ending a fortnight of court drama that has riveted and revolted France, a court in Saint-Omer sentenced two middle-aged brothers to life yesterday imprisonment yesterday for kidnapping, raping and murdering four teenage girls
fields.body:
Ending a fortnight of court drama that has riveted and revolted France, a court in Saint-Omer sentenced two middle-aged brothers to life yesterday imprisonment yesterday for kidnapping, raping and murdering four teenage girls

The jury found Jean-Louis and Jean-Michel Jourdain, scrap merchants dubbed "the carnival killers", guilty of beating, sexually assaulting and strangling to death two pairs of sisters, Audrey and Isabelle Rufin and Amélie and Peggy Merlin, in February 1997.

"You are the Siamese twins of horror," the public prosecutor, Luc Frémio, said. "You have sickened us. You have made me afraid. You are the dark side of humanity. You are our failure."

Mr Frémiot described how the brothers - both with previous convictions, one for rape, the other for murder and attempted murder - gave the four girls, aged 17 to 19, a lift in their decrepit van as they headed for a carnival in Portel, near Boulogne.

Their bodies were found six days later in the dunes at Saint-Omer, still wearing their makeup and fancy-dress. They had been buried face down in shallow graves, at least one while alive.

Jean-Louis, 41, said Jean-Michel took away the first girl and returned alone 20 minutes later for another. He said: "The little one, the one in red, was crying. She clung to her sister till she, too, was led away."

Jean-Louis admitted only having raped one girl and helped his brother bury all four. Jean-Michel, 38, who served 10 years for killing a former girlfriend, denied being involved.

"These girls left for the ball, joyous, happy, young and beautiful," said Blandine Lejeune, representing the victims' families. "They stepped into a chamber of horrors, entered a world of beasts, not humans. Mr Jourdain, you have ensured two mothers will never sleep. And all you can do is chew your gum."

The defence tried in vain to elicit some sympathy. "This is a man before you, not a monster," pleaded Antoine Duport, for Jean-Louis. "And if he is a monster, he's one our society has created."

webTitle: End of world fair puts Germany out of its misery

fields.headline: End of world fair puts Germany out of its misery
fields.standfirst: Like Britain's Millennium Dome, the poorly attended Expo 2000 in Hanover will go down as a 21st century turkey
fields.trailText: Even before Expo 2000 entered its final week in Hanover, the organisers were selling it off in lots. In a hall on the edge of the site where the world fair opened on June 1, an auctioneer was ploughing his way this week through a list of items that ranged from the commonplace to the bizarre.
fields.body:
Even before Expo 2000 entered its final week in Hanover, the organisers were selling it off in lots. In a hall on the edge of the site where the world fair opened on June 1, an auctioneer was ploughing his way this week through a list of items that ranged from the commonplace to the bizarre.

"Lot 19. One Tree of Life . . . Lot 255. One Statue of Myths." There were several robots for sale: "Plastic. Slightly transparent. Three metres high." The proceeds will go some tiny way towards defraying the losses of what is poised to become the first great turkey of the 21st century - a turkey with striking parallels to Britain's ill-starred Millennium Dome at Greenwich.

Intended as a showcase for a "new", reunited Germany, the event in Hanover has been plagued by mishaps. The US refused to take part. The official Expo 2000 anthem was released on the same CD as a song with grossly obscene lyrics. And worst of all, less than half the number of expected visitors turned up.

Like the dome, Expo 2000 had scant practical justification but enthusiastic backing from a centre-left head of government. Like the dome, it is expected to rack up losses of around £800m.

The chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, who was premier of Lower Saxony when his home town of Hanover won the right to stage the world fair, and became its most influential champion, insisted this week that tax revenues and Expo 2000's beneficial knock-on effects would more than outweigh its losses. But he produced no figures to support his contention.

Expo 2000's senior organiser, Birgit Breuel, took a different line. "Were it not for the problem on the financial side", she told the newspaper Berliner Zeitung, "Expo would have been the best world fair so far."

But why, if it was so appealing, did so few people bother to come? Ms Breuel's team initially expected 40m visits - the same number as went to the last universal exposition eight years ago in the southern Spanish city of Seville, where there were almost 50 fewer exhibitions.

Her press officers said in pre-inaugural briefings that this was an "intentionally modest" target. Hanover was reckoned to have a vastly bigger catchment area than isolated Seville - and it bagged a good share of celebrity visitors. One of them was Prince Ernst August of Hanover; this as it turned out was unfortunate, because he was caught relieving himself by the side of the Turkish pavilion.

After a disastrous start, the target was slashed to a mere 14m. On that basis, the likely deficit was put at 2.4bn marks (£800m).

But, said an Expo spokesman, Nicholas Batten, "Every visit over 14m brings that figure down."

Perversely, with the weather deteriorating in recent weeks, numbers have picked up. By October 19 total entrances had risen to almost 16m.

"The problem is that, after people didn't come, a lot of the workers on the site were laid off. So there really aren't enough now to deal with this number of visitors," said Susana Alvarez, an attendant at the British pavilion.

Sheltering with his wife from the wind and rain in a long queue stretching round the Canadian exhibition, Ernst Müller-Andre confessed to being from a village on the Luneberg heath, just a few miles from Hanover.

"I thought: 'You can go any time'. I was constantly putting off coming here", he said.

He had been "fascinated" by the exhibition. But others, particularly younger people, were disappointed.

"Too long to wait. Too many people. Too big and too expensive," a Hamburg visitor, Michael Grimm, complained, nursing an umbrella in the Romanian pavilion.

"We waited 10 minutes by the cable car," put in his friend, Dirk Raab. "Finally, someone came along and said it wasn't running because of the high winds."

A few yards away folk dancers with fixed smiles were stamping and gyrating. "I feel as if I've spent all day in a travel agency," Mr Raab sighed.

"Yet it's not really a world exhibition at all," grumbled his friend. "Everyone I've met till now has been a German from north Germany."

Christina Drews, also from Hamburg, said: "I'd expected more than just pictures or photographs of the [exhibiting] countries. I could look in a tourist brochure or magazine and see the same things."

"You're told you need at least three days to see it all, but three days for me would be too much", her friend Magdalena Pietkum said as they emerged from the Japanese pavilion.

Across the way was an Expo shop crammed with souvenirs: Expo mugs, Expo caps, Expo pens and endless reproductions of the fair's mascot, Twipsy. Light flooded from the shop into the twilight, illuminating a billboard that wobbled in the stiff breeze.

"Everything 10 marks," it proclaimed: just £3 to clear.

Things to do with £800m

With the money Expo 2000 lost, Germany could have:

Built 10 new hospitals, 50 new schools or 120 new libraries
Put in 80 Olympic-size swimming pools
Bought 16 advanced tactical fighter aircraft
Met the latest estimated losses of Britain's Millenium Dome (well, almost)

fields.bodyText: Even before Expo 2000 entered its final week in Hanover, the organisers were selling it off in lots. In a hall on the edge of the site where the world fair opened on June 1, an auctioneer was ploughing his way this week through a list of items that ranged from the commonplace to the bizarre. "Lot 19. One Tree of Life . . . Lot 255. One Statue of Myths." There were several robots for sale: "Plastic. Slightly transparent. Three metres high." The proceeds will go some tiny way towards defraying the losses of what is poised to become the first great turkey of the 21st century - a turkey with striking parallels to Britain's ill-starred Millennium Dome at Greenwich. Intended as a showcase for a "new", reunited Germany, the event in Hanover has been plagued by mishaps. The US refused to take part. The official Expo 2000 anthem was released on the same CD as a song with grossly obscene lyrics. And worst of all, less than half the number of expected visitors turned up. Like the dome, Expo 2000 had scant practical justification but enthusiastic backing from a centre-left head of government. Like the dome, it is expected to rack up losses of around £800m. The chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, who was premier of Lower Saxony when his home town of Hanover won the right to stage the world fair, and became its most influential champion, insisted this week that tax revenues and Expo 2000's beneficial knock-on effects would more than outweigh its losses. But he produced no figures to support his contention. Expo 2000's senior organiser, Birgit Breuel, took a different line. "Were it not for the problem on the financial side", she told the newspaper Berliner Zeitung, "Expo would have been the best world fair so far." But why, if it was so appealing, did so few people bother to come? Ms Breuel's team initially expected 40m visits - the same number as went to the last universal exposition eight years ago in the southern Spanish city of Seville, where there were almost 50 fewer exhibitions. Her press officers said in pre-inaugural briefings that this was an "intentionally modest" target. Hanover was reckoned to have a vastly bigger catchment area than isolated Seville - and it bagged a good share of celebrity visitors. One of them was Prince Ernst August of Hanover; this as it turned out was unfortunate, because he was caught relieving himself by the side of the Turkish pavilion. After a disastrous start, the target was slashed to a mere 14m. On that basis, the likely deficit was put at 2.4bn marks (£800m). But, said an Expo spokesman, Nicholas Batten, "Every visit over 14m brings that figure down." Perversely, with the weather deteriorating in recent weeks, numbers have picked up. By October 19 total entrances had risen to almost 16m. "The problem is that, after people didn't come, a lot of the workers on the site were laid off. So there really aren't enough now to deal with this number of visitors," said Susana Alvarez, an attendant at the British pavilion. Sheltering with his wife from the wind and rain in a long queue stretching round the Canadian exhibition, Ernst Müller-Andre confessed to being from a village on the Luneberg heath, just a few miles from Hanover. "I thought: 'You can go any time'. I was constantly putting off coming here", he said. He had been "fascinated" by the exhibition. But others, particularly younger people, were disappointed. "Too long to wait. Too many people. Too big and too expensive," a Hamburg visitor, Michael Grimm, complained, nursing an umbrella in the Romanian pavilion. "We waited 10 minutes by the cable car," put in his friend, Dirk Raab. "Finally, someone came along and said it wasn't running because of the high winds." A few yards away folk dancers with fixed smiles were stamping and gyrating. "I feel as if I've spent all day in a travel agency," Mr Raab sighed. "Yet it's not really a world exhibition at all," grumbled his friend. "Everyone I've met till now has been a German from north Germany." Christina Drews, also from Hamburg, said: "I'd expected more than just pictures or photographs of the [exhibiting] countries. I could look in a tourist brochure or magazine and see the same things." "You're told you need at least three days to see it all, but three days for me would be too much", her friend Magdalena Pietkum said as they emerged from the Japanese pavilion. Across the way was an Expo shop crammed with souvenirs: Expo mugs, Expo caps, Expo pens and endless reproductions of the fair's mascot, Twipsy. Light flooded from the shop into the twilight, illuminating a billboard that wobbled in the stiff breeze. "Everything 10 marks," it proclaimed: just £3 to clear. webTitle: Leader: Peace in Ulster endangered again

fields.headline: High noon in Ulster
fields.standfirst:
Peace is on the line - again

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Another Saturday, another high noon for Ulster unionism. Once again the party's 860-member ruling council is gearing up for a round of civil war, with the two camps squaring off in what promises to be yet another nailbiting vote. Once again, the choice David Trimble has put before his council members is "back me or sack me". Once again, the peace process is said to hang by a thread.
fields.body:
Another Saturday, another high noon for Ulster unionism. Once again the party's 860-member ruling council is gearing up for a round of civil war, with the two camps squaring off in what promises to be yet another nailbiting vote. Once again, the choice David Trimble has put before his council members is "back me or sack me". Once again, the peace process is said to hang by a thread.

One could forgive the people of the province if they were getting slightly sick of this never ending saga: unionism on the Edge of a Nervous Breakdown. At the very least they must be suffering an acute case of déjà vu. The protagonists are the same: peacemaker Trimble against hardliner Jeffrey Donaldson. The issue is the same: the decommissioning of IRA guns. And the underlying choice is the same: to proceed with the Good Friday agreement, hard though that is, or to let it die.

There are a couple of differences this time and they are both positive. First, Mr Trimble enters Belfast's Waterfront Hall taller than before. He can claim strength from yesterday's Belfast Telegraph poll which found 68% of the UUP's own voters backing Mr Trimble's belief that the party should stay in Northern Ireland's executive - compared to just 27% who favour Mr Donaldson's talk of an early exit. Almost 60% of Ulster unionist voters still regard Mr Trimble as the best person to lead the party, beating Mr Donaldson by two to one. Of course, Ulster Unionist council members are more militant than regular voters, but yesterday's poll may well cool their ardour: they will surely not want to become too far out of step with their own constituents.

The second boost comes from Mr Trimble's own handling of the current crisis. Rather than seek yet another backroom stitch-up, one which might delay the inevitable showdown, the leader has clearly decided to take Mr Donaldson on. By attacking the latter's demand for decommissioning to happen before a November 30 deadline as "Jeffrey's letter to Santa", he has at last come out fighting. This will delight those supporters who have long believed that Mr Trimble has a good case - he needs only to argue it.

On the current point of dispute, he clearly has the better of his rival. The leader is quite right that deadlines for disarmament have proven to be counterproductive, casting unionists, not republicans, as the block on the peace process. He is right, too, that by adopting a hard line, unionists would end up with the worst of both worlds - certainly no decommissioning, but no assembly or executive either. Finally, as Neil Kinnock, Margaret Thatcher or Tony Blair would all testify, the party leader who confronts his or her internal critics always comes off looking stronger. Mr Trimble appeared weak when he tolerated Mr Donaldson's breathtaking disloyalty. By attacking the anti camp's "constant warfare" on the leadership, Mr Trimble should have increased his own respect.

Still, the Ulster Unionist council is a large, unwieldy, unpredictable body. They may not be cowed into submission by the new, bullish tactics of the leader. Some of them could react against Peter Mandelson's recent warning that, if the agreement collapses, there will be more, not less, Dublin involvement in the running of Northern Ireland's affairs. That prospect scares unionists, but they may regard the secretary of state's mention of it as blackmail - voting to collapse the agreement just to spite him. So Mr Trimble needs to navigate carefully through the Waterfront Hall today. But he should gain strength from the knowledge that he has both his own constituency - and right - on his side.

fields.headline: Hi-techs stage a comeback
fields.standfirst: Market forces. Rob Griffin
fields.trailText: Technology stocks mounted a comeback yesterday after the severe battering they suffered earlier this week at the hands of nervous Wall Street traders.
fields.body:
Technology stocks mounted a comeback yesterday after the severe battering they suffered earlier this week at the hands of nervous Wall Street traders.

With the obvious exception of Psion, which saw its shares sink 165p to 410p after a surprise profits warning, the sector looked to be in generally good health.

Bookham Technology ended a dire week on a positive note with a gain of 141p to £22.91, helped by better than expected results from JDS Uniphase, the Canadian fibre optics supplier.

Also reversing the previous day's losses were a clutch of IT companies, with Logica up 109p at £19.75, Misys climbing 41p to 750p and Sema crawling up 6p at 916p.

The moves provided a tonic for the Techmark index which rose 55.77 points to 3,411.55.

However, traders warned that the past week's upheavals, principally sparked by the disappointing statement from Nortel Networks, meant the market was likely to remain sensitive.

Last night it was the telecoms stocks which stood squarely behind a bolstered FTSE 100 and forced the lead index up 64.2 points to 6,366.5 by the close.

Vodafone was up almost 5%, rising 13p, to 283p, and added 35 points to the FTSE's haul, while Colt Telecom put on 109p at £22.20, Energis enjoyed a 38p climb to 543p and Cable & Wireless closed the day at 980p, a rise of 9.8%.

BT also weighed in with a 45.5p rise to 783p, despite the announced price controls imposed by Oftel, the industry regulator.

Analysts at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite rated BT shares as "buy" for the first time in 10 months and said it was likely to undertake a radical series of disposals, demergers and flotations to reduce its debt.

Staying with telecoms, Kingston Communications enjoyed a 20p rise to 320p on the back of restructuring plans. The Hull-based company plans to divide itself into retail and network divisions to cut costs.

Pharmaceuticals saw some impressive rises with Cambridge Antibody up 162.5p at £40 and the Celltech Group putting on 17p at £13.97. Glaxo Wellcome, however, dropped 18p to £20.26 and Smithkline Beecham , which reports first-half results next week, slid 14.5p to close at 917p.

Dealers said the FTSE 100 volume of 1.2bn shares was down on the week's average of 1.5bn and this was attributed largely to people being away for the school half-term break.

Oil stocks lost ground after Opec warned its price stabilising mechanism, which keeps costs within a range of $22 to $28, would soon kick in.

The announcement, by Ali Rodriguez, president of the oil cartel, of a potential output increase on Monday caused BP Amoco to decline 17p to 588p and Shell to close 7p lower on the day at 557p.

Elsewhere, Linx Printing Technologies put on 20p to 355p after announcing its sales and profits were ahead of expectations in the first three months of the year.

Geo Interactive Media was buoyed by market whispers of a possible deal with Ericsson to develop a mobile phone project aimed at youngsters. The shares went up 5% to 965p at one stage before slipping back to 950p - a gain of 35p.

It was a good start for Lighthouse Group, the independent financial adviser which made its debut on the Alternative Investment Market. By close of play its shares stood at 180p, up from the 160p issue price.

But Quicks Group, the vehicle retailer, had a torrid time after warning its full-year results would be "significantly below the board's previous expectations". Its shares sank 11p to 55.5p as a result, some way off the 78p year's high, although comfortably ahead of the 30p low.

Other indices also climbed with the FTSE Midcap 250 up 19 points at 6,568.7 despite being a victim of Psion's plunge, while the FT Small Caps rose 15.2 points to 3,269.2.

fields.headline: Render bender: Jeremy Hardy on the BSE Inquiry
fields.standfirst: In the future, archaeologists will hand fossilised cow-pats to micro-biologists, who will find that cows were not only carnivorous but cannibalistic
fields.trailText: In the future, archaeologists will hand fossilised cow-pats to micro-biologists, who will find that cows were not only carnivorous but cannibalistic
fields.body:
In the future, archaeologists will hand fossilised cow-pats to micro-biologists, who will find that cows were not only carnivorous but cannibalistic. This will lead to the conclusion that the extinct beast was a vicious predator that walked on its hind legs and bit heads off after mating. Whereas we think of the cow as being a vegetarian mammal, it will be decided that it was in fact related to the praying mantis.

Today, scientists broadly concur with the homespun wisdom of the casual observer that cows, if left alone, eat grass. Lots of grass, all day long. They don't say much or even stampede unless spooked by a rattler. But they sure eat grass. They can be induced to eat other things, but as with humans, they can be squeamish if they can see what they are eating. The commercial feed known as MBM, which sounds like a sweetie but, disappointingly, stands for meat and bone meal, is heavily disguised.

I was listening to a farmer on the radio who said: "We don't just scrape up diseased sheep offal and feed it to cows." But obviously they would if they thought Daisy would eat it and no one would see. Instead it is ground up nice and small. Then, I imagine, it is pumped into sausage skins and served in a bun smothered in ketchup and mustard. Perhaps the farmer even herds the cows into intensive cinema seating and shows them bovine action movies to take their minds off what they are eating.

At one time it would have been thought that if renderers were going to do this, they should at least make sure they brought the mixture to a certain temperature. Then along came the deregulation of business. Thenceforth, industry could pollute with a vengeance, force untrained teenagers to be mangled by machinery, crash any means of transportation you can name and imagine that the many-stomached cow likes its MBM rare.

However, the mild mannered Lord Phillips has concluded that slack rendering practices were not to blame for BSE, because no amount of rendering would kill it. But if feed manufacturers feel vindicated, I can only say, without wishing to give them ideas, my arse.

The key conclusion of the report does, however, point the finger at the practice of turning cows into cannibals. Many of us were unaware that, as the farmers now tell us, they have been doing it for more than a hundred years. Indeed during the second world war, it was actually recommended, although I would imagine that, with Hitler to think about, government was under a lot of stress. One has to remember that, at that time, we also developed nuclear weapons.

But these are different times. Whereas at one time there was an understandable wish to bend nature to the needs of production, most of us are worried that we have bent it completely out of shape. We might not be sure what "organic" labelling means or what the long-term effects of genetic modification are, but our gut fear that the planet is all going a bit wrong is constantly shown to be an articulate response.

What we do know is that the world's food problems are not caused by weather, weeds or weevils, and certainly not by "over- population". Most of us blame the way food is produced and distributed. It is perfectly possible, with proper planning, for the whole world to enjoy a healthy diet.

But such considerations were not the function of the BSE inquiry.

The point of it, one assumes, was to hold people and practice accountable, and this is what it has done, in a terribly forgiving way. The Times's Simon Jenkins, who has in the past refused to believe the link between BSE and nvCJD, is equally sceptical about inquiries. "A judicial inquiry is administrative terrorism", he writes eccentrically. Well, this was one inquiry that was on ceasefire.

I am inclined to agree with Mr Jenkins that the vindication of renderers is a little odd, but his main complaint is the very existence of the "Temple of Blame". He finds especially obnoxious the idea that Phillips might be expected to "blame the Tories". How one could do otherwise, I don't quite see. The Tories are certainly avoiding interviews, which suggests that the kindly criticism dealt to them by Lord Phillips is the way they would prefer to be remembered.

Andrew Hoskin of the Today programme rang John Gummer's mobile and managed to track down a man who said he was "speaking on Mr Gummer's behalf", but would not confirm or deny that he was John Gummer. He didn't force the phone on to his daughter, but she is older and probably less easy to manipulate now.

The fact that the Tories went out of their way to encourage us to eat as much beef as possible is the key to all this. When ideology is bent to the needs of business, politicians believe what they want to believe about science. So they told us the big threat to our young was homosexuality in the classroom - and didn't care what the meat industry was doing to their brains.

fields.headline: Moscow repairs Belgrade breach
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Russia
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: President Vladimir Putin forged stronger bonds with the new Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, in Moscow yesterday, soothing his resentment at Russia's initial refusal to acknowledge his first-round election victory.
fields.body:
President Vladimir Putin forged stronger bonds with the new Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, in Moscow yesterday, soothing his resentment at Russia's initial refusal to acknowledge his first-round election victory.

Much of Mr Kostunica's brief working visit was dominated by the question of energy supplies to Yugoslavia, which the Russian gas giant Gazprom suspended earlier this year when its debts mounted to £280m. But the underlying purpose of his first significant state visit outside the Balkans was bridge-building.

Russia's relationship with its long-term ally was bruised by its prolonged indecision over how to respond to the election standoff.

The Yugoslav democracy movement was enraged by the Kremlin's soft line on the defeated incumbent, Slobodan Milosevic, and Mr Kostunica criticised Russia's fence-sitting in the days after the election.

Yesterday's meeting secured better relations, and the two leaders reached an agreement on restoring energy supplies, which should boost Mr Kostunica's support at home.

Mr Putin praised Mr Kostunica for his handling of last month's turbulent events. "You were able to escape the difficult situation without bloodshed and led your country out of isolation," he said.

He promised to help secure Yugoslavia's re-entry to international institutions, and called on other states to help boost its shattered economy.

"The international community is obliged to do everything to restore the country's economy," he said.

"Russia is ready to participate in this."

Mr Kostunica said Mr Putin backed Belgrade's opposition to independence for Kosovo.

Borislav Milosevic, half-brother of the former president and Yugoslav ambassador to Moscow, was not present at the talks. He was called to Belgrade earlier in the week for "consultations", the embassy said.

Russia's relationship with its long-term ally was bruised by its prolonged indecision over how to respond to the election standoff. The Yugoslav democracy movement was enraged by the Kremlin's soft line on the defeated incumbent, Slobodan Milosevic, and Mr Kostunica criticised Russia's fence-sitting in the days after the election. Yesterday's meeting secured better relations, and the two leaders reached an agreement on restoring energy supplies, which should boost Mr Kostunica's support at home. Mr Putin praised Mr Kostunica for his handling of last month's turbulent events. "You were able to escape the difficult situation without bloodshed and led your country out of isolation," he said. He promised to help secure Yugoslavia's re-entry to international institutions, and called on other states to help boost its shattered economy. "The international community is obliged to do everything to restore the country's economy," he said. "Russia is ready to participate in this." Mr Kostunica said Mr Putin backed Belgrade's opposition to independence for Kosovo. Borislav Milosevic, half-brother of the former president and Yugoslav ambassador to Moscow, was not present at the talks. He was called to Belgrade earlier in the week for "consultations", the embassy said.

webTitle: Elstein out, Airey in at Ch5

fields.headline: Elstein out, Airey in at Ch5
fields.standfirst:
David Elstein has been forced out of his job as chief executive of Channel 5, the often controversial broadcaster he helped launch in March 1997.

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: David Elstein has been forced out of his job as chief executive of Channel 5, the often controversial broadcaster he helped launch in March 1997.
fields.body:
David Elstein has been forced out of his job as chief executive of Channel 5, the often controversial broadcaster he helped launch in March 1997.

It emerged yesterday that Mr Elstein was asked to leave the company earlier this week amid boardroom tensions with executives from Channel 5's parent company RTL.

Staff at the channel were said to be shocked by the news which was announced internally at a meeting yesterday afternoon.

He is walking away with a pay-off of around £3m.

Mr Elstein will be replaced by Channel 5's director of programming, Dawn Airey, who has been in large part responsible for winning the broadcaster the sobriquet of "Channel Filth."

Mr Elstein has taken the brunt of press criticism over programming which some thought plumbed new depths with a game show fronted by a naked Keith Chegwin.

Ms Airey, 40, is understood to have recently been approached with job offers from rival broadcasters and sources said RTL was keen to keep her at Channel 5 by rewarding her with the top job.

A spokesman for RTL said "it had simply been time for a change", adding that the description of Mr Elstein's departure as a sacking would be a harsh interpretation.

Mr Elstein is understood to have had frosty relations with Richard Eyre, the former head of the ITV network who was installed as director of content when RTL took control of Channel 5 in June.

Nick Milligan, director of sales, has been promoted to deputy chief executive.

webTitle: Rebel MPs vow to halt air traffic sale

fields.headline: Rebel MPs vow to halt air traffic sale
fields.trailText: The planned sale of Britain's air traffic control system was cast into further doubt yesterday as rebel Labour MPs said they would continue to oppose it, spurred on by the government's defeat in the Lords on Thursday.
fields.body:
The planned sale of Britain's air traffic control system was cast into further doubt yesterday as rebel Labour MPs said they would continue to oppose it, spurred on by the government's defeat in the Lords on Thursday.

While the prime minister's spokesman insisted the government would overturn the defeat in the Commons, pressure mounted for the measures to be dropped to save the delayed transport bill. Crucial legislation governing the regulation of the railways may be lost if the bill is not passed before the Queen's speech on December 6.

Yesterday, Gwyneth Dunwoody, the chairwoman of the Commons transport select committee, urged the government to drop the part-privatisation plan. "They would be wise perhaps to accept this is not the time to go ahead with this plan," she told BBC Radio 4's The World at One.

"There is a great deal of doubt ... and this will hold up the transport bill, which contains absolutely essential bits of legislation about railways. I don't think any sensible business manager is so wedded to a rather pointless idea that they want to put it ahead of everything else in their programme."

The former transport minister, Gavin Strang, MP for Edinburgh East and Musselburgh, described the Lords vote as "an important and significant defeat" and said it provided the government with "an opportunity to walk away from this privatisation with dignity". He rejected ministers' claims that safety was the primary consideration.

Martin Salter, Labour MP for Reading West and a former Heathrow baggage handler, warned that rebel MPs would continue to vote against the government - as 47 did the last time it was in the Commons - or abstain. He said the rail crisis would make MPs even more resolute.

The government argues that putting 51% into private ownership would bring in £1.3bn investment in the next decade and improve efficiency. But the plans have drawn opposition from pilots and air traffic controllers as well as MPs.

webTitle: MoD helicopter crashes in sea during sonar tests

fields.headline: MoD helicopter crashes in sea during sonar tests
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence was forced to defend its latest helicopter yesterday after one crash-landed in the sea off Skye during tests off the west coast of Scotland and split apart on impact. All five crew were rescued.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence was forced to defend its latest helicopter yesterday after one crash-landed in the sea off Skye during tests off the west coast of Scotland and split apart on impact. All five crew were rescued.

It is the latest in a series of accidents involving the £30m Merlin helicopter, which is replacing the Sea King.

An hour later an RAF Jaguar fighter bomber crashed near Lockerbie after hitting a flock of birds. The pilot ejected unhurt. A spokesman for the MoD said the two accidents, in which more than £50m worth of equipment was lost, were unrelated to a maritime exercise taking place off Scotland.

The crew of the Merlin put out a Mayday call at 9.51am shortly before ditching between Skye and the mainland. A fishing boat was first on the scene, and four of the crew were taken to hospital on Skye for tests. The pilot was airlifted to Stornoway with back injuries. The crew, from the 700 M Initial Flying Trials Unit based at RNAS Culdrose in Cornwall, had been testing sonar equipment.

Salvage efforts were underway last night for the helicopter, which broke in two but stayed afloat, upside down.

Michael Mulford, a spokesman for the RAF Rescue Centre at Kinloss, said: "They were between two bits of land, two or three miles each way.

"They would not take action like that [putting down in the sea] without very good and immediate reason."

The MoD has ordered 58 Merlins, the first six due to become operational next June. They are being built in Britain by GKN Westland and in Italy by Agusta under a £4.5bn collaborative programme.

Merlin's main roles are in ship and submarine warfare, tracking and surveillance, and search and rescue. It is designed to fly in severe weather and over high seas with the aid of sonar equipment and radar altimeters.

But the programme has been dogged by controversy. The national audit office criticised it for being £1bn over budget and late getting machines into service, and there have been several accidents on test flights.

In 1993 a prototype crashed in Italy, killing four people, and in 1995 another crashed in Somerset. The crew survived. In July a 3ft panel fell from a Merlin on to a beach in Worthing, West Sussex.

Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, called for a full investigation.

An MoD spokesman said there was no evidence yesterday's crash would affect the Merlin project.
