webTitle: Double life and death of Hindu priest

fields.headline: Double life and death of Hindu priest
fields.trailText: The last full day of Harish Purohit's life began with the Hindu priest in a Leicester city centre night club that draws a predominantly gay clientele. At around 2.15am on October 19 he was seen by an acquaintance leaving Streetlife. He got into his silver BMW 320i and drove off. After waking, the rest of his final hours were spent between his duties at the family's temple where he was based, the care home he co-owned and his job working for social services.
fields.body:
The last full day of Harish Purohit's life began with the Hindu priest in a Leicester city centre night club that draws a predominantly gay clientele. At around 2.15am on October 19 he was seen by an acquaintance leaving Streetlife. He got into his silver BMW 320i and drove off. After waking, the rest of his final hours were spent between his duties at the family's temple where he was based, the care home he co-owned and his job working for social services.

Just before 11pm he went to 79 Harrison Road, a house his family was renovating, to check on its progress. In the small terraced house he died after suffering 13 stab wounds.

For the last week his family and the Hindu community have been trying to come to terms not only with his savage murder, but the fact that he was bisexual.

The police investigation is reporting little progress, but detectives believe the motive may lie in Harish's links to Leicester's gay community.

This week - the week of the largest Hindu festival, Diwali - should have been one of joy for the Purohits. Instead, at the Shree Shakti Mandir, a steady stream of mourners call into the temple founded and run by Harish's father, who brought his son up to be a priest.

Jai Purohit, 35, and Janardan Purohit, 46, are not only mourning their 42-year-old brother, but a man who had modernised the role and style of the Hindu priesthood in Britain. Those who had seen Harish conducting ceremonies did not forget him.

Five years ago I went to the Shree Shakti Mandir for the marriage of my uncle and aunt, conducted by Harish. What he did was very simple, but for the Hindu priesthood near revolutionary; he spoke in English, and explained to non-Hindus and those with a shaky grasp of their culture, each part of the wedding ceremony and its significance.

Harish told us: "Hinduism is not a religion, it's a way of life, a way of thinking, a way of disciplining oneself, physically, spiritually and emotionally.

"The word religion has been attached because there isn't any equivalent word to the Hindu Dharma in the Oxford dictionary, so the nearest thing to dharma [in English] is religion."

Most Hindu priests in this country are elderly and perform ceremonies in Hindi, catering for an audience born and raised in India, for whom the culture and rituals are part of the warp and weft of their lives.

Compassion

"People loved him for the way he delivered his services. He was more casual, more sociable," remembers Jai.

"He felt that the Hindu priesthood was not delivering enough to the younger generation, he believed there was work needed so that the younger generation would know their heritage."

Harish's brothers tell the story of how six months ago he saw a group of refugees on the street while out driving. He went home, made curry, then went to the local shop and bought its entire stock of milk and bread, grabbed a bag of clothes, and took it to the refugees.

Within the religion he was a progressive, while in wider society he fought to protect Hinduism. He lifted a bar on widows participating in rituals at wedding ceremonies and took people with learning disabilities to functions and ceremonies.

Those closest to Harish speak of his love, compassion and belief in everyone's equal rights. Nothing they knew of him suggests why he was murdered.

His body was discovered after a neighbour rang the Purohits to say there was smoke coming from the property. Jai and his father rushed to the house.

Jai said: "I saw smoke and I saw the body on the floor. When I saw the jumper I knew it was my brother, he was face down on his side. I tried to resuscitate him, but couldn't open his mouth because of rigor mortis." He had been repeatedly stabbed, the final wound inflicted close to the front door which the attackers blocked with a sofa before they set fire to the house.

Yesterday police said they wanted to question five Asian men in their thirties seen leaving an alley at the back of the house at 3.30am on October 20.

"Obviously somebody didn't like the work he did," says Janardan. "The motive is obviously jealousy of the work he was doing."

His brothers say they did not know Harish was bisexual, a fact confirmed to the Guardian by his long term partner, solicitor Anjana Joshi, and by another close friend.

Police had said Harish led a double life, but as he was known in several gay clubs and pubs across Leicester, he does not appear to have been trying hard to keep it a secret.

Harish's marriage broke down 1992 after a year. He and Ms Joshi did not marry and lived apart.

She said: "He was a truly godly person. He took away the darkness and brought in the light wherever he was."

She told the Leicester Mercury: "I knew he was bisexual and didn't have a problem with it. My love is unconditional."

Ray McClaghlan was a friend of Harish's for 17 years and they jointly ran a residential care home for people with learning disabilities. He said: "It's not fair to say he led a double life, that suggests hypocrisy. He led a life that was at one with his beliefs."

Not all in Leicester's Hindu community are comfortable with the details of Harish's private life emerging.

Jagdish Bhatt, secretary of the federation of Hindu priests of which Harish was a leading figure, said Harish was "a very good man" but criticised his homosexual conduct.

Inspirational

Rajendrabhai Chauhan, of the Gujarat Hindu Association, said: "It is something, in the Hindu community, that nobody expected. [Hinduism] is hierarchical. The priest is the highest. Everyone looks up to them. What they do does matter to the community."

Those who followed the development of Harish's Hindu philosophy and style as a priest feel his best was yet to come. Hinduism, Britain's third largest religion, is grappling with the challenge of keeping its young interested. He was one of the few leading Hindu figures making much progress.

Sumeer Kalyani, 21, president of the city's federation of Hindu youth, said Harish had a special appeal to young people: "He was an inspiration to the younger generation of Hindus. A lot of people looked up to him because he was so knowledgeable, but took the time to explain any aspect of Hinduism.

"Harish bridged that gap between old and young Hindus. Sometimes it was like a one man show in Leicester, he didn't get the support."

fields.headline: Kosovo polls feed separatist fever
fields.standfirst:
Ethnic Albanians believe council elections today mean an independence vote soon

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Ethnic Albanians believe council elections today mean an independence vote soon, reports Ewen MacAskill in Pristina.
fields.body:
Kosovo will take a step closer to a final break with Yugoslavia when it holds its first democratic elections today.

The pro-independence Kosovan Albanian parties will sweep the board in the polling for municipal authorities, which will be almost totally boycotted by the few remaining Serbs.

Thousands of peacekeeeping troops will guard the 1,464 polling stations to prevent trouble. In an effort to minimise intimidation and corruption, more than 1,000 European monitors have been drafted in to support 3,000 local observers.

The Kosovo Albanians' overwhelming support for independence is a problem for the US, Britain and other Nato members, which are hoping for a reconciliation between Kosovo and the newly elected government in Belgrade. The west is afraid that any further fragmentation in the Balkans will create instability.

Hashim Thaci, the former leader of the Kosovan Liberation Army (KLA), who now heads the PDK (Democratic Party of Kosovo), said at a rally in the capital, Pristina, on Thursday: "On Saturday, it is up to you to give an answer to the dilemma of the final status of Kosovo ... your vote will put an end to the Serb dream of returning to Kosovo."

The more moderate Ibrahim Rugova, the leader of the LDK (Democratic League of Kosovo), who is likely to emerge with the biggest share of the votes, also stressed that the only solution to the Kosovan problem was a speedy move towards independence. He called for today's poll to be followed quickly by elections for an assembly and president - de facto independence.

Richard Holbrooke, the US special envoy, said such elections would be held soon, but a UN spokeswoman said it was too early to say if they would be held in the spring.

Despite the replacement of the hated Slobodan Milosevic as president of Yugoslavia by the more conciliatory Vojislav Kostunica, who called this week for the poll to be postponed, the demand for independence has increased.

Party political broadcasts have been unequivocal, showing footage of fleeing refugees and Serbian police entering Kosovo Albanian villages, a reminder of the events that led to Nato's intervention last year.

Kosovo is still recovering from that war: many buildings in Pristina are still wrecked from the Nato bombing, there are frequent power cuts, the roads are pitted and communication is irregular.

The biggest problem remains lawlessness in a country with one of the highest concentrations of guns in the world. The judicial system is biased against Serbs; crime and corruption are endemic.

The PDK, which has many members who fought in the KLA, and close links with organised crime, has control of many towns and villages. The UN is braced for bloodshed if it refuses to hand over control of any municipalities it looses."The behaviour of the PDK is the big question," a western diplomat in Pristina said.

The run-up to the election has been relatively peaceful by Kosovan standards. There was a grenade attack on Thursday, and a suspected incident of arson. Earlier in the week there was a power cut as Mr Rugova rose to deliver a speech at a rally. One of the main causes of tension is the Kosovo Albanian flag. The UN said it could not be shown at polling stations.

Almost a million Kosovo Albanians have registered to vote, and about 1,000 Serbs. In one exclusively Serb area, Zvecan, only 23 people - all Serbs - have registered to vote in 17 wards. To try to circumvent the boycott the UN administrator in Kosovo, Bernard Kouchner, will appoint Serbs to some municipalities.

There are no reliable opinion polls but Mr Rugova's LDK is forecast to emerge as the biggest party, Mr Thaci's PDK second and Ramush Haradinaj's AAK (Alliance for the Future of Kosovo), also pro-independence, third.

There is little difference between their programmes, most of the debate focusing on their roles in the past 10 years: Mr Thaci argues that his military option was more successful than Mr Rugova's passive resistance.

There are no reliable opinion polls but Mr Rugova's LDK is forecast to emerge as the biggest party, Mr Thaci's PDK second and Ramush Haradinaj's AAK (Alliance for the Future of Kosovo), also pro-independence, third. There is little difference between their programmes, most of the debate focusing on their roles in the past 10 years: Mr Thaci argues that his military option was more successful than Mr Rugova's passive resistance.

fields.headline: Enigmas of war history
fields.trailText: John Patterson (Bruckheimer goes to war, October 27) seems not to have picked up most of the plot of Jerry Bruckheimer's latest film.
fields.body:
John Patterson (Bruckheimer goes to war, October 27) seems not to have picked up most of the plot of Jerry Bruckheimer's latest film. It is not just the story of the attack on Pearl Harbor, highlighted by a love story, it also features other second world war story strands, including the Battle of Britain.

It is rumoured that these scenes threaten to extend the argument over the "Hollywoodising" of British history, as they involve a non-existent "Eagle" (American volunteer) squadron taking the place of a Polish squadron which did fight in the Battle of Britain. It looks as if Hollywood is again walking all over other peoples' (mainly Polish) sensibilities.

Phil Gollin
East Molesey, Surrey

The Enigma machine was probably stolen by a Pole. His objective was no doubt to help Nick Hopkins (Paxman's post solves Enigma riddle, October 18) and countless others acquire some basic facts on the relevant history.

Polish cryptographers handed over to their British allies in 1939 a copy machine they built and the mathematical basis for breaking the German codes. Bletchley Park developed their own machines on these foundations. Their first substantial contribution to our winning the war was during the Battle of Britain in 1940. It is misleading to say that the machine captured later by the Royal Navy "was then used to crack the German code". By then the German codes were being broken at Bletchley routinely.

I would not be surprised if the thief demands not only £25,000 for the missing rotors, but also the publication of a full, undistorted history.

Andrew M Stankiewicz
Selby, North Yorks
AndMStan@cs.com

fields.headline: BSE: where's the beef?
fields.trailText: The BSE crisis, as Helen Grant reminds us (Letters, October 27), goes back to 1989.
fields.body:
The BSE crisis, as Helen Grant reminds us (Letters, October 27), goes back to 1989. But even before that, in 1979, the victorious Tory government threw out the recommendations of a royal commission on animal feed and deregulated the industry, with catastrophic results. A Tory legacy of poll tax, recession, sleaze etc, and a railway system that is only safe when it is not working: I just hope the electorate remembers all this and consigns these scallywags into oblivion at the next general election. How sweet PR looks now, Tony.

Phil Cubbin
Oxton, Wirral
PhilCubbin@cwcom.net

 I note with sadness that two teachers may well face criminal charges over the incident at Stainforth Beck where two children drowned. As an ex-head of geography who has conducted 20 "river studies" in that very stretch of water, I can probably say "there but for the grace of God ..."

I also note that the directors of Railtrack, on whose line four people died, do not face any such charges, despite the fact that the track was unsafe. They knew this accident could happen.

And I note that ministers in the last Tory government, along with their civil servants, do not face serious charges despite the fact that they encouraged us to eat poisoned meat with the result that at least 80 people have since died (Denial, failure and betrayal of the public, October 27).

If the teachers may face serious charges, then so be it. But why is the same principle not applied to ministers, civil servants and the directors of public companies who may be guilty of criminal negligence, greed and political expediency, rather than a desire to provide extra curricular activities? Why am I angry and confused?

Jim Ryan
Batley High school
ryan@ls185ps.fsnet.co.uk

 But they did lie to us. We listened to Farming Today and the Today programme and we read the Guardian. As a result we gave up eating all beef products in 1987. They lied to protect their jobs, their power bases and their "reputations". They lied about thalidomide, global warming and the safety of Windscale. They still lie to us about GM foods. All we can do is to listen to those quiet voices which seek to warn us - particularly if they (the establishment) tell us that those quiet voices are scaremongers.

Wendy and Peter Richards
Thorpe Bay, Essex

 The Phillips Report on BSE details yet another instance of actions by ministers and civil servants having huge adverse financial implications for the taxpayer. Had they been only lowly local government officials or councillors, all concerned could have been surcharged for the full value of the losses concerned. What reason can there be for this continuing discrepancy?

Stephen Eeley
St. Ives, Cambs
tamour@ntlworld.com

In reference to criminals, I seem to recall that John Major once called for less understanding and greater condemnation. As he, and various other Tory ministers and civil servants have played fast and loose with the lives of the entire population, how fortunate for them that Lord Phillips has erred on the side of understanding. I suspect that history will not be so kind.

Dr David Hardman
London Guildhall University

 I have just heard a report on Radio 4 that a man answering the telephone on John Gummer's number and sounding very like Mr Gummer was unable to confirm whether or not he was Mr Gummer. Has the poor man eaten too many beefburgers?

Andy Robinson
Baginton, Warks

fields.headline: Sweetheart deals
fields.trailText: I feel for Mr Jones and his complaints about ticket prices at the Royal Opera House (Letters , October 24).
fields.body:
I feel for Mr Jones and his complaints about ticket prices at the Royal Opera House (Letters , October 24). On a first visit to New York last week we saw Zeffirelli's superb Turandot at the Metropolitan Opera House for $25 and a splendid La Traviata at New York City Opera for $10. And if we'd had time, we'd have gone to the New York Philharmonic's rehearsal at the Avery Fisher Hall for $12. Pity about the airfare.

Joanna Page
Exmouth, Devon

 I think you would need to be the Guardian's oldest reader (Letters, October 27) to remember I'll Be Your Sweetheart first time around. The song was written by Harry Dacre in 1899 and sung by Lil Hawthorne. Her recording is apparently available on a CD, The Glory of Music Hall Volume 2, produced by Pavilion Records.

Mike Pepper
Leicester

 Was there ever a "keep the groat" or "don't dismantle the dubloon" campaign similar to today's "save the pound" (Patten beats drum for euro, October 27)? Perhaps organised by hansom cab or sedan chair operators.

Mitch Mitchell
Bromley, Kent

 If only the little machine that is being used to test rail track for defects (Front-page picture, October 26) could have been adapted to test Railtrack for defects.

Adam Potterton
Oxford

 What a shocking waste of resources. Shouldn't the man with his little yellow machine walking up and down the tracks have been working on building retail units on station concourses?

Paul Brazier
London

 Where is Darren Tackle this season? Is he resting in The Priory?

Laura Field
Clitheroe, Lancs

fields.headline: Far from the killing fields
fields.trailText: I know living in a suburb like KT2 is a bit of a disadvantage, but I am anxious to climb socially and join the country set and, having observed the people of Fulham, I don't see why something like geography should get in my way (Vicki Woods, G2, October 26).
fields.body:
I know living in a suburb like KT2 is a bit of a disadvantage, but I am anxious to climb socially and join the country set and, having observed the people of Fulham, I don't see why something like geography should get in my way (Vicki Woods, G2, October 26). However, this killing animals thing seems to be a real stumbling block. I just don't get the opportunity. Is it really strictly necessary?

Please could you consult Clarissa Dickson-Wright. I have observed the life-cycle of the pigeon from egg to carcass on the office balcony, so am no stranger to nature, and I see lots of animals on my daily cycle commute from Kingston to Chelsea, including cats, rats, rabbits, squirrels (both dead and alive), dogs, horses (police, shire, riding school), foxes and cows, although I have to admit that all of these were living. I have only ever seen live deer - they close the park during the cull.

In anticipation I have ordered some green wellies and a sticker saying "I slow down for horses" (I expect it will fit on my mud guard).

Kirstie Newson
Kingston, Surrey

 Bilious hackettes and squirrels are both God's creatures, though both undoubted pests. In the event of injury in a road accident, the choice of which to knock on the head with a car-jack and which to call out the emergency services for would surely require the judgment of Solomon.

Maggie Winkworth
London

 Thank you Vicki Woods for a dose of common sense and bucket of cold water over urban sentimentality for animals. I am a townie but I used to spend my childhood holidays on my uncle's farm and I agree with every word. An animal charity used to tell us that it costs something like £200 to save a stray kitten found on a rubbish dump. Just think what that money would do for people in the third world.

Geof Davey
St Albans, Herts

fields.headline: Dome truth
fields.trailText: I went to the Millennium Dome expecting rubbish, but what I found was impressive.
fields.body:
I went to the Millennium Dome expecting rubbish, but what I found was impressive. If there was a gold medal for knocking things, we British would win every time. I'm no flag-waver, but I felt proud of what I saw and experienced. The power of the press and TV really came home to me. None of you has anything to be proud of - especially your latest piece (Dome's not-so-amazing last day, October 25). You have helped make the dome a failure by damning it to all and sundry. The sad thing is that they believed you.

Pat Nunn
Ossett, W Yorks

fields.headline: House work
fields.trailText: Rachael Whiteread seems almost keen to have her Holocaust memorial in Vienna daubed with racist slogans so as "to make people think about it" (Closed books and stilled lives, October 26).
fields.body:
Rachael Whiteread seems almost keen to have her Holocaust memorial in Vienna daubed with racist slogans so as "to make people think about it" (Closed books and stilled lives, October 26). Perhaps this is merely a cynical comment on the fact that the value of an artwork is increasingly judged by the public "controversy" created around it, rather than by its intrinsic form and content. In this case her comment also evokes the old argument that the European Jews "needed" anti-semitism before they could discover their true identities. The comment does a double disservice - to the inventiveness of her own work, and that of Jewish diasporic cultures, neither of which are dependant on mindless reactions on the part of people who hate just that quality.

Prof Phil Cohen
University of East London
P.A.Cohen@uel.ac.uk

fields.headline: Key bored
fields.trailText: Whatever Fanny Waterman and Mischa Donat say to justify the Leeds Piano Competition, it has played a significant part in creating the current climate of soulless piano playing.
fields.body:
Whatever Fanny Waterman and Mischa Donat (Letters 25, October) say to justify the Leeds Piano Competition, it has played a significant part in creating the current climate of soulless piano playing. Once again it has rewarded clinical digital accuracy over expressive playing and tonal beauty. Much contemporary piano playing is dry and colourless. Let us ditch the whole concept of competitions in music. Instead of worshipping the merely facile, let us celebrate the ability to communicate our deepest feelings and emotions through great music.

Raymond Banning
Cambridge

 Of Fanny Waterman's list of outstanding finalists, only two of seven were winners and their careers have been outshone by three of the others. And there are other non-winning finalists who have become major figures in the field (notably Schiff and Uchida).

Dan Usiskin
London

fields.headline: Psion shares lose 30%
fields.standfirst:
Fall in modem market leads to handheld computer firm facing crisis of confidence

Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Psion, the hi-tech company best known for its handheld computers, faced a crisis of confidence in the City yesterday after warning that a collapse in demand for its modems would push its annual profits "well below" analysts' expectations.
fields.body:
Psion, the hi-tech company best known for its handheld computers, faced a crisis of confidence in the City yesterday after warning that a collapse in demand for its modems would push its annual profits "well below" analysts' expectations.

The news led to a fall in the company's shares of 165p to 410p, wiping £650m, nearly 30%, off its market capitalisation. Analysts questioned whether the management could deliver on other projects, such as its Symbian venture with the world's leading mobile phone companies.

Psion's chief executive, David Levin, said: "Of course this is disappointing, it's particularly disappointing to me.

"But does it impact one's view of our strategy? The answer is no."

Psion has been hit by a technological shift as an increasing number of laptop computers are manufactured with built-in modems. This has meant that fewer people are buying Psion's detachable PC card modems.

Although the modems business, Psion Connect, had anticipated such a change, the effect has been more sudden than expected. Psion Connect's next products, a range of wireless modems, are not due to be introduced until next year. Mr Levin said: "I don't feel we've been tardy or acted inappropriately with this - quite the contrary. Maybe we announced that this would happen too early and people have forgotten we predicted it."

Psion's problems have been aggravated by rising prices for commodities such as memory chips, and by the weak euro, which means its European earnings are less valuable.

The profits warning provided ammunition for critics of the company, who suggest that its core handheld computers are losing ground to competitors such as those of the Californian company Palm.

Mr Levin denies this, maintaining that because Palm Pilots are cheaper and have no keyboards they are targeted at entirely different customers. The firm has also been hit by rumours that it has been losing key staff, although insiders claim this is a false allegation that has been spread by a disgruntled former employee.

Furthermore, Psion's Symbian joint venture, which is to develop operating systems for net-enabled mobile phones, has been hit by revelations that two partners, Ericsson and Motorola, have been talking to other computer companies. Mr Levin pointed out that they both still stress their commitment to Symbian.

Philip Smith, an analyst at Teather & Greenwood, said: "The general environment for Psion has not been good. When you bundle all these factors together it's not a pretty picture."

Founded 20 years ago by Zimbabwean physics professor David Potter, Psion is one of Britain's most successful technology firms but its shares have historically been volatile. Microsoft boss Bill Gates famously identified the firm in 1998 as his corporation's "number one threat".

Before yesterday's warning the group was predicted to make profits of £6.7m.

Psion spent £250m last month buying Teklogix International, a Canadian maker of handheld scanners.The group said integration was going well, with costs likely to total £3.5m.

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Tim Murley Managing director of Cahoot, Abbey National's online bank
fields.trailText: Tim Murley Managing director of Cahoot, Abbey National's online bank.
fields.body:
When did you first become a manager?
It was too many decades ago.

What has been you best moment in management?
Watching one of my guys beat cancer. We use to go round his flat weekly and ask him what the latest cell count was.

What was your greatest mistake?
Forgetting, once, to manage upwards. Ouch!

How would you describe your management style?
It starts democratically but quickly becomes directive.

Which deal would you most like to have done?
Setting up GE Capital.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?
Not being "perfect" - I am a classic Virgo, constantly striving for stability and perfection.

Does your organisation have a glass ceiling?
It's more toffee glass, not that difficult to break through.

What management wisdom is most overrated?
It's not always first to market, or first to use a new technology who is the most successful. It's the first to do it right.

What single lesson would you pass on to budding managers?
It does not matter what it looks like - it almost always ends up being a people problem.

Which management guru do you believe in?
Sun Tzu; his Art of War, the oldest military treatise in the world, doubles as a useful management manual worth re-reading every year or so.

Who is your management hero?
Jack Welch at General Electric or Willie John McBride.

Who is your favourite politician?
Peter Sellers playing Chancy Gardner in Being There.

If you could change one aspect of British business, what would it be?
To focus more on success and less on failure.

What phrase or saying do you most over-use?
"In no particular order".

Apart from quality time with your family, what else makes you happiest in life?
Sunshine - it changes the atmosphere.

What annoys you most?
Wasting time.

How do you relax?
With great difficulty. In reality, golf.

What was your last cultural experience?
Puccini's Madam Butterfly sung in the original Italian.

What is your favourite city?
Rome. Thousands of years of history have left a wealth of treasures that form an extraordinary artistic and monumental heritage.

Do you have a favourite website?
The one my daughter is developing for our dog.

What is your greatest regret?
Not being able to retire earlier - voluntarily!

What is your biggest fear?
Not being remembered for the right reasons by my children.

What would you really like to have been?
An engineer or an architect.

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: Moving house has opened up my door to a stream of plumberswho, when lubricated with tea, dispense ideas on life with the confidence of a tabloid columnist.
fields.body:
Moving house has opened up my door to a stream of plumbers, builders, electricians and telephone engineers who, when lubricated with tea, dispense ideas on life with the confidence of a tabloid columnist.

As they pass by the box-strewn chaos which I claim as my office, all at some point have asked me what I do. A vague description is usually enough to direct their attention back to more engaging topics, but one man kept probing me further as to what I "actually did" that earned me an income.

I told him about a very talented individual whom I was helping to become more confident in the people management aspects of her new role. His eyes lit up. "In my job I get to meet all sorts of people who are nothing at all like me, and I am meeting them on their territory," he began.

"What I have learned is that if you stop worrying about yourself, and just start asking them questions and really listen to what they say, it works out fine. Common sense really."

I was reminded of our conversation when the new Charles Handy book, 21 ideas for Managers, arrived in the post. It is a series of short essays repeating the key messages which he has shared with countless readers over the years. His status as the UK's management guru is based on a style which draws on his experiences as an academic and manager. What separates him from my builder is not wisdom, but the confidence to believe that wisdom has value to others, and the skill to convey it in writing.

The development of management as a business discipline has led to the explosion of writings on management and leadership, fuelled by the career ambitions of the writers and the hope of individuals that there are new and easier answers to the age-old problem of how to get people to do well and willingly what is required of them at work.

In seeking the answers on bookshop shelves we may be overlooking the insights that can be gained through listening to those untainted by management theories. Ben Furman, an internationally-recognised therapist, tells the story of having a house built in Norway and being aware that he was being observed with curiosity by the chief workman. Finally, the man asked him what he did. Mr Furman explained, and when interest was shown he shared the solution-focused philoso phy that underpinned his work. He spoke of how he helped people to recognise what they already did well so they could apply it to a current difficulty. The man became animated. "Oh, so you use the 6:1 rule," he said, in a tone that assumed a common bond. Mr Furman looked blank. Seeing his confusion the man explained carefully.

"I have found," he said, "that if you want to get a job done well, give someone six pieces of praise for every one piece of criticism. They will learn, the job will be fine and everyone will be happy."

The workman had learned from experience what Handy in his writings calls the "stroking formula"; the greater benefits that come from giving recognition for what is being done well, rather than directing anger on what is not. Whether better performance comes from a 6:1 or a 4:1 ratio is the concern of academics, but the underlying discovery that praise builds confidence, openness to learning and enhanced performance was made long before management writers existed.

Before accepting Handy's messages as the insights of a guru, ask a non-guru what they have learned about working with others,and you will be surprised at how much wisdom there is around.

 Carole Pemberton is managing consultant, Career Matters: e-mail: carole.pemberton@careermattersconsulting.co.uk

webTitle: Playdough: Wristwatches to make a hole in your pocket

fields.headline: Wristwatches to make a hole in your pocket
fields.standfirst: Stewart Dalby previews a sale of top timepieces
fields.trailText: Stewart Dalby previews a sale of top timepieces.
fields.body:
Ask most people what is the classiest wristwatch and they would probably reply: "Rolex." Rolexes have been extremely well marketed and they have a robust workaday image while still being a luxury accessory.

The wristwatch took over from the pocket watch in the First World War when soldiers, and airmen in particular, found it inconvenient to fish around in their uniforms to find out the time.

Hans Wilsdorf and Alfred Davis founded the Rolex Company in 1905. Wilsdorf was concerned with the accuracy of his company's watches and submitted each to rigorous tests. He believed there were three vital components to a good wristwatch: precision, waterproofing and an automatic (self winding.) mechanism. In 1916 a Rolex watch received a Class A Kew Observatory certificate, the first wristwatch ever to do so.

In the following years famous models were turned out in great numbers. There was the Explorer, which Sherpa Tenzing used when climbing Everest,and the Oyster Perpetual, the flagship of the range still popular today,and the Chronometer and Calendar.

Christie's South Kensington has held dedicated auctions of Rolex and Omega watches and old Rolexes have been known to fetch £40,000. But for the real cognoscenti other venerable names - Vaucheron, Cartier and Patek Philippe - are considered more exquisite. Charles Tearle at Somlo Antiques in London says: "There is no doubt in my mind that a Patek Philippe is the Rolls Royce of wristwatches. Rolexes are like Volvos in comparison."

Richard Lister, a consultant at Christies, agrees. He says: "Rolexes are more popular amongst sporting types. Vaucheron are considered very well made, but in terms of preci sion engineering and the optical look as well as design, Patek Philippe are definitely top of the range."

Patek Philippe was established in Geneva in 1839 as Patek Czapek & Co. The firm became known as Patek Philippe in 1851 when Jean Adrien Philippe became a full partner with one of the original founders, Antoine Patek. Patek Philippe quickly found success and by the late 19th century century Queen Victoria was said to be a client.

The company is still synonymous with precision and in 1989 manufactured what is considered to be one of the most complicated watches of all time, the Calibre 89, to mark the company's 150th anniversary.

The passion to buy old Patek Philippe watches started in the 80s, according to Richard Lister. He says: "At that time discerning buyers did not like the quality of wristwatches being offered by Swiss makers and began to look back to the 20s and 30s. Patek Philippe was much favoured. There were not so many made, around 15,000 a year compared to 800,000 for some other brands. Also the company was very good at keeping its records, so you could be sure of the authenticity."

He continues: "Once collectors realised that prices were rising there was a bit of a rush and prices for quality pieces went up 50%." It has quietened since, but Patek Philippe watches still realise very good prices, as a dedicated auction on November 16 at Christie's South Kensington should show.

Christies is selling a private American collection of Patek Philippes amassed over 20 years. With 68 lots it is thought to be the largest private collection ever to be offered at auction, covering watches from the 20s to the present day.

Leading the collection is a platinum perpetual calendar split-second chronograph wristwatch with moon phase which may fetch up to £70,000. It has a glazed back which enables the owners to see the movement. Another highlight is a rare 18ct gold keyless minute repeating pocket watch with digital perpetual calendar and moon phase made for Tiffany & Co which carries a estimate of £60,000 to £65,000.

There are a number of vintage watches in the collection including a rare early platinum wristwatch made for Tiffany & Co in the 30s, which could fetch £6,500.

Prices start, however, at £1,500. As collector's items how will they fare in price? Richard Lister says: "We don't expect to see the kind of price increases you saw in the 80s."

But as these themed sales are very popular you can expect dealers, as well as collectors, to be out in force, because the Patek Philippes will more than hold their value.

 For further information telephone Christie's South Kensington 020-7581-7611 or visit www.christies.com. Somlo Antiques 020-7499-6526.

fields.headline: Cash 18-30
fields.standfirst: Our new weekly money clinic for twentysomethings
fields.trailText: Our new weekly money clinic for twentysomethings.
fields.body:
The facts

Mark Burman is a 29-year-old senior scientific researcher living in London, in a quandary about what to do with investments and endowments.

He has been working full time since he graduated in 1991 and now earns around £29,000. His major outgoings are his social life, holidays and his car. "I basically want to have enough money to allow me to do what I want to do."

He rents, but still pays into two endowment policies (around £100 a month in total) with a current value of £8,000, hangovers from two previous flats he owned in Leeds. He has a company pension with his present job and transferred a sum from his previous employer's scheme, giving him around four years of contributions.

Savings total £6,000 plus "a few" shares from this and his previous employment packages. He does not currently hold any Isas, Peps or Tessas.

His sole debt is a car loan taken out 18 months ago, on which he pays 9% a month, or £120, although he never pays off his credit card in full, a NatWest combined Visa and Mastercard, with a rate of 19.4%. He currently owes £600 on this.

He has three current accounts, one of which he opened recently to operate as a share buying fund. "I would put a percentage of money at risk, but I can't afford to lose much," he says, adding that he would like investments to be in fairly liquid form and would expect to tie up money for around five years.

He would like to get rid of the endowment policies and put the money into an Isa instead: "I think I would get a better return." He would also like to find a financial adviser to manage a small share portfolio.

The solution

Many people think that the tax breaks on an Isa are better than an endowment, but the tax credits on an Isa are equal to only about 0.25% for a basic rate payer, which may mean he is better off keeping the endowment.

By trading it in, he could indeed invest the proceeds into an Isa, but that would mean him using up his Isa allowance. Keeping the endowment he would not only be keeping an investment free of capital gains and income tax, but also keep the life cover element of his policy, which could be useful if he decides to buy another property.

He has some shares from his previous and current employers which could potentaily be wrapped in an Isa. He also has £6,000 in cash savings, £3,000 of which could be put into a cash Isa, where they would earn a better rate. The remainder of the money could be used to pay off his credit card, leaving £2,400 for "rainy day" cash.

He says he wants to invest small sums of money in the stock market and is looking for a broker to do this for him, but given the small amounts involved it is very unlikely he would find anyone to manage his portfolio. The best idea would be to look at a share dealing service on the internet.

There are other considerations, too. He has a very expensive credit card and he may be better considering one of the cheaper cards, such as Egg, RBS Advanta and Cahoot.

And his pension could be looked at. Given that he is not saving for a house and has few committments at the moment, now would be an ideal time to look at his pension as the more you invest and the earlier you invest it, the better.

He should be investing at least 10% of his salary (including his employer's contributions), particularly as this is the most tax efficient way of saving for the future.

Ray Boulger
Senior manager,
Charcol IFA

 If you are 18-30, working and want advice on managing your money, e-mail jobs.and.money@theguardian.com

webTitle: Nerves of steel: Lottery funds £40m millennium science park

fields.headline: Nerves of steel: Lottery funds £40m millennium science park
fields.trailText: A former steelworks is being transformed into Britain's first "science adventure park", in a final £40m lottery millennium venture.
fields.body:
A former steelworks is being transformed into Britain's first "science adventure park", in a final £40m lottery millennium venture.

Magna, Latin for big, is being built beside the M1 between Sheffield and Rotherham, on what was once the world's largest steelworks and is due to open in April with immense pavilions focusing on earth, water, fire and air, with artificial tornados, firestorms and floods.

The park's enormous home is ominously sited between two lottery duds - the Earth Centre and the National Centre for Popular Music - but its staff have a formidable track record.

"That pool of light has come 93m miles to Rotherham," says Stephen Faber, Magna's chief executive, standing in a shaft of sun from the roof of a line of furnaces which once stretched a mile and a quarter and built battleships, tanks and railway track. "Some of the biggest things ever manufactured were made here. You can feel it."

Mr Faber came to the project from the highly successful Eureka children's museum in Halifax. The site of the furnaces is the setting for the four pavilions, "based on the Aristotelian elements," he says. These, modernised into the "digger park - drive your own JCB" or the "wind tunnel - feel what it's like to fly", aim to give Magna its hands-on appeal.

Earnestness seems to be a trademark of millennium flagships. There will be no rolling-mill rollercoaster or steel time cars here, and caution from road safety agencies ruled out the idea of putting giant steel daffodils into two vase-like redundant cooling towers by the nearby M1, as a signpost.

But the success of Eureka, which has lost three other senior staff to Magna, shows earnestness need not be lethal and Magna has enlisted the team from the TV programme Robot Wars to make "flyborgs" - radio-controlled blimps with artificial intelligence, and there will be water cannon and DIY lasers to cut steel souvenirs.

Magna's transport links still need sorting out, but only a mile away lies the Meadowhall shopping centre, pulling in 30m visitors a year, a feat which has eluded so many of the huge lottery fund projects.

The imaginative pavilions and the huge steel mill (complete with heat-sensitive seats designed to show exactly how big your bum is) may be the heart of Magna, but Meadowhall could be its life support.

"Every lottery project should have one," says a colleague of Mr Faber.

webTitle: Woman jailed for US copter hijack

fields.headline: Woman jailed for US copter hijack
fields.trailText: A US judge has jailed for 12 years a British grandmother who hijacked a helicopter in an attempt to free her husband, a convicted murderer, from a top security prison.
fields.body:
A US judge has jailed for 12 years a British grandmother who hijacked a helicopter in an attempt to free her husband, a convicted murderer, from a top security prison.

Josie Clark, 54, originally from Keighley, West Yorkshire, and latterly from the Isle of Wight, and a woman accomplice chartered the helicopter last December.

Once aboard, she drew a gun and ordered the pilot to fly to the Union correctional institution at Raiford, Florida, where her husband, Ronald, was on death row after being sentenced to death for killing a man in 1991. He had been sentenced to life for an earlier murder in 1989. Her friend, Wendy Calderon, 30, wanted to free her boyfriend.

The two women forced the helicopter pilot to turn back once they were in sight of the jail and were arrested as they tried to make their escape. Both later pleaded guilty to hijacking an aircraft.

Calderon was jailed for 11 years and three months last month and yesterday Judge Henry Lee Adams passed sentence on Clark. "This offence is unusual in any circumstance outside of a movie," he said. He also ordered Clark to pay a helicopter charter fee of £3,700.

Judge Adams said he did not give Clark the maximum 20-year sentence because she had attempted to free her husband after he was threatened by another death row prisoner, identified in court records only as Costa. She had been reluctant to cooperate with the plan and had no criminal record.

webTitle: Comment: Edmond Warner on corporations' astuteness

fields.headline: Control and exploit? If you think you can
fields.standfirst:
Corporations are increasingly politically astute

Net news
fields.trailText: Corporations are increasingly politically astute, says Edmond Warner, chief executive of Old Mutual Securities.
fields.body:
The Italian government and executives at BT were left red-faced this week by the collapse of the Blu consortium's bid for a third-generation mobile phone licence. Governments typically lack commercial nous; corporations, on the other hand, are often highly adept at politics. Politicians need to learn the lessons of the commercial jungle if they are ever to gain the upper hand in the state-enterprise struggle.

Dazzled by the windfalls accruing to the British and German state finances, the Italian government chose an auction process in an attempt to maximise revenues from the sale of licences for third-generation mobile operation. In a lather of excitement about the business to be gained from 3G technology, such as the market in text messaging, the telecoms groups collectively bid £22.5bn for the five UK licences. In Germany the bids totalled a third as much again.

I admit to being something of a luddite. The only text message I have received on my mobile came from BT Cellnet, offering me, as a "valued customer", a free handset upgrade. Needless to say I took them up on this no-strings offer - primarily because I could not understand how it represented good business.

Even allowing for my reactionary response to new technology, I cannot see the text-to-mobile or mobile internet revolution justifying the valuations placed on 3G licences: £22.5bn represents around £380 for every man, woman, child and baby in Britain - and that is before taking into account the cost of operating a network. It is telling that the heaviest users of text messaging are school children - they understand that a message can be sent at a fraction of the cost of a voice call.

The UK licence auction raised five times original estimates. The chancellor - already perched on a healthy public purse - has refused to be seduced by unsolicited suggestions regarding spending this windfall.

The Italians, by contrast, have a public debt mountain that must be dramatically reduced - at least if the Maastricht criteria are to be taken seriously. It has always been clear what Italy intended to do with its 3G licence fees.

What the Italians failed to allow for was the ability of the potential bidders to learn from past experience. The British auction succeeded - from the government's perspective - because 13 bidders lined up at the outset for the five licences, and because none of the participants had any experience. In the intervening months investors and analysts have questioned the wisdom behind the prices paid for licences. Balance sheets have become stretched. Telecoms share prices have tumbled, reducing the ability of successful bidders to restructure their finances. The game, in short, has changed.

Only six bidders lined up for the Italian auction of five licences. One of those, Blu, was an uneasy consortium led by motorway operator Autostrade, with our own BT as a minority shareholder but majority provider of telecoms expertise. The same BT, it should be said, whose share price has halved, the market questioning its strategy and taking fright at its projected £30bn debt burden.

Two days into the auction and it was effectively all over. The Blu consortium folded its hand, choosing instead to indulge in an unseemly round of mutual recriminations. The Italian government was left with five bidders for five licences, raising a total of only £8bn, or around half the government's publicly stated expectation. That is about £140 per head of Europe's most mobile-enthusiastic population - and only 35% of the UK take.

Whatever governments throw at them, companies invariably find ways of maximising commercial opportunities. Italy's government may rail at Blu - withholding its auction deposit in the process - but the ragbag consortium was merely the proximate cause of what has become a political crisis.

The real issue was that the telecoms groups discovered that by forming alliances to bid for licences they could shift the balance of power in the auction process away from the vendor. Hence the reduced number of runners at the start.

It is not just new industries that present governments with such problems of control and commercial exploitation. Britain's rail industry has a structure that was designed by government to maximise service to customers and returns to taxpayers. In the depth of the industry's present crisis this structure is the subject of intense scrutiny - as is its core philosophy of private ownership but public regulation.

The history of state ownership in rail, as in many other industries, is one of commercial failure. However, privatisation carries the risk that a commercial business focus undermines public service; in the case of rail, not only in safety but also in breadth of service and return to the exchequer. Government faces the dilemma of juggling service and return. Higher licence or franchise fees reduce financial returns - which must tempt commercial organisations to make economies on service quality.

There is a spectrum of industries to which these privatisation and regulation issues can be applied. At one end there is mobile telephony, in which few would blame governments for seeking to maximise revenue generation and caring little about service quality. If licence holders cannot provide the right service, market forces will resolve the problem. There will be failures, takeovers, higher charges to customers - or some combination of these three.

At the other end of the spectrum, how ever, are the "backbone" industries critical to the functioning of society in its modern form. Here, service will be of paramount importance. These industries will often also be natural monopolies, making any privatisation process particularly tricky. That is not to say competition cannot be achieved, as demonstrated by the growing number of companies offering domestic gas supplies.

It is difficult, however, to envisage a break-up of the monopoly of air traffic control - and yet here is an industry close to privatisation in the UK. I am not a nervous flyer, but it is never too late to begin being so. Frankly, in this case I am a passenger first and a taxpayer second. I do not care a jot if nobody ever makes a profit out of a safe landing.

 Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities.

fields.headline: Oftel demands £270m phone bill cut
fields.standfirst:
Regulator dismisses BT argument that price controls should be removed

Net news
fields.trailText: BT came under further pressure yesterday after Oftel announced new price controls which should cut domestic telephone bills by £270m a year by 2002.
fields.body:
BT came under further pressure yesterday after Oftel announced new price controls which should cut domestic telephone bills by £270m a year by 2002.

David Edmonds, director general of Oftel, rejected BT's argument that price controls were no longer needed. "BT has argued that price controls should be removed because of the extent of retail competition. Oftel does not believe that this can be justified at this time."

Mr Edmonds plans to extend the present price-cutting controls, which are due to run out in the middle of next year, for at least another 12 months. In addition he is forcing BT to make bigger reductions in the prices it charges other operators for the use of its network.

At present BT has had to reduce these interconnection charges by the retail price index, or RPI, minus 8%. Mr Edmonds plans to increase this to RPI minus up to 11.5% over four years. He said the move would allow other operators to offer lower prices by passing on the saving to customers.

BT said it was disappointed by Mr Edmonds' decision to maintain price controls. The group has six weeks to persuade the regulator to change his mind.

A BT spokesman said Oftel was proposing price cuts of between 7.5 and 11.5 percentage points below the rate of inflation. BT is having to reduce prices by RPI minus 8%; he said that anything tougher would be "pretty challenging".

The group, which recently parted company with its finance director, Robert Brace, is trying reduce its borrowings by the flotation or sale of subsidiaries or minority interests.

Its attempt to secure a third-generation mobile phone licence in Italy collapsed this week.

Operators such as Energis and Colt, which use BT's local network to deliver calls to customers, would benefit from the Oftel proposals.

BT argues that, although it has a virtual monopoly of this local loop, many of the lines are unprofitable.

In the more profitable markets it has seen its share whittled away. It now handles only 25% of international business calls and two-thirds of residential international calls. Mr Edmonds warned BT he would impose tougher controls if prices did not fall.

"Oftel estimates that the average bill for a residential customer has reduced by about 20% in real terms over the past three years due to price controls on BT and greater competition from indirect access suppliers and cable operators.

"The introduction of carrier pre-selection from January 2001, which will enable consumers to use alternative carriers for the voice calls without dialling additional digits, is also likely to have a significant effect on competition."

fields.headline: A final salute for 12 unknown soldiers returned to the earth of Flanders
fields.standfirst: Remains of men who fell at Ypres found after 85 years
fields.trailText: It was just another cemetery: neat tombstones, a memorial arch and the haunting words: "Their name liveth for ever more."
fields.body:
It was just another cemetery: neat tombstones, a memorial arch and the haunting words: "Their name liveth for ever more."

But under a wintry Flanders sun a poignant record was set this week with the biggest burial of unknown British soldiers in decades.

More than 80 years on, they are still anonymous, victims and perhaps heroes of the charnel house that was the first world war. They were given an honourable send-off, but in 12 pitifully small boxes lowered carefully into the damp clay.

Scenes like this have been going on since 1918. And though a staggering 100,000 Commonwealth soldiers are still missing - listed on the Menin Gate at Ypres and the nearby memorial at Tyne Cot - it is rare for more than one or two to be interred at once.

Burial on such a large scale is the result of unique circumstances. The undulating land where the remains were found, by a canal at Boezinge, is being used to extend the unlovely industrial estate of Ypres - "Wipers" to the men who fought and died here during three offensives over a few miles of ground.

But the land has been used only for grazing since the guns fell silent. Since last summer Belgian archaeologists, keeping one step ahead of the bulldozers, have unearthed 103 victims - 39 British, the rest French and German.

The 12 buried on Thursday included an officer from the Yorks and Lancaster Regiment, two Lancashire Fusiliers, a Northumberland Fusilier and three rifle brigade soldiers - identified by scraps of clothing or a badge, but nothing to give them a name.

"It's the biggest single find in recent memory," said Barry Murphy, of the Commonwealth war graves commission, which runs the Cement Hill cemetery and scores of others like it across Belgium and northern France. "We are talking decades."

Twelve wooden boxes, each smaller than a child's coffin, were lined up on green baize before the brief ceremony, conducted by Reverend Ray Jones, himself a former soldier and now chaplain of St George's Memorial Church, Ypres.

"Its very strange," Mr Jones said, surplice fluttering in the stiff autumn breeze. "There are times when a burial is extremely moving and others when you begin to distance yourself from it.

"But you can't do that here. Being an ex-soldier makes me feel it's more emotive."

Nothing special was laid on. But the smart salutes of two uniformed officers - a Greenjackets representative for the now disbanded rifle brigades and a colonel from the British embassy in Brussels - were a reminder that these men had died on duty.

So were the poppy wreaths, laid slowly by the edge of the neat, deep trench cut so carefully into the Flanders earth.

Two buglers - men of the Ypres fire brigade who perform nightly at the Menin Gate - sounded the Last Post and Reveille.

Otherwise there was just silence broken by the roar of the passing traffic, a few passing battlefield tourists, cemetery workers, veterans, local historians and a couple of saluting Belgian officers. It was respectful, but no one knew who they were mourning.

Boezinge was the scene of heavy fighting during three separate offensives around Ypres, where the allied salient protruded into the German lines. Most of the men found since last summer died in early July 1915. Only one has been identified.

The final attack, in November 1917, through mud which swallowed soldiers, horses and tanks, took the ruins of Passchendaele, a village which by then no longer existed. Typically a box of remains contains bones, wet uniform fragments, leather, buttons, shaving brushes, even overcoats.

Uncovering them is the passion of Aurel Sercu, a retired teacher who spends his Saturdays with fellow members of the Diggers group, operating under licence from the Belgian ministry of interior, and was at Thursday's burial to pay his last respects.

"It is very careful work, because you realise you are dealing with mortal remains," said Mr Sercu, 55, who once found five bodies at the bottom of a trench he had excavated.

"I'm not sure if satisfaction is the right word," he said. "But it does give you a sense of pride that these poor guys are finally going to a decent grave after 80 years in the soil."

webTitle: Grave offences of Turkish census-takers swell population count

fields.headline: Grave offences of Turkish census-takers swell population count
fields.trailText: Turkish census-takers, it seems, cannot please everyone. Even after the country was placed under a 14-hour curfew last Sunday, many people still complained angrily that they had not been counted.
fields.body:
Turkish census-takers, it seems, cannot please everyone. Even after the country was placed under a 14-hour curfew last Sunday, many people still complained angrily that they had not been counted.

There are suspicions that the the official body-counters may have been too busy plumping the population figures to visit every house.

According to unofficial estimates released yesterday, the population is rising far faster than expected.

A 1997 census counted 62.8m people.

This week the figure rose dramatically to 71.2m - at least 5m more than the experts had predicted. Many of those experts now suspect foul play. And it seems they are right.

In some areas where big increases were recorded the census-takers apparently listed the names of those buried in local cemeteries in an attempt to boost their figures.

"They even counted the gravestones", exclaimed the headline in one newspaper.

"Unfortunately, this is true," said Sefik Yildizeli, head of the state statistics institute. "Officials are currently inspecting the numbers."

The cause of the excessive enthusiasm is pretty simple.

The census findings determine how much money each local authority gets from the central government to provide municipal services. They also determine how many members of parliament each district is allowed.

Power, influence, and lots of cash are at stake.

As a result, there were competing claims on people's residential loyalties in the run-up to census day.

Some large municipalities, including Istanbul and Ankara, threatened their residents with "dire consequences" if they returned to their home towns or villages for the census weekend, which some were offered enticements to do.

Many Turks thought the idea of imposing a curfew during the count was absurd; it was seen as yet another example of the authoritarian tendencies that linger in some state institutions.

In the central city of Sivas, for example, prosecutors are seeking prison sentences for 51 people who broke curfew, including seven schoolchildren who went outside to play football.

Some of the 43 questions on the census form have also been criticised - one asked women over the age of 12 how many miscarriages they had had.

The government insists that a regular census is a necessary evil in a country with huge internal migration. But it has promised that things will change.

A new computerised system will be introduced, and this census, they say, will be the last held under curfew.

In some districts the very thought will have them turning in their graves.

fields.headline: Mireille Johnston
fields.standfirst: Her scholarship, wit and cookery skills brought the wonders of French cuisine to millions
fields.trailText: "Food writing's shameful secret is its intellectual poverty," wrote John Thorne, himself a distinguished member of the fraternity. This widely valid generalisation was notably challenged by Mireille Johnston, the French/American cook, author, scholar and television presenter, who has died aged 65. Her distinction lay not so much in her books as in the totality of her life.
fields.body:
"Food writing's shameful secret is its intellectual poverty," wrote John Thorne, himself a distinguished member of the fraternity. This widely valid generalisation was notably challenged by Mireille Johnston, the French/American cook, author, scholar and television presenter, who has died aged 65. Her distinction lay not so much in her books as in the totality of her life.

She was born Mireille Busticaccia, the only child of a successful importer-exporter, in a house on the old promenade des Angles in Nice: "A tall, apricot-coloured house with green shutters overlooking the sea," she began her first cookery book. "We were constantly sent to the seashore, the garden or the hills to find ingredients for the kitchen".

This idyllic childhood was shattered by the second world war. The family home was blown up by the Germans, and Mireille's father became a key member of the Marseilles resistance. Part of her bilingual education took place in an English board- ing school. She returned to France after the war to study in Aix-en-Provence, and was awarded a Fulbright scholarship to study American Indian civilisation at Oberlin College, Ohio.

A woman of extraordinary intelligence, modesty, beauty and charm, Mireille wore her PhD as lightly as anyone I have met. Thus, she was admirably suited for her tour de force, the 12-part BBC2 series, A Cook's Tour Of France. Recorded in 1992 and 1993, it did not have to be formulated as light entertainment, and so her interviews with chefs and artisanal food producers were conducted in French and broadcast with English subtitles. This made it possible for Mireille to converse fluently on camera with some of the most distinguished names in contemporary French cuisine, including Paul Bocuse, André Daguin, Joel Robuchon and Lulu Peyraud.

The format and content were worked out in collaboration with further education producer Clare Brigstocke. Mireille was able to establish in a few words the distinctive cultural identity of each locale, with the help of music related directly to the scenes it accompanied. The series has recently been rebroadcast on BBC Choice; it is a timeless document that should be available on DVD.

Mireille came to food by way of an academic career and political activism. Both activities were encouraged by her husband, Thomas Johnston, whom she met in 1958. They were married within a year, and pursued their academic qualifications at Yale, and then their careers, in parallel. After gaining her doctorate in comparative literature, Mireille taught successively at Yale, Sarah Lawrence College and Columbia University. She also became a civil rights protester.

Tom, in the meantime, was beginning his own career as a documentary film-maker. This took them both to New York, where his work brought him into contact with the Kennedy family. In 1964, he took charge of Robert Kennedy's senatorial office, and four years later became his presidential campaign manager. Mireille was thus introduced to world leaders, such as President Mitterrand, and to many of America's leading intellectuals, including Norman Mailer, Jules Feiffer, Pierre Salinger, and Random House Publisher Jason Epstein.

The fact that Mireille was a polished hostess and able cook did not go unnoticed, and it was Epstein who commissioned her first book, Cuisine Of The Sun: Classical Dishes From Nice And France (1976). This and her subsequent book, The Cuisine Of The Rose (1982), were both designed by Milton Glaser, another dinner companion. Mireille's Complete French Cookery Course (1992-4) was based on her television series. Her books contain highly personal versions of classical French recipes, but her departures from tradition are conscientiously noted.

In 1972, Mireille translated into English the transcript of Marcel Ophuls's remarkable four-hour documentary on occupied France, The Sorrow And The Pity. When I spoke with her last May, she explained that her work on the film had been a tribute to her father, Jean, who had been disgusted at the number of known collaborators who, after the war, claimed to have remained loyal to France.

Inheriting from her father this sense of social justice, Mireille remained a dedicated and active socialist. Once back in France, she joined the Socialist party and demonstrated against Le Pen and the National Front. Her translation for the film, together with biographical and appendix material, was published in Britain in 1975.

Mireille brought to her life's work all that she had received through her father's Italianate family, conditioned and enriched by her Nicean upbringing. The result was a cultural blend as complex, yet coherent, as the cuisine which she so ably practised and presented.

She is survived by her husband and her two daughters.

fields.headline: Letter: Heberto Padilla
fields.standfirst: Dr S Wilkinson writes: Nick Caistor's obituary of the Cuban poet Heberto Padilla (October 14) does little to redress the prevailing view, sadly tainted by cold war propaganda, that Padilla was an innocent victim of the Castro regime
fields.trailText: Dr S Wilkinson writes: Nick Caistor's obituary of the Cuban poet Heberto Padilla (October 14) does little to redress the prevailing view, sadly tainted by cold war propaganda, that Padilla was an innocent victim of the Castro regime. A closer inspection of the facts reveals a more complex sequence of events, in which the poet can be seen - wittingly or unwittingly - as the author of his own destiny.
fields.body:
Dr S Wilkinson writes: Nick Caistor's obituary of the Cuban poet Heberto Padilla (October 14) does little to redress the prevailing view, sadly tainted by cold war propaganda, that Padilla was an innocent victim of the Castro regime. A closer inspection of the facts reveals a more complex sequence of events, in which the poet can be seen - wittingly or unwittingly - as the author of his own destiny.

It is true that, in 1968, Padilla attracted the attention of the Cuban revolutionary literary establishment with his collection of poems, Fuera del juego, but any objective reader would understand why.

The poems are deeply anti-communist, explicitly individualistic and were taken by many at the time to be intended to attract the attention of foreign, anti-communist critics. Although the subject of a great deal of criticism in Cuba at the time, Padilla was not, as Caistor writes, put under house-arrest.

Nor was it because of this book, or any other publication, that Padilla was arrested and interrogated three years later. In fact, he was detained alongside a French photographer called Pierre Gollendorf, who was later convicted of spying for the CIA. Gollendorf and Padilla had been recorded by the Cuban secret police in numerous conversations with the then Chilean ambassador to Cuba, Jorge Edwards, at his residence in the Hotel Riviera. Edwards was also accused of being a spy, and was expelled from the island.

It transpired that Padilla had been enjoying Edwards's hospitality, and was living at the Chilean's expense in a suite at the hotel. He was therefore suspected as guilty by association with these highly suspicious foreign individuals.

These facts were entirely overlooked by the foreign media and the many famous intellectuals who leapt to Padilla's defence on the basis that he was being victimised for his art. Their antagonism towards the Cuban revolution in this case so enraged the government that it did lasting damage.

Ironically, what was intended as a protest against incipient Stalinism in Cuban life did much to create an atmosphere of paranoia, in which witchhunts of intellectuals could take place. It is a fact that is frequently overlooked that the worst excesses of Cuban revolutionary censorship took place after the Padilla affair, and were, in some measure, a reaction to it.

webTitle: Yule Catto braced for job cuts

fields.headline: Yule Catto braced for job cuts
fields.trailText: Chemicals group Yule Catto is preparing to shed jobs after issuing its second profits warning in a year, blaming a surge in the price of oil-based products for a shortfall in earnings from its polymers business.
fields.body:
Chemicals group Yule Catto is preparing to shed jobs after issuing its second profits warning in a year, blaming a surge in the price of oil-based products for a shortfall in earnings from its polymers business.

The Essex-based firm, which employs 5,000 people in 40 locations, admitted its profits could be 25% below forecasts. Its shares dropped 24.5p to 138p.

Yule Catto is taking a £25m hit to cover restructuring which could involve the closure of several sites with up to 200 redundancies.

Finance director Sean Cummins said the cost of oil-based ingredients for its latex and emulsion products had rocketed.

Yule Catto's polymers are used in paint, paper coatings and construction materials.

Mr Cummins said: "It's extremely disappointing, of course, but we see it more as a blip than as a fundamental change in the profitability of the business."

The effect has been aggravated by an explosion earlier this year at a supplier's factory in Pasadena, California, which has led to a delay in obtaining raw materials. The US authorities ordered months of safety checks after the accident, in which two people died.

Mr Cummins said: "We've been damn unlucky. It's not the sort of thing you'd expect to happen too often."

The weakness of the euro against the pound will also hurt because 60% of the group's earnings are made in eurozone countries.

Mr Cummins expects the group's restructuring to increase the focus on supplying ingredients for drugs to pharmaceuticals companies. This will reduce its dependence on cyclical prices for polymers.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Oil price eases on Opec pledge
fields.body:
Oil price eases on Opec pledge

Oil prices eased yesterday after the main exporting countries promised to increase production next week unless prices fall steeply on Monday.

Opec, the oil producers' cartel, repeated its pledge to lift production by 500,000 barrels if crude prices stayed above $28 a barrel for more than 20 working days.

On Thursday, the average price for Opec's basket of crude stood at $31.14, the 19th day it has been above the $28 threshold.

Opec president Ali Rodriguez said the cartel would announce an increase in supply on Monday night if prices stayed above its target range until then. The announcement caused Brent crude to fall 68 cents to $31.28 a barrel.

A&L takes on Big Four

Alliance & Leicester joins the race to wrest current account customers from the "big four" today with a new account offering free perks such as travel insurance. The account's introduction comes as other former building societies, such as Halifax and Abbey National are also trying to boost current account business. NatWest, HSBC, Barclays and Lloyds TSB dominate the sector.

Hartford Group expects losses

The Hartford Group, the small restaurant chain including trendy west London eatery the Pharmacy, yesterday announced it expects to fall into losses for the full year.

Hartford, which in February forecast profits of £1m and once promised six new restaurants a year, now faces an uncertain future despite a recent programme of cost-cutting measures.

Shares in the group fell 7.69% to 9p on the back of the announcement. That follows a drop in the share price of almost 25% in July after a profits warning.

Sega dream turns to red

Struggling Japanese game console maker Sega Enterprises said yesterday it would make a full-year loss of around £145m.

The company said the move into the red was mainly due to its decision to cut the sale price of its Dreamcast machine outside Japan, to combat the threat from Sony's PlayStation2 console.

"We might have had good demand without the price cut but we wanted to achieve cumulative total sales of 10m units by March," said Hideki Sato, who will become chief operating officer in November.

China moves closer to WTO

China has moved closer to joining the World Trade Organisation by ironing out disagreements with the European Union over European firms' access to its markets, EU officials said yesterday.

In talks with the EU, China confirmed it would grant seven further licences to allow EU insurance companies to operate in the Chinese market, in addition to two already issued, the officials said.

The two sides reached an agreement paving the way for China's WTO entry in May but disagreed later over interpretation of several parts of the pact.

webTitle: OM attacks LSE's lack of expertise

fields.headline: OM attacks LSE's lack of expertise
fields.trailText: OM of Sweden yesterday launched a fierce attack on the London Stock Exchange's lack of technological expertise and its "180 degree U-turn" on strategy, after failing to use its last chance to raise its £900m hostile bid for Europe's largest exchange.
fields.body:
OM of Sweden yesterday launched a fierce attack on the London Stock Exchange's lack of technological expertise and its "180 degree U-turn" on strategy, after failing to use its last chance to raise its £900m hostile bid for Europe's largest exchange.

Under the official takeover code, yesterday was the deadline for any higher offer from OM. The Swedish group's top officials will now embark on a last-ditch charm offensive to try to win the backing of the LSE's shareholders for its audacious bid.

Olof Stenhammar, chairman of Stockholm-based OM, said: "The shareholders have come to understand a weakness in the LSE management. Those doubts are now getting more obvious when we talk to shareholders."

LSE shareholders, many of whom are also major users of the exchange, have until November 10 to decide whether to take the mixture of cash and shares from OM.

The Swedish offer values the LSE shares at either £32.71 each or £31.68 depending on the mix of cash and shares chosen by shareholders, in comparison with the £24.25 at which they were trading yesterday.

This final offer is higher than the initial one, which sent a jolt though the City, ending the LSE's controversial merger with its German rival and prompting the resignation of Gavin Casey, London Stock Exchange chief executive.

The LSE has since revised its strategy, pledging to expand in Europe on its own and enhance its market for hi-tech stocks.

Mr Stenhammar cast doubt on the capabilities of the LSE's "inferior" technology to cope with these plans.

But, Don Cruickshank, chairman and acting chief executive of the LSE, hit back at OM's own technology, making a jibe about last week's trading problems at the exchanges it operates.

"Despite serving only these two small-scale equity exchanges, OM's management has consistently failed to maintain reliable equity trading systems and to manage capacity demands," Mr Cruickshank said as he again urged shareholders to reject the "inadequate offer".

While the surprise bid by OM, which owns the Stockholm stock exchange, was expected to attract rival offers for the LSE, none had emerged by last night. Nasdaq, the United States' hi-tech exchange, Deutsche Börse - with which a merger had been planned - and other European exchanges have been cited as potential bidders.
