fields.headline: A fevered pitch
fields.trailText: Hardly surprising, a football reporter wrote at the weekend, that Brighton FC - now second in the English third division - should be on song, when they have in their ranks players called Rogers and Hart, plus a sub called Crosby. That comment is based on very inadequate research. Their team sheet for Saturday's game read as follows: Kuiper, Watson, Mayo, Cullip, Rogers, Hart (sub: Crosby) Oatway, Carpenter, Jones (sub: Melton), Wicks, Zamora (sub: Steele).
fields.body:
Hardly surprising, a football reporter wrote at the weekend, that Brighton FC - now second in the English third division - should be on song, when they have in their ranks players called Rogers and Hart, plus a sub called Crosby. That comment is based on very inadequate research. Their team sheet for Saturday's game read as follows: Kuiper, Watson, Mayo, Cullip, Rogers, Hart (sub: Crosby) Oatway, Carpenter, Jones (sub: Melton), Wicks, Zamora (sub: Steele).

Even those who know as little of popular music as Smallweed will instantly recognise that there used to be a brother-and sister group called the Carpenters, which ended when one of them died. As for Joneses, the industry is awash with them: Tom, Grace, Quincy, Spike, Catherine Zeta... the list is endless. Barry Melton was the guitarist of Country Joe and the Fish.Doc Watson was a guitarist and Johnny "Guitar" Watson may well have been one too. And Zamora? The Zamora brothers are the mainstay of a group called Mascara, one of the most influential bands in Equatorial Guinea. As for Steele: could they really have forgotten ace songster Tommy? These people must have cloth ears.

Strummer (Devizes) writes: Wasn't there also an artiste called Chickadee Cullip, whose foot-tapping number, Eh oombally-oombally rubadub-rubadub clink-a-dink dink-a-clink cheep-cheep-cheep, finished 23rd in the Eurovision song contest of 1986?

Smallweed replies with searing eloquence: No.

JH Judge (Worplesdon, Surrey) writes: Could you perhaps give us a progress report...

Smallweed retorts with thinly-veiled impatience: In a moment.

While I am on about football, I found it extremely odd that reporters speculating about the three candidates whom the FA are considering for the England manager's job should everywhere have been named as Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger, former Blackburn supremo Roy Hodgson and the Lazio coach Sven Goran Eriksson. Yet it's perfectly clear that Wenger won't take it, since he prefers to stay at Arsenal while Hodgson seems to be a case of mistaken identity. It is no good dreaming of Alex Ferguson either. Why ruin a record of huge success by taking on England? That leaves only Sven Goran as a genuine runner. As to the rest of the field, Smallweed's frequently impeccable sources suggest that the list looks like this:

 Sven Goran Persson, Swedish prime minister and a notable conciliator. It is thought he might even persuade Teddy Sheringham and Andrew Cole (as Andy Cole is nowadays known) to speak to each other.

 Sven Goran Ivanisevic, tennis player. Only those who could pronounce his name would be considered for places in the England squad, thus raising its intellectual level by several Melvyns.

 Sven Gore'n'Joe Lieberman. A bit too busy at present but may have bags of time on their hands after November 7.

 Sven Gali. Many insiders believe that given England's problems he's probably the only one worth hiring.

A member of Mensa writes: What's a Melvyn, exactly?

Smallweed coldly responds: It's a world-recognised measure of intellectual achievement, named after Lord Bragg. B est lines of the week - 1. "I do tend to fall in love with exceptional brains" - Erica Jong, the Guardian, Thursday.

In a piece in the Sunday Times, the writer and hunting-obsessive John Mortimer reported an incident at a dinner party involving his wife Penny and the Labour public opinion guru Philip Gould. According to Mortimer, Gould remarked to Lady M: "He really is getting old, isn't he? Why do you stay with John? Is it love or duty?"

This is the second time I have seen this story: the other was in an interview with Penny herself in the Daily Telegraph on September 23. They found themselves, she said, placed next to each other at Chequers, she said, and Gould began to question her about how John had managed to "brainwash" her into supporting his campaign on hunting. "He's getting very old, isn't he?" she reported Gould as saying, to which she replied; "Well, he's 75 and getting a bit dicky in the leg department, but I can assure you that his brain is firing on all cylinders."

Gould's response, according to her, was to say: "Why do you stay with him? Is it love or duty?" "I was flabbergasted," Lady M told the Telegraph. She wished now that she had replied: "It's neither, it's just great sex . . . But that's not something you would know about."

Perhaps this is what comes of running too many focus groups.

The origin of the term "white knight", beloved of the city pages, has not I fear been resolved by my blundering inquiries so far. Theories continues to reach me by email, carrier pigeon and extra-sensory perception. Here is another. The Rev Ben Humphries of Preston writes: " think that it has become the shortened reference to the rider, or knight on a white horse, the first of the four horsemen of the Apocalypse, mentioned in chapter 6 verse 2 of the Revelation of St John, also known as the book of the Apocalypse, in the Bible. This rider 'rode forth conquering and to conquer'. In chapter 19 verse 11, the white horse appears once more; its rider's name is Faithful and True, for he is just in judgment and just in war'." I must say my dealings with city folk make that reference to faithful and true seem pretty conclusive.

Best lines of the week - 2. "For a writer steeped in Herodotus and Plotinus to have been reviewed by those who have read neither must be galling." - Erica Jong, on Gore Vidal, a man with a sky-high Melvyn quotient, the Guardian, Thursday.

JH Judge (Worplesdon, Surrey) writes: Let me try again. Could you now perhaps kindly favour us with a progress report on the unfortunate Chimérique de la Jalousie, whom you so ungallantly left last week wading knee-deep down the River Irrawaddy, west Burma, on a mission whose purpose remained, even at the end of your column, a mystery to me and also, I have to tell you, to my fellow Worplesdonians?

Smallweed replies with a supercilious smirk: Gladly, old chap. Here it is. "She has very wet knees."
fields.bodyText: Hardly surprising, a football reporter wrote at the weekend, that Brighton FC - now second in the English third division - should be on song, when they have in their ranks players called Rogers and Hart, plus a sub called Crosby. That comment is based on very inadequate research. Their team sheet for Saturday's game read as follows: Kuiper, Watson, Mayo, Cullip, Rogers, Hart (sub: Crosby) Oatway, Carpenter, Jones (sub: Melton), Wicks, Zamora (sub: Steele). Even those who know as little of popular music as Smallweed will instantly recognise that there used to be a brother-and sister group called the Carpenters, which ended when one of them died. As for Joneses, the industry is awash with them: Tom, Grace, Quincy, Spike, Catherine Zeta... the list is endless. Barry Melton was the guitarist of Country Joe and the Fish.Doc Watson was a guitarist and Johnny "Guitar" Watson may well have been one too. And Zamora? The Zamora brothers are the mainstay of a group called Mascara, one of the most influential bands in Equatorial Guinea. As for Steele: could they really have forgotten ace songster Tommy? These people must have cloth ears. Strummer (Devizes) writes: Wasn't there also an artiste called Chickadee Cullip, whose foot-tapping number, Eh oombally-oombally rubadub-rubadub clink-a-dink dink-a-clink cheep-cheep-cheep, finished 23rd in the Eurovision song contest of 1986? Smallweed replies with searing eloquence: No. JH Judge (Worplesdon, Surrey) writes: Could you perhaps give us a progress report... Smallweed retorts with thinly-veiled impatience: In a moment. While I am on about football, I found it extremely odd that reporters speculating about the three candidates whom the FA are considering for the England manager's job should everywhere have been named as Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger, former Blackburn supremo Roy Hodgson and the Lazio coach Sven Goran Eriksson. Yet it's perfectly clear that Wenger won't take it, since he prefers to stay at Arsenal while Hodgson seems to be a case of mistaken identity. It is no good dreaming of Alex Ferguson either. Why ruin a record of huge success by taking on England? That leaves only Sven Goran as a genuine runner. As to the rest of the field, Smallweed's frequently impeccable sources suggest that the list looks like this:  Sven Goran Persson, Swedish prime minister and a notable conciliator. It is thought he might even persuade Teddy Sheringham and Andrew Cole (as Andy Cole is nowadays known) to speak to each other.  Sven Goran Ivanisevic, tennis player. Only those who could pronounce his name would be considered for places in the England squad, thus raising its intellectual level by several Melvyns.  Sven Gore'n'Joe Lieberman. A bit too busy at present but may have bags of time on their hands after November 7.  Sven Gali. Many insiders believe that given England's problems he's probably the only one worth hiring. I must say my dealings with city folk make that reference to faithful and true seem pretty conclusive. Best lines of the week - 2. fields.headline: Granada uplift
fields.trailText: UBS Warburg has upgraded Granada Media to "buy" from "hold" with a price target of 580p in the wake of its deal to sell HTV to Carlton Communications and take full control of Meridian, the lucrative south-east TV franchise.
fields.body:
UBS Warburg has upgraded Granada Media to "buy" from "hold" with a price target of 580p in the wake of its deal to sell HTV to Carlton Communications and take full control of Meridian, the lucrative south-east TV franchise.

It describes the deal as being "very positive for both parties" and highlights fears HTV could have been sold to someone other than Carlton.

"The deal and the encouraging speed with which it has been done is a key step in the development of ITV," says the UBS note.

The benefits, it predicts, include cost savings, the creation of a family of ITV channels and the development of ONdigital as the interactive and pay-TV arm of ITV.

"It leaves both in a position to fully drive ITV as a more single entity, which has not been done before due to the existence of three major shareholders and the years of jockeying for position within ITV," it added.

fields.headline: Shire
fields.trailText: Investors who bought into Shire Pharmaceuticals a few months ago will be patting themselves on the back this weekend. The company has finally fulfiled its promise and joined the FTSE 100, taking the place of Woolwich, now part of Barclays.
fields.body:
Investors who bought into Shire Pharmaceuticals a few months ago will be patting themselves on the back this weekend. The company has finally fulfiled its promise and joined the FTSE 100, taking the place of Woolwich, now part of Barclays.

It seems a just reward for Shire, which has delighted the City with a string of positive announcements, including strong interim results, in recent months.

The company has been told US regulators are ready to approve Reminyl, its treatment for Alzheimer's disease, following approval in Europe. The Alzheimer's market is estimated to be worth around £400m.

Analysts believe last week's promotion means it will come to the attention of many more fund managers, with the prospect of further boosting its shares.

"It's a very solid company with excellent management," said one. "Promotion raises the whole profile of a company and there are certain funds that won't look at a company under a certain size."

Yesterday Shire announced its SLI 381 product might control symptoms of attention deficit disorder throughout the day and evening.

But, after making strong gains on Thursday, shares dipped slightly to close down 5p at £13.80, a long way ahead of its 580p year's low, and predicted rises could push it near its high of £14.88.

Further news might also come next week when the company releases third-quarter results, although nothing too dramatic is expected.

On the downside, some observers feel the company has been too reliant on its drug Adderall, while others predict it will face increasingly stiff competition.

Shire, strong in the US, should beef up its European distribution business and add to its therapeutic product business.

Ensuring it retains its place in December re-evaluation of the FTSE 100 will provide Shire with its toughest test to date. Hold.

fields.headline: Click watching
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... the pros and cons of website links
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... the pros and cons of website links
fields.body:
Even if you are not an aficionado of the internet you will have noticed increasing references to websites in the Guardian in the form of short lists of links provided at the end of features and reports. These are designed to encourage readers of the paper to use the freedom of the net to get a broader or deeper view of the subject dealt with in our own version. But how much freedom should the Guardian be encouraging its readers to enjoy?

Should we provide links to, say, Hamas, which describes itself as the Islamic resistance movement, or to the website of the Guardian's closest rival, the Independent? We have done both of those things in the past few days and both attracted protests.

The Hamas link drew strong complaints from outside the paper, chastising us for linking to a "terrorist" organisation, or for not making clear enough to what we were linking. (There was a flurry of calls within the space of half an hour, one caller mistaking the recipient and asking why the BBC, rather than the Guardian, was linking to Hamas, suggesting perhaps that a lobby was at work.)

Complaints about links to the website of the Independent came from inside the paper, arguing that linking to routine coverage in a rival newspaper was demoralising for the authors of the equivalent pieces in the Guardian.

The editor of Guardian Unlimited, our website, resisted the complaints about the Hamas link. The link was offered at the end of a report on Israel and the Middle East by the former editor of the Guardian, Peter Preston.

In the printed version only the writer's email address was provided. In the web version the Hamas link was one of seven provided at the end of the piece. The others offered access to the offices of Madeleine Albright, Yasser Arafat and Ehud Barak; and to the websites of the Israeli government, the Palestinian National Authority and the Egyptian presidency. If you have internet access you may still read the piece in the archive, explore the links and reach your own conclusion.

When the editor of the website asked the editor of the Guardian for an opinion, the latter replied, "I think I'm relaxed about the link. We were, as a paper, against the broadcasting ban on Sinn Fein, believing that the battle for ideas needs to be fought in the open. I think the vast majority of people reading Peter Preston's column would be perfectly aware of what Hamas was. In a Spanish context, it would be interesting to read the Herri Batasuna site, now under construction, better to understand the political aims behind Eta." [Herri Batasuna is the political wing of the armed Eta movement.]

We have run over some of the ground before in this column (Click here for free speech: links to controversial websites, February 13 1999). One of the important considerations is the context in which a link is made. In this case the Hamas site was in the company of other links offering the broadest possible access to views in the debate. Whether some additional flagging should have been offered, other than the one-word link "Hamas", is open to debate. On other parts of the website efforts are being made to develop a vocabulary of signals, and it might have appeared, for example, as "Key player: Hamas".

It is also important to see this point in the context of the whole coverage of the Middle East on the Guardian website. This is widely admired, a fact of which I was reminded when I noticed that the website of Rai, the Italian state broadcasting service, was directing attention to the Guardian's website among the links it offered on the Middle East.

Careful consideration is given to the provision of links. The freedom of the net is not, the editor of the Guardian believes, to be restricted lightly. "If CP Scott [the famous former editor] were alive today he would say, 'What an amazing medium'." He quoted from CP Scott's own words in his introduction to the American edition of The Manchester Guardian by William Haslam Mills, 1922, and his enthusiastic espousal of the technological advances of his own day. "The world is shrinking. Space is every day being bridged. Already we can telegraph through the air or the ether, from Penzance to Melbourne, and tomorrow we shall be able to talk by the same mechanism. Physical boundaries are disappearing; moral boundaries must speedily follow suit... What a change for the world! What a chance for a newspaper."

To return to the matter of linking to the Independent, or other newspaper sites. Guidelines have now been formulated that should avoid the risk of appearing either to undervalue the Guardian's own material or to be linking on a whim, without, it is to be hoped, detracting from the spirit of free inquiry.

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.body:
It turns out that Paul, the new man in Mum's life, became a director in a big security firm after he retired from the police. 'He's asked me to go to Manchester with him on Friday, dear, they've rented the hospitality suite at Belle Vue [www. thedogs.co.uk] to entertain clients, and I'll be his hostess,' she announced, almost shaking with excitement.

The predicable outcome was that she parked Redwood in my loft yet again. I didn't really mind. Home-bound in the evenings to avoid temptation until Migraine Alan is fully recovered, I liked the idea of company, even if it was only with an overeager doberman. We got on well enough after dinner, when we snuggled on my fabulous new black leather Diesis sofa (www.coexistence.co.uk) to watch Never Mind The Buzzcocks.

But, after a while, Redwood began to whine and whimper, and started to scratch my arm. Mark Lamarr and all the panellists were at their wittiest, so I tried to ignore the bothersome pooch until he clawed at my leg with desperation, tearing my lace-edged stocking.

By now, it was impossible to disregard the fact that I was alone with a lovelorn, rampant male. Like a Trojan horse, Mum had brought the enemy within the walls of my fortress.

The Net saved me, as usual. Thanks to www.thinknatural.com, a site specialising in natural medicines for humans and pets, I found Dorwest Gelsemium, a homeopathic remedy that reduces sex drive in male dogs; soon, Redwood was as subdued as a politician who has just lost the election.

As for my beautiful stockings, I was able to replace them immediately through www.MyTights.com, where you can find almost every form of hosiery from coveted brands. They don't do fishnets though, which are essential for tango, and Migraine Alan will be out of his plastercast very soon.

 Contact: tanya@gorgeoustanya.co.uk; www.gorgeoustanya.co.uk.

fields.headline: The last word on   Eating
fields.standfirst: When a man's stomach is full it makes no difference whether he is rich or poor -   Euripides
fields.trailText: When a man's stomach is full it makes no difference whether he is rich or poor - Euripides
fields.body:
It hardly comes as news this week that many jockeys suffer from eating disorders. As Richard Dunwoody's autobiography reveals, the pressure to maintain weight at consistently low levels can result, as it did in his case, in anorexia, and it seems to be common for jockeys to struggle before races to shed pounds by taking diuretics and laxatives, and by sweating in saunas.

On the same theme at the other end of the bathroom scales, newspapers across the Atlantic this week reported new efforts by medical researchers to discover ways of controlling America's national plague of obesity. It seems that telling people to eat less and exercise more - the obvious remedy - is ineffective; in a culture of self-gratification, unused to personal restraint and surrounded by mountains of fat and sugar in the form of cheap ready-to-eat foods, people want to eat and be slim: they want to follow their hamburgers and ice-creams with a pill which blocks absorption of the resulting intestinal chyme.

Some theories identify the link between love, comfort and food in early life as the source of eating problems, because the ready availability of food is a standing inducement to self-administered doses of reassurance and affirmation. We also have evolutionary instincts telling us to gorge in times of plenty in case times of dearth follow, which in the rich west they now rarely do.

The combination of instinct with psychological residues of childhood pleasure makes it surprising that obesity is not more common. It is nevertheless a chief symptom of "affluenza", the disease of wealth, as shown by the saying, "The poor man must walk to get meat for his stomach, but the rich man must walk to get stomach for his meat."

Before modern, technologised medicine, a doctor's best prescription was moderation of regimen. To eat frugally and drink wisely, to exercise and to ensure enough refreshing sleep, was the height of wisdom - and remains so to this day. Hippocrates, first doyen of physicians, enjoined just such moderation more than two millennia ago, pointing out that not only is it the best guarantee of good health, but therefore of all that attends it: a clear mind, an equable temper, and a relish for life. Modern medical science has caught up with him in noting that some laboratory creatures - mice and fruit flies, principally - live much longer lives if given reduced-calorie diets, making them the experimental analogues of the philosophers of antiquity.

None of this reduces the truth that eating is a great and important pleasure, especially when done well, and among friends. It converts pessimists into optimists, reconciles enemies, advances business, educates the aesthetic sensibilities of mankind, and promotes the welfare of society - for, as the Burmese proverb has it, "A full belly supports moral precepts." One Jacobean theologian agreed: dining well is a way of getting to heaven, he said: he that dines well sleeps well, and he that sleeps well does not sin.

Dining in good company is the best kind of eating. Hosts have to prepare by cooking dishes, chilling wine, setting cutlery, thinking how to seat guests for amity and conversation.

But what about guests? In his Dinner of the Seven Wise Men, Plutarch remarks that a guest must also prepare; not for the Sybarites' reason - they needed their invitations a year in advance to plan what to wear - but so that one can ready the mind and character. "Unpalatable food and wine can be declined," says Plutarch, "but a boorish guest at dinner ruins wine and meat for all."

This constitutes an entirely different eating problem, but one as important to overcome; for as Plutarch adds, "The man of sense who dines out does not go merely to fill himself like a pot, but to take his part well in listening, speaking, and exchanging ideas." This remark indicates what we must be to be good guests at the banquet of life: no less than thoughtful, open-minded, and informed.

"Unpalatable food and wine can be declined," says Plutarch, "but a boorish guest at dinner ruins wine and meat for all." This constitutes an entirely different eating problem, but one as important to overcome; for as Plutarch adds, "The man of sense who dines out does not go merely to fill himself like a pot, but to take his part well in listening, speaking, and exchanging ideas." This remark indicates what we must be to be good guests at the banquet of life: no less than thoughtful, open-minded, and informed.

fields.headline: Great - a trophy!
fields.trailText: A week in radio
fields.body:
It has been a search that has brought sleepless nights, a quest involving moments of deep doubt. What is it about people who call up radio stations to enter competitions to win less than nothing? How can I put into words the existential emptiness that creeps across the airwaves as a caller once again admits they are "not doing much" on their day off or tries to sound enthused about the cheap, inappropriate tat they stand to win? "The Ronan album - great," chirps the Ronan- loathing caller, weakly.

But Saturday Night Jack (Radio 2) gave me the words. Marianne, calling from Blairgowrie, was the first contestant on The Very Hard Quiz, on Jack Docherty's new series. As this was a Very Hard competition, Marianne won with just one point (to be fair, her competitor was asked questions all about Jack, including: "What is my dad's middle name?") The prize: any item from one of those trophy-engraving shops. "I've never won a trophy in my life, so I'd love a trophy," said Marianne.

People who've never won trophies, raffles, egg-and-spoon races and how-much-does-the-cake-weigh competitions - they are the sort who phones up to win nothing. The show will improve when Jack relaxes into the format, but for now it's all a bit hit and miss as far as the jokes are concerned, with Jack dogged by a problem I've noticed with him before - he is funny, but not as funny as somebody has clearly told him he is. So there were good lines, including references to the MOBO Awards (Music of Belgian Origin, with Plastique Bertrand nominated for every award) and the MOJO ones, too (Music of Jersey Origin).

Jack, who has "Hang the DJ" as his mobile-phone ring, reflected on the mid-dinner-party slot he has been given. The show, he said, is for people "eating their asparagus tips in absolute terrible haunting silence. We want to fill those silences." The music - Taj Mahal, Mamas and Papas, New Order - is dandy, too.

The same could be said of A Beginner's Guide to Reggae (Radio 2), presented by Mark Lamarr. Until now, Radio 2's reggae output has consisted of 10CC's Dreadlock Holiday; what I especially like is the idea of the older stable of Radio 2 presenters tuning in to these shows. Can we expect exclamations of "Chant down Babylon Kingdom!" from Jimmy Young, or a spot of toasting on Desmond Carrington? (No, Desmond, it has nothing to do with crumpets and open fires).

The show's title makes it sound like it's going to be hard work, with lots of educative chat, but Lamarr wisely lets the music speak for itself. "You'll notice I always play them in twos and never talk over them," he says, and there really is very little in the way of Lamarr showing off his knowledge. He does mention first hearing Burning Spear "while walking past Jack Ruby's studio in Jamaica", but then, as if realising we'll all be shouting "name dropper", adds: "Well, obviously I didn't hear it in Tibet."

As with his rock'n'roll series, this is already a great show for one good reason: Lamarr may know his stuff, but it's the tracks that are the stars.

fields.headline: The magical mystery tour
fields.standfirst: The man who put Christ in Trafalgar Square is now the subject of a major retrospective.  Jonathan Jones  on Mark Wallinger
fields.trailText: The man who put Christ in Trafalgar Square is now the subject of a major retrospective. Jonathan Jones on Mark Wallinger
fields.body:
What do Jesus and a pantomime horse have in common? They are both figures of unresolvable mystery, suggests Mark Wallinger's retrospective at Tate Liverpool. The pantomime horse catches you by surprise. The figures inside the soft brown costume are so perfectly lifesize, it's hard to shake the idea there really are people inside.

Then you do a double-take. The figure in the rear end of the pantomime horse is standing upright, thrusting its pelvis against the backside of the figure in front. Something very lewd appears to be going on. The horse's tail stands pertly upright and the horse is grinning. The title on the wall nearby says: "Oh no he isn't, oh yes he is."

Wallinger's art uses everyday, prosaic materials and yet its intentions are nothing short of visionary. The pantomime horse is a modern centaur, just as Ecce Homo - the statue of Christ he made for the empty plinth at Trafalgar Square - aims to be a new kind of religious art. Wallinger rejects the opposition of high and low, the polite world of art, religion and refined society and the coarse, carnival culture of the crowd.

He makes Greek myth slum it with British music hall, working out his salvation in the streets. In 1994, he had himself photo-graphed grinning in the middle of a soccer crowd at Wembley, holding one end of an immense union jack banner imprinted with the name Mark Wallinger. One of us, one of us, you can hear him chant at the world of high art that he mocks and brings down to his own level. Except his level turns out to be one of intense spiritual enquiry and introspection.

The exhibition is called Credo. I believe. But everything in Wallinger's art induces doubt. On the walls are biblical texts over-written in red and green, so you can only read them clearly when you look through 3-D glasses, when you seem to see words float off the wall like the writing at Belshazzar's feast. The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing. Ecclesiastes 18, says one.

On video, Wallinger stands in a park wearing a white shirt, black tie and dark glasses, breathing helium from a rubber mask and singing a morbid Victorian hymn about the special place in heaven for little children. In his hand, he clutches a balloon with a boy's face on it. His voice is squeaky and he has to breathe more helium between verses to keep it that way. It's creepy, but the man's sincerity challenges you to accept him as an innocent.

Wallinger has excluded from this retrospective the works he became known for in the 1990s, and that got him nominated for the Turner prize in 1995. So there are no paintings of horses or portraits of his friends as homeless people. Instead, he juxtaposes recent explorations of religious imagery with his paintings from the 1980s. These are hilarious journeys into the British cultural past. Stately Home (1985) remakes history with deranged abandon. Wallinger has enlarged an 18th-century mezzotint print subtitled "Hare Hall in Essex, the Seat of John Arnold Wallenger Esq", and crossed out the "e" in Wallenger and replaced it with an "i". In the picture, ladies and gentlemen take the air in their private parkland. To the left is an ornamental canal with a man punting and then_ there's something out of place, though perfectly in style. A servant stands in the water carrying his master on his shoulders, so the red-coated landowner can hold the skinny claws of a tyrannosaurus rex. The aristocrat and the dinosaur appear to be dancing. Oh no he isn't, oh yes he is.

In Lost Horizon (1986), a china model of a blinkered shire horse and toy guardsman stand guard on a rural scene reminiscent of Constable, while painted on the evening sky are five ghostly names: John, Paul, George, Ringo and Lord Wilson of Rievaulx. You don't know whether this is mournful or bitter about recent cultural history.

Wallinger loves Britain and wants to redeem it. In The Bottom Line (1986), he juxtaposes an image copied from a snapshot of him and his mother visiting Tower Bridge with an upside-down Constablesque landscape. The two pictures have been sandwiched together with red paint suggesting an eviscerated British soul, a gory rupture in the national psyche.

In his recent photowork Word in the Desert I (2000), he appears upside-down in a Roman cemetery, again in his blind persona, with black suit trousers and no shoes, and through an optical illusion is apparently lying in the grave, with Shelley's tombstone looming above him. The stone is engraved with Ariel's song from The Tempest:

"Nothing of him that doth fade,

But doth suffer a sea-change,

Into something rich and strange."

Is it a romantic, optimistic statement, that Shelley lives through art?

In the video installation Prometheus - Shelley wrote Prometheus Unbound - the blind Mark Wallinger sings Ariel's song in slow motion while strapped in an electric chair. When he reaches the end of the song, he jerks as if being shocked while the tape rewinds with a high-pitched scream. He dies - but in art, perhaps, everything is redeemed: those are pearls that were his eyes.

More and more, Wallinger's art is about mystery. The statue of Christ he placed in Trafalgar Square last year was also a statue of a man suffering, forced to stand naked in the middle of London in a crown of thorns. What lay ahead of him was unknown. He stood on the edge of the huge plinth as if on a cliff, about to step off. Like Holbein's devastating painting of the Dead Christ, Wallinger's statue strips the story of its ending.

Wallinger's success in Trafalgar Square led him to be chosen to represent Britain at next year's Venice Biennale, and this exhibition demonstrates the depth and scope of thought that make him the right choice. Now fetching top prices in the sales rooms, Wallinger is one of our best artists and is getting better.

In his new work Threshold to the Kingdom (2000), he has placed a secret camera in a British airport arrivals hall. Its findings are projected in slow motion, to sacred music. The double door into arrivals opens mysteriously. People come out of this portal looking strangely exalted. They've cleared customs, they've been saved. It's a work of art that finds spiritual beauty effortlessly in the everyday, a video installation in the mode of Robert Bresson, as mysterious as a pantomime horse. Is that businessman smiling because he has glimpsed paradise? Oh no he isn't, oh yes he is.

 Credo is at Tate Liverpool (0151-702 7400), until December 23.

fields.headline: The lost weekend
fields.standfirst: Does the Wexford opera festival select its programme at random?  Andrew Clements  seeks a theme
fields.trailText: Does the Wexford opera festival select its programme at random? Andrew Clements seeks a theme
fields.body:
The Wexford Festival has become all too predictable over the past six years. Under the artistic directorship of Luigi Ferrari, whose day job now is running the Teatro Communale in Bologna, the repertoire has narrowed: anything written earlier than 1800 or after 1920 appears to be out. Indeed, Ferrari is on record as saying opera "died" at the beginning of the 20th century.

The products of Italian verismo, however minor, are definitely in, though - apparently chosen almost at random, as if Ferrari had just stuck a pin in a publisher's catalogue and programmed whatever he impaled. There could be no other explanation for the inclusion of Riccardo Zandonai's Conchita in this year's triptych of productions - a profoundly unsavoury story, first seen in 1911, that wanly attempts to capitalise on the popularity of Bizet's Carmen, and is set to music of total vacuity. It is hard to believe that anyone with the faintest glimmer of musical intelligence could have believed that Conchita was worth hearing again: neglected operas are sometimes neglected for the very good reason that they are rubbish.

The other works this time, though, are worthwhile. In reviving Tchaikovsky's Orleanskaya Deva (The Maid of Orleans) and Adolphe Adam's Si J'Etais Roi, the festival is continuing to fulfil the role that made it an important fixture in the operatic calendar from the 1950s onwards, giving audiences a chance to evaluate scores that have either become unfashionable (the Adam) or overshadowed by greater stage works by the same composer (The Maid of Orleans).

If Tchaikovsky had not produced two blazing masterpieces in Eugene Onegin and The Queen of Spades, The Maid of Orleans would probably not be the forgotten score it is. The libretto is based upon Schiller's play about Joan of Arc, and though the four acts sprawl a bit (the Wexford performances are tactfully cut), there is more good music than bad. Some of it, especially the set pieces for Joan, is very clearly the work of a great composer. As always Tchaikovsky's dramatic juices flow most copiously when he has a female character to whom he can respond, and in Joan's conflict between her mission to save France from the English and her love for the Burgundian knight Lionel, he found the resonance he wanted.

Si J'Etais Roi is a very different operatic animal, an opéra comique first seen in Paris in 1852, which takes a story from the Arabian Nights and, for no obvious reason, relocates it to Goa. A young fisherman saves a mysterious young woman from drowning (and, as the programme puts it, manages to "lay her, still unconscious, on the sand"). Without knowing that she is a princess, he falls in love, and is transformed into a king for a day; finally everyone lives happily ever after. It's frothy, make-believe stuff, carried along by its unabashed good humour and a wealth of fine (if never very memorable) tunes. Adam's music is wonderfully polished: his scoring is deft, his vocal writing brilliant; he was obviously a consummate professional who knew exactly what his singers needed. And here the score gets the kind of punchy presentation it needs, with an outstanding perfor mance from Iwona Hossa as the princess Néméa (she is a coloratura soprano of whom much more will be heard) and strong, touching singing from Joseph Calleja as the fisherman Zéphoris, while David Agler in the pit keeps the score bouncing along. Musical standards at Wexford seem to be high: The Maid of Orleans is solidly cast, too, with Lada Biriucov as Joan, Igor Tarrassov as Lionel and a dark, burnished baritone Aleksander Teligar as her father Thibaut.

But production values certainly have reached rock bottom under the present regime. While the Adam is decently enough staged by Renaud Doucet, with colourfully improbable sets and plenty of over-the-top humour, both Conchita and The Maid of Orleans are woeful, clad in dismal designs and lacking even a modicum of dramatic credi bility. The Tchaikovsky could have been a concert performance for all that the village-hall acting and costumes added to the occasion. Staging opera convincingly doesn't need more money than staging it badly, only more imagination, and that is a commodity that seems in short supply in Wexford at the moment.

 The Wexford Festival runs until November 5. Details: 00 353 5322400.

fields.headline: Don't mention the drugs
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
Clubbing. Television. Tricky combination, I'm sure you'll agree. So hard is it to capture on screen the exuberance and atmosphere of clubs that most of TV's attempts to do so are reminiscent of Russ Abbott in his video for (I Love a Party with a Happy) Atmosphere. He reckons he's getting it right but in fact everyone thinks he's a tit.

This applies to both dramas and factual programmes, with the latter inevitably resorting to shoogly close-ups of girls bouncing around in bikini tops while topless lads, obviously completely off their heads on ecstasy, spasm behind them. And sometimes, when the four horsemen of the apocalypse really want to torment humanity without resorting to plagues of locusts, they wheel out Lisa I'Anson as mistress of ceremonies.

Happily, Choice World Clubbing (BBC2) avoided most of the cliches associated with clubbing TV by adopting a Craig Doyle approach to Sidney, the chosen "party city". There was information on what clubs play what and how much a cigar costs. The narrator was not unlike, as Cordelia said in Angel (Channel 4), "the bald Star Trek bloke". Actually, it was DJ Dave Seaman. (He, like Charles Manson, is infinitely preferable to Lisa I'Anson.)

However, the biggest cliche of all did crop up in Choice World Clubbing: the obligatory someone who says, "Some people party all night. I don't know how they do it," to which anyone in the audience with half a brain shouts: "Drugs!" And that's the best thing about clubbing documentaries - no one mentions the drugs. People dancing like convulsing Cossacks are "up for it". They are never "off their heads on a cocktail of coke, ecstasy and god knows what else". Which they should be, if they're clubbing. Some people have no idea how to have fun_

fields.headline: Ghosts at the banquet
fields.standfirst: John L Walters  on a fond tribute to the music of Robert Wyatt
fields.trailText: John L Walters on a fond tribute to the music of Robert Wyatt
fields.body:
'What kind of spider understands arachnophobia?" sings Ian Maidman in the uncompromisingly English accent of the young Robert Wyatt. There may be people out there with no comprehension of Wyatt's oddball oeuvre, or even with a phobia for anything from the short-lived art-jazz-rock phase of pop culture, but that's of no concern to anyone at the Queen Elizabeth Hall tonight. The former Soft Machine drummer/vocalist has amassed a generous sprawl of music that wraps itself comfortably around the good-humoured performers Annie Whitehead has assembled for this tour under the banner of Soupsongs: the Songs of Robert Wyatt.

Friendly ghosts at the banquet included the late Mongezi Feza, whose tune Sonia opened the show. There were tributes to saxophonist Gary Windo and any number of impeccable influences, from free jazz and the Liberation Music Orchestra to several flavours of South American music. Yet Wyatt's songs are as English as tea and toast, with a political sting. "Simplify, reduce, oversimplify," chant Julie Tippetts and Maidman at the head of Left on Man. "What we call freedom in the north/ means our freedom to use you," he croons over a gentle Latin groove. "And if you don't co-operate/ we'll cut off your supply lines/ but you'll be free to reconnect/ if you beg our forgiveness." The critique of global capitalism doesn't limit the power and warmth of Wyatt's music - there's more affection in a couple of his lopsided chord changes than the entire back catalogues of Elton John and Neil Diamond.

The first Soft Machine single was Love Makes Sweet Music (written by Kevin Ayers, but sung by Wyatt) which bombed, but sounds so much like a hit you wonder what would have happened if they had gone to number one in 1967. Instead, the Softs became a cult progressive outfit, injecting the influence of jazz and systems music into the rock mainstream before splintering in several contradictory directions. Wyatt's accent, his explosive drumming and his questioning nature have been hugely, quietly influential.

The Soupsongs band doesn't include Wyatt, though he was installed happily on the front row. It is based around Whitehead regulars Liam Genockey (drums) and Steve Lamb (bass) plus Janette Mason (keyboards) and Julie Tippetts (nee Driscoll) sharing lead vocals with Maidman. The horn section is completed by trumpeter Harry Beckett and saxophonists Larry Stabbins and Lol Coxhill, all on superb form. Tippetts is as wonderful, particularly on the spine-chilling Alliance, which develop, from an eight-note phrase straight out of The Maids of Cadiz (in the Gil Evans version) into ecstatic heavy blues with the horns coming on like the Brotherhood of Breath. A favourite moment was hearing Beckett play the simple tune of Left on Man and then splashing joyous squiggles of sound all over the chord sequence: the trumpeter played like a dream all evening.

Dondestan was an opportunity for everyone to show off, with virtuosic brushwork from Genockey and a brief, hilarious bass solo from Lamb. Whitehead is the perfect hostess for what felt like a big family party. All the anger and fire embedded in Wyatt's music seems to come from a love of people rather than a hatred of oppressors. And the elliptical originality of the early work hasn't been dimmed by time and the disappointments of life. Perhaps he knew it all at the beginning: love really does make music sweet.

 The Soupsongs band play the Wardrobe, Leeds (0113-383 8800), tonight, then tour to Coventry, Warwick, Brighton and Oxford.

fields.headline: South Yorkshire
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
Along the canals and riverbanks on the north-western fringes of Rotherham, soapwort is enjoying its last few days of flowering. A member of the pink family, it isn't widespread in the British Isles, but owes its presence here in South Yorkshire to commercial growing. Not for the horticultural trade, but for the woollen industry of 200 years ago. When bruised and boiled in water, the fleshy green parts of the plant produce a liquid soft soap, hence its common name.

Apparently, it was brought to Britain during the Middle Ages from the continent, presumably as the woollen industry grew and prospered. Why is this flower on the edge, even in the centre, of a town noted more for its iron and coal industry than for agriculture? The answer is that 250 years ago, it was grown commercially on the slopes of the Don Valley. In Sheffield City archives, there is a mid 18th-century map showing the area around Droppingwell. On either side of Green Lane, an ancient trackway leading towards the Pennines, were fields marked "Soapfeld". Others nearby were marked pasture or coppice. Whether the crop for these soapfields was used locally is a matter of conjecture, but it is a relatively short wagon journey from Droppingwell, over through Penistone to Holmfirth and sheep country.

It is suggested that soapwort is a native plant of Devon and Cornwall. and well it may be. Here in South Yorkshire the seedpods often fail to ripen, but it spreads vegetatively via creeping rhizomes. That they are typically found close to watercourses suggests that the network of colonisation is via broken roots washed up in suitable places having been carried downstream on floodwaters.

Flowering from late June through to the very end of October, soapwort blooms in vast swathes of pink and white flowers. Even its fleshy, light green leaves stand out as you walk along the pathways. Just imagine what a whole field would have looked like, before being harvested and carted up the valley to wash the wool that produced the wealth which built Huddersfield, Halifax, Leeds and Bradford.

webTitle: Alexander Chancellor: Travel has become unbearable

fields.headline: Travel has become unbearable
fields.standfirst: The horrors of travel have done inestimable damage to this country and its people. Amiable citizens have been turned into snarling beasts
fields.trailText: The horrors of travel have done inestimable damage to this country and its people. Amiable citizens have been turned into snarling beasts.
fields.body:
Staying with my sister in East Sussex last weekend, I thought how incredibly beautiful bits of England still are. From one side of her old farmhouse you look out towards the South Downs, from another across tall yew hedges at a medieval village church, from yet another over an apple orchard strewn at the moment with windfalls, and from the fourth side over a duck pond and some ancient barns into a valley full of grazing sheep.

There are still many such places of peace and rustic beauty in this overcrowded island, and the city-dweller needs to visit them regularly for corporal and spiritual refreshment. But the problem is getting to them. The misery of the journey there and back can more than negate the pleasures and benefits that the country offers. The horrors and stresses of travel have done inestimable damage to this country and its people. Amiable and tolerant citizens have been turned into snarling beasts. Pent-up bitterness and frustration explode in irrational outbursts of rage and violence. Chivalry is dead. Even good manners are rare.

These are the consequences when too many people are herded together without the possibility to move. They are not inevitable consequences, though. Holland, which is more overcrowded even than the south of England, has managed, by creating an excellent transport system, to avoid the worst of them. Yet successive British governments have remained inexplicably blind to the gravity of the transport crisis here.

The Hatfield rail crash, tragic and inexcusable though it was, may finally have changed this for the better. The resignation of Gerald Corbett as head of Railtrack was a significant event. He may not have actually quit his job. He may still be drawing his large salary. But the mere fact of his willingness to resign in circumstances that clearly demanded it is so unusual for contemporary Britain, in which principled and responsible behaviour is almost unheard of, that a grateful people practically canonised him. If I had had my way, the entire board of Railtrack would have been summarily dismissed and possibly thrown into jail, but Mr Corbett's resignation did at least indicate belated recognition on his part that a crisis in the railways exists. And it woke up the government, too.

Still, things are going to get worse before they get better. Public confidence in the safety of the railways has taken a disastrous battering. It can only be restored by huge improvements to the infrastructure that will partially paralyse the system for years to come. Efforts to persuade people to leave their cars at home and travel by train instead will have to be put indefinitely on hold. So further investment in roads is now another urgent priority. More money, more disruption, more delays, more rage.

I can hardly bring myself to travel around London any more, and luckily, since I work from home, I don't often have to. But that's not true of most people, who still have factory or office jobs and have to endure soul-destroying journeys to work each day by bus, car, or tube. So far as road travel in London is concerned, every effort is being undertaken to make a bad situation worse.

The united objective of all the authorities is to seek out places where the traffic moves and take steps to stop it doing so. This is achieved by building expensive bumps in the roads, creating artificial bottlenecks, and cordoning off areas with traffic cones to suggest that important excavation work is about to begin. As I have pointed out before, London is unique among the great cities of the world in striving to delay traffic rather than speed it up.

In one's misery, one looks up yearningly into the sky to watch the planes soaring overhead. It's a pity that they cannot take one from London to East Sussex. But in any case, plane travel isn't exactly pleasant either. The conditions in economy class are more cramped than in any other form of transport, and especially now that so many passengers are obese and overflow their allotted space.

The phenomenon known as "economy class syndrome" that gives people blood clots in their legs - and caused the untimely death of young Emma Christoffersen a couple of weeks ago after a flight home from Australia - has been known about and studied for decades, but still the airlines enjoy squeezing passengers together like sardines in a tin.

The fact is that almost any form of travel has become unbearable. The answer is to stay put, if you can, and go nowhere. This may be a pity. It may stop you enjoying the many delights that Britain and the rest of the world still have to offer. But it is the only way of keeping calm. And at least now, since the internet revolution, we can all keep constantly in touch.

fields.headline: Unhealthy disinterest
fields.standfirst: Health is often what we obsess about most when we lack those very things which make life truly transcendent - politics, sex, God
fields.trailText: Health is often what we obsess about most when we lack those very things which make life truly transcendent - politics, sex, God.
fields.body:
I don't know if any of you remember that fantastic bit in the film Jackie Brown, where Bridget Fonda, playing a sexy slacker, is warned by her boyfriend as she lights up the nth joint of the day and surfs channels, "That stuff's gonna rob you of your ambition." Bridget giggles: "Not if your ambition is to get high and watch TV!"

It was a great answer, and I thought of it the other day when the usual suspects were banging on about us endangering our poor ickle kiddies by stuffing them full of junk food and leaving them to fester on the sofa. When columnists use "us" in this context, of course, they mean "the working class", but they can't say that because they're meant to be liberals and it would sound snooty. So they cover themselves in communal guilt while covertly making the best of this fine opportunity to give the proles a good kicking; yes, the paedophile protests in Portsmouth have died down, but here's another window of contempt for oiks that every good closet-patrician can access.

I'm not so sure, myself; having grown up working class, it's struck me as I've moved up the social ladder how much more right about lots of things they instinctively are than their so-called betters - who don't even come out of full-time education until their mid-20s and spend the rest of their lives exploiting the contacts they made during it and their family connections, rather than truly making their own way in the world. If you took away their cleaners and nannies, I doubt whether these people could cope for a weekend nearly as well as numerous single parents I've known living in garden-free council flats. And yes, I am aware of how self-righteous that sounds and, no, I don't give a toss.

Nigella Lawson and her fragrant ilk are currently berating the working-class women of Britain for condemning their kids to a life of corpulence and couch-potatory; excitable health minister, Yvette Cooper, has even more of her elastic in a twang, declaring that today's children "may" not live as long as their parents. But Bridget's answer rings once more in my ears; why should working-class children want to be fit? And why should they want to live until they are 90?

Should they be fit for the soul-destroying call-centre McJobs which will be their main source of income now that traditional industry has been destroyed? Should they want to stay fit into middle-age so that they can experience being told that they are too old to hire at 55, as they have seen happen to their grandparents? And should they want to live to be old so that they can receive a 75p a week rise in their pension, find that D0 NOT RESUSCITATE is written on their hospital records and wait five years for a hip operation before dying on a trolley in the corridor of some filthy hospital? Is it any wonder that the working class often do not appear to have the same attachment to longevity as the middle class, but would rather enjoy the here and now?

Maybe they have it right, like dogs eating grass to then attain the desired effect of making themselves sick after ingesting poison. Because whatever our class, the fact remains that those of us who do not die of heart disease, brought on by a sedentary lifestyle, will probably die of cancer, brought on by Christ knows what. In the past two years, I have seen both my parents die; my father, who was extremely fit and sporty, slowly and painfully from a type of cancer and my mother, who was extremely self-indulgent, from a heart attack in the time it took me to leave the room and make her a cup of tea. And I sure as hell know how I'd like to go. "Five portions of fruit and veg a day!" we chant like children afraid of the dark, convinced that this bizarre counting ritual will in some way help us.

Alternatively, you could eat, drink and be chubby, because we're all going to die anyway. "Gimme a pig's foot and a bottle of beer", sang Bessie Smith, and her delight in the swinish pleasures of gluttony reflected a joie de vivre that just wouldn't be the same if we changed it to an apple and a bottle of Evian. Health is often what we obsess about the most when we lack those things which make life truly transcendent: politics, sex, God.

Those who place too much emphasis on healthy eating display a fear of both life, in all its messiness, and death, in all its inevitability. And I've got to say that the muesli-munching middle classes, last time I looked, didn't even throw up half as many appealing physical specimens as the junk-crunching proles, from where we recruit our best examples of beauty and athleticism: Moss, Campbell, Lewis, Beckham.

Middle-class parents may stuff their children full of fruit and veg, but they abuse them in a hundred ways completely unknown to the innocent, coronary-courting sink-estate mum, by hot-housing them academically until suicide seems a welcome option (middle-class young men aged between 18 and 25 have never killed themselves as much, often just before or after an "important" exam), by making them appear in self-serving TV programmes as dinky accessories to their parents' fab lifestyle, and worst of all by waving their horrible hairy scrotums in tiny children's faces in the name of (yeah, right) "growing up with a healthy attitude to sex".

Among all of last week's breast-beating about the beastly proles killing their kiddies with calories, no one so much as raised an eyebrow at an excerpt from John Mortimer's forthcoming autobiography, printed in a Sunday paper:

"I was 62 when my daughter Rosie was born. When she was very young we were having a bath together (a fact which would lead to our immediate arrest if known to the social workers) and she suddenly said, 'I don't love you, Dad.'

"'That's very sad,' I told her.

"'Yes,' Rosie admitted, 'it's sad but it is interesting.'"

Such is the arrogance of the middle classes that it obviously never occurred to Mortimer that his daughter had ceased to love him because, let's face it, to be trapped in a confined space with a naked, wet, 64-year-old John Mortimer must be so unpleasant that it would feel to a small child exactly like a punishment, one that must be outlawed somewhere in the Geneva Convention - he's a lawyer, he should know. I've often thought it would be fun to be a lesbian, but such an early experience would make it practically compulsory. No, there's definitely worse things I could do than fill my teen angel up with carbos; praise the Lord and pass the chip pan.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Bruce Oldfield
fields.trailText: Bruce Oldfield
fields.body:
Bruce Oldfield was born in 1950, the illegitimate son of a London woman and a Jamaican boxer. A Barnardo's boy, he went to Ripon Grammar School before gaining a grant to study fashion. He showed his first collection in 1975. A major retrospective, Bruce Oldfield: Fashion Designs 1973-2000, is at the Laing Art Gallery, Newcastle, until December 31. He lives in Oxfordshire.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?

Sunday, 10am, linen sheets.

What is your greatest fear?

Drowning.

With which historical figure do you most identify?

Diana, Princess of Wales - we went through some of the same learning curves together.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?

Short temper.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?

An inability to know when to quit.

What is your greatest extravagance?

Entertaining.

What makes you depressed?

Sunday afternoons in town.

What would your motto be?

Yes, please.

When and where were you happiest?

Durham in the 50s.

Which words or phrases do you most overuse?

I try never to say 'basically'.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?

Growing waistline.

How did you vote in the last election?

Tory.

How will you vote in the next election?

Anybody's guess.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?

My dog, Babe.

Which living person do you most despise?

If only I could say.

What do you consider the most overrated virtue?

Modesty.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?

I've never said it.

How do you relax?

Gardening (new challenge).

How often do you have sex?

So rarely that I've forgotten how.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?

Sex.

What keeps you awake at night?

Worrying about projects - but rarely.

How would you like to die?

In my sleep.

Do you believe in life after death?

Not sure - nice idea.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?

Nothing is permanent - adapt or die.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: Assets
fields.standfirst: 'I may have over done the "all men's minds are sinks of filth" a bit recently'
fields.trailText: 'I may have over done the "all men's minds are sinks of filth" a bit recently'
fields.body:
Aunt Elspeth has had a phone call from her errant son Alistair in Western Australia. "He says I've got to go and live with him, dearrr, and I don't want to! He says I'm being a burrrden to you! He says that I'll love the kookaburrrrrras ! But I can't get interrrested in kookaburrrrrras at my age! I want thrrrushes and blackbirrrds to sing overrr my grrrave !"

Try to encourage Aunt Elspeth away from thoughts of graves. Anyway, with the decline of British bird life, soon the only thing that will tweet over anybody's grave is a cellphone. Assure Aunt that she is independent and can do what she likes. "He's going to forrrce me down therrre !" she mutters fearfully. "He's just like his fatherrr - won't listen!" Aunt goes off into her room and broods. My heart bleeds for the poor old thing. Just the words, "long-haul flight to Australia" make me want to lie down - and she's half-a-century older than me.

"Mum?" Harriet appears at my elbow. "Can I have 50 quid for a pair of Doc Martens? I'll pay you back 'n' everything. You've always said they were sensible shoes, right? I can wear them to school and, like, run fast away from pervy men or even kick them in the balls more easily." I may have been overdoing the "men's minds are sinks of filth" a bit recently. Although ... perhaps not.

Uneasily aware that our overdraft has reached four figures, but shell out another 50, anyway. I would rather Harriet strode than teetered any day.

"Cheers, Mum, you're brilliant!" She kisses me and runs off on shoes that are really quite adequate, and fairly new, as well.

I turn to the internet to do a search on Perth. My notions of Western Australia are fairly primitive. Somehow, I think of convicts shooting it out in a desert of red sand, but I expect that's not the whole story. "Premier Opens New Bunbury Playground For All Ages". Quite sweet, really. "Premier Opens Kings Park Wildflower Festival". Does this guy never get tough with taxes, or does he just frolic about all day saying, "Hello clouds, hello sky?" "Meerkat Triplets For Perth Zoo". Meerkat triplets? Never mind Aunt Elspeth, I'm going there myself! Right now! "Victorian Deer Park Will Not Affect Acacia Prison". Bloody hell! Even the prisons have flowery names! I don't just want to go there - I want to offend there! I want to be banged up in Croci!

Aunt comes out of her room looking pale. "I've found some lovely stuff about Perth on the internet, Auntie," I smile. The aunt does not flinch. "I'm just not interrrested , dearrr . I'm too auld for that. Besides, I know why Alistairrr's doing this. He's just afterrr my money."

Express incredulity, even though we both know that would be Just Like Alistair.

"Sit down with me for a moment, dearrr , if you will." Aunt has become strangely authoritative. " Alistairrr doesn't know how much I've got." Try not to boggle visibly. "But the fact is, he's ignorrred me forrr yearrrs . You'rrre the one who'd always looked afterrr me. I can see you'rrre strrruggling , dearrr . I can see what you've got to contend with. And I don't want to be a burrrden ."

Aunt lays an envelope on the coffee table. "This is a cheque made out to you, Dulcie," she says solemnly. "I don't want to have any assets. If I need nurrrsing the National Health Serrrvice is good enough forrr me - and don't do it yourrrself , I won't have that. I'm not going to change my will in your favourrr - that would only cause frrriction between you and Alistairrr afterrr I've gone. I'm just going to give most of it to you now." Feel faint, and grasp Auntie's hand. Eyes fill with tears. We have a little cuddle, almost like Dot and Ethel on EastEnders - although, of course, I am a lot less smartly dressed than Dot. And I thought nobody loved me! Dearest Auld Aunt! Assure her I will care for her to the end. "No, no, Dulcie, I wouldn't like you to have to deal with my bedpans," she insists, and walks, with great dignity, back to her room, leaving me staring at the envelope.

Ex-spouse comes in, shakes the rain off his coat, and glimpses the envelope. "Post been, then?" he asks. "Is that for me?"

fields.headline: How to...
fields.standfirst: ... make toast
fields.trailText: ... make toast.
fields.body:
Toast is the thin white line that stands between millions of young single men and starvation. When mothers insist that their young men get three square meals a day, this is usually translated into three square slices of bread, lightly browned in the toaster.

Brown bread isn't much good, because it doesn't change colour when you toast it. It also already has a lot of attitude (as well as all sorts of bits from the bakery floor), and toasting it is like punishing it for being too good for you in its natural state. With white bread, however, you feel as though you're doing it a favour by toasting it. It's the equivalent of giving it two weeks in the Caribbean.

Some people cut the crusts off their toast. These people don't understand where real pleasure lies - the sort of people who wear cycle helmets in the country and have sex in their pyjamas. The whole point of toast is that it is crusty, crunchy, crispy and crustacean.

In toasting terms, sliced bread is clearly the best thing since sliced bread. However, the good thing about cutting your own bread is that you can put huge doorstops in the toaster, which you then have to crush down with your hand. This prevents the toast from being ripped to pieces when you attempt to spread butter on it.

Making toast may look simple, but it isn't - that's why no one else can ever make it quite the way you like it. For example, some people absolutely insist that you spread the jam to the furthest corners of the toast. Others insist on jam applied in Marmite-sized quantities. Still others insist on Marmite applied in jam-sized quantities - these people don't normally have friends who are prepared to make them toast.

Cold toast is a very sad affair, and gives a small insight into death - something you've known and loved, that was warm and comforting, but that is now cold and stiff and destined for the bin. If this thought gets you down, pop in another couple of slices and smear them with half a pound of honey. It's impossible to be sad afterwards.

Toasters are one of the high points in western civilisation, It's just a shame that you can't cook bigger meals such as roast beef or country chicken pie in them. The quintessence of toast is thick, white bread, well-browned but not burned, hand-crushed and then soaked in salted butter with a layer of tangy marmalade on top. That's real cooking, and is why millions of single men choose it over a lot of fancy restaurant cuisine. Unless someone else is paying.

fields.headline: The Knowledge
fields.standfirst: The world is your oyster - once you know where to look ...
fields.trailText: The world is your oyster - once you know where to look...
fields.body:
The subject

East is east, and west is west, and never the twain shall meet. Except on dinner tables from Berkeley to Bermondsey, where Pacific Rim (aka, fusion) cooking may be observed in action. Like most developments in cooking, reassuringly, it isn't new at all. When 17th-century English cooks developed a craving for nutmeg from the Molucca Islands of Indonesia, they were doing fusion. So were the Indian and south-east Asian cooks who took the chilli pepper (native to Mesoamerica) to their hearts, minds and bellies from around the turn of the 16th century.

The basics

Fusion cooking is an elusive concept, but if you want a definition, try this: cooking that freely mixes ingredients, methods and equipment from every part of the globe, with results that can't be identified with a single national cuisine. On occasion, the Knowledge wishes it had never been invented: some chefs turn their global larders into fusionistic dog's dinners. About as appetising as mouldy bread, and better described as con fusion. But when it's good, it's very, very good. And you can do it successfully in the privacy of your own home. Herewith, the Knowledge's top-10 starting-point ingredients ...

The details

Fusion fodder 1: noodles
The shapes of Asian pasta are few (basically, round or flat long noodles, a bit like vermicelli, spaghetti or linguini), but the starchy matter - hubba hubba! - is something else. It can be egg and flour, buckwheat, rice, soy beans or mung beans (as in Chinese "cellophane" noodles), in addition to plain old wheat flour. Japan has the greatest variety, China follows close behind. Use them as a side dish, sauced as you please. They make the best noodle soups, the best noodle salads, and the only stir-fryable noodles.

Fusion fodder 2: lemongrass
One of the most seductive flavours on earth. Top and tail, slip off the tough outer husk, bruise at brief intervals with the dull edge of a knife, and slice or chop for use in soups, braises, salsas or sautés. Creamy chicken soup flavoured with lemongrass and coconut does the Pacific Rim job sensationally.

Fusion fodder 3: lime leaves
Lemongrass's constant companion in Thai cooking and even more extravagantly aromatic. There's almost nothing in which the Knowledge wouldn't consider using these green goddesses, but they were made for soups and sauces, shellfish and chicken in any guise, and anything with garlic. The dried version is acceptable, but fresh is best.

Fusion fodder 4: dashi
One of the basic flavours of Japanese food. Dashi is a mixture of dried bonito and dried seaweed, reconstituted in water to make a broth of wonderfully delicate flavour. This is your friend for fused soups, sauces and gravies. Instant versions are widely available.

Fusion fodder 5: ginger
Will get Knowledged in full at a later date. If I had an extra page or two, a full listing of ginger's possible uses would be possible. In the meantime, consider ginger in: meatballs, burgers, braised carrots, fishcakes.

Fusion fodder 6: galangal
Ginger's rarer cousin. Galangal is almost chilli-hot, and has to be used in moderation; but when it's used well, watch out!

Fusion fodder 7: Asian greens
The stuff called "Chinese cabbage" (often from Israel) is ubiquitous and okay, but a good Chinese supermarket or food shop will present you with things you've never seen before. You won't know their names, but you will fall in love when you take them home for sacrifice on the fusionistic altar. Treat them as you would spinach, celery or fennel. Braise them, steam them, stir-fry them, add them to stews for the last 15 minutes of cooking, stir them into the juices from a roast chicken or piece of pork.

Fusion fodder 8: fish sauce
The odour repels some people, and why shouldn't it? Made from dried, salted fish, it smells a bit like a mackerel tail that got stuck to the side of the rubbish bin and stayed there all weekend. But used in small quantities, it makes gravy, steamed veg, potato gratins or even salad dressing zoom into the stratosphere.

Fusion fodder 9: Chinese five-spice powder
A fragrant mix of star anise, cloves, cassia, fennel seeds and Sichuan peppercorns. If this stuff hadn't been invented in China, it would have been invented in Europe, so perfect is it in a multitude of western devices. In baked goods, or dusted on to a duck breast or pork chop, or in a fusionistic rice pudding or rice pilaf, and in marinades - this quintet has legs. Run with it.

Fusion fodder 10: soy sauce
The grandaddy of east meets west cooking and truly a case of last but not least. Soy sauce isn't just for stir-fries. It's also for seasoned butter, vinaigrettes, seafood salads, gravies - you name it.

Fusion reading 1: Simple Good Food, by Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Mark Bittman (Kyle Cathie) Food from the several Vong restaurants, which many people rate as the best examples anywhere, made truly accessible for home cooks.

Fusion reading 2: Ken Hom's East Meets West Cuisine (1988, sadly out of print, but you might be able to pick up a copy secondhand) A pioneering book from the days before the term "fusion" had been coined, from a cook who's equally well grounded in Asian and European cuisines.

Fusion reading 3: The Sugar Club Cookbook, by Peter Gordon (Hodder & Stoughton) One of the foremost exponents of fusioning.

Webbed fusion: www.foodoo.com, where Hom and John Torode, another seasoned fusioneer, figure in a cast of media-beloved cooks.

Where to buy

Asian ingredients are always best and cheapest at any shop serving people who associate the word fusion with nuclear physics - that is to say, at Asian food shops. The four branches of the Wing Yip supermarkets (www.wingyip.com) are a good place to start. Ordinary supermarkets are okay for soy sauce and a few bottled or jarred items, but the mass-market brands they sell aren't always the finest in fusion.

The easy way out

Experiment, within reason, and don't worry about it. Most dogs will eat failed fusionistic forays, as long as they don't contain chillis.

fields.headline: Beer
fields.standfirst: Have I got brews for you - Roger Protz discovers a world of surprises on his travels around the Pacific. And there's not a drop of the 'amber nectar' in sight
fields.trailText: Have I got brews for you - Roger Protz discovers a world of surprises on his travels around the Pacific. And there's not a drop of the 'amber nectar' in sight.
fields.body:
Australians do give a XXXX for good beer, after all. Cooper's Sparkling Ale, with roots in the early days of the country, has survived the icy flood of Castlemaine, Foster's and other sweetish, unmemorable lagers to become a cult drink. Naturally conditioned in bottle and keg, it tends to be cloudy, due to its yeast sediment, and has burst out of its Adelaide heartland to become a national brand.

Thomas Cooper emigrated to Australia from Yorkshire in 1852. His wife, the daughter of an innkeeper, brewed at home while Thomas worked as a cobbler and later as a dairyman. When she fell ill, Thomas tried his hand at brewing, and his homebrew so impressed friends that he set up as a commercial brewer.

The brewery is still run by members of the family. Sparkling Ale (5.8%) is brewed from pale and crystal malts, cane sugar and Pride Of Ringwood hops from Tasmania. After primary fermentation, it is given a dose of wort, to encourage a strong second fermentation. The mature beer is intensely fruity, with apple and banana dominating, a peppery hop aroma, citric fruit in the mouth, and a long, quenching finish.

Cooper's portfolio has since broadened to include lagers, and pale and dark ales. Its other classic is a 6.8% bottle-conditioned stout, which features roast malt alongside pale and crystal, with a big aroma and a flavour dominated by coffee, roasted grain and liquorice.

Japan, on the other hand, didn't even begin brewing beer until the mid-19th century, and has come a long way in a short time: there are now dark and pale lagers, stouts and black beers, as well as a growing number of micro-breweries and brew pubs to challenge the local big four, Asahi, Kirin, Sapporo and Suntory. The Japanese giants are best known in Britain for their pale lagers (Kirin, for example, is brewed under licence by Charles Wells of Bedford). Sapporo (5%) is the most characterful, with a rich, rounded juicy maltiness balanced by aromatic hops.

Tiger Beer from Singapore, meanwhile, will bring a tear to the eye of any old colonialists still around. It refreshed the British in the 30s and second world war, and was made famous by Anthony Burgess in his novel, Time For A Tiger, a slogan that was later adopted by the brewery. The clean, quenching 5.1% beer has some good hop notes.

Indonesia's main beer, Bintang, has a similar colonial resonance, not least for the powerful Dutch influence, right down to the familiar Dutch-style stubby bottle. The 5% beer has a pronounced perfumy aroma and palate, and is decidedly malty with only a light hint of hops.

The US, more than anywhere else, has undergone a beer revolution in recent years. It now boasts some 1,300 breweries - more even than Germany - producing a vast range of brews that at last brings choice to a country that was too long dominated by the bland offerings of Budweiser, Coors and Miller. The West Coast, in particular, stands out, with splendid beers now available from San Francisco to Seattle, notably Pike Place's Pale Ale, Pyramid's Espresso Stout and Wheaten Ale. Portland, Oregon, alone has 20 breweries, and can lay claim to being brewing capital of the world. Look out for Portland Brewing's MacTarnahan's Gold Medal and BridgePort's India Pale Ale and Old Knucklehead Barley Wine.

But this new wave of US craft brewers is so busy meeting the clamour at home that few of their beers cross the Atlantic. Fortunately, the man credited with launching the revival, Fritz Maytag of the Anchor Brewery, San Francisco, does export to Britain. He used his share of the family washing machine fortune to rescue an ailing brewery that made a local speciality, Steam Beer, which first saw the light of day in the California gold rush of the 1890s, when prospectors from the East Coast brought with them a taste for the new-style lager beer. San Francisco lacked the technology and the ice to make beer by cold fermentation, so a hybrid was produced: a beer made at an ale temperature but using a lager yeast. Anchor Steam is 5% alcohol, bronze in colour and made from pale and crystal malts with Northern Brewer hops. It has a complex malty-nutty aroma, with more malt and light citrus fruit in the mouth, and a lingering, hop-dominated finish.

Two other Anchor beers, made as conventional ales, are the glorious Liberty Ale (6.1%) - which uses big, bold American Cascade hops that add a citrus note and which was produced to commemorate Paul Revere's ride of 1775 - and Anchor Porter (5%), which conversely owes a lot to the British, being influenced by the 18th-century English style.
